Crawfish hush puppies, Memphis-style baby back ribs, Carolina pulled pork and fried catfish are some stops along this place\u2019s tour of the South. The setting is rustic, with roadside gas station artifacts. (Friday, Jan. 19): 496 Ninth Avenue (38th Street), 212-273-1168.\n\nChefs on the Move\n\nYUVAL LITMANOVICH, the Tel Aviv chef who worked at restaurants there owned by Meir Adoni of Nur in New York, is adding more Israeli touches to the Southern Mediterranean menu at Green Fig, in Yotel on West 42nd Street.\n\nPHILLIP KIRSCHEN-CLARK is the new chef at the Milling Room on the Upper West Side. He replaces Scott Bryan, who has been the chef at the spacious restaurant since it opened a little over three years ago.", "title": "Turkish Chef Known as Salt Bae Opens Midtown Restaurant", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Off The Menu"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe U.S. has tried to walk a very fine line in Syria, depending heavily on the Kurdish rebels in the fight against the so-called Islamic State, while not rupturing the already strained relations between Turkey and the U.S.\u201d said Ali Soufan, a former F.B.I. counterterrorism agent who is now chairman of The Soufan Group.\n\n\u201cAs the battlefield shrinks in Syria, the line has become near impossible to maintain, and the U.S. will likely have to either dramatically scale back its support of the Kurdish rebels \u2014 which would be seen as yet another U.S. betrayal of the few groups that have consistently supported and helped the U.S. in Syria and Iraq \u2014 or risk indirect and even direct conflict with Turkey, a fellow NATO member.\u201d\n\nThe Turkish assault also highlights the deepening ties between Russia and Turkey. That relationship seems to have recovered from the nadir it hit in November 2015, when the Turks shot down a Russian fighter plane over Syria, but has warmed considerably since then. Analysts say that Moscow, which controls the skies in the area, almost certainly had to give the go-ahead for the Turkish assault on the Kurds.\n\nTurkish Assault on Kurdish-Held Part of Syria Turkish movement Monday Turkey Kobani Turkish positions Sunday Azaz Manbij Kurdish control Afrin Al Bab Al Bab Aleppo Idlib Raqqa Government Control Rebel control Ath Thawra Euphrates River Maarat al-Noaman Latakia Isis control Jabla Syria Hama Turkish movement Monday Turkey Kobani Turkish positions Sunday Azaz Manbij Kurdish control Afrin Al Bab Al Bab Aleppo Idlib Government Control Rebel control Ath Thawra Maarat al-Noaman Latakia Isis control Jabla Syria Hama Turkey Turkish movement Monday Turkish positions Sunday Azaz Kurdish control Afrin Al Bab Aleppo Idlib Rebel control Syria Maarat al-Noaman Latakia Isis control Government Control Hama\n\nRussia has good reason to give the Turkish attack its blessing. It stands to gain in numerous ways, analysts say \u2014 first by sowing discord between the United States and its two allies, Turkey and the Kurds, and more broadly by extending diplomatic influence in the region.\n\nAnalysts also speculate that Turkey, in return for Moscow\u2019s forbearance, has agreed to turn a blind eye to Russian and Syrian attacks on Syrian rebels in Idlib Province, who are nominally allied with Turkey against the Syrian government.\n\nTurkish fighter jets bombed Kurdish militia targets around Afrin on Sunday. Ten people were reported killed in the bombing raids, according to Kurdish militants, and three people died on the Turkish side of the border in retaliatory shelling, local people said.\n\nPrime Minister Binali Yildirim of Turkey said the forces intended to create a security zone about 18 miles deep inside Syria. The area would encompass urban centers, including the city of Afrin, with a predominantly Kurdish population, and the much larger city of Manbij, further east, as well as dozens of outlying villages.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTurkey\u2019s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, has vowed to eliminate \u201cterrorist nests\u201d in the Kurdish enclave, but on Sunday he promised that the operation would be swift. \u201cHopefully, we will complete this operation in a very short time,\u201d he said in a speech to the women\u2019s branch of his Justice and Development Party in the city of Bursa.\n\n\u201cThe real issue here is to deliver Afrin to its real owners,\u201d Mr. Erdogan said. He said that \u201cwe have 3.5 million Syrians in our lands\u201d and that Turkey wanted \u201cto send our Syrian brothers back to their own land as soon as possible.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Erdogan\u2019s comments came during growing international dismay over Turkey\u2019s intervention, and reports of Syrian fighters gathering to join the fight on both sides.\n\nMembers of the Free Syrian Army have been joining to fight alongside Turkish troops. Many of them are refugees from Arab villages and towns in the region.\n\nAt the same time, hundreds of Kurdish fighters from the American-backed Syrian Democratic Forces, which has been leading the fight against the Islamic State in Syria, were assembling in towns to the east and south of Afrin, according to The Associated Press.\n\nPhoto\n\nA shopkeeper in Raqqa, who asked not to be named out of fear for his safety, said by text message that a large number of Arab fighters in the Syrian Democratic Forces were being sent from Raqqa to Manbij to prepare for a Turkish attack. His cousin was among 1,000 fighters gathered in Manbij and commanders were telling them an attack was imminent.\n\nSecretary of State Rex W. Tillerson spoke by telephone with his Turkish and Russian counterparts on Saturday to express concern about the situation, a State Department spokeswoman, Heather Nauert, said in a statement.\n\n\u201cWe urge Turkey to exercise restraint and ensure that its military operations remain limited in scope and duration and scrupulous to avoid civilian casualties,\u201d the statement said.\n\nFrance called for an emergency United Nations Security Council meeting to discuss the developments and also urged Turkey to act with restraint, noting that the humanitarian situation was deteriorating in several regions of Syria.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTurkish officials have repeatedly criticized the United States for its support and arming of the Kurdish People\u2019s Protection Units, known as the Y.P.G., which are spearheading the fight against the Islamic State in Syria. Yet they made clear Sunday they did not want to confront American troops in Syria.\n\nMr. Yildirim said Turkish forces would seek to destroy any logistics supply routes to Kurdish units, but Deputy Prime Minister Bekir Bozdag said United States officials had assured Turkey there were no American troops in the region.\n\n\u201cIt is out of the question to have a direct clash between Turkey and the U.S. in the region,\u201d he said at a news briefing for international reporters Sunday.\n\nBy nightfall Turkish troops seemed to have advanced only a few miles into Syria.\n\nSyrian fighters allied with Turkish forces claimed to have seized control of Shankal, a village on the northwestern edge of the Afrin district, but Kurdish fighters rejected the claim.\n\nCasualties were reported from both sides, but numbers varied.\n\nHanadi Hafsi, a homemaker who lives in Reyhanli, a border district in Turkey, said two Syrians and a Turk died Sunday afternoon from shelling by Kurdish militias. The shells fell on a market, killing three and wounding 32, she said. Turkish officials said that only one Syrian had refugee died and that 37 people were wounded.\n\nTurkey\u2019s Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu condemned the \u201cindiscriminate rocket fire by #PYD/#YPG terrorists\u201d in a Twitter post. \u201cThis attack on innocent people shows the real face of #PYD terrorists.\u201d", "title": "Turkish Troops Attack U.S.-Backed Kurds in Syria, a Clash of NATO Allies", "authors": ["Carlotta Gall"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 At the age of 6, a child is full of imagination and may not distinguish reality from fantasy. She is beginning to read and can\u2019t grasp nuances in written communication. She also doesn\u2019t understand privacy.\n\nCiting those reasons and more, dozens of pediatric and mental health experts are calling on Facebook to kill a messaging service the company introduced last month for children as young as 6.\n\nIn a letter to the company, they said the service, Messenger Kids, which pushes the company\u2019s user base well below its previous minimum age of 13, preys on a vulnerable group developmentally unprepared to be on the social network.\n\nThe letter was organized by the Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood, an advocacy group that has successfully pushed companies to abandon marketing like a Pokemon Go app that sent children to fast food and other stores, and McDonald\u2019s advertising on the envelopes of report cards in Florida.", "title": "Turn Off Messenger Kids, Health Experts Plead to Facebook", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "During the weeks last fall when I was interviewing male nurses for my recent article about how more men were entering nursing, the #MeToo moment was just beginning. It felt as if I were reporting in an alternate reality: The men who talked to me about their call to caregiving bore little resemblance to the men preying on women at work.\n\nThe tension was clearly something they were grappling with too \u2014 not just because of the cultural moment but also as men doing a stereotypically feminine job. As the reporting on sexual harassment made clear how much masculinity can be about power and misogyny, the nurses offered a very different definition of masculinity.\n\nPeople often assume that writing about gender \u2014 my beat at The Upshot and the focus of a new reporting pod at The New York Times \u2014 means writing about women. But writing about men is just as urgent.\n\nFor example, I\u2019ve written about how some men have been reluctant to take so-called pink-collar jobs \u2014 those held predominantly by women and historically less valued, both in compensation and prestige, as \u201cwomen\u2019s work\u201d \u2014 even though they\u2019re growing, while male-dominated jobs are shrinking. I\u2019ve also written about how we raise girls to fight stereotypes, but not boys, and how young men want to be more involved fathers than previous generations, but workplaces don\u2019t make that possible. The world is changing for men, and women won\u2019t achieve equality unless men make changes.", "title": "Turning Up the Pink Collar", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cStores, particularly mom-and-pop shops that I relied on for years, are now replaced by banks and drugstores and Starbucks,\u201d said Candi Obrentz, a product designer and consultant who has lived in Turtle Bay since 1995 and runs her businesses from her one-bedroom apartment on East 49th Street, for which she pays $3,200 a month.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt used to be that anything west of Third Avenue became the business side of Midtown,\u201d Ms. Obrentz said. \u201cNow, with so many bars and restaurants popping up, the rest is changing. People from out of the neighborhood take limos to have brunch on Second Avenue.\u201d\n\nBut Turtle Bay still offers Midtown convenience at a relatively affordable price (heavy stress on the adverb). And while cold towers and cavernous chain stores numb other parts of the city, Turtle Bay continues to have a strong character, thanks to an active neighborhood association and its most prominent landmark, the United Nations.\n\nThe modernist riverfront complex, with its newly renovated buildings, sets the tone for the neighborhood, which is international even by Manhattan standards. In Turtle Bay, you can study Spanish at Instituto Cervantes, admire Asian art at the Japan Society and enjoy pickled herring in the cafe of the Norwegian Seamen\u2019s Church. Foreign consular buildings with their mix of architectural styles help keep the streetscape human-scaled and visually perky.\n\nEven the selection at the Ideal Cheese Shop on First Avenue and 52nd Street is a nod to neighborhood diversity. Michael Binetti, an owner of the 63-year-old specialty store, said he mainly sticks to European cheeses to suit the tastes of his many customers who work at the U.N. \u201cIt\u2019s a good niche for us,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Binetti said he is benefiting from an influx of cheese-loving millennials to the neighborhood \u2014 the sunny side of development. As for the dark side, he said he does enough wholesale trade to ensure that his shop would stay afloat if the rent became unaffordable when his lease comes up for renewal in four years.\n\nKeeping Turtle Bay small-scale and personable has been the mission of the Turtle Bay Association for 60 years. The organization was founded in 1957 to quash attempts to widen East 49th Street, and it has collaborated with other community groups to rezone side streets for low-rise housing and improve neighborhood parks. Lately it has succeeded in modifying the rezoning plan that will bring taller commercial towers to 78 blocks of Midtown East, including a stretch of Turtle Bay. An adjustment curtails building heights on Third Avenue from East 47th to East 52nd Streets.\n\nE. 57TH ST. Manhattan Turtle Bay 6 5 E. 55TH ST. MADISON ave. E 4 M Norwegian Seamen\u2019s Church park ave. Greenacre Park second ave. E. 53rd ST. lexington ave. first ave. Instituto Cervantes Peter Detmold Park Turtle Bay third ave. E. 47TH ST. F.D.R. DR. Japan Society Dag Hammarskjold Plaza East River E. 42nd ST. E. 43RD ST. United Nations Headquarters 7\n\nLee Frankel, a Turtle Bay Association member who has lived in the area since 1967, said she lost the view from her north-facing windows to development, but remains philosophical. \u201cThe neighborhood is responding to people\u2019s wants and needs,\u201d she noted, referring to the arrival of two popular restaurants on Second Avenue, the Smith and La Pecora Bianca, as well as the evaporation of antiques shops and grocery stores.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s New York,\u201d she said. \u201cIf you can\u2019t stand change, you need to move somewhere else.\u201d\n\nWhat You\u2019ll Find\n\nTurtle Bay is dressed in brownstone, limestone, red brick, white brick, terra cotta, granite and acres of glass. Its buildings tell better stories than Scheherazade.\n\nThe palatial River House (1931), for instance, which sits on a bluff 40 feet above the East River between 52nd and 53rd Streets, is as famous for the celebrities the cooperative rejected (Joan Crawford, Gloria Vanderbilt) as for those who bought in (Henry Kissinger, Uma Thurman).\n\nTurtle Bay Gardens is a cluster of 20 1860s townhouses on East 48th Street and East 49th Street, between Second and Third Avenues, whose backyards were united in the 1920s. Dorothy Thompson (a plaque describes her as \u201cthe intrepid girl reporter\u201d) and Katharine Hepburn were former occupants; the composer Stephen Sondheim and the actress-turned-designer Mary-Kate Olsen currently live there.\n\nA Tudor-style building at 225-227 East 49th Street, redesigned in 1929 for the violinist Efrem Zimbalist and his wife, the Metropolitan Opera soprano Alma Gluck, is now a rental property owned and occupied by Angela Paolini, whose father ran Louise Jr., a popular former neighborhood restaurant.\n\nMs. Paolini recalled getting misdirected mail for Keith Hernandez, when the former Mets player lived down the block at Sterling Plaza. Mr. Hernandez was enticed to live in the 1985 postmodern building at 255 East 49th Street by Fred Wilpon, who in addition to being the majority owner of the Mets was one of Sterling Plaza\u2019s developers. Rosie O\u2019Donnell bought the triplex penthouse there in July.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd in 2001, the audacious square black column called Trump World Tower, at 845 United Nations Plaza, rose more than 350 feet higher than the United Nations Secretariat Building across the avenue. \u201cTrump wanted that building to be gold,\u201d said Ms. Frankel of the Turtle Bay Association. \u201cCan you imagine?\u201d\n\nVincent Smith, a real estate agent with Halstead, said Turtle Bay\u2019s status, prices and celebrity quotient have surged with three recent buildings: the Halcyon (2014), a 32-story condominium at 305 East 51st Street, developed on the site of a 2008 crane accident that killed seven people; 50 United Nations Plaza (2015), a 43-story luxury tower designed by Norman Foster; and the Sutton (2016), a 30-story Toll Brothers development at 959 First Avenue.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nResidential buildings sprouting up to higher altitudes include a 64-story shimmering ribbon at 100 East 53rd Street (another Foster and Partners project); a 64-story glass-and-terra-cotta tower at 138 East 50th Street; and a 49-story shard at 131 East 47th Street. All three buildings are on the western side of the district, close to Midtown workplaces and Grand Central Terminal.\n\n\u201cTurtle Bay, for me, is a great crossroads,\u201d Mr. Smith said. \u201cYou have all the office buildings coming up as part of the Midtown East development; a lot of people are looking there as an easy way to walk to work.\u201d\n\nWhat You\u2019ll Pay\n\nDespite a boost in its luxury market, Turtle Bay is considered one of Manhattan\u2019s better buys. According to PropertyShark, between Jan. 1 and Dec. 6, 2017, the median sales price of homes was $893,700, a year-on-year decrease of 10 percent based on 396 transactions. Of 54 neighborhoods in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens, the site ranked Turtle Bay 39th in median sales price. The most expensive was TriBeCa, at $4,683,950 million; the least expensive, Bedford-Stuyvesant, at $799,000.\n\nAs of Jan. 8, the real estate site StreetEasy calculated the median rent of a one-bedroom apartment in Turtle Bay at $3,200, based on 113 available listings and a map that extends the southern border to 42nd Street.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTwo hundred listings in Turtle Bay were featured on Zillow as of Jan. 8. They ranged from a one-bedroom co-op on East 51st Street, priced at $315,500, to a four-bedroom duplex penthouse condo with a private swimming pool at 50 United Nations Plaza, priced at $56 million (a bargain compared to its original asking price of $70 million).\n\nThe Vibe\n\nTurtle Bay is an enclave with its own surprising pockets. Beekman Place, a two-block stub between 49th and 50th Streets east of First Avenue, where Irving Berlin lived for more than 40 years (his home was sold to the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg), has the scrubbed, hushed perfection of a movie set. Peter Detmold Park, a patch at 454 East 51st Street with a dog run, includes a bridge that juts over the F.D.R. and connects to a paved slice of riverside. Amster Yard is a courtyard and sculpture garden at 211 East 49th Street with original and reconstructed 19th-century buildings at the entrance of Instituto Cervantes. And Greenacre Park is a refuge at 217 East 51st Street with honey locust trees and a 25-foot waterfall.\n\nThe Schools\n\nTurtle Bay has no public schools; residents are zoned for elementary and middle schools near its borders and, like all New Yorkers, attend high school throughout the five boroughs.\n\nP.S. 59, Beekman Hill International, at 233 East 56th Street, serves about 620 students in first through fifth grades. On 2016-17 state tests, 77 percent met standards in English versus 40 percent statewide; 80 percent met standards in math versus 45 percent statewide.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJ.H.S. 104, Simon Baruch Junior High School, at 330 East 21st Street, serves more than 1,100 students in sixth through eighth grades. On state tests, 67 percent met standards in English versus 41 percent statewide; 68 percent met standards in math versus 33 percent statewide.\n\nA nearby secondary school, the High School of Art and Design, at 245 East 56th Street, enrolls about 1,500 students in ninth through 12th grades. The average 2015-16 SAT scores, the last for which data was available, were 479 for critical reading and 464 for mathematics, compared with 494 and 508 statewide.\n\nThe Commute\n\nGrand Central Terminal, at 42nd Street and Park Avenue, provides access to the 4, 5, 6, 7 and S trains, as well as Metro-North Railroad. The 4, 6, E and M trains stop at the Lexington Avenue/51st Street M.T.A. station. Buses are available on the M15, M42, M50, M101, M102 and M103 lines.\n\nThe History\n\nNamed for a cove that was later filled in, Turtle Bay has a history that is as disjointed as an exquisite corpse. (Whether the name was a homage to actual reptiles is dubious; it is more likely a corruption of the Dutch word \u201cdeutal,\u201d or bent blade, referring to the inlet\u2019s shape.) This little neighborhood has been a 17th-century rural seat, an 18th-century shipbuilding site, a 19th-century industrial center with stockyards, breweries and tenements, and a 20th-century gathering place for writers, musicians and artists.", "title": "Turtle Bay, Manhattan: The Convenience of Midtown, at a Relatively Affordable Price", "authors": ["Julie Lasky", "Living In"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Efforts to reconcile Sinn Fein with the senior partner in the Belfast government, the Democratic Unionist Party, have foundered over a number of issues, including a failure to agree on how to deal with unpunished crimes committed during the Troubles.\n\nImage A still from a video posted on Twitter by Barry McElduff with a loaf of Kingsmill bread.\n\nSouth of the border, Sinn Fein is now the third-largest political party in the Dublin Parliament. It decided in November that it was willing to be a junior partner in a future coalition government there \u2014 the latest shift from its original policy of refusing to recognize or sit in any parliament or government other than one representing a united Ireland.\n\nHowever, the party\u2019s previous links to I.R.A. violence and racketeering are still problematic for some southern voters, who might otherwise be attracted to its center-left social platform and strong constituency work.\n\nLast November, the party\u2019s veteran president, Gerry Adams, who has led Sinn Fein since 1983, announced that he would stand down at the next election, a move interpreted as passing the torch to a new generation of leaders with no personal involvement in what republicans term the \u201carmed struggle.\u201d\n\nMr. McElduff himself was convicted on charges stemming from his role in the I.R.A.\u2019s false imprisonment of a suspected police informant and was given an 18-month suspended sentence in 1992.\n\nA blurb on the Sinn Fein Bookshop website describes him as an \u201cirrepressible republican raconteur and wit.\u201d In the video on Twitter, since taken down, he jokes: \u201cI\u2019m in the Classic service station here, but I\u2019m just wondering, where does McCullough\u2019s keep the bread?\u201d\n\nThe post was immediately condemned by a range of politicians and community leaders. Arlene Foster, the leader of the Democratic Unionist Party, which draws most of its support from Protestants, said in a post on Twitter: \u201cShame on any elected rep who posted that inhuman video. I feel sorry for IRA victims & West Tyrone who have McElduff as their MP. All murder was wrong. Glorifying any murderer is sickening. Mocking is depraved.\u201d\n\nMr. McElduff later offered to meet with relatives of the Kingsmill victims.\n\n\u201cHad not realized or imagined for a second any possible link between product brand name and Kingsmill Anniversary,\u201d he wrote on Twitter, adding: \u201cFurther, I apologize for any hurt or offense caused. Never my intention to offend anyone who has suffered grievously.\u201d", "title": "Tweet on Massacre Anniversary Puts Harsh Light on Sinn Fein Member", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "In The New York Times Book Review, Adrian Wooldridge reviews David Frum\u2019s \u201cTrumpocracy: The Corruption of the American Republic.\u201d Wooldridge writes:\n\nImage\n\nWhat does Trump want to do with all his power? The answer, Frum argues, certainly does not lie in helping the white working class that put him in the White House. His tax cuts will widen America\u2019s already high levels of inequality. It lies instead in \u201cthe aggrandizement of one domineering man and his shamelessly grasping extended family.\u201d The essence of Trumponomics is running a country just as you run your family business: appointing people with whom you have strong personal ties, ideally ties of DNA, directing business to your properties, using public resources to avenge private grudges.\n\nOn this week\u2019s podcast, Frum talks about \u201cTrumpocracy\u201d; Helen Thorpe discusses \u201cThe Newcomers: Finding Refuge, Friendship, and Hope in an American Classroom\u201d; and Gregory Cowles, Tina Jordan and John Williams on what people are reading. Pamela Paul is the host.\n\nHere are the books mentioned in this week\u2019s \u201cWhat We\u2019re Reading\u201d:\n\n\u201cThe Portrait of a Lady\u201d by Henry James\n\n\u201cBluebird, Bluebird\u201d by Attica Locke\n\n\u201cPersonal History\u201d by Katharine Graham\n\n\u201cThe Perfect Nanny\u201d by Leila Slimani\n\nWe would love to hear your thoughts about this episode, and about the Book Review\u2019s podcast in general. You can send them to books@nytimes.com.\n\nHow do I listen? Two ways\n\nFrom a desktop or laptop, you can listen by pressing play on the button above.\n\nOr if you\u2019re on a mobile device, the instructions below will help you find and subscribe to the series.", "title": "Twilight\u2019s Last Gleaming?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Is there any situation that would cause Twitter to suspend or ban President Trump?\n\nGiven Friday\u2019s announcement, it seems highly unlikely that President Trump will ever lose access to his account while he still holds office.\n\nIn the past, Twitter has insisted that there are no exceptions to its rules and that all individuals using the platform must adhere to them, or risk disciplinary action or permanent suspension.\n\nBut the company refused to entertain hypothetical scenarios about suspending high-profile accounts, including that of Mr. Trump.\n\nFriday\u2019s announcement explained:\n\n\u201cBlocking a world leader from Twitter or removing their controversial Tweets would hide important information people should be able to see and debate. It would also not silence that leader, but it would certainly hamper necessary discussion around their words and actions.\u201d\n\nQuestioned about the president in a Wired interview last year, Jack Dorsey, the company\u2019s chief executive, said that all users would be held to the same standard. But he pointed out that Twitter\u2019s policies made an exception for newsworthiness, a factor that must be considered in regard to any and all of the president\u2019s tweets.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s really important that we maintain open channels to our leaders, whether we like what they\u2019re saying or not,\u201d he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHas a Trump tweet raised these questions in the past?\n\nYes, including on Sept. 23, when another threat toward North Korea led to a similar outcry.\n\n\u201cJust heard Foreign Minister of North Korea speak at U.N.,\u201d Mr. Trump tweeted. \u201cIf he echoes thoughts of Little Rocket Man, they won\u2019t be around much longer!\u201d\n\nTwitter declined to take the tweet down.\n\n\u201cWe hold all accounts to the same Rules, and consider a number of factors when assessing whether Tweets violate our Rules. Among the considerations is \u2018newsworthiness\u2019 and whether a Tweet is of public interest,\u201d the company said. \u201cThis has long been internal policy and we\u2019ll soon update our public-facing rules to reflect it. We need to do better on this, and will.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDoes Twitter treat the president differently from other users?\n\nTwitter bans what it calls abusive behavior, or \u201cbehavior that harasses, intimidates or uses fear to silence another user\u2019s voice.\u201d For example, the writer Milo Yiannopoulos was barred in 2016 amid coordinated harassment of the comedian Leslie Jones.\n\nBut there are caveats, including the above passage, in the rules about tweets that are deemed in the legitimate public interest.\n\nThat language suggests that in some if not many cases, a user whose tweets fit that definition \u2014 like the president \u2014 would have more leeway than others when engaging in abusive behavior. And with Friday\u2019s rule change, that difference became explicit.\n\n\u201cWe review Tweets by leaders within the political context that defines them, and enforce our rules accordingly,\u201d the statement said. \u201cNo one person\u2019s account drives Twitter\u2019s growth, or influences these decisions.\u201d\n\nTwitter has acknowledged that decisions about policing newsworthy accounts can be difficult.\n\nHow does the company decide who to bar?\n\nIt\u2019s unclear. Twitter will not comment on its internal deliberations over complaints about any individual tweet or account.\n\nHow has its stance on violent language and harassment changed recently?\n\nTwitter has made several changes to its guidelines in recent months involving sexual content and abusive language, though many users have called for more.\n\nIn December, the company began enforcing new rules on violence. \u201cSpecific threats of violence or wishing for serious physical harm, death, or disease to an individual or group of people is in violation of our policies,\u201d it said in a blog post. It also banned hateful imagery and symbols in profile images and headers.\n\nTwitter pulled some white supremacist organizations and other extremists from the platform soon after, citing the new policies. Others, including David Duke and Richard B. Spencer, remain.", "title": "Twitter\u2019s Shifting Positions on Trump\u2019s Tweets", "authors": ["Jonah Engel Bromwich", "Johanna Barr"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere are still many drinkers who have yet to experience the hazy, citrusy brew,\u201d said Meaghan Quinn, a spokeswoman for Samuel Adams.\n\nThe fervor around these beers is ripe with hyperbole, but in the best examples, it\u2019s warranted. Hazy I.P.A.s offer lush, juicy flavors that beers have never had before. Brewers are harnessing the citrus and tropical notes of new hop varieties while eschewing their characteristic bitterness, a trick they achieve by loading their hops late in the brewing process, and in huge quantities.\n\nThese beers seem to defy large-scale production and cross-country shipping; many brewers intentionally keep batches small to ensure freshness through high turnover. But Sierra Nevada in particular has consistently made world-class beers in big volume, and these ephemeral I.P.A.s will be its biggest test.\n\nThe beers\u2019 haze has traditionally come from hop particles that mix with yeast in suspension. The result is hop flavors that, rather than wafting up to your nose from the glass, burst in your mouth after each sip.\n\nAs the New England style has proliferated, breweries have turned to high-protein grains, like oats and unmalted wheat, to build a more stable haze for their beloved hops to nest in. Others use additives like pectin or even flour, igniting debate in the most fervent corners of the craft-beer world.\n\nSierra Nevada uses oats in its recipe for Hazy Little Thing. But it also employs other tricks for quality control, including one common among wheat beer producers: When sending kegs to restaurants and bars, the company instructs distributors to ship them upside down. That way, the bartender is forced to flip them upon delivery, stirring up the proteins and restoring the haze.\n\nToday, an I.P.A.\u2019s cloudy appearance has become its signifier, even a status symbol, flooding Instagram feeds and inspiring hashtags like #hazyipa and #newenglendipa. Garrett Oliver, the brewmaster of Brooklyn Brewery, has declared the New England ales \u201cthe first beer style based around Instagram culture and based around social media.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut in the beginning, haze wasn\u2019t the goal; it was a side effect. \u201cWe never set out to brew an I.P.A. that was hazy,\u201d said John Kimmich, a founder and the head brewer of the Alchemist in Waterbury, Vt. \u201cOur I.P.A. was hazy because we brewed it the way I wanted it to taste.\u201d\n\nMr. Kimmich is the creator of Heady Topper, the ale that popularized the style and still sells out hours after a shipment hits New York City. His beer brims with flavors of tropical fruit and pine, balanced with a keen, citrus-peel bitterness. When he began brewing Heady Topper in 2004, his goal was to load up on hop flavors using \u201cdry hopping,\u201d or adding hops during fermentation rather than during the boiling process. This coaxes more aroma than bitter flavor from the hops; the sheer volume of hops happened to turn the beer hazy.\n\nPhoto\n\nLike many brewers of this style, Mr. Kimmich is intent on keeping his operation and availability regional. In true Vermont fashion, it doesn\u2019t take much to get him started about corporate greed and his allegiance to helping the local community.\n\nSome might question the need to sell a beer this perishable nationwide. Fresh, locally made beer is readily available these days in most metropolitan areas.\n\nBut the hazy-I.P.A. trend hasn\u2019t swept the middle of the nation yet, and Samuel Adams hopes to bring some people their first taste of the style. The company is keeping an eye on distributors to ensure that consumers get their beer fresh.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cNo beer is ever going to be as good as it is five days out of the brewery,\u201d said Megan Parisi, the head brewer at the Boston nanobrewery where Samuel Adams researches and develops new recipes. But the company is banking on the beer\u2019s staying good for a while; it is setting an expiration date of three months for its New England I.P.A.\n\nMr. Kimmich is most excited about the new beer from Sierra Nevada, a company he idolized early in his career, as a brewer in the 1990s at the Vermont Pub and Brewery.\n\n\u201cSierra Nevada? Those guys,\u201d he said. \u201cHow many countless beers have they inspired with their pale ale?\u201d\n\nHow the New Brews Taste\n\nNew England-style I.P.A.s walk a spectrum from bitter to sweet. This is a case where balance isn\u2019t always preferred: If you already love I.P.A.s, there are many bitter ones to satisfy you. If you don\u2019t, the sweet variety could be your gateway drink.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow that two of the nation\u2019s largest craft brewers have entered the scene, with Sierra Nevada Hazy Little Thing (6.7 percent alcohol by volume) and Samuel Adams New England I.P.A. (6.8 percent A.B.V.), how do they fit into that spectrum?\n\nIn terms of flavor, both are a tier below their small-batch counterparts, missing the vibrant fruitiness that distinguishes the best of breed. Samuel Adams\u2019s beer evokes citrus but not in the literal, tastes-like-juice way that is the New England style; it\u2019s scarcely different from an ordinary I.P.A.\n\nThe Sierra Nevada beer has more pleasant flavors of dried apricot and dried pineapple, and is the better choice if you can\u2019t find something fresh and local.\n\nBut in many parts of the country, local examples will be more expressive and worth seeking out. In New York, Other Half Brewing is the king of hazy I.P.A.s, so much so that its cans are nearly impossible to find. But they are worth the hunt \u2014 lean, racy and sharp with hops.\n\nGreenpoint Beer & Ale\u2019s Instant Credibility (7.8 percent A.B.V.) punches with aggressive bitterness and an undercurrent of pulpy orange and mango nectar. Also lovely is its spiritual opposite from upstate, Industrial Arts Wrench (6.8 percent A.B.V.), which embodies the sweet end of the spectrum with a silky mouth feel and flavors that verge on pineapple juice. I.P.A. skeptics, start here.\n\nAs the originator of the New England style, the Alchemist\u2019s Heady Topper (8 percent A.B.V.) has one foot in the traditional I.P.A. style, with familiar notes of pine, grapefruit and resin turned up in the foreground, washing over a background of fruit-driven hops.\n\nMr. Kimmich, Alchemist\u2019s brewer, calls it \u201cbalanced,\u201d and hopheads will attest to that. It won\u2019t bring new fans to hoppy beers, but it\u2019s a treat for the already converted.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Two Big Brewers Try to Cash In on an I.P.A. Craze", "authors": ["Orr Shtuhl"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nI\u2019m going to take a break from All Things Trump this morning to talk about two important misperceptions in American life:\n\nThe Flu. If you\u2019re like most American adults, you haven\u2019t gotten a flu vaccine this year.\n\nMaybe you think you don\u2019t need one, because you\u2019re not elderly or a child. Or maybe you think it\u2019s too late. But none of that is correct. You should get a flu vaccine every year \u2014 for your own sake and for the sake of public health \u2014 and it\u2019s not too late to get one this year.\n\nFlu season remains near its peak through February, and the flu remains a risk well after that, as Aaron Carroll, an Indiana University medical professor, told me yesterday. Carroll has written two recent Times pieces making the case for taking the flu seriously. It\u2019s the country\u2019s eighth-leading cause of death.", "title": "Opinion | Two Big Misperceptions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Two influential, if woefully under-read, American classics \u2014 George S. Schuyler\u2019s \u201cBlack No More\u201d (1931) and Nella Larsen\u2019s \u201cPassing\u201d (1929) \u2014 have been reissued in handsome new editions in time for Black History Month. This is excellent news for readers, but I imagine the authors, both famously ambivalent about causes of any kind, would have greeted the news with some exasperation.\n\nThey were contemporaries with little in common. Schuyler was prolific, pugnacious and very much in the public eye; Larsen was recessive, and vanished from literary life after publishing two novels and a few stories. Schuyler\u2019s obituary appeared in the major newspapers; Larsen was buried in an unmarked grave in Brooklyn. But they were both deeply wary of allegiances, racial or otherwise.\n\nSchuyler, in particular, was the king of contrariness. \u201cI used to tell people that George got up in the morning, waited to see which way the world was turning, then struck out in the opposite direction,\u201d his friend the historian John Henrik Clarke once recalled. He was a socialist turned right-wing reactionary who deplored Martin Luther King Jr., opposed the Voting Rights Act (\u201canother typically American attempt to use the force of law to compel the public to drastically change\u201d) and toured Africa advocating for colonialism.\n\n\u201cHe showed neither sentimentality nor chauvinism for his own race or any other. He hated everyone,\u201d the novelist Danzy Senna writes in a new introduction to \u201cBlack No More.\u201d \u201cIt is his resistance to pandering, to joining tribes and clubs \u2014 to courting today what we might call \u2018likes\u2019 \u2014 that feels so refreshing. It is the loneliness of Schuyler\u2019s position that makes me trust it.\u201d", "title": "Two Classic American Novels About the Madness and Beauty of Race", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Pence, in his role as president of the Senate, administered the oath of office.\n\nBut the real stars of the day were the two former vice presidents, both of whom also served as senators. As they milled about the Senate chamber after the brief swearing-in, the gregarious Mr. Biden greeted former colleagues with a hearty clap on the shoulder.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s a good guy,\u201d Mr. Biden told Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, referring to Mr. Jones.\n\nIn a sense, the #MeToo movement played a hand in the arrival of both Mr. Jones and Ms. Smith. Mr. Jones, 63, comes to Washington after a raucous special election in which his Republican opponent, Mr. Moore, was accused of assault and molestation of girls as young as 14.\n\nMs. Smith, 59, the former lieutenant governor of Minnesota, was appointed by that state\u2019s governor to fill the seat left vacant by the departure of Mr. Franken, who resigned amid allegations that he had forcibly kissed one woman and groped several others.\n\nShe becomes the 22nd woman in a chamber that remains heavily lopsided in favor of men. Nonetheless, there are more female senators now \u2014 17 Democrats and five Republicans \u2014 than at any time in United States history. Ms. Smith has already said she will run in a special election in November to claim the seat in her own right.\n\nMr. Jones replaces Senator Luther Strange, a Republican who was appointed to fill the seat vacated by Jeff Sessions when Mr. Sessions became Mr. Trump\u2019s attorney general. His arrival in the Senate makes life more difficult for Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, who must now manage his sometimes fractious conference with a narrow majority.\n\nMr. Jones made his name in Alabama as a lawyer who successfully prosecuted two members of the Ku Klux Klan involved in the bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, nearly 40 years after the crime. He is the first Democrat elected to the Senate from Alabama in 25 years.", "title": "Two Democrats Sworn In to Senate, Cutting the Republican Edge to One", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "It is unusual for the Fed\u2019s top three jobs to change hands at the same time. Janet L. Yellen, the Fed\u2019s chairwoman, plans to step down at the end of her term in early February, pending the confirmation of Mr. Powell. The Senate Banking Committee, which approved his nomination last session, did so again on Wednesday, clearing the way for a final vote.\n\nThe vice chairman job has been open since Stanley Fischer stepped down in October. And William C. Dudley, the New York Fed\u2019s outgoing president, has said that he plans to step down this summer, once a successor is in place.\n\nThe Fed\u2019s new leaders will take the helm during a period of relative tranquillity. The economy is expanding and the Fed is in the middle of a slow-and-steady retreat from its post-crisis stimulus campaign. But there are significant long-term challenges, including a brewing debate about whether the Fed should adjust the way that it conducts monetary policy before the next downturn.\n\nPhoto\n\nKrishna Guha, head of the central bank strategy team at Evercore ISI, wrote in a recent note to clients that Mr. Powell does not have a deep background in monetary policy or financial markets \u2014 and might benefit from the presence of lieutenants who do.\n\n\u201cFor Powell to be effective, he needs the right leadership team around him,\u201d wrote Mr. Guha, a former New York Fed official. He added, \u201cWhile most decisions taken by even a Fed chairman are in the end not make-or-break, most Fed chairs face at least one profoundly consequential decision during their tenure.\u201d\n\nThe Trump administration has discussed some vice-chairman candidates who could fit the bill, including Lawrence B. Lindsey, a former Fed governor and director of the National Economic Council under President George W. Bush, and Mohamed A. El-Erian, the chief economic adviser at Allianz, who is widely respected as both an investor and a commentator on monetary policy, according to a person who has participated in some of those conversations.\n\nThe White House has not said when it plans to announce a decision.\n\nThe New York Fed\u2019s board of directors, which is at an earlier stage in its search, has said that it was focused on finding a technocrat who understood the bank\u2019s work.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut technocrats come in many flavors, and there are signs that the New York Fed would like someone in the mold of Mr. Dudley or Ms. Yellen, both of whom have emphasized the effects of monetary policy on ordinary people.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cHow monetary policy is considered seems very high-level for many people in the community, but it has a direct impact on how well they may do economically,\u201d Denise Scott, a member of the four-person search committee, said in a video released by the New York Fed that described what it\u2019s looking for in a candidate. Ms. Scott is executive vice president of the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a nonprofit that backs community development projects.\n\nThe leaders of the search committee are Sara Horowitz, the executive director of a New York labor union, and Glenn Hutchins, a private equity executive who has long been a major donor to Democratic political candidates. The fourth member is David M. Cote, chairman of Honeywell International.\n\nThe committee has hired two search firms, one of which specializes in identifying a diverse field of candidates. It also made a point of meeting with a group of liberal activists, including labor unions and community development groups, in addition to the standard roster of banks and business officials.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe divergent selection processes are an artifact of the Fed\u2019s structure: A board of political appointees in Washington oversees the operations of 12 regional reserve banks, which are privately owned by the commercial banks in each region. The New York Fed is owned by major banks including Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase as well as smaller community banks.\n\nAlthough the regional reserve banks have lost much of their original autonomy, they retain the power to select their own presidents, subject to the approval of the Federal Reserve Board in Washington.\n\nMonetary policy is made by a committee comprising the Fed\u2019s governors and five of the regional presidents. The president of the New York Fed holds one of those votes on a permanent basis, a reflection of New York\u2019s longstanding role as the nation\u2019s financial center, and serves as the committee\u2019s vice chairman. The remaining four votes rotate among the other 11 regional banks.\n\nWhile private ownership of central banks was once quite common, most developed nations have converted to fully public systems, and the list of holdouts is dwindling. Austria took ownership of all shares in the Oesterreichische Nationalbank in 2010. South Africa said in December that it would move to take full ownership of the South African Reserve Bank.\n\nAndrew Levin, a Dartmouth economist and a former Fed official, said it\u2019s past time to make the Fed a fully public institution, too. Mr. Levin has proposed that the federal government should take ownership of the regional reserve banks, and that the selection of regional reserve presidents should be a public process.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis is one of the most important public officials in the United States and that person is being chosen by a private board of directors of a private institution,\u201d he said, referring to the New York Fed\u2019s current search.\n\nBut some liberal activists who, under the Obama Administration, pushed for the government to take control of the reserve banks now see the New York Fed\u2019s independence from Washington as potentially valuable.\n\nShawn Sebastian, director of the Fed Up campaign, a consortium of groups that lobbies the Fed to prioritize employment and wage growth when making monetary policy, said his organization is pushing for the New York Fed to make a statement with its decision.\n\n\u201cThe next president needs to have a real and demonstrated commitment to full employment, by having worked for the public interest and low-income people in their career,\u201d he said.", "title": "Two Federal Reserve Openings Provide One Chance to Counter Trump", "authors": ["Binyamin Appelbaum"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Smith\u2019s \u201cFeel Free\u201d is a gentler ride. If Amis\u2019s book is like hurtling down a black-diamond ski run, hers is more like a brisk day on the cross-country trails. She writes a good deal about art and gardens and travel, and about non-controversial \u2014 at least for her New York Review of Books readers \u2014 topics like libraries (good) and global warming (bad).\n\nImage Zadie Smith Credit Dominique Nabokov\n\nIn the best of these pieces, however, Smith presses down hard as a cultural critic, and the rewards are outsize. Who else would deliver an observation quite like this one, from her profile of Jay-Z?:\n\n\u201cAsking why rappers always talk about their stuff is like asking why Milton is forever listing the attributes of heavenly armies. Because boasting is a formal condition of the epic form.\u201d\n\nSmith prints two shrewd pieces about Jordan Peele, one before and one after his success as the director of the indie horror movie \u201cGet Out.\u201d Here she is on the compendium of black fears that Peele\u2019s movie illuminates:\n\n\u201cBanjos. Crazy younger brothers. Crazy younger brothers who play banjos.\u201d And: \u201cWell-meaning conversations about basketball. Spontaneous arm-wrestling, spontaneous touching of one\u2019s biceps or hair. Lifestyle cults, actual cults. Houses with no other houses anywhere near them. Fondness for woods. The game Bingo!\u201d\n\nTrump figures only slightly in Smith\u2019s essays, which were written almost entirely before his presidency. But in a bitter piece about Brexit composed for The New York Review of Books, she takes aim at its spiritual fathers, David Cameron and Boris Johnson.\n\nAbout them, she declares: \u201c\u2018Conservative\u2019 is not the right term for either of them anymore: that word has at least an implication of care and the preservation of legacy. \u2018Arsonist\u2019 feels like the more accurate term.\u201d\n\nFor six months, Smith was a book critic for Harper\u2019s Magazine, and the results are printed here. These reviews are a mixed bag, mostly because the titles seem random and often infra dig.", "title": "Two Generations on View in Essays by Martin Amis and Zadie Smith", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Over the past few years, the discussion of crime and violence in the United States has focused on police brutality, mass incarceration and the sharp rise in violence in cities like Baltimore, St. Louis and Chicago. This is entirely appropriate: Any spike in violence should garner attention, and redressing the injustices of our criminal justice system is a matter of moral urgency.\n\nBut it is also worth reflecting on how much the level of violence has fallen in this country over the past 25 years and how widespread the benefits of that decline have been. From the 1970s through the early part of the 1990s, the murder rate in some cities in the United States rose to levels seen only in the most violent, war-torn nations of the developing world. In the years since, violent crime has decreased in almost every city, in many cases by more than 75 percent.\n\nFor well-off urbanites, the decline of crime is most visible in sanitized, closely guarded city spaces where tourists and others can now comfortably wander about. But far more consequential have been the changes in low-income, highly segregated urban communities. Indeed, my research has shown that the most disadvantaged people have gained the most from the reduction in violent crime.\n\nStart with the lives saved. Though homicide is not a common cause of death for most of the United States population, for African-American men between the ages of 15 and 34 it is the leading cause, which means that any change in the homicide rate has a disproportionate impact on them. The sociologist Michael Friedson and I calculated what the life expectancy would be today for blacks and whites had the homicide rate never shifted from its level in 1991. We found that the national decline in the homicide rate since then has increased the life expectancy of black men by roughly nine months.", "title": "Opinion | Two Lessons of the Urban Crime Decline", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "As proof of the happy results when a director and a literary titan align, along comes Ian Rickson\u2019s 60th-anniversary production of \u201cThe Birthday Party\u201d from a writer, Harold Pinter, who relished language just as much as Wilde, but with very different results. The play is running at the Harold Pinter Theater \u2014 how apt! \u2014 through April 14.\n\nNot that Pinter\u2019s disorienting amalgam of mirth and menace was particularly welcomed at its 1958 premiere; the play was greeted with general befuddlement until a celebrated review from Harold Hobson in The Sunday Times of London alerted readers to the playwright\u2019s singular capacity to disturb and provoke. No matter: The production nonetheless closed after a week.\n\nIts current iteration by contrast looks likely to be London\u2019s first theatrical hit of 2018 \u2014 a testament to a starry cast that anchors the piece in a recognizable time and place while allowing its absurdism to shine through. (You can tick off the various textual nods to \u201cWaiting for Godot,\u201d which was first seen in London only several years before \u201cThe Birthday Party.\u201d)\n\nThe setting is one of those rundown seaside boardinghouses that Pinter would have known firsthand when he used to tour the regions as an actor under the stage name David Baron. You can practically smell the damp rising from behind the cracked wallpaper of the living room set.\n\nThe evocatively dreary environs belong to Meg (Zo\u00eb Wanamaker) and her husband Petey (Peter Wight), though questions of ownership and control soon come to define the play. The couple have a lodger, Stanley (Toby Jones), who seems to be a surrogate for the son Meg never had. Stanley is a study in unspecified damage, and an unspoken anger courses beneath his blandly bespectacled visage. It\u2019s not altogether surprising when he reaches toward Meg in what looks like an embrace, only to put his hands around her throat.\n\nPhoto\n\nPetey, a deckchair attendant, keeps absenting himself, allowing Meg and Stanley to pursue their warped interactions unbothered, until into this peculiar trio comes the troubling double-act of Goldberg (Stephen Mangan) and McCann (Tom Vaughan-Lawlor). They have arrived to deliver Stanley to an unseen character called Monty, though who Monty is or what he represents is anyone\u2019s (fearsome) guess.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrom this self-enclosed landscape \u2014 we never leave the living room \u2014 Pinter maps out themes of dominance and usurpation that he would revisit throughout a lifetime of plays that shifted over the years from the domestic to the more overtly political. His gift for ambiguity, too, is everywhere evident: Meg refers more than once to a boardinghouse that is \u201con the list,\u201d by which she presumably doesn\u2019t mean the tourist itinerary. (Is it under surveillance? Has it been condemned?)\n\nComedy, of which there is plenty, arises from the characters\u2019 capacity for surprise \u2014 Goldberg for no apparent reason sticks out his tongue \u2014 and from Pinter\u2019s self-evident delight in the effect of certain words. Ms. Wanamaker\u2019s Meg looks taken aback early on by Petey\u2019s use of the adjective \u201csucculent\u201d \u2014 one that is clearly more suggestive than she is used to.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs Simon Baker\u2019s sound design ratchets up the tension, the company play with the ensemble ease that is one of the director Mr. Rickson\u2019s many gifts. (Nor is he any stranger to Pinter, having directed Pinter as an actor in Beckett\u2019s \u201cKrapp\u2019s Last Tape\u201d and overseen productions of his plays \u201cOld Times\u201d and \u201cBetrayal.\u201d)\n\nAmong a uniformly attuned cast, of whom only Ms. Wanamaker is on occasion a tad too studied, it\u2019s worth noting Mr. Mangan\u2019s dampening down his natural charm and full coiffeur to play a man on a none-too-cheerful mission: He and the ramrod-straight Mr. Vaughan-Lawlor revel in vaudevillian banter toward the end as a chastened, newly captive Stanley looks on motionless.\n\nAnd in the pivotal role of the piano-playing victim, Mr. Jones, known from such films as \u201cInfamous\u201d and the recent \u201cHappy End,\u201d delivers a climactic scream worthy of Edvard Munch. Think of it as the first of Pinter\u2019s many theatrical alarm calls: a cry for help from a writer besotted with language who also knew the forbidding terrain that exists beyond words.", "title": "Two Literary Greats, One Done Well and One Done Wrongly", "authors": ["Matt Wolf", "London Theater Reviews"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "The conflict between Turkey and the Kurds has escalated since Turkey started a military offensive against the Syrian Kurdish enclave of Afrin on Jan. 20. The Kurdish militia, the People\u2019s Protection Units, which is the United States-led coalition\u2019s top partner in the fight against the Islamic State, controls Afrin. And Turkey is a critical NATO ally.\n\nThe Trump administration is floundering. President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has ignored President Trump\u2019s appeal to avoid actions that might risk conflict between Turkish and American forces and torpedo the campaign against the Islamic State. Mr. Erdogan has vowed to carry the battle further east to militia-controlled territory stretching all the way to the Iraqi border, where an estimated 2,000 American Special Operations Forces are deployed.\n\nTurkey blames Washington\u2019s support for the People\u2019s Protection Units for the meltdown in American-Turkish ties. Many of the militia\u2019s top cadres are drawn from the Kurdistan Workers\u2019 Party, or P.K.K., the armed group that has been waging a bloody campaign for self-rule inside Turkey. The State Department lists the P.K.K. as a terrorist organization but does not so designate the People\u2019s Protection Units. Turkey insists that the P.K.K. and the militia are the same.\n\nTurkish officials believe that once the Islamic State is defeated, the People\u2019s Protection Units will melt back into the P.K.K. and train its American weapons on Turkey. American officials retort that it was Turkey\u2019s tolerance for \u2014 if not outright collusion with \u2014 thousands of jihadist fighters who flowed into Syria through Turkey that forced them to embrace the militia. Condemns Congo\u2019s Use of Force Against Protesters and Monitors", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "The report was a result of a resolution passed by the Human Rights Council in March 2016 that called for a database detailing the companies engaged in a list of specified activities that directly enabled, supported or profited from Israeli settlements. Those activities included supplying construction machinery or materials, surveillance equipment and security services, as well as providing banking and financial services.\n\nThe 16-page report released Wednesday did not produce what critics of the initiative had feared would be a blacklist naming and shaming companies doing business with the settlements, but it still drew condemnation from the Trump administration and Israeli diplomats in New York and Geneva, who cited the report as proof of the Human Rights Council\u2019s institutional bias.\n\nPresident Trump\u2019s United Nations ambassador, Nikki R. Haley, who has vowed to combat what she has described as antipathy toward Israel in parts of the organization, strongly condemned the human rights office\u2019s report.\n\n\u201cThis whole issue is outside the bounds of the High Commissioner for Human Rights office\u2019s mandate and is a waste of time and resources,\u201d she said in a statement. \u201cWhile we note that they wisely refrained from listing individual companies, the fact that the report was issued at all is yet another reminder of the Council\u2019s anti-Israel obsession. The more the Human Rights Council does this, the less effective it becomes as an advocate against the world\u2019s human rights abusers.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. His many attempts to bring the antagonists together in Yemen were repeatedly flustered.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAny prospects for his success may have been fatally damaged in June, when the Houthis accused Mr. Ahmed of having abandoned his neutrality and warned him never to come to Yemen again.\n\nThe basis for the Houthi accusation was never made clear. But it came a few weeks after the United Nations requested that the Houthis investigate an attack on Mr. Ahmed\u2019s motorcade as it traveled from the Sana airport to the United Nations compound. The Houthis denied that any attack had occurred.\n\nIn more recent months, Mr. Ahmed has been able to do little except implore the warring sides to ease the plight of civilians, entreaties that have been largely ignored.\n\nIn November, Saudi Arabia imposed what humanitarian groups described as a draconian blockade on Yemen ports, raising fears of famine in the country. The Saudis only recently have loosened the blockade.\n\nThe announcement that Mr. Ahmed was leaving came the same day that Saudi Arabia said it was expanding emergency relief to Yemenis with an infusion of more than $3.5 billion in aid, including $1.5 billion in funding to United Nations agencies and humanitarian groups. Relief agencies welcomed the Saudi announcement but coupled their response with caution about the details and timetable.\n\nThey said previous pledges by Saudi Arabia to help ease a crisis that its own military helped create had not always been fulfilled. Bassam Khabieh, a freelance photographer working for Reuters, was in the vicinity and said in an interview that it occurred between 5:30 and 6:00 on Monday morning. By the time he arrived, he said, a chlorine smell hung in the air and dead cats littered the ground. All the victims had already been taken to the hospital, he said.\n\nThe Douma Medical Center in East Ghouta said 21 people, including six children, had been admitted by the Ambulance Department at the Damascus Countryside Specialty Hospital at 6 a.m.\n\nIt was at least the second time chlorine assaults were reported in Syria this month, with no provision for establishing who was responsible. The United Nations Security Council\u2019s panel for investigating such attacks was disbanded two months ago in a political showdown between Russia and the United States.\n\nIn a statement, Ms. Haley said that Russia bore some responsibility for the latest attacks because of its decision to veto the renewal of the panel, known as the Joint Investigative Mechanism. Russia said the panel had been biased and unprofessional, accusations that the United States and its allies angrily disputed.\n\nBy halting the work of the investigative body, Russia sent a \u201cdangerous message to the world,\u201d Ms. Haley said on Tuesday, \u201cone that not only said chemical weapons use is acceptable but also that those who use chemical weapons don\u2019t need to be identified or held accountable.\u201d\n\nMr. Tillerson also criticized what he called Syria\u2019s continued use of chemical weapons in the war and what he described as Russia\u2019s complicity.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNo matter who was behind the East Ghouta chlorine attack, Mr. Tillerson said, Russia was responsible because of its 2013 deal with the United States that had guaranteed Syria would eliminate chemical weapons.\n\n\u201cThere is simply no denying that Russia, by shielding its Syrian ally, has breached its commitments to the United States as a framework guarantor,\u201d Mr. Tillerson said. \u201cRussia\u2019s failure to resolve the chemical weapons issue in Syria calls into question its relevance to the resolution to the overall crisis.\u201d\n\nMr. Tillerson was speaking at a Paris meeting of envoys from France and more than 20 other nations to establish a new organization intended to identify and punish any government or group that uses chemical weapons.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. conflict.\n\nIn particular, Moscow objected to the investigative panel\u2019s conclusions that Mr. Assad\u2019s forces had carried out a sarin attack on the rebel-held village of Khan Sheikhoun last April that killed at least 83 people and sickened roughly 300.\n\nRussia called the Khan Sheikhoun findings \u201cnonsense.\u201d\n\nBut the attack led President Trump to order a cruise missile strike on an airfield that American intelligence officials said had been used by Mr. Assad\u2019s air force to strike Khan Sheikhoun.\n\nThe Trump administration said its missile retaliation had sent a strong message to Mr. Assad not to use chemical weapons again. Last June, Ms. Haley told Congress that the White House\u2019s willingness to use force had dissuaded the Syrian government from another attack and had \u201csaved innocent lives.\u201d\n\nIt was not clear from the remarks by Mr. Tillerson and Ms. Haley on Tuesday whether the United States was prepared to respond militarily to the East Ghouta attack.\n\nDuring his campaign for president, Mr. Trump criticized his predecessor\u2019s decision to avoid military action after the 2013 sarin assault, describing it as a sign of weakness that emboldened Mr. Assad.", "title": "U.S. Accuses Syria of New Chemical Weapons Use", "authors": ["Michael Schwirtz"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Attorney General Jeff Sessions has named interim United States attorneys in Brooklyn and Manhattan, two of the country\u2019s most prominent federal prosecutors\u2019 offices, replacing lawyers who had served as top deputies to Obama appointees.\n\nOn Friday, Geoffrey S.
