Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThere was a new fighter that had joined the group, and he was the one who opened fire on the Americans,\u201d said Khair Mohammed, a commander in Mr. Qadir\u2019s militia.\n\nTwo years ago, Mr. Qadir\u2019s militia decapitated four members of the Islamic State, also known as ISIS, in what they said was an act of retaliation, and then circulated on social media pictures of the heads placed on piles of rocks on the side of a road.\n\nIn southern Afghanistan, at least five police officers were killed and two civilians were wounded during a Taliban attack in the Nawa district of Helmand Province. The Taliban overran a check post in the Surkhgulf area of the district, said Bashir Ahmad Shakir, a member of the provincial council.\n\nBut there was also some better news in the south.\n\nOfficials in Kandahar Province said they had completed a polio vaccination campaign in Shah Wali Kot, a district that last year reported the most polio cases in the world. As a measure of the gravity of the problem in the region, a fifth polio case within the past year was recently confirmed in the district: Ashrafia, a 2 \u00bd-year-old girl, tested positive about two weeks ago and died soon after because of the severity of the virus.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfghanistan is one of only three countries in the world reporting polio cases. Last month, the United Nations appealed to all sides in the conflict to allow polio workers to conduct the first of three vaccination campaigns in Shah Wali Kot. Although the campaign got off to a rocky start, with the Taliban restricting access and government forces reportedly burning a health center and arresting a vaccinator, officials announced that they had managed to complete the first phase.\n\n\u201cI am grateful to the authorities and community leaders who enabled 503 frontline workers to conduct the first campaign this week,\u201d Toby Lanzer, the United Nations humanitarian coordinator in Afghanistan, said in a statement on Wednesday.\n\nDr. Sardar Wali, the senior health official in Shah Wali Kot, said the United Nations appeal and attention from the news media, including The New York Times, had compelled the governor to mobilize his staff members to take urgent action.\n\n\u201cThe W.H.O. and Unicef representative met the Taliban in Shah Wali Kot after The New York Times report, and the governor summoned district authorities and elders and warned them to work hard in order to convince the Taliban through elders to allow the campaigners to carry out the polio drive in those blocked regions,\u201d Dr. Wali said. \u201cThe Taliban agreed to allow the polio campaign in those 14 restricted regions, and it has been done.\u201d", "title": "U.S. Bombs Afghan Militia Behind Insider Attack, Officials Say", "authors": ["Zabihullah Ghazi", "Mujib Mashal"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "CARACAS, Venezuela \u2014 The top United States diplomat in Venezuela urged the authorities there on Friday to ensure transparency in the case of a jailed American whose trial has become another sore spot in relations between the two nations.\n\nThe diplomat, Todd D. Robinson, said that he reminded Foreign Minister Jorge Arreaza in a recent meeting of his \u201cresponsibility to guarantee transparency\u201d in the case of the detained American, Joshua Holt.\n\nMr. Robinson also pressed for United States consular access to Mr. Holt, a 25-year-old Utah man whose mother recently voiced concerns about his health. The head of the United States Embassy in Venezuela before Mr. Robinson\u2019s arrival had been denied access to a hearing in December.\n\n\u201cWithout the ability to talk with him it\u2019s difficult to know exactly what is happening,\u201d Mr. Robinson said.", "title": "U.S. Diplomat in Venezuela Raises Concern About Detained American", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "ISLAMABAD, Pakistan \u2014 A leader of the militant Haqqani network and two of his aides were killed Wednesday in an American drone strike in northwestern Pakistan, an attack that was denounced by the Pakistani government.\n\nThe attack took place on Wednesday morning in the Speen Thal Dapa Mamozai area of the Kurram tribal region and was directed at a house that the Pakistani authorities said was being used by Afghan refugees. The militant commander, Nasir Mehmood, who was also known as Khawari, and two of his aides were killed.\n\nThe Haqqani network, affiliated with the Taliban and designated as a terrorist group by the United States, has carried out numerous deadly attacks in Afghanistan in recent years. The presence of its leaders and militants in Pakistan and its links with the country\u2019s military intelligence agency have long caused friction between United States and Pakistan.\n\nThe Kurram region has been used frequently by Haqqani network fighters to cross into neighboring Afghanistan.", "title": "U.S. Drone Strike Kills Militants in Pakistan but Angers Its Government", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe economy\u2019s sustainable trend is around 2 percent,\u201d Mr. Prakken said.\n\nThe Commerce Department\u2019s report on the gross domestic product \u2014 which showed growth for all of last year at 2.3 percent \u2014 is a rough draft. The fourth-quarter estimate will be revised twice in the next couple of months, and it could increase or drop by as much as a percentage point, based on previous recalculations. After all, government statisticians have to put together the fourth-quarter estimate without complete data on construction, trade and inventories.\n\nMr. Trump inherited an improving economy, and during his first year in office, the trend continued and growth accelerated. Supporters credit Mr. Trump with revving up business and consumer confidence, and say tax cuts and eased regulation are fueling capital investment and job creation. They also point to a booming stock market, though market gains are not necessarily a gauge of economic underpinnings.\n\nThe president ticked off those items on Friday when he hailed America\u2019s economic strength at the World Economic Forum\u2019s annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland, where global leaders have been sharing encouraging economic news all week.\n\nThe American economy recovered from a plodding start in the first three months of 2017, when sharp cuts in consumer spending limited G.D.P. growth to 1.2 percent on an annualized basis. It sprang back over the next six months, with the rate reaching 3.1 percent in the second quarter and 3.2 percent in the third.\n\nIn the fourth quarter, holiday shoppers were enthusiastic, and spending on business and residential housing was up. A persistent appetite for foreign goods continued to widen the trade deficit \u2014 it reached nearly $72 billion for goods alone in December \u2014 and dragged down gains. But inventory declines that detracted from G.D.P. last quarter should rebound over the next as businesses refill empty shelves.\n\nThe American economy\u2019s performance has also been buoyed by simultaneous growth in nations around the world, which has fueled trade and enabled foreign consumers to buy more American-made products.\n\nFor several years after the recession, the United States\u2019 steady if unremarkable growth was a bright spot compared with struggling economies abroad. Under President Barack Obama, who took office when the economy was floundering, yearly growth averaged 2.1 percent during the recovery. After a high of 2.9 percent in 2015, it dropped to 1.5 percent in 2016.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut in 2017, more than eight years into the nation\u2019s recovery, the expansion spread to at least 120 countries, according to a report released this week by the International Monetary Fund. In several, growth rates outpaced that of the United States. Among large economies in the Group of 7, the United States ranked fifth, according to a report from the World Economic Forum. On a list of 29 advanced economies, it ranked 10th, though it sank close to the bottom in terms of equitably sharing the gains.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nExhilarating stock market gains have also been a worldwide phenomenon. Lawrence H. Summers, the Harvard economist and former Treasury secretary, pointed out that the major stock indexes in Japan, Hong Kong, Germany and South Korea registered gains comparable to the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index, if not better.\n\n\u201cThe U.S. performance doesn\u2019t stand out relative to the rest of the world,\u201d he said.\n\nThe I.M.F. warned against assuming that the current economic cycle would go on indefinitely, however, particularly given the towering debt of the United States and other countries. By borrowing so much, the government can crowd out other investors and drive up interest rates. At the same time, giant deficits crank up pressure to cut government spending on health care and housing, policing and schools. With less money to go around, spending dries up and consumer demand \u2014 the economy\u2019s primary engine \u2014 slows.\n\n\u201cPolitical leaders and policymakers must stay mindful that the current economic momentum reflects a confluence of factors that is unlikely to last for long,\u201d said Maurice Obstfeld, the I.M.F.\u2019s chief economist.\n\nDespite all the attention that the growth statistics engender, economists warn against reading too much into G.D.P. figures. In recent years, more and more experts have noted the increasing difficulty in measuring a knowledge-based economy where services like Facebook and Google are free and innovations and improvements often lack an accurate price tag.\n\nAn additional, unexpected flaw in recent United States data may come more sharply into focus this year. G.D.P. figures may have been artificially lowered over the last decade because of tax policies that encouraged domestic-based multinationals to shift billions of dollars in domestic profits overseas.\n\nAfter Ireland became a tax haven, its growth rate suddenly rocketed to more than 25 percent in 2015. At least a portion of what was counted, however, had been generated in the United States and should have been counted toward American growth, said Alan J. Auerbach, an economist at the University of California, Berkeley. A significant chunk of the United States trade gap has been caused by companies overstating imports from their foreign subsidiaries and underreporting exports, Mr. Auerbach said.\n\nOne analysis estimated that such accounting methods subtracted $280 billion from the tally of the nation\u2019s output in 2012. The new tax law reworks many of those international provisions. Those changes \u201cshould somewhat temper the incentives\u201d to book money offshore, said Fatih Guvenen, one of the authors of the analysis, \u201cbut still doesn\u2019t eliminate them.\u201d\n\nThe tax-code changes could muddy attempts to measure growth in 2018, and possibly 2019, though. If enough companies stop disguising significant domestic profits as foreign, G.D.P. in the United States would suddenly expand \u2014 without any underlying change in output.\n\n\u201cOver the next couple of years, I think there will be a one-time jump in the level of G.D.P. because the profits that Apple, Google, Facebook and others attributed to an offshore tax haven affiliate will now appear in their U.S. accounts,\u201d said Mr. Guvenen, an economics professor at the University of Minnesota.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf it happens at a larger scale, it will give the appearance of faster G.D.P. growth,\u201d he said.", "title": "U.S. Economy Grew at 2.6% Rate in Fourth Quarter", "authors": ["Patricia Cohen"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Moreover, rather than working to reduce its rolls by resettling refugees in other countries, the agency has focused on helping refugees where they are until a political end to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict can be reached.\n\n\u201cUnrwa would like nothing more than to shut up shop,\u201d Mr. Gunness said. \u201cBut there has to first be a just and durable solution.\u201d\n\nThe Arab states that have taken in the bulk of the refugees ask why they should grant them citizenship instead of helping them to return to their homes in what is now Israel.\n\nThe agency\u2019s critics in Israel and in the United States say that it has perpetuated the problem by maintaining a steadily growing refugee population, which in turn means more refugees demanding a right of return.\n\n\u201cAt the rate we\u2019re going now, it\u2019s going to be 15 million soon,\u201d said Asaf Romirowsky, executive director of Scholars for Peace in the Middle East, who has called for disbanding the agency and turning over its functions to other institutions, like the Palestinian Authority. \u201cUnrwa will tell you they\u2019ll leave the situation when there is a resolution to the conflict, but it\u2019s a catch-22: They are the gatekeepers for the one single issue that perpetuates the conflict from generation to generation.\u201d\n\nHe said that freezing the agency\u2019s money could be a good step if it forced Israel and the Palestinians to the table. \u201cThe endgame from a political standpoint has to be about fully ending refugee status and ending the right of return,\u201d he said. \u201cOtherwise, this is just going to come back in a different formulation.\u201d\n\nThe right of return for the refugees and their descendants has long been a stumbling block in the peace process, with Palestinians insisting on it and Israel objecting to it. Mediators have proposed settling the issue with a payment to the refugees, but such a deal would only be likely to happen as part of a negotiated peace settlement.", "title": "U.S. Funding Cut Reignites Debate on Palestinian Refugee Agency", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "The bustling United States economy is beginning to benefit some American workers who have not gotten a taste of the recovery and have been most in need of relief.\n\nThat picture was reinforced by a report on Friday from the Labor Department, which showed an increase of 148,000 jobs last month. The figure fell short of economists\u2019 expectations, but some of the most impressive job gains in the past year were in blue-collar and service industries that pay a decent salary.\n\nOver all, average hourly earnings were 2.5 percent higher in December compared with the year before, scarcely keeping up with inflation. But other data shows that wages have increased most for the least-educated workers and for people in many industries that are generally low-paying.\n\n\u201cGrowth is strong, and the benefits of this growth have been widely shared,\u201d Jed Kolko, the chief economist for Indeed.com, a job-search site. \u201cThis has been a year in which some of the gaps in the economy that had been growing narrowed a bit.\u201d", "title": "U.S. Job Market\u2019s Strength Is Allowing More to Share in Pay Gains", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Keys began her answer apprehensively, but quickly grew steadier.\n\n\u201cI think you kind of just have to figure out why you\u2019re feeling like that, first of all,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019m sure people like you, and I\u2019m sure you would have lots of friends. Maybe you just have to get outside of your comfort zone, and talk to people. Sometimes it takes work to find a great group of friends whom you feel super comfortable and confident with.\u201d\n\nWhitfield said Keys had needed little training on how to relate to the girls in their audiences.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t ever know what people are going to say,\u201d Whitfield said of the Fearlessly Girl events. \u201cBut there was really no coaching for her.\u201d\n\nWhitfield added: \u201cThe reason I was so excited about teaming up with her was that it was so authentic and so real. You can\u2019t fake it in front of a room full of teenagers. They can detect that instantly.\u201d\n\nKeys\u2019s empathy was fostered by her mother, who made certain not to treat her tennis-playing daughter as any more special than her younger sisters, Montana, now 19, and Hunter, 16.\n\n\u201cI was very concerned about making her not the center of attention,\u201d Christine Keys said. \u201cI thought it would be unfair all the way around. I thought it was unfair to her, and I thought it was unfair to her sisters. I was always very conscious of that.\u201d\n\nOne telling moment came last year: Late in Keys\u2019s run to the U.S. Open final, Montana sent her big sister an essay to proofread. Madison dutifully did it.\n\n\u201cMontana forgot that she was playing at the U.S. Open,\u201d Christine Keys said. \u201cThere have been multiple times when my girls have come home and asked: \u2018What tournament is Madison in? My teacher said she won.\u2019\u201d", "title": "U.S. Open Loss Behind Her, Madison Keys Accentuates the Positive", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "The Department of the Interior\u2019s traffic crash report, a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times, says the episode began on Nov. 17 at 7:31 p.m. According to the report, Mr. Ghaisar was driving south on George Washington Memorial Parkway \u2014 a federal road \u2014 in a green Jeep when he abruptly \u201cstopped in the roadway.\u201d The car behind Mr. Ghaisar then rear-ended him, according to the report, and Mr. Ghaisar drove away.\n\nThe driver who struck Mr. Ghaisar\u2019s Jeep got a citation for failing to \u201cmaintain proper control,\u201d according to the police report, which did not classify the episode as a hit-and-run.\n\n\n\nIt was not entirely clear why the Park Police sought Mr. Ghaisar, given that they cited the other driver.\n\nThe video captured by the Fairfax County police begins about six minutes later, at 7:37 p.m. It appears to show the Jeep being pursued by a Park Police car, its lights flashing and sirens blaring. A Fairfax County police officer follows behind.\n\nSoon, the Park Police vehicle catches up to the Jeep, and after the Jeep stops, the police vehicle pulls up alongside it. An officer gets out of the passenger-side door and appears to point a gun at the Jeep\u2019s driver-side window and tug at the door. The Jeep, though, pulls away, and the officer bangs on the window as Mr. Ghaisar flees.\n\nThe Fairfax County police officer gives chase \u2014 its in-car camera still recording \u2014 until the Park Police vehicle catches up. All three vehicles then exit the parkway and stop.\n\nThe video then appears to show two Park Police officers approaching the Jeep\u2019s driver-side door. At least one of the officers appears to have his gun drawn. The officer kicks the door as the Jeep, once again, drives away.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe chase continues along several residential streets; at 7:41 p.m., the Jeep stops at a stop sign, and the Park Police vehicle wheels around in front of it, effectively blocking it.\n\nThe video then appears to show one officer approach the Jeep\u2019s driver-side door, with a gun drawn and pointed toward the Jeep door\u2019s window; the Jeep moves slightly forward; then one gunshot rings out.\n\nAfter a brief pause, three more shots are fired as the car continues to lurch forward; another officer then approaches, and the sound of a fifth gunshot can be heard on the video.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter having come to a stop during the gunfire, the Jeep veers to the right \u2014 a few feet toward the stop sign and off the road. Two more gun shots can be heard on the video.\n\nA third officer in a different uniform then appears onscreen with a gun drawn. The Jeep then lurches a few feet farther off the road and into a ditch, knocking over the stop sign as it begins listing; two more gunshots can be heard.\n\nIn a statement on Wednesday, lawyers for the Ghaisar family called the video \u201cdisturbing\u201d and said it showed a \u201csenseless killing.\u201d\n\nThe lawyers, Roy L. Austin Jr. and Thomas Connolly, also said the family was grateful to Chief Roessler \u201cfor all he has done to ensure the appropriate amount of transparency throughout this process.\u201d\n\n\u201cBijan Ghaisar was repeatedly threatened by over-aggressive and out-of-control law enforcement officers, after he drove away from a minor traffic incident in which he was the victim and in which there was little property damage and no known injuries,\u201d the lawyers said in the statement.\n\nMr. Ghaisar was a college graduate who had been working as an accountant, Mr. Austin said in a phone interview on Wednesday night.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAsked to explain why Mr. Ghaisar had repeatedly fled when police officers attempted to stop him, Mr. Austin said that \u201chis behavior is what a lot of people would do when they feel like they\u2019re threatened.\u201d\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s fair to say he was finding a more populated, better-lit space to go to based on the behavior of the officers,\u201d he said.\n\nAlthough the F.B.I. is leading the inquiry, Robert D. MacLean, the chief of the United States Park Police, said in a statement that he recognized that there is a \u201cdesire for more information and details\u201d about it.\n\nThe statement said the chief had met with the Ghaisar family in the days after the shooting and pledged a fair and impartial investigation.\n\nThe Park Police did not appear to have released any identifying information about the officers involved in the shooting. They remain on administrative leave, a Park Police sergeant told The Washington Post.\n\n\u201cPublic and community trust remain paramount to our agency and profession,\u201d Chief MacLean said in the statement.\n\nIn an email late Wednesday, a spokeswoman for the F.B.I.\u2019s Washington field office said the agency was unable to provide additional information because the investigation was continuing.", "title": "Video Shows U.S. Park Police Firing 9 Times in Fatal Shooting of Driver", "authors": ["Matt Stevens"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHONG KONG \u2014 The United States plans to send an aircraft carrier to dock in Vietnam, officials from both nations said on Thursday, a telling sign of Washington\u2019s warming relations with a country that was once battered by American bombs.\n\nThe proposed visit to the port of Danang comes amid heightened tensions over China\u2019s territorial claims in the South China Sea, including to islands claimed by Vietnam. The Defense Ministry of Vietnam announced the port call while the American defense secretary, Jim Mattis, was in Hanoi.\n\nDanang was where the first conventional American combat unit was deployed in the Vietnam War, landing on a beach there in 1965. Hundreds of thousands more troops were to follow.\n\nThe arrival of the aircraft carrier, planned for March, would represent the largest presence of United States forces in Vietnam since the war ended in 1975. Smaller Navy ships have visited Vietnam as the two countries\u2019 relationship has improved.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWord of the carrier\u2019s visit comes about a week before the 50th anniversary of the Tet offensive, the military campaign by North Vietnamese and Viet Cong forces that punctured American hopes of winning the war.", "title": "U.S. Plans to Send First Aircraft Carrier to Vietnam Since War\u2019s End", "authors": ["Gerry Mullany"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "The timing of the move has caused tensions between Mr. Tillerson and the White House. Mr. Friedman, who worked as a lawyer for Mr. Trump, pushed to move the embassy this year, and Mr. Trump\u2019s son-in-law and senior adviser, Jared Kushner, who oversees the president\u2019s Middle East peace initiative, backed him.\n\nBut Mr. Tillerson petitioned Mr. Trump in a meeting on Thursday for more time to upgrade the security of the building, and the president agreed. \u201cWhat you\u2019ll see from the secretary is that we will do this at the pace of security, not at the pace of politics,\u201d said the under secretary of state for public diplomacy and public affairs, Steven Goldstein.\n\nThe Arnona building sits near the Green Line, which served as the de facto border of the state of Israel from 1949 until the Arab-Israeli War of 1967. While the building, which now issues visas and offers consular services to American citizens, would need to be retrofitted for the ambassador to conduct classified operations, it is a fairly new structure with better physical security than the embassy in Tel Aviv.\n\nThe timetable for moving the embassy became a charged footnote to Mr. Trump\u2019s landmark decision. When the president signed a proclamation in December recognizing Jerusalem as the capital, he quietly signed another document waiving a congressional demand that the United States move the embassy to Jerusalem within six months.\n\nAt the time, White House officials said practical and logistical considerations drove the decision. The State Department, they said, could not open a functioning embassy in Jerusalem on the timetable stipulated under a 1995 law that requires the president to sign a national security waiver every six months to keep the embassy in Tel Aviv.\n\nScouting a site, commissioning a design and building the embassy compound could take up to six years, according to State Department officials, and cost $600 million to $1 billion.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLegal experts, however, said nothing in the 1995 law would prevent the United States from hanging a placard outside the existing consulate in Jerusalem and calling it the embassy.\n\nAfter the fall of the Soviet Union, the United States hastily set up embassies in temporary quarters in the capitals of newly independent republics. American ambassadors have sometimes shuttled between offices in countries like Myanmar, which built new capital cities.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut putting off the move also had diplomatic advantages for a White House eager to keep alive the peace process between Israel and the Palestinians. It avoided creating a tangible symbol of Mr. Trump\u2019s new policy and spared the White House a series of decisions \u2014 like where in the city to place the embassy \u2014 that would begin to define the geography of the president\u2019s deliberately general statement about Jerusalem.\n\nSince Mr. Trump\u2019s announcement, however, relations between the United States and the Palestinians have curdled. The Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, vowed never again to take part in peace negotiations brokered by the United States. In a recent speech to Palestinian officials, he said of Mr. Trump, \u201cMay your house be destroyed.\u201d\n\nThe administration, in turn, said it would withhold $65 million \u2014 or more than half the funding that the United States generally provides \u2014 to a United Nations agency that aids Palestinian refugees.\n\nThe decision was a rebuke to the United Nations, whose members voted by a lopsided margin last month to condemn the United States for its Jerusalem decision. It also reflected the view of some in the White House that the organization, the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, needed to be overhauled and was impeding, rather than aiding, the peace process.\n\nMoving the embassy quickly, officials said, could also be a political boon for Mr. Trump in a midterm election year, given the popularity of his decision to recognize Jerusalem with evangelical voters and hard-line pro-Israel Americans like the casino magnate Sheldon G. Adelson.\n\nMr. Trump, a former property developer, has taken a personal interest in the location and cost of embassies. This month, he said on Twitter that he had canceled a planned visit to London out of pique that the Obama administration had sold \u201cthe best located and finest embassy in London for \u2018peanuts,\u2019 only to build a new one in an off location for 1.2 billion dollars.\u201d\n\nThe George W. Bush administration made the decision to close the embassy at Grosvenor Square in Mayfair and build a new tower south of the Thames River, at a cost of more than $1 billion.\n\nIn an interview with Reuters, Mr. Trump said of the Jerusalem embassy: \u201cWe\u2019re looking at doing a beautiful embassy, but not one that costs $1.2 billion. You know what that means, you know what I mean by that?\u201d", "title": "U.S. Presses to Relocate Embassy to Jerusalem by 2019", "authors": ["Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "The Trump administration imposed sanctions Friday on four Venezuelan officials, accusing them of engaging in political repression and public corruption as part of President Nicol\u00e1s Maduro\u2019s government.\n\nOne official, a sitting governor, had served as head of the food ministry, which has been blamed for mismanaging a program critical in a nation where children have died of hunger. Another, a former governor, was said to have empowered armed gangs in Bol\u00edvar State.\n\n\u201cPresident Maduro and his inner circle continue to put their own interests above those of the Venezuelan people,\u201d Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said in a statement. \u201cThis action underscores the United States\u2019 resolve to hold Maduro and others engaged in corruption in Venezuela accountable.\u201d\n\nIn announcing the sanctions, the Treasury Department criticized Venezuela\u2019s all-powerful National Constituent Assembly \u2014 which the United States considers \u201cillegitimate\u201d \u2014 for effectively stripping the three biggest opposition parties of their ability to participate in the next presidential election, which is supposed to take place this year. The assembly has decreed that only parties that took part in the previous election will be eligible.", "title": "U.S. Sanctions Four More Venezuela Officials", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "On this day in 1968, the Pueblo, a lightly armed Navy intelligence ship, was attacked and seized by North Korean patrol boats. Its crew of 83 servicemen was taken to Pyongyang and charged as spies. Washington denounced the seizure, but could do little: It soon became a tense Cold War standoff.\n\nA Times editorial called the attack \u201chumiliating,\u201d and a prisoner drama \u2014 marked by fraught negotiations, forced confessions and propaganda ploys \u2014 dragged on for 11 months. Here\u2019s more about the Pueblo incident.\n\nThe Americans told of beatings, torture and deprivation, but they still found ways to get back at their captors. They slipped outrageous puns into self-written confessions, such as this one by the ship\u2019s commander, and surreptitiously raised their middle fingers in films and photographs. (The sailors said it was the Hawaiian good luck salute.)\n\nIn the end, Washington reluctantly apologized, and the Pueblo crew was home in time for Christmas. The Pueblo itself is still in Pyongyang, where it\u2019s a tourist attraction at the Victorious War Museum.\n\nCharles McDermid contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nThis briefing was prepared for the European morning and is updated online. The Pentagon did not indicate whether the episode involved the Taliban or members of the Islamic State, but both groups have been active in the area.\n\n\u201cWe are deeply saddened by the loss of one of our own,\u201d Gen. John W. Nicholson Jr., the commander of the Afghanistan war effort, said in a statement. \u201cAt this very difficult time, our heartfelt sympathies go out to the families and friends of our fallen and wounded brothers.\u201d\n\nDefense Department officials said they would have more information after they have notified family members.", "title": "U.S. Service Member Is Killed in Afghan Province", "authors": ["Helene Cooper"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "The solar panel case in particular has been a case study in the complexity of global trade. Suniva, one of the American solar companies that had sought the tariffs, filed for bankruptcy protection last year, citing the effects of Chinese imports. But the majority owner of Suniva is itself Chinese, and the company\u2019s American bankruptcy trustee supported the trade litigation over the objections of the Chinese owners.\n\nHere is a rundown of the wide-ranging impact the new tariffs may have.\n\nWill there be a backlash?\n\nPossibly \u2014 but not without costs for all the countries involved.\n\nChina and South Korea could take their complaints to the World Trade Organization, which arbitrates international trade disputes.\n\nIf the W.T.O. sided with those countries, the United States would be under considerable pressure to back down. If it did not, there would be two major sets of consequences. For one, the World Trade Organization could greenlight other countries\u2019 setting similar trade limits. More broadly, it would raise the question of whether the United States accepts the organization\u2019s decisions \u2014 Robert E. Lighthizer, the United States trade representative, has argued for years that such decisions should, essentially, be advisory.\n\nThe United States market has long been very attractive to foreign companies, and not just for its large and affluent set of consumers. Its tariffs on imports are much lower than those of most other countries, and it also has relatively low sales taxes. But President Trump has regularly questioned whether existing free trade agreements are in the best interests of the country, making it possible that such favorable terms may erode.", "title": "U.S. Tariffs, Aimed at China and South Korea, to Hit Targets Worldwide", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 An American interceptor missile missed its target in a test off the Hawaiian coast on Wednesday, Defense Department officials said, renewing concerns of how the United States will defend itself in the event of a missile attack by North Korea or another adversary.\n\nA Pentagon official said that the interceptor, an SM-3 Block IIA missile that is being developed by the Raytheon Company, was launched from a test site in Hawaii. Officials likened the test launch to an attempt to hit a bullet with another bullet.\n\nIt was the second failure over the past year of a test of the SM-3, known as the standard missile; the last one was in June.\n\nMark Wright, a spokesman for the Missile Defense Agency, confirmed \u201ca live-fire missile flight test\u201d from Kauai. He did not confirm that the test had failed.", "title": "U.S. Test of Missile Interceptor Fails Off Hawaiian Coast, Officials Say", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "The Norwegian Refugee Council, which works in more than 30 countries, urged the Trump administration to reconsider, saying that the funding reduction will have \u201cdevastating consequences for vulnerable Palestinian refugees across the Middle East.\u201d\n\nAt the United Nations, Secretary General Ant\u00f3nio Guterres said he was \u201cvery concerned\u201d about any cuts to the agency.\n\nHe said the relief agency\u2019s services were of \u201cextreme importance\u201d to the populations of Palestinians who had lived as refugees for 70 years. Mr. Guterres said that was not only his opinion but \u201can opinion that is shared by most international observers, including some Israeli ones.\u201d\n\nMany Israelis worry that any rapid reduction in such aid could destabilize the region and force Israel to pick up a larger share of the costs. Jordan, where many Palestinians have settled, is also coping with a huge influx of Syrian refugees.\n\n\u201cThat the Trump administration is using humanitarian aid for schools and hospitals as a cudgel to punish those who disagree with their policy decisions is deeply troubling,\u201d said Jeremy Ben-Ami, president of J Street, a Washington-based liberal advocacy group for peace in the region.\n\nRobert B. Satloff, executive director of the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, said he was \u201cnot a fan of massive cuts\u201d to funding for the relief agency, saying he would prefer other solutions, such as changes to how Palestinians become eligible for refugee status.\n\nUnited Nations funding for Palestinian refugees grows in part out of a longtime assumption that a Palestinian state would eventually be created. Relief Agency for Palestinians", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "American officials said that there were no Afghan refugee camps in Kurram, a remote tribal region straddling the border with Afghanistan, where they said Wednesday\u2019s drone strike had taken place. The strike, which killed Nasir Mehmood, a commander of the Taliban-affiliated Haqqani network, was at least the third American drone strike in the past two months in Pakistani territory.\n\nThe United Nations refugee agency also said it had not been operating in the tribal regions of Pakistan since 2005. \u201cWe don\u2019t have any access to FATA,\u201d Qaisar Khan Afridi, the agency\u2019s spokesman said, referring to the semiautonomous tribal regions.\n\nBut Pakistani officials maintain that there are 43 Afghan refugee settlements in Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa Province, and that some of the settlements overlap with the adjoining tribal regions.\n\nThe Pakistani military said in a statement that the drone strike had singled out a house in one such settlement in the province\u2019s Hangu District, and that Afghan refugees were present in the settlement. The settlement was not an \u201corganized terrorist sanctuary,\u201d it said.\n\nA Pakistani security official, speaking on the condition of anonymity as he was not authorized to speak to the news media, said that the confusion about the location had arisen as the targeted house was in a settlement at the junction of the Kurram, North Waziristan and Hangu regions.", "title": "U.S. and Pakistan Give Conflicting Accounts of Drone Strike", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "With South Korea, the White House\u2019s overarching goal for renegotiating the trade pact is to reduce America\u2019s trade deficit, which was $17 billion in 2016. But analysts view such a goal with skepticism, saying that the tendency of the United States to import more than it exports is linked to larger economic factors like saving and spending rates, not the terms of trade agreements.\n\nEach side was likely to look to the other on Friday to articulate their goals for the renegotiation, said Wendy Cutler, the former chief United States negotiator for the deal. The United States will probably focus on areas of the agreement that it believes have not met its expectations, Ms. Cutler said, including trade in automobiles and, potentially, financial services and procedures related to importing goods.\n\nShe noted that the Trump administration had not notified Congress of its intention to renegotiate the agreement, something that is required before substantial changes are made. That may suggest that the United States is not seeking to significantly alter the terms of the deal or that, although it is seeking changes from South Korea, it is not willing to make big concessions itself.\n\nThe United States Korea Free Trade Agreement, America\u2019s largest trade pact after the North American Free Trade Agreement, was negotiated during the President George W. Bush\u2019s administration and signed by the two countries in 2007. It set off enormous protests from Koreans in 2008 over concerns about the safety of imported goods, such as beef. And it was not ratified by Congress until 2011, after President Barack Obama reworked the pact.\n\nThe agreement took effect in March 2012, cutting almost all tariffs and many other trade barriers between the countries. The deal opened South Korea, now the United States\u2019 seventh-largest export market for goods, to imports of American agriculture, services and investment, and the American market to Korean cars and other manufactured goods like washing machines.\n\nTrade officials estimated in 2007 that the lower barriers to trade under the agreement would increase annual exports of American goods by up to $11 billion, a claim that Mr. Obama repeated.\n\nBut, as the Trump administration has argued, that did not happen.\n\n\u201cSince KORUS went into effect, our trade deficit in goods with Korea has doubled from $13.2 billion to $27.6 billion, while U.S. goods exports have actually gone down,\u201d Mr. Lighthizer, said in a statement in July. \u201cThis is quite different from what the previous administration sold to the American people when it urged approval of this agreement. We can and must do better.\u201d\n\nMuch of the American trade deficit in goods with Korea is generated by automobiles, a key reason cars will probably be a primary focus of the talks. Korean car brands like Hyundai and Kia are popular in the United States, but American carmakers have struggled to gain as much ground in South Korea as their European and Asian competitors.", "title": "U.S. and South Korea Start Trade Talks Amid Rising Tensions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Secretary of State Rex W. In 2001, it was designated as the national training center for United States women\u2019s gymnastics, and, in 2011, it was named an Olympic training site.\n\nThe center played a crucial role in the building of American women into an international power that rivaled Russia, Romania and China. American gymnasts have won the gold medal in the women\u2019s individual all-around competition at the last four Summer Olympics, and combined for gold in the women\u2019s team all-around competition in 2012 and 2016.\n\nElite athletes met for monthly camps at the ranch, which was equipped with a gymnastics center, medical facility, dining and lodging facilities, but was secluded and had unreliable cellphone service. Also, families were not invited.\n\nIn such an out-of-the-way environment, Ms. Raisman told Time magazine in November, Dr. Nassar became a seeming ally, giving the gymnasts gifts and sweets. \u201cHe was always that person who would stick up for me and make me feel like he had my back,\u201d Ms. Raisman told Time. \u201cThe more I think about it, the more I realize how twisted he was, how he manipulated me to make me think that he had my back when he didn\u2019t.\u201d\n\nThe ranch is owned by Bela and Martha Karolyi, the coaching couple who defected from Romania and became the guiding force of U.S.A. Gymnastics. They have not been accused of being directly involved with Dr. Nassar\u2019s criminal behavior, but some gymnasts who trained there have claimed that the atmosphere created by the Karolyis at the ranch enabled Dr. Nassar to get away with mistreating them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Karolyis have said that they are not at fault.", "title": "U.S.A. The confidential $1.25 million settlement the organization struck with McKayla Maroney required her to remain silent. It wasn\u2019t until the model Chrissy Teigen offered to pay the $100,000 fine Ms. Maroney could be subject to for violating a nondisclosure agreement that U.S.A. Gymnastics said it would not seek money from her if she chose to give a victim impact statement.\n\nIn the meantime, all efforts were made to look out for Steve Penny. Starting next week, it will let certain users in San Francisco reserve pedal-assist electric bicycles through its app. The idea is that people will see the bicycles as a cheaper and faster alternative \u2014 not a huge stretch of the imagination for anyone who has been stuck in Friday evening gridlock traffic in San Francisco.\n\nUber is not supplying its own bicycles. It is working with Jump Bikes, a bike-sharing service that secured a permit in January to put 250 motorized bicycles \u2014 making it easier to tackle San Francisco\u2019s steep hills \u2014 in locations throughout the city.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re excited about the future of bike sharing in the Uber app, and this is the first step,\u201d said Andrew Salzberg, Uber\u2019s head of transportation policy and research.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe pilot program is the latest indication of Uber\u2019s ambitions to move beyond its ride-hailing origins. It is also working on autonomous trucking services, while aggressively expanding into the food delivery market with Uber Eats.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUber said it saw the bicycles as yet another option for riders \u2014 alongside car-pooling and rides on the less expensive Uber X or the pricier Uber Black. The company declined to detail whether the San Francisco test was a prelude to a bike-sharing service in other locations.", "title": "Uber\u2019s New Training Wheels: Testing Bike Sharing in San Francisco", "authors": ["Daisuke Wakabayashi"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Ukraine was once a vital part of the Soviet space program, home to many research institutes and rocket factories. Now, wracked by war and shaken by political upheaval, the nation struggles to hold on to its scientific traditions. On a recent visit, I was struck by the determination of researchers stripped of the resources taken for granted in the West. The biologist still tending a jar filled with bacteria once destined for space. The retiree holding together a small astronomy museum in Kiev with spare parts and pluck.\n\nFrom black garbage bags and duct tape, Tatiana Kovalchuk-Skorokhodnik, of the Ukrainian Space Agency, has built a mobile \u201cplanetarium\u201d for children. With holes pricked in the makeshift dome, she has reconstructed the starry night skies above Ukraine.", "title": "Ukraine\u2019s Lofty Ambitions, Fallen to Earth", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Wegener, who at that time was a federal police liaison officer for the German interior ministry, was subsequently assigned to create and lead what became GSG-9, working with Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the West German interior minister. The Germans received help and training from Britain, Israel and the United States, among the few countries at the time with specialized counterterrorism units.\n\nImage Mr. Wegener in 2012. Credit Target Presse Agentur Gmbh, via Getty Images\n\nDuring the Lufthansa hijacking, Mr. Wegener was flown to Dubai, where he requested and was granted permission from the government to storm the aircraft with his commandos. But senior operatives insisted on additional combat exercise and dry runs on an adjacent airstrip, and while they were carrying out that training, the plane took off for Yemen. There, the militants executed the pilot; they then forced the co-pilot to fly the jetliner to Somalia.\n\nAs the West German chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, held discussions with Somalia\u2019s president, Mohammed Siad Barre, Colonel Wegener\u2019s commandos quietly flew to Mogadishu, under the direction of Hans-J\u00fcrgen Wischnewski, the minister designated to deal with the crisis. The militants were falsely told that their comrades had been released.\n\nAround 2 a.m. on Oct. 18, Somali soldiers lit a fire 65 yards in front of the jet, creating a diversion. As the hostage takers entered the cockpit to see what was going on, Colonel Wegener and his commandos stormed the aircraft. Over the next seven minutes, three militants were killed and the fourth was wounded. Three passengers, a flight attendant and a commando were injured. But all 86 passengers, along with the four surviving crew members, were saved.\n\nLater that night, three members of the Red Army Faction \u2014 Gudrun Ensslin, Jan-Carl Raspe and Andreas Baader \u2014 were found dead in their cells, having committed suicide, and Mr. Schleyer, the abducted executive, was murdered.\n\nMr. Schmidt later said that he would have resigned if the operation had failed.\n\nMr. Wegener continued to command GSG-9 until 1979. He stayed within the Federal Police, rising to the rank of brigadier general, before he left in 1988 to train special forces in Saudi Arabia.\n\nIn an autobiography, \u201cUlrich Wegener, GSG-9: Stronger Than Terror,\u201d Mr. Wegener wrote that he came from a family steeped in the Prussian military tradition. He was born on Aug. 22, 1929, in the village of J\u00fcterborg in the eastern state of Brandenburg, the son of an Army officer.\n\nHe was conscripted as a teenager into the Battle of Berlin, which fell to the Soviets in 1945, ending the Nazi regime and Germany\u2019s involvement in World War II. Briefly held by American troops as a prisoner of war, he returned home, to what became East Germany, to finish his schooling.", "title": "Ulrich Wegener, German Commando Who Ended 1977 Hijacking, Is Dead", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "On Monday, the House Ethics Committee announced that it had started an investigation into the aide\u2019s accusations and the possibility that Mr. Meehan had \u201cmisused official resources\u201d by using funds from his congressional office to settle her complaint.\n\nThe House speaker, Paul D. Ryan, said that Mr. Meehan should repay the amount of the settlement and removed him from the Ethics Committee, where Mr. Meehan had taken a leading role in fighting sexual harassment in Congress.\n\nMr. Meehan expressed confidence that he would be cleared, declaring, \u201cI didn\u2019t do anything wrong.\u201d\n\nHe declined to specify the amount of the payment to his former aide, and also disputed that it was a settlement, instead calling it \u201ca severance agreement with a valued employee who I felt a great deal of not only respect for, but concern for, and believed that that was a way to reward the work that she had done for me.\u201d\n\nBut John Elizandro, Mr. Meehan\u2019s spokesman, called the payment a \u201csettlement\u201d and said that Mr. Meehan \u201cis prepared to repay the taxpayers for the amount of the settlement,\u201d but only \u201cif found to be guilty\u201d of the allegations by the House Ethics Committee.\n\nThe disclosure of the complaint against Mr. Meehan comes amid a national conversation about gender dynamics in the workplace, and about the inadequacy of support systems for victims of sexual harassment. Mr. Meehan\u2019s case sheds light on the arcane and secretive process for handling harassment complaints in Congress, which advocates say favors abusers, allowing them to use the resources of the federal government to intimidate, isolate and silence their victims.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Gender Letter A weekly newsletter on women, gender and society. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Meehan said that the way he handled the case was consistent with House rules and done \u201cwith the advice of counsel from the government that suggested it was a way to explore a potential resolution.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe said it was his former aide who insisted on a confidentiality agreement, and reiterated a request she waive it to allow a full airing of the facts.\n\nAlexis Ronickher, a lawyer for the woman, whom The Times is not naming, said it was Mr. Meehan who was flouting the agreement. She said her client\u2019s privacy \u201cis important to her, so she is not willing to discuss the fact of this case in the media,\u201d but added that she intends \u201cto fully cooperate\u201d with the House Ethics Committee\u2019s investigation.\n\nBefore news of his settlement, Mr. Meehan already faced an uphill battle in a suburban Philadelphia district that is among the most severely gerrymandered in the country and that Hillary Clinton narrowly carried in the 2016 presidential election.\n\nRepublicans in the state have mostly taken a wait-and-see approach to Mr. Meehan\u2019s troubles. Val DiGiorgio, the chairman of the Pennsylvania Republican Party, issued a statement on Monday saying that the party was \u201ctroubled\u201d by the allegations and that they \u201cmust be treated seriously and fully investigated.\u201d\n\nIn an interview with The Philadelphia Inquirer earlier Tuesday, Mr. Meehan said he told the aide that last year he \u201cwas struggling\u201d to keep his feelings from interfering with his position as her superior, and told the newspaper that he had exchanged a hug with her that lasted \u201cmaybe longer that night than needed to be.\u201d\n\nMr. Meehan supplied the newspaper with a copy of the handwritten letter he wrote to the aide last May, after he said he reacted \u201cselfishly\u201d when he learned that she had a serious boyfriend close to her own age. In the letter, he told the woman that \u201cit is a very, very lucky man who might get to be your partner for more of your life.\u201d\n\nAccording to people close to the former aide who worked in the office, she was regarded as a calming force in a workplace where Mr. Meehan would often yell and put his staff on edge when displeased. \u201cYou go hardest on the ones that you care the most about,\u201d Mr. Meehan told The Inquirer.\n\nSome saw the former aide\u2019s influence in Mr. Meehan\u2019s decision to buck his party\u2019s leadership in May by voting against a Republican bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act. The bill went down in defeat, much to the chagrin of the Republican leadership and President Trump.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Meehan said in the letter, dated the evening the House voted to repeal and replace major parts of the law, that he had said \u201cno\u201d to the president and Mr. Ryan, and \u201cyes\u201d to her.\n\n\u201cAs I walked this evening and glanced over at the White House I smiled at the irony that on a day that I had to say \u2018no\u2019 to the President and to the Speaker of the House, I got to say \u2018yes\u2019 to you,\u201d Mr. Meehan wrote. \u201cI hope that the former will be judged as a vote of conscience and the latter as an expression of care.\u201d\n\nIn the interview with The Times, Mr. Meehan said he was trying to be supportive of her new relationship.\n\n\u201c\u2018Yes to you\u2019 was \u2018yes to this great relationship,\u2019\u201d Mr. Meehan said.", "title": "Under Fire for Harassment, Congressman Says Aide \u2018Invited\u2019 Behavior", "authors": ["Kenneth P. Vogel", "Katie Rogers"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Both authors emphasize that grief is not a problem to be solved or resolved. Rather, it\u2019s a process to be tended and lived through in whatever form and however long it may take.\n\n\u201cThe process cannot be hurried by friends and family,\u201d however well meaning their desire to relieve the griever\u2019s anguish, Ms. Samuel wrote. \u201cRecovery and adjustment can take much longer than most people realize. We need to accept whatever form it takes, both in ourselves and in others.\u201d\n\nWe can all benefit from learning how to respond to grief in ways that don\u2019t prolong, intensify or dismiss the pain. Likewise, those trying to help need to know that grief cannot be fit into a preordained time frame or form of expression. Too often people who experience a loss are disparaged because their mourning persists longer than others think reasonable or because they remain self-contained and seem not to mourn at all.\n\nI imagine, for example, that some adults thought my stoical response to my mother\u2019s premature death when I was 16 was \u201cunnatural.\u201d In truth, after tending to her for a year as she suffered through an unstoppable cancer, her death was a relief. It took a year for me to shed my armor and openly mourn the incalculable loss. But 60 years later, I still treasure her most important legacy: To live each day as if it could be my last but with an eye on the future in case it\u2019s not.\n\nLikewise, I was relieved when my husband\u2019s suffering ended six weeks after diagnosis of an incurable cancer. Though I missed him terribly, I seemed to go on with my life as if little had changed. Few outside of the immediate family knew that I was honoring his dying wish that I continue to live fully for my own sake and that of our children and grandchildren.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJust as we all love others in our own unique ways, so do we mourn their loss in ways that cannot be fit into a single mold or even a dozen different molds. Last month, James G. Robinson, director of global analytics for The New York Times, described a 37-day, 6,150-mile therapeutic road trip he took with his family following the death of his 5-year-old son, collecting commemorative objects along the way and giving each member of the family a chance to express anger and sadness about the untimely loss.\n\nMs. Devine maintains that most grief support offered by professionals and others takes the wrong approach by encouraging mourners to move through the pain. While family and friends naturally want you to feel better, \u201cpain that is not allowed to be spoken or expressed turns in on itself, and creates more problems,\u201d she wrote. \u201cUnacknowledged and unheard pain doesn\u2019t go away. The way to survive grief is by allowing pain to exist, not in trying to cover it up or rush through it.\u201d\n\nAs a bereaved mother told Ms. Samuel, \u201cYou never \u2018get over it,\u2019 you \u2018get on with it,\u2019 and you never \u2018move on,\u2019 but you \u2018move forward.\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Devine agrees that being \u201cencouraged to \u2018get over it\u2019 is one of the biggest causes of suffering inside grief.\u201d Rather than trying to \u201ccure\u201d pain, the goal should be to minimize suffering, which she said \u201ccomes when we feel dismissed or unsupported in our pain, with being told there is something wrong with what you feel.\u201d\n\nShe explains that pain cannot be \u201cfixed,\u201d that companionship, not correction, is the best way to deal with grief. She encourages those who want to be helpful to \u201cbear witness,\u201d to offer friendship without probing questions or unsolicited advice, help if it is needed and wanted, and a listening ear no matter how often mourners wish to tell their story.\n\nTo those who grieve, she suggests finding a nondestructive way to express it. \u201cIf you can\u2019t tell your story to another human, find another way: journal, paint, make your grief into a graphic novel with a very dark story line. Or go out to the woods and tell the trees. It is an immense relief to be able to tell your story without someone trying to fix it.\u201d\n\nShe also suggests keeping a journal that records situations that either intensify or relieve suffering. \u201cAre there times you feel more stable, more grounded, more able to breathe inside your loss? Does anything \u2014 a person, a place, an activity \u2014 add to your energy bank account? Conversely, are there activities or environments that absolutely make things worse?\u201d\n\nWhenever possible, to decrease suffering choose to engage in things that help and avoid those that don\u2019t.", "title": "Understanding Grief", "authors": ["Jane E. Brody", "Personal Health"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trumka said the president had been generous with access to the Oval Office and administration officials, and he described Mr. Trump as \u201ccharming person to person.\u201d One meeting scheduled to last 30 minutes went on for nearly three hours, he said.\n\nBut those meetings, and the president\u2019s affability, failed to yield results, Mr. Trumka said: \u201cAccess isn\u2019t the problem. Impact is the question. Is the access having any impact? So far I would say we haven\u2019t done real well.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cWe have a president who is on all sides and no side.\u201d\n\nOn specific issues, Mr. Trumka criticized Mr. Trump for failing to \u201clabel China as a currency manipulator\u201d and said the president had rejected plans to \u201crevitalize our coal communities.\u201d\n\n\u201cAnd despite calling himself a \u2018builder president,\u2019\u201d Mr. Trumka continued, \u201che\u2019s done nothing to invest in America\u2019s infrastructure.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe promised a trillion and we\u2019ve seen nothing so far,\u201d Mr. Trumka said of the president\u2019s pledge to deliver an enormous program to rebuild the nation\u2019s crumbling roads, bridges and other infrastructure.\n\n\u201cHe tells whoppers all the time and denies the obvious truth,\u201d Mr. Trumka said.\n\nMr. Trumka said his union would participate aggressively in the midterm elections, backing candidates who supported its agenda in what he labeled \u201cTier 1\u201d states like Pennsylvania, Ohio and Michigan, and in Florida, Illinois, Missouri, New Mexico and Arizona. Labor unions will also target another dozen states.\n\nHistorically, labor has aligned strongly with the Democratic Party, but Mr. Trump\u2019s election showed that many in the rank and file were open to a Republican candidate. Mr. Trumka said union members were willing to vote for Mr. Trump because they felt establishment candidates in both parties had failed them, and they were ready to give the first-time politician \u201ca chance.\u201d", "title": "Union Chief Says Trump, Having \u2018Actively Hurt\u2019 Workers, Is Losing Support", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "The organizing effort was galvanized in part by an abrupt change to employees\u2019 vacation policy in 2016 that effectively eliminated accrued vacation days. Organizers called for more competitive salaries, annual raises, equal pay for women and minorities and lower health premiums, among other goals.\n\nThe next step for the union will be to negotiate a collective bargaining agreement with management.\n\n\u201cWe respect the outcome of the election and look forward to productive conversations with union leadership as we move forward,\u201d Tronc said in a statement. \u201cWe remain committed to ensuring that The Los Angeles Times is a leading source for news and information and to producing the award-winning journalism our readers rely on.\u201d\n\nThe result was announced the day after the publication of a report by National Public Radio that Mr. Levinsohn had twice been a defendant in sexual harassment lawsuits while employed by other companies. After the article was published, the committee organizing the unionization effort called for Mr. Levinsohn to resign or be fired.\n\n\u201cIt is critical that in any such circumstances we conduct a thorough review so that we have a full understanding of what happened,\u201d Justin Dearborn, the chief executive of Tronc, said in the newsroom email announcing Mr. Levinsohn\u2019s leave. \u201cWe will not hesitate to take further action, if appropriate, once the review is complete.\u201d\n\nMr. Dearborn said that Mickie Rosen, the president of The Times, would take over Mr. Levinsohn\u2019s duties during the investigation.\n\nThe NPR article about Mr. Levinsohn included allegations that he had used a derogatory term for gay men and rated the attractiveness of female colleagues. It also questioned whether he was fit to lead a newsroom in the time of #metoo protests and revealing media reports about sexual harassment.\n\nNPR reported that Mr. Levinsohn called the allegations against him \u201clies\u201d in a call to NPR\u2019s chief executive, Jarl Mohn. Tronc then said in a statement that the company was investigating the claims against Mr. Levinsohn \u201cso that we have a better understanding of what\u2019s occurred.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter the NPR article was posted online, members of the Los Angeles Times Guild organizing committee released a statement saying, in part, \u201cWe demand an independent investigation to examine how Levinsohn was hired given his documented history of misconduct; whether he acted inappropriately toward Times employees during his tenure as publisher; and how the company and board have responded previously to allegations of sexual misconduct by newspaper leaders.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe newsroom also responded with a letter to the board of Tronc. The letter, signed by more than 180 Times journalists, said in part, \u201cLevinsohn has lost credibility as the leader of one of the country\u2019s top newspapers.\u201d\n\nTimes journalists \u2014 who have withstood many years of management and ownership turmoil along with an industrywide downturn that has resulted in significant cost cuts and layoffs \u2014 have long professed dissatisfaction with their newsroom and corporate leaders.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTronc, which is based in Chicago, ousted several top newsroom leaders, including Davan Maharaj, the publisher and editor, in August.\n\nSome employees were optimistic that new leadership installed by Tronc, which publishes newspapers including The Chicago Tribune and The Baltimore Sun, would cultivate journalistic excellence while also returning The Times to financial strength.\n\nThe company appointed Mr. Levinsohn, a former Yahoo executive, as its publisher and named Lewis D\u2019Vorkin, formerly the chief product officer at Forbes, editor in chief.\n\nMany newsroom employees were frustrated with the way Mr. D\u2019Vorkin handled a dispute between The Times and the Walt Disney Company soon after his arrival \u2014 and the union drive did not help to soothe relations between the journalists and their bosses.\n\nIn the weeks leading up to the union vote, Times management distributed fliers and sent emails that warned of the risks of unionization. At the same time, union organizers handed out signs and published information online about the compensation and perks received by Tronc executives.\n\nJournalists at many of the country\u2019s prominent news publications, including The Wall Street Journal, The Washington Post, Reuters and The New York Times, are already represented by unions. The decision by Los Angeles Times workers comes amid a wave of organizing efforts that has swept through newsrooms at digital outlets, including Salon and Vox Media. Workers at several digital organizations, including HuffPost and Vice Media, are now union members.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut owners at other digital organizations have spoken against the need for their employees to form unions, including Jonah Peretti, Buzzfeed\u2019s founder. In October, employees of the New York news sites Gothamist and DNAinfo voted in favor of forming a union through a National Labor Relations Board formal vote. The websites\u2019 owner, Joe Ricketts, then closed both of them.\n\nKnown for years as the \u201ccitadel of the open shop,\u201d The Times, and the city it covered, has traditionally been against organized labor \u2014 a sentiment cultivated under Gen. Harrison Gray Otis, who acquired part ownership of the paper in 1884, and continued under his son-in-law, Harry Chandler.\n\n\u201cLos Angeles is the major city in America most resistant to the power of labor unions, not because it evolved naturally that way but because first Gen. Harrison Gray Otis and then Harry Chandler fought the unions in a constant ongoing struggle that was nothing short of war,\u201d David Halberstam wrote in his 1979 media tome \u201cThe Powers That Be.\u201d\n\nThe city, however, has become friendlier to unions in recent years.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a huge symbolic shift,\u201d said Ruth Milkman, a sociology professor at the CUNY Graduate Center, who has written about labor in Los Angeles. \u201cThe Times was literally the celebrated centerpiece of anti-unionism for such a long time. Turning that around is a big achievement.\u201d", "title": "Union Is Formed at Los Angeles Times and Publisher Put on Leave", "authors": ["Sydney Ember"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "For ordinary Iranians, the great promise of the 2015 nuclear deal was economic revival. International sanctions would be lifted, foreign investment would flow and the standard of living, crippled by years of ostracism by the United States and its partners, would rise, allowing Iran to once again flourish.\n\nThat hasn\u2019t happened, or at least not the way Iranians expected, thus producing conditions that helped make the recent protests \u2014 the most serious since 2009 \u2014 possible. Over two weeks, thousands of Iranians in more than 80 cities took to the streets to denounce high unemployment, inflation, corruption and the government\u2019s habit of spending money on foreign wars while cutting programs at home.\n\nAs the unrest unfolded, President Trump blamed the 2015 nuclear deal negotiated under President Barack Obama because it required the United States to put millions of dollars back into the hands of a repressive government \u2014 money that belonged to Iran but was frozen after the 1979 Islamic Revolution and returned when Iran curbed its nuclear program.\n\nIt\u2019s more plausible that by raising expectations for a better life, the deal opened Iranians\u2019 eyes and made them less tolerant when the government fell short.", "title": "Opinion | Unrest Shows the Iran Nuclear Deal\u2019s Value, Not Its Danger", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "While she remains unseeded here, she continues to get the star treatment: a spot on one of the tournament\u2019s main show courts on Tuesday and, more mysteriously, a starring role in the Australian Open\u2019s official broadcast of the draw last week, alongside Roger Federer.\n\nIt was a questionable gesture from tournament organizers toward a player who was suspended for a doping violation at their tournament, even if the Court of Arbitration for Sport did rule that Sharapova had not intentionally cheated.\n\nCraig Tiley, the Australian Open tournament director, said Sharapova, a former champion, \u201cdeserved the opportunity\u201d and indicated that the case had been adjudicated and that she had served out her sanction.\n\n\u201cI was invited to be part of the draw by Craig Tiley and the tournament organization, and I kindly accepted,\u201d Sharapova said on Tuesday, declining to comment on any criticism of her appearance.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut the Grand Slam leaders have not agreed on how to handle Sharapova. The French Tennis Federation president, Bernard Giudicelli, declined to offer her a wild card into the main draw or qualifying for last year\u2019s French Open, even though she had won two titles there.\n\nWimbledon was also considered unlikely to offer her a wild card, although the All England Club leadership that runs the event never had to make that decision because she withdrew from the entire grass-court season last year with an injury.\n\nWith her level of play and enduring competitive streak, it seems exceedingly likely that Sharapova will be seeded at major tournaments again soon \u2014 at least until the majors make their planned move to 16 seeds, instead of 32, in 2019.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSharapova was ferocious from the start on Tuesday, moving inside the baseline and striking the ball with relentless aggression against Maria, a 30-year-old German working mother who, with a world ranking of 47, is still one spot ahead of Sharapova.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThough Sharapova versus Maria sounds as if it could be self-defeating (and led to some pointing and smiling at the scoreboard on Tuesday), it was actually a contrast in styles: Sharapova\u2019s flat strokes against Maria\u2019s slice; Sharapova\u2019s two-handed backhand against Maria\u2019s one-hander; Sharapova\u2019s offense and swing volleys against Maria\u2019s defense, which often sent the latter scrambling into the shadows deep behind the court.\n\nMaria made Sharapova sweat, particularly in a tight second set, but the bigger challenges lie ahead. In the next round, she will face the crafty Anastasija Sevastova, who beat Sharapova at last year\u2019s U.S. Open.\n\n\u201cI missed a lot of swing volleys at the U.S. Open,\u201d Sharapova said of that loss to Sevastova. \u201cJust going back home, my father made me hit swing volleys till I was blue in the face. It\u2019s not an easy match, not an easy match for anyone, especially for an aggressive player like I am. You know, she\u2019s an opponent that tests my patience, and I\u2019m willing to be there and out there for as long as it takes.\u201d\n\nIf Sharapova survives that match, she will most likely face a revitalized Angelique Kerber in the third round. Kerber won the title here in 2016 and eventually rose to No. 1 before struggling through the 2017 season. But she is back on the rise under new management: her veteran coach Wim Fissette. And after winning the title in Sydney last week, she defeated Anna-Lena Friedsam, her German compatriot, 6-0, 6-4 in Melbourne on Tuesday.\n\n\u201cEvery draw is different and has its own challenges, and people are saying I have a tough draw,\u201d Sharapova said. \u201cThese are the players I want to be playing.\u201d\n\nAfter having watched from afar, playing, in her view, definitely beats the alternative.\n\n\u201cWhen I was a teenager I didn\u2019t think I would be playing past 30, definitely not, and here I am,\u201d she said. \u201cI think I might surprise myself on when I finish, and I don\u2019t know when that will be.\u201d", "title": "Unseeded Maria Sharapova Returns to Australian Open as a Star", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "UNIONDALE, N.Y. \u2014 The Islanders will be returning part-time to Nassau Coliseum for the next three seasons as their new arena at Belmont Park is being built.\n\nGov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced Monday that the Islanders would play about half of their games at their former home, splitting time with Barclays Center in Brooklyn. The Brooklyn arena, which the Isles share with the N.B.A.\u2019s Nets, has been an odd fit for hockey since the team began playing there after the 2014-15 season.\n\n\u201cWhen the Islanders left, it was sad,\u201d said Governor Cuomo, who grew up nearby in Queens. \u201cYou feel like you are losing part of who you are, your identity.
