For anyone who frequented the old PS122 \u2014 the site of rebellious experiments in dance, theater and hard-to-classify performance \u2014 the new, extensively renovated one may take some getting used to. There\u2019s an elevator. And a lobby. And a 3,600-square-foot theater that feels larger than the two old, grittier theaters combined, with soaring ceilings, flexible seating and windows overlooking Lower Manhattan. There\u2019s a brand-new smaller theater, too, that can double as an exhibition space.\n\nWith the updated home comes an updated name: Performance Space New York.\n\nJenny Schlenzka, Performance Space\u2019s artistic and executive director, said the organization had decided \u201cnothing would be too holy to be rethought.\u201d The new name, she added, \u201cis signaling an ambition to be relevant and accessible to all of New York.\u201d\n\nIt has been almost a year since Ms. Schlenzka, previously a curator of performance at the Museum of Modern Art and MoMA PS1, stepped into her current role. Like her predecessor, Vallejo Gantner, who organized interim programming at theaters and alternative spaces around the city, Ms. Schlenzka, 39, has had to navigate a state of limbo. She said the $37 million renovation \u2014 financed by the city\u2019s Department of Cultural Affairs to bring the 1894 building, formerly a public school, up to code \u2014 was expected to take two years. It has taken about three times as long.\n\nOn Wednesday, the revamped space will host its first show \u2014 \u201cvisions of beauty,\u201d by the choreographer Heather Kravas \u2014 as the final edition of the Coil festival gets underway. Coil, founded by Mr. Gantner in 2006, comprises mostly works that he commissioned; Ms. Schlenzka\u2019s first full season begins next month.", "title": "Unveiling Performance Space New York", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "An election victory by Mr. da Silva would be a dramatic return to power for him and his party two years after the impeachment of his prot\u00e9g\u00e9, Dilma Rousseff. Her removal elevated Mr. Temer, of the center-right Brazilian Democratic Movement party, to the presidency.\n\nFederal Judge S\u00e9rgio Moro, the most prominent figure in the judiciary\u2019s crackdown on political corruption, convicted Mr. da Silva in July on corruption and money laundering charges for accepting bribes from O.A.S., a major construction company, in the form of a seaside apartment that was being renovated to his liking. The judge sentenced Mr. da Silva to nearly a decade in prison, but ruled that he should remain free pending appeals.\n\nMr. da Silva has called the conviction a miscarriage of justice orchestrated by underhanded political actors within the judiciary.\n\n\u201cWe will continue to fight this political conviction,\u201d Cristiano Zanin Martins, Mr. da Silva\u2019s lawyer, said in a statement on Wednesday. \u201cAnd we will win this fight, not just for Lula but for all Brazilians who believe that the rule of law and democracy must prevail.\u201d\n\nMr. da Silva\u2019s supporters claim that he never lived in, or took ownership of, the renovated apartment at the heart of the case. They have cast doubt on the reliability of witnesses who implicated him, asserting that the witnesses testified in return for leniency in their own corruption cases.\n\nThey have also noted that politicians accused of more egregious wrongdoing \u2014 including President Temer, who was recorded appearing to condone the payment of a bribe \u2014 have so far dodged accountability.\n\nThe three-judge panel that considered Mr. da Silva\u2019s appeal included two jurists appointed by the former president\u2019s political ally, Ms. Rousseff: Jo\u00e3o Pedro Gebran Neto and Leandro Paulsen. The third judge, Victor Laus, was appointed by the former President Fernando Henrique Cardoso.", "title": "Upending Brazil\u2019s Presidential Race, Court Upholds Ex-Leader\u2019s Conviction", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Energy Fuels\u2019 lobbying campaign, elements of which were first reported by The Washington Post, is part of a wider effort by the long-ailing uranium industry to make a comeback.\n\nThe Uranium Producers of America, an industry group, is pushing the Environmental Protection Agency to withdraw regulations proposed by the Obama administration to strengthen groundwater protections at uranium mines. Mining groups have also waged a six-year legal battle against a moratorium on new uranium mining on more than a million acres of land adjacent to the Grand Canyon.\n\nFor the Navajo, the drive for new mines is a painful flashback.\n\n\u201cBack then, we didn\u2019t know it was dangerous \u2014 nobody told us,\u201d Mr. Holiday said, as he pointed to the gashes of discolored rocks that mark where the old uranium mines cut into the region\u2019s mesas. \u201cNow they know. They know.\u201d\n\nSupporters of the mining say that a revival of domestic uranium production, which has declined by 90 percent since 1980 amid slumping prices and foreign competition, will make the United States a larger player in the global uranium market.\n\nIt would expand the country\u2019s energy independence, they say, and give a lift to nuclear power, still a pillar of carbon-free power generation. Canada, Kazakhstan, Australia, Russia and a few other countries now supply most of America\u2019s nuclear fuel.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Climate Fwd: Sign up for our newsletter to get our latest stories about climate change \u2014 along with answers to your questions and tips on how to help. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe dwindling domestic market was thrust into the spotlight by the contentious 2010 decision under the Obama administration that allowed Russia\u2019s nuclear agency to buy Uranium One, a company that has amassed production facilities in the United States. The Justice Department is examining allegations that donations to the Clinton Foundation were tied to that decision.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf we consider nuclear a clean energy, if people are serious about that, domestic uranium has to be in the equation,\u201d said Jon J. Indall, a lawyer for Uranium Producers of America. \u201cBut the proposed regulations would have had a devastating impact on our industry.\u201d\n\n\u201cCountries like Kazakhstan, they\u2019re not under the same environmental standards. We want a level playing field.\u201d\n\nScaling back a monument\n\nPhoto\n\nThe trip was one of the earliest made by Mr. Zinke to the vast lands he oversees as secretary of the interior: a visit to Bears Ears, where he struck a commanding figure, touring the rugged terrain on horseback.\n\nA notable presence on Mr. Zinke\u2019s trip was Energy Fuels, the Canadian uranium producer. Company executives openly lobbied for shrinking Bears Ears\u2019 borders, handing out the map that marked the pockets the company wanted removed: areas adjacent to its White Mesa Mill, just to the east of the monument, and its Daneros Mine, which it is developing just to the west.\n\n\u201cThey wanted to talk to anyone who\u2019d listen,\u201d said Commissioner Phil Lyman of San Juan County, Utah, a Republican who participated in the tour and is sympathetic to Energy Fuels\u2019 position. \u201cThey were there representing their business interest.\u201d\n\nMr. Zinke has insisted that mining played no role in the decision to shrink Bears Ears, and a department spokeswoman said he had met with interested parties on all sides.\n\nBut President Trump has prioritized scrapping environmental regulations to help revitalize domestic energy production. His executive order instructing Mr. Zinke to review Bears Ears said that improper monument designations could \u201ccreate barriers to achieving energy independence.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn theory, even after President Barack Obama established Bears Ears in 2016, mining companies could have developed any of the claims within it, given proper local approvals. But companies say that expanding the sites, or even building roads to access them, would have required special permits, driving up costs.\n\n20 miles Utah Colorado R. New boundaries, effective Feb. 2, 2018 191 Current boundaries Bears Ears National Monument Blanding Daneros Mine White Mesa Mill 276 261 491 San Juan R. Monument Valley 160 Arizona 163 70 Utah San juan County 15 Arizona Navajo Nation Canyon Mine Grand Canyon National Park 40 Sanders\n\nEnergy Fuels said it had sold its Bears Ears claims to a smaller company, Encore Energy, in 2016. But Encore issued shares to Energy Fuels in return, making Energy Fuels Encore\u2019s largest shareholder, with a seat on its board.\n\nCurtis Moore, an Energy Fuels spokesman, said the company had played only a small part in the decision to shrink Bears Ears. The company proposed scaling back the monument by just 2.5 percent, he said, and was prepared to support a ban within the rest of the original boundaries.\n\nYet two weeks after Mr. Zinke\u2019s visit, Energy Fuels wrote to the Interior Department arguing there were many other known uranium deposits within Bears Ears \u201cthat could provide valuable energy and mineral resources in the future\u201d and urging the department to shrink the monument away from any \u201cexisting or future operations.\u201d\n\nA bill introduced last month by Representative John Curtis, Republican of Utah, would codify Mr. Trump\u2019s cuts to the monument while banning further drilling or mining within the original boundaries. But environmental groups say the bill has little chance of passing at all, let alone before the monument is scaled back next month.\n\n\u201cCome February, anyone can place a mining claim on the land,\u201d said Greg Zimmerman, deputy director at the Center for Western Priorities, a conservation group.\n\nNew mine, new challenges", "title": "Uranium Miners Pushed Hard for a Comeback. They Got Their Wish.", "authors": ["Hiroko Tabuchi"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIf you cannot or will not imagine the results of your actions, there\u2019s no way you can act morally or responsibly,\u201d she told The Guardian in an interview in 2005. \u201cLittle kids can\u2019t do it; babies are morally monsters \u2014 completely greedy. Their imagination has to be trained into foresight and empathy.\u201d\n\nThe writer\u2019s \u201cpleasant duty,\u201d she said, is to ply the reader\u2019s imagination with \u201cthe best and purest nourishment that it can absorb.\u201d\n\nShe was born Ursula Kroeber in Berkeley, Calif., on Oct. 21, 1929, the youngest of four children and the only daughter of two anthropologists, Alfred L. Kroeber and Theodora Kracaw Kroeber. Her father was an expert on the Native Americans of California, and her mother wrote an acclaimed book, \u201cIshi in Two Worlds\u201d (1960), about the life and death of California\u2019s \u201clast wild Indian.\u201d\n\nAt a young age, Ms. Le Guin immersed herself in books about mythology, among them James Frazer\u2019s \u201cThe Golden Bough,\u201d classic fantasies like Lord Dunsany\u2019s \u201cA Dreamer\u2019s Tales,\u201d and the science-fiction magazines of the day. But in early adolescence she lost interest in science fiction, because, she recalled, the stories \u201cseemed to be all about hardware and soldiers: White men go forth and conquer the universe.\u201d\n\nShe graduated from Radcliffe College in 1951, earned a master\u2019s degree in romance literature of the Middle Ages and Renaissance from Columbia University in 1952, and won a Fulbright fellowship to study in Paris. There she met and married another Fulbright scholar, Charles Le Guin, who survives her.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn their return to the United States, she abandoned her graduate studies to raise a family; the Le Guins eventually settled in Portland, where Mr. Le Guin taught history at Portland State University.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBesides her husband and son, Ms. Le Guin is survived by two daughters, Caroline and Elisabeth Le Guin; two brothers, Theodore and Clifton Kroeber; and four grandchildren.\n\nBy the early 1960s Ms. Le Guin had written five unpublished novels, mostly set in an imaginary Central European country called Orsinia. Eager to find a more welcoming market, she decided to try her hand at genre fiction.\n\nHer first science-fiction novel, \u201cRocannon\u2019s World,\u201d came out in 1966. Two years later she published \u201cA Wizard of Earthsea,\u201d the first in a series about a made-up world where the practice of magic is as precise as any science, and as morally ambiguous.\n\nThe first three Earthsea books \u2014 the other two were \u201cThe Tombs of Atuan\u201d (1971) and \u201cThe Farthest Shore\u201d (1972) \u2014 were written, at the request of her publisher, for young adults. But their grand scale and elevated style betray no trace of writing down to an audience.\n\nThe magic of Earthsea is language-driven: Wizards gain power over people and things by knowing their \u201ctrue names.\u201d Ms. Le Guin took this discipline seriously in naming her own characters. \u201cI must find the right name or I cannot get on with the story,\u201d she said. \u201cI cannot write the story if the name is wrong.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Earthsea series was clearly influenced by J. R. R. Tolkien\u2019s \u201cThe Lord of the Rings\u201d trilogy. But instead of a holy war between Good and Evil, Ms. Le Guin\u2019s stories are organized around a search for \u201cbalance\u201d among competing forces \u2014 a concept she adapted from her lifelong study of Taoist texts.\n\nShe returned to Earthsea later in her career, extending and deepening the trilogy with books like \u201cTehanu\u201d (1990) and \u201cThe Other Wind\u201d (2001), written for a general audience.\n\n\u201cThe Left Hand of Darkness,\u201d published in 1969, takes place on a planet called Gethen, where people are neither male nor female but assume the attributes of either sex during brief periods of reproductive fervor. Speaking with an anthropological dispassion, Ms. Le Guin later referred to her novel as a \u201cthought experiment\u201d designed to explore the nature of human societies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI eliminated gender to find out what was left,\u201d she told The Guardian.\n\nBut there is nothing dispassionate about the relationship at the core of the book, between an androgynous native of Gethen and a human male from Earth. The book won the two major prizes in science fiction, the Hugo and Nebula awards, and is widely taught in secondary schools and colleges.\n\nMuch of Ms. Le Guin\u2019s science fiction has a common background: a loosely knit confederation of worlds known as the Ekumen. This was founded by an ancient people who seeded humans on habitable planets throughout the galaxy \u2014 including Gethen, Earth and the twin worlds of her most ambitious novel, \u201cThe Dispossessed,\u201d subtitled \u201cAn Ambiguous Utopia\u201d (1974).\n\nAs the subtitle implies, \u201cThe Dispossessed\u201d contrasts two forms of social organization: a messy but vibrant capitalist society, which oppresses its underclass, and a classless \u201cutopia\u201d (partly based on the ideas of the Russian anarchist Peter Kropotkin), which turns out to be oppressive in its own conformist way. Ms. Le Guin leaves it up to the reader to find a comfortable balance between the two.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe Lathe of Heaven\u201d (1971) offers a very different take on utopian ambitions. A man whose dreams can alter reality falls under the sway of a psychiatrist, who usurps this power to conjure his own vision of a perfect world, with unfortunate results.\n\n\u201cThe Lathe of Heaven\u201d was among the few books by Ms. Le Guin that have been adapted for film or television. There were two made-for-television versions, one on PBS in 1980 and the other on the A&E cable channel in 2002.\n\nAmong the other adaptations of her work were the 2006 Japanese animated feature \u201cTales From Earthsea\u201d and a 2004 mini-series on the Sci Fi channel, \u201cLegend of Earthsea.\u201d\n\nWith the exception of the 1980 \u201cLathe of Heaven,\u201d she had little good to say about any of them.\n\nMs. Le Guin always considered herself a feminist, even when genre conventions led her to center her books on male heroes. Her later works, like the additions to the Earthsea series and such Ekumen tales as \u201cFour Ways to Forgiveness\u201d (1995) and \u201cThe Telling\u201d (2000), are mostly told from a female point of view.\n\nIn some of her later books, she gave in to a tendency toward didacticism, as if she were losing patience with humanity for not learning the hard lessons \u2014 about the need for balance and compassion \u2014 that her best work so astutely embodies.\n\nAt the 2014 National Book Awards, Ms. Le Guin was given the Medal for Distinguished Contribution to American Letters. She accepted the medal on behalf of her fellow writers of fantasy and science fiction, who, she said, had been \u201cexcluded from literature for so long\u201d while literary honors went to the \u201cso-called realists.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe also urged publishers and writers not to put too much emphasis on profits.\n\n\u201cI have had a long career and a good one,\u201d she said, adding, \u201cHere at the end of it, I really don\u2019t want to watch American literature get sold down the river.\u201d", "title": "Ursula K. Le Guin, Acclaimed for Her Fantasy Fiction, Is Dead at 88", "authors": ["Gerald Jonas"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Recently at a dinner party in La Paz, Bolivia, a friend told me about heading out of the canyon where the capital dwellers live and up to a concert on the plateau that sits above the city. The route his phone had calculated was on a dirt road that went straight up on a 45-degree angle that people generally walked or went up by mule.\n\nIt reminded me of the stories that every correspondent had about using Google or Waze when I used to cover Israel and the Palestinian territories. Your phone would regularly take you in and out of each as if there weren\u2019t a conflict going on, through military checkpoints and down roads that often ended in a wall put up 10 years before. Even if impassable, it was always the shortest route, Google assured.\n\nYou were barred from Venezuela last year after reporting on the financial crisis there in 2016. You witnessed shortages of food, medical supplies and electricity. What were some of the technology challenges you faced under such tough circumstances?\n\nA correspondent there warned me before I arrived to bring a Kindle \u2014 books were sometimes easier to download than to buy in Caracas, especially best-sellers or anything in English. You also lived in fear of losing things as basic and easy to get as a power cord. Venezuela is a country where people are having trouble finding tires when they get holes in them on the road, let alone Apple products. It is very unfortunate.", "title": "Using Drones and Netflix in the Andes, but Sidestepping Google Maps", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Chalidze challenged a Soviet law under which people could land in prison for five years on sodomy charges.\n\nSoviet officials responded with a campaign of pressure, searching his apartment and raising suspicions about his own sexuality. \u201cThe authorities started to spread rumors that he is homosexual,\u201d Mr. Litvinov said.\n\nMr. Sakharov and other dissidents were surprised in 1972 when Mr. Chalidze, invited to speak at American universities, was granted an exit visa and agreed to go; his colleagues assumed he would not be allowed to return.\n\nMr. Chalidze, however, said he wanted to prove that it was possible to leave and come back.\n\n\u201cHe had one briefcase that he kept with him at all times\u201d to avoid any possibility that the authorities might plant something on him, like drugs, Mrs. Chalidze said by telephone from Vermont.\n\nIn the United States, Soviet consular officials confiscated his passport, forcing him to remain.\n\nIn New York, he became involved in the publication of dissident literature, advising Robert Bernstein, at the time the president of Random House and later a founder of Human Rights Watch, on what material to publish. Random House published two books by Mr. Chalidze, \u201cTo Defend These Rights: Human Rights and the Soviet Union\u201d and \u201cCriminal Russia: A Study of Crime in the Soviet Union.\u201d\n\nHis most important association was with Edward Kline, a retail heir who was aligned with the dissident movement and Mr. Sakharov. Mr. Chalidze and Mr. Kline created Khronika Press, which published underground material that had been smuggled out of the Soviet Union, often as carbon copies, and then smuggled it back in as printed works. Mr. Kline died in June; Sakharov died in 1989.\n\nMr. Chalidze also started his own imprint, Chalidze Publications, publishing works on political thought that dissidents in the Soviet Union had been deprived of.", "title": "Valery Chalidze, Soviet Dissident Forced Into Exile, Dies at 79", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "The public integrity center\u2019s report recommended that lawyers with clients facing criminal charges in Manhattan donate no more than $320 to a candidate for district attorney, though that cap would be lifted six months after a case was resolved. Partners in their firms would be limited to $3,850 in each election cycle, roughly the same general election cap as exists for borough president candidates under city rules, the report said.\n\n\u201cMy campaign will meet and exceed these recommendations,\u201d Mr. Vance said in a statement.\n\nDonations to candidates running for district attorney from defense lawyers are legal in New York and have been made since the 19th century. Individual contribution limits are based on the number of voters in a county. In Manhattan, the legal donation limit in a general election is $50,000.\n\nThe recommendations in the 38-page report are aimed at limiting the influence of donations on the criminal justice system. The report said district attorneys should never accept donations from people under investigation or indictment, or from assistant district attorneys.\n\nIt also recommended prosecutors enforce a strict separation between their campaign and office staffs, so that the district attorney\u2019s office has no knowledge of who has offered financial support.\n\nThe report suggested limits of $250 for lawyers with pending cases in counties with smaller populations.\n\nPerhaps the most radical recommendations involved keeping the list of donors secret from sitting district attorneys, and banning prosecutors from soliciting contributions in person.\n\nMr. Vance said he did not expect other district attorneys in the state to follow his lead, but he believed the blind approach to raising money would allay public concerns that lawyers could buy leniency for their clients. Barring donations from lawyers with clients facing criminal proceedings until six months after the case is resolved is \u201ca sound, solid rule that makes sense,\u201d he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe said he will abide by these campaign contribution rules even if a challenger does not. \u201cThat\u2019s their decision and that\u2019s for the newspapers to ask them about,\u201d Mr. Vance said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJennifer Rodgers, a former federal prosecutor who leads the public integrity center, said the study found a wide variation in practices among the state\u2019s 62 prosecutors\u2019 offices. Most do not have any written policy regarding campaign donations, she said.\n\nIf all the state\u2019s district attorneys voluntarily adopted the recommendations, Ms. Rodgers said, it would go a long way toward eliminating the appearance that contributions can buy a prosecutor\u2019s decision.\n\nBut she said a voluntary system has limitations. Some incumbents and challengers may not opt to follow the guidelines. Only a change in state law would ensure everyone across the state is playing by the same rules, she said.\n\n\u201cIt definitely is something that should be addressed by the Legislature,\u201d she said.\n\nSusan Lerner, the executive director of Common Cause New York, called Mr. Vance\u2019s decision \u201ca really strong step in the right direction,\u201d but she said the Legislature should now codify the recommendations into law.\n\nEven if voluntarily followed by all candidates, the guidelines may not remove the influence of campaign money entirely. For instance, under the center\u2019s recommendations, district attorneys would still be allowed to attend fund-raising events where they could give campaign speeches. They would be able to see who attended the event, but in theory the candidate would not know how much each person donated. The report also acknowledged that there is no way to stop a candidate from learning the identities of donors through public websites maintained by the city and state election boards.\n\nAbout 40 percent of the $6.1 million in contributions to Mr. Vance, who was re-elected in November, came from lawyers. But many of the biggest givers are not criminal defense lawyers who practice in Manhattan, but financiers and business leaders.\n\nIn the case involving Trump SoHo, Mr. Vance\u2019s chief assistant at the time, Daniel R. Alonso, directed the campaign to return a $25,000 contribution from the Trumps\u2019 lawyer, Marc E. Kasowitz, before a meeting with Mr. Kasowitz. A year later, however, Mr. Vance\u2019s campaign accepted a $32,000 gift from Mr. Kasowitz, only to end up returning it after reporters highlighted it.\n\nScott D. McNamara, the district attorney for Oneida County, said capping donations from defense lawyers with active cases would be easier for prosecutors in smaller counties, where there are few large contributions.\n\nBut in the end, he said, it would depend on the honor system.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s only as good as a candidate\u2019s word,\u201d he said.", "title": "Vance Bans Donations From Lawyers With Pending Cases", "authors": ["James C. Mckinley Jr."]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhen it got down to answering the questions about what the impacts on health are, there is still a lot to be learned,\u201d said David Eaton, of the University of Washington, who led the committee that reviewed existing research and issued the report. \u201cE-cigarettes cannot be simply categorized as either beneficial or harmful.\u201d\n\nThe report was commissioned in 2016, after the F.D.A. gained the authority to regulate tobacco products that had previously been outside its jurisdiction, such as e-cigarettes and cigars.\n\nMitch Zeller, head of the agency\u2019s tobacco division, said the committee was assigned to assess the existing science, and to point out gaps in research. The report will aid the agency in its review of applications for lower-risk tobacco products and the potential harm or benefits those pose to individuals and the public.\n\nOn Wednesday, an F.D.A. advisory panel will review an application from Philip Morris International for iQOS, an electronic device that, unlike e-cigarettes, contains tobacco in a stick that the company says heats it but does not burn it. It releases nicotine vapor, which the company says is less hazardous than smoke. If approved, Philip Morris would be the first company allowed by the government to claim its product is less harmful than cigarettes.\n\nAlso this week, on Friday, the agency\u2019s new nicotine steering committee will hold a public hearing on over-the-counter therapeutic products, among them gums, patches and lozenges, designed to help smokers quit.\n\n[READ: The health effects of e-cigarettes]\n\nCessation was one area where the committee\u2019s report did give the booming e-cigarette industry some good news. It pointed out the benefits for smokers trying to quit. But people who continue to smoke cigarettes, alternating with e-cigarettes, do not gain the same health benefits, the committee said. That\u2019s especially important given that most adults who vape also still smoke or use other tobacco products. The report also said the evidence was limited on whether e-cigarettes were effective for quitting smoking.\n\nWhile there is no evidence at this time that e-cigarettes or their components cause cancer, the committee recommended more long-term research. Some e-cigarettes contain chemicals and metals whose long-term effects \u2014 including on pregnancy \u2014 also need further study, the committee said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSmoking rates among adults and teenagers have declined significantly over the last few decades. In 2015, the last year for which the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has statistics, about 37 million Americans, 15 percent of adults aged 18 and older, smoked cigarettes. The number has declined from nearly 21 percent of every 100 adults in 2005; and 42 percent in 1965.\n\nWith that decline, the e-cigarette industry has emerged as a potential substitute and Big Tobacco has been among the device developers enjoying new profits from the tobacco alternatives. Bonnie Herzog, a Wells Fargo tobacco analyst, predicted the industry will grow about 15 percent to $5.1 billion in retail sales in the United States, in 2018.\n\nThe vaping industry, as well as traditional tobacco companies, are gearing up for a lengthy fight with the F.D.A. over the campaign by the agency\u2019s commissioner, Dr. Scott Gottlieb, to slash levels of nicotine in traditional cigarettes to nonaddictive or minimally addictive levels.\n\nDr. Gottlieb is expected to issue an initial proposal, calling for public comment on lower nicotine levels, in the near future.\n\nThe new report reflects the complexity of the issues surrounding e-cigarettes and the balancing act regulators face over the pros and cons of the alternatives to conventional cigarettes.\n\nAdam Leventhal, a professor of preventive medicine at the University of Southern California, and an author of the report, said his group did an exhaustive literature search, reviewing all studies on youths and e-cigarette use from around the world. Of those, 10 studies were deemed strong enough to address the question. But they did not show that using e-cigarettes caused teens to move on to tobacco, only that the use of e-cigarettes was associated with later smoking of at least one traditional cigarette. The report noted that more than 11 percent of all high school students \u2014 nearly 1.7 million youths \u2014 reported using e-cigarettes within the past month.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe evidence was substantial that this association was consistent across a number of research methodologies, age ranges, locations, and research groups in and outside the U.S.,\u201d Mr. Leventhal said.\n\nThis conclusion is at odds with the findings of the British Royal College of Physicians, which asserts that e-cigarettes are not a gateway to smoking.\n\n\u201cConcerns about e-cigarettes helping to recruit a new generation of tobacco smokers through a gateway effect are, at least to date, unfounded,\u201d the organization notes on its website.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore intriguing was the newest report\u2019s finding of moderate evidence that youths who use e-cigarettes before trying tobacco are more likely to become more frequent and intense smokers.\n\nCritics have long contended that the flavored liquids for the devices are luring adolescents to the habit, at a time when nicotine is especially hazardous for their brain development. Three of the top-selling flavors at e-liquid.com, a large online retailer, include \u201cUnicorn Milk\u201d (strawberries and cream), \u201cTNT\u201d (strawberry, apple and peach) and \u201cI Love Donuts\u201d (blueberries and pastry).\n\nThe authors of the new report cite conclusive evidence that vaping can be addictive, and that exposure to nicotine from e-cigarettes is highly variable, depends on the characteristics of the device, as well as how it is used. They also cited conclusive proof that in addition to nicotine, most e-cigarettes contain and emit potentially toxic substances.\n\nIn terms of second-hand vapor, the committee said there was conclusive evidence that e-cigarette use increases airborne concentrations of particulate matter and nicotine indoors.\n\nThe report concluded that much of the current research on e-cigarettes is flawed, either in methodology or because of industry-financed bias. In addition, the levels of nicotine and other chemicals, including metals, vary in e-cigarettes from brand to brand.\n\n\u201cAnd for kids who initiate on e-cigarettes, there\u2019s a great chance of intensive use of cigarettes. As the regulator, we\u2019ve got to factor all that in,\u201d Mr. Zeller said.\n\nIn July, the F.D.A. delayed the deadline at least four years for e-cigarette companies to apply for approval to keep their products on the market, largely by showing some public health benefit.\n\nSeveral major tobacco companies that produce e-cigarettes declined to comment on the report. R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company issued a statement saying it was encouraged by the report\u2019s findings, and highlighted the committee\u2019s point that e-cigarettes \u201care likely to be far less harmful than conventional cigarettes.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut public health advocates who objected to the July delay said this report gave them further concern.\n\n\u201cWhat the report demonstrates is that despite the popularity of e-cigarettes, little is known about their overall health effects, and there is wide variability from product to product,\u201d said Matthew L. Myers, president of Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids. \u201cThat makes the case even stronger for F.D.A. regulation.\u201d\n\nThe vaping industry was cautiously optimistic about the report. Gregory Conley, president of the American Vaping Association, a nonprofit that advocates for vapor products, said the findings were consistent with those reached by the Royal College of Physicians and other institutions in Britain that have issued reports indicating e-cigarettes are less dangerous than traditional smoking and help with cessation.\n\n\u201cIn the wake of this report, it is more apparent than ever that true leadership is needed in public health to ensure that adult smokers have access to truthful information about the benefits of switching to smoke-free products,\u201d he said.\n\nAs for the F.D.A., Dr. Gottlieb said the report would play a critical role.\n\n\u201cWe need to put novel products like e-cigarettes through an appropriate series of regulatory gates to fully evaluate their risks and maximize their potential benefits,\u201d he said.", "title": "Vaping Can Be Addictive and May Lure Teenagers to Smoking, Science Panel Concludes", "authors": ["Sheila Kaplan"]} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "VARIETY PUZZLE \u2014 The quote in today\u2019s acrostic was unusual for me, not just because I was not familiar with many of the answers (OVIPOSIT?), but also because you don\u2019t see the word CHICKENPALOOZA in your puzzle every day.\n\nMy gimmes today were NUTMEG, DUMPLING and KITSCH, and most of my solve was guessing at the words in the grid until I could take a whack at the clues.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nThis author took a vacation from writing about lighthouses (18 books) and astronomy (4 books) to concentrate on chickens. The door is therefore open to gallinaceous puns. We can put them on the pulletin board.\n\nHa! Get it? Pullet? They\u2019re good eggs, our constructors.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "Variety: Acrostic", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "VARIETY PUZZLE \u2014 It\u2019s not every day that we get to read a quote that is critical of whales. Most writing, as far as I\u2019ve seen, is highly supportive of whales, and, in fact, is stoutly in favor of saving them.\n\nToday, however, CHARLES D\u2019AMBROSIO tells us all the reasons GRAY WHALES are UGLY, unmaneuverable, and, of all things, LUMPY.\n\nI had few gimmes today, but among them were RINGS, STRAIT and ISHMAEL (the clue seems unfair until you have a few letters and realize that it can be none other than the opening sentence, \u201cCall me ISHMAEL\u201d of the 1851 Melville novel, \u201cMoby-Dick.\u201d)\n\nOur constructors have even more questions about our whale friends:\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nWhat do they \u201csing\u201d about? What do they think? How do they sleep? We understand they are \u201cconscious breathers,\u201d meaning they must decide to take each breath, meaning they cannot be completely unconscious, meaning they must be somewhat aware as they snooze. Apparently sperm whales have been seen napping in a vertical position (head topmost or tail topmost) just under the surface, drifting along. Do they dream?\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "Variety: Acrostic", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "Let\u2019s get you started. There are plenty of places on the internet where you can read about the rules of cryptic crossword clues (I particularly like Alan Connor\u2019s series in The Guardian), but here\u2019s the first one you need to know: A cryptic clue is made up of two parts: 1) A definition or synonym and 2) A form of wordplay to help you get to the same answer as the definition. The clues are written to sound vaguely like phrases, although they are not always phrases that make the most sense. Also, the definition part of the clue will always be at either the beginning or the end of the clue, so finding it will go a long way toward helping you interpret the clue.\n\nSo far, so good, right? Now that you know that there is a pattern of sorts for cryptic clues, I\u2019m going to tell you that there are lots of different kinds of wordplay to be enjoyed. Don\u2019t run away! There are different kinds of clues in American-style crosswords and you solve those, don\u2019t you?\n\nThe best way to dip your toe in is to just heave your entire body into the pool, so to speak. Let\u2019s start with 1A: \u201cF.B.I. director fired by Trump circumvents low-grade farce (6).\u201d How\u2019s that for a delicious clue? Of course, you know that James COMEY has to be in there somewhere, but we still need one more letter to make the six-letter answer, so let\u2019s dissect the clue first.\n\nIt\u2019s most likely that \u201cfarce\u201d is the definition, because there really are no synonyms for F.B.I. director, and the rest of the clue will help us out. \u201cCircumvents\u201d is a word that can mean \u201cget around,\u201d so there is an excellent chance that we will be putting something around something else.\n\nWhat\u2019s left? Well, a \u201clow grade\u201d is a D, and if we put COMEY around that D, we get the word COMEDY, which is a synonym for \u201cfarce.\u201d", "title": "Variety: Cryptic Crossword", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "VARIETY PUZZLE \u2014 There is a notepad on this puzzle, which reads: \u201cSix answers in this puzzle are each missing a word, as suggested by the shape of the completed grid.\n\n\u201cThis diagramless crossword is 17 squares wide by 17 squares deep and has top/bottom symmetry (that is, the grid pattern is reflected over a central horizontal axis). 1-Across starts in the 7th square of the top row.\u201d\n\nThis one was a bit harder for me, since I not only had to count squares, but I also had to figure out what word was missing from the theme entries.\n\nIt turns out that the shape of the grid gives it away, and the answer is the number \u201c3.\u201d The black and white squares form the number, which has been \u201csubtracted\u201d from them phrases like ___ MARTINI LUNCH and ___ DAY WEEKEND.", "title": "Variety: Diagramless", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "While Mr. Figari was never charged, many of the allegations against him were eventually confirmed by a Vatican inquiry. He was ordered to cut contact with members of the society last year, and he has been living in Rome ever since.\n\nMr. Figari has never provided concrete responses to the accusations, though the society has said they were most likely true. His lawyer, Armando Lengua, has said he has not been in contact with Mr. Figari, describing him unreachable in the Sodalitium prayer and retreat house in Rome.\n\nSome of the victims have denounced the Vatican\u2019s handling of the case and the decision to allow Mr. Figari to live in comfortable retirement in Rome.\n\nIn the statement, the Vatican said that Francis had followed the Sodalitium saga for years, and that he had asked that the congregation pay particular attention to it. After that, the Vatican named Cardinal Joseph W. Tobin to monitor Sodalitium.\n\nThe decree to place the society under a Vatican-appointed commissioner signals that the Holy See believes the Sodalitium is incapable of reforming itself despite a series of measures its new leadership had taken to try to make amends with victims, acknowledge past abuses and change its internal operations.\n\nThe society said it only learned of the takeover on Wednesday. In a statement, it thanked Francis, pledged to cooperate fully with the new commissioner and said it would accept whatever was decided in the future.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe reaffirm once again our absolute obedience to the Holy Father and the Holy Mother Church,\u201d a statement on the group\u2019s website said.\n\nMr. Figari founded the society, known as SCV, in 1971 as a lay community to recruit \u201csoldiers for God.\u201d It was one of several Catholic societies born as a conservative reaction to the left-leaning liberation theology movement that swept through Latin America starting in the 1960s.\n\nA 2017 investigative report commissioned by the society\u2019s new leadership found that Mr. Figari was a charismatic intellectual but also \u201cnarcissistic, paranoid, demeaning, vulgar, vindictive, manipulative, racist, sexist, elitist and obsessed with sexual issues and the sexual orientation of SCV members.\u201d\n\nThe report, by two Americans and an Irish expert in abuse, found that Mr. Figari sodomized his recruits and forced them to touch him and one another. He liked to watch them \u201cexperience pain, discomfort and fear,\u201d and humiliated them to enhance his control over them, the report found.", "title": "Vatican Takes Over Troubled Catholic Group in Peru Ahead of Pope\u2019s Visit", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 In a move that has upset many in the Roman Catholic Church, the Vatican asked two \u201cunderground\u201d bishops in China to surrender their positions to individuals approved by the country\u2019s authoritarian government, including one the Vatican had excommunicated, a cardinal who traveled to Rome said on Monday.\n\nThe decision in December came amid what observers describe as an extraordinary effort by the Vatican to advance negotiations to restore ties with Beijing after a nearly 70-year schism among Catholics in the world\u2019s most populous nation.\n\n\u201cMy feeling is the Vatican wants a breakthrough,\u201d said Dr. Chen Tsung-ming, research director at the Ferdinand Verbiest Institute in Belgium, which studies religion and society in modern China. \u201cIf they can solve, little by little, the problem of the illegal and the underground bishops, then it may help create a model of negotiations.\u201d\n\nDiplomatic ties between the Vatican and Beijing were severed after the Communist Party took power in China in 1949. Today, about half of the estimated 10 to 12 million Catholics in China worship in underground churches that refuse to recognize government control over the faith. The other half worship in government-managed churches run mostly by clergy members appointed by Beijing.", "title": "Vatican, Eager for China Ties, Asks \u2018Underground\u2019 Bishops to Step Aside", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Midway through their wildly successful first season in the National Hockey League, the Vegas Golden Knights have run into a problem off the ice. To the government he was a terrorist. To his followers he was a freedom fighter, a modern folk hero in the ilk of Robin Hood or Che Guevara. Some skeptics said his story was too improbable to be true \u2014 they mused that he must have been a double agent of some sort, meant to cast the opposition in a bad light.\n\nHowever people viewed him, his actions resonated across the whole country.\n\nVenezuela has suffered from an economic crisis that has left hospitals without medicine and babies dying of malnutrition. An unpopular president has put down protests with an iron fist, leaving more than 100 dead on the streets of Caracas last year among police and protesters. Few seem to hold out hope for democracy in Venezuela.\n\nAfter his helicopter flight above Caracas in June, Mr. P\u00e9rez became an avatar of the nation\u2019s mounting grievances: He was the daring cop who had defected and asked others to do the same.\n\nBut if there is one thing that would haunt him to the grave, it was that the rebellion never came.\n\n\u201cWe wanted there to be a call to the streets that day, there to be big displays, that the people realized there a movement had started,\u201d he said in one of his messages. \u201cBut unfortunately, there wasn\u2019t one.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. P\u00e9rez, who joined the investigative unit of the Venezuelan police 15 years ago, might have been just another detective if it hadn\u2019t been for his acting. The film he starred in, \u201cSuspended Death,\u201d or \u201cMuerte Suspendida\u201d in Spanish, was released in 2015. He plays an inspector named Efra\u00edn Robles who rescues a Venezuelan businessman from kidnappers.\n\nHe said the idea to act in the film had come to him after a police operation in a poor neighborhood in Caracas, where he met a young man on the verge of joining a gang. Mr. P\u00e9rez saw no way of talking him out of crime, but noticed how influenced the young man was by what he saw on television.\n\n\u201cHe literally forgot his hunger watching TV,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was there you see the great power of audiovisual mediums, of movies.\u201d\n\nThe film foreshadows the theatrics Mr. P\u00e9rez would become known for in real life. His character \u2014 also a pilot \u2014 chases criminals through the streets of the capital from the air, and in the finale, he scuba dives with a rifle to the yacht of the villain.\n\nMr. P\u00e9rez said the movie also showed the kind of police force that he wished had existed in Venezuela: Mug shots displayed on high-tech screens. Crime scenes carefully dusted by forensics experts. Men in lab coats analyzing the results.", "title": "Venezuela\u2019s Most-Wanted Rebel Shared His Story, Just Before Death", "authors": ["Nicholas Casey"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "FRIDAY PUZZLE \u2014 Far be it from me to harp on an entry that might or might not violate the so-called \u201cBreakfast Test\u201d \u2014 a subjective look at entries that might be considered highly unpleasant if encountered while solving a puzzle with your breakfast \u2014 but let\u2019s talk about WORD VOMIT, which makes its New York Times Crossword debut today.\n\nThe Crossword editor, Will Shortz, has said that he does not subscribe to the idea of a Breakfast Test, although the word VOMIT has never graced the grids of a New York Times crossword, and for good reason. Who wants to see that while you\u2019re eating, or for that matter, at any time of day?\n\nSo I will admit to being a bit stunned when I wrote in WORD VOMIT, but here\u2019s the thing: It\u2019s a very well-known phrase that merely means saying things that you didn\u2019t mean to, and probably in greater quantities than you intended. If you Google the phrase, it\u2019s all over the internet, but it probably is best known for a scene from the movie \u201cMean Girls,\u201d in which WORD VOMIT precedes the real thing and yes, I will spare you that.\n\nO.K., maybe I did harp on it a bit. Occasionally he has teared up, but mostly he sits passively, staring down at papers in front of him.\n\nOn Tuesday, Judge Aquilina heard from nearly 30 more victims: sisters who said that Dr. Nassar had molested them; a former rower at Michigan State, who said she had received no response to two separate reports of abuse against Dr. Nassar; and several others who described the crippling effects of depression and mental illness they attributed to Dr. Nassar\u2019s behavior.\n\n\u201cYou are so strong and brave,\u201d Judge Aquilina said.\n\nJudge Aquilina\u2019s unconventional approach has not elicited any discernible criticism, but she has generated attention. Not only has she opened the floodgates to emotional testimony in a very pronounced way, but she seems determined to lend her voice, shedding any pretense of judicial distance.\n\nSeveral victims \u2014 and their parents \u2014 have thanked Judge Aquilina, including Doug Powell, whose daughter Kassie spoke out last week as one of Dr. Nassar\u2019s many accusers.\n\n\u201cJudge Aquilina, I applaud you,\u201d Mr. Powell said after his daughter addressed the court. \u201cWe applaud you. This room applauds you.\u201d\n\nThe use of victim impact statements has generated debate in sentencing hearings before juries, as some scholars have questioned the tactic as an obvious emotional ploy meant to sway the panel for a tougher term.", "title": "Victims in Larry Nassar Abuse Case Find a Fierce Advocate: The Judge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The mudslides in Montecito wiped out entire blocks, killing at least 18 people with a brutal force that shocked residents and even emergency workers \u2014 in neighborhoods that survived fires just weeks ago. On Thursday, rescue teams continued to search for as many as 43 people, holding out hope that they could survive in the thick mud, as deep as 10 feet in some places.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe area was ravaged by the largest wildfire in California history last month, and the mudslides were a direct result of the burned ground. Without any vegetation in the way, the hills were vulnerable to falling rock and debris. Parts of the hills still puffed with smoke from those fires as the rain came down Tuesday.\n\nFour children were killed by the mud; the youngest victim was just 3 years old, according to a list issued by the Santa Barbara County Sheriff\u2019s Office on Thursday. Nearly all of those who died lived within a two-mile radius in the flatlands of this small wealthy community just south of Santa Barbara. Most of the area was under voluntary evacuation orders.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story California Today The news and stories that matter to Californians (and anyone else interested in the state). Sign up to get it by email. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAmong those reportedly missing were the 25-year-old stepsister of 12-year-old twins, one who lived, one who died; a 28-year-old woman whose 10-year-old son died; and a teenage boy whose father died and 14-year-old sister was dramatically rescued Tuesday after firefighters slogged through the rubble for six hours.\n\nOn Wednesday, Mr. Gower went to his mother\u2019s home, where he had grown up and she had lived for decades. The mud around San Ysidro Creek had spread nearly 1,000 feet, he said, and there were boulders the size of cars.\n\nLast year, the front yard flooded when about four inches of rain came down in a day, Mr. Gower said. But Ms. Gower assured him on Monday that she had set out sandbags and was prepared. They had no idea that the mud would prove far more dangerous than the water.\n\n\u201cThe creek was not even there,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019ve had nothing like this at all, nothing like this has happened in Santa Barbara\u2019s history, and nobody was prepared.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the past 48 hours, Mr. Gower and his sister, Breezy Haigh, have gone over and over what could have been done differently \u2014 alternating between blaming themselves and blaming county officials.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe night before I told her, \u2018Why don\u2019t you come stay here?\u2019 and now of course I wish I would have pushed her,\u201d Ms. Haigh said Thursday. Like her children, Ms. Gower had been back in her home for only a few weeks. \u201cI feel like the county let us down. During the fire, they took so much precaution. People didn\u2019t take this seriously. If it had been a mandatory, she would still be here.\u201d\n\nSome blamed the desire to stay put on \u201cevacuation fatigue,\u201d because so many residents had returned to their homes only in the days before Christmas.\n\nOfficials from the Santa Barbara County Sheriff\u2019s Office did not immediately respond to requests for comment. But they have said that they notified residents of the danger and decided which areas to evacuate based on input from weather, fire and flood experts.\n\nLike several other victims in the neighborhood, Alice and James Mitchell chose to stay home because they were not under mandatory evacuation, said their daughter, Kelly Weimer. The couple, married more than 50 years, had left for the wildfire and were still packed in case the floods forced them to leave again.\n\nSo the Mitchells stayed in for dinner to celebrate Mr. Mitchell\u2019s 89th birthday and went to bed early. Their bodies were found Tuesday down the road from their house, which they had named Casa Contenta, the house of contentment. All that was left was its foundation.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cNothing else is recognizable,\u201d said Clay Weimer, the Mitchells\u2019 son-in-law. Another home nearby had apparently slid down the hill. \u201cThe house next to them? Who knows where that house came from.\u201d\n\nThe white poodle Ms. Weimer gave her father for his birthday last year, Gigi, is still missing.\n\nAnother nearby neighbor, Rebecca Riskin, 61, was found by the freeway about a mile away from her home, said her ex-husband, Ralph Riskin. The couple\u2019s 25-year-old daughter, Julia, was rescued by a Coast Guard helicopter from the roof of a cottage on Ms. Riskin\u2019s property, Mr. Riskin said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cRobert, my son, called me and said that his sister Julia was O.K.,\u201d said Mr. Riskin, before he was overcome with emotion. \u201cBut he said, and I\u2019ll never forget it: \u2018We can\u2019t find Mom.\u2019\u201d\n\nMany residents were still stunned at the sight of massive boulders around the town Thursday. A huge hole had taken the place of the living room in Ms. Gower\u2019s home. Initially, Mr. Borgatello tried to get himself out of the mud, using his arms to pull his body up. But after he began shivering, he told Ms. Haigh, he realized he would be warmer if he stayed covered in the muck. Mr. Borgatello was released from the hospital Wednesday, she said, and has repeatedly spoken with some confusion about the night.\n\n\u201cShe looked at least 10 years younger than she was,\u201d said Ms. Haigh, 35, adding that her mother swam at the local YMCA daily and kept her hair platinum blond. \u201cShe would have lived to be 100. I\u2019m too young to have a dead mother.\u201d\n\nThe child of Italian immigrants who settled in Santa Barbara, Ms. Gower had spent her entire life in the area and delighted in having her three grandchildren, who called her Nonna, all nearby.\n\n\u201cShe was the life of the party, every party,\u201d Ms. Haigh said through tears. \u201cFor her, every party was the \u2018party of the century.\u2019\u201d\n\nMs. Haigh and Mr. Gower had only begun to think about making plans for a funeral Thursday, anxious that they would not be able to find a place big enough for all the mourners in town.", "title": "Victims of California Mudslides Were Swept Away Weeks After Surviving Fires", "authors": ["Jennifer Medina", "Patricia Mazzei"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 The model in the latest Victoria Beckham eyewear advertising campaign looks young and waiflike, her twiglike limbs in a silken tunic and cotton-candy pink slacks, her face as full of sharp angles as the square-frame tortoiseshell spectacles perched on her nose.\n\nThe glossy image of the Lithuanian model Giedre Dukauskaite, published by Ms. Beckham on social media last week as she unveiled designs from her spring and summer 2018 eyewear range, has drawn a fierce public response. It is not the first time the fashion designer has been accused of promoting an unhealthy body image while advertising her luxury products, and is just the latest campaign to fan the perennial debate around when thin is too thin.\n\nIn a recent study the research and advocacy group Model Alliance conducted in conjunction with Harvard and Northeastern University, the results of which were published in the International Journal of Eating Disorders, 81 percent of the models surveyed reported a body mass index of less than 18.5, which the World Health Organization considers underweight.\n\n\u201cVictoria Beckham\u2019s shocking and shameful promotional image made me feel physically sick \u2014 but will have a far more damaging effect on many impressionable young girls who see it,\u201d the writer and TV host Piers Morgan wrote in his Mail Online column on Monday. He went on to call Ms. Beckham a \u201cshameless and dangerous hypocrite\u201d who had pledged in the past not to use models who were too thin.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHundreds of social media users agreed. Elena Mata Westerman commented on Ms. Beckham\u2019s Facebook post, saying: \u201cEyes didn\u2019t even notice the glasses. The model was the focus. Sickly skinny! Beckham should be ashamed promoting eating disorders. Her young daughter is heavier than her models. Shame.\u201d", "title": "Victoria Beckham Draws Uproar Over Superthin Model in Ad Campaign", "authors": ["Elizabeth Paton"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nVictoria Chan and Stephen David Okin were married Jan. 20 at 26 Bridge, an events space in Brooklyn. Francesca Martinelli, a Universal Life minister, officiated.\n\nThe bride, 29, is a program officer for the Fulbright program in the State Department\u2019s Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs in Washington. She graduated from Hunter College, and received a master\u2019s degree in international education from George Washington University.\n\nShe is the daughter of Bonnie Chan and Paul Chan of Manhattan. The bride\u2019s father, who is retired, was a social worker for the Chinese American Planning Council in Manhattan. Her mother is a researcher for the New York City Housing Authority in Manhattan.\n\nThe groom, 30, is a senior analyst for Avascent, a defense consulting firm in Washington. He graduated from Hamilton College in Clinton, N.Y., and, as a Fulbright scholar, received a master\u2019s degree in integration studies from the University of the West Indies at Cave Hill, Barbados. He also received a master\u2019s degree in United States national security policy from Georgetown.\n\nHe is a son of Dr. Lisa M. DeAngelis and Dr. Peter M. Okin of Manhattan. The groom\u2019s father is a professor of medicine at Weill Cornell Medicine there. His mother is the chair of neurology at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, also in Manhattan.\n\nThe couple met in October 2013 at the Rennert New York Language School, while Mr. Okin was observing a class that Ms. Chan was teaching.", "title": "Victoria Chan, Stephen Okin", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "However, Mr. Fedorov said, \u201cMiracles happen only rarely.\u201d\n\nEven if a large turnout fails to materialize, analysts said, the Kremlin is determined to discourage cheating to make the elections at least appear legitimate and to ward off a repeat of the street protests that questioned the 2012 results.\n\n\u201cPutin wants the elections to look honest,\u201d said Dmitri Oreshkin, a political scientist and Kremlin critic. But that means motivating Russians to go to the polls.\n\nAt first, as several Russian news outlets reported, the goal was the \u201c70/70\u201d formula, meaning the administration wanted Mr. Putin to start his fourth presidential term having secured 70 percent of the vote with a turnout of 70 percent.\n\nIt would match the roughly 70 percent support and 70 percent turnout that Dmitri A. Medvedev won in 2008 as Mr. Putin\u2019s substitute for one term as president. At a minimum, by many accounts, Mr. Putin wants to surpass the nearly 64 percent support he received in 2012 with a turnout of more than 65 percent.\n\nTrustworthy polling numbers are elusive, but most analysts believe Mr. Putin will fall well short of his goal, with turnout of around 55 to 60 percent and support at about the same or slightly higher.\n\nPhoto\n\nParticularly vexing for the Kremlin is that Mr. Putin\u2019s current numbers do not match his favorability ratings, which have consistently been above 80 percent since he annexed Crimea in 2014.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nClearly, though, Russian voters are less and less interested in voting, as all manifestations of vitality have been drained from the process. Free elections, a free news media, free political parties and other hallmarks of democracy have been gradually eliminated or sharply restrained, starting even before Mr. Putin first became president in 2000 but accelerating thereafter.\n\nBarely 48 percent of the electorate turned out for the September 2016 parliamentary elections, although the presidential vote is expected to generate greater interest.\n\nThe oddball characters the Kremlin has allowed to oppose Mr. Putin are not about to light any electoral fires, with their support mired in single digits.\n\n\u201cSome figures are allowed in, like backup dancers,\u201d said Lev D. Gudkov, director of the Levada Center. Perhaps the most reliable polling organization on Russian politics, the center just announced it would sit out the election, having been labeled a \u201cforeign agent\u201d for receiving grants from abroad, and thus barred by law from political activity.\n\nThe most recognizable candidate is Vladimir Zhirinovsky, 71, a wily nationalist known for his political antics who has been a stalwart of the opposition for decades. Another perennial, Gennadi Zughanov, 73, the Communist Party leader who has run in four presidential elections and nearly won in 1996, has dropped out.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe surprise Communist Party candidate is Pavel N. Grudinin, 57, the director of a farming enterprise whose name, the Lenin State Farm, is redolent of the Communist era. But his ownership stake in what is actually a privatized agricultural company pays him more than $350,000 a year, inspiring the moniker \u201cCommunist Billionaire\u201d on social media.\n\nThe smattering of liberals includes Ksenia Sobchak, 36, a reality TV star and the daughter of Mr. Putin\u2019s political mentor, as well as Grigory Yavlinsky, 65, another longtime opposition figure.\n\nNone represents a real challenge to Mr. Putin.\n\nThere is one surefire way for the Kremlin to electrify the voters \u2014 allowing the candidacy of Alexei A. Navalny, Russia\u2019s most outspoken and best-organized opposition figure. Instead, it has barred him from the race, and a Moscow court has shuttered the legal entity that pays the rent for his campaign offices in 84 cities and the wages for several hundred campaign workers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Navalny is pushing for an election boycott, though some analysts consider that unwise because it might reveal an embarrassing shallowness in his support if it has little impact. He has also called for nationwide protests on Sunday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn fact, Mr. Navalny was unlikely to pose a real challenge to Mr. Putin given the president\u2019s significant popularity. But an official presidential run would give him a public platform to further publicize his accusations of corruption against the Kremlin, including possibly the president himself, potentially tarnishing what amounts to Mr. Putin\u2019s coronation.\n\nPlus there is always the possibility of an electoral surprise, and Mr. Putin hates surprises. He has shown a marked distaste for elections ever since he helped to organize a losing 1996 mayoral campaign in St. Petersburg.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn about 15 regions of Russia, what Mr. Oreshkin calls \u201celectoral sultanates,\u201d Mr. Putin can count on Soviet-style support. In the Chechen Republic under the strongman Ramzan Kadyrov, for example, Mr. Putin in 2012 received more than 99 percent of the votes cast with more than 99 percent turnout.\n\nThose regions account for only about 10 percent of the electorate, however, and fantastic numbers like those in Chechnya are considered an embarrassment in the modern era.\n\nIf there is an element of competition in the race, it is actually between senior bureaucrats to see who can generate the most support for Mr. Putin. The prize might be a federal post, with expectations high that Mr. Putin will try to dispel a certain sense of stagnation by shaking up his cabinet after the election.\n\n\u201cPutin\u2019s election campaign becomes an election campaign for his servants, where the electorate is just a platform to demonstrate your skills and political-administrative talents,\u201d wrote Tatyana Stanovaya, the chief analyst for the Center for Political Technologies, a Moscow think tank, in an op-ed for Republic.ru.\n\nRegional leaders will resemble carnival barkers as they try to lift the numbers, turning Election Day into something of a festival, Russian news outlets have reported. That includes fairs, flash mobs spurring people to vote and possible prizes like a new iPhone for the most creative selfie posted from a polling place.\n\nMuch of it is aimed at getting young people to the polls. Senior citizens and the budgetniki, the Russian term for state employees, have the habit of voting as a civic duty left over from Soviet days. Those younger than 40 do not.\n\n\u201cThe president does not want to be elected by the elderly and the budgetniki. He wants to be elected by the young,\u201d said Igor Mintusov, a veteran Moscow political consultant.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUltimately, elections in Russia tend to set Western methods on their head.\n\n\u201cIn a Western, U.S.-style campaign, the procedure is certain, but the result \u2014 who will win \u2014 is uncertain,\u201d Mr. Mintusov said. \u201cIn Russia the procedure is uncertain, but the result is certain.\u201d", "title": "Victory in Russia Election Assured, Putin Seeks High Turnout", "authors": ["Neil Macfarquhar"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201c1975?\u201d Diggs said. \u201cI think I was still swimming at the time.\u201d\n\nTheir forebears may never have won a Super Bowl in four tries, but the Vikings are adamant that the curse does not extend to them. What transpired on a snowy afternoon here may be their best evidence: After they blew a 17-point lead but recovered, after 12 points were scored in the final 89 seconds of a matchup between New Orleans\u2019s second-ranked offense and Minnesota\u2019s top-ranked defense, the scoreboard showed the Vikings had more.\n\n\u201cCraziest ending I\u2019ve ever been a part of out of my 25 years,\u201d running back Jerick McKinnon said in the locker room afterward.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s official,\u201d running back Latavius Murray added. \u201cHe said he\u2019s going to name his kid Stefon.\u201d\n\n\u201cStefon, my first kid is going to be named Stefon,\u201d McKinnon said.\n\n\u201cMine is going to be Diggs based off of today,\u201d Murray said.\n\nPhoto\n\nKeenum, playing for his third team in four seasons, matched Drew Brees, one of the best quarterbacks in league history, and preserved Minnesota\u2019s bid to become the first team to play a Super Bowl in its home stadium. The N.F.C. championship in Philadelphia next weekend will feature two reserves elevated by injury, a matchup of Nick Foles and Keenum, teammates on that paragon of mediocrity known as the 2015 St. Louis Rams. In a league where the quality of quarterback so often defines the quality of a team, the conference finalists reinforce the value of having a complete roster.\n\nMinnesota\u2019s defense is loaded with stars at every position, but its offense, Diggs noted, is populated by castoffs and misfits and low draft picks. Keenum went undrafted, as did receiver Adam Thielen.\n\nThey stood on the sideline and watched Wil Lutz drill a go-ahead 43-yarder with 25 seconds left, which incited a few Saints personnel to head into in the press box to exclaim that they were headed to the N.F.C. championship. Some fans departed, numbed, perhaps, by the anguish.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKeenum had been waiting his entire peripatetic career for a moment like the one that came next. He had those 25 seconds to guide the Vikings roughly 50 yards \u2014 into the desired field-goal range of kicker Kai Forbath, whose 53-yarder with 1 minute 29 seconds left had pushed Minnesota ahead by 23-21. His task, all at once, was to rescue his defense, demonstrate his season was more revelation than fluke and lift his team, and a fan base grated by playoff misery, to victory.\n\nAfter gaining 19 yards on one completion across the first three plays, to their own 39, the Vikings left the ensuing huddle with Keenum\u2019s words echoing in their ears: \u201cI\u2019m going to give somebody a chance.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Vikings practice the play regularly. It is a staple, receiver Wright said, of their Saturday preparation, and they had actually run it a few times earlier in the game. Wright ran an out, as did tight end Kyle Rudolph. The Vikings had no timeouts, and since those routes direct them toward the sideline, where the clock would stop if they stepped out after making a catch, Wright figured he would be the first option.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s why it was amazing,\u201d Wright said. \u201cIt was meant for us.\u201d\n\nAs Diggs tracked the ball, cornerback Terence Newman, watching on the sideline, knew he would catch it. \u201cHave you seen Stefon jump?\u201d he said. Leaping a few feet, Diggs hovered above Saints safety Marcus Williams, who made the critical gaffe of lowering his shoulder to hit him \u2014 but missed, instead striking teammate Ken Crawley.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI felt the guy brush past me,\u201d Diggs said. \u201cI took a picture before I turned around to catch the ball. There was only one guy there. If he slipped, I\u2019m going to try to stay up.\u201d\n\nSaid Williams: \u201cIf the play happened different, I would go attack the ball and make a play.\u201d\n\nTeammates yelled at Diggs to run out of bounds to set up a field-goal attempt, but, after seeing the vast expanse ahead, he just kept running. He sprinted into the end zone. He flung his helmet. Teammates mobbed him, and he lay there at the bottom of the pile, delirious with joy, gasping for air.\n\n\u201cThere were some heavy guys, and I almost passed out,\u201d he said.\n\nThe ball squirted free, and he wondered where it went. In the locker room, Diggs clutched it. He found Keenum, and they gathered to pose for a photo. Diggs\u2019s mouth was open, his eyes wide, and his hand messed with Keenum\u2019s hair.\n\nAs teammates unpacked what Thielen called \u201cone of the greatest games of football ever played,\u201d Keenum turned around and went back toward his locker, shaking his head once more and not for the last time.", "title": "Vikings Shock Saints on Stefon Diggs\u2019s Last-Second Touchdown", "authors": ["Ben Shpigel"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "The surest way to make fans of the Philadelphia Eagles cringe, to make them look as if they downed a handful of ghost peppers and chased it with hydrochloric acid, is to mention Ronde Barber, Ricky Manning Jr. or a Branch \u2014 Cliff or Deion, take your pick.\n\nGo ahead and say Drew Pearson, Gary Anderson and Blair Walsh to hardened Minnesota Vikings supporters \u2014 we dare you.\n\nThose names are synonymous with playoff misery for two franchises well acquainted with it.\n\nNo team, according to Pro Football Reference, has won more games in the Super Bowl era without capturing a championship than Minnesota (20). Second? The Eagles (16).\n\nThe Vikings are 0-4 in Super Bowls, losing all by double-digit margins, an average of 15.3 points. Since appearing in its last Super Bowl, in 1977, Minnesota has lost five N.F.C. championship games, two in overtime, including one when Anderson, who had not missed a field-goal attempt all season, pulled a 38-yarder in the fourth quarter that would have given the Vikings, who were 15-1 in the regular season, a 10-point lead against the Atlanta Falcons with two minutes left and oh the pain.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Eagles, aside from going 24 years between their only Super Bowl appearances, played in five conference championship games from 2001 to 2007 and won only one. Pressed into service again for an ailing Bradford, Keenum led Minnesota to victory in Chicago, and he went on to start the next week, and the week after, and the week after that.\n\nWhen the other injured quarterback, Teddy Bridgewater, rejoined the roster in November, Coach Mike Zimmer declined to designate Keenum the full-time starter. Keenum kept playing, anyway, and the Vikings kept winning, 13 times in all, tied for most in the N.F.L.\n\nThe Vikings continue to abide week by week, this time without any questions about who the starter will be on Sunday, when they host the New Orleans Saints in a divisional-round matchup that, fairly or not, represents the latest test of Keenum\u2019s viability.\n\nA paradox in the modern N.F.L. is that quarterbacks tend to absorb a disproportionate share of the credit or blame, and yet regardless of the talent or coaching surrounding them, rarely do teams thrive without a great one. It\u2019s why year after year, conference championships include the likes of Tom Brady, Aaron Rodgers and Ben Roethlisberger \u2014 and not, for example, Brandon Weeden.", "title": "Vikings\u2019 Case Keenum Isn\u2019t a Star, but He Is Playing Like One", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump, who has denounced N.F.L. players\u2019 protesting racial injustice by refusing to stand during the anthem, has long been involved with the McMahons and W.W.E. Linda McMahon, Vince\u2019s wife, was appointed by Trump to run the Small Business Administration.\n\nTrump has hosted wrestling events at his properties and has been involved in the showmanship, once shaving McMahon\u2019s head in the middle of a ring. Trump was also involved in an alternative professional league in the 1980s, owning the New Jersey Generals of the short-lived United States Football League.\n\nBut McMahon said that he had not consulted with Trump about the XFL, and that the ban on politics during games would extend to the president\u2019s positions.\n\n\u201cDemocrat, Republican, Independent, I don\u2019t care, and no one should,\u201d said McMahon. \u201cWe come to the field not to state what I am pro or against, that\u2019s not why we\u2019re there. We are there to play football.\u201d\n\nThis XFL also won\u2019t be affiliated with wrestling, at least not officially. McMahon has formed Alpha Entertainment to run the league with completely separate management. He recently sold off about $100 million in W.W.E. stock to fund it.\n\n\u201cI am very committed to this, and it\u2019s going to take more than $100 million to do this league,\u201d he said.\n\nMcMahon did not further estimate what amount of capital \u2014 including media rights fees, ticket sales and sponsorships \u2014 would be required to start the league.
