The Democrat, Blaine Eaton, drew a long green straw. His Republican opponent, Mark Tullos, had a short red straw. But the victory was short-lived: The Republican-controlled House threw out some ballots for Mr. Eaton, the incumbent, and seated his Republican challenger.\n\nAlaska, 2006\n\nAfter two Democrats tied in a primary for a House seat, a recount and state Supreme Court challenge followed, but the matter was ultimately decided by a coin toss. A special coin with a walrus on one side (heads) and the state seal on the other (tails) was flipped at a library in Anchorage. The challenger, Bryce Edgmon, won the toss and his luck has held: he is now Speaker of the Alaska House.\n\nNevada, 2002\n\nA 107-107 tie for a seat on the Esmeralda County Commission was settled Old West-style by drawing a high card. The county clerk and treasurer shuffled the deck, then fanned them out like a blackjack dealer. Both candidates drew jacks, but the Democrat\u2019s spade beat the Republican\u2019s diamond.\n\nWyoming, 1994\n\nAfter a deadlocked race for the state House, a Ping-Pong ball was drawn from the cowboy hat of Wyoming\u2019s governor. The winning ball bore the name of the Republican, Randall Luthi.\n\nVirginia, 1971\n\nThe last time Virginia\u2019s State Board of Elections broke a tie \u201cby lot\u201d was in 1971 after a House race deadlocked with 16,410 votes apiece in the northern suburbs. The elections board chairman donned a patriotic blindfolded and drew an envelope from a silver trophy cup, which had been borrowed from a collection at the Executive Mansion, according to The Richmond Times-Dispatch.\n\nThe winner, Republican William H. Moss, and the loser, Democrat Jim Burch, agreed that drawing was a bad idea, according to The Times-Dispatch. \u201cThere should have been a runoff to let the people decide,\u201d Mr. Burch said.\n\nNew Jersey, 1804\n\nThe famous duel between Aaron Burr, the sitting vice president, and Alexander Hamilton, a former Treasury secretary, wasn\u2019t over an election. But the roots of their yearslong feud can be traced to a tied race. In the presidential election of 1800, the Electoral College deadlocked with 73 votes each for Burr and Thomas Jefferson. The race was thrown into the House of Representatives, where Hamilton used his considerable influence to elect Jefferson. Four years later, the bitterness between the two men had escalated and they faced off with dueling pistols beneath the cliffs of Weehawken. Hamilton was mortally wounded, and although Burr was physically unscathed his political career was over, showing that it is possible to win a face-off but also lose.", "title": "Virginia\u2019s Tiebreaker Drawing Is Back On. But It May Not Settle House Race.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "HAVANA \u2014 \u201cBeing here is like heaven,\u201d the composer and musician David Amram said after watching the singer Daym\u00e9 Arocena light up the crowd at the Casa de la Cultura here on Friday. \u201cLike getting a second chance at life, and most people don\u2019t even get a first chance.\u201d\n\nMr. Amram, who first visited Cuba in 1977, returned last week for the 33rd International Jazz Plaza Festival, a six-day event that drew Cuban jazz veterans like Chucho Vald\u00e9s and the Orquesta Arag\u00f3n, as well as rising stars like Ms. Arocena and Yissy Garc\u00eda. Despite tightened restrictions on travel to Cuba from the United States, the festival relied heavily on American performers, including Joe Lovano, whose first trip to Cuba was in 1986, and Randy Weston and Dee Dee Bridgewater, who were visiting for the first time.\n\nHowever this year\u2019s event took place under a cloud of renewed uncertainty for many Cuban musicians. Since the Trump administration\u2019s withdrawal of diplomats from Havana in September, the United States Embassy here has stopped processing visa applications from Cubans, who have taken to traveling to a third country to apply for visas to the States.\n\nBut visiting musicians like Mr. Amram and Ms. Bridgewater spoke of their role as cultural ambassadors who could touch hearts in spite of political borders. \u201cMy being here is my way of saying, yes, Cuba, yes, you all amazing musicians, I stand with you,\u201d Ms. Bridgewater said at a news conference, raising her fist in solidarity. \u201cI am your sister in music and that is all I care about.\u201d", "title": "Visa Troubles Aside, Jazz Flows Freely at a Cuban Festival", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI hope we flood the polls, and the House turns pink, the Senate turns pink, and the White House in 2020 turns pink.\u201d\n\nDorothy Engelman, 68, of Lansing, Mich., marched with a group of friends. \u201cWe\u2019ve been through a lot together,\u201d she added.\n\nPhotographs by Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times", "title": "Voices From the Women\u2019s Marches", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Merkel, through her spokesman, was among the political leaders and auto industry executives who in recent days condemned the experiments at a lab in Albuquerque, in which monkeys were exposed to diesel exhaust. The project was financed by German carmakers, who wanted to show that diesel cars were less of a threat to human health than groups such as the World Health Organization have claimed.\n\nA separate project financed by the carmakers subjected human volunteers in Germany to doses of nitrogen dioxide, one of diesel\u2019s most noxious byproducts.\n\nEnvironmental groups and other critics of Volkswagen said the suspension of Mr. Steg, whose formal title at Volkswagen is head of external relations and sustainability, made him a sacrificial lamb meant to insulate the company\u2019s top managers from consequences.\n\nThese critics drew parallels with the Volkswagen emissions scandal, in which the company initially said that a small number of rogue engineers were responsible for installing software intended to dupe regulators. German prosecutors have since identified dozens of suspects.\n\n\u201cThey are again playing the game where the subordinates were the culprits,\u201d said Christian Strenger, a former member of a commission that wrote Germany\u2019s rules on corporate governance. Mr. Strenger is among the people suing Volkswagen for violating its legal obligations to shareholders.", "title": "Volkswagen Suspends Top Lobbyist Amid Inquiry Into Diesel Tests on Monkeys", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "HONG KONG \u2014 A sailboat competing in the Volvo Ocean Race, a marquee around-the-world sailing competition, collided with a Chinese fishing vessel near Hong Kong early Saturday, killing one of the Chinese boat\u2019s crew members, race organizers and Chinese state media said.\n\nThe Vestas 11th Hour Racing boat hit the fishing vessel around 1:20 a.m. local time. The crew alerted the Hong Kong authorities and race officials immediately after the collision. The Hong Kong Marine Rescue Coordination Center said that nine of the fishing boat\u2019s crew members were rescued. A tenth who was taken by helicopter to a hospital, however, later died, race officials said.\n\nThe dead sailor was from mainland China, according to the English-language Twitter account of The People\u2019s Daily, the Communist Party-run newspaper.\n\n\u201cOn behalf of the Volvo Ocean Race and Vestas 11th Hour Racing, we offer our deepest condolences to the loved ones of the deceased,\u201d the team and race officials said in a statement.", "title": "Volvo Ocean Race Yacht Involved in Fatal Accident Near Hong Kong", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSUNDAY PUZZLE \u2014 UPDATE: The earlier version of the web puzzle has been fixed. If you are solving on iOS and you loaded the puzzle at 6 p.m., you can get the update by going to the Archive page, long pressing today\u2019s date, say \u201cYes\u201d when it asks if you want to update the puzzle. Updating the puzzle should allow users to put in the OU in the section. Thank you for your patience.\n\nFirst, let\u2019s get the housekeeping out of the way. There are two things solvers need to know about this puzzle by David Steinberg:\n\n1. There is a notepad that says, \u201cIn the print version of this puzzle, the squares that are circled are instead each divided into two halves with a diagonal line.\u201d That slash might be helpful for keeping the entries straight, so for ease of online solving, I am offering a simultaneous, \u201cno Wordplay spoilers\u201d mini-post with a blank PDF of the print version of this puzzle. You might also want to keep a pad of paper next to you to take notes. 2. When the Sunday Magazine puzzle went to press (Ha ha, what fun we have!), the original clue for 114D (\u201cOnly N.F.L. team ever to go 0-16 for a season\u201d) was correct. At least, it was correct until the Cleveland Browns lost to the Pittsburgh Steelers on New Year\u2019s Eve, and became the second team to go 0-16. Unfortunately, it was too late to correct the original clue in the magazine, but it has been updated for all online versions.\n\nI know. It\u2019s been a tough week, solvingwise. So, why not settle down with a nice, predictable Sunday puzzle, where absolutely nothing is a surprise and you know all the answers?\n\nNope, not today, sorry. Think about how bored you would get if all the puzzles were the same. Sure, the comforting routine of reading a clue, thinking a bit about it and then writing the answer into the grid \u2014 no numbers, no rebuses, just letters \u2014 is what some of us crave. But what if, just for today, you got to do that twice for some of the answers? Would that make it better?\n\nIf you are not a solver of our Variety puzzles, you might not be familiar with Split Decisions, a fun and very satisfying puzzle where you are given pairs of letter strings and have to figure out what the pairs of words are that share those letters. Here\u2019s an example from 2017 to print out and solve. Give it a try; I think you\u2019ll like it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt will also help you understand what you need to do in order to solve today\u2019s puzzle.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nThe name of the game is Vowel Play, so you know you\u2019re going to be \u2014 wait for it \u2014 playing with vowels. Mr. Steinberg has pulled off a true feat of construction that combines the best of Split Decisions and Schr\u00f6dinger puzzles, and his grid is packed with this theme material.", "title": "Vowel Play", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA new, highly effective typhoid vaccine \u2014 the only one safe for infants \u2014 has been approved for global use by the World Health Organization. The approval was given in December but announced on Wednesday.\n\nTyphoid fever, caused by Salmonella typhi bacteria in sewage and contaminated food, infects up to 20 million people a year and kills up to 160,000 of them, mostly young children. The disease once killed many Americans \u2014 Typhoid Mary was a famous carrier \u2014 but is now found mostly in Africa and Asia.\n\nThe need for an effective, affordable vaccine has risen urgently as urban slums grow, hotter weather spreads the disease to new regions and the bacteria develop resistance to more antibiotics.\n\nApproval means the new vaccine, named Typbar TCV and made by Bharat Biotech of Hyderabad, India, can be purchased by donors, including United Nations agencies, for use in poor countries. GAVI, the Vaccine Alliance, has earmarked $85 million for doses to be given to children starting next year.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe vaccine now costs $1.50 a dose when purchased for developing countries, and the price will drop to $1 or less if donors order more than 100 million doses, said Bharat\u2019s chairman, Krishna M. Ella. The vaccine has been tested and used in India since 2005.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt gained approval for worldwide use after an unusual \u201cchallenge trial\u201d that began in 2015. About 100 healthy volunteers in Oxford, England \u2014 many of them students \u2014 received the vaccine or a placebo, and then swallowed live Salmonella typhi.", "title": "W.H.O. Approves a Safe, Inexpensive Typhoid Vaccine", "authors": ["Donald G. Mcneil Jr.", "Global Health"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s a huge opportunity for us,\u201d Simon said. \u201cIt\u2019s going to allow us to do some things as a tour and invest with a long-term vision and planning, and we haven\u2019t had that opportunity before.\u201d\n\nThe move to Shenzhen was clearly driven by economics. Stacey Allaster, the former head of the WTA Tour, once said the existing five-year deal with Singapore provided \u201c35 to 40 percent\u201d of the tour\u2019s net operating revenue.\n\nSimon said the percentage was no longer that high, because of increased revenue from other sources. But while he called the Shenzhen agreement \u201ca huge deal,\u201d he also argued that it was not simply a case of chasing the highest offer. He said the move also had to make sense strategically.\n\n\u201cI think Shenzhen and the Delta region down there is the new Silicon Valley of Asia,\u201d he said, referring to the Pearl River Delta, which is now one of the world\u2019s biggest urban areas and includes Guangzhou and Hong Kong. \u201cIt\u2019s a growing region and growing area, and we\u2019re excited to be a part of that growth.\u201d\n\nShenzhen, whose population has exploded from less than 100,000 in 1980 to over 10 million today, already stages an ATP event in September and a WTA event in January.\n\nA WTA spokesperson said it was unclear whether the Shenzhen Open would continue to exist with the arrival of the WTA Finals. But the region is now particularly well served by women\u2019s tennis.\n\nThere are eight WTA tournaments in China this season, including the China Open in Beijing, one of the tour\u2019s four top-tier premier mandatory events. The Pearl River Delta region has four tournaments, including events in Guangzhou, Hong Kong and Zhuhai.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe WTA Elite Trophy event in Zhuhai, near Hong Kong, is a second-tier, season-ending event for players outside the top eight. It currently is the final event on the WTA calendar, an anticlimactic state of affairs that Simon expects to be corrected in 2019 by moving Zhuhai forward on the schedule. That would allow the Finals in Shenzhen to be the last event.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSimon said he and the WTA board of directors were committed to anchoring the Finals in one venue for an extended run, hoping to mirror the success of the ATP Finals, which have been in London since 2009.\n\n\u201cI think it takes time to build the traditions, and if it\u2019s long term, people are going to invest behind it to build it,\u201d he said.\n\nThough staying in Singapore, a major financial hub and prosperous modern city, would certainly have allowed the chance to build those traditions more quickly.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s a fair statement,\u201d Simon said.\n\nThere also have been concerns about attendance at WTA events in China, a situation that was not helped by the sudden retirement in 2014 of Li Na, the first Chinese player to win a Grand Slam singles title.\n\nBut Simon said attendance was increasing at events in China, specifically citing tournaments in Wuhan, Tianjin and Shenzhen.\n\n\u201cAnd I think in Shenzhen we have a tremendous opportunity,\u201d he said, \u201cbecause the new stadium coming with this deal is actually going to be built in the downtown district rather on the outskirts, where a lot of the stadiums are being built. So now we are in the heart of an area of 68 million people, and I think we\u2019ll have a great opportunity to draw well.\u201d\n\nSingapore, where attendance has been strong, clearly could not match Shenzhen\u2019s offer, although Simon did confirm that Singapore was one of five finalists in the bidding.\n\nThat group included Prague, Manchester in England and St. Petersburg in Russia. Simon said there were no North American finalists.\n\nBut the decision to keep the Finals in Asia in a difficult window for the North American television market will continue to create challenges in generating interest for the event in the United States, one of the traditional hubs of the sport and one that has produced more major women\u2019s tennis stars than any other with a talented new generation on the rise that includes Sloane Stephens and Madison Keys.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe tournament was staged at Madison Square Garden in New York in 1977 and again from 1979 through 2000. It was also held in Los Angeles from 2002 to 2005.", "title": "WTA Finals Will Move to China for Next 10 Years", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Still, other investments by Mr. Son, the leader of the Japanese conglomerate SoftBank, suggest that he is not likely investing in Wag solely to bet on the business of keeping Fluffy content.\n\nA little over a year into its existence, the Vision Fund has come to focus on companies that can collect and harness vast oceans of data to transform industries as diverse as medicine, food and finance.\n\nApart from big names like Uber, it has invested in outfits like Compass, a New York-based platform for buying and selling property; Vir Biotechnology, which researches and develops treatments for infectious diseases; and Oyo, a hotel network in India.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWag\u2019s app keeps track of exactly where your pooch is being taken by its walker. That makes Wag a potentially useful fount of location data. (Although, to be clear, this location data is not about Wag\u2019s users, but about its users\u2019 dogs.)\n\nWhen the Vision Fund invested in a mapping start-up called Mapbox last year, the fund\u2019s Rajeev Misra said, in a statement, that Mapbox\u2019s use of sensor data to generate live maps made it an investment in \u201cthe foundational infrastructure for the next stage of the information revolution.\u201d\n\n\u201cLocation data is central and mission critical to the development of the world\u2019s most exciting technologies,\u201d Mr. Misra said.\n\nData on the real-world comings and goings of internet users \u2014 and, evidently, their dogs \u2014 is a highly sought-after commodity among technology companies. It can attract furious controversy when it is mishandled, though. Security analysts criticized the fitness app Strava this week for inadvertently revealing the locations of military bases by publishing its users\u2019 running routes.\n\nAnd Wag itself does not have an unblemished record for safeguarding users\u2019 information. The Wall Street Journal recently found unprotected pages on the company\u2019s website that contained the personal data, including home addresses, of at least 100 customers.\n\nThe pages were later taken down. They satisfy my inner-O.C.D. artistic needs for geometry, simplicity and angularity.\n\nPhoto\n\nA bushel of Apples\n\nI have Apple computers starting from the 1980s that I just can\u2019t throw out. They\u2019re industrial-design genius inventions. Apple gave the New York City schools tons of computers back then. My dad was a New York City teacher, and when one broke he took it home and fixed it, or I did. Apple didn\u2019t want them back. I used Macs in high school and college. One may be worth a couple thousand, but I\u2019d never sell it.\n\nTwo monikers\n\nLast year we rang the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange. I use Matthew Zachary as my business name, but for security reasons, I had to use my legal surname, Greenzweig, to get into the building, which is why it appears on the engraved collectible they gave me. I noticed the Stock Exchange staff had Greenzweig for the chyron that appears on the TV screen, so I had to catch them beforehand and have them change it to Zachary.\n\nOur public relations team gave me the beer can, which is from an English brewery with the same name as our yearly gala. We named our annual fund-raiser Toast to salute our community and our impact.\n\nPhoto\n\nTech savvy\n\nI have an external monitor that mirrors my laptop screen, and I use an old Galaxy tablet for the time and the weather. You could say I\u2019m the IT director here. I\u2019ve been coding since I was a kid. I minored in computer science and was an Apple-certified engineer in college.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCreature of habit\n\nI drink only water, Starbucks coffee, and when I\u2019m sick, mint tea. For lunch, I either walk to Starbucks or the deli downstairs to get something and eat at my desk.\n\nMini medical professional\n\nIn the early 2000s, Genentech invited me to attend a hematology conference and play the grand piano at their trade booth. I performed for attendees on the trade show floor.\n\nThe company also gave out copies of my CD and squishy doctor toys. Mine is next to a couple of models of the brain. After my experience with cancer, every time I see a model of a brain, I buy it. When I was sick, my mother\u2019s friend gave me a yardstick that\u2019s inscribed, \u201cYard by yard, life is hard, inch by inch it\u2019s a cinch.\u201d It was apropos at the time.\n\nAlerting fans\n\nThe fliers atop the piano, which I designed myself, are from four cabaret shows, or concerts, I gave after college. The concerts were my way of rehabilitating myself and getting back into what I was passionate about. I emailed them to a bunch of people and they also served as signage and programs at the events. I stopped playing in 2002 because I was so busy.\n\nPhoto\n\nOldie but goody\n\nAs a consummate 1980s kid, I still think the Transformers are the coolest thing in the universe. When my 7-year-old son was 2, I tried to introduce him to a Playskool Mr. Potato Head takeoff of the Optimus Prime Transformer, but it didn\u2019t work. He tried to eat it. I bought a replacement but decided to keep it myself.\n\nNever enough\n\nI have four or five Transformers in the office. I never had a man cave at home, so this place is perfect for displaying all the things my wife has asked me to get rid of.\n\nIn the limelight\n\nNewsweek contacted me early in 2017 and said they were doing a special issue on disruption in health care and wanted to include me. I thought it would be an inside article, I didn\u2019t realize I\u2019d be on the cover as an angry rebel. I\u2019m a cover model.\n\nFriends forever\n\nThe photo of my friend Adam Price and me on a mountain peak is the most important from my cancer experience. He was the person who held my head over the toilet bowl when I was sick. I had finished radiation and was told that without chemo, I was risking my odds of survival. While all my friends were leaving for grad school, he and I flew to Las Vegas, rented a car, and drove around the Southwest before there was a GPS or Google Maps. We ended up in the Grand Canyon and had someone take our picture on a crazy precipice. We had to jump through space to get to it. It was a bucket list item before there were bucket lists.", "title": "Waging the Cancer War, Surrounded by Signs of Life", "authors": ["Patricia R. Olsen", "As Told To"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 The government of Wales has a question for parents: Is it ever right to physically punish your children?\n\nIt began a 12-week feedback process on the issue on Tuesday, with officials saying they hoped to join more than 50 countries that have adopted an outright ban on the practice.\n\nThey would also be following the example of Scotland, which announced plans for a ban after a consultation of its own last summer.\n\n\u201cWe all want to give our children the best start in life,\u201d said Huw Irranca-Davies, the Welsh minister for children and social care, and a father of three boys. \u201cChildren do not come with an instruction manual and sometimes parents need guidance and support to help them raise healthy and happy children.\u201d", "title": "Wales Prepares to Ban Physical Punishment of Children", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI was walking my dog in the park one morning when I noticed a woman up ahead of me.\n\nHer dog, a Shih Tzu, was straining at his leash in anticipation of our arrival. On Monday, the bank said he planned to stay in the job for five more years.\n\nSince taking JPMorgan\u2019s helm more than 12 years ago, Mr. Dimon has survived a financial crisis, a monumental trading blowup and throat cancer. These days, he is the closest thing there is to Wall Street royalty.\n\nBut JPMorgan is preparing for life without Mr. Dimon, who will turn 62 in March. In an announcement that seemed designed in part to address questions about the bank\u2019s succession planning, JPMorgan said two of his deputies, Daniel Pinto and Gordon Smith, would be promoted to the joint roles of presidents and chief operating officers.\n\nMr. Pinto, 55, has led JPMorgan\u2019s investment bank for five years. Says He Isn\u2019t Going Anywhere", "authors": ["Emily Flitter"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Walmart is making a circuitous and belated push into the digital book market, teaming up with a Japanese company to sell e-books and audiobooks.\n\nThe deal with Rakuten, an e-commerce giant based in Japan, will allow Walmart to start selling digital books on its website for the first time later this year.\n\nThe move, which was announced late Thursday, comes years after Walmart\u2019s archrival, Amazon, began to dominate the market for digital readers.\n\nWalmart customers will be able to read the books through Rakuten Kobo e-reading devices \u2014 which have not taken hold with Americans the way Amazon\u2019s Kindle and Barnes & Noble\u2019s Nook have.", "title": "Walmart Makes a Late Entry Into the E-Book Market", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "The need is most acute for hourly employees, who are 59 percent of the American work force. They are least likely to be able to afford unpaid leave or newborn child care, and more likely to drop out of the labor force after giving birth.\n\nA mother\u2019s physical recovery from childbirth generally takes at least six weeks, doctors say, and there is an emotional adjustment period as well. Newborns demand frequent feedings, on an irregular schedule, and it is hard for mothers to breast-feed or rest if they return to work immediately. Most day-care providers do not offer newborn care, or it is very expensive.\n\nIn the Pew survey, 16 percent of people employed in the last two years said they needed to take leave but were unable to. They were more likely to be low earners, and also more likely to be women, black, Hispanic or without a college degree.\n\nResearch has found that mothers who take paid parental leave are more likely to be working a year later, and less likely to receive public aid. It also improves mothers\u2019 physical and mental health; the duration of breast-feeding; babies\u2019 health and development; and gender equity.\n\nWhen fathers take such leave, research shows, they are more involved in their children\u2019s lives years later; their children are healthier; and mothers have increased earnings and better mental health.\n\nMany of the large employers that give hourly employees paid leave do so through short-term disability. It is available only to birth mothers, and generally pays about 60 percent of wages for six weeks for a vaginal birth and eight weeks for a C-section.\n\nLow-wage workers are much less likely to have access to short-term disability: 23 percent of service workers have it, compared with 43 percent of office workers and 61 percent of managers. They are also more likely to contribute payment, instead of having employers pay for it: 42 percent of service workers are required to contribute, compared with 13 percent of managers and professionals.", "title": "Walmart and Now Starbucks: Why More Big Companies Are Offering Paid Family Leave", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Since President Trump signed the tax law last month, a number of large companies \u2014 including AT&T, Southwest Airlines and Wells Fargo \u2014 have said they were using the savings to help their employees. On Thursday, Fiat Chrysler Automobiles announced that it would give a $2,000 bonus to 60,000 hourly and salaried employees.\n\n\u201cIt is only proper that our employees share in the savings generated by tax reform,\u201d Sergio Marchionne, the company\u2019s chief executive, said in a statement.\n\nWalmart, which is the country\u2019s single largest corporate taxpayer, said in a statement Thursday that it was still determining how much it would save as a result of the new law.\n\nMatt Gardner, a senior fellow at the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy, a nonprofit research group, said it was difficult to forecast precisely how much Walmart would save. But based on the company\u2019s average annual United States earnings over the past five years, he said, savings from the cut in the corporate tax rate alone could be roughly $2.2 billion a year, or 40 percent. He said the figure could be higher or lower depending on tax breaks the company might be losing, or new advantages in the treatment of capital investments and other provisions.\n\nWalmart said the wage increases and bonuses would cost the company roughly $700 million.\n\n\u201cTax reform gives us the opportunity to be more competitive globally and to accelerate plans for the U.S.,\u201d Walmart\u2019s chief executive, Doug McMillon, said in a statement.\n\nStill, many economists are skeptical that the tax cut will have a meaningful impact on wages. In an economic research memo released on Thursday, Goldman Sachs wrote that \u201cwe expect no significant short-term effect of tax reform on\u201d average hourly earnings.\n\nGoldman predicted that, to the extent that the tax bill would drive up pay, it would do so over time, partly by stimulating the economy and forcing employers to pay more as they competed for workers.", "title": "Walmart\u2019s Bumpy Day: From Wage Increase to Store Closings", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cCombs, brushes, wave caps \u2014 everything was grouped together and separated,\u201d she added.\n\nMs. Grundy said that the second time she visited this month she asked to speak to a supervisor about why these specific products were locked up. He informed her, she said, that the policy to add additional security came directly from corporate headquarters. Ms. Grundy said that it was a two-hour process to discuss the policy, but that no employees could do anything.\n\nOn her third visit, she wanted to buy a comb that was in a glass case. She had to ask for it to be unlocked, she said, and then a staff member said he would have to take the comb to the register so she could pay for it before taking it.\n\n\u201cI felt that I was being treated as a person who might be a thief,\u201d Ms. Grundy said in a statement she issued on Friday, the same day her lawyer, Gloria Allred, filed the lawsuit in California Superior Court in Riverside County.\n\nCharles Crowson, a spokesman for Walmart, acknowledged that certain items are kept locked up for security reasons because they are more likely to be stolen. The items, he said, may differ from store to store.\n\n\u201cYou go into any of our stores \u2014 a good part of our items are behind additional security,\u201d Mr. Crowson said. \u201cWe\u2019re sensitive to this situation and also understand, like other retailers, that some products such as electronics, automotive, cosmetics and other personal care products are subject to additional security. Those determinations are made on a store-by-store basis.\u201d", "title": "Walmart\u2019s Locking Up of Certain Beauty Products Is Racial Discrimination, Suit Claims", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Walmart\u2019s pay increase, purportedly inspired by the recent cut in the corporate tax rate, is a little less than real largess. The retailer\u2019s extra spending on hourly wages is just a sliver of what it could save in taxes, though \u2014 and a tight labor market is likely to have been a more potent driver.\n\nWalmart will raise its hourly rate for starting staff to $11 in the United States, the third upward move in three years. Assuming a 40-hour workweek, the $300 million increase the company expects in its wage bill would suggest fewer than one in 10 workers in the United States will benefit directly. Put another way, the raise is equivalent to just 0.3 percent of the company\u2019s sales and administration costs.\n\nMoreover, the reduction in the corporate tax rate to 21 percent from 35 percent means that Walmart\u2019s chief executive, Doug McMillon, in theory, had room to give away much more. The company is forecast to make $20.3 billion of pretax profit in 2018. Around three-quarters of that comes from the United States, which suggests a tax savings of $2.1 billion. Factor in the one-off bonuses the company is paying to some staff, at a total cost of $400 million, and Walmart is giving back only around one-third of what it could save in taxes.\n\nIn fairness, there are other demands on Walmart\u2019s tax windfall. Competition from rivals and the online behemoth Amazon are going to call for investment in stores and lower prices. On the same day the company trumpeted its pay rise, it revealed the closure of some members-only Sam\u2019s Club stores. So competitive is the market that Morgan Stanley reckons in most cases only 50 percent of what retailers save in tax will make it back to investors.", "title": "Walmart\u2019s Minor Act of Redistribution", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Twice a week, often between video calls or meetings, Andrew Lowenthal takes a break from work to open an app on his phone that helps him focus on his breathing.\n\nThe payoff? Better stress management, clearer thinking at work and \u2014 to Mr. Lowenthal\u2019s surprise \u2014 more strength and power in the gym. \u201cIt\u2019s such a fundamental part of being human but not something that we think about often,\u201d Mr. Lowenthal said about his breathwork.\n\nAs the executive director of Out in Tech, a Manhattan-based nonprofit, Mr. Lowenthal, 33, typically spends three to 10 minutes on an app created by Inscape, a New York meditation studio. He inhales, holding and exhaling his breath for various lengths of time according to prompts. Mr. Lowenthal said that he now exercises more regularly and takes care of himself better because of his breathing exercises. \u201cIt definitely helps me with my endurance,\u201d he said.\n\nLong a key part of meditation and some kinds of yoga, breathwork is now becoming a discipline in its own right, with proponents offering classes, one-on-one sessions and apps dedicated to the practice. And whereas the focus has predominantly been on the mental and psychological benefits of breathwork, fitness industry professionals are increasingly saying that it can also enhance athletic performance or speed muscular recovery after a workout.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMindbodygreen, a wellness-focused media company that has published articles on breathwork, has noted an uptick in interest in the subject from its audience \u2014 in particular from \u201cpeople who are thinking meditation is too woo-woo,\u201d said a company co-founder, Colleen Wachob. \u201cIt\u2019s a slightly different cohort that\u2019s looking for a shortcut or hack and that\u2019s more performance- or science-driven,\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt has been long recognized that deep, controlled breathing can calm someone having an anxiety attack or help anyone in need of a little more stress-relief and mental clarity. Hillary Clinton, for example, has talked about using alternate side nostril breathing to help her relax while on the 2016 presidential campaign trail. But what\u2019s new is that scientists have found a physical link between breathing and what they call \u201cemotionality.\u201d", "title": "Want a Better Workout? Just Breathe", "authors": ["Tatiana Boncompagni", "Fit City"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAfter serving as vehicles for a mass statement on sexual harassment and pay inequity, some of the black dresses and tuxedos of the Golden Globes are ready for their second act. And it is one that may reassure critics who worried that the all-black dress code was an empty gesture of protest.\n\nBeginning on Friday at noon, and for one week, eBay will host an auction for 39 of the dresses and tuxedos worn by celebrities including Laura Dern, Tracee Ellis Ross, Reese Witherspoon, Meryl Streep, Seth Meyers and Zo\u00eb Kravitz to the Golden Globes. Minimum bids will range from $2,500 to $10,000 and are based on prices suggested by the designers who donated the pieces.\n\nWhy the designers? Most boldface names do not pay for what they wear on the red carpet. Some have contractual relationships with fashion houses that require them to wear designs from those brands. Others receive dresses from designers eager for the exposure, which can be worth significantly more than the cost of the items themselves.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Open Thread Fashion Newsletter A look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAll of the proceeds from the auction will go to the Time\u2019s Up Legal Defense Fund, which is administered by the National Women\u2019s Law Center and connects those who experience sexual misconduct in the workplace with lawyers. Try eBay", "authors": ["Valeriya Safronova"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "The Basics\n\nRecharge launched in San Francisco in 2016 and last April in New York City and can be used to book rooms by the minute in about 20 hotels in each destination, at any time of day or night. Many are five-star properties, such as the Surrey and the Pierre in New York City and the Taj Campton Palace in San Francisco, and some are in the four-star category. In 2018, the service will expand to Los Angeles, Chicago, Miami and Washington, D.C.\n\nThe company\u2019s co-founder and chief executive officer, Manny Bamfo, said that he started Recharge because he believed that there was a demand for hotel stays in minute-long increments. These stays can be booked for immediate visits or for ones up to a day in advance, but booking is only through the app.\n\nRecharge\u2019s customers \u2014 more than 30,000 as of November \u2014 are mostly locals and include mothers who want a clean place to nurse their babies or pump their breast milk, people seeking a quiet space to take a phone call and those seeking a midday reprieve. \u201cWe\u2019ve even had fathers who need to change their child\u2019s diaper and would rather do it in a hotel room than in a coffee shop bathroom,\u201d Mr. Bamfo said. \u201cYou pay for the amount of time you need and nothing more.\u201d\n\nHotels benefit, too, Mr. Bamfo said: According to the company\u2019s research, a 250-room property can get almost 275-rooms\u2019 worth of revenue in one day from these short stays.\n\nImage The Recharge app. Credit Recharge\n\nThe Prices\n\nEvery hotel listed on Recharge\u2019s app has a service fee, ranging from $30 to $50. The more luxurious the hotel, the higher the fee. After the service fee, per minute prices for the stays range from 50 cents to $2. Pricing for the same property can fluctuate throughout the day, depending on supply and demand, and some hotels may have a minimum charge at certain times of the day.\n\nMy Stays\n\nI tried Recharge on a weekend when I had to hit different neighborhoods in Manhattan for various errands.\n\nMy first trial was on a Saturday afternoon after I unexpectedly spent two hours at the Apple store on Fifth Avenue in Midtown, getting my iPhone fixed. There was just an hour before my dinner reservation on the West Side, and going back to my East Side apartment only to leave again almost immediately for the meal seemed like a waste of time. Here was my opportunity to turn to Recharge. The app showed availability in a dozen hotels, including the Pierre, just a few blocks away. I reserved my room, showed up five minutes later and was warmly greeted at the front desk by an employee, who had a record of my booking and offered me a bottle of water.", "title": "Want to Relax in a Nice Hotel for 15 Minutes? An App Can Make That Happen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWEDNESDAY PUZZLE \u2014 It is always a good day when I can reassure solvers that today\u2019s theme is not about poop.\n\nI bring this up because in the process of creating today\u2019s puzzle, Jules Markey briefly entertained the idea of creating a theme around something that must have happened to his car\u2019s windshield. He\u2019s not alone; many constructors vent their spleen in their crosswords, and heaven knows that\u2019s cheaper than therapy.\n\nFortunately for us \u2014 and Mr. Markey \u2014 the editors keep a firm hand on the sort of entries that are considered acceptable in a New York Times crossword, and so today\u2019s theme is not about excrement, but about another part of our avian friends.\n\nThank goodness.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nTip: When you see all the theme entries in the Downs, it\u2019s a good idea to think about whether \u201cdown\u201d or falling or dropping or gravity might have something to do with the revealer. In this case, it does, but we have some work to do to uncover it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Mr. Markey\u2019s grid, all of the starred Down entries have birds hidden in them. For example, at 7D, \u201cA likely story!\u201d is TELL ME ANOTHER ONE, which has a HERON hidden inside. Similarly, the \u201cSports legend who was an M.V.P. for eight consecutive seasons\u201d is WAYNE GRETZKY, who has an EGRET trapped inside him, which sounds incredibly uncomfortable.", "title": "Warm Winter Coat Contents", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Iran is the latest example of a country where a water crisis, long in the making, has fed popular discontent. That is particularly true in small towns and cities in what is already one of the most parched regions of the world. Farms turned barren, lakes became dust bowls. Millions moved to provincial towns and cities, and joblessness led to mounting discontent among the young. Then came a crippling drought, lasting roughly 14 years.\n\nIn short, a water crisis \u2014 whether caused by nature, human mismanagement, or both \u2014 can be an early warning signal of trouble ahead. A panel of retired United States military officials warned in December that water stress, which they defined as a shortage of fresh water, would emerge as \u201ca growing factor in the world\u2019s hot spots and conflict areas.\u201d\n\n\u201cWith escalating global population and the impact of a changing climate, we see the challenges of water stress rising with time,\u201d the retired officials concluded in the report by CNA, a research organization based in Arlington, Virginia.\n\nClimate change is projected to make Iran hotter and drier. A former Iranian agriculture minister, Issa Kalantari, once famously said that water scarcity, if left unchecked, would make Iran so harsh that 50 million Iranians would leave the country altogether.", "title": "Warming, Water Crisis, Then Unrest: How Iran Fits an Alarming Pattern", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLOS ANGELES \u2014 Ending a power struggle in its senior ranks, Warner Bros. on Tuesday gave control of worldwide film production, marketing and distribution to Toby Emmerich, who rose through the studio by finding hits like \u201cIt\u201d and shepherding \u201cThe Lord of the Rings\u201d movies.\n\nSue Kroll, one of Hollywood\u2019s highest-ranking female executives, will leave Warner\u2019s management team on April 1 to become a producer on the studio\u2019s lot, where she will have offices next to Clint Eastwood and work on films like a remake of \u201cA Star Is Born.\u201d Ms. Kroll had run Warner\u2019s film marketing and distribution division.\n\n\u201cI love movies, and working even more closely with the filmmakers who bring great stories to life is both a great opportunity and an exciting new challenge for me,\u201d Ms. Kroll said in a statement. In an email to Warner employees, Kevin Tsujihara, the studio\u2019s chairman and chief executive, called her \u201ca legend in the marketing world.\u201d\n\nThe changes are being made as Warner anticipates new corporate oversight. AT&T is fighting the Justice Department for approval of its $85.4 billion takeover of Time Warner, the studio\u2019s parent company.", "title": "Warner Bros. Shakes Up Senior Film Ranks, Ending a Power Struggle", "authors": ["Brooks Barnes"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWho might succeed Warren Buffett became clearer Wednesday.\n\nMr. Buffett\u2019s investment vehicle, Berkshire Hathaway, named Gregory E. Abel and Ajit Jain as vice chairmen. Mr. Abel is the chief executive and chairman of Berkshire\u2019s energy unit and will become vice chairman of the conglomerate\u2019s non-insurance businesses. Mr. Jain, the longtime head of Berkshire\u2019s vast reinsurance operations, will serve as vice chairman of Berkshire's insurance operations.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s part of a movement toward succession over time,\u201d Mr. Buffett said in an interview on CNBC. \u201cThey are the two key figures at Berkshire. This would have made sense five years ago, too. They both have Berkshire in their blood. They love the company. They know their operations like the back of their hand. So it's very good for Berkshire. And it's even better for me.\u201d\n\nWho Berkshire would pick to succeed Mr. Buffett as chief executive has long been on the minds of investors. Mr. Buffett has kept his succession plan closely guarded, though in recent years, a clearer picture has emerged.\n\nMr. Buffett has said that his responsibilities \u2014 chairman, chief executive and chief investment officer \u2014 would be split into three once he departs. His son Howard will be chairman. Todd Combs and Ted Weschler, the two investment managers that Berkshire hired in recent years, will be the chief stock pickers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWho would take over as chief executive has remained the big question. In a 2011 filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Berkshire said there were \u201cfour current Berkshire subsidiary managers who are capable of being CEO.\u201d\n\nFour years later, Charlie Munger, Berkshire\u2019s vice chairman, praised Mr. Abel and Mr. Jain in a shareholder letter, saying \u201cin some important ways, each is a better business executive than Buffett.\u201d That set off speculation that the race to succeed Mr. Buffett was down to two.", "title": "Warren Buffett\u2019s Succession Plan Is Down to Two", "authors": ["Michael J. De La Merced"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Miller\u2019s films depicted winter sports with grandeur, beauty and a mischievous sense of fun that attracted viewers who had never set foot on a slope. The mainstream appeal of his films helped turn winter sports from a niche pursuit to a widely popular pastime and a multibillion-dollar industry.\n\n\u201cWarren Miller is the man who made the snowball that created the whole industry,\u201d Dirk Collins, a founder of the adventure sports production company Teton Gravity Research, told Outside magazine for a 2004 profile of Mr. Miller.\n\nWithout any cinematic training, while working as a ski instructor in Sun Valley, Mr. Miller created \u201cDeep and Light\u201d in 1949 using a borrowed 16-millimeter movie camera. It was the first of more than 500 feature and promotional films he made.\n\nPhoto\n\nHis feature films hewed to a simple formula, depicting winter-sport athletes in challenging locales, leavened with wipeouts and shots of pretty female skiers. Performers spanned generations, including Jean-Claude Killy, who won three Olympic gold medals in 1968, and Stein Eriksen, who won one in 1952. But in all his movies, the narration of Mr. Miller, who delivered deadpan wisecracks in his trademark baritone, loomed largest.\n\n\u201cLooking back on what set my films apart,\u201d he recalled in his autobiography, \u201cFreedom Found\u201d (2016), \u201cit was the emphasis on entertaining people, which means making them laugh.\u201d\n\nHaving known privation while growing up during the Depression and in his early days as a ski bum, Mr. Miller was no snob. He was inclusive in his embrace of the mountain scene, featuring fads such as freestyle ballet skiing and snow kayaking in his films. His \u201cEscape to Ski\u201d (1988) championed snowboarding at a time when that upstart activity was barred at many ski resorts across the United States.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor the first 14 years of his career, Mr. Miller provided all the photography, editing and music for his movies, and spent up to eight months traveling to mountain locations around the world. He screened his films in rented halls with live narration, a practice developed by the ski cinema pioneer John Jay.\n\nAs skiing grew in popularity, so did Mr. Miller\u2019s films. By 1960 he was booked for screenings in more than 100 cities. Unable to attend every show, he began recording narration. His audience did not seem to mind. Mr. Miller\u2019s films became an annual autumn rite among skiers looking forward to the season\u2019s first snows.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Miller\u2019s films also kept pace with new styles of skiing and innovations in the sport over the decades. In 1954 he filmed Stein Eriksen performing a front flip on skis, one of the earliest examples of what would become known as freestyle skiing. In 1985 he released \u201cSteep and Deep,\u201d a film that featured a fresh generation of extreme skiers who launched from cliffs and performed tricks and showed how far freestyle skiing had come in three decades.\n\nBorn on Oct. 15, 1924, in Hollywood, Mr. Miller was the youngest of three children. His father, Albert, was a radio actor, and his mother, Elena, sewed quilts for the Works Progress Administration during the Depression.\n\nMr. Miller learned to ski as a Boy Scout on trips to the San Gabriel Mountains, north of Los Angeles. In 1942 he enrolled in a naval officers\u2019 training program at the University of Southern California, where he studied astrophysics. He left the university to serve in the Pacific during World War II. Discharged in 1946, he bought his first movie camera with a $100 Navy bonus and set off for the mountains.\n\nIn 1989 Mr. Miller sold Warren Miller Entertainment \u2014 including his archives and the rights to his voice and name \u2014 to his son Kurt and a partner. He continued to narrate films until 2005 as the company changed hands again, first to Time Warner in 2002, then to the Bonnier Corporation, a Swedish publisher. Active Interest Media acquired the company in 2013.\n\nIn September 2009, Warren Miller Entertainment sued a Colorado production company for copyright infringement after Mr. Miller narrated one of its films, arguing that he had relinquished the right to use his name and voice in other ski films when he sold the company. Mr. Miller, in turn, filed a motion to intervene, essentially asking that the Miller company sue him instead. A year later, an arbitration panel determined that Mr. Miller\u2019s appearance in the film did not cause harm to the company and that Mr. Miller was free to use his own name, likeness, voice and brand in anything outside of ski movies.\n\nVideo\n\nIn 2016 he returned to narrate a section of a Warren Miller Entertainment film, \u201cHere, There & Everywhere,\u201d featuring the skier Ingrid Backstrom and the rider Jeremy Jones.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn addition to his son Kurt, Mr. Miller is survived by his wife of 30 years, Laurie; another son, Scott; a daughter, Chris Lucero; a stepson, Colin Kaufmann; and five grandchildren.\n\nMr. Miller continued to write a weekly column about the outdoors for several small newspapers in the West and served as honorary director of skiing at the Yellowstone Club in Big Sky, Mont., an exclusive enclave whose members have included Bill Gates and former Vice President Dan Quayle.\n\nIn a 2008 speech, Mr. Miller summed up with uncharacteristic seriousness what had led him \u2014 as well as ski bums and heads of state and corporations \u2014 to head for the mountains.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s our search for freedom, \u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s what it\u2019s all about \u2014 man\u2019s instinctive search for freedom.\u201d", "title": "Warren Miller, Ski Bum Turned Filmmaker, Is Dead at 93", "authors": ["Matt Higgins"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere\u2019s a lot of time, and I would be very derelict in my duty if I said I wasn\u2019t worried,\u201d said Cathryn Oakley, state legislative director and senior counsel at the Human Rights Campaign, which helped organize opposition to many proposals seen as harmful to gay and transgender people, among others. \u201cWe as advocates, but also our allies, will be very sorry if we take our eyes off the ball,\u201d she said.\n\nEven so, many pending bills that are of the greatest concern to gay and transgender rights activists are stalled or have effectively been defeated.\n\nIn South Carolina, for instance, a bill about restricting restroom access remains technically alive, but has been languishing in a committee for more than a year. And in Tennessee, a lawmaker withdrew his proposal to give state backing to school officials who impose restrictive bathroom policies, only eight days after he introduced it.\n\n\u201cI think people are tempering, and I think they\u2019re thinking harder about what can be achieved, what needs to be achieved,\u201d said Robin Fretwell Wilson, a law professor at the University of Illinois who has written extensively about the intersection of gay rights and religious freedom. \u201cThere\u2019s been a slow IV drip of common sense to legislators, and you have lots and lots of people speaking to them and saying, \u2018It\u2019s not viable to do an extreme thing.\u2019\u201d\n\nFor generations, and especially in the 31 months since the United States Supreme Court recognized a constitutional right to same-sex marriage, the legislatures of the South have been a cultural battleground.\n\nMississippi passed, and has so far successfully defended in court, a law allowing people to use their religious beliefs to justify refusing to provide services to gay people. North Carolina was the setting for the legal and cultural clash over restrooms and discrimination protections that drew national attention. Last year, Alabama passed a law allowing faith-based adoption groups to refuse to work with same-sex couples and still keep their state licenses. And a candidate there who had publicly condemned gay people and tried to block same-sex marriages in the state nearly won election to the United States Senate.\n\nOn the other hand, Gov. Nathan Deal of Georgia vetoed a bill that lawmakers passed in 2016 to shield religious groups from repercussions if they refused to employ or serve gay people. In Tennessee, two bills that reaffirm the state Constitution\u2019s view that marriage is between a man and a woman, and that criticize the Supreme Court\u2019s decision legalizing same-sex marriage as \u201ca lawless opinion with no basis in American law or history,\u201d have sputtered.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd in Texas, where some of the country\u2019s most contentious bills on gay and transgender rights have been brought up, the Legislature is not scheduled to meet at all in 2018. A \u201cbathroom bill\u201d failed twice there last year.\n\nObservers on all sides say it is too early to know with certainty whether more contentious social legislation will eventually emerge this year. But the evidence so far suggests that the pace has slowed markedly.\n\nLawmakers, advocates and experts offer several explanations for this year\u2019s apparent falloff. Washington figures prominently in some of them: Legislators are waiting to see what the Supreme Court decides in a major case involving a baker's refusal to make a wedding cake for a gay couple, some say. And many conservatives are said to be focused on pushing ahead at the federal rather than state level while Republicans control Congress and the White House.\n\nPhoto\n\nThere are also worries that lawmakers have been distracted for too long from practical issues like education and infrastructure. And some point to a creeping sense of rancor fatigue.\n\n\u201cAfter you have a bill come up two or three years in a row, or an issue, you sort of lose the fervor,\u201d said Steven Dickerson, a Republican state senator in Tennessee.\n\nSteven W. Long, a South Carolina Republican who sponsored the restroom bill that is mired in the Legislature there, said that he and people who share his views know they may not see swift action.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
