David Goodman"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "What information do I need to complete my submission?\n\nYou must include your full names, the date of your event and the approximate time of day. We need your address, postsecondary education and occupations. Also please mention any noteworthy awards you received, as well as charitable activities and special achievements. And tell us how you met.\n\nWe also require information on the residences and occupations of the couple\u2019s parents. Please include this even if the parents are deceased.\n\nSubmissions are rewritten, fact-checked and edited to Times standards.\n\nWe must have the name, title and religious and/or legal affiliation of the person who will legally sign the official certificate. For an interfaith event, include the names and affiliations of any other celebrant who will participate with the officiant, though please limit to only one other celebrant. Also state the exact location of the event.\n\nAll announcements must include daytime, evening and cellphone numbers for the couple and their parents. We also need the office phone numbers for those performing the ceremony. Submissions without telephone numbers cannot be considered.\n\nImportant Photo Information\n\nWhat photo requirements are there?\n\nThe Weddings pages typically publish formal portraits of couples and individual brides. Couples posing for pictures should arrange themselves with their eyebrows on the same level and with their heads fairly close together with plenty of space at the top and sides of the couple\u2019s heads. Pictures should be in color and in a horizontal format. Include the photographer\u2019s name if professional credit is required. Examples of formal portraits can be found here, here and here.", "title": "Wedding Submission FAQs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Seven weeks after Matt Lauer was ousted from NBC\u2019s \u201cToday\u201d amid allegations of sexual misconduct, there has been another shake-up at the morning show.\n\nNBC said on Wednesday that Don Nash, the show\u2019s executive producer since 2012, would leave and would be succeeded by Libby Leist, a veteran \u201cToday\u201d producer with deep ties to Washington and a strong working relationship with Savannah Guthrie, a co-anchor. The move makes Ms. Leist the first woman to hold the top producing job for the show\u2019s first two hours.\n\n\u201cToday\u201d has surged in the ratings since Mr. Lauer\u2019s firing, beating ABC\u2019s \u201cGood Morning America\u201d for seven straight weeks, its longest such streak in nearly six years. Some people in the television industry have asked whether the NBC show\u2019s rise reflects early interest in the post-Lauer era at \u201cToday\u201d \u2014 Hoda Kotb was named as his permanent replacement this month \u2014 or whether it signals a long-term shift. Even NBC officials have been caught off guard by the strong viewership figures.\n\nThe ratings improvement makes Mr. Nash\u2019s departure something of a surprise, although changes in show anchors are often accompanied by changes at the executive producer level. Mr. Nash had a close working relationship with Mr. Lauer.", "title": "Weeks After Matt Lauer Is Ousted, \u2018Today\u2019 Changes Show\u2019s Top Producer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIf it was a hit in the 1980s or 1990s, there\u2019s a good chance it will be back soon.\n\nCBS announced on Wednesday that \u201cMurphy Brown,\u201d its 1988-98 TV newsroom sitcom, was making its return to prime time. It joins revivals of numerous other vintage shows \u2014 including \u201cRoseanne,\u201d \u201cWill & Grace,\u201d \u201cFull House,\u201d \u201cAmazing Stories,\u201d \u201cTwin Peaks\u201d and \u201cThe X-Files\u201d \u2014 to get the green light in recent years from executives eager to foist attention-grabbing names in front of an increasingly distracted audience.\n\nCBS ordered 13 episodes and said the sitcom will be part of its 2018-19 season. Candice Bergen, who won five Emmys for her work on the show, will return in the title role. Diane English, the creator of \u201cMurphy Brown,\u201d who also produced lesser-known 1990s programs like \u201cLove & War,\u201d \u201cInk\u201d and \u201cDouble Rush,\u201d will be back as a writer and executive producer.\n\nThe winner of the best comedy Emmy in 1990 and 1992, \u201cMurphy Brown\u201d aired mostly on Monday nights and was regularly a top 10 show. While the sitcom, like its 1970s predecessor \u201cThe Mary Tyler Moore Show,\u201d focused on the workplace, it included scenes from the main character\u2019s home life, many of which featured the actor Robert Pastorelli as a perfectionist house painter. Mr. Pastorelli died of a narcotics overdose in 2004.\n\nIn 1992, the show\u2019s main character, a single divorced woman, became a subject of the culture wars of the day when Vice President Dan Quayle criticized her decision to have a child outside marriage. More than two decades later, Murphy Brown \u201creturns to a world of cable news, social media, fake news and a very different political and cultural climate,\u201d CBS said in a statement.", "title": "Welcome Back, Murphy Brown: CBS Joins the Reboot Craze", "authors": ["John Koblin"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "In Columbus, Ohio, Nationwide Realty Investors has constructed the 75-acre, $1 billion Arena District, with an N.H.L. arena (home to the Blue Jackets), surrounded by 1,030 apartments, 2 million square feet of commercial space for 80 businesses, a minor-league baseball stadium, restaurants and stores. In Cincinnati, the Banks, a new $1 billion mixed-used district, has emerged on the Ohio River shoreline between the city\u2019s baseball and football stadiums. In Inglewood, Calif., a $3.8 billion, 298-acre mixed-use development currently under construction will include a privately financed N.F.L. stadium to be shared by the Los Angeles Rams and the newly located Los Angeles Chargers.\n\nAnd in Detroit, the $863-million, 19,500-seat Little Caesar\u2019s Arena, home to both the Pistons and the Red Wings, opened last summer in amid the 50-block District Detroit, a $1.2 billion mixed-use neighborhood.\n\nThe explosion in mixed-use developments like these is owed, in part, to the urban American economic renaissance. City populations grew faster from 2010 to 2016 than those in the suburbs, reversing a 60-year trend that started in 1950, according to census data. And cities \u2014 not suburbs \u2014 are the now primary generators of the nation\u2019s economic growth, according to research compiled by the Federal Reserve.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the one-square-mile effect,\u201d said Bruce Katz, an urban development specialist at the Brookings Institution. \u201cDowntowns and midtowns possess an enormous amount of value in a relatively small geography.\u201d\n\nStrong-Arming Local Governments\n\nFor years, owners used their team\u2019s popularity or perceived economic importance to strong-arm government officials. In many cases, owners threatened to move their teams if governments did not build them new stadiums along with the roads and public utilities needed to operate them.\n\nA 2016 study by the Brookings Institution found that 45 stadiums and arenas for the four major professional sports \u2014 football, baseball, basketball, hockey \u2014 were constructed or renovated in the United States from 2000 to 2014 at a cost of nearly $28 billion. Of that, $13 billion was publicly financed with tax-exempt bonds.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut previous projects that foundered, particularly in the 1990s, point up the potential risk of these investments. \u201cWhat was at work in those deals was the idea that a large public subsidy for a stand-alone facility would keep the team in place and would stimulate economic activity,\u201d said Roger Noll, emeritus professor of economics at Stanford University. \u201cThe financial catastrophes that occurred convinced cities and residents that multimillion-dollar subsidies for stand-alone stadiums are a loser.\u201d\n\nExamples of that are legion, particularly for N.F.L. stadiums. In the early 1990s, St. Louis city and county, and the state of Missouri, spent $258 million to build a 70,000-seat domed stadium downtown to attract an NFL team. The city lured the Rams, who played in the stadium from 1995 to 2015 before moving back to Los Angeles. The city, county and state still have $140 million in debt, and millions more in annual maintenance costs to pay until the debt service is completed \u2014 on an empty stadium \u2014 at the end of 2021.\n\nUrban design specialists also raised their voices in opposition to the old model. They noted that generous public-stadium financing ignored almost every facet of sound real estate development, like location. America was producing a generation of isolated arenas in the suburbs and countryside, ringed by giant parking lots, many of which sat empty much of the year.\n\nPhoto\n\nThat certainly characterized Detroit\u2019s comparatively brief experience with suburban sports stadiums. In 1975, the NFL Lions moved from the nine-acre, 63-year-old Tigers Stadium in Detroit\u2019s Corktown neighborhood to the $55.7 million Silver Dome in Pontiac, which was surrounded by over 100 acres of surface parking near the center of the struggling Oakland County city. The team stayed until 2002, when it returned to Ford Field, a $500 million stadium alongside the two-year-old $300 million Comerica Park, the baseball Tiger\u2019s new home on Woodward Avenue in downtown Detroit. Both stadiums were partially financed with taxpayer dollars.\n\nLast year, Little Caesars Arena opened across the avenue, completing a strategic development vision, developed by business and civic leaders in the 1990s, that focused on professional sports as a catalyst for Detroit\u2019s revival. The NBA Pistons play in the new arena after spending the previous 29 seasons in The Palace of Auburn Hills, a 22,000-seat arena in a prosperous suburb 33 miles north of downtown Detroit that opened in 1988.\n\nThe Palace held its last event in September and is scheduled for demolition. Its 109-acre site, most of it surface parking, is being rezoned as a campus for high tech business and research.\n\nA Role Model in Kansas City\n\nIf there is particularly good model for what\u2019s happening in Sacramento, it can probably be found in Kansas City and the city\u2019s Power and Light District. The $1 billion, 12-block district features a 150,000-square-foot covered plaza, more than 50 restaurants and taverns and hundreds of market-rate apartments. It opened in 2007 next to the city\u2019s publicly financed $263 million, 18,500-seat Sprint Center, which, though it does not host a professional team, has been frequently used as a site for college basketball games, including regional rounds of the annual NCAA tournament.\n\nA decade later, the Power and Light District, developed by the Cordish Companies \u2014 whose chief executive, David Cordish, is credited with being a leader in sports-focused mixed-use development \u2014 is cited by city officials as the primary reason that a 2.5-mile, $102 million downtown streetcar line in the city center started in 2016. Thousands of new apartments opened, the downtown population increased to 30,000 from 8,000, and city tax revenue soared.\n\nPhoto\n\nTroy Schulte, city manager of Kansas City, explained how the project was initially seen as a risk but eventually remade his city and its finances. \u201cI was budget director at the time,\u201d he said. \u201cI was the guy saying, \u2018I don\u2019t know if this is going to pay for itself.\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe transition from empty parcels to crowded streets was swift. H & R Block opened its 17-story, 531,000 square foot headquarters in the neighborhood in 2006.\n\nA year later, the arena opened and so did a 150,000-square-foot KC Live! entertainment plaza across the street. Office workers strolled the sidewalks by day. Thousands more rolled into town for dinner and drinks before concerts and games, and stayed afterward to party.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Schulte and his colleagues have been criticized for a consultant\u2019s overly enthusiastic estimate that the district would generate sufficient tax revenue to service the bond debt, which is $17 million this year. The district produces $6 million in revenue from taxes on property, sales, earnings and utilities.\n\n\u201cThat debt was issued with almost no safety cushion,\u201d a former city councilman, Dan Cofran, told The Kansas City Star in 2015. \u201cIt was reckless.\u201d Mr. Cofran said the project should have been smaller and constructed in stages.\n\nMr. Schulte disagrees. He said the city tried to finance the development with a dedicated sales tax, which was rejected in a referendum. Depleted at its center and stranded in an era of sluggish growth, the city pursued what he said was the next best option \u2014 selling municipal bonds paid for with revenue from a special taxing district.\n\nKansas City\u2019s tax base now raises $8 billion annually, with $2 billion from downtown activity. Before the Power and Light District opened, the city\u2019s tax base was $5 billion with $1 billion from downtown. There are now 40,000 downtown jobs, twice as many as a decade ago.\n\nMr. Schulte acknowledges that although tax revenue from the district is steadily increasing, it is not clear that enough will be generated to cover the debt service. \u201cBut from the perspective of economic development and economic resurgence,\u201d he said, \u201cit\u2019s the best $300 million we\u2019ve ever spent.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nKeeping the Kings in Sacramento\n\nSacramento\u2019s downtown was ready for a makeover back in 2013, when Mr. Ranadiv\u00e9 met with Mayor Kevin Johnson to consider a pitch by David Stern, then the N.B.A. commissioner, to buy the Kings.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA growing city of about 480,000, and the hub of a seven-county metropolitan region with 2.4 million residents, Sacramento struggled for years to replace the home of the Kings, the 17,300-seat Sleep Train Arena, the smallest in the N.B.A. and which the team had played in since 1988.\n\nVarious proposals to build a new arena in the same area, publicly financed with sales tax or other public sources were floated and then sunk, two times by failed ballot measures. As the venue aged and the Kings consistently lost more games than they won, the owners, the Maloof brothers, sought to sell the team. A buyer\u2019s group from Seattle, which lost its own N.B.A. team to Oklahoma City in 2008, was interested. But city officials were determined to keep the team \u2014 and Mr. Ranadiv\u00e9, who had become a Silicon Valley billionaire with the software company he founded, was a prime recruit to help make that happen.\n\nMr. Ranadiv\u00e9 had earlier parlayed the success of his company, TIBCO Software, into a role as vice chairman and co-owner of the Golden State Warriors, lending him credibility with Mr. Stern and Mr. Johnson, who himself had been an N.B.A. all-star during the 1990s.\n\nMr. Johnson had also become a fan of Mr. Ranadiv\u00e9\u2019s story, described in a 2009 New Yorker article by Malcolm Gladwell. In 1973, when he was 16, Mr. Ranadiv\u00e9 emigrated from India and arrived in the United States with $50 in his pocket. A graduate of M.I.T. and Harvard, in 1985 he founded a company that enabled investors and traders to instantly collect and analyze large amounts of data in real time.\n\nAs part of the pitch, Mr. Ranadiv\u00e9 and Mr. Johnson toured a decrepit downtown mall that would be replaced with a new arena for the Kings. The mayor proposed spending $255 million, essentially a long-term loan, to construct the $560 million facility.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Ranadiv\u00e9 would be expected to pay the balance, plus 65 percent of the city\u2019s investment through a 35-year lease agreement and property taxes. When all was said and done, Sacramento\u2019s investment in an arena that it would own would be $86.7 million.\n\nThe proposal departed from almost every previous arena-financing deal. Arena-construction packages that relied on public investments typically featured taxpayers paying all, or nearly all of the development costs without ever being paid back.\n\nWould Mr. Ranadiv\u00e9 bite?\n\nHe did. Visiting downtown Sacramento that day, he said, he envisioned crowds on the sidewalks, and in the space occupied by the near-empty 42-year-old mall, he saw a plaza surrounded by a state-of-the art arena, hotel, offices, restaurants and stores. And he sensed opportunity in a city desperate to keep its N.B.A. franchise.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn May 2013, as the principal investor, Mr. Ranadiv\u00e9 bought the Kings for $534 million, at the time the highest price paid for an N.B.A. franchise up to that date. (It\u2019s since been eclipsed by the $2.2 billion paid last September for the Houston Rockets.) In buying the Kings, and agreeing to pay for more than half the new arena, he hoped to leverage his knowledge in technology, sports, information, and design to not only gain control of a sports franchise, but to revive what he considered an important American city.\n\nThough Mr. Ranadiv\u00e9 has turned out be a somewhat polarizing figure among fans of the Kings, the project itself has since unleashed more than $1 billion more in new construction and redevelopment in surrounding blocks. And just north of the city center and Downtown Commons, on the site of the Sacramento\u2019s former 244-acre Union Pacific rail yard, a local development group broke ground in the summer on a second sports-focused, mixed-use neighborhood anchored by a privately financed, $245 million, 20,000-seat outdoor major league soccer stadium.\n\n\u201cFour years ago, I said no other city is going to steal our team,\u201d Mr. Ranadiv\u00e9 said. \u201cThe Kings are the heart and soul of the city.\u201d", "title": "Welcome to the Neighborhood: America\u2019s Sports Stadiums Are Moving Downtown", "authors": ["Keith Schneider"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Wendell Castle, the whimsical designer who coaxed wood into weird, mind-bending shapes that blurred the boundary between serviceable furniture and fine art, died on Jan. 20 at his home in Scottsville, N.Y., near Rochester. He was 85.\n\nThe cause was complications of leukemia, his brother, Wayne, said.\n\n\u201cWendell is the most important postwar American furniture designer, by a long shot,\u201d Glenn Adamson, senior research scholar at the Yale Center for British Art and the former director of New York\u2019s Museum of Arts and Design, told Hyperallergic, an online arts forum.\n\nTrained as an industrial designer and a sculptor, Mr. Castle was after World War II part of what was known as the American studio craft movement. His idiosyncratic works became prized as collectibles, if not necessarily for comfort.", "title": "Wendell Castle, 85, Dies; Blurred the Line Between Furniture and Art", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "A collection of bright West African soups made in Harlem is a good way to put a steaming bowl on the table. Densely textured groundnut (peanut) soup has spicy heat and, thinned a bit, is also excellent cold. Melon seed is the most unusual of the lot, packed with vegetables. Thick Gbegiri, made from Nigerian honey peas, combines mellowness with some chile fire, and does well with chicken added. The smooth, ruddy Obe Ata tomato soup pops with a faintly peppered kick that still shines if you enrich it with some cream: Egunsifoods African soups, Fairway Markets Manhattan (except Kips Bay) and Red Hook, Brooklyn; $8.99 for 17.3 ounces, $40 for four containers (frozen) from egunsifoods.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "West African Soups: When Chicken Noodle Gets Boring", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe West Coast albacore tuna fishery is so well managed in the Pacific that it gets a green light from the Monterey Bay Aquarium\u2019s Seafood Watch program. Almost all the fish, which are pole-caught and frozen on the boats, are shipped to Japan for sushi, but Vinny Milburn, an owner of Greenpoint Fish & Lobster, has some of the fish through May. Albacore is pink, excellently mild and sweet when raw in sashimi, crudo or tartare, and acquires a subtle beefiness when seared with the interior still rare. Slowly poach it in seasoned olive oil for confit: Boneless albacore tuna, previously frozen and lightly brined to prevent freezer burn, $16.99 a pound, Greenpoint Fish & Lobster, 114 Nassau Avenue (Eckford Street), Greenpoint, Brooklyn, 718-349-0400, and 5-43 48th Avenue (Vernon Boulevard), Long Island City, Queens, 718-472-2040, greenpointfish.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "West Coast Albacore Tuna Now Available in Brooklyn", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nYears of scolding from health experts about a good night\u2019s rest may be breaking through.\n\nAmericans are finally getting more sleep \u2014 about 18 minutes more per weeknight compared with 2003.\n\nIt may not sound like much, but researchers say it\u2019s a positive sign.\n\nWeeknight Sleep, in Hours Americans gained an average 1.4 minutes per year in weeknight sleep between 2003 and 2016. 8.4 8.2 8.0 8.3 2004 2006 2008 2010 2012 2014 2016\n\n\u201cIf we only got more sleep, we would then see that we actually perform better and would probably be more creative and more productive during the day,\u201d said Dr. Mathias Basner, the associate professor of sleep and chronobiology in psychiatry at the University of Pennsylvania and the lead author of the analysis of federal survey data, published this month in the journal \u201cSleep.\u201d\n\nThe incremental gains took place over 13 years. Dr. Basner and his colleague, Dr. David F. Dinges, found that Americans gained about 1.4 minutes of sleep per weeknight each year between 2003 and 2016.\n\nPeople also slept more on weekends, though the improvement was not as great \u2014 an extra 50 seconds of sleep per weekend night per year, a total gain of about 11 minutes.\n\nWeekend Sleep, in Hours Americans gained about 50 seconds per year in sleep on weekend nights from 2003 to 2016. 9.3 9.2 9.1 9.0 8.9 9.2 2004 2006 2008 2010 2012 2014 2016\n\nOn average, Americans get more than eight hours of sleep on weeknights and more on weekends, according to the data. But sleep length varies widely. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, more than a third of adults get insufficient sleep, which it defines as less than seven hours.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMany studies have pointed to the potential health benefits of a good night\u2019s sleep. Poor sleep has been linked to weight gain, focus issues and even an increased risk of Type 2 diabetes and heart disease. It can even exacerbate relationship problems.", "title": "We\u2019re Getting More Sleep. A Whole 18 Minutes. It\u2019s Not Enough.", "authors": ["Niraj Chokshi"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "The world has about four times the number of inhabitants it did in 1918, including hundreds of millions of people, poultry and pigs living close together. This provides a potent biologic mixing bowl and natural influenza virus mutation factory. What\u2019s more, nearly any point on the planet is accessible to any other point within hours, and there are more than a billion international border crossings each year. The virus will spread rapidly.\n\nWhen a pandemic does strike, we\u2019ll be in trouble in part because American hospitals and pharmacies keep in stock no more than a few days supply of most lifesaving drugs, almost all of which are made in Asia. Worldwide manufacturing and shipping are highly susceptible to disruption, which could mean shortages in many areas.\n\nA 1918-type influenza pandemic could cause ruin on the order of what the Black Death did to 14th-century Europe, but on a global scale. Like the Black Death, such a pandemic would alter the course of history.\n\nOne avian influenza strain, H7N9, is causing widespread infection in Chinese poultry and occasionally infecting humans. During the 2016-17 flu season, 759 Chinese who had been in contact with infected poultry were stricken; 281 of them died. While H7N9 still is rarely transmitted human to human, it may be just one spin of the genetic roulette wheel away from mutations that could make it the next human pandemic strain.\n\nWe are not prepared. Our current vaccines are based on 1940s research. Deploying them against a severe global pandemic would be equivalent to trying to stop an advancing battle tank with a single rifle. Limited global manufacturing capacity combined with the five to six months it takes to make these vaccines mean many people would never even have a chance to be vaccinated. Little is being done to aggressively change this unacceptable situation. We will have worldwide flu pandemics. Only their severity is unknown.", "title": "Opinion | We\u2019re Not Ready for a Flu Pandemic", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "By Claire Fitzsimmons\n\nI returned to Australia this week after living in New York for six exhausting years.\n\nI feel like I\u2019ve woken up on another planet. The culture shock is visual and visceral. I forgot how clean the streets were. The sound of the birds, relentless and reassuring. Everything happens so slowly.\n\nBut the one thing I notice most abruptly is the men at work.\n\nEverywhere I go. Men. Working.\n\nMen building roads.\n\nMen constructing buildings,\n\nMen driving Utes full of building materials.\n\nMen on the side of the road.\n\nMen digging holes.\n\nThe men are plumbers. The men are builders.\n\nThe men are miners.\n\nThe men are impossible to miss, in their hi-vis vests.\n\nBut where are all the women?\n\n(We\u2019re watching the men.)\n\nAdelaide", "title": "We\u2019re Watching the Men", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "So far, Mr. Obama has remained silent on the shutdown.\n\nThe Senate majority leader\n\n2013 \u2014 Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada\n\n\u201cYou know with a bully you cannot let them slap you around, because they slap you around today, they slap you five or six times tomorrow,\u201d Mr. Reid, a former boxer, continued. \u201cWe are not going to be bullied.\u201d \u2014 Sept. 30, 2013 \u201cShe\u2019s struggling because she doesn\u2019t make that much money, and now to have her job gone. It\u2019s that way all over America. And why? To extract political concessions through hostage taking of one issue, one issue: Obamacare.\u201d \u2014 Oct. 1, 2013\n\n2018 \u2014 Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky\n\n\u201cThe American people, the citizens who actually elected us, will be watching. They will see which senators make the patriotic decision to stand up for the American people to vote to continue government funding.\u201d \u201cThey will see which senators, he continued, \u201chold the entire country hostage until we pass an immigration bill they haven\u2019t even written yet. This is completely unfair and uncompassionate.\u201d \u2014 January 18, 2018\n\nThe Senate minority leader\n\n2013 \u2014 Mr. McConnell\n\n\u201cWe got off track with a tactical error earlier starting in July and August that diverted our attention away from what was achievable,\u201d Mr. McConnell said in an interview with Politico. \u201cAnd so we\u2019ll be back at it in January and February, which is why the best you can say is, \u2018It\u2019s a punt.\u2019\u201d \u2014 Oct. 17, 2013\n\n2018 \u2014 Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re going to have to go in a different direction. Ideally, we would all roll up our sleeves and try to reach an agreement on all of the issues we need to resolve,\u201d Mr. Schumer said. \u201cWe could easily sit down and find a cosmic agreement that would get the support of the majority on both sides, in both houses, and keep the government open. Despite all the rhetoric around here, I genuinely believe that. The one thing standing in our way is the unrelenting flow of chaos from the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue. It has reduced the Republicans to shambles. We barely know who to negotiate with.\u201d \u2014 January 18, 2018\n\nMick Mulvaney\n\n2013\n\nMr. Mulvaney was then Representative Mick Mulvaney, Republican of South Carolina, and a member of the House Freedom Caucus, which was largely blamed for setting off the shutdown. His office released the following statement during the shutdown.\n\n\u201cIn many ways, then, this is a government \u2018slowdown\u2019 more than it is a \u2018shutdown.\u2019 I know that is not much consolation for folks who are personally affected by the 25% of government that is closed, but again, the House is working to fix that.\u201d\n\n2018\n\nNow, Mr. Mulvaney is the president\u2019s budget director and the acting director of the Consumer and Financial Protection Bureau.\n\n\u201cOne of the things that I\u2019ve learned since I\u2019ve been in this office is that \u2014 there\u2019s no other way to describe it \u2014 but the Obama administration weaponized the shutdown in 2013. What they didn\u2019t tell you was that they did not encourage agencies to use carry forward funds, funds that they were sitting on, nor did they encourage agencies to use transfer authority.\u201d \u2014 Jan. 19, 2018, during a White House briefing\n\nPaul Ryan\n\n2013\n\nRepresentative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, was then the chairman of the House Budget Committee.\n\n\u201cRight now, we need to find common ground. We need to open the federal government. We need to pay our bills today \u2014 and make sure we can pay our bills tomorrow,\u201d Mr. Ryan wrote in an op-ed for The Wall Street Journal. \u201cI want a budget agreement \u2014 because if we don\u2019t make the tough decisions now, we\u2019ll face only tougher decisions later. We can work together. We can do some good. All it takes is leadership \u2014 and for the president to come to the table.\u201d \u2014 Oct. 8, 2013\n\n2018\n\nNow, as Speaker of the House, Mr. Ryan\u2019s words carry the weight of congressional leadership.", "title": "We\u2019ve Heard It All Before. Shutdown Talk in 2013 Compared to Today.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Damien Cave, our Australia bureau chief, shares insights on Australia, news of the world, and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. Want to receive it by email? Sign up here.\n\n______\n\nI threw off my Blundstone boots in the baggage claim area, swapping them out for flip-flops. The air-conditioning wheezed hello.\n\nWe\u2019d arrived back in Sydney just in time for an asphalt-melting heat wave, having left New York in the middle of a shark-freezing Arctic cyclone \u2014 and man, was I thrilled to be home.\n\nBecause that, it seems, is where we landed: HOME.\n\nMany people take the concept for granted, but for those of us who move around the world to help explain the world, it\u2019s a process of becoming.", "title": "We\u2019ve Made It Home", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Age: 22\n\nHow many layers are you wearing?\n\nThree. I got a tank top and shirt and a sweater and a jacket.\n\nThat\u2019s four. Everyone else here just dressed for warmth. You have a color scheme.\n\nMy brother taught me about color coordination. I used to just put on everything. He\u2019d be like, \u201cYou\u2019re crazy. You\u2019re not going to get any attention like that.\u201d\n\nWhere are your cargo pants from?\n\nRalph Lauren.\n\nAnd on your feet?\n\nThe LeBrons. I have over 150 pairs of sneakers.", "title": "What 8 Shoppers Wore to the Freezing Market in Union Square", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "What advice have you gotten from your parents, teachers, counselors or other responsible adults in your life about sexting?\n\nIn \u201cTeenagers, Stop Asking for Nude Photos,\u201d Lisa Damour writes:\n\nTeenagers are drafted into a sexual culture that rests on a harmful premise: On the heterosexual field, boys typically play offense and girls play defense. This problematic framework underlies the findings of a new study that documents, in alarming detail, girls\u2019 reports of the common coercive practices boys use to solicit nude digital photographs. An analysis of nearly 500 accounts from 12- to 18-year-old girls about their negative experiences with sexting found that over two-thirds had been asked for explicit images. The majority described facing intense pressure that often began with promises of affection and discretion in exchange for \u201cnudes,\u201d before accelerating to \u201cpersistent requests, anger displays, harassment and threats.\u201d The study drew from comments posted between 2010 and 2016 on A Thin Line, MTV\u2019s campaign against sexting, cyber bullying and digital dating abuse. As one research participant explained about being pressured by her boyfriend, with the shorthand and spelling errors of a texting teenager: my bf preaused me for hours to send him pictures of me naked. Now he threarens to send them out if i dont send hin more really nasty pics. The stuff i have to do is unbelievable. im 14. Other research has found that while both boys and girls send naked images, boys are nearly four times as likely to pressure girls to send sexts as girls are to pressure boys to do so. In the wider culture, it appears we have suddenly come to the limit of our tolerance for the sexualized abuse of power by adult men. A logical next step is to recalibrate some of the toxic norms that have taken hold among teenagers. Most schools and many parents already tell teenagers not to send sexualized selfies. But why don\u2019t we also tell adolescents to stop asking for nude photos from one another?\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\n\n\u2014 To what extent do the experiences with sexting described by teenagers in the article resemble your own experiences? The experiences of your friends?\n\n\u2014 Were you aware of the social and legal consequences of sending and asking for sexually explicit photos from minors? Which consequences surprised you most and why?\n\n\u2014 Do the gender dynamics described in the article, in which girls are more likely to feel pressure to send sexualized selfies than boys are, ring true to you? Do you think girls and boys get different messages about their sexuality from society?", "title": "What Advice Should Parents and Counselors Give Teenagers About Sexting?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor our first Student Opinion question of 2018, we wonder: What do you think will happen this year? What predictions can you make for global, national or local events? For your own personal life? Why?\n\nIn the Opinion essay \u201cWhen Forecasters Get It Wrong: Always,\u201d Ruchir Sharma writes about predictions made one year ago\u2014and just how wrong experts were:\n\nTo borrow from Yogi Berra, it is tough to make predictions, especially about the future. But 2017 was particularly difficult. On many of the biggest forecasts \u2014 global growth, inflation, the trajectory of the big powers \u2014 the experts got the year wrong. They thought the global economy would continue to struggle, inflation would stage a comeback, right-wing nationalism would prevent economic revival in Europe and laggards like Japan, Russia and Brazil would remain weak. They expected the United States to be the one relatively bright spot and that Donald Trump\u2019s promises of tax cuts and protectionism would drive the mighty dollar higher. Instead, President Trump had little impact on the economy, and the dollar fell against every major currency. While American stocks did well, foreign markets did better, because the rest of the world grew faster than expected, and inflation remained quiet. Given up for dead, even Japan bounced back. The nationalist right underachieved, and recovery spread to Europe and beyond. Three-quarters of the globe saw an acceleration in economic growth for the first time in a decade.\n\nBut you might also want to read articles that make predictions about the year ahead in politics (will the U.S. Senate achieve more bipartisan agreement this year?); sports (can any team unseat the New England Patriots as Super Bowl champions?); culture (will the \u201cmost vexing\u201d questions of 2017 be answered?); or fashion (will Ultra Violet be a ubiquitous color? will women stop wearing high heels?).\n\nStudents: Read some of these articles, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 What predictions do you have about our world in 2018 in general?\n\n\u2014 What do you think will happen in global or U.S. politics? What economic predictions can you make?\n\n\u2014 What do you think could happen in the realms of culture, the arts, fashion and style? Be as specific as you can, especially about the aspects of culture that interest you most.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 What about new trends in how people communicate, travel and even shop?\n\n\u2014 When it comes to your life and your loved ones\u2019 lives, what do you hope or believe will happen?", "title": "What Are Your Predictions for 2018?", "authors": ["Shannon Doyne", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "This month, the Trump administration reversed protections for Salvadorans living legally in the United States through a program known as Temporary Protected Status, which allows people whose native countries are afflicted by armed conflict, natural disaster or other dire conditions to remain in the United States. El Salvador was first added to the list in the 1980s as a result of a bloody civil war that lasted 12 years and left 75,000 dead. In 2001, when a pair of earthquakes badly impaired the country\u2019s infrastructure, these protections were renewed. In the books below, two writers captured life during the civil war, while a third follows a pair of twin brothers who immigrated in 2013.\n\nImage\n\nSALVADOR\n\nBy Joan Didion\n\n108 pp. Simon & Schuster. (1983)\n\nBased on a 1982 visit to El Salvador, when the country was in the midst of war, this book documents the violence and bloodshed of that time. Didion writes about the body dumps, where \u201ca skull surrounded by a perfect corona of hair is a not uncommon sight,\u201d and details the macabre lessons about the body\u2019s deterioration that one learns upon arriving. At the time, it was \u201ctaken for granted\u201d that most of the killing was done by government forces, and even students were at risk of being \u201cdisappeared.\u201d Our reviewer wrote that Didion \u201cbrings the country to life so that it ends up invading the flesh. To get rid of it then is as simple as shaking off leeches.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nSMALL HOURS OF THE NIGHT\n\nSelected Poems of Roque Dalton\n\nBY Roque Dalton\n\n228 pp. Curbstone Press. (1996)", "title": "What Awaits Salvadoran Immigrants in Their Native Country?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "ALBANY \u2014 Until very recently, care packages for inmates in New York State prisons could contain a hodgepodge of items to let them know someone on the outside was thinking of them: a fresh apple, a hoodie, a dog-eared paperback.\n\nAs of this month, all those things are no longer allowed.\n\nNew York\u2019s prison system is testing a policy that would bar family members and friends from mailing their incarcerated loved ones a used book, or bringing fresh fruit and vegetables on a visit. They would instead be limited to the catalogs of a handful of state-approved vendors, through whom all packages for inmates would need to be ordered.\n\nThe state corrections department, which introduced the policy as a pilot program in three prisons on Jan. 2, says it will help officers crack down on recent increases in package-room contraband. It plans to implement the policy statewide by the fall.\n\nBut critics say the move would enrich a few private companies, and would limit prisoners to the catalogs\u2019 paltry, price-inflated roster of TV dinners, potato chips and Scrabble dictionaries. A coalition of opponents, from the Legal Aid Society to PEN America to the New York-based National Supermarket Association, has rallied to denounce the policy and petition officials to reconsider. And Representative Joseph Crowley, the House Democratic caucus chairman from New York, urged that the restriction on books be reconsidered, citing their importance to inmates\u2019 successful re-entry into society.", "title": "What Can\u2019t You Send to an Inmate in New York? Apples, Used Books and More", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhat do you think about the place where you live? Do you think you will live there as an adult? Is there another city or town you often think of, and maybe even hope to live in someday?\n\nIn \u201cGreta Gerwig: My Mother, My City,\u201d the actress writes about her hometown, Sacramento, and also her current home, New York City, as well as her mother, whom she calls \u201cthe first New Yorker I ever knew.\u201d\n\nSacramento is a place where you can always see the horizon. It is flat and beautiful and open. But I loved the crowdedness of New York City, how when it rained it seemed like the buildings were raining, not the sky. My mom held my hand tight as she walk-sprinted through the city. She was in her element here; everyone was moving as quickly as she was. She was joyfully sweaty. So was I. The Gerwig women belonged in New York. ... When I finally made it back to New York to attend Barnard College, I was 19 and felt \u201cAh, yes, now life can really begin,\u201d as if life hadn\u2019t been going on before. Against explicit warnings not to, I climbed to the roof of my dorm to look down at the city below. It was my city, or I wanted it to be. But I had no idea which way was uptown and which was downtown. This place I had wanted so badly to be part of was still a mystery.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 Ms. Gerwig at 19 felt this way about New York: \u201cIt was my city, or I wanted it to be.\u201d Do you have similar feelings about a place?\n\n\u2014 If so, what place is it?\n\n\u2014 Like Ms. Gerwig, is there a person or people you associate with your special place? Explain.\n\n\u2014 Describe the place that most captures your imagination. What makes it unique?", "title": "What City or Town Most Captures Your Imagination?", "authors": ["Shannon Doyne", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI actively tried to avoid this,\u201d said Moira Donegan, sitting in the headquarters of The New York Times on Wednesday.\n\nJust over a week ago, she had identified herself for the first time as the creator of an online spreadsheet that allowed women to list men in the media industry who they accused of sexual misconduct. Now, Ms. Donegan was sitting down for her first on-camera interview since revealing her identity.\n\n\u201cI was watching the spreadsheet fill up. It became clear to me that a problem I had already understood as widespread was in fact, much, much broader,\u201d she said.\n\nMs. Donegan, a New York-based writer, spoke with Ainara Tiefenth\u00e4ler, a Times journalist, about the #MeToo movement, the fear of being outed as the spreadsheet\u2019s creator, and the hard work ahead. Below are excerpts from the interview. Some comments have been edited lightly for brevity and clarity.\n\nOn how it all began:\n\nDONEGAN: \u201cThe idea was that women could use it to name somebody who had behaved badly toward them, whether through sexual assault or rape or harassment. I shared it with some women colleagues and friends in my industry, whom I knew had stories. From there, they sent it to people they knew had stories \u2014 and they sent it to people they knew had stories.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOn the spreadsheet\u2019s impact:\n\nDONEGAN: \u201cSo much of the conversation after the spreadsheet was made public was about the methodology of the spreadsheet, and sort of the tactics that anonymous women were using to try and keep each other safe. People were more worried about a hypothetical man whose reputation might be damaged than real women who were really raped.\u201d TIEFENTH\u00c4LER: \u201cIt\u2019s not a hypothetical man, right? There were men who were named on this who had to suffer repercussions in their real life.\u201d DONEGAN: \u201cSome companies decided to conduct investigations. Not all, but some of them did result in men leaving their jobs or being fired, because they were found to have committed wrongdoing. I think it\u2019s their responsibility that they acted that way.\u201d\n\nOn what comes next:\n\nDONEGAN: \u201cThere are a lot of conversations to be had about sex. We\u2019re not done talking about sex. There\u2019s #MeToo in 2017 and 2018. In 2014, there was #YesAllWomen. And in 1991, there was \u2018I Believe Anita.\u2019 It can feel like we\u2019ve been defeated \u2026 but I think that every time we get a little louder, and we get a little closer to making the changes that actually need to be made.\u201d\n\nYou can watch the full video here.", "title": "What Comes After the Media Men List? \u2018A Lot of Hard Work\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "I\u2019m fairly certain Katie would have had ambivalent feelings about her ashes\u2019 unresolved fate if she\u2019d considered this issue beforehand. But then, who thinks about such things? To devote attention to the topic is to admit to ourselves that we are mortal, and even though we all know better, many of us share the belief of William Saroyan, who said, \u201cEverybody has to die, but I always hoped an exception might be made in my case.\u201d\n\nAs my ill luck would have it, I\u2019m the member of my family who thinks of ashes as sacred. Which is probably why the ashes wound up with me \u2014 I was the one who\u2019d endlessly complained that Katie\u2019s remains were \u201cjust lying around\u201d in the house of her former girlfriend and lobbied hard for us to take possession of the ashes and return them to the earth. I\u2019d succeeded in trying the patience of virtually all of my loved ones with this campaign, so that when at last the cremains came back to us, I was so embarrassed about the fuss I\u2019d made that I was too self-conscious to follow through with the interment.\n\nWhich is why they then lingered on a shelf in my office for five years, next to a collection of short stories by James Thurber.\n\nThis is not an uncommon end for one\u2019s leftovers. The remains of Dorothy Parker, for instance, sat in a file drawer in a Wall Street law firm for 14 years before they were finally interred in a memorial garden at the N.A.A.C.P. headquarters in Baltimore, bearing a tribute to her as well as the epitaph she\u2019d written for herself: \u201cExcuse My Dust.\u201d Then there\u2019s Maj. Raphael Guido Rombauer, a Civil War veteran, whose ashes remained unclaimed for 102 years. He was finally buried in 2015, when his great-granddaughter arranged for the interment, assisted by volunteers wearing Civil War uniforms.\n\nThere are a lot of things you can do with cremains. A green burial mixes your ashes with a seedling, wood chips and a special soil mix. There\u2019s also a company that will turn your cremains into bullets. Or, as the actor James Doohan (who played Scotty on \u201cStar Trek\u201d) did, you could choose to send your ashes into space on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket.", "title": "Opinion | What Do Our Ashes Mean to Us?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDo you consider yourself a collector? If so, what do you collect?\n\nIs it a hobby to create, and tend to, a collection of things?\n\nIn \u201cPostcard People,\u201d Annie Correal writes:\n\nMarilyn Stern held out a black-and-white postcard of a baby panda from 1948. \u201cWhat\u2019s interesting to me is that it says, \u2018Most valuable captive animal,\u2019\u201d said Ms. Stern, one of a few dozen postcard collectors who had gathered on a recent Sunday at the Watson Hotel in Midtown. \u201cI have a category that almost no one collects, which is superlatives\u2014 \u2018the biggest,\u2019 \u2018the smallest,\u2019 \u2018the newest,\u2019 \u2018the oldest,\u2019 \u2018the most expensive,\u2019 \u2018the most beautiful,\u2019 et cetera,\u201d said Ms. Stern, a photographer and graphic artist. She admired the panda, which looked out from a crib. \u201cIsn\u2019t he cute?\u201d Stuff tends to collect in New York City. So, too, do collectors \u2014 who bring more stuff. It is a cycle that over the years has created huge collections in the city \u2014 of art, antiques, manuscripts, classic cars, but also some unexpected items: glass eyeballs, buttons, fluff. And postcards.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 What, if anything, about the article resonates with you?\n\n\u2014 Why do you think some people are drawn to collect old postcards? What other objects are you aware of that people collect?\n\n\u2014 Do you personally have a collection of anything? If so, what?\n\n\u2014 If you don\u2019t collect anything, what, if anything, would you like to collect?\n\n\u2014 Why do you think clubs made up of collectors, like the Metropolitan Postcard Club of New York City, exist? Would you join a club in which all the members share an interest in the same thing you collect? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 What do collections say about the person who amasses them? Why?", "title": "What Do You Collect?", "authors": ["Shannon Doyne", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "SUPERNORMAL\n\nThe Untold Story of Adversity and Resilience\n\nBy Meg Jay, Ph.D.\n\n387 pp. Twelve Books, $28\n\nOne of the many disputes currently roiling American culture is just how psychologically strong we mortals are. Can we muster the wherewithal to master the difficulties that life typically tosses at us, sometimes at an early age, or are we sitting ducks apt to crumble with every disagreeable word that blows, especially across a college campus near you? Into this combat zone steps the psychologist Meg Jay with her second book, \u201cSupernormal: The Untold Story of Adversity and Resilience.\u201d\n\nWith much passion, her earlier book, \u201cThe Defining Decade: Why Your Twenties Matter \u2014 And How to Make the Most of Them,\u201d revealed the private quandaries of millennials seeking her out for psychotherapy and exposing a very different side of themselves than their public posts on Facebook. To \u201cSupernormal,\u201d Jay again brings her skill at telling the stories of her patients.\n\nThere\u2019s Sam, who was 9 when his father walked out on the family; Emily, the child of an alcoholic father; Paul, a nuclear engineer who was bullied as a kid; Jessie, who was dominated by her sister; the doctor-lawyer Elizabeth, whose parents focused on her special-needs brother; Nadia, orphaned in college when her parents were murdered; Martha, emotionally harassed by a mother who constantly criticized her appearance; Michelle, sexually abused by her polo coach; Vera, a daughter of neglect; Jennifer, born into a household marked by domestic violence; and others.\n\nMany are the ways that lives can get distressed. Unfortunately, we rarely learn exactly what turns misfortune into resilience. From the story of Emily, whose success at swimming was her ticket out of town, and that of Mara, the daughter of a bipolar mother, we learn that separating from one\u2019s surroundings, in reality or fantasy, is a crucial act of self-preservation \u2014 a necessary, but hardly sufficient, first step in overcoming adversity.", "title": "What Does It Take to Overcome Adversity?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Dirty air has been seen as the unavoidable byproduct of economic growth ever since the coal-stoked advent of the industrial age. The soot-stained \u201cfogs\u201d of 19th-century London seemed to bring about, as Charles Dickens wrote, \u201cthe death of the sun.\u201d The perpetual smoke that enveloped Pittsburgh, the musclebound center of American industrial power, reminded one 19th-century writer of \u201chell with the lid taken off.\u201d Back then, residents of these industrial capitals had little idea about the dangers of inhaling soot and smog. Indeed, many Londoners took pride in their \u201cpea soup\u201d as a symbol of progress and prosperity.\n\nIn recent years, Beijing has been the embodiment of the city besieged by air pollution, an economic juggernaut with episodes of smog so extreme that they have earned their own sobriquet: \u201cairpocalypse.\u201d Now the mantle passes to India. In the past two years, Delhi has had only eight days when pollution levels have met W.H.O. safety standards, according to Usman Nasim, a researcher at the Delhi-based Center for Science and Environment. And Delhi is probably not the most polluted city in India. Recent data suggest that four other Indian cities have higher average levels of PM2.5, microscopic airborne particulates that are especially harmful to humans.\n\nThe old logic about pollution \u2014 that it is the price of progress \u2014 has shifted, even in the developing world. Tackling air pollution in countries still dependent on coal (as both China and India are) takes an abundance of political will \u2014 and money. Shutting down dirty factories, cleaning up industry and shifting toward renewable energy can initially drive up costs and impede growth. But researchers are finding that pollution can be an even bigger drag on growth over the long term. It not only damages a country\u2019s image and hurts its ability to attract talent, tourists and investors; air pollution also exacts heavy losses in health expenditures, labor losses, agricultural activity and premature deaths. (The W.H.O. estimates that air pollution causes close to a million deaths per year in both India and China.) Over all, the World Bank estimates that air pollution already drains at least $55 billion worth of labor output alone from the Indian economy every year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSuch economic tidings, environmentalists hope, will push India to finally rise above its fractious politics and fragile institutions to tackle endemic pollution. The signs, however, are not all promising. India\u2019s former environment minister himself dismissed what he called a \u201cmisleading\u201d W.H.O. report that listed more than 30 Indian cities among the world\u2019s 100 most polluted \u2014 and rejected another scientific study linking air pollution to mortality.\n\nPhoto\n\nLooking at how India and China deal with pollution crises raises the question of which type of government might get better results: democratic or authoritarian? Even in India, environmentalists marvel at China\u2019s ability to mobilize its bureaucratic machinery. But the reality is messier. China\u2019s pollution crisis, which grew out of its three-decade pursuit of economic growth at all costs, festered in a closed one-party system that suppresses information and public opinion. It was considered almost revolutionary in 2012 when the U.S. Embassy, defying Beijing, continued to share real-time pollution data online from its own air-quality monitor. My family lived in Beijing for four years, at a time when every winter morning was a roll of the dice: crisp blue skies or apocalyptic smog-scape. My sons knew that if they could not see the building across from us, 100 yards away, school would be canceled. For them, a smog day was just like a snow day, only spent indoors \u2014 next to the air purifiers.\n\nHow, then, did China suddenly declare its \u201cwar on pollution\u201d in 2014? There were factors beyond the poisonous smog: a slowing economy, a crippling coal addiction, a fed-up middle class clamoring for better quality of life. Above all, it was economics. China\u2019s Ministry of Environmental Protection estimated that pollution in 2010 cost the economy around $227 billion, or roughly 3.5 percent of G.D.P. Despite resistance from industry and local governments \u2014 China is not a monolith, after all \u2014 the country has shut down coal-burning factories, doubled down on renewable energy, created a dense grid of air-monitoring stations and exposed thousands of officials for violating environmental laws. This is all good, but so far, much of the effort has focused on the region around China\u2019s showcase city, Beijing.\n\nIn Delhi, the government submitted a new antipollution plan days after the cricket incident. \u201cIn the end, the question always is: Will it be implemented, or will it only be the blame game again?\u201d Nasim says. An emergency plan drawn up after heavy pollution in late 2016 went largely unused during the recent crisis. \u201cThe same cycle happens every year,\u201d says Michael Brauer, a professor of environmental health at the University of British Columbia. \u201cAt some point, Delhi will have to address air pollution as a chronic problem requiring long-term solutions, not just a seasonal event.\u201d\n\nPollution will still plague Asia\u2019s two largest capitals for years to come. When Delhi\u2019s worst smog subsided this winter, The Times of India ran the headline: \u201cAir Quality Very Poor \u2014 and It\u2019s Good News.\u201d Beijing, for its part, rang in 2018 with another bout of hazardous smog. My family and I left that city three years ago for Shanghai, where the air, though still dirty, was better for our children\u2019s lungs. A few months ago, we left China altogether for a cleaner Asian city, where we wake up to the sound of tropical birds singing in the flame tree outside, happy to call ourselves pollution fugitives.", "title": "What Does It Take to Stop Accepting Pollution as the Price of Progress?", "authors": ["Brook Larmer", "On Money"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "What Goes With Basketball? Dance.\n\nThe challenge for the Brooklynettes, who perform at home games of the Brooklyn Nets, is to capture the attention of fans.", "title": "What Goes With Basketball? Dance.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "As the anesthesiologist Henry Jay Przybylo explains in \u201cCounting Backwards,\u201d the word \u201canesthesia\u201d means \u201cwithout feeling,\u201d but a modern general anesthetic is about much more than just rendering a patient unconscious. It also involves analgesia, the prevention of pain; anxiolysis, the relief of anxiety; and amnesia, the obliteration of memory. The latter is necessary because it is by no means certain that patients are fully unconscious when anesthetized \u2014 a problem explored at length in Kate Cole-Adams\u2019s book \u201cAnesthesia.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDespite the central role that anesthetic drugs play in medicine, very little about how they work is known for certain. Equally remarkable is the fact that ether, the first agent to be used as a general anesthetic, was shown by Paracelsus in the 16th century to put chickens to sleep. He wrote that it \u201cquiets all suffering without any harm and relieves all pain\u2026\u201d It remains mysterious as to why 300 years were to pass before it came to be used as a general anesthetic. Some would point to Kuhn\u2019s scientific paradigms and argue that medicine wasn\u2019t ready for such a shift in thinking, others that it reflects the entirely unscientific nature of premodern medicine and the blinkered self-confidence of doctors. There are, of course, many similar examples in the history of medicine \u2014 perhaps the most egregious being the failure of the medical profession to exploit Leeuwenhoek\u2019s invention in the 17th century of the microscope and his discovery of microbial life, as discussed in David Wootton\u2019s book \u201cBad Medicine.\u201d\n\nSeveral American doctors began to use ether as a general anesthetic in the 1840s. There were bitter disputes about who could claim to be the first, but what is clear is that ether was rapidly taken up by the medical profession. It is interesting to note that it was also widely used as a recreational drug in countries like Ireland and Poland, where it was used as an alternative to alcohol.\n\nEther is no longer used in general anesthesia, and has been replaced by different \u201cvolatile\u201d agents \u2014 such as sevoflurane and isoflurane. The way in which these volatile anesthetic agents dissolve in oil led to the theory that they worked by interfering with the lipoprotein membranes of nerve cells, implying that all the brain\u2019s neurons were inactivated by the drugs and that the unconsciousness of general anesthesia was complete. This theory is no longer believed and instead there is near-complete uncertainty as to how the agents do work. More recent research on injectable anesthetic drugs like propofol suggests that they interfere selectively with certain neurotransmitters and with the interaction between the cerebral cortex (where thought and perception resides) and the deep part of the cerebral hemispheres known as the thalamus, which acts as some kind of gateway between the cerebral cortex and the rest of the brain. In other words, it is by no means certain that all of your brain is \u201casleep\u201d when you are anesthetized.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe possibility of \u201cawareness under anesthesia\u201d is obviously of deep concern to both anesthesiologists and patients and is reminiscent of the fear in previous ages of being buried alive after being mistakenly assumed dead. Awareness became a clinical problem in the 1940s with the introduction of the paralyzing drug curare. Until then, if an anesthetic was inadequate, the patient would start to wake up and to move. With curare this cannot happen and it is possible for patients to be awake and, since they are entirely paralyzed, for the anesthesiologist to be unaware of it.\n\nAwareness undoubtedly can occur under anesthesia although there is much argument as to how often. A 2014 survey in the United Kingdom of three million cases of anesthesia suggested an incidence of 1 in 19,000 with not all the episodes causing distress. This survey relied on patients volunteering their memory of being aware, so it is possible that some chose not to report the experience and that the true incidence might be higher. The issue is further complicated by the possibility of implicit or \u201cunconscious\u201d memory as opposed to conscious or \u201cexplicit\u201d memory. The \u201cexplicit\u201d memories would be the horror stories of patients wide-awake but unable to move while being operated on, usually as a result of medical error. It seems that the paralysis is even more distressing than the pain and can lead to long-term psychiatric harm and PTSD. Implicit, unconscious memories of being awake under anesthesia are much harder to uncover.\n\nCole-Adams makes much of these sorts of hidden memories in her book, and of various experiments with hypnotizing patients before and after anesthesia to find them, but as she admits, the evidence is confused and contradictory. Nevertheless, some anesthesiologists are careful in what they say in front of anesthetized patients in case the patient is able to later recall what they overheard. This is quite unlike surgeons who, on the whole, are disinhibited extroverts when operating.\n\nA good experience of anesthesia should be as routine and dull as a commercial airplane ride, with the added feature that the patient should have no memory of it. Both anesthesia and flight have become dramatically safer in recent decades and there is much in common between flying an aircraft and anesthetizing a patient \u2014 uneventful most of the time but occasionally terrifying and very occasionally fatal. The Patient Safety movement of recent years has been largely driven by anesthesiologists and analogies to aviation safety, which perhaps apply less well to surgery.\n\nIt is difficult to write an exciting book about modern anesthesia but Przybylo is thoughtful and workmanlike in his production, as he is, it is quite clear, when administering his anesthetics. Consciousness is an entirely subjective phenomenon and, perhaps inevitably given its subtitle, you will learn as much, if not more, about Cole-Adams\u2019s own anxieties and preoccupations as you will about anesthesia in her book. The effect, as she streams her consciousness over many pages, can in itself be somewhat anesthetic.", "title": "What Happens When You Go Under", "authors": ["Henry Marsh"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Like most prominent Republicans at the time, Romney no doubt assumed that the fever swamp stuff didn\u2019t need to be attacked, that it would evaporate once the G.O.P. won back the White House. But instead the fever swamp stuff helped hand the G.O.P. to Trump himself, and the birther\u2019s grip-and-grin with an uncomfortable Romney was a small but notable milestone on that path.\n\nThe larger, indirect role that Romney played in Trump\u2019s ascent was in the way he ran and lost in 2012. There were times when the Man From Bain Capital seemed to have some sense of the populist discontents that Trump successfully played upon four years later. Romney\u2019s rhetoric on China and immigration was a more restrained version of Trump\u2019s nationalist pitch, and here and there he tried to imitate Franklin Roosevelt\u2019s promise, updated crudely by Trump, to be a traitor to his successful class.\n\nBut not nearly often enough. Instead, the defining pitch of the Romney campaign was the tone-deaf \u201cyou built that,\u201d which valorized entrepreneurs and ignored ordinary workers; the defining policy blueprint was a tax reform proposal that offered little or nothing to the middle class; and the defining gaffe was the famous \u201c47 percent\u201d line, in which Romney succumbed, before an audience of Richie Riches, to the Ayn Randian temptation to write off struggling Americans as losers.\n\nAs a result, whether in his father\u2019s Michigan, in his running mate\u2019s Wisconsin, or in Pennsylvania where he campaigned hopefully near the end, downscale white voters who could have gone Republican either voted for Obama or stayed home. And in that failure lay the opportunity that Trump intuited \u2014 for a Republican candidate who would rhetorically reject and even run against the kind of corporation-first conservatism that Romney seemed to embody and embrace.\n\nSince taking office, of course, Trump has mostly turned his back on his own economic populism \u2014 and lost much of his modest-to-begin-with popularity in the process. But in that time, the men who imagine themselves the party\u2019s stewards or its conscience have learned little from the way he beat them and then beat the Democrats. They are still suffering from what Pete Spiliakos, in a withering column for First Things last month, called \u201cThe Romney Disease\u201d \u2014 a condition that combines admirable personal probity and decency with an abiding commitment to unpopular economic policies:\n\nThe best of the current Republicans (the Paul Ryans, the Ben Sasses, the Mitt Romneys) have certain common features that should be appealing to the electorate. They seem to have the home life of the family man. They have the discipline and diligence of the organization kid. They have the looks of the pretty boy. Yet the public still rejects them, because the voters find their ideas even more unpleasant than Donald Trump\u2019s odious personality.\n\nIf Romney joins the Utah Senate race, and ultimately the Senate, there will be a lot of talk about the service he can perform for his country by resisting the worst of Trumpism. But he could also perform a service by showing that he has learned something from watching Trumpism succeed where his own campaign failed \u2014 which would mean steering a different and more populist course than those NeverTrump Republicans who pine for a party of the purest libertarianism, and those OkayFineTrump Republicans who are happy now that Trump has given them their corporate tax cut.", "title": "Opinion | What Has Mitt Romney Learned?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Before publicly sharing his findings over the weekend, he discussed them in a private chat group on Twitter, made up of people interested in intelligence and security issues. \u201cI know about two-thirds of what I know about the world from the group chats,\u201d he said.\n\nVideo\n\nDanielle Cave, a senior analyst at the Australian Strategic Policy Institute, said that Twitter is playing an increasingly important role in open-source intelligence, the collection of sensitive information from publicly available sources. Researchers from think tanks, nongovernmental organizations and the corporate sector who are at the cutting edge of cybersecurity work gravitate to the platform to exchange information, she said.\n\n\u201cTwitter\u2019s being used to piece it together like a jigsaw,\u201d Ms. Cave said. \u201cUsually I see them on top of a cyberrelated issue hours, if not days, before it ends up on the media.\u201d\n\nJohn Blaxland, a professor of international security and intelligence studies at Australian National University, taught Mr. Ruser last year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. He said he has written 7,000 words of an article about a pro-government militia in northern Myanmar, which he plans to send to Bellingcat, an open-source citizen journalism site, when it\u2019s finished.\n\nHe said he hoped the Australian intelligence community saw his Strava revelation as a positive contribution, helping the Australian government and others address their vulnerabilities. \u201cI would definitely not like to be a Manning, or a Snowden, or an Assange,\u201d he said.\n\nLike many 20-year-olds, he is not sure what he wants to do after graduation.
