What has happened since has been unexpectedly revealing \u2014 so to speak \u2014 of the real Russia, the one that exists beyond the conservative anti-Western facade put up by the Kremlin.\n\nThe original Benny Benassi video to accompany \u201cSatisfaction\u201d shows models slick with sweat, using power tools while licking their lips \u2014 a campy dig at the objectification of the female body for marketing purposes. The Russian students aren\u2019t the first to be inspired to make their own version: In 2013, for instance, British military personnel made a parody in which they, too, wore almost nothing and danced erotically while cleaning their living quarters.\n\nThe Russian clip resembles the British version: It follows a gyrating, nearly naked cadet up the stairs of a dormitory building where the camera floats through various spaces typical of post-Soviet communal interiors. He encounters other young men dancing suggestively while engaged in household chores. In one scene, a cadet comes out of a bathroom stall and playfully tilts his peaked cap. In another, a young man thrusts away while ironing his uniform. A banana makes a pivotal appearance. At the end, the dozen or so performers converge to shake their butts together, with youthful abandon.\n\nThe reaction was immediate.\n\nThe Ulyanovsk Institute of Civil Aviation, where these students study, trains civilian pilots, not military ones. But as the clip went viral, officials began accusing the young men of desecrating their uniforms and offending veterans, as if they\u2019d neglected their duties to the motherland by staging an ironic erotic performance. State television also immediately suggested the participants were gay \u2014 another taboo in modern Russia.", "title": "Opinion | What Homoerotic Videos Can Teach Us About Modern Russia", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Other games \u2014 officially counting as part of the regular season \u2014 have resulted in the winner advancing to the L.C.S. Think of the Yankees, propelled by a Bucky Dent homer, eliminating Boston at Fenway Park in 1978. But if we limit this to the 96 division series in baseball history, we find one-third (32) that have gone the full five games.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe finality of Diggs\u2019s catch (let\u2019s forget the kneel-down on the extra-point attempt) means the baseball precedent would have to be a game-ending play. Because of the structure of baseball, with the home team batting last, that means this happens only when the home team wins. Somewhat surprisingly, the home team has won just 13 of those 32 Game 5s.\n\nNow our pool gets a lot smaller. How many of those 13 games ended on so-called walk-off plays? Just three: the 1995 series between the Yankees and the Seattle Mariners; the 2001 series between the St. Louis Cardinals and the Arizona Diamondbacks; and the 2011 series between the Diamondbacks and the Milwaukee Brewers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut here\u2019s an added wrinkle. When Case Keenum found Diggs for the winning touchdown, the Vikings were losing. In 2001, when Tony Womack singled to win it for Arizona, and in 2011, when Nyjer Morgan singled to win it for Milwaukee, the games were tied.\n\nThat brings us to 1995, at the Kingdome in Seattle. As the Yankees\u2019 Jack McDowell delivered the final pitch of that game, the Mariners were losing, 5-4. By the time the play was over, the Mariners had won. Edgar Martinez ripped a double into the left-field corner, scoring Joey Cora with the tying run and Ken Griffey Jr. with the winning run. The Yankees went home and the Mariners rolled into the American League Championship Series.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSeems like a match, doesn\u2019t it? Yet it\u2019s not quite perfect. There were no outs when Martinez connected, so the game would have continued if he had made an out. Likewise, when the New York Giants\u2019 Bobby Thomson homered to vanquish the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1951 \u2014 the fabled \u201cShot Heard \u2019Round the World\u201d \u2014 there was one out, not two.\n\nThat homer comes pretty close, though, as the Giants also went from losing to winning on the final play. It sent the Giants to the World Series, so there was more at stake than there was in Minnesota on Sunday.\n\nHere\u2019s another that almost works: Game 7 of the 1992 National League Championship Series in Atlanta. It\u2019s the wrong round, of course, but everything else lines up. The Pittsburgh Pirates were winning, 2-1, with two outs and two on when Francisco Cabrera stepped up against Stan Belinda. If Cabrera had made an out, the Braves would have been eliminated. Instead, he singled in both runners to win the pennant.\n\nElimination game? Yes. Winning to losing on the final play? Yes. Game over if Cabrera fails? Yes. Just one round too late. There\u2019s even a bonus connection: both moments were aided by a defensive blunder. In 1992, the tying run reached base on an error by Jose Lind. On Sunday, Marcus Williams missed the tackle on Diggs.\n\nI could be missing a similar situation from generations past. If so, please let me know. In any case, it\u2019s fun to think about, and it\u2019s one way to unite baseball, football and basketball. In those sports, unlike hockey or soccer, you can go from losing to winning on the final play \u2014 an exquisite kind of euphoria for the winner and torture for the loser.\n\nAnd while I can\u2019t precisely match the Diggs catch to baseball, one precedent absolutely works. As my pal Gar Ryness, better known as Batting Stance Guy, pointed out on Twitter, we had seen another player wearing No. 14 catching the final ball of a postseason victory in a domed stadium in Minnesota.\n\nIndeed, when the Twins won their first championship, in Game 7 of the 1987 World Series at the Metrodome, the final out nestled in the glove of the big first baseman Kent Hrbek. He wore No. 14, just like Diggs at the same site more than three decades later.", "title": "What Is Baseball\u2019s Equivalent of the Vikings\u2019 Miraculous Victory?", "authors": ["Tyler Kepner", "On Baseball"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "The agency has never been involved in peace negotiations and has instead focused its attention on humanitarian efforts throughout the Middle East in areas where the largest numbers of displaced Palestinians are concentrated. Israel has regularly feuded with the organization, as it rejects the Palestinian demand for a right of return for the refugees displaced by the Arab-Israeli conflict.\n\nBut despite Israel\u2019s reservations, the organization is internationally recognized for its humanitarian efforts, and it plays a major role in the region.\n\nAt times its role is as basic as providing a safe space for civilians. Much in the same way that other United Nations facilities have become a haven in times of active conflict, an Unwra school was used by thousands of civilians seeking shelter during the 2014 Gaza war.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat does Unrwa do?\n\nUnrwa mainly provides services and funding for those registered as Palestinian refugees in the Gaza Strip, the West Bank, Jordan, Lebanon and Syria. (The Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees is responsible for Palestinian refugees outside Unrwa\u2019s areas of operation.)\n\nNearly the entire population of the Gaza Strip receives aid from Unrwa. The agency acts almost as a de facto government there, responsible for the majority of schools, health care facilities and some public services.\n\nIn Jordan, which hosts more than two million registered Palestinian refugees, hosts the largest number of people who are provided aid by Unrwa.\n\nMore than half of Unrwa\u2019s budget for programs goes toward education, and in 2016, 17 percent of the budget was set aside for health care. On Wednesday, the agency pointed out the role that it plays in the region, while also highlighting the United States\u2019 contribution to those efforts.\n\nThe agency also provides loans through its microfinance department, which support small local businesses.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat would a U.S. funding cut mean?\n\nPhoto\n\nThe United States is the top funder of Unrwa, and according to figures released in 2016, it contributed nearly $369 million, including emergency funding for aiding Palestinian refugees caught up in Syria\u2019s brutal civil war.\n\nIf the American funding was eliminated, the agency would face a significant deficit in its budget. The next biggest donor in 2016, the European Union, contributed less than half of what the United States did. The agency receives contributions from more than 100 donors, and its entire budget for 2016 was nearly $1.25 billion.\n\nBut any cuts would affect those most in need.\n\nMore than 500,000 children are taught in 700 Unrwa-run schools across the Middle East, according to the agency. Unrwa provides funding for more than nine million patients visits at health care facilities in the region. It employs more than 30,000 people.\n\nDespite Mr. Trump\u2019s Twitter message, Chris Gunness, an Unrwa spokesman, said the agency had not received any formal notification that the Trump administration intended to cut its funding.", "title": "What Is Unrwa and What Would It Mean if Trump Cuts Its Funding?", "authors": ["Megan Specia"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "When discussing the storm, some weather forecasters have referred to a \u201cbomb cyclone.\u201d Calling it a \u201cbomb\u201d sounds dire, but those kinds of storms are not exceedingly rare \u2014 there was one in New England recently.\n\nWhat makes a storm a \u201cbomb\u201d is how fast the atmospheric pressure falls; falling atmospheric pressure is a characteristic of all storms. By definition, the barometric pressure must drop by at least 24 millibars in 24 hours for a storm to be called a bomb cyclone; the formation of such a storm is called bombogenesis.\n\nHere is how it works: Deep drops in barometric pressure occur when a region of warm air meets one of cold air. The air starts to move, and the rotation of the earth creates a cyclonic effect. The direction is counterclockwise in the Northern Hemisphere (when viewed from above), leading to winds that come out of the northeast \u2014 a Nor\u2019easter.\n\nThat\u2019s what happened at the end of October, when warm air from the remnants of a tropical cyclone over the Atlantic collided with a cold front coming from the Midwest. Among other impacts then, more than 80,000 electric customers in Maine lost power as high winds toppled trees.", "title": "What Is a \u2018Bomb Cyclone?\u2019 Here\u2019s How It Works.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "One explanation for all this is that the acceleration of information flow has heightened our impatience with not knowing. Until the internet\u2019s arrival, the \u201cjour,\u201d or day, was the primary unit of time by which journalism functioned. But now that the minute, or better, the second, is the new unit of preference, it might be more fitting to change the profession\u2019s name to minutalism or secondalism. In the attempt to capture an event just as it happens, or even before it does, the news becomes less factual and more hypothetical. The absurdity of the word \u201ctomorrowism\u201d might just match the absurdity of the phenomenon.\n\nAnother theory is offered by Richard Grusin in his excellent book \u201cPremediation: Affect and Mediality After 9/11,\u201d in which he describes the ways in which the media in all its iterations tries to buffer itself against a repetition of the shock that was Sept 11. In response to an event that caught everyone off guard and left the nation steeped in residual trauma, premediation allows for the sustainment of a constant, baseline fear by keeping catastrophe always within peripheral view. This is accomplished in part by creating a media apparatus into which any future event might be plugged, offering us the illusion of preparedness. Hurricanes, nuclear wars, stock market plunges, epidemics, terror attacks, earthquakes and currency collapses: The headlines prepare us for all of these by rehearsing them in advance.\n\nMr. Grusin writes: \u201cPremediation is not about getting the future right, but about proliferating multiple remediations of the future both to maintain a low level of fear in the present and to prevent a recurrence of the kind of tremendous media shock that the United States and much of the networked world experienced on 9/11.\u201d Mediatic readiness \u2014 and anticipation \u2014 has become necessity.\n\nI believe something similar is going on in response to Trump trauma. Despite efforts to remain poised for all of the world\u2019s contingencies through the process of premediation Mr. Grusin describes, many of us were startled by Mr. Trump\u2019s victory. The media, which seems to be repenting for having misread or misrepresented polls that showed a sure Hillary Clinton win, now atones by constantly hedging \u2014 offering us a tree of all possible outcomes and a range of fairly noncommittal speculations that can be backed away from if their conjectures prove false.\n\nThis leads us to a third possible reason speculative journalism thrives today: its mitigation of risk. What the speculative journalist has in common with the gamblers of Las Vegas and Wall Street is the willingness to take risks, but the stakes in this game are relatively low. When the future materializes, there will certainly be winners and losers. Someone will have gotten it right, and this certainty reassures us somehow. But given the superabundance of speculations clouding the mediascape, will anyone remember or care exactly who got it wrong? Those who were right will trumpet their prophetic insight and ascend as soothsayers; those who were wrong will simply keep quiet. One has little to lose but much to gain from this wager.", "title": "Opinion | What Is the Future of Speculative Journalism?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nQ. What is the health and nutritional value of mushrooms?\n\nA. Mushrooms may lack the deep green or brilliant red hues consumers have come to associate with nutrient-rich fruits and vegetables, but they are a \u201cpowerhouse of nutrition\u201d and not a white food to be avoided, said Angela Lemond, a registered dietitian nutritionist and spokeswoman for the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics.\n\nLow in calories and fat and cholesterol-free, mushrooms contain a modest amount of fiber and over a dozen minerals and vitamins, including copper, potassium, magnesium, zinc and a number of B vitamins such as folate. Mushrooms are also high in antioxidants like selenium and glutathione, or GSH, substances believed to protect cells from damage and reduce chronic disease and inflammation.\n\nSome studies suggest mushrooms are the richest dietary source of another antioxidant called ergothioneine, or ERGO, which is also present in large amounts in red beans, oat bran and liver. ERGO and other antioxidants are primarily concentrated in the caps, not the stems.\n\nBut the nutrient profile of a mushroom varies depending on the type and the method of cultivation, according to Robert Beelman, a professor emeritus of food science and director of the Center for Plant and Mushroom Foods for Health at Penn State College of Agricultural Sciences. His 2017 study, which compared ERGO and GSH in different mushroom types, found levels varied more than twentyfold.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile the common button mushroom carried in most supermarkets in the United States is high in potassium and selenium, Dr. Beelman\u2019s study found specialty mushrooms like gray and yellow oyster, shiitake, maiitake and porcini have far higher concentrations of both ERGO and GSH, whereas porcini mushrooms have the highest amounts of ERGO, followed by yellow oyster mushrooms. (The study did not include cremini or portobello mushrooms; they also contain significant, though lower, amounts of ERGO, according to the Mushroom Council.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSome mushrooms also contain vitamin D, but generally only if they were grown in sunlight or exposed to ultraviolet light, Dr. Beelman said.\n\nObservational studies suggest that people who consume a lot of mushrooms have a lower risk of developing breast cancer and dementia, but these studies are not definitive and do not prove a causal relationship.", "title": "What Is the Health and Nutritional Value of Mushrooms?", "authors": ["Roni Caryn Rabin", "Ask Well"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Hurricane Maria's devastating effects on Puerto Rico, along with the political face-offs and logistical problems that ensued, have been widely reported. There are still important problems to address. But it seems that San Juan, the capital, is starting to regain its stride as a travel destination.\n\nI first came to San Juan in the late \u201980s, when my stepfather was transferred here for work. My most vivid memories of that time include swimming in the ocean at night during St. John\u2019s Eve (one of Puerto Rico\u2019s biggest festivals), developing a serious crush on the shaggy-haired members of the band Poison, and experiencing Hurricane Hugo, which ripped into the island on Sept. 19, 1989, and was considered the worst disaster in 50 years.\n\nWe spent the night of the storm with a family that lived in a sturdy old house about a mile away from the coast (our apartment was practically on the sand). While I realized we were properly sheltered, the furious rattle of the wind against the home\u2019s metal shutters left me cold with fear. I didn\u2019t know that surviving the brunt of a hurricane is only part of the ordeal, and the days that followed were not difficult enough to make me think otherwise. Brushing my teeth with bottled water and reading magazines by flashlight for a couple of weeks felt more like an adventure than a hardship. I was just a kid \u2014 and so, it turns out, was Hugo.\n\nI left San Juan after graduating from high school, but I come back every year to visit my mother and stepfather, who are still living here as retirees. When I learned that Maria would make landfall as a possible Category 5 hurricane, memories of Hugo came flooding back, especially the eerie rattle of those shutters. Texting with my mother on the evening of Sept. 20, I felt irrationally worried that she would be scared during the storm, not guessing that the scariest part would come later.", "title": "What It\u2019s Like to Visit San Juan Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "I listened to his steady, quiet voice guide me and my breathing. I believe, as he tells me, as my Catholic tradition tells me, that there will be no end to war until each of us calms the conflicts within ourselves. A simple task, to change only ourselves, and yet such a difficult one. I resolve to hold the shell of my self up to my ear every day, to listen to the sound of my own self, before I set out into the unsettled world, as I must.\n\nWhile our religions instruct us to behave ourselves, I find that my son teaches me, too, even as I teach him. What have I learned from our relationship this year? That we must believe in what is good and right, without demonizing those that we oppose; that we must fight for what we believe in, without recourse to hate or insults; that we must give, in ways great and small, to distant organizations and the people we meet face to face; that we must connect to others who believe as we do, and grow our values and our organizations; that we must write and read what is meaningful, and ignore the morass of public opinion and media-induced emotions.\n\nIf we all do this, perhaps we can change our country, even in the face of entrenched power, the oligarchy of billionaires, the fear and hatred of those who feel powerless. It will take years to stop the tax cuts and the environmental assault, and it may take forever to stop our forever wars and to dismantle racism and patriarchy. But we can stop the moral and political degradation. We can say: Me, too, or I support you. We can say: Enough. We can say: What can I do?\n\nI gave money to Mai-Khanh Tran, a California Democrat who might beat the Republican incumbent, Ed Royce, in a House race. I support Pivot, a Vietnamese-American progressive network started by my brother, Dr. Tung Thanh Nguyen, who resigned from a White House commission rather than serve the current administration. I gave money and raised money for the Diasporic Vietnamese Artists Network and its blog, because I believe that arts and stories matter in changing our minds and therefore our world.\n\nI continue to write and to give talks in parts of the country that are beautiful but alien to me. Even if this costs me time to write, I want to reach out to people who are different than me, as we all must. I want to listen to strangers and I continue to listen to my son, knowing that if I do not listen to him, he will not listen to me.\n\nThat is true for all of us. Not everyone will listen, caught up in the noise, but enough might. Those who do not listen will never know what those who listen do: that it is the listening itself that matters, that listening is what connects us to others, and ourselves.", "title": "Opinion | What I\u2019ve Learned from My 4-Year-Old", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHE BUGHOUSE\n\nThe Poetry, Politics and Madness of Ezra Pound\n\nBy Daniel Swift\n\n302 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $27\n\nPerhaps no other poet in the 20th century presents more forcefully than does Ezra Pound the need to separate the life from the work \u2014 and the impossibility of doing so. Pound\u2019s visionary role in leading poetry in English into the modern, after the etiolations of the late 19th century, seems incontestable. So do his generosity and loyalty as a critic and friend (to Eliot, Joyce and others), his tirelessness as a teacher, his unorthodox brilliance as a translator from multiple languages and above all, his supreme ambition for poetry, expressed in his long poem the \u201cCantos,\u201d and in its animating conviction that poetry not only could but should guide the practical motions of society itself.\n\nOn the other hand, Pound was a sort of Antaeus. As long as his feet were on the ground that fed him with images and experiences, he was a giant. In the air, as a seer, a social theorist and a philosopher, he was notoriously vulnerable. He worshiped strong leaders; he indulged in a virulent anti-Semitism; and only slyly, belatedly, offhandedly did he take responsibility for mistaken actions and for detestable opinions that he expressed in writing. His life resists posterity\u2019s best efforts to make it resemble a morality play. His arrogance, his ambition and his hopes for his country led him to record more than 100 radio broadcasts critical of the American government while he was in Mussolini\u2019s Italy between 1941 and 1943. Indicted on a charge of treason during the war, he was eventually declared of unsound mind and spent almost 13 years confined at St. Elizabeths Hospital outside Washington, D.C. Upon arriving at Naples, Italy, in 1958 after his release, his first gesture was the Fascist salute. Yeats foresaw all of this when he met the young Pound in 1912: \u201cHe is a headlong ragged nature, is always hurting people\u2019s feelings, but he has I think some genius and great good will.\u201d\n\nThe latest contribution to the Pound conundrum is Daniel Swift\u2019s \u201cThe Bughouse: The Poetry, Politics and Madness of Ezra Pound.\u201d Swift is not a literary scholar. Instead, he is a kind of literary-critical memoirist. His approach is to provide new insights into poetry by reconstructing the environment in which poems were written, incorporating his own experience into the text. His book \u201cBomber County\u201d (2010) examined some poetry of World War II through an exploration of a relative\u2019s service in the Royal Air Force. Now he seeks insights into Pound through biographical investigations of those who visited him over the years at St. Elizabeths and through other extramural research. Swift declares, \u201cWherever people speak of Pound, there I tried to go.\u201d His strategy is intriguing but prone (as is memoir itself) to a kind of irrelevant narcissism. Declaring that previous biographies have sought to provide too unified a portrait of Pound, Swift suggests that he will \u201cpermit rival tellings to sing their discord\u201d through a \u201cstyle of telling \u2014 occasional, fragmented, in glimpses\u201d not unlike the collage effect of Pound\u2019s own poems.\n\nSwift has done a certain amount of detective work here, though no doubt not enough to satisfy the Poundians, who are a fierce and demanding tribe. The names on those cartes de visite to St. Elizabeths constitute a roll call of major American poets: John Berryman, Elizabeth Bishop, T. S. Eliot, Randall Jarrell, Robert Lowell, W. S. Merwin, Charles Olson, Marianne Moore, William Carlos Williams, Louis Zukofsky and others. Swift reveals himself to be no deep student of American poetry, and he is occasionally given to unhelpful generalities, as when he declares that \u201ctragedy, modernism, translation, collage: All are concerned with the great action of drawing together.\u201d He reads the work of Pound\u2019s visitors and those works of poetry, translation and prose that Pound created during his confinement. It is hard to identify Swift\u2019s final judgment of the poetry; he declares that \u201cthe grand bad faith of the \u2018Cantos\u2019 \u2014 its pomposity, its anger \u2014 is a constant, running line after line,\u201d but this is so instantly untrue that one wants to chalk it up to the spiteful impatience every reader has felt who has engaged deeply with Pound\u2019s allusive and polyphonic poem and emerged occasionally inspired but also baffled and frustrated. Swift\u2019s most useful discovery may be the extent to which Pound at St. Elizabeths became a kind of touchstone by which other poets \u2014 beginning with Olson, but including Lowell and Pound\u2019s old friend Williams \u2014 sought \u201cto take Pound in, incorporate him, shape him\u201d for themselves. Captivity invites appropriation, and appropriation can take different forms, as for example when Eliot protectively sought to shape the perception of Pound in the world at large as a cold high modernist, rather than as an intemperate propagandist.\n\nPhoto\n\nBy focusing on a nexus of relationships leading to and from Pound at St. Elizabeths, Swift also illuminates what he rather grandly calls \u201cthe riddle at the heart of the 20th century.\u201d The genius is a madman; the savior is a betrayer; the populist is an aristocrat; the intellectual and artistic hero is a coward and a faker; the innovator is a reactionary; the artist is a politician; the legislator is an inmate. The contradictions multiply until they seem to describe something larger than any one man. Swift quotes the literary scholar Samuel Hynes in 1955 to the effect that Pound\u2019s confinement is \u201ca reflection of an apparently insoluble modern dilemma, of the way in which individual freedom and the common good have come to be seen as antithetical.\u201d This is by way of saying that when we indict Pound, we indict ourselves and our society.\n\nUnfortunately, this argument goes only so far. Swift also quotes Williams in 1947 declaring that Pound \u201chas lost faith in the efficacy of the poem and gone over to ideas, using poetry as his stick.\u201d Here is the ultimate tragedy: that the attention to crystalline detail, in Pound\u2019s poems, to the particulars on which life and truth depend, should be sacrificed to his desire to be, as Gertrude Stein famously remarked, the village explainer. Nor does Williams\u2019s \u201cstick\u201d ignore the darker consequences of Pound\u2019s skewed beliefs, which have, as Swift shows, fed a range of conspiracy theorists and white supremacists as well as the movement known as CasaPound in Italy. And yet, and yet: Apparently Pound, in one of his late notebooks, asked, \u201cHave I seen the divine where it is not?\u201d And no reader of Pound\u2019s lyrics, his translations or sections of his \u201cCantos\u201d could respond in the negative. Pound saw the divine, and he helped us see it too. Is he discounted as a seer, then \u2014 or supremely validated as one? Not a poet himself, Swift nonetheless understands poets when he writes, \u201cWhat is moving and important is the attempt and not the achievement.\u201d And he quotes Olson, the first poet to visit Pound in St. Elizabeths, who asks, \u201cShall we learn from his line and not answer his life?\u201d One longs for deliverance from the contradictions, but there is none. As Swift remarks: \u201cSome parts we keep and some we send away. It is by choosing between the two that we get to glory.\u201d", "title": "What Life in Confinement Meant for Ezra Pound\u2019s Work", "authors": ["Karl Kirchwey", "Daniel Swift"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Have you ever played or heard of the app HQ Trivia? If so, what do you think is its appeal?\n\nIn \u201cHow HQ Trivia Became the Best Worst Thing on the Internet,\u201d Amanda Hess writes:\n\nOn New Year\u2019s Eve, I went to dinner in Los Angeles to close out 2017 with friends. Naturally, the meal ended with me white-knuckling my phone, my eyeballs glued open and my mind laser-focused on spitting up ephemeral internet trivia like who is the most followed celebrity on Instagram (Selena Gomez) or which book topped Goodreads\u2019 best-of list in 2017 (\u201cLittle Fires Everywhere\u201d). That\u2019s because, just as the check arrived, HQ beckoned: The live trivia app had announced a surprise game, and if I wanted a shot at answering 12 multiple-choice questions and vying for a share of the $18,000 pot, I had to tap in instantly. For the next 15 minutes, I was not exactly human. I was a slave to HQ. HQ blasted out of obscurity this fall to become the best worst thing on the internet. It\u2019s the most popular app that barely even works. The questions (\u201cHow many times does the word \u2018sex\u2019 appear in the U.S. Constitution?\u201d) can be so obscure as to be meaningless, and the wording (\u201cWhat is the more common plural form for octopus?\u201d) is frequently indecipherable. (The hugely controversial \u201ccorrect\u201d answer: octopuses.) Some questions (\u201cWhich retro fashion style did NOT make a comeback this year?\u201d) basically test opinions. Others, which mine inconsequential information about obscure start-ups, stink strongly of advertorials. Then there\u2019s the app itself, which is riddled with glitches and lags. Players are regularly booted from the game without explanation. The live host\u2019s face is frequently obscured by the wheel of death. Sometimes, the whole game is scrapped for mysterious technical reasons \u2014 including one high-stakes game scheduled for 11:45 p.m. EST on New Year\u2019s Eve, which was unceremoniously aborted, then rescheduled for 45 minutes later \u2014 the game I hopped into. And yet, as many as half a million people are tuning in for each session. It\u2019s maybe the only real appointment viewing across all of entertainment right now. Why?\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 Ms. Hess calls HQ Trivia \u201cthe best worst thing on the internet.\u201d What is your opinion of the game and why?\n\n\u2014 Why do you think the app has become so popular? Is it the cash prize? The feelings of intellectual superiority and being aggrieved it fosters? The entertaining host? The sense of community it creates among players? Or a combination of all of the above?\n\n\u2014 Are there other apps or games you like to play that involve the elements that make HQ Trivia so appealing to such a wide audience? If so, what are they and what do you find enjoyable about them?\n\n\u2014 What do you think the obsession with HQ Trivia says about our society? What does it say about the things we value and what we find entertaining? What does it say about how we connect with others? Does it say anything about us at all?", "title": "What Makes HQ Trivia So Popular?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "My favorite one, Rosemarie, was a lady in her 70s. She was hardheaded. But she had more enthusiasm than anyone else in class. One time, it took me an entire week to get her through a paragraph in the assigned textbook. It was hard; I almost lost my patience. But every day her eagerness got me through. Every time I was frustrated, she would say: \u201cMet, map aprann li. Pa lagem.\u201d (Teacher, I will get it. Don\u2019t give up on me.)\n\nI didn\u2019t. We finally got through it. The next week, she cooked diri ak lalo \u2014 the best Haitian meal, don\u2019t let anyone tell you otherwise \u2014 and brought it for me in class and thanked me profusely. It nearly brought me to tears. She was my Davos Seaworth and I was her Shireen Baratheon. It\u2019s one of my most cherished memories, and I will take the grateful look on her face to the grave with me.\n\nThis is the place where I\u2019m from.\n\nI\u2019m not going to give you a history lesson here, but there\u2019s a short apocryphal story that illustrates the pride and sense of righteousness of Haitians. It goes like this: In 1939, when World War II broke out, Haiti, a pioneer of freedom, having led the most successful slave rebellion in the history of the world, joined the Allied forces and declared war on Nazi Germany. When that was reported to Hitler, he picked up a map to look for this presumptuous place he\u2019d never heard of. He couldn\u2019t find it. Suddenly, a fly flew from the map, revealing the small island nation.\n\nWe\u2019re a tiny country, but we have the courage of a continent. Yet Mother Nature has tested us. I don\u2019t believe the natural world has a conscience, I think we\u2019re merely geographically unlucky. But sometimes it feels like natural disasters punish us as if we were a nation of reincarnated Nazis.\n\nThis is the place where I\u2019m from.\n\nI do a bit on stage sometimes where I say that Trump, in his incompetence, will turn America into a third world country. And I proceed to describe what it would be like for white people to do their own dirty work. It\u2019s a world where cellphones are made by Kurts and Brocks, and white women are laboring under the sun picking their own pumpkins.", "title": "Opinion | What Makes a Country Great? Meet Haiti\u2019s People.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe main thing is not turning the ball over,\u201d said Jake Coker, the quarterback on the most recent Alabama championship team, which won after the 2015 season. \u201cBut also making the right decisions.\u201d\n\nSaban is \u201cnot looking for someone to take over the game, really at any position,\u201d Coker added.\n\nFew expect the current starter, the sophomore Jalen Hurts, to alter the track record of recent Alabama quarterbacks. Coker recently retired from football; AJ McCarron, who led championship teams in the 2011 and 2012 seasons, has started three games in his N.F.L. career; and Greg McElroy, quarterback of the 2009 Crimson Tide team, is an SEC Network analyst.\n\nCritics worry that Alabama\u2019s offense does not test Hurts as the N.F.L. might and lets him rely on his legs. While Hurts\u2019s mobility sets him apart from those previous signal-callers, he is in other important respects a classic Saban quarterback.\n\nThe Saban philosophy of quarterbacking can be summarized as: Don\u2019t screw up. For Saban, who was an N.F.L. defensive coordinator under Patriots Coach Bill Belichick and coached the Miami Dolphins for two seasons, the quarterback\u2019s main goals are to get the ball to talented backs and receivers, avoid big errors and let his typically top-ranked defenses do the rest.\n\n\u201cJalen has always been a guy that, because of his athleticism and his ability to run the ball, has made a lot of plays with his feet,\u201d Saban said. \u201cBut I also think that we\u2019ve been able to help him develop as a quarterback in terms of his decision-making in the pocket.\u201d", "title": "What Makes a Nick Saban Quarterback", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "During his eight years as the chief official White House photographer for President Barack Obama, Pete Souza, the former director of the White House Photo Office, traveled to all 50 states and more than 60 countries. Those trips added up to more than 1,300 flights on Air Force One and nearly 1.5 million miles.\n\n\u201cMy job was to basically tag along with the president and visually capture the professional and personal moments in his life,\u201d said Mr. Souza, 62, who was also the official White House photographer for President Ronald Reagan.\n\nHe shot almost two million images during his tenure with Mr. Obama, and his new book, \u201cObama: An Intimate Portrait,\u201d released in November, has 315 of the most memorable ones. Besides the tension-filled shot of Mr. Obama and his advisers in the Situation Room during the Osama bin Laden mission, there are several pictures from the president\u2019s travels including an image of him with his family in front of the Christ the Redeemer statue in Rio de Janeiro at night in the fog and a picture of him looking at the Great Wall of China.\n\nBelow are edited excerpts from an interview with Mr. Souza.\n\nCan you share some of your most memorable trips with President Obama?", "title": "What Obama\u2019s Photographer Learned About Travel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "After a year with a reality-TV ratings junkie in symbiosis with \u201cFox & Friends,\u201d there are many reasons to wonder about a turn to another television star. Is politics becoming permanently celebritized? Do we want the presidency to become the ultimate Cecil B. DeMille Award?\n\nBut to argue that Ms. Winfrey should run for president \u2014 or shouldn\u2019t \u2014 simply because she\u2019s a celebrity oversimplifies the issue. Most celebrities would make terrible candidates. (No offense, Kid Rock.) The real consideration here is why Ms. Winfrey is a celebrity, and all those qualifications were on display in that speech.\n\nIt\u2019s a master\u2019s stage performance. It builds from kitchen confession to mountaintop thunder. It shifts perspective cinematically \u2014 close in on young Ms. Winfrey sitting on the linoleum floor, pull back to a panorama of America. It uses preacherly rhythms and even cliffhangers (\u201ca young worker by the name of \u2026 Rosa Parks\u201d).\n\nBut above all, it\u2019s a story. And it\u2019s a story about stories. It moves from the personal (young Ms. Winfrey watching Sidney Poitier win an Oscar) to the communal (women in Hollywood, and women working on farms and even \u201csome pretty phenomenal men\u201d). It links \u201cyour truth\u201d and \u201cabsolute truth.\u201d It tells the audience: I have my struggle, and I know you have yours, and that connects us all in the sweep of a global struggle.\n\nConventional politicians can do that too, though it\u2019s not easy or common. Barack Obama was no one\u2019s idea of a shoo-in when he announced his campaign. But he synthesized his biography (as the \u201ckid with a funny name\u201d), his country\u2019s current struggles and an idea of generational social progress into one evocative narrative \u2014 change.", "title": "What Politicians Could Learn From Oprah Winfrey", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Rachel Bloom is the co-creator and star of \u201cCrazy Ex-Girlfriend,\u201d a standout television show on the CW network that combines elaborate song-and-dance numbers with comedy and drama. It has scooped up a number of awards, including a Best Actress Golden Globe for Ms. Bloom, and is currently in its third season.\n\nBased in Los Angeles, Ms. Bloom travels frequently, but still struggles to (politely) avoid conversations with strangers on the plane. \u201cI like to be solitary and kind of left alone when I travel and so something that I\u2019m still learning is, how do I remain solo and be in my quiet space without feeling guilty \u2014 like I have to talk to someone just because they talk to me?\u201d She\u2019s developed a technique to deal with chatty seatmates. \u201cI meditate now, and when you say to someone, \u2018Hi, you know, I\u2019m just gonna meditate,\u2019 they don\u2019t know what to say. They go, \u2018Oh, oh, O.K.!\u2019 It\u2019s either that they really respect it, or they think you\u2019re a weirdo, and either way they leave you alone.\u201d\n\nHer favorite travel accessory? Her dog, Wiley. \u201cBecause my husband was in New York for so long, I got my dog certified as an emotional support animal. And you can always tell when you\u2019re on a flight coming in from L.A., with the amount of emotional support dogs on it.\u201d Wiley\u2019s first cross-country flight was a success. \u201cShe understood that it was quiet time. She\u2019s in her middle years \u2014 my dog\u2019s around eight \u2014 so she\u2019s a woman in her comfortable middle age, who kind of knows how to chill out.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s what she takes on every trip.\n\nImage Credit Estelle Morris\n\nHumidifier\n\n\u201cMy throat gets really dry on plane rides, so I have a little portable humidifier that I bring. It actually just plugs into a phone charger, it\u2019s a USB-powered humidifier. What you do is you get a water bottle, and you screw it in, and the water bottle creates the moisture for the humidifier. So that\u2019s always exciting.\u201d", "title": "What Rachel Bloom Can\u2019t Travel Without", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Alipoor doesn\u2019t think \u201cThe Believers\u201d is about ideology, but about technology and its impact on masculinity. The characters are all frustrated young men who can briefly make sense of their dismal, unrewarding lives via fantasies they access through their screens. What they believe and how sincerely they believe it is irrelevant. The medium is the message.\n\nCrucially, Ethan never attempts to take violent action. As Mr. Alipoor points out, most in his position don\u2019t. The two Muslim characters do, but Mr. Alipoor said that in terms of Britain\u2019s total Muslim population, they\u2019re in a minority of \u201cless than one 1,000th of one percent.\u201d\n\n\u201cMore jihadi videos are viewed in the U.K. than in the rest of the E.U.,\u201d Mr. Alipoor said. But, he continued, \u201cFewer British Muslims per capita have gone to fight for the Islamic State in Syria than almost anywhere else in Europe with a significant Muslim population, including Belgium and the Netherlands.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cTo me that suggests that the vast majority of people who are watching those videos in the U.K. are watching them for the same reason that any young man watches a video: a violent kind of slightly sexualized pornographic ding in the middle of the night.\u201d\n\nThere is no hard evidence that social media has led to an uptick in radicalization, said Dr. Ketan Alder of Lancaster University, a specialist in media, religion and politics who acted as a consultant in the show\u2019s early stages.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think there\u2019s anything that could possibly demonstrate that there\u2019s a quantifiable link between recruitment and the videos,\u201d he said in an interview, in which he argued that many of the web radicals who made this propaganda were trying to convince themselves as much as others. \u201cIf you look at Islamic State activist videos, it\u2019s not just about recruiting in the West, it\u2019s about the activists proving to themselves that they are men.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Believers Are But Brothers\u201d is in essence a show about toxic masculinity in the internet age. But it documents it rather than explains it, and refuses to be drawn into pat explanations or false empathy. All of the characters come from comfortable enough backgrounds. None of them have to do what they do. But doing it is made easier by the device that whirs away in the audience\u2019s pockets throughout the show.\n\n\u201cTo me what the show is about is the fantasy of screens,\u201d Mr. Alipoor said. \u201cWhat 21st-century digital technology seems to have done is make some nightmares and dreams become real. It has made some people want to go into the screen.\u201d", "title": "What Radicalizes Young Men? This Show Tells You via WhatsApp", "authors": ["Andrzej Lukowski"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "A year into the Trump administration, Americans have a pretty good idea what the president has been watching on TV during his time in office, largely thanks to his active Twitter feed.\n\nBut if you look closely, Twitter gives us a sense of what President Trump may be reading as well. Indeed, here are the books that seem to have sat on the White House nightstand this year.\n\nForty-two days after taking office, Trump wrote his first book-related tweet as president. In a 4.a.m. comment on March 3, he announced that \u201cGreen Card Warrior: My Quest for Legal Immigration in an Illegals\u2019 System,\u201d a book by Nick Adams, a conservative commentator from Australia seeking permanent-resident status in the United States, was a \u201cmust read.\u201d", "title": "What Sat on Trump\u2019s Nightstand This Year?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDo you consider yourself a millennial, or are you part of some other generational group?\n\nWhat should be the name of your generation?\n\nIn \u201cTell Us What to Call the Generation After Millennials (Please),\u201d Jonah Engel Bromwich writes:\n\nMillennials are getting older. Not that much older, of course. We\u2019re a roughly defined generational cohort, but arguably the oldest members of our demographic set are just beginning to reach the age of 40. Meanwhile, the American generation behind millennials has started to move into the workplace. And while some have proposed names for this group born in 1995 and after \u2014 Generation Z, Post-Millennials, The Homeland Generation, iGeneration \u2014 all of these names are bad. The first two don\u2019t even strive for originality! Come on. Then again, it\u2019s hard to know what makes a generational name stick. \u201cMillennial\u201d was coined in the late 1980s by the consultants Neil Howe and William Strauss, both baby boomers, before the term Generation X was even popularized. (They wanted to call them \u201c13th Gen,\u201d but that didn\u2019t stick, and neither did \u201cslackers.\u201d) But their term \u201cmillennial\u201d did not become the dominant name for the huge generation after those two until much later. \u201cIn retrospect, it\u2019s easy to see that names that people gravitate to say something,\u201d Mr. Howe said in a recent interview. \u201cEither the name itself or the way in which it was adapted.\u201d But Malcolm Harris, the millennial author of \u201cKids These Days: Human Capital and the Making of Millennials,\u201d argues that those most interested in naming generations are those trying to sell things to that cohort. \u201cGenerations are really only understood in retrospect,\u201d Mr. Harris said. \u201cSome people have a financial interest in naming them as soon as possible, people trying to sell stuff.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 What makes a generational name stick, in your view?\n\n\u2014 Do you agree with the author Malcolm Harris that \u201cgenerations are really only understood in retrospect\u201d? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 Do you like any of the proposed names for the generational group that comes after millennials? If not, what suggestions do you have for a new name for the group born in 1995 and after?\n\n\u2014 What is the best generational name for people ages 22 and younger, and why? Add your suggestion in our comment box, and make sure to fill out the form, too, here, at the end of the Times article we use for this Student Opinion question.\n\nFor a related Learning Network lesson on millennials, written by a student, see Minding the Generation Gap: Investigating Media Portrayals of Millennials and \u2018Gen Z.\u2019", "title": "What Should We Call Your Generation?", "authors": ["Caroline Crosson Gilpin", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "America\u2019s immigration system was a mess before Mr. Trump took office, but so far he has injected only poison and confusion into the work of rationalizing it. Many studies have shown that immigrants commit crimes at far lower rates than native-born Americans, and experts say the evidence doesn\u2019t support any claim that undocumented immigrants commit a disproportionate amount of crime. But Mr. Trump again on Tuesday raised the specter of an immigrant crime rampage. He\u2019s right that the gang MS-13 is a terrible scourge; he was deeply wrong to suggest it was somehow representative of immigration\u2019s effects on the nation.\n\nDigging in on his maximalist demands for limiting legal immigration and dividing immigrant families, Mr. Trump said he would bring the immigration system into the 21st century. He\u2019s actually trying to drag it back to a shameful, bigoted past.\n\nIn the campaign, Mr. Trump promised a new kind of politics, a populist administration that would end corruption in the capital, crack down on Wall Street and deliver for Middle America. Instead, underneath distracting surface spectacles like his trolling on Twitter, he is delivering the most ruthless, conventionally conservative domestic policy in memory. Nowhere is this more evident than in the way he is packing the courts \u2014 including the Supreme Court \u2014 with far-right justices, taking advantage of the vacancies created by nihilistic Republican filibusters of Obama appointees. Washington is more paralyzed than ever by partisanship, and as for corruption \u2014 well, lobbyists can now do their deals in the bar of the Trump International Hotel.\n\nHow, then, can we say with Donald Trump as president that the state of the union is strong? Here, Mr. Trump deserves much of the credit: So far, the reaction against his authoritarian impulses, assault on truth and cruelties great and petty has revealed abiding American strengths. Despite the strong economy, Americans overwhelmingly disapprove of this presidency. Most Americans say immigrants strengthen the country, according to the Pew Research Center. A profound national reckoning is underway over the status and treatment of women. Voters have streamed to the polls in off-year elections, defying suppression efforts even in Alabama to register their revulsion at Trumpian politics.\n\nAs a national party, the Democrats have yet to find a coherent, appealing voice with which to do more than rail against Mr. Trump and instead address the nation\u2019s needs. But as Republican members of Congress, in disgust or despair, choose not to run again, first-time candidates, many of them women, are stepping forward at the grass roots across the United States.\n\nIf not exactly \u201cwoke,\u201d this country might certainly be described as awakening, with a shot at shedding the civic apathy that has afflicted it for far too long. It is with backhanded gratitude that we might all thank President Trump for that.", "title": "Opinion | What Trump Doesn\u2019t Get About the State of the Union", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "5. African health officials have strongly promoted breast-feeding to make sure that babies get the healthiest possible start in life. So while 20 percent of American babies are exclusively breast-fed for the first six months of life, the figure is 42 percent in sub-Saharan Africa. In Rwanda, it\u2019s a stunning 87 percent.\n\n6. African governments have conscientiously followed recommendations of the World Health Assembly to curb infant formula marketing that discourages breast-feeding; the U.S. has not. In this respect, suggests Shawn Baker of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, \u201cThe U.S. might benefit from technical assistance from Botswana.\u201d\n\n7. Nigeria ensures that 93 percent of households get iodized salt, to reduce iodine deficiency that causes mental disability as well as goiters. In the U.S., only a bit more than half of salt sold to households is iodized, and iodine deficiency is becoming more common.\n\n8. At a time when much of the rich world has turned against refugees, Uganda has quietly accepted more than one million South Sudan refugees. Likewise, the Diffa region of Niger is heroic in taking in refugees from northern Nigeria, and it now resettles refugees at extraordinarily high rates, helping the newcomers rather than demonizing them.\n\n9. In the latest Freedom House index, the U.S. fell in the rankings of freedom and democracy and is now outranked by two African countries, Cape Verde and Mauritius. Both successfully manage multiracial societies in a way we can learn from.\n\n10. The fastest-growing economy in the world is Ethiopia\u2019s, according to the World Economic Forum, with Tanzania\u2019s and Djibouti\u2019s also in the top six. They are all growing more than twice as fast as the U.S. economy.\n\n11. The Trump administration could learn something about diplomacy from Botswana, which asked the U.S. to please clarify whether the U.S. considers Botswana a shithole. No bluster, no military threats, no rude tweets \u2014 but the point was made.", "title": "Opinion | What We Can Learn From \u2018S-Hole Countries\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "More than a decade ago, I was coming off a successful summer stint as a Wall Street Journal reporting intern. Naturally, I vied with other interns for a full-time reporting job. A post came up in the Hong Kong bureau. Did I, a Cantonese speaker with prior Asian reporting experience, get it? I wasn\u2019t even asked to apply. Instead, a fellow intern with no prior Asia experience was hired. He was white.\n\nLater, the Journal offered me a part-time reporting job in Hong Kong, which I took to get a foot in the door. But it was a struggle to achieve pay parity from such a lowly start, even after winning awards and a shared Pulitzer. \u201cYou\u2019re asking for a 70 percent pay raise! That\u2019s never been given before,\u201d I heard from an editor during salary negotiations. How hilarious, I thought at the time, that The Journal should expect its reporters to understand the financial intricacies of large corporations while swallowing this kind of flimflam. But the joke was on us.\n\nLast year, the Independent Association of Publishers\u2019 Employees reported a persistent wage gap between men and women employed by Dow Jones, The Journal\u2019s parent company. The report found that full-time female employees make on average less than 85 percent of what their male counterparts earn, even when accounting for differences in age and location. And there is a distinct and persistent gap between pay for men and for women, even when they hold the same job title and have worked the same amount of time. Dow Jones female employees in New York \u2014 hardly a cheap place to live \u2014 made $10,000 less than their male counterparts, and $13,000 less in Washington. Multiply that difference over the span of a career and that\u2019s the home you can never buy, or several children\u2019s college educations.\n\nNone of this is, of course, unique to media: The gender pay gap is an unfortunate feature of many industries, from banking to Hollywood to even female-dominated industries, such as cleaning and teaching. But this particular pay gap affects our crucial understanding of China\u2019s rise, one of the biggest news stories of our time.\n\nForeign correspondents of Carrie Gracie\u2019s caliber, who are fluent in the language and have several decades of experience, are rare. Spanning 10 years, her stories on a rural farming community\u2019s transformation into a huge city is one of the definitive narratives of China\u2019s urbanization process. Foreign correspondents of her caliber who are women, who have spent their careers underpaid and faced challenges their male peers never had to, are rarer still. While there\u2019s no accurate data comparing the numbers of male and female foreign correspondents, it\u2019s quite likely that the figures mirror or surpass those of general newsrooms, which are two-thirds male. Such imbalances are certainly reflected in journalism prizes, as Pulitzers for international reporting and even the Martha Gellhorn Prize \u2014 named for a female correspondent \u2014 go overwhelmingly to men.", "title": "Opinion | What We Lose When We Lose Female Reporters", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "At least a dozen members of Congress wore purple ribbons at President Trump\u2019s State of the Union address on Tuesday night to help raise awareness about the country\u2019s opioid epidemic.\n\nIn October, Mr. Trump declared that the crisis had become a \u201cpublic health emergency.\u201d Overdoses killed about 64,000 Americans in 2016, making it the leading cause of death for people under 50.\n\nMr. Trump mentioned the opioid crises again in his speech on Tuesday.\n\n\u201cWe must get much tougher on drug dealers and pushers if we are going to succeed in stopping this scourge,\u201d Mr. Trump said, noting the number of overdose deaths in 2016. \u201cMy administration is committed to fighting the drug epidemic and helping get treatment for those in need. The struggle will be long and difficult \u2014 but, as Americans always do, we will prevail.\u201d\n\nLawmakers who donned the purple ribbons included Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, as well as Senators Maggie Hassan and Jeanne Shaheen, both Democrats of New Hampshire. Ms. Reed takes a long view of the difficulties that women have had being elected to or chosen for political office in the United States since its founding, reintroducing us to pivotal progressive figures like Albert Gallatin and Jeannette Rankin (the first woman elected to national office and still the only congresswoman ever to represent Montana). \u2014 Jonah Engel Bromwich, reporter, Express Team\n\n_____", "title": "What We\u2019re Reading", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Much Fire ...\n\nFrom Hollywood Reporter: Outsiders have viewed the Trump administration much like one of the reality shows the president is famous for \u2014 a chaotic spectacle. Her book \u201cI\u2019m Fine \u2026 and Other Lies\u201d was published in October. The film \u201cThe Female Brain,\u201d which she wrote and directed, will be released on Feb. 9.\n\nMs. Cummings has mastered the art of travel, from maintaining her skin care regimen on the plane to the ideal hotel sleep routine. She is a self-defined \u201cpsycho\u201d about miles programs (she has \u201cmore miles than I\u2019ll ever be able to use\u201d and likes the JetBlue credit card because \u201ctheir customer service is unbelievable\u201d). And she\u2019s learned to be unusually productive when she flies.\n\n\u201cBeing on the plane is my catch-up time,\u201d she said. \u201cI write thank-you notes. I read. I write stand-up jokes. For writing stand-up, I have to have a little bit of anger and frustration to be motivated to do it. Stand-up for me comes from kind of a hostile engine. And by the time I\u2019ve done the airport and gone through PreCheck and fought with nine people and had luggage stub my toe, I\u2019m ready to write.\u201d\n\nShe\u2019s not shy when it comes to what she calls \u201cowning her space\u201d on the plane. \u201cI\u2019m in the television and movie business and I want to know what people are interested in, so I\u2019ll slowly, creepily, walk down and look at everyone\u2019s computer screen to see what they\u2019re watching. If I hear someone laughing I\u2019ll go back and see what they\u2019re watching.\u201d", "title": "What Whitney Cummings Can\u2019t Travel Without", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "She first wore an outfit by Ms. Hearst at the Sundance Film Festival last year, and the two soon struck up a friendship. For the Met Gala last May, Ms. Dern not only wore a peekaboo navy column dress by Ms. Hearst, but also invited the designer along as her date.\n\nRemoving her wrap, Ms. Dern headed for the racks of clothes, beelining for a black belted dress made of wool from Ms. Hearst\u2019s ranch in Uruguay. Ms. Dern ran a hand over it, relishing a sheer panel. \u201cEvery texture is thrilling,\u201d she said. \u201cThis is what happens when women work together, when women are designing for women.\u201d\n\nThe choice of black was no accident. In response to the reckoning of sexual misconduct throughout Hollywood, Ms. Dern is among the 300 women, including famous actors, producers and directors, who formed a movement called Time\u2019s Up. Along with other things, the group is asking that women wear black on the red carpet to raise awareness.\n\n\u201cThis is a beautiful opportunity,\u201d she said firmly. She has also been working with the group to help victims of sexual misconduct navigate the awards season. \u201cThey don\u2019t need to be on the red carpet at an awards event talking about their personal assault or harassment,\u201d she said. \u201cLet\u2019s talk about women.\u201d\n\nBut even anxious moments call for beautiful clothes, and Ms. Dern doesn\u2019t apologize for embracing fashion. \u201cIt\u2019s the most beautiful art form,\u201d she said.\u201d I\u2019ve always loved it, so I\u2019ve never felt trite about it.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019m so lucky that I have these beautiful friends, brilliant actresses \u2014 Isabella Rossellini, Julianne Moore, Naomi Watts \u2014 these are great artists,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd, oh my God, if you hear us talk about fashion. We are obsessed.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter setting the belted wool dress aside, Ms. Dern sifted through four racks of clothing and paged through the spring look book, picking out pieces that she wanted pulled. It felt more like a shopping spree on Net-a-Porter than a cliffhanger on \u201cThe Rachel Zoe Project.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt one point, Ms. Dern even pushed into the back room, where prototypes and leftovers are kept. \u201cI am very embarrassed to show you this mess right now,\u201d Ms. Hearst said. But Ms. Dern didn\u2019t seem to mind.\n\nEvery piece seemed to delight Ms. Dern, and if any weren\u2019t to her taste, she kept it to herself. (Everything was \u201cbeautiful\u201d or \u201cgorgeous,\u201d unless it was merely \u201cpretty.\u201d)\n\nIt was too cold to wriggle out of her jeans and boots, so Ms. Dern and her stylist kept a tally of items she might like to order for luncheons and press gauntlets. From a look book, Ms. Dern chose a long-sleeve black blouse paired with a gold lam\u00e9 skirt. \u201cI\u2019d love to wear these together,\u201d she said. A handbag shaped like a concertina also caught her eye. \u201cWho makes this?\u201d Ms. Dern said. \u201cThis is insane.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. McMaster and Gary Cohn (if Mr. Trump goes)\n\nThat\u2019s a big delegation for a populist leader to send to a hotbed of global elitism.\n\nHot topics at Davos\n\n\u2022 Populism \u2014 though, Mr. Trump aside, anxiety is on the wane (NYT)\n\n\u2022 How long the world\u2019s economies can continue to expand (NYT)\n\n\u2022 How to respond to cyberwarfare by the likes of North Korea (NYT)\n\n\u2022 How to improve women\u2019s standing in the world, with several top women leaders in attendance (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Big tech companies\u2019 image woes (FT)\n\n\u2022 France\u2019s efforts to woo business leaders, including a pre-Davos summit at Versailles that will be attended by Jamie Dimon and Sheryl Sandberg (Reuters)\n\nBacardi wants to get into premium tequila.\n\nBacardi has agreed to buy Patron Spirits International for $5.1 billion, the WSJ\u2019s Carla Lombardo reports.\n\nThe deal between the two privately held companies ranks as one of the biggest liquor deals in recent years.\n\nWhy Bacardi is doing the deal according to the WSJ:\n\n\u2022 \u201cU.S. volumes of super-premium tequila jumped more than 700% from 2002 to 2016, compared with a 121% rise in all tequila volumes over the same period, according to the Distilled Spirits Council.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Patr\u00f3n is the premium tequila market leader with U.S. sales of $1.6 billion in 2016, according to Euromonitor, a market research firm.\n\nCan you remember the last time stocks pulled back?\n\nWe here at DealBook will forgive if you don\u2019t. It has been a long time.\n\nWith Monday\u2019s close, the S&P 500 has now gone 395 sessions without a decline of 5% or more from a record high, MoneyBeat\u2019s Ben Eisen reports. That\u2019s the longest streak on record, surpassing the previous record of 394 trading days set in the mid-1990s.\n\nSo when was the last time the market fell 5 percent from a recent high? The aftermath of Brexit in June 2016.\n\nMorgan Stanley says Harold Ford Jr. wasn\u2019t fired for sexual misconduct.\n\nKate Kelly of NYT reports that six weeks after firing the former congressman Harold E. Ford Jr. for unspecified misconduct, Morgan Stanley has clarified that the misconduct was not sexual in nature.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe statement is part of a legal settlement that Mr. Ford reached over the weekend with Morgan Stanley, according to a person who was briefed on the resolution but was not authorized to speak publicly. The broader contours of the settlement were unclear, including whether there was a financial component. Through a spokesman, Mr. Ford declined to comment.\n\nBefore his firing last month, Mr. Ford had spent seven years at Morgan Stanley recruiting clients. He joined the investment banking industry after losing a United States Senate race in Tennessee as the Democratic nominee in 2006.\n\nMr. Ford, 47, was fired after a female journalist told Morgan Stanley that he had harassed her at a dinner in 2014. At the time, Morgan Stanley said he had been fired \u201cfor conduct inconsistent with our values and in violation of our policies.\u201d Some media reports of his firing said it had been triggered by the harassment allegation.\n\nDan Loeb keeps the pressure on Nestl\u00e9\n\nSince Mr. Loeb\u2019s Third Point emerged as an investor in the Swiss food giant, Nestl\u00e9 has sold off its U.S. confectionary business, named new directors and bought Blue Bottle coffee.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAll of those have been great moves, according to the hedge fund. But there\u2019s more to be done, Third Point wrote in its latest letter to investors.\n\nFrom the investor letter:\n\nThese actions are important steps in the right direction that make it clear that Nestle\u0301 is responding to calls for action. While we recognize that Nestle\u0301 has certain unique cultural and structural constraints, we hope now that Dr. Schneider has completed his first year and there is new blood on the Board, the company is able to move with greater alacrity.\n\nWhat Third Point wants\n\n\u2022 Better demonstrate that the company is focused on \u201cnutrition, health and wellness,\u201d with the implication being to divest products like ice cream and frozen pizza.\n\n\u2022 Buy back more shares.\n\n\u2022 Again consider selling the L\u2019Oreal stake, something Nestl\u00e9 has been loath to do historically.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nCharles Kushner isn\u2019t worried about Robert Mueller\n\nThe father of Jared Kushner, who is again working at the family real estate business \u2014 this time without a title \u2014 told the WaPo in an interview that the Kushner Companies hasn\u2019t been a target of the Russia investigation so far and hasn\u2019t had problems getting financing.\n\nMore from the article by Michael Kranish of the WaPo:\n\n\u201cAll I know is that we are not at all concerned, and we are cooperating,\u201d Kushner said in a half-hour interview at his headquarters at 666 Fifth Avenue. \u201cAnd they can knock themselves out for the next 10 years reading those papers as far as I\u2019m concerned.\u201d\n\nThe elder Mr. Kushner also lamented the amount of criticism that his son, a senior presidential adviser, has taken:\n\n\u201cI try not to focus in my life on the haters but it\u2019s just, I have never seen anything like this,\u201d Kushner said.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nA.I.G. becomes a big acquirer once again\n\nThe insurer\u2019s $5.56 billion deal to acquire Validus Holdings signals that the company is increasingly looking outward, instead of inward, as it had done since its bailout during the global financial crisis. Validus is A.I.G.\u2019s biggest acquisition by far over the past decade, according to Standard & Poor\u2019s Global Market Intelligence.\n\nThe transaction is expected to bolster the A.I.G.\u2019s general insurance business, by adding a reinsurance platform, an insurance-linked securities asset manager and \u201ca meaningful presence\u201d at the Lloyd\u2019s of London marketplace.\n\nHere\u2019s what Brian Duperreault, A.I.G.\u2019s chief executive, said:\n\n\u201cValidus is an excellent strategic fit for AIG, bringing new businesses and capabilities to our General Insurance operation, expanding the bench of our management team and deepening our underwriting expertise.\u201d\n\nThe details\n\n\u2022 Validus shareholders would receive $68 a share in cash.\n\n\u2022 Shares of Validus closed Friday at $46.72, meaning the deal represents a 46 percent premium.\n\n\u2022 The transaction is expected to close in mid-2018.\n\nThe advisers\n\nFor A.I.G.: Citigroup, Perella Weinberg Partners and the law firm Debevoise & Plimpton\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor Validus: JPMorgan Chase and the law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom\n\n\u2014 Chad Bray\n\nCelgene continues its deal streak with Juno\n\nIn offering to buy the Juno shares that it doesn\u2019t already own for about $9 billion, Celgene is adding a maker of blood disease treatments. Perhaps more notably, it shows that the biopharmaceutical company is still on the hunt for more acquisitions.\n\nRemember that earlier this month, Celgene agreed to pay up to $7 billion for Impact Biomedicines, which also makes a treatment for a kind of blood cancer.\n\nCelgene, which is based in Summit, N.J., already owns about 9.7 percent of Juno\u2019s shares.\n\nHere\u2019s what Mark Alles, Celgene\u2019s C.E.O., said:\n\n\u201cThe acquisition of Juno builds on our shared vision to discover and develop transformative medicines for patients with incurable blood cancers.\u201d\n\nThe details\n\n\u2022 Celgene would pay $87 a share in cash for each share of Juno.\n\n\u2022 Juno\u2019s shares closed on Friday at $67.81, meaning the deal is at a 28 percent premium.\n\n\u2022 The transaction is expected to close in the first quarter.\n\nThe advisers\n\nFor Celgene: JPMorgan and the law firms Proskauer Rose and Hogan Lovells\n\nFor Juno: Morgan Stanley and the law firm Skadden\n\n\u2014 Chad Bray\n\nPhoto\n\nWhy markets should worry about a long shutdown\n\nFrom a recent note by analysts at Pantheon Macroeconomics:\n\nWe would be astonished if Congress could not cobble together a majority of the sane in order to prevent a default. But astonishment has been quite common in response to events over the past couple of years, so investors would be well-advised to rule out nothing, however outlandish.\n\nHere\u2019s more on the damage from a prolonged shutdown from the NYT.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhere things stand\n\nA group of moderate lawmakers is still working on a compromise. The Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, has scheduled a vote on a temporary funding bill for noon E.T. today, though it\u2019s unclear whether it will pass.\n\nElsewhere in Washington\n\n\u2022 Wilbur Ross has fallen from Mr. Trump\u2019s graces because of a perceived inability to strike good trade deals and a propensity to sleep in meetings. (Axios)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 How Jared Kushner became a focal point for China\u2019s diplomatic outreach to the U.S. \u2014 and stirred up the worries of U.S. officials. (New Yorker)\n\n\u2022 Deutsche Bank has flagged bank accounts tied to the Kushner family for \u201csuspicious transactions\u201d and referred the matter to German authorities \u2014 and may send its information to Robert Mueller as well, according to Manager Magazin of Germany. (Manager, Mother Jones)\n\nCorporate profits are shrinking. What gives?\n\nThe tax overhaul signed into law last month is muddying the fourth-quarter earnings picture.\n\nImproving corporate profit have been a pillar of the current rally, and analysts have forecast robust earnings growth in the coming months as the global economy gained momentum.\n\nYet with 11 percent of S&P 500 companies having reported four-quarter results, profits have slipped 0.2 percent from a year ago. That\u2019s well below the 10 percent analysts expected ahead of earnings season.\n\nSo what gives? The tax law.\n\nLarge financial firms, which have made up the bulk of companies reporting thus far, have taken big one-time, tax-related charges. Profits for financial firms in the S&P 500 fell $29.2 billion, or 57 percent. Citigroup accounted for 73 percent of that decline. John Butters, a senior earnings analyst at FactSet, writes:\n\n\u201cPrior to the earnings release, many analysts had not updated their EPS estimates to reflect the impact of the charge. However, since the majority of analysts covering Citigroup provide EPS estimates to FactSet on a GAAP basis, the tax charge was included in the actual EPS for comparison.\u201d\n\nExclude Citi, and the earnings growth rate for the S&P 500 would improve to 7.9 percent from -0.2 percent.\n\nTwo points of note:\n\n\u2022 \u201cWhile some of the biggest banks are reporting fourth-quarter earnings hits stemming from the new tax law, they see rich benefits over the long term, including effective tax rates that are even lower than the new 21 percent corporate rate,\u201d as NYT\u2019s Jim Tankersley reported last week.\n\n\u2022 As the fourth-quarter earnings growth rate has fallen over the last week for S&P 500 companies, profit expectations for 2018 have risen.\n\nPhoto\n\nFacebook isn\u2019t certain it\u2019s good for democracy\n\nHere\u2019s what Samidh Chakrabarti, a product manager at the tech giant, wrote in a post on the company\u2019s Hard Questions blog:\n\nFacebook was originally designed to connect friends and family \u2014 and it has excelled at that. But as unprecedented numbers of people channel their political energy through this medium, it\u2019s being used in unforeseen ways with societal repercussions that were never anticipated.\n\nMr. Chakrabarti added that while the company was slow to address Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election, it\u2019s working to prevent it happening again.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore news from Facebook\n\n\u2022 It spooked some publishers again by saying it would let users rank the trustworthiness of news outlets. (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nCan Bitcoin mining go green?\n\nRight now, the computation to \u201cproduce\u201d a new Bitcoin uses as much energy as an American household consumes in two years, according to analysts at Morgan Stanley and the economist Alex de Vries. Some in the virtual currency community are looking for ways to reduce that figure.\n\nHere\u2019s what Vitalik Buterin, the creator of Ethereum, told Nathaniel Popper of the NYT:\n\n\u201cI would personally feel very unhappy if my main contribution to the world was adding Cyprus\u2019s worth of electricity consumption to global warming.\u201d\n\nSome, however, say an independent, decentralized monetary system is worth the cost.\n\nThe virtual currency flyaround\n\n\u2022 Louis Dreyfus has teamed up with ING and ABN Amro of the Netherlands and Soci\u00e9t\u00e9 G\u00e9n\u00e9rale of France to create a blockchain platform for agricultural trading.
