Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "What Will Trump Do in Davos: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "On Wednesday, a group of security experts revealed two security flaws that affect nearly all microprocessors, the digital brains of the world\u2019s computers. These flaws, called Meltdown and Spectre, could allow hackers to lift passwords, photos, documents and other data from smartphones, PCs and the cloud computing services that many businesses rely on.\n\nSome of the world\u2019s largest tech companies have been working on fixes for these problems. But the researchers who discovered the flaws said one of them, Spectre, is not completely fixable. \u201cIt is a fundamental flaw in the way processors have been built over the last decades,\u201d said Paul Kocher, one of the researchers who discovered these flaws.\n\nHere is a guide to what you need to know and what you should do.\n\nWhere exactly are these flaws?\n\nBoth are issues with the way computer chips are designed.\n\nMeltdown affects most processors made by Intel, the company that supplies the chips for a majority of PCs and more than 90 percent of computer servers.", "title": "What You Need to Do Because of Flaws in Computer Chips", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "But it\u2019s also more intimate and personalized than a spin class. The company produces more than a dozen classes every day in a variety of lengths, tailored to every workout style. The instructors are shot close up, and they often shout out the names and accomplishments of home riders, as if they are cheering you on directly. The bond between rider and instructor runs so deep that Peloton\u2019s instructors have become the sort of social media celebrities who are instantly mobbed on the street.\n\n\u201cWhen you have the endorphins flowing and you\u2019re in people\u2019s homes three to seven times a week, there\u2019s a real familiarity that builds up \u2014 and so, yeah, it\u2019s a little interesting when people stop me at the supermarket to say hi,\u201d said Robin Arzon, Peloton\u2019s vice president for fitness programming and its chief instructor.\n\nIf this sounds over-the-top, you\u2019re right: The Peloton cult is real.\n\nThat annoying friend who can\u2019t shut up about how SoulCycle is her church? Peloton groupies are kind of like that, only more insistent, because they also point out how convenient it is \u2014 you can Peloton at any time without prebooking, without commuting, in any clothes you want. They are also likely to argue they are saving money, too: If you ride three times a week for a year, you\u2019ll pay about $16 per Peloton workout in your first year, cheaper than classes at many fitness studios.\n\n\u201cOver 95 percent of the bikes we\u2019ve ever sold are still paying subscriptions,\u201d Mr. Foley said.\n\nAnd here\u2019s a confession: I\u2019m one of them. After hearing three different people in the tech industry sing the bike\u2019s praises last summer, I asked Peloton to send me a bike to review to see what the fuss was about. After three weeks, I couldn\u2019t give it up. I called up the company and handed over my credit card number. I\u2019ve been a committed rider ever since.", "title": "What a $4,000 Treadmill Means for the Future of Gadgets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Alas, her career mostly predated the era when film and TV routinely came to international opera houses. We have some wonderful films of Callas in concert. And there is an amazing video of her in Act II of Puccini\u2019s \u201cTosca\u201d in 1964.\n\nBut no full operas by one of the greatest singing actresses in history; this hologram performance can seem to fill in a bit of that gap. The operatic voice, and the art form itself, can feel so fragile. What better way to represent that fragility \u2014 while also reviving it, in a kind of s\u00e9ance \u2014 than a hologram?\n\nThe respected stage director Stephen Wadsworth, with a distinguished record in opera and theater (including a production of Terrence McNally\u2019s \u201cMaster Class,\u201d about Callas), is the creative director for this \u201cCallas in Concert.\u201d In introductory comments, Mr. Wadsworth said that the project has tried to present Callas with \u201crestraint, subtlety and delicacy.\u201d The notion of a singing hologram might seem incompatible with such a goal. Yet moments during Sunday\u2019s preview were surprisingly affecting.\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter the \u201cHabanera\u201d from \u201cCarmen,\u201d this Callas sang the Act III scene in which Carmen reads her fortune in some cards and sees death foretold for herself and her lover. In the recording that was used, Callas\u2019s singing was chillingly subtle and sad. In the hall, however, the sound was a little spotty, at times tinny (the producers say they are still tweaking the technology).\n\nAt the end of the excerpt, the holographic Callas tossed Carmen\u2019s cards into the air above her, where they hovered in space for a moment before slowly drifting down, an effect that allowed the conductor time to segue seamlessly into the next aria, from \u201cMacbeth.\u201d Though a melodramatic touch, it worked. If you\u2019re going to use hologram technology, then it makes sense to go all out and create something new, rather than just copy a standard concert.\n\nThere were several stretches during Lady Macbeth\u2019s sleepwalking scene that got to me, mostly because the real Callas\u2019s singing on the recording was so honest and revealing. At her best, Callas redefined what it meant to sing beautifully. Her deeply emotional, sometimes delicate, sometimes frayed singing of the Verdi aria was the essence of truth, something that cut through all the holographic stage tricks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut what is the point of this spectacle? Who is the intended audience? Callas, a symbol of chic, remains an object of fascination extending even beyond opera fans. Perhaps the hologram will introduce some newcomers to her incredible artistry; I\u2019d urge everyone to listen to Callas\u2019s extensive discography. Like so many now, I loved her without ever seeing her live; this holographic specter was weirdly tantalizing, even if it hardly made up for that.\n\nThe problem, as it always has been in opera fandom, will be if this specter from the past prevents a full appreciation of the vitality of opera and singing today. Lovers of opera, more than probably any other art form, have always been too quick to complain that the \u201cgolden age\u201d has long since left us, and have preferred to sit at home with their records rather than seek out young performers and live, necessarily imperfect performances.\n\nRather than recommend that fledgling operagoers hear Callas\u2019s hologram, I\u2019d tell them to get to the Metropolitan Opera, where Sonya Yoncheva and Anna Netrebko singing \u201cTosca\u201d this season will tell them much more about what makes opera so endlessly exciting.", "title": "What a Hologram of Maria Callas Can Teach Us About Opera", "authors": ["Anthony Tommasini"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nQ. Tall kiosks labeled \u201cLinkNYC\u201d are replacing phone booths, offering free Wi-Fi and nationwide phone calls. The thing is, I have never seen anybody using one. What gives?\n\nA. Compared with the pay phones they often replace, LinkNYC kiosks, known as Links, get plenty of use, even if no one is standing next to them.\n\nAccording to CityBridge, the consortium that operates LinkNYC, over 3.2 million people have registered for the system\u2019s Wi-Fi service, with 600,000 users each week. The Wi-Fi operates at gigabit speed, meaning it can be up to 100 times faster than cellular LTE networks. The range of a Link is about 150 feet in any direction.\n\nLinks are a critical piece in the city\u2019s goal to bring broadband internet access to all New Yorkers, but the system\u2019s community-first approach provides other social benefits, as well.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEach Link has an interactive screen, which offers everyday information you might expect, like weather, local maps, and transit updates, as well as a connection to the city\u2019s 311 service. Through a partnership with the software program Aunt Bertha, however, users can anonymously search for nonprofit and social services.", "title": "What are those tall kiosks that have replaced pay phones in New York?", "authors": ["Keith Williams"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Rebecca Ribiero, 45, a hospital social worker of Newfield, N.Y. Her husband, Alexandre, 42, is an assistant manager at Cornell University. CHIP covers their son, Max, 12, who has a learning disorder.\n\nI worry about what will happen to my kids, and to my husband and me, in the future if CHIP were to go the way of the dinosaur. My husband and I would have to evaluate which of our employers would offer the best deal. We\u2019re lucky that\u2019s even an option to consider, but insurance through my employer would still be $200 per month, as opposed to the $45 we pay now. We would have to cut back even more, and honestly, find out where to cut. We keep a pretty tight budget and we live simply. We don\u2019t have cable. I shop at thrift stores for myself so I can afford a car that works.\n\nMax has a learning disorder; his school has done testing and they\u2019re able to get some reimbursement through CHIP, and I\u2019m not sure if that would be true through my employer\u2019s insurance. It\u2019s hard enough for a small school that doesn\u2019t have a lot of money; testing is very expensive and it took them years to do so, in part because of financial concerns. The Individualized Education Plan, or IEP, has been very, very supportive. If CHIP folds, what happens to my son, to the school district and to the other kids relying on state-subsidized insurance?", "title": "What if CHIP Funds Run Out? Here\u2019s What 6 Families Would Do", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Should she have broken her word to you in order to satisfy her child\u2019s curiosity? Adopted children are naturally curious about their biological parents. Occasionally, they even have a need to find things out about them in order to understand their medical situation, though that will be increasingly unnecessary as we get to know more about the human genome. But if we want to encourage unprepared mothers to consider giving children up for adoption, we should respect the terms on which they want to do it, and \u2014 for reasons your case illustrates \u2014 this means allowing them to insist on privacy, absent some weighty countervailing consideration. I understand why someone would give in to the persistent demands of a child she loved, but the child\u2019s mere curiosity probably wasn\u2019t a good-enough reason to break the covenant.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNow your biological child wants to establish a connection with you. But this isn\u2019t something she\u2019s entitled to, which means that you\u2019re entitled to decline. It would be an act of generosity, given your feelings, to meet with her again yourself. You shouldn\u2019t let her try to impose a relationship on the children you have raised, however. That decision is up to them.\n\nI\u2019m a European working in a central African country. A friend of mine (a native of that country) told me that his youngest sister was raped by his brother-in-law. He decided quickly to get him arrested. While the offender was still in detention, a huge family conflict arose. The wife of the offender, my friend\u2019s older sister, who has children, as well as his mother, argued that the case should not proceed to court. They wanted to free the offender before the community could spread the news. They feared that the family\u2019s honor would be damaged, and the victim would never find a husband (as most men here would never marry a victim of rape). My friend told me that even the victim decided to forgive the offender so that the community would never know, and she would have a chance to marry one day. But given the family pressure, I wonder if their quick pardon was genuine. I wonder if there might have been a solution to this situation, in which the victim would receive justice and still have the chance to marry one day. Name Withheld\n\nHonor codes are often brutal for victims of rape. This was true in many parts of Europe until very recently as well. In Pietro Germi\u2019s brilliant and disturbing 1964 film, \u201cSeduced and Abandoned,\u201d a man is required to stage the abduction and violation of a 16-year-old girl, who is already pregnant with his child, so that they can get married in a way that will preserve her honor and protect him from the charge of corrupting a minor. In their Sicilian community, the honor of the girl\u2019s family can be preserved only if she marries the man who has \u201cdefiled\u201d her. (And marrying a rapist is more honorable than having a child outside of marriage.) Until 1981, in fact, Article 544 of the Italian criminal code recognized a kind of marriage \u2014 the matrimonio riparatore \u2014 that \u201crepaired\u201d the wrong done by rape, even of a minor. In marrying his victim, the rapist was restoring her family\u2019s honor. Not much concern there for her feelings or interests.\n\nIn such cultures, a rape victim has a strong incentive not to press charges, however much she might believe that justice requires it. She can\u2019t have justice without becoming unmarriageable, and perhaps rendering her siblings unmarriageable as well. Unless, that is, there are decent men around who can see the wrong here. In Italy, the 1965 case that helped lead to the repeal of Article 544 involved the rape of a Sicilian teenager, Franca Viola, who refused a matrimonio riparatore and defied social codes by insisting on the prosecution of her rapist. It helped that she had a boyfriend she knew would marry her anyway and a father who was willing to accept that the family would be regarded as dishonored by most of their neighbors. Your friend\u2019s sister wasn\u2019t so lucky. And the only solution is a social movement that will reform the honor code to make it consistent with one simple moral insight: The sole person whom rape shames is the rapist. Forty years after her rape, Franca Viola told an interviewer that her advice, when faced with an important decision, was \u201cto follow always your own heart.\u201d She\u2019s a hero of mine because she makes that sound far easier than it is.", "title": "What if I Don\u2019t Want to See the Child I Gave Up for Adoption?", "authors": ["Kwame Anthony Appiah", "The Ethicist"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "In my opinion, she has a hoarding disorder and the beginnings of dementia, and she has had problems maintaining her apartment to the landlord\u2019s satisfaction. She also has trouble dealing with documents, paying bills and scammers. She never became a Canadian citizen, and her Canadian and American identification have both expired so she can no longer travel.\n\nI am in my 70s and live hundreds of miles away in the United States. I have a husband, an adult child and grandchildren, for whom I provide a lot of child care. My sister is behind my other family in my priorities, and frankly she drives my husband and me crazy. I am not willing to relocate to Canada or have her live with my husband and me.\n\nShe has refused to give me power of attorney so that I can deal with financial institutions when she has been scammed or has neglected to pay bills. For some time, she refused to admit that she has any \u201cmemory problems\u201d or to consult her doctor. She does not want anyone messing around in her business.\n\nI see her a few days each year, during which I try to touch base with the last of her friends, do some cleaning and decluttering, have some fun with her and yes, nag her to make some changes. If she continues to refuse help, may I be excused from feeling guilty?\n\nName Withheld\n\nBeing excused by me isn\u2019t likely to stop you from feeling guilty. You seem to have done all that you could reasonably be expected to do at this point. The trouble is that your sister is likely to cross the border into incompetence, where the balance shifts as to what your relationship demands. For now, you must respect her autonomy; once she reaches a certain stage, caring for her may involve ignoring her expressed wishes.\n\nEarly-onset dementia, a concern faced by our previous writer, poses one set of complications. But dementia among the elderly poses a broad social burden simply because it\u2019s so common. By 2030, all the baby boomers will be 65 or older. Last year, in Canada, the number of seniors (ages 65 or older) for the first time exceeded the number of children (14 or younger). If your sister\u2019s dementia advances, as is likely, and if she has the resources to be cared for in a residential facility (or to receive in-home care), you might want to hire a lawyer in Canada to help you manage her affairs and establish her legal identity.\n\nIf your sister received permanent residency in Canada, there are procedures for replacing an expired permanent-resident card. If she\u2019s in Canada against the law, you\u2019ll want a copy of her U.S. birth certificate, because Canada will have the right to send her back to the United States. Once she regularizes her documents, the authorities might let her back in, but if she was in a condition in which she needed frequent attention, it might be better if she were near you. The laws governing who can get certified copies of birth certificates vary by state. But as a sibling, you will generally be in a better position than a stranger. With the certificate in hand, you would be able to present it to United States consular officials in Canada in order to get her settled in a home in the United States. If she doesn\u2019t have the necessary savings, she could be eligible for Medicaid as a citizen.\n\nI\u2019ve gone into the weeds a little bit to make the point that taking over when your sister can\u2019t care for herself would be a major commitment. But no one else is in a position to do this, and as her sibling, you do owe her what philosophers call \u201cspecial obligations.\u201d Some people would like to think that such special obligations are binding only if they are voluntary. That\u2019s not the case. Your sister, ornery as she may be, has someone she can expect to help her when she can\u2019t help herself any longer. And that person, I\u2019m afraid, is you.", "title": "What if My Mother\u2019s Extramarital Cravings Are Linked to Dementia?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Research has shown that, in some cases, visual platforms can be good for us. One study, published by researchers at the University of Oregon in 2016, found that the use of image-based platforms like Instagram and Snapchat was associated with lower levels of loneliness among users, and higher levels of happiness and satisfaction, while text-based platforms had no correlation with improved mental health.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA heavily visual platform also makes a relatively poor conduit for breaking news and in-the-moment commentary, which might explain why Instagram often feels less exhausting than other social networks. (It also explains why last month, before I went on vacation, I deleted every social media app from my phone except Instagram \u2014 the only app I trusted not to ruin my beachside calm.)\n\nLesson No. 2: Rethink the share button.\n\nOne of Instagram\u2019s most underrated virtues is that it has imposed structural limits on virality \u2014 the ability of a given post to spread beyond its intended audience. Unlike Twitter and Facebook, on Instagram there is no native sharing function, meaning that the reach of most Instagram posts is capped at the number of people who follow the user\u2019s account. (There are ways to \u201cregram\u201d someone else\u2019s photo using a third-party app, but they\u2019re clunky, and relatively few people use them. Instagram also recently began showing users posts from people they don\u2019t follow, a Facebook-inspired change that I\u2019d argue is a mistake.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA native share button has been tremendously useful for Facebook\u2019s and Twitter\u2019s growth. It has also allowed upstart media organizations like BuzzFeed and Upworthy to build enormous audiences by specializing in highly shareable stories. But ease of sharing has also allowed the loudest and most emotional voices to be rewarded with clicks \u2014 and attention. It\u2019s this incentive structure that has allowed partisans and profiteers to hijack Facebook\u2019s algorithms and spread divisive messages and false news to millions of people.\n\nThe easy virality of Facebook also seems to have made individual users more hesitant about opening up. That makes sense \u2014 it\u2019s easier to share a selfie if you know it won\u2019t accidentally find its way into the feeds of a million strangers.\n\nLesson No. 3: Ban links.\n\nInstagram\u2019s greatest structural advantage, though, may be a result of its decision to go mostly link-free. Links in Instagram captions and comments aren\u2019t clickable, and while some users have found workarounds, the vast majority of Instagram posts aren\u2019t meant to send users to outside websites. (The exceptions are ads, which can contain clickable links and are, not coincidentally, the most troubled part of Instagram\u2019s platform.)\n\nPhoto\n\nThe walled-garden nature of Instagram has frustrated publishers, who want to send followers out to their websites, where the publishers can earn advertising money and \u201ccontrol the reader experience.\u201d (It\u2019s really just about the money.) But Instagram has wisely refused to give in, perhaps realizing that allowing links might turn the platform into a screeching bazaar, with publishers and pages all doing circus acts for clicks.\n\nRemoving links from Facebook would wreak havoc on the digital media industry, which has built an economic model around referral traffic from Facebook. It would also risk alienating some users, who enjoy promoting and discussing stories from other parts of the internet. But it would also solve some of the platform\u2019s most vexing challenges. And ultimately, it would be better for the world.\n\nAfter all, malicious actors don\u2019t post fabricated news, wildly exaggerated headlines or partisan outrage-bait on Facebook only for fun. They do it, in many cases, because it\u2019s profitable. Take away bad actors\u2019 incentives and they\u2019ll go elsewhere.\n\nBanning most links doesn\u2019t seem to have hurt Instagram as a business. It had more than 800 million monthly active users as of September, and it gained a million new advertisers last year. Facebook doesn\u2019t break out Instagram\u2019s revenue, but some analysts expect the app could one day generate as much as $10 billion in annual revenue. That\u2019s still nowhere near Facebook, which earned $10 billion in revenue last quarter alone, but it\u2019s a meaningful number, and it shows that insularity isn\u2019t always a bad thing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLesson No. 4: Bad actors are unavoidable, but their influence can be contained.\n\nInstagram is far from a perfect social network, and copying it wouldn\u2019t fix all of Facebook\u2019s problems overnight. Among other issues, some research has shown that use of Instagram can breed insecurity and bullying, and exacerbate body image issues, especially among young women.\n\nInstagram also hosts its own sketchy microeconomy \u2014 just witness the scourge of Insta-celebrities endorsing dubious health products, or the uptick in fly-by-night consumer brands that market themselves using Instagram ads.", "title": "What if a Healthier Facebook Is Just \u2026 Instagram?", "authors": ["Kevin Roose", "The Shift"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "The wildfire that ravaged much of Ventura and Santa Barbara Counties last month was the largest in California history. But it was the mudslides this week that proved far more deadly, killing at least 18 people. Rescue crews were looking for more than 40 people still missing on Friday morning. Officials said they expect the death toll to rise.", "title": "What the Aftermath of a Deadly Mudslide Looks Like", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Admit it: You were worried.\n\nYou watched 53 days elapse with no transactional movement in the wake of the Brooklyn Nets\u2019 acquisition of Jahlil Okafor from the Philadelphia 76ers on Dec. 7, and inevitably feared that the N.B.A.\u2019s 2018 trade deadline would be a snoozer.\n\nAnd then, without warning, the N.B.A. did what it does best.\n\nThe Los Angeles Clippers roused the basketball world out of its personnel slumber Monday night, with slightly more than a week to go before the Feb. 8 trade buzzer, by coming to terms on a blockbuster swap with the Detroit Pistons that sends their rugged big man and marketing darling Blake Griffin to Motown.\n\nIt\u2019s a monstrous midseason gamble for the Pistons\u2019 coach and team president Stan Van Gundy, who is trying to arrest Detroit\u2019s ongoing 8-20 swoon and keep hold of his job. Yet it might actually be an even bigger deal for the Clippers, who just followed up last June\u2019s breakup with Chris Paul by dealing away their other face of the franchise only seven months after bestowing a five-year contract worth nearly $175 million upon Griffin.\n\nAnd here\u2019s what it really means: L.A.\u2019s new front-office voices, most notably the legendary Jerry West, convinced the Clippers\u2019 ring-hungry owner, Steve Ballmer, that they have a real shot to force their way into the free-agent mix this summer for Paul George and (gasp) even LeBron James \u2014 if they could jettison Griffin and then create some more salary-cap flexibility.", "title": "What the Blake Griffin Trade Means for the Clippers and Pistons", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s a sure thing that Donald Trump will spend much of his State of the Union boasting about the economy. So this seems like a good time for a refresher on some basic macroeconomics \u2013 and the reasons why the expansion of 2017, which continued the long expansion that began in 2010, is in no sense a justification for wildly optimistic growth projections looking forward.\n\nAs a reminder, the Trump Treasury department claims that tax cuts will pay for themselves because the economy will grow at almost 3 percent a year for the next decade. This growth projection didn\u2019t come from any model; it was just pulled out of \u2026 well, you fill in the rest. But every time there\u2019s a good quarter of growth, the usual suspects take time off from talking about deep state conspiracies to claim that the forecast is coming true. Why is this nonsense?\n\nFirst, you need to know that quarter-to-quarter and even year-to-year growth rates are very variable. The economy grew at a 5 percent annual rate during much of the Carter administration (how many people know that?); it grew around 4 percent during the second Clinton administration:", "title": "Opinion | What the Economic Data Don\u2019t Tell Us", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Jobs changed, boyfriends came, boyfriends went. I moved from rural Pennsylvania to Lexington, Ky., then on to Philadelphia. Wendell was my constant. He was stylish: Every morning, when I got dressed for work, Wendell would lie on my bed, paws crossed, scrutinizing my stirrup pants and shoulder pads with a chilly disdain. He was loving: When I came home from work, he would act like I\u2019d returned from a war, scampering in circles and leaping with joy as if to declare YOU\u2019RE BACK! YOU\u2019RE BACK! YOU\u2019REBACKYOU\u2019REBACKYOU\u2019REBACK! He believed in me: Every night, when I\u2019d work on my first novel, he would fall asleep at my feet, his somnolence suggesting that he was in this for the long haul and I should be, too.\n\nI sold my book. Wendell feigned nonchalance, but I have to believe that he enjoyed the upgrade from generic to name-brand kibble. I got engaged. Wendell would start the day by chasing my fianc\u00e9 down the hallway, back fur bristling, posture declaiming \u201cand don\u2019t come back.\u201d By the end of his life Wendell had a cardiologist and was on a variety of medications, the pills carefully crushed and tucked into bits of pat\u00e9. He needed a boost to get onto the bed. Still, every night, he would sleep on my pillow, furled like a halo above my head.\n\nWhen Wendell died, it felt like the world had been knocked off its orbit. When it was, finally, time to get another dog, my daughters were adamant, rejecting puggles and poodles and bat-eared French bulldogs, insisting that we get another dog \u201cjust like Wendell.\u201d In 2011, Ratterrierrescue.com brought us Moochie, who had been dumped, pregnant, at a kill shelter, where she\u2019d languished as her pups went off to \u201cforever homes.\u201d Moochie spends most of her life within five feet of my person, heralding my movements by preceding me down the hall or up the stairs, curled up in a padded wicker basket while I work, or on my husband\u2019s legs while he reads, a black-and-white spotted package of pure love.\n\nOur president doesn\u2019t understand any of that. He mocked Vice President Mike Pence for allowing his family to bring their cats, snake and rabbit to Washington, deriding them as \u201clow-class\u201d and \u201cyokels.\u201d Meanwhile, his adult sons are big-game hunters, whose relationship to higher mammals seems to be informed by questions like \u201cAm I allowed to kill it?\u201d and \u201cCan I cut off its tail before I pose for the picture?\u201d\n\nIt takes a lot to elicit sympathy for a man whose life goals seem to be deepening America\u2019s divisions, lining his pockets and starting a third world war on Twitter, not necessarily in that order. But it\u2019s hard not to be a little sad for anyone who won\u2019t ever know the singular pleasure of a dog\u2019s companionship.\n\nMr. Trump may never know the steadying warmth of a dog by his side while he rage-watches cable TV. He won\u2019t know the way a dog\u2019s paw-pads smell like corn chips, or the pleasure at the sight of her paddling her feet, giving little yips and snarls as she chases squirrels in her dreams.\n\nHe might be the president, with Air Force One and a model wife and, if you believe him, a desk equipped with a nuclear button that is bigger than anyone else\u2019s button. But if you\u2019ve got a dog, you are rich in a way that Mr. Trump will never be.", "title": "Opinion | What the President Doesn\u2019t Get About Dogs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNot long ago a friend told me how she had come to end her relationship with WeWork, the entrepreneurial-class fun house that at recent count had been rolled out in 59 cities around the world. A playwright and producer, she had been renting office space at a WeWork location in Brooklyn when one night a little over a year ago, she showed up after a rehearsal to get some rewriting done and found a party in progress.\n\nAs she settled down at her desk, she could see that across the hall a couple was getting down to business of the kind that did not involve calculating price-earnings ratios. Things were loud and many people around her, none of whom she knew, were drunk, but she was determined to spend the next hour or so accomplishing something despite the ambient hedonism.\n\nThat effort was thwarted when two men who comfortably fit the stereotype of young hustlers on Planet Start-Up approached her desk, sat on it and began a vaguely menacing flirtation \u2014 poking at her computer, reading what was on the screen, poking at her. The next day she decided to render a complaint about the bacchanal she had encountered \u2014 if that were what she wanted, she could save $1,000 a month and set up a laptop on a curb in the meatpacking district on a Friday at midnight.\n\nBut where or to whom would one deliver a grievance? WeWork makes it easier to speak with a human being than other innovators born of the Silicon Valley ethos that talking on the phone is as crude an anachronism as cleaning your girdle with a washboard, but it is still not a simple matter. When my friend finally reached someone at the company, she was greeted solicitously and told she could have a desk on another part of the floor away from the offending fraternity. But moving a woman around to accommodate male misbehavior felt like a solution Roger Sterling would have come up with during the second season of \u201cMad Men.\u201d Disillusioned, she left and sought another arrangement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe co-working revolution has offered as one of its lures the blurred distinction between work life and private life, but it is precisely the obscuring of those boundaries \u2014 in Hollywood, in the restaurant industry, in theater and so on \u2014 that created the opportunities for harassment and abuse over and over again in the first place: the meetings called in hotel rooms, the research projects conducted at country houses, the bathrobes as uniforms.\n\nPhoto\n\nWeWork\u2019s website features a page entitled \u201cWhat Is WeWork\u2019s Beer Keg Policy?\u201d an idea that presumably has no analog at Proctor & Gamble. The policy, in fact, allows for kegs to be open on weekdays until approximately 9:30 p.m., but insists that they close on weekends \u201cas they are intended to be a workplace amenity.\u201d", "title": "What the Sharing Economy Really Delivers: Entitlement", "authors": ["Ginia Bellafante", "Big City"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "They started changing in the latter part of the Obama era, as rank-and-file Democrats became impatient for their party\u2019s leaders to endorse much bolder approaches to inequality and other economic challenges, an impatience that drove the enthusiasm behind Bernie Sanders\u2019s campaign. And since Mr. Trump has been president, rank-and-file Democrats have become energized and aggressive in ways we\u2019ve not seen in 50 years.\n\nChuck Schumer, the Democrats\u2019 leader in the Senate, is not himself a to-the-barricades kind of guy. But in the wake of the 2016 election, he\u2019s been attuned to where things are headed. He added Mr. Sanders to an expanded leadership team. In last year\u2019s contest for a new chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Mr. Schumer backed Representative Keith Ellison, the favorite candidate of the Sanders wing.\n\nAnd now, he has led his party into a possibly risky government shutdown. It\u2019s not because he\u2019s a different person than he once was, or because he\u2019s somehow tougher than his predecessor, Harry Reid. It\u2019s because the Democratic base demands it, in a way that base would not have, I believe, a decade or so ago.\n\nFor now, liberals should cheer this unreservedly. For one thing, the cause of these young undocumented Americans is a good one. But more broadly, the Republicans have been playing this way for years. If Democrats won\u2019t, they\u2019ll just lose. You can\u2019t bring a squirt gun to the O.K. Corral.\n\nAt the same time, there are longer-term concerns that citizens should keep in the back of their minds \u2014 not about the Democratic Party, but about the republic. I believe the Democrats are still several years away from becoming a movement party in the way the Republicans are. And it\u2019s not necessarily fated to happen, for a host of reasons, ranging from psychological differences between liberals and conservatives to the simple fact that there just aren\u2019t as many liberals in the United States as there are conservatives.\n\nBut if it were to happen \u2014 if we were to have two movement-subsumed parties \u2014 we would be in for some pretty big changes. We would move inexorably toward a more parliamentary system. New parties would pop up in the center \u2014 at least one, and I think probably two. Eventually the Constitution would get a revisit. It\u2019s a potentially ominous road. But for now, the Democrats have no choice but to walk it.", "title": "Opinion | What the Shutdown Says About the Future of the Democrats", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nRed carpet photos conceal as much as they reveal. Old photos, from awards seasons and film premieres long past, show victims of Harvey Weinstein\u2019s alleged harassment captured in front of cameras with the man they now call their abuser. In recent months, many of these actresses have said they felt they had no choice but to smile and pose. The photos have become a metaphor for the difficulty of confronting or rejecting powerful men who harass or assault.\n\n\u201cI never showed Harvey how terrified I was of him,\u201d Salma Hayek wrote. \u201cWhen I saw him socially, I\u2019d smile and try to remember the good things about him, telling myself that I went to war and I won.\u201d (Mr. Weinstein has disputed Ms. Hayek\u2019s account and denied all allegations of non-consensual sex.)\n\nAfter The Times revealed Mr. Weinstein\u2019s long record of harassment allegations, he and his advisers tried to weaponize some of those photos. Melissa Clark has a fine new recipe for you to try this evening, if you can find yourself some firm white-fleshed fish at the market. It\u2019s for cod braised in butter and wine, and it marries sweetness and silk to remarkable effect. Add mashed potatoes if you like, or a spinach salad, and see if you aren\u2019t warming to this business of cooking during the week, like, all the time.\n\nAlternatively, try out this other new gem we\u2019ve slid into our display case at NYT Cooking, for the kale-sauce pasta served by the chef Joshua McFadden, of Ava Gene\u2019s in Portland, Ore. Tejal Rao tracked it down, part of her recent dive into the history of America\u2019s obsession with kale, in The New York Times Magazine.\n\nMe, I\u2019d like to make this old Mark Bittman \u201cMinimalist\u201d recipe for deviled chicken thighs this evening, though I\u2019ll deminimalize it so it\u2019s a little more substantial a feed. First, by melting some leeks in a pan with some butter and white wine, then putting them, soft and pliant, onto a sheet pan. Second, by browning the skin of the chicken thighs in a saut\u00e9 pan on top of the stove instead of using the broiler. Third, by adding some bread crumbs to the mustardy spice mixture on the skin of the birds. And fourth and finally, by finishing the chicken in a very hot oven on top of the leeks, which makes the dish into a high school cover-band version of one the chef Suzanne Goin sometimes serves at her Lucques in Los Angeles. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.\n\nGood morning. How\u2019s it going with your resolution to eat better in 2018? Some are going big on the shredded tofu and shiitake stir-fries. My interpretation allows that you can serve a two-pound aged rib-eye to seven people, at least so long as there\u2019s a seven-yolk hollandaise to drizzle over the ruby-red slices of meat and a sheet-pan of smashed potatoes and a free-form salad of kale, crushed almonds, goat cheese and dried cranberries to take up the rest of the plate.\n\nThat salad, incidentally, can stand as our no-recipe recipe of the week, the chance we provide readers each Wednesday to cook off narrative suggestion, rather than from listed instructions. The ratio of nuts and cheese and fruit to greens is up to you (though you can learn a lot about the math behind your decision from Julia Moskin\u2019s ace guide to making salad), but I\u2019ll help with the dressing: a big splash of buttermilk, a dab of Dijon mustard, a healthy squeeze of lemon juice, and enough olive oil to allow it all to come together in an emulsified whole. Salt and pepper to taste. Grate a clove of garlic in there, if you desire. (I like to mix in a few cranberries and nut crumbles as well.) With a baguette and some butter, it\u2019s not a bad Wednesday night meal, not even close.\n\nIf you\u2019ve got a little more time, or just want to start daydreaming about cooking this coming weekend, check out John Willoughby\u2019s ode to the country-style pork rib and his accompanying recipes: one for braised country-style pork ribs with chipotle; the other for pork stew with pears and sweet potatoes. A week ago, I was asking you to make my new recipe for sausage risotto with parsley for Sunday dinner. And I hope you did because it\u2019s great. This week, though, I hacked the recipe, adding a lot of baby kale to the rice just before I served the meal, and if possible that turned out to be even more delicious than the original, with swirls of soft green amid the creamy grains of rice. So maybe this evening you could make the dish again or for the first time in this new, vegetable-forward way, and enjoy a very fine meal? Omit the sausage if you like. It\u2019s flexible excellence, a fantastical feed.\n\nAlternatively, try Tejal Rao\u2019s new recipe for a garlicky beef stir-fry with basil (above), which comes at the end of her delightful \u201cEat\u201d column for The Times this week, about the Thai food writer Leela Punyaratabandhu. Do so, and I\u2019ll bet you it enters your monthly repertoire.\n\nFor a Monday night dinner, I like the idea of these mushroom quesadillas this week, rather a lot of them, cooked serially and served with salsa verde, a version of pizza night, before \u201cThe Alienist\u201d drops at 9 p.m. Eastern, on TNT.\n\nTry Florence Fabricant\u2019s recipe for braised chicken with gochujang on Tuesday night, even if you have to detour on the way home to get a box of the Korean hot-pepper paste. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.\n\nGood morning. The feast of the Epiphany was yesterday, Twelfth Night for some, and if you didn\u2019t make Dorie Greenspan\u2019s recipe for galette des rois to celebrate, you really ought to today. It\u2019s delicious, and will bring good luck all year if your slice holds the little trinket traditionally baked into the cake. (Dorie calls for a bean. My mother used a ring. In New Orleans, where a different kind of king cake is served during Mardi Gras, they use a little plastic baby. I like these porcelain dudes.)\n\nSo make the cake! And have it for dessert this evening after eating something hearty against the cold that grips a big part of the country right now. Perhaps Regina Schrambling\u2019s justly famous recipe for beef stew with Dijon and Cognac? Or this insanely good recipe for Caribbean stew I read about in an old Jim Harrison story and tested into reality? You\u2019ll absolutely love Melissa Clark\u2019s recipe for Japanese chicken and root vegetable stew.\n\nOn Monday, I think you should keep up the theme, with a pot of spiced brown lentils with yogurt that is rather thicker than stew.", "title": "What to Cook This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning! I\u2019ve got a new \u201cEat\u201d column for you to read today, about how I tried to make a little savory treat I had not long ago at the French Laundry in Yountville, Calif., and about how it turned out great, but how in the end the dinner that followed \u2014 a meal one of the kids got me to cook, her riffing off the memory of something her friend made recently and me taking instruction at the stove \u2014 was transcendent. That is the way of the world, sometimes. We aim for one thing in our cooking. Then another thing brings the thrill. Who knew?\n\nOf course we ginned up a proper recipe for it: risotto with sausage and parsley. I think you should make that tonight. It is home cooking at its best, a dish that\u2019s ideal to make with friends or family crowded tight in the kitchen, everyone talking and talking as you stir and stir.\n\nThen, on Monday night, I like the idea of soup, and a vegetarian soup at that. Our pal Alison Roman gave us two to consider. One\u2019s for a fine recipe for broccoli and Cheddar soup that tastes of like what you always think this soup should taste of when you\u2019re on the road and order it off the menu at the only restaurant open near the hotel: broccoli and cheese. (At the restaurant, invariably, it tastes only of salt.) It\u2019s so good.\n\nThe other is for a vegetarian tortilla soup that draws a lot of flavor from canned chipotles in adobo, and spreads it through tomatoes and corn. Lots of raw crisp onion and cilantro and a handful of fried tortilla strips added at the end add texture, and brightness. I got into it with the cutting boards and butcher block just now, scrubbing away the sins of 2017, allowing everything to dry and then rubbing an immense amount of beeswax and mineral oil into the wood. It was mindless labor \u2014 simple work that made the kitchen a better place to be \u2014 and it helped keep the Sunday panic at bay. The work set life in my control, and not the other way around.\n\nYou might try something like that this afternoon yourself, particularly if there are things about your surroundings that bum you out, definitely if there are things in your life that kick up anxiety, that make you restless, that leave you tight. Winter\u2019s crowding us hard this month. So do something with your hands. It\u2019s a way of taking charge.\n\nLike, look at your cast-iron pans. And then let me show you how to take care of them properly. Then cook in them, all the time, so that you get in the habit of doing so.\n\nCook a lot whatever you do! Then cook!\n\nAnd, if something goes wrong along the way, either with a recipe or the technology we use to power the site and apps, or with your subscription or your need of a subscription, just reach out for help. We have operators standing by: cookingcare@nytimes.com.\n\nNow, please read this ugly update to the report four years ago that held the shrimp industry in Thailand was rife with forced labor and other abuses: This week Human Rights Watch said that not much has changed. That\u2019s worth keeping in mind when you buy shrimp at the store, or order it in restaurants.\n\nThen, and nothing at all to do with food, see what you think of Kathryn Schulz\u2019s mesmerizing and very odd meditation in The New Yorker on the life and work of the American writer William Melvin Kelley, who among much else first brought the term \u201cwoke\u201d to print \u2014 in 1962, and in The Times at that. Ordering his \u201cA Different Drummer\u201d right \u2026 now. Have a great weekend.", "title": "What to Cook This Weekend", "authors": ["Sam Sifton", "Julia Moskin", "Yossy Arefi", "Alison Roman", "Melissa Clark", "Joan Nathan", "Mark Bittman"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning. Canada Week is coming to an end for those of us on the Food desk of The Times. I spent the other evening interviewing the Montreal restaurateur David McMillan on stage at the Corona Theater in Little Burgundy, before repairing across the street for an epic dinner at his restaurant Joe Beef with, among others, the Times journalists Ian Austen, Dan Bilefsky and Jasmin Lavoie. The Canadian mixed-martial artist Georges St-Pierre was at the next table, The Streets on the stereo above the wood stove in back, and all the deliciousness left me wanting to cook French food with a Qu\u00e9b\u00e9cois accent all weekend: to lay out some smoked trout under mustard and maple, perhaps, or saut\u00e9 sweetbreads and serve them above a sauce grenobloise, with more capers than you\u2019d think, listening to old Ren\u00e9e Martel songs.\n\nBut the children will balk. They were home in the slush and sleet while I did my difficult job in the snowy north, and the menu choices for the next few days will fall to them. Stew is on order, if I\u2019m reading the mood correctly. So perhaps a big pot of galbijjim, my adaptation of Roy Choi\u2019s adaptation of his mom\u2019s recipe for Korean braised short-rib stew (above).\n\nFailing that, maybe Mark Bittman\u2019s recipe for spicy-sweet Peruvian pork stew with chiles, lime and apples? Or Kim Severson\u2019s simple and delicious recipe for Eastern North Carolina fish stew? I suppose we could go old school if the spices are fresh enough in the larder, with Florence Fabricant\u2019s rich, satisfying recipe for beef stew with sweet and hot paprika. (Seriously, if you make that one, sniff deeply at your paprikas before you start cooking. If they don\u2019t have a bright, fresh scent, they\u2019re probably dead, and you\u2019ll need a re-up before cooking, lest the stew taste chalky and pale.) I ask, they answer.\n\nFor dessert, though: only one choice. One of the kids has been knocking down fantastic versions of Katharine Hepburn\u2019s recipe for brownies, with a generous dusting of kosher salt strewn over their tops at the end, just after they come out of the oven. So definitely that, either with vanilla ice cream or, shades of Montreal, a maple-scented whipped cream.", "title": "What to Cook This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGood morning. Samin Nosrat has a supercool new recipe for us to make on one of those nights when all we want is to feel comforted and safe, and it comes at the end of her latest \u201cEat\u201d column for The Times, about cooking with her friends Mara and Twilight. It\u2019s basically hippie tofu (above): bean curd marinated in unfermented soy sauce, fried in coconut oil and served over rice and quinoa. I think it would be an ace dinner tonight. Soundtrack: The Roches, obvs.: \u201cKeep on Doing.\u201d\n\nThen tomorrow you could make Dorie Greenspan\u2019s excellent new recipe for rice pudding, which would follow Melissa Clark\u2019s recipe for roasted chicken thighs with winter squash quite nicely. Or you might make our old recipe for Katharine Hepburn\u2019s brownies, the perfect capper to a meal of spaghetti and meatballs.\n\nSunday, you can prepare for the week ahead. Cook some bone broth on the stove top, or rather more quickly in a pressure cooker. Make yogurt, into which some morning soon you can stir seeded pecan granola or jam or both. Roast some beef for sandwiches. Bake bread for same.\n\nMaybe make a lasagna and throw it in the freezer for the middle of the week? I like Regina Schrambling\u2019s version. Also: Julia Moskin\u2019s rather fancier green lasagna with Bolognese and b\u00e9chamel. (Or, hey, you could always make lobster mac and cheese.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Cooking Newsletter Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnd, for dinner on Sunday night, think about pizza and all the joys that it can bring to your table, whether in the form of a plain pie or an ethereal clam-chowder one, a rectangular grandma number or a gluten-free special, with tomatoes and olives.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere are thousands and thousands more recipes to cook this weekend at NYT Cooking. Head on over there to explore, to save recipes and rate them and leave notes on them and share them within your world. (Yes, you\u2019ll need a subscription to access the site and apps. We think it\u2019s worth the scratch.) We\u2019ll be here to help if something goes sideways and you can\u2019t get into your recipe box, or find yourself with a gallon of trotter gear and no sense what to do with it. Just write: cookingcare@nytimes.com. We\u2019ll get back to you.", "title": "What to Cook This Weekend", "authors": ["Sam Sifton", "What To Cook", "Dorie Greenspan", "Melissa Clark", "Samin Nosrat", "The New York Times", "Julia Moskin"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGood morning. On Wednesdays, most of the time, we don\u2019t cook with recipes but instead with narrative, looking for a story in the refrigerator to avoid a trip to the market after work. You should do the same. Wednesdays are hard enough. Tonight, breakfast for dinner, and the only good use of a nonstick pan: cheesy eggs, with buttered toast, and jelly glasses of chilled red wine.\n\nYou\u2019ll maybe recall my colleague and pal Julia Moskin\u2019s instructions in the matter of cooking scrambled eggs, \u201cthe most satisfaction in the least amount of time\u201d (above). So if you\u2019re game, make the toast as you like, then slide it into a low oven to keep warm. Scramble two eggs per person in a bowl with a splash of milk and a pinch of salt, and tip them into a hot pan foaming with butter. Stir and stir, quite heartily. Add a big handful of shredded cheese per person to the pan right at the start, and watch as it melts even as large curds form in the eggs, the whole pan turning into little pillows, glossy and soft. Anoint these with minced chives and you\u2019re good to go, dinner in an instant. You\u2019ll be in bed reading \u201cBleak House\u201d before 9. (If that\u2019s your thing. You could also stay up late scrolling through Instagram, then watch the Knicks play the Warriors.)\n\nEggs aren\u2019t for everyone, of course. If you have a little more time on your hands today, Florence Fabricant\u2019s recipe for pot roast may answer a little more happily this evening, especially if you serve them alongside buttered egg noodles. Or, if you\u2019d like a recipe that falls in between fast and slow, you could make Julia\u2019s recipe for coconut curry chicken noodle soup, or the chef Amanda Cohen\u2019s recipe for charred cauliflower stew. It calls for broiling some of the cauliflower and pickling the rest, which is a combination that results in big, big flavor. \u201cExcellent,\u201d one Cooking user wrote. \u201cI am not a vegetarian, but this stew got me closer.\u201d\n\nHave you made Nigella Lawson\u2019s recipe for baked cod with prosciutto, which she serves over lentils with garlic and thyme? You can omit the legumes in the name of midweek haste, and serve it on a bed of arugula instead.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOr you could knock down Mark Bittman\u2019s recipe for creamy pasta with chicken and mushrooms, which deploys the cool trick of treating the pasta as if it were risotto, which requires a lot of stirring but rewards the stirrer with a one-pot meal.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCome visit us at NYT Cooking for more ideas for what to cook tonight. Browse away, and save the recipes you like to your recipe box. Send yourself a grocery list. Then cook, and rate (five stars for that creamy pasta, no doubt!) and leave notes on those recipes you\u2019ve improved or altered or substituted ingredients for \u2014 we all benefit from the collective experience of our growing number of cooks. And, if something goes upside down, either with a recipe or our site or apps, do sing out for help. Smart cats reside at cookingcare@nytimes.com. They\u2019ll get back to you.", "title": "What to Cook Tonight", "authors": ["Sam Sifton", "Florence Fabricant", "Julia Moskin", "Amanda Cohen", "Nigella Lawson", "Mark Bittman"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "JetBlue said that beginning May 3 it will increase its presence in New England, with nonstop service between Worcester Regional Airport in Massachusetts and John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York, becoming the only commercial airline to serve Worcester. On that same day, JetBlue also plans to begin nonstop service between Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport and Boston Logan International Airport.\n\nAmerican Airlines is homing in on Canada, adding service from its hub in Chicago\u2019s O\u2019Hare International Airport to Vancouver International Airport beginning May 4. Seasonal service to Calgary International Airport from O\u2019Hare begins June 7. There will be more flights from the east coast of the United States to eastern Canada as well, including Toronto, Ottawa and Quebec City.\n\nAlso in June, Delta Air Lines will offer new nonstop service between Mineta San Jose International Airport in California and John F. Kennedy Airport in New York.\n\nLooking for a deal? Norwegian Air, the low-cost, long-haul carrier, is planning 11 new trans-Atlantic routes for 2018, including service from John F. Kennedy International Airport to Amsterdam Airport Schiphol in the Netherlands (beginning May 7) and to Madrid-Barajas Airport in Spain (beginning July 18). There will also be service from Los Angeles International Airport to Milan (beginning June 18) and Madrid (beginning July 16).\n\n\u2026 and say goodbye to smart bags (unless you can remove those lithium-ion batteries)\n\nWhen deciding what to pack, you may need to think twice about so-called smart bags that allow travelers to do things like charge their portable electronic devices and lock the bag remotely.\n\nBeginning Jan. 15, major airlines, including American, Delta, United, Hawaiian and Alaska will no longer accept smart bags with lithium-ion batteries unless the batteries can be removed on site. Why? Because, as Delta put it, the batteries have the potential to overheat and start a fire during flight. So if you\u2019re planning to travel with a smart bag, be sure you know how to remove the battery before leaving home.\n\nIn addition to new airport rules, the year ahead will also bring new airports.\n\nRelations between the United States and Turkey may be strained, but a state-of-the-art airport, Istanbul New Airport (yes, that\u2019s what it\u2019s called), is slated to be completed in 2018 and will become the primary gateway to the city.", "title": "What to Expect in 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "In The New York Times Book Review, Nicholas Kristof writes about the best fiction and nonfiction to read for glimpses into the secretive world of North Korea. Kristof writes:\n\nImage\n\n\u201cThousands of North Koreans have fled their homeland since the famine of the late 1990s, and many are writing memoirs recounting their daily lives and extraordinary escapes. A leading example is \u2018In Order to Live: A North Korean Girl\u2019s Journey to Freedom,\u2019 by Yeonmi Park, with Maryanne Vollers. Park is a young woman whose father was a cigarette smuggler and black market trader. As a girl, she believed in the regime (as did her mother), for life was steeped in propaganda and anti-Americanism. Even in her math class, \u201ca typical problem would go like this: \u2018If you kill one American bastard and your comrade kills two, how many dead American bastards do you have?\u2019\u201d What opened Park\u2019s eyes was in part a pirated copy of the film \u2018Titanic.\u2019 \u201d\n\nOn this week\u2019s podcast, Kristof discusses books about North Korea; Tui Sutherland talks about the graphic novel edition of \u201cWings of Fire\u201d; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; and Gregory Cowles, Jennifer Szalai and John Williams on what people are reading. Pamela Paul is the host.\n\nHere are the books mentioned in this week\u2019s \u201cWhat We\u2019re Reading\u201d:\n\n\u201cThe Radetzky March\u201d by Joseph Roth\n\n\u201cWinter\u201d by Karl Ove Knausgaard\n\n\u201cSelected Letters\u201d by John Keats\n\n\u201cThe Secret River\u201d by Kate Grenville\n\nWe would love to hear your thoughts about this episode, and about the Book Review\u2019s podcast in general. You can send them to books@nytimes.com.\n\nHow do I listen? Two ways\n\nFrom a desktop or laptop, you can listen by pressing play on the button above.\n\nOr if you\u2019re on a mobile device, the instructions below will help you find and subscribe to the series.", "title": "What to Read About North Korea", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "What to Read About Best Picture Winner \u2018The Shape of Water\u2019 Share\n\nAnother year, another class of Oscar winners. Once you\u2019ve streamed the winning movies and caught up with the best and worst moments of the ceremony, you may want to read more about the best picture competition. To help, we\u2019ve compiled a brief list of essential interviews, features and critical essays on the Academy\u2019s favorite films of last year, starting with the winner, Guillermo del Toro\u2019s \u2018The Shape of Water,\u2019 which also won awards for best directing, score and sound design.\n\nImage Sally Hawkins with Doug Jones, as the Asset, in \u201cThe Shape of Water.\u201d Credit Fox Searchlight Pictures\n\n\u2018The Shape of Water\u2019\n\nReview: \u2018The Shape of Water\u2019 Is Altogether Wonderful [The New York Times]\n\n\u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d is partly a code-scrambled fairy tale, partly a genetically modified monster movie, and altogether wonderful. Guillermo del Toro, the writer and director, is a passionate genre geek,\u201d writes A. O. Scott in his review. \u201cIn Mr. del Toro\u2019s world, though, reality is the domain of rules and responsibilities, and realism is a crabbed, literal-minded view of things that can be opposed only by the forces of imagination.\u201d\n\n\u2018How \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d\u2019s Aquatic Beast Got So Sexy\u2019 [Vanity Fair]\n\nKatey Rich investigates the unnerving allure of a scaly fish-man with washboard abs in interviews with the team behind the beautiful beast. Mike Hill, the sculptor who gave life to the director Guillermo del Toro\u2019s vision for the character, recalls that: \u201cThe main thing he said to me was, \u2018Mike, I don\u2019t want you to make a creature; you\u2019re designing the leading man.\u2019 What Guillermo was interested in was giving the fish-man a soul, a personality, a heart, so to speak.\u201d\n\n\u2018Stream the Movies That Inspired \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d\u2019 [Watching]\n\nDel Toro is a genuine cinephile, and he loves to reference his favorite films in his own work. If you liked \u201cThe Shape of Water,\u201d why not celebrate its 13 Oscar nominations by watching \u201cThe Creature From the Black Lagoon,\u201d Jean Cocteau\u2019s \u201cBeauty and the Beast\u201d or one of the other streamable movies on this list compiled by Jason Bailey?\n\n0\n\nOther Great Reads on \u2018The Shape of Water\u2019:\n\n\u2018Why Are We Ashamed to Call \u201cGet Out\u201d and \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d Horror Films?\u2019 [The New York Times ]\n\n\u2018The Case for More, Hotter Fish Sex in \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d\u2019 [The Village Voice ]\n\n\u2018Sally Hawkins on the Art of Romancing a Fish-Man\u2019 [Rolling Stone ]\n\n\u2018Phantom Thread\u2019\n\nImage Vicky Krieps and Daniel Day-Lewis in \u201cPhantom Thread.\u201d Credit Laurie Sparham/Focus Features\n\nReview: Daniel Day-Lewis Sews Up Another Great Performance in \u2018Phantom Thread\u2019 [The New York Times]\n\n\u201cWhat kind of love story is \u201cPhantom Thread\u201d?\u201d asks A. O. Scott in his review. \u201cThe wrenching tale of a woman\u2019s love for a man and a man\u2019s love for his work. A dry, comic study of the asymmetries and conflicts at the heart of a marriage. A refined gothic nightmare in the manner of Henry James. A perverse psychological fable of unchecked ego and unhinged desire. That\u2019s a partial catalog, and one that can\u2019t quite capture how bizarre this movie is.\u201d\n\n\u2018Daniel Day-Lewis and Paul Thomas Anderson on How They Created \u201cPhantom Thread\u201d\u2019 [The New York Times]\n\n0\n\n\u201cPhantom Thread\u201d is, at its core, the story of a romance between two deeply bizarre individuals: the fictional midcentury fashion designer Reynolds Woodcock and the love of his life, Alma.\n\nThe Times\u2019s Reggie Ugwu interviewed director Paul Thomas Anderson and the leading cast members about how they captured the film\u2019s unique, ineffable weirdness. \u201cThere\u2019s no strangeness you can imagine that is more strange than the lives of apparently conventional people behind closed doors,\u201d says Day-Lewis, who stars as Woodcock.\n\n\u2018The Dresses in \u201cPhantom Thread\u201d Are Gorgeous, But Not Dazzling \u2014 and That\u2019s the Point\u2019 [The Washington Post]\n\n\u201cBecause this is a story that revolves around a designer\u2019s creative and emotional impulses, one might presume the film would feature any number of extraordinary and memorable ensembles,\u201d writes the fashion critic Robin Givhan in a perceptive analysis Woodcock\u2019s creations. \u201cBut there are none.\u201d\n\nOther Great Reads on \u2018Phantom Thread\u2019:\n\n\u2018\u201cPhantom Thread\u201d Is the Best Food Movie in Ages\u2019 [The New Yorker ]\n\n\u2018Decoding the Strange Mysteries of \u201cPhantom Thread\u201d\u2019 [Vice ]\n\n\u2018In Honoring Paul Thomas Anderson\u2019s \u201cPhantom Thread,\u201d the Academy Shows There\u2019s More to Greatness Than Relevance\u2019 [L.A. Times ]\n\n\u2018Get Out\u2019\n\nImage Daniel Kaluuya in \u201cGet Out.\u201d Credit Universal Picture\n\nReview: In \u2018Get Out,\u2019 Guess Who\u2019s Coming to Dinner? (Bad Idea!) [The New York Times]\n\n\u201cPart of what makes \u201cGet Out\u201d both exciting and genuinely unsettling is how real life keeps asserting itself, scene after scene,\u201d writes Manohla Dargis in her review. \u201cOur monsters, Jordan Peele reminds us, are at times as familiar as the neighborhood watch; one person\u2019s fiction, after all, is another\u2019s true-life horror story.\u201d\n\n\u2018The Movie \u201cGet Out\u201d Is a Strong Antidote to the Myth of \u201cPostracial\u201d America\u2019 [The New York Times]\n\nThe filmmaker and comedian Jordan Peele has expressed frustration at the characterization of his movie \u201cGet Out\u201d as a comedy. In an editorial, Brent Staples underlines the seriousness of Peele\u2019s political critique, writing: \u201cThe film is a disquisition on the continuing impact of slavery in American life. Among other things, it argues that present-day race relations are heavily determined by the myths that were created to justify enslavement \u2014 particularly the notion that black people were never fully human.\u201d\n\n0\n\n\u2018Jordan Peele Goes Inside \u201cGet Out\u201d\u2019s Biggest Twist\u2019 [Entertainment Weekly]\n\nEvery horror movie has a moment when the floor finally drops out from under the protagonist. Peele goes deep into his version of that scene in a spoiler-filled interview. \u201cThat was the hardest scene to shoot,\u201d he tells the writer Derek Lawrence. \u201cIt was very hard for me to put into words exactly why we were going to be able to reveal this twist twice in a matter of four minutes.\u201d\n\nOther Great Reads on \u2018Get Out\u2019:\n\nNew York Public Library\u2019s list of books to read and films to watch after \u2018Get Out\u2019\n\n\u2018Jordan Peele on a Truly Terrifying Monster: Racism\u2019 [The New York Times ]\n\n\u2018In \u201cGet Out,\u201d the Eyes Have It\u2019 [The Atlantic ]\n\n\u2018Call Me By Your Name\u2019\n\nImage Armie Hammer, left, and Timoth\u00e9e Chalamet in \u201cCall Me by Your Name.\u201d Credit Sony Pictures Classics\n\nReview: A Boy\u2019s Own Desire in \u2018Call Me by Your Name\u2019 [The New York Times]\n\n\u201c\u201cCall Me by Your Name\u201d is less a coming-of-age story, a tale of innocence and loss, than one about coming into sensibility,\u201d writes Manohla Dargis in her review. \u201cIn that way, it is about the creation of a new man who, the story suggests, is liberated by pleasure that doesn\u2019t necessarily establish sexual identity.\u201d\n\n\u2018The \u201cCall Me by Your Name\u201d Monologue Leaving Audiences in Tears\u2019 [The Daily Beast]\n\nTimoth\u00e9e Chalamet got the Oscar nomination, but Michael Stuhlbarg, who plays the father of Chalamet\u2019s character, dominates the film\u2019s most touching scene. In a conversation with the reporter Kevin Fallon, Stuhlbarg explains, \u201cAll you can hope for is an opportunity to tell a story that seems to be what a lot of people have lived through, and perhaps present a different version of what it seems most people may have gone through in trying to communicate with a parent about who they are, what they feel, what their lives have been like.\u201d\n\n\u2018\u201cCall Me by Your Name\u201d Is a Love Letter to Missed Opportunity\u2019 [Pacific Standard]\n\nIn an essay, Brandon Tensley writes, \u201cOn top of so much else, \u2018Call Me by Your Name\u2019 is an exploration of the sometimes-heartrending ways in which time, whittled down by a nasty world, works against queer people.\u201d\n\nOther Great Reads on \u2018Call Me by Your Name\u2019:\n\n\u2018\u201cCall Me by Your Name\u201d Director Luca Guadagnino on the Music of His Movies\u2019 [Pitchfork ]\n\n\u2018What Should We Make of \u201cCall Me by Your Name\u201d\u2019s Age-Gap Relationship?\u2019 [Slate ]\n\n\u2018\u201cCall Me by Your Name\u201d Gave Me More Than I Thought I Needed From a Movie\u2019 [Esquire ]\n\n\u2018Lady Bird\u2019\n\nImage Lucas Hedges and Saoirse Ronan in \u201cLady Bird.\u201d Credit Merie Wallace/A24.\n\nReview: Greta Gerwig\u2019s \u2018Lady Bird\u2019 Is Big-Screen Perfection [The New York Times]\n\n\u201cThe idea that attention is a form of love (and vice versa) is a beautiful insight, and in many ways it\u2019s the key to \u201cLady Bird,\u201d\u201d writes A. O. Scott in his review. \u201cAnd if you pay the right kind of attention to \u201cLady Bird\u201d \u2014 absorbing its riffs and digressions as well as its melodies, its choral passages along with its solos and duets \u2014 you will almost certainly love it. It\u2019s hard not to.\u201d\n\n\u2018Greta Gerwig Is a Director, Not a Muse\u2019 [New York Magazine]\n\nGreta Gerwig rose to fame as an actress, in films by directors like Joe Swanberg and her partner and collaborator, Noah Baumbach. But, as she explains to the journalist Noreen Malone in this perceptive profile, \u201cI did not love being called a muse.\u201d Considering that she is now the fifth woman ever to earn a best director nomination, it appears that Hollywood is finally getting the message.\n\n\u2018The Miseducation of \u201cLady Bird\u201d\u2019 [The Baffler]\n\n\u201cLady Bird\u201d currently boasts a 99 percent \u201cfresh\u201d rating on Rotten Tomatoes. And, Lauren Oyler concedes, it is \u201cgood as a feel-good movie.\u201d But does it really deserve such ecstatic, universal praise? \u201cWhy Gerwig and her audience would want to mother themselves through the horrors of high school, the necessary milestones that range from un-special to uncomfortable to traumatizing, is not hard to figure out,\u201d Oyler writes. \u201cWhat\u2019s surprising, or at least dispiriting, is the willingness with which adults sacrifice their hard-won autonomy for an existence so remedial.\u201d\n\nOther Great Reads on \u2018Lady Bird\u2019:\n\n\u2018A Memorable Mother-Daughter Talk in \u201cLady Bird\u201d\u2019 [The Atlantic ]\n\n\u2018\u201cLady Bird\u2019s\u201d Laurie Metcalf on the Mom Role That Hit Close to Home\u2019 [Vanity Fair ]\n\n\u2018Greta Gerwig Somehow Redeems Dave Matthews Band\u2019s \u201cCrash Into Me\u201d\u2019 [The New Yorker ]\n\n\u2018The Post\u2019\n\nImage Tom Hanks and Meryl Streep in \u201cThe Post.\u201d Credit Niko Tavernise/20th Century Fox\n\nReview: In \u2018The Post,\u2019 Democracy Survives the Darkness [The New York Times]\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s more than a little corn and wishful thinking in the high-minded moments in \u201cThe Post\u201d; movies like either to glorify or demonize journalists, relying on heroes and villains,\u201d writes Manohla Dargis in her review. \u201cYet given the recent assaults on journalism and the truth, this heroizing is also irresistible. And Steven Spielberg, a shrewd entertainer who can be waylaid by moralism, rarely lets virtue drag this movie down.\u201d\n\n\u2018Behind the Race to Publish the Top-Secret Pentagon Papers\u2019 [The New York Times]\n\nSteven Spielberg\u2019s latest film dramatizes The Washington Post\u2019s historic efforts to cover the Pentagon Papers after the government barred The New York Times from following the story. The Times\u2019s Niraj Chokshi digs through the archives in this piece tracing the newspapers\u2019 race to publish the documents and defend the free press.\n\n\u2018Breaking Down a Crucial Phone Call in \u201cThe Post\u201d\u2019 [The Atlantic]\n\nMeryl Streep racked up yet another Oscar nomination for her performance as the Post\u2019s publisher, Katharine Graham. Here, David Sims gives a close reading of the scene where Graham must decide whether her paper will take on the enormous risk of publishing the documents. \u201cHer decision is something the film has spent an hour building toward, dramatizing Graham\u2019s nervy debates with [Ben] Bradlee, with [Frederick] Beebe, and with her lawyers over the necessity of standing up to Nixon,\u201d he writes. \u201cBut once she makes her choice, it\u2019s ironclad.\u201d\n\nOther Great Reads on \u2018The Post:\u2019\n\n\u2018Steven Spielberg: The Urgency to Make \u201cThe Post\u201d Was Because of Trump\u2019s Administration\u2019 [Guardian ]\n\n\u2018Ranking the Supporting Characters of \u201cThe Post\u201d\u2019 [The Ringer ]\n\n\u2018Spielberg\u2019s \u201cThe Post\u201d: Good Movie, Bad History\u2019 [The Daily Beast ]\n\n\u2018Dunkirk\u2019\n\nImage A scene from \u201cDunkirk.\u201d Credit Melinda Sue Gordon/Warner Bros. Pictures\n\nReview: \u2018Dunkirk\u2019 Is a Tour de Force War Movie, Both Sweeping and Intimate [The New York Times]\n\n\u201c\u201cDunkirk\u201d is a tour de force of cinematic craft and technique,\u201d writes Manohla Dargis in her review. But it\u2019s also a film \u201cthat is unambiguously in the service of a sober, sincere, profoundly moral story that closes the distance between yesterday\u2019s fights and today\u2019s. Christopher Nolan closes that distance cinematically with visual sweep and emotional intimacy, with images of warfare and huddled, frightened survivors that together with Hans Zimmer\u2019s score reverberate through your body.\u201d\n\n\u2018What\u2019s Fact and What\u2019s Fiction in \u201cDunkirk\u201d?\u2019 [Slate]\n\n\u201cWhy the obsession with airplane fuel?\u201d \u201cWhat was the deal with the French being denied places on the boats and ships?\u201d And, of course, \u201c\u2018Where the hell were you?\u2019\u201d The history professor John Broich answers all these questions and more in this thorough explainer on the real story behind Christopher Nolan\u2019s World War II epic.\n\n\u2018Christopher Nolan\u2019s Latest Time-Bending Feat? \u201cDunkirk\u201d\u2019 [The New York Times]\n\nNolan, the acclaimed auteur behind \u201cInception\u201d and the most recent Batman trilogy, picked up his first best-director nomination this year. \u201cAs a filmmaker you\u2019re looking for gaps in the culture, pop culture at least; you\u2019re looking for things that haven\u2019t been addressed in movies,\u201d Nolan explained to Cara Buckley in an interview before the movie\u2019s release. \u201cAnd Dunkirk, for whatever reason, has never been addressed in modern cinema.\u201d\n\nOther Great Reads on \u2018Dunkirk:\u2019\n\n\u2018Six Films to Stream if You Loved \u2018Dunkirk\u2019\u2019 [Watching ]\n\n\u2018How Christopher Nolan\u2019s \u201cDunkirk\u201d Team Captured the Sounds of Battle\u2019 [Variety ]\n\n\u2018Your Guide to the Similar-Looking Men of \u201cDunkirk\u201d\u2019 [Vulture ]\n\n\u2018Calgary Veteran Who Survived Dunkirk Causes Stir at Movie Premiere\u2019 [Global News ]\n\n\u2018Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u2019\n\nImage Frances McDormand in \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri.\u201d Credit Fox Searchlight\n\nReview: On Violence and the Pain of Others in \u2018Three Billboards\u2019 [The New York Times]\n\n\u201c\u201cThree Billboards\u201d is more ambitious than Martin McDonagh\u2019s earlier features,\u201d writes Manohla Dargis in her review. \u201cLike the older ones, it has loads of gab, plenty of guns and the spectacle of men (mainly) behaving terribly. It also restlessly, if not satisfyingly, shifts between comedy and tragedy \u2014 a McDonagh specialty \u2014 splattering blood along the way.\u201d\n\n\u2018Does \u2018Three Billboards\u2019 Say Anything About America? Well \u2026 \u2019 [The New York Times]\n\nWesley Morris places \u201cThree Billboards\u201d in a category of movies that includes \u201cCrash\u201d from 2005: \u201cIn its own accidental way, it does seem to be saying something about, you know, now ,\u201d he writes. Cycling through the issues of the day, he adds, \u201cIt\u2019s one of those movies that really do think they\u2019re saying something profound about human nature and injustice.\u201d And yet, for Morris, the film is \u201cso off about so many things\u201d \u2014 a \u201cmisfire\u201d that \u201cfails to sufficiently poeticize or dramatize\u201d the injustices that it, like its admirers, believes it is aware of.\n\n\u2018Caleb Landry Jones: \u201cWorking With Frances McDormand Terrified Me\u201d\u2019 [The Guardian]\n\nFrances McDormand, Sam Rockwell and Woody Harrelson all earned Oscar nominations for their stellar work in \u201cThree Billboards.\u201d Caleb Landry Jones played a smaller role in the film, but his additional performances in \u201cTwin Peaks: The Return,\u201d \u201cThe Florida Project\u201d and \u201cGet Out\u201d helped to make him one of 2017\u2019s most promising breakout actors.
