Get to know him in this lively interview with Jonathan Romney.\n\nOther Great Reads on \u2018Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u2019:\n\n\u2018\u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d Is Hopelessly Bad on Race\u2019 [Pacific Standard ]\n\n\u2018\u201cThree Billboards\u201d Is an Unfortunate Metaphor for Our Complicated Cultural Moment\u2019 [BuzzFeed ]\n\n\u2018The Monsters in \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d\u2019 [The Ringer ]\n\n\u2018Darkest Hour\u2019\n\nImage Gary Oldman as Winston Churchill in \u201cDarkest Hour.\u201d Credit Jack English/Focus Features\n\nReview: \u2018Darkest Hour,\u2019 or the Great Man Theory of History (and Acting) [The New York Times]\n\n\u201c\u201cDarkest Hour\u201d is proud of its hero, proud of itself and proud to have come down on the right side of history nearly 80 years after the fact,\u201d writes A. O. Scott in his review. \u201cIt wants you to share that pride, and to claim a share of it. But we have nothing to be proud of.\u201d\n\n\u2018Blood, Sweat, Toil and Tears: Playing Churchill on Screen\u2019 [The New York Times]\n\nWhat did Gary Oldman learn while preparing for his Golden Globe-winning, Oscar-nominated performance as Winston Churchill? \u201cI discovered a man who was not as fat as we all thought he was in 1940 and who had really an athletic tread,\u201d he tells The Times\u2019s Julie Bloom. \u201cHe skipped around and he had this sort of stoop and it was forward moving.\u201d He adds: \u201cThere\u2019s a real twinkle in the eye, and he has humor. The Churchill I saw and I discovered had charm.\u201d\n\n\u2018The True Story Behind the Winston Churchill Biopic \u201cDarkest Hour\u201d\u2019 [Time]\n\nWhy might the filmmaker have chosen to focus on just a few months of Churchill\u2019s lengthy career, May and June of 1940? \u201cIt\u2019s the most important moment in Churchill\u2019s life and career and the most important historical turning point of the 20th century,\u201d Michael Bishop, the executive director of the International Churchill Society, tells Time\u2019s Olivia B. Waxman. \u201cIt was really the moment when Hitler could have won the war.\u201d\n\nOther Great Reads on \u2018Darkest Hour\u2019:\n\n\u2018How Gary Oldman Lured a Makeup Magician Back for One Last Job\u2019 [Vulture ]\n\n\u2018Here\u2019s What the Churchill Family Thinks of Gary Oldman\u2019s \u201cDarkest Hour\u201d\u2019 [The Wrap ]\n\n\u2018\u201cDarkest Hour\u201d Writer on the Struggle Between \u201cArtistic License and Artistic Licentiousness\u201d\u2019 [The Hollywood Reporter ]", "title": "What to Read About Best Picture Winner \u2018The Shape of Water\u2019", "authors": ["Judy Berman"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAmerican Crime Story,\u201d the jewel in the prolific TV creator Ryan Murphy\u2019s FX anthology-series crown, is back for the first time since 2016. Season 2, \u201cThe Assassination of Gianni Versace,\u201d debuted Wednesday, with an episode that wasted no time in re-enacting the iconic fashion designer\u2019s murder on the front steps of his Miami Beach home on July 15, 1997. But where will Murphy go from there? And how much of this story is true? Our list of essential pieces on the show and on the story behind it will help you answer those questions and more.\n\nAbout the Show\n\n\u2018There\u2019s Not That Much Fashion in FX\u2019s Big Versace Drama\u2019 [The New York Times]\n\nVersace may be the marquee name this season, but the story has about as little to do with fashion as \u201cThe People v. O.J. Simpson\u201d had to do with football. \u201c\u2018American Crime Story\u2019 at its core only works if you\u2019re telling a bigger story about a societal ill,\u201d Murphy tells The Times\u2019s John Koblin in a feature on the making of the series. \u201cSo I thought, \u2018Can we do something on homophobia in the \u201990s and the \u201cdon\u2019t ask, don\u2019t tell\u201d policies at the time that I think ruined so many lives?\u2019\u201d\n\n\u2018\u201cAmerican Crime Story\u2019 Star Darren Criss on Serial Killers and Queer Narratives [Newsweek]\n\nDarren Criss has already earned heaps of critical praise for his lead performance as Versace\u2019s young, gay killer, Andrew Cunanan. \u201cAndrew not only envied the wealth and success of Gianni, but also that he was a famous, out man who had love in his life,\u201d says Criss in a profile by Anna Menta. \u201cFor Andrew, whose homosexuality keeps leading him to dark places, to see somebody so victorious at it had to be infuriating.\u201d\n\n\u2018How \u201cThe Assassination of Gianni Versace\u201d Looks Beyond Its Subject\u2019 [The Ringer]\n\nIn a conversation with Alison Herman, Tom Rob Smith, the frequent Murphy collaborator who wrote all nine episodes of the season, discusses his decision to tell the familiar but complicated story backward. \u201cYou start with the thing that everyone knows [Versace\u2019s murder], and then you guide them backward through the bits that they don\u2019t know,\u201d he explains.\n\n0\n\n\u2018A Timeline of the \u201cVersace: American Crime Story\u201d Drama\u2019 [Vogue]\n\nThe real Versace family, which takes issue with Smith\u2019s source material (Maureen Orth\u2019s book \u201cVulgar Favors: Andrew Cunanan, Gianni Versace and the Largest Failed Manhunt in U.S. History\u201d), is not thrilled about the show\u2019s existence. Earlier this month, the family released a statement calling the screenplay a \u201cwork of fiction.\u201d But the conflict between the Versace camp and Murphy\u2019s team has actually been building since last summer. If you need to catch up on the kerfuffle, Vogue has you covered.\n\nAbout Gianni Versace and Andrew Cunanan\n\n\u2018The Killer\u2019s Trail\u2019 [Vanity Fair]\n\nIf you don\u2019t have time for \u201cVulgar Favors,\u201d Orth\u2019s original investigation into Cunanan\u2019s murder spree \u2014 which she began reporting before he killed Versace \u2014 is a rich character study. \u201cA voracious reader with a reported genius-level I.Q., he coveted the lifestyles of the rich and famous,\u201d she writes of Cunanan. \u201cHe tracked possible sugar daddies with care and would say with a pout that he didn\u2019t know whether to fly to New York or Paris for dinner. He could describe the texture and delicacy of the blowfish he claimed to have eaten at an $850 Japanese lunch. Or he could say of a work of art what year it had been painted, who had owned it through the centuries, what churches it had hung in. His wit was biting, his memory photographic.\u201d\n\n\u2018The True Story of \u201cThe Assassination of Gianni Versace\u201d\u2019 [Smithsonian.com]\n\nIn a recent interview, Orth speculates on what a 21st-century Cunanan might look like. \u201cToday you can be an Instagram star or YouTube star,\u201d she tells Roger Catlin. \u201cIf he had been born later, maybe that\u2019s what he would have gone for. But in order to be recognized, he wanted to be famous so much that he was willing to kill for it.\u201d\n\n\u2018\u201cMy Life Was Torn in Two When Gianni Was Shot\u201d: Versace\u2019s Lover Breaks Silence\u2019 [Guardian]\n\nRicky Martin made a memorable guest appearance as a night-school Spanish teacher on an episode of Murphy\u2019s \u201cGlee\u201d that aired nearly six years ago. In his first small-screen role since then, he plays Versace\u2019s devastated partner, Antonio D\u2019Amico. In a rare interview, the real D\u2019Amico gives a chilling account of the morning the designer died. \u201cThe house had stained glass windows so we couldn\u2019t see what had happened from inside, so we had to open the gate,\u201d he tells Angela Giuffrida. \u201cI saw Gianni lying on the steps, with blood around him. At that point, everything went dark. I was pulled away, I didn\u2019t see any more.\u201d\n\n\u2018How the Assassination of Gianni Versace Turned Out the Lights on Miami\u2019s Moment in the Sun\u2019 [W Magazine]\n\nThe journalist Horacio Silva recounts Versace\u2019s relationship with his part-time home city, Miami Beach, through conversations with those who frequented its clubs and beaches in the 1990s. According to Silva, the designer \u201cwas so much a part of the fiber of the colorful community that in time Versace and Miami became indissolubly fused in the public imagination, with images of palm trees and hunky male models in foulard-print shirts on South Beach, or paparazzi pics of Versace and his famous friends, appearing in every magazine of note.\u201d\n\n\u2018The True Story of the Versace Mansion\u2019 [Vanity Fair]\n\nCasa Casuarina, the sprawling villa in Miami Beach where Versace lived \u2014 and died \u2014 plays a starring role in the season premiere. Katey Rich looks back at the ostentatious property\u2019s history, from its construction in 1930 to its current incarnation as a $1,000-a-night hotel.", "title": "What to Read About \u2018American Crime Story: The Assassination of Gianni Versace\u2019", "authors": ["Judy Berman"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cEverything we learned about Americans was negative,\u201d she writes. \u201cIn cartoons, they were snarling jackals. In the propaganda posters they were as thin as sticks with hook noses and blond hair. We were told they smelled bad. They had turned South Korea into a \u2018hell on earth\u2019 and were maintaining a puppet government there. The teachers never missed an opportunity to remind us of their villainy.\n\n\u201c\u2018If you meet a Yankee bastard on the street and he offers you candy, do not take it!\u2019 one teacher warned us, wagging a finger in the air. \u2018If you do, he\u2019ll claim North Korean children are beggars. Be on your guard if he asks you anything, even the most innocent questions.\u2019\u201d\n\nHmm. No wonder my attempts at interviewing North Korean kids have never been very fruitful.\n\nLee escaped to China at age 17 and started a new life in Shanghai but remained in touch with her family. One day her mom called from North Korea. \u201cI\u2019ve got a few kilos of ice,\u201d or crystal meth, she said, and she asked for Lee\u2019s help in selling it in China. \u201cIn her world, the law was upside down,\u201d Lee says, explaining how corruption and cynicism had shredded the social fabric of North Korea. \u201cPeople had to break the law to live.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s fair to wonder how accurate these books are, for there\u2019s some incentive when selling a memoir to embellish adventures. I don\u2019t know, and in the case of \u201cIn Order to Live,\u201d skeptics have noted inconsistencies in the stories and raised legitimate questions.\n\nSo how did North Korea come to be the most bizarre country in the world? For the history, one can\u2019t do better than Bradley K. Martin\u2019s magisterial UNDER THE LOVING CARE OF THE FATHERLY LEADER: North Korea and the Kim Dynasty (St. Martin\u2019s Griffin, paper, $29.99). Martin recounts how a minor anti-Japanese guerrilla leader named Kim Il-sung came to be installed by the Russians as leader of the half of the Korean peninsula they controlled after World War II. Martin discovers that Kim\u2019s father was a Christian and a church organist, and Kim himself attended church for a time. That didn\u2019t last, and Kim later banned pretty much all religion \u2014 though he became something of a god himself, quite a trick for an atheist. But do North Koreans really believe in this \u201creligion\u201d?\n\nJudging from defectors I\u2019ve interviewed and much of the literature on North Korea, many do \u2014 especially older people, farmers and those farther from the North Korean border. That\u2019s partly a tribute to the country\u2019s shameless propaganda, which B.R. Myers explores in his interesting book, THE CLEANEST RACE: How North Koreans See Themselves \u2014 And Why It Matters (Melville House, paper, $16). He notes that North Korea produced a poster showing a Christian missionary murdering a Korean child and calling for \u201crevenge against the Yankee vampires\u201d \u2014 at the same time that the United States was the country\u2019s single largest donor of humanitarian aid. Myers argues that North Koreans have focused on what he calls \u201crace-based paranoid nationalism,\u201d including bizarre ideas about how Koreans are \u201cthe cleanest race\u201d \u2014 hence the title \u2014 bullied and persecuted by outsiders.\n\nFor a more sympathetic view of North Korea\u2019s emergence, check out various books by Bruce Cumings, a University of Chicago historian, like KOREA\u2019S PLACE IN THE SUN: A Modern History (W.W. Norton, paper, $19.95). Cumings argues that North Korea is to some degree a genuine expression of Korean nationalism. I think Cumings is nuts when he says, \u201cit is Americans who bear the lion\u2019s share of the responsibility\u201d for the division of the Korean peninsula. But his work is worth reading \u2014 unless you have high blood pressure, in which case consult a physician first.", "title": "What to Read if You Want to Know More About North Korea", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "The second exhausting type of response comes from the teachers, who focus on how this experience is supposed to be an education in mind, body and spirit. \u201cI hope you have a \u2018Job\u2019 experience,\u201d one man said bluntly. I can\u2019t think of anything worse to wish on someone. God allowed Satan to rob Job of everything, including his children\u2019s lives. Do I need to lose something more to learn God\u2019s character? Sometimes I want every know-it-all to send me a note when they face the grisly specter of death, and I\u2019ll send them a poster of a koala that says, \u201cHang in there!\u201d\n\nThe hardest lessons come from the solutions people, who are already a little disappointed that I am not saving myself. There is always a nutritional supplement, Bible verse or mental process I have not adequately tried. \u201cKeep smiling! Your attitude determines your destiny!\u201d said a stranger named Jane in an email, having heard my news somewhere, and I was immediately worn out by the tyranny of prescriptive joy.\n\nThere is a trite cruelty in the logic of the perfectly certain. Those people are not simply trying to give me something. They are tallying up the sum of my life \u2014 looking for clues, sometimes for answers \u2014 for the purpose of pronouncing a verdict. But I am not on trial. To so many people, I am no longer just myself. I am a reminder of a thought that is difficult for the rational brain to accept: that the elements that constitute our bodies might fail at any moment. When I originally got my diagnosis at age 35, all I could think to say was, \u201cBut I have a son.\u201d It was the best argument I had. I can\u2019t end. This world can\u2019t end. It had just begun.\n\nA tragedy is like a fault line. A life is split into a before and an after, and most of the time, the before was better. Few people will let you admit that out loud. Sometimes those who love you best will skip that first horrible step of saying: \u201cI\u2019m sorry. I\u2019m so sorry this is happening to you.\u201d Hope may prevent them from acknowledging how much has already been lost. But acknowledgment is also a mercy. It can be a smile or a simple \u201cOh, hon, what a year you\u2019ve had.\u201d It does not ask anything from me but makes a little space for me to stand there in that moment. Without it, I often feel like I am starring in a reality program about a woman who gets cancer and is very cheerful about it.\n\nAfter acknowledgment must come love. This part is tricky because when friends and acquaintances begin pouring out praise, it can sound a little too much like a eulogy. I\u2019ve had more than one kindly letter written about me in the past tense, when I need to be told who I might yet become.\n\nBut the impulse to offer encouragement is a perfect one. There is tremendous power in touch, in gifts and in affirmations when everything you knew about yourself might not be true anymore. I am a professor, but will I ever teach again? I\u2019m a mom, but for how long? A friend knits me socks and another drops off cookies, and still another writes a funny email or takes me to a concert. These seemingly small efforts are anchors that hold me to the present, that keep me from floating away on thoughts of an unknown future. They say to me, like my sister Maria did on one very bad day: \u201cYes, the world is changed, dear heart, but do not be afraid. You are loved, you are loved. You will not disappear. I am here.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | What to Say When You Meet the Angel of Death at a Party", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Where to Eat and Drink\n\nBarcelona\n\nTickets, one of the most sought-after reservations in the restaurant world, is the new culinary success of Ferran Adri\u00e0, who built a gastronomic revolution with his El Bulli. In a quirky space with circus and theater d\u00e9cor, Tickets serves a parade of exceptional dishes that defy description. Dessert is served in a separate room evoking Alice in Wonderland. Book only online two months in advance. Dinner for one (17 tapas plates, dessert tastings and a drink cost 124.85 euros. Avinguda Parallel 179. elbarriadria.com.\n\nCervecer\u00eda Catalana draws a sophisticated morning-to-late-night crowd to its wide selection of hot tapas, salads and sausages, excellent beer and wine. It has a bustling and entertaining atmosphere smack in the middle of the splendid L\u2019Eixample neighborhood. Two tapas and a mug of beer, 12.50 euros. Carrer de Mallorca 236; phone 93 216 03 68.\n\nGranada\n\nCarmela Restaurante specializes in Mediterranean cuisine with Andalusian traditions in a small dining room overlooking a popular corner of the old city. A dinner of bacalao (cod) mozarabe, a pionono dessert (bananas) and one glass of wine, 31.70 euros. Calle Colcha 13; restaurantecarmela.com.\n\nBodegas Castaneda, popular with tourists and locals, the bustling Castaneda is the tapas bar to end all tapas bars. Longtime waiters call out orders, slide through the crowd, and manage to serve hundreds of people quickly and nicely. Go early and expect to wait for a table. No reservations accepted. A dinner of fabulous berenjenas rellenas (stuffed eggplant), a slice of quiche, and one beer, 7 euros. Calle Almineceros, off famous Calle Elvira. No phone.\n\nMalaga\n\nEl Refectorium, enclosed in glass windows in a contemporary setting, is far from the familiar tapas bars of the casco antiguo. It\u2019s informal but serves an elegant dinner in a restful dining room. A terrific sirloin cooked perfectly to order and a glass of exquisite Ribera come to 30.80 euros. Postigo de los Abades 4; phone 952 60 23 89.\n\nEl Piyayo, famous for its pescaitos fritos (fried fish), serves up typical tapas fare including manchego cheese to go with robust red wine. Dinner for one, 10 euros. Calle Granada 36; entreplatos.es.\n\nSeville\n\nLa Azotea, a popular neighborhood tapas bar, offers a welcoming ambience, artfully presented plates and excellent wines. Dinner for one with wine, around 10 euros. Azotea has four branches in Seville. My favorite is on Calle Zaragoza 5; phone 955 11 67 48.", "title": "What to See and Do in Spain", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Celso Renato\n\nThrough Jan. 20. Mendes Wood DM, 60 East 66th Street, 2nd floor, Manhattan; 212-220-9943, mendeswooddm.com.\n\nThe story of modernism\u2019s debt to non-Western, folk and tribal art is complex and only getting more so. A new wrinkle in the narrative is the work of the singular Brazilian artist Celso Renato (1919-1992), seen in its beguiling seven-piece United States debut at Mendes Wood DM. He was a practicing lawyer and self-taught artist who spent most of his life in Belo Horizonte in the Brazilian state of Minas Gerais.\n\nRenato began painting in the 1960s and by the 1980s was working with a spare geometric vocabulary applied freehand to found pieces of wood and lumber, which he tended to use unaltered. The combination made him an odd man out with the Neo-Concretists. Like them he rejected the clean rational forms of the Concretists, but he retained the earlier group\u2019s attachment to the art object\n\nHis efforts communicate and reward empathic attention. A piece of lumber shaped like a narrow irregular house about two feet tall is cracked all the way through at the center, giving it a crevicelike door. Renato simply painted a series of bars and blocks in red, black or white around its edges, giving it a kind of frame and turning it into a votive object of a female goddess. The same blocks and bars appear on a portion of an old tree trunk. They form a narrow stack at the center of the trunk\u2019s round side, like an abstract homage to the tree it was once part of.", "title": "What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "In \u201cPaintings From the Old World,\u201d Gianni Politi\u2019s gallery debut in the United States, the Italian artist is showing six striking painting-related works whose presence and meanings expand as you look at them. They are a blend of painting, collage and clothing, if not fashion: shirts made from coarse, wheat-colored fabric that hang from pegs by their collars. More or less wrinkled, they resemble work shirts, or more precisely artist\u2019s smocks, since they are randomly daubed, stained and brushed with paint in lovely, fresh colors. The brush strokes conjure everything from Abstract Expressionist scumbling to Tiepolo-like sunsets, but the handiwork never crosses the seams; closer examination indicates that the fabric is actually raw linen. Mr. Politi paints on it while it is temporarily stretched, then gives it to his local tailor who cuts it up according to the artist\u2019s instructions and sews the pieces together.\n\nIn this manner, the medium is pushed from pure form toward function, perhaps from an old world where painting was men\u2019s work, or into a more demanding new world where nothing is wasted. The shirt paintings also comment on the medium\u2019s commodity status, as well as on various collaborations between artists and fashion houses, of which Jeff Koons\u2019s ridiculous Louis Vuitton handbags are but the latest example. And they play with the way that much art, especially painting, both builds on \u2014 reuses \u2014 and comments on previous art. In Mr. Politi\u2019s case, Italian Arte Povera, which had an iffy relationship, at best, to painting, might be both a source and a target. I like the piquant way these objects serve no purpose but look as if they might. I also think Mr. Politi might want to rethink his longer titles \u2014 like \u201cReally Dark Place Where We Used to Rave and Do Heavy Drugs (Happy Days).\u201d Maybe self-deprecation is the aim, but the effect is a ponderously adolescent buzzkill.\n\nROBERTA SMITH\n\nChris Dorland\n\nThrough Feb. 11. Lyles & King, 106 Forsyth Street, Manhattan; 646-484-5478, lylesandking.com.", "title": "What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Quietly, one American painter \u2014 unconcerned with trends, unhurried by the market \u2014 has created an oeuvre of such phenomenological sophistication that she deserves to be called a master. Her art can be found in the collections of the Met, MoMA, the Whitney and more than two dozen other major museums (though too rarely displayed); her students, including Ellen Altfest and Njideka Akunyili Crosby, have risen to prominence (though their teacher\u2019s influence is subtle); and she just keeps at it. She is Catherine Murphy, and her first show of paintings in five years reaffirms that no one sees with a keener eye.\n\nWorking without a camera, Ms. Murphy paints expressly choreographed still lifes and landscapes, and her paintings appear as both windows on the world and bluntly flat physical surfaces. In \u201cBecalmed\u201d (2017), a persimmon-colored inner tube floats in a lake, and both the toy and the water reflect nearby foliage: In the plastic doughnut, reeds appear as ghostly spindles, while the surface of the lake is splotched with upside-down pine branches. In the intricate \u201cFlat Screen\u201d (2016), we see a blotchy, impressionistic forest on a lovingly rendered Samsung television; the green and yellow TV leaves echo the wallpaper of the background at left, while the brown of the TV tree trunks is echoed in the burled wood planks on the wall to the right. Both these paintings get their force from the counterbalancing of reality and reflection, image and object, canvas and screen \u2014 and, more than their narrative overtones, it\u2019s their perceptual complexity that makes the greatest impact. Her closest contemporary may be Vija Celmins, another meticulous observer, though Ms. Murphy differs in her use of extreme perspectives and her prepainting scenography.", "title": "What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Brunschwig was born in Le Havre in 1927. Jewish, she escaped deportation thanks to the shelter of a Catholic friend in the south of France, and later in Paris she became friendly with Emmanuel Levinas, the great philosopher of ethics in the wake of the Holocaust. As early as the 1950s, when she overlaid a slate gray board with scumbles of white and black (all her paintings are untitled), Ms. Brunschwig forswore the strategies of both figuration and gestural abstraction in favor of speechless evocations of emptiness. Soon, influenced by Chinese painting, she began to work on paper with opaque India ink, covering the surfaces with saturated zones of black and leaving hazy-edged, abraded voids in the form of trapezoids, lozenges or stalactites. In one recent work here, painted in a leporello (that is, a book whose pages are folded into one another accordion-style), calligraphic black stripes grow denser and denser from page to page, and the resultant blackout has the weight of history.\n\nPhoto\n\nSlowly, in shows such as \u201cSoldier, Spectre, Shaman,\u201d at MoMA, and \u201cPostwar,\u201d at the Haus der Kunst, in Munich, curators are beginning to rewrite the history of European painting after 1945 as something more than a surrender to America\u2019s avant-garde \u2014 and to place the devastation of the Holocaust at the very center of that story. Ms. Brunschwig\u2019s resolute, comfortless art is a critical component of that history, and it is through the very absence of images that she bears witness to the unspeakable.\n\nJASON FARAGO\n\nNaeem Mohaiemen\n\nThrough March 11. MoMA PS1, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, Queens; 718-784-2084, momaps1.org.\n\nPhoto\n\nOne of the standout artists in last summer\u2019s \u201cdocumenta 14\u201d exhibition, held in Athens and Kassel, Germany, was Naeem Mohaiemen. In Kassel, Mr. Mohaiemen presented a terrific three-channel video, \u201cTwo Meetings and a Funeral\u201d (2017), about Bangladesh\u2019s shift from socialism to Islamism in the mid-1970s. In Athens, he showed \u201cTripoli Cancelled\u201d (2017), which is currently on view in the exhibition \u201cThere Is No Last Man\u201d at MoMA PS1. (Mr. Mohaiemen was also part of a group of artists who signed a petition to protect documenta from becoming an entirely \u201ccommercial enterprise.\u201d)\n\n\u201cTripoli Cancelled\u201d was inspired by an actual story about Mr. Mohaiemen\u2019s father, a Bangladeshi doctor who worked in Libya and in 1977 was stranded in Athens\u2019s Ellinikon Airport (an abandoned structure designed by Eero Saarinen that was recently used to house refugees) for nine days after leaving his passport at a preceding checkpoint. Mr. Mohaiemen\u2019s fictional version of the tale is magically existential \u2014 like Franz Kafka and Samuel Beckett mixed with Julio Cort\u00e1zar, threaded through the needle of colonialism and 21st-century security states.\n\nFor \u201cVolume Eleven (Flaw in the Algorithm of Cosmopolitanism)\u201d (2016), Mr. Mohaiemen digs into another interesting episode in 20th-century history: his great-uncle, the Bengali writer Syed Mujtaba Ali, who wrote in support of Hitler\u2019s Germany in the late 1930s as a way of challenging the British Empire. Displayed as a series of diptych photographs of his uncle\u2019s writing, in a darkened room at PS1, the work highlights our own culpabilities and the possibility of falling on the \u201cwrong\u201d side of history. This is obviously a concern for Mr. Mohaiemen as an artist-activist. And yet he aptly shows not just how the personal is always entwined with the political, but how history veers from neat linear narratives into circular, concentric and even fantastic and unimaginable patterns and designs.\n\nMARTHA SCHWENDENER\n\nYasuo Ihara\n\nThrough Jan. 21. Ulterior Gallery, 172 Attorney Street, Manhattan; 917-472-7784, ulteriorgallery.com.\n\nPhoto\n\nYasuo Ihara was born in Osaka, Japan, and started out as an abstract painter. But here in New York, where he arrived in 1963 and found work as a costume designer, his practice took a tilt toward the conceptual. In 1971, he began making latex casts of household objects and preserving the casts in carefully labeled Plexiglas boxes. Ihara died in 2010. Working from a 1973 photo and a typewritten list, with advice from the artist\u2019s daughter Mia, the gallerist Takako Tanabe has reconstructed, for its first public showing, Ihara\u2019s extraordinary \u201cExplanation 1,\u201d which comprises 68 of these stacked boxes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn their own, the latex casts make any number of different points. The paper-white, easily identified \u201cCARTON OF EGGS,\u201d nearly a stand-in for its subject, is pop philosophy, while \u201cDRAWING TABLE,\u201d crumpled unrecognizably in the bottom half of its box, is a tart memento mori. A yellowed and drooping mask of Hermes, part of the separate six-box \u201cExplanation,\u201d could serve as an indictment of the insularity of white art history, and an intricately bumpy cantaloupe as a way of isolating a beautiful texture from distracting color.\n\nPhoto\n\nAll together, though, the casts constitute a symphony of magical absurdity, demonstrating both the elasticity and the uselessness of our human faculty for picking out objects and naming them \u2014 in this case in block capitals. (Not for nothing did Ms. Tanabe hang Maryam Amiryani\u2019s tiny black-and-white painting of Jorge Luis Borges in the gallery\u2019s office.) But they\u2019re also a soothing reminder of the world\u2019s supple resistance to being picked apart that way, because as soon as those separate objects are juxtaposed, they knit themselves together again into some new living whole. In \u201cExplanation 1,\u201d it\u2019s a winning, wistful portrait of a man who ate his fried EGGS with toasted ITALIAN BREAD and drank his COFFEE with MILK and his SCOTCH with COCA-COLA.\n\nWILL HEINRICH", "title": "What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week", "authors": ["Roberta Smith", "Jason Farago", "Martha Schwendener", "Will Heinrich"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s like you\u2019re on edge constantly,\u201d she said. \u201cOne day you have hope that it might go through, and then something else comes up.\u201d\n\nAn agreement did seem to be staggering closer on Tuesday, though how much closer seemed impossible for even the negotiators to predict amid the welter of bewildering signals from Mr. Trump. After a year of holding a hard line on immigration, the president suggested in a meeting with congressional leaders that he supported not only a deal to protect the Dreamers but also a comprehensive immigration reform package, raising the possibility that the DACA recipients\u2019 security could hinge on a much messier set of compromises.\n\nRepublicans, meanwhile, were still pushing to tie any benefits for the young immigrants to curbs on family-based legal immigration, border security and other conservative priorities that Democrats and immigration advocates have frowned upon.\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re being held hostage as a bargaining chip,\u201d said Rafael Robles, 26, a DACA recipient in Chicago who owns an architecture, design and real estate development firm. \u201cI\u2019m not advocating for the Dream Act at the expense of everyone else.\u201d\n\nOn Tuesday night, a federal judge in San Francisco ruled that the Trump administration had ended the program improperly and ordered it restarted. Though immigration advocates welcomed the ruling, they cautioned that they expected it to be challenged, if not overturned, and warned that a court order was no substitute for an act of Congress.\n\nIt was around 5 a.m. in Fall River, Mass., when Hellosa Silva, 18, a high school senior who came to the United States from Brazil when she was an infant, was jolted awake by a news alert on her cellphone informing her of the judge\u2019s decision.\n\n\u201cI read it and got super excited,\u201d she said.\n\nImmigration lawyers were deluged on Wednesday morning with clients eager to take advantage of the court-ordered reinstatement. Jeremy McKinney, an immigration lawyer in North Carolina whose firm has more than 1,000 clients with DACA, said he posted the court ruling on the firm\u2019s Facebook page late Tuesday, only for his phones to blow up in the morning.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. McKinney said that he had advised his clients against filing renewal paperwork because there was no guarantee that the administration would approve any new applications, even if it did not win on appeal, and he did not feel comfortable accepting legal fees for what would likely be a futile effort.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt was difficult news to break to clients who are emotionally exhausted.\n\n\u201cWe certainly have been wearing our counselor hats here at the law firm,\u201d he said. \u201cWe do our best to talk them through it, to kind of decrease their anxiety levels, but frankly, it\u2019s not working.\u201d\n\nRamiro Luna was working late on Tuesday in Dallas when he saw the news about the judge\u2019s ruling on Facebook. It did little to relieve the tension he felt every time he thought about his DACA status \u2014 which was to say, every time he looked at the countdown clock on his iPhone that tells him how many days he has left before it expires.\n\nOn Wednesday, the clock stood at 280 days.\n\n\u201cEvery single day,\u201d he said, \u201cI feel like I have one day left to consider myself safe here.\u201d\n\nMr. Luna, 33, came to the United States from Mexico with his father at the age of 7. Now studying psychology at the University of North Texas at Dallas, he works as the campaign manager for State Representative Victoria Neave, a Dallas Democrat.\n\nHe said he had grown accustomed to living with chaos and uncertainty. For one thing, he might lose his work permit before ballots are cast in the election he is working on.\n\nPhoto\n\nDACA has allowed its recipients to get jobs, go to college, obtain driver\u2019s licenses and open 401(k)s. All of those opportunities are now at risk.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re at the mercy of the administration. We\u2019re at the mercy of court rulings,\u201d Mr. Luna said. \u201cRight now I\u2019m already thinking: What kind of remedial job am I going to be able to do without documentation?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor Missael Garcia, 27, the question was no longer theoretical. The work permit he obtained through DACA has already expired, forcing him to give up his job as a mentor with the Baltimore city schools system. Now he works as a restaurant cook, paid off the books in cash, he said.\n\nOn Wednesday, unwilling to leave matters to a judge, he was in Washington, knocking on lawmakers\u2019 doors with a Baltimore-based advocacy group, Casa in Action.\n\n\u201cI feel like this government says things that get people excited and then gets their hopes up,\u201d he said, \u201cand at the end of the day it\u2019s like a stab in the back.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nKnocking on doors, calling members of Congress, spreading the word on social media: Activism was the only hope most DACA recipients had of influencing a process that had played out in front of millions, on television and in news outlets across the country, yet would ultimately come down to the inclinations of a few.\n\nMost immigration activists believe their best chance at a deal for the Dreamers is now, when Democrats can threaten to withhold support for a spending bill Congress would need to pass to prevent the government from shutting down on Jan. 19.\n\nMore than 100 DACA recipients have been traipsing throughout the Capitol in Washington for the past two days, telling their stories to lawmakers in an urgent effort to persuade them to enshrine the program into law.\n\nOne of them was Hector Rivera Suarez, 20, the student body president at Guilford College, in Greensboro, N.C., whose DACA status expires Jan. 21.\n\n\u201cNow I feel like I don\u2019t have control over my own future anymore,\u201d he said. \u201cI had all these plans, but now it\u2019s up to someone else to make those decisions for me.\u201d", "title": "What \u2018Dreamers\u2019 Say About the Great Immigration Debate", "authors": ["Vivian Yee", "Caitlin Dickerson", "Sheryl Gay Stolberg"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The trend is not only depriving giant investment banks of a staple income source. It is also altering the pecking order and business practices of Wall Street in profound ways.\n\nNowhere is the shift more pronounced, or more painful, than at Goldman Sachs Group, not long ago regarded as the unrivaled king of Wall Street. These days, the bank is fighting to maintain an edge that has been blunted by the diminution of its core trading business.\n\nAt its peak, Goldman\u2019s fixed-income division churned out nearly a billion dollars every two weeks. Last year, it took the bank an average of more than two months to earn that sum.\n\nThe shift has left its once cocksure traders at times reeling. One day last spring, for example, they were caught by surprise when energy prices began to move sharply. After a few inquiries, the traders learned that Petr\u00f3leos Mexicanos, the Mexican state energy company, known as Pemex, was buying instruments designed to protect against the possibility of falling oil prices.\n\nNot only was Pemex not using Goldman to execute the trades, but Goldman hadn\u2019t even been aware that the trades were happening. It was a rude awakening for Goldman, which previously had done tens of millions of dollars\u2019 worth of work for the Mexican government, helping it protect itself against swings in the oil market, current and former employees with knowledge of the trades said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUntil a few years ago, traders at big banks spent much of their time wagering on the future direction of markets. Sometimes those trades were executed on behalf of clients; often, they were done using the banks\u2019 own cash. Successful traders pocketed a percentage of their winnings, earning Hollywood-style glory in the financial media.\n\nTrading jobs are much different now \u2014 less risky, less glamorous and, most of all, less lucrative.\n\nNew government rules require banks to hold thicker capital cushions to guard against losses, which makes trading less profitable by tying up more of a firm\u2019s capital. Other regulations outlaw bank employees from trading with their companies\u2019 cash.\n\nThat leaves traders spending much of their time looking for efficient ways to connect buyers with sellers.\n\n\u201cThese banks are basically utilities now,\u201d said Harley Bassman, who retired last year as a portfolio manager at the giant bond fund manager Pimco.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEven when it comes to serving clients, traditional investment banks are finding themselves at a disadvantage to upstarts that move faster at a lower price.\n\nJane Street is one such firm. Founded in 2000, it originally served as a behind-the-scenes broker, helping big banks make complex trades with one another, out of view of the investors and money managers who were the banks\u2019 customers. These days, though, Jane Street offers the same services as the banks but with more power to automate trades.\n\nMichael Bumkeun Cho, a portfolio manager at Samsung Asset Management in Seoul, South Korea, which manages $200 billion, specializes in the trading of exchange-traded funds, baskets of stocks or bonds that are easily traded. He said he had stopped relying exclusively on banks for his trading when he learned that Jane Street responded more quickly to his trading orders and charged lower fees.\n\n\u201cWe understand the advantage of the independent market makers over the big investment banks,\u201d Mr. Cho said.\n\nCitadel Securities, part of the Chicago-based hedge fund conglomerate run by Kenneth C. Griffin, is also muscling in on the banks\u2019 traditional turf, using technology to undercut the banks on speed and price. One particular area that Citadel has targeted are interest rate swaps, an instrument that companies traditionally used to protect themselves against swings in interest rates.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cFor many years \u2014 decades, actually \u2014 the big Wall Street firms had a stranglehold on those clients,\u201d said Paul Hamill, global head of fixed-income, currencies and commodities at Citadel Securities. But two years ago, he said, it became clear that \u201csome banks were going to pull away from being all things to all clients.\u201d Citadel saw an opportunity.\n\nCompounding the pressure on banks, market conditions for the past year have been, well, boring.\n\nTraders \u2014 and by extension their employers \u2014 thrive in volatile markets. Rapid fluctuations in prices tend to generate lots of buying and selling among clients.\n\nBut markets have been remarkably steady for more than a year. Nothing seems to shake them much anymore \u2014 not hostility with Russia, not President Trump\u2019s tweets, not saber-rattling on the Korean Peninsula.\n\nTraders and sales representatives in banks\u2019 fixed-income businesses are struggling to find ways to drum up business from clients. A rates salesman at a big American bank who was not authorized to speak publicly said it had become hard to even engage clients in a substantive conversation about their expectations for future market prices. He described having to hunt for conversation topics during phone calls with them \u2014 low volatility, it seems, can make for awkward silences.\n\nAmrit Shahani, the research director for Coalition, said he didn\u2019t see anything coming that would improve conditions for the biggest banks.\n\n\u201cI think you can expect another slow year in 2018,\u201d he said.", "title": "What\u2019s $27 Billion to Wall Street? An Alarming Drop in Revenue", "authors": ["Emily Flitter", "Kate Kelly"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nYou never know what you\u2019ll find when crossing the threshold into someone else\u2019s home. Ask Vivian Toy. As a reporter for The New York Times\u2019s Real Estate section, Ms. Toy entered thousands of strangers\u2019 residences. Many homeowners prepared accordingly for the visit: Floors were mopped, throw pillows fluffed, desks straightened and toothbrushes tucked away. But then there were the surprises \u2014 the ones that were, in brief, a mess.\n\nShe and the accompanying Times photographer would jump into housekeeper mode, cleaning the place up so it could be presentable for photographing. In one memorable visit to a celebrity\u2019s exceptionally untidy apartment, Ms. Toy returned to the office and announced, \u201cI just handled a movie star\u2019s underwear!\u201d\n\nFor six years, Ms. Toy \u2014 now the section\u2019s editor \u2014 reported on for-sale properties for \u201cOn the Market,\u201d a weekly column that features three New York City listings and two regional ones. The column consistently ranks among The Times\u2019s most popular online features. \u201cIt\u2019s house porn,\u201d said Stefanos Chen, a real estate reporter who took over the column in July. \u201cYes, there\u2019s a consumer part to it, but there\u2019s also an element of voyeurism.\u201d\n\nThe Times has been covering real estate for decades, but until the early aughts, the articles were geared toward developers and brokers as well as buyers. As content migrated online, however, it became clear that pieces that helped individuals \u2014 typical Times readers \u2014 navigate the real estate market resonated best.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStories today focus on buying and selling as well as renting, renovating and living. The \u201cWhat You Get\u201d column showcases three properties around the country listed for the same price, while \u201cHouse Hunting In \u2026\u201d serves those looking to buy abroad. One of the Real Estate section\u2019s primary goals is also to capture what it\u2019s like to live in New York \u2014 including the unique challenges the city presents, Ms. Toy said. And to that end, there\u2019s the \u201cAsk Real Estate\u201d column, which addresses questions ranging from how to get rid of a terrible roommate to how to make peace with a neighbor\u2019s annoying whistling. \u201cThere are basically three main questions: I hate my neighbors, I hate my landlord and I hate this city,\u201d said Ronda Kaysen, who writes the column. \u201cBut within those categories there\u2019s a lot of variability.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s Behind Door No. 2? Life as a Real Estate Reporter", "authors": ["Rachel Nuwer"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Turkey is now trying to disrupt the Syrian Kurds\u2019 control of Afrin. It is not the first time Turkey has intervened: In August 2016, it launched a major offensive to clear ISIS remnants from their border stronghold, and to roll back gains by Syrian Kurdish forces.\n\nMr. Erdogan fears that the Syrian Kurds would use control of much of northern Syria to support the outlawed Kurdistan Workers\u2019 Party, also known as the P.K.K., a separatist group that Turkey, the United States and the European Union all consider a terrorist group.\n\nPhoto\n\nHere\u2019s where things get complicated. The United States has armed a Syrian Kurdish militia, the People\u2019s Protection Units, that has played a crucial role in battling ISIS. That militia was founded as the armed wing of a leftist party that grew out of the P.K.K.\n\nAs the fight against ISIS nears an end, Turkey fears that the militia will turn its attention toward helping its Kurdish allies in Turkey. That fear is not entirely unjustified, according to Renad Mansour, a scholar at Chatham House in London, who points out that Abdullah Ocalan, the Kurdistan Workers\u2019 Party leader imprisoned since 1999, was based in Kurdish Syria for nearly two decades.\n\nAmy Austin Holmes, a fellow at the Wilson Center who has studied the Syrian Kurds, says that many of them joined the Protection Units \u201cfor the simple reason that they wanted to defend their towns, like Kobani, that were under attack from the Islamic State, and not necessarily because they were convinced by the ideology of the P.K.K.\u201d\n\nMichael M. Gunter, a political scientist at Tennessee Tech who also studies the Syrian Kurds, said, \u201cThe Turks overplay the threat, but it\u2019s not completely a figment of their imagination.\u201d\n\nHow did the Kurds end up in the middle of all this?\n\nThe Kurds have been one of the United States\u2019 most effective allies in the fight against ISIS, and the implosion of authority in Syria in 2011, and in Iraq in 2003, revived the aspirations of a people often described as the world\u2019s largest stateless nation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nISIS, a mostly Sunni movement, considers Kurds and Shiites apostates and heretics. The Kurds have also recruited, trained and promoted women as fighters, a rare sight in the Middle East.\n\nThe Kurds make up a substantial minority in Iraq, Iran, Syria and Turkey, and while some share aspirations of an independent Kurdish nation, that aspiration is far from universal. In particular, the leadership of the largely autonomous Kurdish region in Iraq has close economic ties to Turkey and is skeptical of the Syrian Kurds.\n\nPhoto\n\nPartly to avoid the appearance of siding too closely with the Kurds, the United States helped organize a multiethnic force, the Syrian Democratic Forces, in 2015 to help lead the fight against ISIS.\n\n\u201cWe knew this day would come, when ISIS would be defeated and the U.S. would have to decide what to do: stop supporting the S.D.F., or continue supporting them,\u201d Mr. Gunter said.\n\nJordi Tejel, a historian at the University of Neuch\u00e2tel in Switzerland, said that Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson\u2019s announcement last week that the United States would support a new, 30,000-strong, Kurdish-led border force in northeastern Syria helped precipitate the Turkish attack. It raised fears across the region that the United States was trying to cement an autonomous Kurdish enclave.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cTurkey has wished to intervene in this area for a while,\u201d he said. \u201cThe Trump administration\u2019s announcement gave it a good excuse.\u201d\n\nIs this bad for the United States?\n\nYes, but it\u2019s partly Washington\u2019s fault for pursuing an anti-ISIS strategy that set up the Turkish-Kurdish time bomb that is now going off.\n\nNikolaos van Dam, a former Dutch ambassador to Iraq and a scholar of the Middle East, said that the Trump administration was supporting the Syrian Kurds \u201cagainst the explicit wishes of Turkey\u201d because it wanted to keep a foothold in Syria after ISIS collapses. But he warned that this approach was unlikely to succeed if Mr. Assad stayed in power.\n\nThe conflict now risks pitting former allies against each other: Members of the Free Syrian Army, a loose coalition of American-backed moderate rebels fighting Mr. Assad, are now fighting alongside the Turkish Army against the Kurds.\n\nIn the long run, Mr. Van Dam said, Washington will probably consider its alliance with Turkey to be more important than its relationship with the Kurds.", "title": "What\u2019s Behind Turkey\u2019s Attack on Syria\u2019s Kurds", "authors": ["Sewell Chan"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "2. Next, join the conversation by clicking on the comment button and posting in the box that opens on the right. (Students 13 and older are invited to comment, although teachers of younger students are welcome to post what their students have to say.)\n\n3. After you have posted, try reading back to see what others have said, then respond to someone else by posting another comment. Use the \u201cReply\u201d button or the @ symbol to address that student directly.\n\nEach second Tuesday of the month, our collaborator, the American Statistical Association, will facilitate a discussion from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern Time by paraphrasing comments and linking to responses to help students\u2019 understanding go deeper. You might use their responses as models for your own.\n\n4. On Thursday afternoon, Jan. 11, we will reveal at the bottom of this post more information about the graph. How does the original New York Times article and the moderators\u2019 additional questions help you see the graph differently? You can incorporate the statistical terms defined in Stat Nuggets in your response.\n\n_________\n\nMore?\n\n\u2022 Read our introductory post, which includes information about using the \u201cNotice and Wonder\u201d teaching strategy.\n\n\u2022 Go to the A.S.A. K-12 website, which includes This is Statistics, resources, professional development, student competitions, curriculum, courses and careers.\n\n_________\n\nUpdated: Jan. 11, 2018\n\nStudents, I bet you never realized that the differences in projected career earnings by college major could be so large. For example for just these 21 majors, the difference in the median goes from a low of $2.2 million in education to a high of $4.2 million in chemical engineering \u2014 almost twice as large. Many of you wrote about how unfair this is. O\u2019BryantGirlNamedFallon in Boston wrote:\n\nWell, to me it seems like the teachers, who shape the future of our children, are not getting the money they deserve. I wonder, why should the teachers who help all these people reach their dreams, why should they get the lowest pay?\n\nDe Kween of Uganda wrote:\n\nThis (graph) is important for people who will soon be going into college to see. We often have skewed views of wages. This is a great and easy-to-digest example. This also shows what\u2019s wrong in the job market. Teachers are paid the least even though they provide an extremely important service to the entire country. They are needed by this country, and we have let them down. They need to be paid more ... and that has a huge impact on the future of this country. It is also important to notice the lack of information the graph provides about the survey, and to take the information with a grain of salt.\n\nHis last sentence brings up the questions: Where do these data come from? Was it from a survey or a statistical model? If a survey, who was included and what questions were asked? How was \u201cprojected career earnings\u201d calculated?\n\nThe New York Times article \u201cSix Myths About Choosing a Major\u201d was part of the November 5, 2017 Education Life section. The table of the data is here. There is a time series graph of the data here. Which is easier to interpret \u2014 the article\u2019s boxplots, the table or the time series graph?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHere are some questions you may want to think about critically:\n\n\u2022 Learn some more about boxplots from the Stat Nuggets below or elsewhere. What is the significance of a longer or shorter boxplot? What is the significance of the darker blue segments of the boxplots? And, the lighter blue segments?\n\n\u2022 Compare the medians of the different majors (which many of you did), but don\u2019t stop there\u2026 also compare the other percentiles \u2014 10%, 25%, 75%, and 90%. Which majors tend to have the least career earnings and most career earnings? Do career earnings vary more above or below the median? What does this imply?\n\n\u2022 The length of each segment of the boxplot shows the variability of the earnings within that segment. (See the Stat Nugget Percentiles & Quartiles below.) Which majors have the greatest variability in earnings? The least variability? How might this affect your view of the career?\n\n\u2022 \u201cMajor\u201d is not the same as \u201ccareer.\u201d Identify careers that do not fit into a specific major, like being an actor, minister or lawyer. Where would these individuals be in the boxplots?\n\n\u2022 If college students studied this graph and many decided to major in the fields with the greatest earnings, how do you think this would affect earnings for these majors?\n\nBelow in Stat Nuggets, we define and explain boxplots and their components: percentiles, quartiles and median. Look into the archives to see past Stat Nuggets terms.\n\nThank you for participating in \u201cWhat\u2019s Going On in This Graph?\u201d, which is intended to have you think more critically about graphs and the underlying data in a news story. Critical thinking is an essential element of statistics, the science of learning from data. Data visualizations, like this graph, are an important part of statistics. They help us to understand and communicate about data.\n\nKeep noticing and wondering. Come up with conjectures based on the graphs. We continue to welcome more responses.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSee you next month on Tuesday, February 13, for our next \u201cWhat\u2019s Going On in This Graph?\u201d This is the day before Valentine\u2019s Day. Maybe the graph will be about love.\n\n_________\n\nStat Nuggets for \u201cSix Myths About Choosing a Major\u201d\n\nPERCENTILES & QUARTILES\n\nPercentiles are numbers that divide ordered, quantitative datasets into one-hundredths. After putting data in order from smallest to largest, you can find the percentiles. For example, for the 90th percentile, 90% of the data is less than this value.\n\nQuartiles are numbers that divide data into quarters. The 25th percentile is called the first quartile (Q1). 25% of the data is less than Q1. The 50th percentile is called the median and is the second quartile (Q2). 50% of the data is less than the median. The 75th percentile is the third quartile (Q3). 75% of the data is less than Q3.\n\nLet\u2019s look at college graduates that have degrees in chemical engineering. Someone in this field who is at the 10th percentile among their peers is projected to earn about $2.5 million dollars over their entire career. Is that a lot? What do you think that breaks down to in terms of dollars per year? What about the highest performers in chemical engineering? Someone who is at the 90th percentile is projected to earn about $5.8 million over their entire career. Is this substantially better than the projected career earnings in other fields?\n\nMEDIAN\n\nThe median is the middle value of the data when the data is put in order from smallest to largest. Half of the values are less than the median and half are greater.\n\nFor example, for general business, the median projected career earnings for college graduates is about $3.1 million, which is less than the median for nursing.\n\nBOXPLOT\n\nA boxplot is a graph on a number line that shows five statistics from quantitative data \u2014 minimum value, first quartile (Q1), median, third quartile (Q3) and maximum value.\n\nThis graph is sometimes called a box and whiskers plot when the values between the 1st and 3rd quartile are bounded with a box and the median marked in the box. The minimum and maximum are shown with \u201cwhiskers\u201d extending outside the box.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn this graph, we have a variation of a boxplot. Of the five statistics, we see the 25th percentile (Q1), the median and 75th percentile (Q3). The minimum and the maximum are not shown. Why? For each career, there\u2019s probably someone who earns nothing as well as someone who earns millions of dollars. So, a minimum of $0 and a maximum of $5,000,000+ would not be very informative about what career earnings are expected. Instead, the 10th and 90th percentiles are shown to give a clearer idea of what the middle 80% of college graduates are projected to earn by major.\n\nNote that the center \u201cbox\u201d with half of the data (75% - 25% = 50%) is in a darker color. These are the most typical earnings. Also, notice that the four quarters are not of equal length. Longer segments indicate that earnings are more spread out. For example, look at the variability in the top earners that have degrees in the humanities. There are some who make a lot more than others in this major! Who could they be? Famous writers or even humanities majors who went into seemingly unrelated fields.\n\n_________\n\nThe graphs for \u201cWhat\u2019s Going On in This Graph?\u201d are selected in partnership with Sharon Hessney, the Statistics Content Director at Mass Insight Education. In addition, Ms. Hessney and Erica Chauvet, author and teacher at Waynesburg University and Hillcrest Christian Academy in Pennsylvania, moderated the Tuesday comments and wrote this week\u2019s \u201creveal\u201d and Stat Nuggets section.", "title": "What\u2019s Going On in This Graph? | Jan. 9, 2018", "authors": ["The Learning Network", "What'S Going On In This Graph"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Updated: Jan. 25, 2018\n\nStudents\n\n1. The new play by existential specialist Enda Walsh (\u201cOnce,\u201d \u201cLazarus\u201d) asks a lot of questions. Who are these men? And where are they? And if the town of Ballyturk really looms outside, what kind of a place is this? The actors Mikel Murfi, Tadhg Murphy and Olwen Fou\u00e9r\u00e9 will suggest some answers.\n\n866-811-4111, stannswarehouse.com\n\n\u2018A CHRONICLE OF THE MADNESS OF SMALL WORLDS\u2019 at Next Door at NYTW (performances start on Jan. 17). Off Off Broadway gets a little weirder every time a new Mac Wellman play is announced. In this production, the director Elena Araoz adapts two short stories, each imagining life and love on nearby asteroids. Anastasia Olowin and Timothy Siragusa star.\n\n212-279-4200 , nytw.org\n\n\u2018FIRE AND AIR\u2019 at Classic Stage Company (previews start on Jan. 17; opens on Feb. 1). The actors of Terrence McNally\u2019s new play may not quite manage a perfect arabesque in midair, but they\u2019ll attempt to capture the spirit of the Ballets Russes, particularly the relationship between Sergei Diaghilev (Douglas Hodge) and his prot\u00e9g\u00e9 and lover Vaslav Nijinsky (James Cusati-Moyer).\n\n866-811-4111, classicstage.org\n\n\u2018HANGMEN\u2019 at the Linda Gross Theater (previews start on Jan. 18; opens on Feb. 5). Will the new Martin McDonagh play slay? The playwright and filmmaker arrives at the Atlantic Theater with his latest play, a London hit, directed by Matthew Dunster. Set in 1963 and 1965, its mysteries and yarns straddle the end of capital punishment in England. Reviewing an earlier production, Ben Brantley wrote, \u201cI can think of few contemporary playwrights who infuse old-fashioned, precision-tooled dramaturgy with such fresh blood.\u201d\n\n866-811-4111, atlantictheater.org\n\n\u2018HE BROUGHT HER HEART BACK IN A BOX\u2019 at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center (previews start on Jan. 18; opens on Jan. 30). Adrienne Kennedy, one of the American theater\u2019s great experimentalists, brings a new play to Theater for a New Audience, her first in nearly a decade. An interracial love story set in the Jim Crow south, it melds personal explorations of racial prejudice with fairy tale, theater and film. Evan Yionoulis directs.\n\n866-811-4111, tfana.org\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. A beachy comedy-drama of sex and class from 1912, this play by Stanley Houghton, revived by the Mint Theater Company, centers on a flirty weekend between a mill owner\u2019s son and one of the women workers. After their parents find out, things get a lot less flirty. Gus Kaikkonen directs.\n\n212-239-6200, minttheater.org\n\n\u2018IN THE BODY OF THE WORD\u2019 at New York City Center Stage I (previews start on Jan. 16; opens on Feb. 6). Eve Ensler, the author of the celebrated \u201cVagina Monologues,\u201d turns her attention back to anatomy in this play adapted from her 2013 memoir, which discusses her treatment for uterine cancer. In this Manhattan Theater Club production, Ms. Ensler discusses her growing understanding between local illness and global concerns. Diane Paulus directs.\n\n212-581-1212, nycitycenter.org\n\n\u2018THE UNDERTAKING\u2019 at 59E59 Theaters (in previews; opens on Jan. 17). Having tackled sex, loss, the Paris Commune and an apocalyptic future, the Civilians turn their attention to death. In this piece, a nurse, a soldier, a trainee embalmer and an artist describe their experiences with death and the writer and director Steve Cosson confronts his own fears.\n\n212-279-4200, 59e59.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018UNTIL THE FLOOD\u2019 at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater (in previews; opens on Jan. 18). Extreme weather events are a new normal, but in Dael Orlandersmith\u2019s new play, it\u2019s the emotional and social atmosphere that\u2019s turbulent. Motivated by the death of Michael Brown, Ms. Orlandersmith conducted interviews with St. Louis residents then created a theatrical mosaic based in their words.\n\n(212) 627-2556, rattlestick.org\n\nLast Chance\n\n\u2018METEOR SHOWER\u2019 at the Booth Theater (closes on Jan. 21). While Jesse Green complimented many of the jokes, he wrote that \u201ctiny wit bombs do not make a satisfying play.\u201d Like most meteors, the show \u201cglows and is gone.\u201d\n\n212-239-6200, meteoronbroadway.com\n\n\u2018MISS SAIGON\u2019 at the Broadway Theater (closes on Jan. 14). Friedman Theater (closes on Feb. 4). In Lucy Kirkwood\u2019s gripping eco-thriller, three physicists walk into a country cottage and worlds unfold.
