Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.\n\nPreviews and Openings\n\n\u2018AMY AND THE ORPHANS\u2019 at the Laura Pels Theater at the Harold and Miriam Steinberg Center for Theater (previews start on Feb. 1; opens on March 1). In this new play from Lindsey Ferrentino (\u201cUgly Lies the Bone\u201d) a father dies and two adult siblings (Debra Monk and Mark Blum) set out to inform their sister, a woman with Down syndrome. For Roundabout Theater Company, Scott Ellis directs the road trip, which stars Jamie Brewer of \u201cAmerican Horror Story.\u201d\n\n212-719-1300, roundabouttheatre.org\n\n\u2018AT HOME AT THE ZOO\u2019 at the Pershing Square Signature Center (previews start on Jan. 30; opens on Feb. 21). In this darkly comic Edward Albee diptych, the outside world has its uncertainties and terrors. So does the inside one. For the Signature Theater, Lila Neugebauer directs the twinned one-acts \u201cHomelife\u201d and \u201cThe Zoo Story,\u201d which star Katie Finneran, Robert Sean Leonard and Paul Sparks.\n\n212-244-7529, signaturetheatre.org\n\n\u2018CARDINAL\u2019 at the Tony Kiser Theater at Second Stage (in previews; opens on Jan. 30). In Greg Pierce\u2019s play about returns and restorations, a woman returns to her hometown with a colorful plan for urban renewal \u2014 paint the place red. In Kate Whoriskey\u2019s production, Anna Chlumsky stars as Lydia, the visionary, with Adam Pally as the skeptical mayor. Becky Ann Baker and Stephen Park also star.\n\n212-246-4422, 2st.com", "title": "What\u2019s New in NYC Theater", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nEvery month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of movies and TV shows to their libraries, and every month we write about those titles we think are most interesting. Here\u2019s our list for January.\n\nSometimes it\u2019s hard to keep track of what\u2019s arriving when. But we\u2019re here to help. To that end, here are those picks that were recently added, just ahead of the three-day weekend. Note that streaming services occasionally change their schedules without giving notice.\n\nNew to Netflix\n\nMatt LeBlanc in \u201cEpisodes.\u201d Colin Hutton/Showtime\n\n\u2018Episodes\u2019 Seasons 1-5\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 6\n\nJan. 6 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis wry comedy follows a British husband-and-wife writing team (Tamsin Greig and Stephen Mangan), as they alternately endure and simply marvel at American television executives\u2019 efforts to dumb down their award-winning British show. Matt LeBlanc gamely plays himself as a rich, narcissistic nightmare. \u201cEpisodes\u201d is serialized and doesn\u2019t hit its stride until midway through the first season. Give yourself at least four episodes to get hooked.\n\n\u2014\n\nVera Farmiga in \u201cThe Conjuring.\u201d Michael Tackett/Warner Bros. Pictures\n\n\u2018The Conjuring\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 8\n\nJan. 8 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nDirector James Wan (\u201cSaw\u201d) channels the spirit of 1970s horror films like \u201cThe Exorcist\u201d and \u201cThe Amityville Horror\u201d to create a mythology around a real-life married pair of paranormal investigators. The premise may feel familiar, but Vera Farmiga and Patrick Wilson do wonders with their roles as the ghost-hunting couple.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nNew Netflix Original Movies\n\nJack Black, left, and Jason Schwartzman in \u201cThe Polka King.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018The Polka King\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 12\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nBased on the true story of Jan Lewan \u2014 who is also the subject of a 2009 documentary \u2014 \u201cThe Polka King\u201d stars Jack Black as Lewan, a popular Pennsylvania polka bandleader who takes advantage of his mostly older fan base to raise money in a shady investment scheme. The film finally arrives on Netflix this month, almost exactly one year after it was well received in its debut at the Sundance Film Festival.\n\n\u2014\n\nNew to Amazon Prime\n\nA scene from \u201cA Ghost Story.\u201d A24\n\n\u2018A Ghost Story\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 7\n\nJan. 7 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe ghost in this minimalist indie drama by David Lowery (\u201cPete\u2019s Dragon\u201d) dons a white sheet with two eyeholes, like the world\u2019s least creative Halloween costume. But it isn\u2019t out to scare anybody and neither is the film. Instead, \u201cA Ghost Story\u201d is about a dead man (Casey Affleck) who sticks around his home after he dies to observe what happens as his wife (Rooney Mara) mourns and moves on, and as the house changes ownership over the years.\n\n\u2014\n\nNew to Hulu\n\nMichael Fassbender as the title character in \u201cFrank.\u201d Magnolia Pictures\n\n\u2018Frank\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 8\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nYou\u2019ve probably seen Michael Fassbender in one of his many serious roles, but his performance in this 2014 dark comedy is odder than usual. For most of the movie, his face is concealed by a big, bizarre papier-m\u00e2ch\u00e9 head that his character, a bandleader named Frank, wears at all times.\n\n\u2014", "title": "What\u2019s New to Streaming Services in Time for This Weekend", "authors": ["The Watching Team"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWatch the trials and tribulations of another young British queen. And Sarah Jessica Parker\u2019s \u201cDivorce\u201d returns for a second season.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nVICTORIA 9 p.m. on PBS. The appetite for the dramatization of the lives of young British royalty seems to be limitless at the moment. Just a month after the second season of \u201cThe Crown\u201d arrived on Netflix to widespread interest, Season 2 of \u201cVictoria\u201d touches down on PBS. Jenna Coleman plays Queen Victoria with a modern feistiness she brought in spades to the role of the Companion on \u201cDoctor Who.\u201d This season takes place in the 1840s, as Victoria enters a state of serial pregnancy and engages in power struggles with her husband, Prince Albert (Tom Hughes). Diana Rigg, celebrated for her witty, acidic turn in \u201cGame of Thrones,\u201d will play a pivotal role as the Duchess of Buccleuch.\n\nMASTERCHEF LATINO 8 p.m. on Telemundo. The first ever Spanish-language iteration of the popular cooking competition turns its taste buds to Texan enchiladas, Puerto Rican mofongo, California fish tacos and more, as 14 amateurs from an array of countries compete for a prize of $100,000. Claudia Sandoval, winner of the sixth season of \u201cMasterChef,\u201d serves as one of three judges for the new show.\n\nFAMILY GUY 9 p.m. on Fox. Seth MacFarlane\u2019s iconoclastic and absurdly sturdy cartoon will hit its 300th episode on Sunday. It has recently drawn attention for alluding to misbehavior by high-profile men, from Kevin Spacey to Brett Ratner to Charlie Rose, before formal misconduct accusations were made against them. But in this episode, Stewie and Brian set their cross hairs on each other, after a provocation from Brian turns into an all-out war.\n\nDIVORCE 10 p.m. on HBO. The show\u2019s first season ended on a shocking and sour note, with Robert (Thomas Haden Church) calling the cops on his ex-wife, Frances (Sarah Jessica Parker). \u201c(It can be a caustic pleasure, a chaser, heavy on the bitters, to Carrie\u2019s fruity cosmo,\u201d James Poniewozik wrote in his review in The New York Times, in a reference to \u201cSex and the City.\u201d) But the new showrunner Jenny Bicks has promised that the second season will be lighter, with a focus on the pair\u2019s reconciliation as they navigate their newly single lives. An ensemble cast that includes Molly Shannon and Tracy Letts is also expected to play a larger role.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nSOMEBODY FEED PHIL on Netflix. Sending a funnyman around the world to eat local delights is not exactly a new idea. But derivative or not, this Netflix series is in good hands with its earnest and affable Phil Rosenthal, who created the sitcom \u201cEverybody Loves Raymond.\u201d Mr. Rosenthal eats crab omelet in Bangkok and po\u2019 boys in New Orleans (which The Times named the top place to go in 2018), feeds elephants in Thailand and stops by Saigon, Lisbon, Mexico City and other spots.", "title": "What\u2019s on Sunday: \u2018Victoria\u2019 and \u2018Family Guy\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDavid Letterman\u2019s new talk show comes to Netflix, while new adaptations of Philip K. Dick stories come to Amazon.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nMY NEXT GUEST NEEDS NO INTRODUCTION WITH DAVID LETTERMAN on Netflix. David Letterman\u2019s Santa Claus beard, which he sprouted after leaving \u201cThe Late Show\u201d two years ago, seemed to be a clear symbolic gesture that his days of thoughtful interviews with cultural dignitaries were over. \u201cThe beard is a good reminder to me that that was a different life,\u201d he said in an interview with The New York Times. But after a well-deserved break, Mr. Letterman will return to the screen. And although he\u2019s no longer on network TV, his interviews will still pack a wallop: His first guest is Barack Obama, with later episodes to feature George Clooney and Malala Yousafzai.\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE POLKA KING on Netflix. In the films \u201cNacho Libre\u201d and \u201cWalk Hard,\u201d Jack Black rolled out Mexican and British accents that were so bad they actually became endearing. He tries an exaggerated Polish accent in this movie, in which he stars as the real-life polka star Jan Lewan, who ended up in jail for running a Ponzi scheme (perhaps unknowingly). As with all of his best roles, Mr. Black imbues his character with a mixture of manic glee and tragedy. Jenny Slate plays his wife, while Jason Schwartzman plays his best friend.\n\nPHILIP K. DICK\u2019S ELECTRIC DREAMS on Amazon. The worlds of Philip K. Dick seem to be multiplying. An adaptation of his novel \u201cThe Man in the High Castle\u201d rolls along on Amazon, while the bleak cityscape of \u201cBlade Runner 2049\u201d arrived in theaters in October. Now, more of his hallucinatory and terrifying visions arrive on Amazon, with 10 stand-alone adaptations of his short stories. These episodes explore future scenarios both distant and very close, from parallel universes to global warming; plenty of stars show up, from Bryan Cranston to Steve Buscemi to Janelle Mon\u00e1e. But the critic James Poniewozik of The Times was mostly unmoved: \u201cThis license and talent, plus lavish scale of production, add up to little that feels freshly imagined or newly provocative,\u201d he wrote in his review.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nHELL\u2019S KITCHEN 8 p.m. on Fox. Gordon Ramsay hosts this furiously paced cooking competition. In this episode, contestants must use their senses to re-create a dish, and whip up a meal with mystery ingredients.\n\nPhoto\n\nTONY BENNETT: THE LIBRARY OF CONGRESS GERSHWIN PRIZE FOR POPULAR SONG 9 p.m. on PBS. As music\u2019s attitude and center have frantically shifted from decade to decade, one of the few constants has been Tony Bennett \u2014 since 1950 he has been relentless in his charm, gravitas and commitment to the American Songbook. (He remained steadfast even in an extended collaboration with Lady Gaga.) The Library of Congress honors him in this star-studded event, which includes appearances by Stevie Wonder, Josh Groban, Gloria Estefan, Chris Botti and more.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Friday: David Letterman\u2019s New Show and a Tribute to Tony Bennett", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJane Fonda and Lily Tomlin return for another season of \u201cGrace and Frankie.\u201d And Nicolas Cage goes crazy in \u201cMom and Dad.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nGRACE AND FRANKIE on Netflix. It\u2019s awards season, which means rare onstage appearances from reclusive Hollywood legends. These riveting cameos mostly consist of three lines from a teleprompter and the opening of an envelope. But two of those legends, Lily Tomlin and Jane Fonda, are still working up a storm \u2014 the fourth season of their sitcom \u201cGrace and Frankie\u201d arrives on Friday. The show follows the unlikely friendship that blossoms after the pair\u2019s husbands leave them for each other. This season deals with the aches and pains of aging, as Grace (Fonda) and Frankie (Tomlin) care for the next generation, while their ex-husbands (Martin Sheen and Sam Waterston) try an open marriage. And Lisa Kudrow joins the all-star cast as Grace\u2019s manicurist.\n\nPhoto\n\nMOM AND DAD on iTunes. Nicolas Cage has mesmerized audiences with his unhinged alter egos in plenty of movies, so why not go for it one more time? In \u201cMom and Dad,\u201d he and Selma Blair play a totally normal couple with two children in Middle American suburbia. But their town is soon infected by a virus that compels parents to kill their children. The pair soon wield saws and other sharp objects in a series of manic attempts to off their offspring.\n\nTROLLS: THE BEAT GOES ON on Netflix. The year 2017 brought many surprises, among them the phrase \u201cOscar-nominated movie \u2018Trolls.\u2019\u201d The exuberant animated movie, which brings those colorfully tufted dolls to life, was a huge hit at the box office and earned an Oscar nod for best original song for Justin Timberlake\u2019s \u201cCan\u2019t Stop the Feeling!\u201d Now, the story continues with this Netflix series, created by a mostly different creative team. Amanda Leighton and Skylar Astin take over vocal duties from Anna Kendrick and Mr. Timberlake.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nVICE NEWS TONIGHT 7:30 p.m. on HBO. In August, Vice News provided a detailed and unencumbered look behind the scenes at the white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Va. The program will attempt to pull off a similar feat with a much wider scope on \u201cAmerica First,\u201d which airs Friday as President Trump wraps up his first year in office. The episode sends the correspondents Michael Moynihan and Isobel Yeung across the country to talk to people who voted for Mr. Trump and examine how his campaign promises have manifested.\n\nPhoto\n\nAMERICAN MASTERS \u2014 LORRAINE HANSBERRY: SIGHTED EYES/FEELING HEART 9 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). Ms. Hansberry was just 27 when she wrote \u201cA Raisin in the Sun\u201d \u2014 and just 34 when she died of cancer in 1965. This melancholy documentary delves into her short life, which she devoted to art and activism, with interviews with Sidney Poitier and Ruby Dee (both original Broadway cast members of \u201cRaisin\u201d), Harry Belafonte, and more.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Friday: \u2018Grace and Frankie\u2019 and a Tribute to Lorraine Hansberry", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Watch a broadcast of the Met Opera\u2019s production of \u201cNorma.\u201d And pick from among several train capers.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nGREAT PERFORMANCES AT THE MET: NORMA 9 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). The Met Opera\u2019s current season kicked off in September with Bellini\u2019s 1831 bel canto opera. It\u2019s set deep in the forest and weaves tales of power, betrayal and vengeance; the powerhouse soprano Sondra Radvanovsky takes on the title role, with Joyce DiDonato and Joseph Calleja also performing. \u201cMs. Radvanovsky, with her bright, powerful voice and dramatic fervor, excelled in Norma\u2019s moments of torment and fury,\u201d Anthony Tommasini wrote in his Times review.\n\nJANE THE VIRGIN 9 p.m. on the CW. Jane and Rafael decide to send their son, Mateo, to a new school. Petra finds herself in trouble with no one to turn to for help.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Friday: \u2018Norma\u2019 and \u2018Jane the Virgin\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "A documentary on the folk-rock group the Avett Brothers airs on HBO. And a pair of immigration stories in \u201cBetween 2 Shores.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nMAY IT LAST: A PORTRAIT OF THE AVETT BROTHERS (2017) 8 p.m. on HBO. Eschewing the star-studded route that many rock documentaries take, this film focuses on the familial bond between the brothers and group co-founders Scott and Seth Avett. Shot largely in their native North Carolina and co-directed by Michael Bonfiglio and Judd Apatow, the documentary chronicles the making of the band\u2019s 2016 album \u201cTrue Sadness\u201d while also telling the group\u2019s origin story through interviews with the brothers, band members and others close to them. At the center of the film is a sibling relationship that has proved both enduring and lucrative. \u201cHe\u2019s my older brother, he\u2019s bigger and stronger,\u201d Seth says. \u201cHe knows how to do all these things I don\u2019t know how to do.\u201d When they were kids, the film reveals, that often involved roughhousing. Now they use their hands for songwriting.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Monday: Avett Brothers Documentary and \u2018Between 2 Shores\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDavid Bowie\u2019s final years are explored in a new documentary. And \u201cA Ghost Story\u201d stars a sheet-covered Casey Affleck.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nDAVID BOWIE: THE LAST FIVE YEARS (2017) 8 p.m. on HBO. \u201cThoughts of death hover throughout \u2018Blackstar,\u2019\u201d Jon Pareles wrote in his review in The New York Times of David Bowie\u2019s final album. Less than a week later, Mr. Pareles would write Mr. Bowie\u2019s obituary. The British singer-songwriter died only days after the album\u2019s release in 2016. This documentary is built around interviews with Bowie\u2019s artistic collaborators, including the producer Tony Visconti and the composer Maria Schneider. They helped Bowie create songs that, as Mr. Pareles wrote in the obituary, are \u201cabove all, about being an outsider: an alien, a misfit, a sexual adventurer, a faraway astronaut.\u201d\n\nANTIQUES ROADSHOW 8 p.m. on PBS. This antique-hunting show\u2019s 22nd season kicks off with an episode in Harrisburg, Pa., with rare objects including a Pennsylvania Dutch tinware coffee pot.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nA GHOST STORY (2017) on iTunes and Amazon. Although 2017 was the year of the horror film, there was at least one ghost story that wasn\u2019t scary: this one, directed by David Lowery. It stars Casey Affleck and Rooney Mara, a couple who are separated, in some ways but not others, by the death of Mr. Affleck\u2019s character, who is portrayed post-mortem by Mr. Affleck in a bedsheet with eyeholes. Here, death does not, in fact, do them part.\n\nFRANK (2014) on iTunes, Amazon and Hulu. Fancy another film featuring an A-list actor in an absurd costume? How about Michael Fassbender in a giant papier-m\u00e2ch\u00e9 head? You\u2019ll find that, as well as Domhnall Gleeson as a would-be rocker and Maggie Gyllenhaal as a tantrum-throwing synth player, in this film from the director Lenny Abrahamson. The story follows Mr. Gleeson\u2019s character, who quits his boring day job to join an avant-garde rock band fronted by Mr. Fassbender\u2019s character, who never takes off his big head. The group goes on a long retreat, during which they record an album (or try to). Other members of the band are played by Fran\u00e7ois Civil and the real-life drummer Carla Azar. In his review for The Times, A.O. Scott wrote that \u201cMr. Abrahamson\u2019s main achievement, enabled by the sensitive and resourceful cast, is to find a tone that is funny without flippancy, sincere without turning to mush.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBABEL (2006) on iTunes and Hulu. Alejandro G. I\u00f1\u00e1rritu\u2019s continent-hopping drama juxtaposes four disparate stories set in three continents. There\u2019s Brad Pitt and Cate Blanchett, an American couple on holiday in Morocco; a local family who become both directly connected and very distant from that couple; the couple\u2019s children, who travel with the family\u2019s housekeeper from their native San Diego to a wedding in Mexico; and a deaf teenager in Tokyo, played by Rinko Kikuchi, who deals with both the challenges of adolescence and her mother\u2019s death. The connections found between these stories \u2014 not so much the direct ones, but the more abstract, human ones \u2014 are the focus of the film.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Monday: \u2018David Bowie: The Last Five Years\u2019 and \u2018A Ghost Story\u2019", "authors": ["Gabe Cohn"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cI Am Not Your Negro\u201d is on PBS. And the third season of \u201cDetectorists\u201d streams on Acorn.tv.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nINDEPENDENT LENS 9 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). Raoul Peck\u2019s Oscar-nominated film, \u201cI Am Not Your Negro\u201d (2016), which addresses pervasive racism in America through the words of the writer James Baldwin, will run as part of \u201cIndependent Lens.\u201d Baldwin\u2019s essays are read by a reserved Samuel L. Jackson, and are paired with archival and recent documentary footage, including images of Black Lives Matter demonstrations. Mr. Jackson, as Baldwin, discusses the Southern United States during the civil rights era, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and John Wayne films. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t just make you aware of Baldwin, or hold him up as a figure to be admired from a distance,\u201d A. O. Scott wrote in his review for The New York Times. \u201cYou feel entirely in his presence, hanging on his every word, following the implications of his ideas as they travel from his experience to yours.\u201d\n\nJOS\u00c9 JOS\u00c9, EL PR\u00cdNCIPE DE LA CANCI\u00d3N 8 p.m. on Telemundo. This Spanish-language biographical musical series is about the Mexican singer Jos\u00e9 Jos\u00e9, who became prominent in the 1970s and is known for his love ballads. (His unofficial title, \u201cEl Pr\u00edncipe de la Canci\u00f3n,\u201d translates to \u201cThe Prince of the Song.\u201d) His story includes struggles with addiction, money and, of course, love.\n\nCHAIN OF COMMAND 9 p.m. on National Geographic. Chris Evans narrates this eight-part documentary, which offers an intimate (if tailored) look at the United States military\u2019s efforts to combat extremism. Highlights include an interview with Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., the 19th chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; a fly-on-the-wall look at an American captain working with Iraqi security forces; and a discussion of the tactics used by Islamic State recruiters.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nDETECTORISTS on Acorn.tv. This British series about two metal-detecting enthusiasts made our Best TV Shows of 2016 list. It\u2019s written and directed by Mackenzie Crook (of \u201cPirates of the Caribbean\u201d and the British version of \u201cThe Office\u201d), who stars alongside the actor Toby Jones. The third season continues the show\u2019s quietly hilarious examination of two friends\u2019 lives. The Times critic Mike Hale wrote that it\u2019s \u201cnot for everyone, but bound to be fiercely loved by those who fall into its rhythms.\u201d\n\nTHE MARCH (2013) on Amazon. Denzel Washington narrates this documentary on the 1963 March on Washington, describing the grass-roots efforts required to plan that historic demonstration.\n\nPhoto\n\nEYES ON THE PRIZE on Amazon. This documentary series, narrated by the equal-rights champion Julian Bond, begins in the mid-1950s and provides a powerful chronological overview of that era\u2019s struggle for civil rights. \u201cCivil rights is not an issue that lends itself to even-handedness,\u201d Walter Goodman wrote in his review for The Times. \u201cThe battle shown here is between oppressors and oppressed, between brute force and steadfast endurance, until the legal, physical and moral weight of the Federal Government brings victory.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Monday: \u2018I Am Not Your Negro\u2019 and \u2018Detectorists\u2019", "authors": ["Gabe Cohn"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cThe Alienist\u201d has its premiere on TNT. And Steven Soderbergh\u2019s mini-series, previously released as a smartphone app, shows in a more traditional form on HBO.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nTHE ALIENIST 9 p.m. on TNT. The most expensive show produced by TNT is based on Caleb Carr\u2019s best-selling 1994 historical thriller about a psychiatrist (or alienist, as they were once called) in Gilded Age New York who tries to catch a serial killer. His team\u2019s method? Piecing together a picture of the killer\u2019s mental traits in attempt to get inside his head. Daniel Br\u00fchl plays the title character; the cast includes Dakota Fanning as a headstrong secretary and Luke Evans as an illustrator. Their performances are bolstered by meticulously designed period sets and costumes, which help maintain the novel\u2019s rich historical specificity. \u201cEvery detail matters,\u201d Jakob Verbruggen, a director and executive producer of the series, recently told The New York Times. \u201cWe could only sell this world if we made it 100 percent believable.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMOSAIC 8 p.m. on HBO. At the end of last year, the director Steven Soderbergh released a mini-series as a smartphone app that let users choose their own path through a series of videos. The story followed the disappearance of a famous children\u2019s author (played by Sharon Stone) whose lover (Frederick Weller) is convicted, perhaps wrongfully, of murdering her. Now, both those who gave the app a spin (The Times\u2019s James Poniewozik found it \u201cfascinating, if not ultimately successful\u201d) and those who are coming to the story fresh can experience it as a more traditional six-part HBO series.\n\nTWO SIDES 10 p.m. on TV One. This four-part series, narrated by Viola Davis, examines the cases of Eric Garner, Ezell Ford, John Crawford III and Sandra Bland, all African-Americans whose deaths during confrontations with police officers or while in police custody added fuel to the national conversation about law enforcement bias and the use of force. The first episode focuses on Mr. Garner, whose death at age 43 in 2014 sparked a wave of protests.\n\nPhoto\n\nINDEPENDENT LENS: THE FORCE 9 p.m. For Peter Nicks\u2019s 2017 documentary, \u201cThe Force,\u201d he embedded himself in the Oakland Police Department in California, chronicling, The Times\u2019s Manohla Dargis wrote, a \u201ctroubled department struggling \u2014 and failing and struggling \u2014 to right its wrongs.\u201d Mr. Nicks acts as a fly-on-the-wall observer, and the film strives for evenhandedness. \u201cThe movie may offer an incriminatory catalog of organizational failure,\u201d Ms. Dargis wrote. \u201cBut it also repeatedly shows people trying to make the system work.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nTHE FATE OF THE FURIOUS on HBO streaming platforms. Tires squeal, custom cars flip and Vin Diesel\u2019s arms spin steering wheels in this eighth film in the \u201cFast and Furious\u201d series. \u201cPunctuated by crashes and drums of doom, the movie moves to a dependable blockbuster beat,\u201d Ms. Dargis wrote, \u201cas a little exposition is followed by an action scene, and more exposition is followed by a bigger, noisier, nuttier action scene.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Monday: \u2018The Alienist\u2019 and \u2018Mosaic\u2019", "authors": ["Gabe Cohn"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "The Independent Lens series features a portrait of the writer behind \u201cTales of the City.\u201d And \u201cLovesick\u201d returns to Netflix.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nTHE UNTOLD TALES OF ARMISTEAD MAUPIN (2017) 10:30 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). The writer Armistead Maupin came out as gay in 1977, the year after he began writing his seminal newspaper serial \u201cTales of the City,\u201d a daring account of love, sex and L.G.B.T.Q. culture in San Francisco. In this documentary, Mr. Maupin explains, \u201cI knew that I had landed on something that was going to make me famous because I had this subject matter that wasn\u2019t being covered.\u201d His hunch was right: \u201cTales\u201d has been morphed into a nine-part novel series, an Emmy-nominated television mini-series and a musical. The documentarian Jennifer M. Kroot traces Mr. Maupin\u2019s conservative upbringing, naval service and journalism career to his later success spurred by his groundbreaking stories. The biopic is available to stream on pbs.org on Tuesday.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Monday: \u2018The Untold Tales of Armistead Maupin\u2019 and \u2018Lovesick\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSam Rockwell, the \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d actor, hosts \u201cS.N.L.\u201d And a documentary about a lesser-known James Bond actor, George Lazenby, streams on Hulu.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nSATURDAY NIGHT LIVE 11:30 p.m. on NBC. \u201cS.N.L.\u201d returns from its holiday hiatus with an episode hosted by the actor Sam Rockwell, who\u2019s fresh off his first Golden Globe win for his performance in \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d (a victory that has fueled a debate over the script\u2019s racial politics). The musical guest is the pop singer-songwriter Halsey.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nBECOMING BOND (2017) on Hulu. The fanfare that surrounded the announcement of the current James Bond (Daniel Craig arrived to the announcement by boat) and the level of speculation over who his successor might be make it even more unbelievable that, in the late \u201960s, the actor who replaced Sean Connery in the role of the suave British spy was an Australian mechanic and model who had never acted in a single film. This documentary recounts that story from the source: George Lazenby. Speaking between wry smiles, Mr. Lazenby proudly recounts his life story, and how he ended up playing Bond in \u201cOn Her Majesty\u2019s Secret Service\u201d (1969). His words are accompanied by over-the-top comic re-enactments by a cast that includes Jeff Garlin, Dana Carvey and Jane Seymour, who played a bona fide \u201cBond girl\u201d in \u201cLive and Let Die\u201d (1973).\n\nTHE MAZE RUNNER (2014) on iTunes and Amazon. The third film in this dystopian sci-fi trilogy hits theaters this month. In his review for The New York Times, Ben Kenigsberg wrote that this first installment \u201ccombines elements of \u2018Lord of the Flies\u2019 with the Minotaur and Orpheus myths, but it plays as something closer to \u2018The Hunger Games\u2019 experienced through a dissociative fog.\u201d\n\n\n\nFARGO (1996) on iTunes and Amazon. Frances McDormand\u2019s win at the Golden Globes makes this a perfect time to revisit her Oscar-winning performance as a sometimes-fierce and sometimes-chipper pregnant cop in this Coen brothers film, where a car salesman played by William H. Macy hires a pair of criminals (Steve Buscemi and Peter Sormare) to kidnap his wife so he can collect ransom from his father-in-law. The recent television series of the same name, based on the film, is streaming on Hulu.\n\nPhoto\n\nAFERIM! (2016) on Sundance Now. The Times\u2019s A.O. Scott called this black-and-white western a \u201cfunny and brutal costume drama with a potent contemporary kick.\u201d Directed by Radu Jude, the story follows a constable (Teodor Corban) and his deputy and son (the same person, played by Mihai Comanoiu) in 19th-century Walachia, an area that\u2019s now part of Romania, as they travel on horseback through the countryside in search of a fugitive. The film was controversial in its home country for its frank portrayal of the enslavement of the Roma people, a practice which lasted nearly 500 years before being abolished in 1856, and which remains a sensitive subject. Speaking with The Times in 2015, Mr. Jude said that he \u201cwanted to look at how the repercussions of the past come into the present.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Saturday: Sam Rockwell Hosts \u2018S.N.L.,\u2019 and George Lazenby Becomes Bond", "authors": ["Gabe Cohn"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSir David Attenborough returns to host \u201cBlue Planet II,\u201d and average citizens are thrust into an international incident in \u201cFalse Flag.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nPLANET EARTH: BLUE PLANET II 9 p.m. on BBC America. \u201cNever has there been a more crucial time to reveal what is going on beneath the surface of the seas,\u201d Sir David Attenborough says in the introduction of this sequel to the blockbuster nature series \u201cThe Blue Planet.\u201d It arms itself with a more direct appeal for conservation than its predecessor did, but it\u2019s still mostly observational \u2014 and what a spectacle to observe! Dolphins, giant turtles and coral reefs are all captured in impossibly clear shots. Despite the high production values, there\u2019s a sense of primal delight, evident in an early scene featuring a pod of dolphins as they ride the waves in the Red Sea. \u201cThey surf,\u201d says Mr. Attenborough, \u201cAnd, as far as we can tell, they do so for the sheer joy of it.\u201d\n\nSATURDAY NIGHT LIVE 11:30 p.m. on NBC. Jessica Chastain, who recently starred in \u201cMolly\u2019s Game,\u201d will host \u201cS.N.L.\u201d for the first time. The Australian singer-songwriter Troye Sivan (whom The New York Times\u2019s Jon Caramanica called \u201can easeful polymath who manages to make big moments feel intimate\u201d) is the musical guest.\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE SOCIAL NETWORK (2010) 11 p.m. on TNT. The fable of a Harvard underclassman taking some equations written on his dorm window, drinking a few beers and spawning a world-altering social network is by now a well-known origin tale. And the Winklevoss twins, whose lawsuit against the Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg over the creation of the social media platform helps provide the narrative backbone of this film, have moved on to Bitcoin trading. But given that the scope of Facebook\u2019s influence is the topic of more discussion than ever, it\u2019s a particularly interesting time to revisit this fictionalized version of the social network\u2019s story, directed by David Fincher. Jesse Eisenberg was nominated for an Academy Award for his role as Mr. Zuckerburg, Armie Hammer plays both Winklevoss twins and Andrew Garfield portrays the other Facebook co-founder, Eduardo Saverin. In her review for The Times, Manohla Dargis called the film \u201ca resonant contemporary story about the new power elite and an older, familiar narrative of ambition, except instead of discovering his authentic self, Mark builds a database, turning his life \u2014 and ours \u2014 into zeros and ones, which is what makes it also a story about the human soul.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nFALSE FLAG on Hulu. A preschool teacher, a chemist and a bride walk into a motel room and kidnap an Iranian government minister. Or do they? This Israeli series is loosely based on the 2010 assassination of Mahmoud al-Mabhouh, a Hamas official who was murdered by a team of killers who used fake passports. It follows five people whose identities were on the passports connected to an international incident, and who then get thrust into it. In his review for The Times, Mike Hale wrote that it\u2019s \u201cthe kind of solid psychological action thriller that Israeli TV regularly provides.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Saturday: \u2018Blue Planet II\u2019 and \u2018False Flag\u2019", "authors": ["Gabe Cohn"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA new Netflix comedy focuses on dancing sororities. And an HBO documentary tells a touching story on Holocaust Remembrance Day.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nSTEP SISTERS (2017) on Netflix. \u201cPerfection over excellence, sister over self\u201d is the motto of the predominantly African-American sorority that Jamilah (Megalyn Echikunwoke) \u2014 a Type A, driven college senior \u2014 belongs to. Every year, they compete in a stepping competition. (Stepping, a form of percussive dancing, has its American roots in historically black sororities and fraternities.) When Jamilah is asked to teach a mostly white sorority how to step, she worries that her \u201cblack card would get revoked\u201d if she were to agree. But the person asking is the dean (Robert Curtis Brown), who can help her get into Harvard Law School, so she has to say yes. That\u2019s the premise of this Netflix comedy, directed by Charles Stone III, that raises questions about cultural appropriation and stereotyping even as it progresses with the playful feel of a jokey teen drama. Most laughs come from cultural collisions, but in the final, inevitable competition between the two sororities, the rival groups avoid a head-on crash. What they find instead is mutual understanding.\n\nPhoto\n\nUNREST (2017) on iTunes, Amazon and Netflix. This documentary from Jennifer Brea is about chronic fatigue syndrome, a condition that hasn\u2019t been fully accepted by the medical world but that affects millions of people. The symptoms \u2014 which can include loss of energy and muscle control, an inability to speak and intense pain \u2014 are on harrowing display as Ms. Brea, who suffers from the condition, shows how it has affected her life. She also interviews others coping with the illness. In his review for The New York Times, Daniel M. Gold wrote that the film \u201cpowerfully insists on giving a voice to victims whose greatest challenge, apart from their symptoms, is surmounting a world of indifference.\u201d\n\nINDECENT on Broadway HD. Paul Vogel\u2019s play explores the controversy that surrounded the early-20th-century Yiddish drama \u201cGod of Vengeance.\u201d Ms. Vogel\u2019s play closed last August (after an out-of-the-ordinary extension of its closing date), but a film of the production is now streaming on Broadway HD. The Times\u2019s Ben Brantley called the show \u201cvirtuous, sturdily assembled, informative and brimming with good faith.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE NUMBER ON GREAT-GRANDPA\u2019S ARM 6 p.m. on HBO. Celebrating Holocaust Remembrance Day, this short documentary, presented by HBO with the Museum of Jewish Heritage, captures a conversation between a boy and his great-grandfather, a Polish Holocaust survivor who was imprisoned at Auschwitz.\n\nELTON JOHN: THE NATION\u2019S FAVORITE SONG 8 p.m. on Reelz. This documentary about the voice behind \u201cYour Song\u201d and \u201cTiny Dancer\u201d features interviews with big names like Rod Stewart, Ed Sheeran and Lulu. Mr. John himself is also interviewed by the British comedian David Williams.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Saturday: \u2018Step Sisters\u2019 and \u2018The Number on Great-Grandpa\u2019s Arm\u2019", "authors": ["Gabe Cohn"]} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "High-strung emus are among a vet\u2019s patients in \u201cThe Incredible Dr. Pol.\u201d And \u201cSay Yes to the Dress\u201d returns for its 16th season.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nTHE INCREDIBLE DR. POL 9 p.m. on Nat Geo Wild. Don\u2019t expect your usual cats and dogs; this reality show follows a veterinary clinic in rural Michigan whose patients often include livestock. This premiere of the 12th season includes a horse with teeth troubles, chickens whose clucks have turned to gurgles and some high-strung emus.\n\nEVERYTHING, EVERYTHING (2017) 8 p.m. on HBO. Stella Meghie\u2019s adaptation of Nicola Yoon\u2019s young-adult novel stars Amandla Stenberg as a girl with an immune system disorder that prevents her from leaving her house. She finds a boy outside the bubble, and they strike up an unlikely relationship. The film \u201cscores a direct hit on the teenage-girl market,\u201d Neil Genzlinger wrote in his review for The New York Times. \u201cOthers might find it pretty enjoyable as well.\u201d\n\nSAY YES TO THE DRESS 8 p.m. on TLC. After 15 seasons, there\u2019s still something endearing about the format of this wedding reality show, in which brides try on dresses in search of the perfect match. You might find yourself with a renewed appreciation for wedding dresses, and how they can reflect the people inside of them.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Saturday: \u2018The Incredible Dr. Pol\u2019 and \u2018Everything, Everything\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Seth Meyers hosts the Golden Globe Awards. And \u201cThe Chi\u201d premieres on Showtime.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nTHE 75TH GOLDEN GLOBE AWARDS 8 p.m. on NBC. The Golden Globes are usually a breezy, joyous affair, but the tone this year is likely to be much more solemn, as sexual harassment scandals hover. Many stars will wear black on the red carpet in solidarity, and the host, Seth Meyers, said he will attempt to find a balance between humor and gravity in his monologue. \u201cIt\u2019s safe to say Hollywood has been tipped on its side,\u201d Mr. Meyers said in an interview with The New York Times. \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d and \u201cThe Post\u201d lead the movie nominations, while \u201cBig Little Lies\u201d (see below) leads the television pack.\n\nNFL PLAYOFFS: WILD CARD ROUND The often-hapless Buffalo Bills return to the playoffs for the first time in 18 years to take on the Jacksonville Jaguars at 1:05 p.m. Then, at the Superdome, Cam Newton and the Carolina Panthers face the New Orleans Saints, who have beaten them twice this year, at 4:40 p.m.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Sunday: The Golden Globes and \u2018The Chi\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBruno Mars and Jay-Z compete for top honors at the 60th annual Grammys. And a documentary explores the infamous religious cult leader David Koresh.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\n60TH ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS 7:30 p.m. on CBS. Can Jay-Z win the award that his spouse, Beyonc\u00e9, failed to capture last year? He\u2019s up for album of the year for the introspective \u201c4:44,\u201d which serves as a companion piece and apologetic response to her explosive \u201cLemonade,\u201d which lost to Adele\u2019s \u201c25\u201d at last year\u2019s ceremonies. But he\u2019ll have to defeat Kendrick Lamar, Bruno Mars and Childish Gambino \u2014 all performing this year \u2014 as well as Lorde. Performers also include Elton John \u2014 who recently announced a retirement tour \u2014 Lady Gaga, Rihanna and U2. There will be tributes to Chuck Berry, Tom Petty and Fats Domino.\n\nN.H.L. ALL-STAR GAME 3:30 p.m. on NBC. Alex Ovechkin and Sidney Crosby are longtime rivals, having clashed in the playoffs countless times over the years. But they\u2019ll suit up next to each other in the All-Star Game, which is played out in a fast-paced 3-on-3 tournament. The winning team takes home $1 million in prize money. And the N.F.L. PRO BOWL airs at 3 on ESPN.\n\nPhoto\n\nBRAVEHEART 4 and 8 p.m. on BBC America. Mel Gibson\u2019s exhaustive, exhausting depiction of the First War of Scottish Independence won five Oscars in 1996, including best picture. He stars as William Wallace, a kilted warrior who rallies his countrymen against British rule through rousing speeches and rugged swordplay. \u201c\u2018Braveheart\u2019 evokes old-fashioned movie epics,\u201d Caryn James wrote in The New York Times. \u201cMr. Gibson\u2019s stroke of brilliance is to revel in those epic qualities \u2014 tragic romance and unbounded heroism, gorgeous photography and a cast of thousands \u2014 and add a swift contemporary kick.\u201d\n\nWACO: MADMAN OR MESSIAH 9 p.m. on A&E. The last few years have brought many \u201990s antagonists back to the forefront of pop culture, from O .J. Simpson to Tonya Harding. The lightning rod of the moment is David Koresh, the religious cult leader who died in 1993 along with many of his Branch Davidian followers after a prolonged confrontation with the F.B.I. Those events are being dramatized on Paramount\u2019s \u201cWaco,\u201d starring Taylor Kitsch. A&E takes a different approach on Sunday, with a documentary special that includes footage of Mr. Koresh during the 51-day standoff. Nine surviving members of the sect are interviewed, as well as members of the F.B.I. who were involved in the siege.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nSTRONG ISLAND on Netflix. In 1991, an unarmed, black 24-year-old teacher named William Ford Jr. was shot and killed on Long Island. The fallout from his death and the circumstances surrounding it are explored in this film, which was directed by his brother Yance and nominated for best feature documentary at the Oscars.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Sunday: The Grammys and the N.H.L. All-Star Game", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "N.F.L. PLAYOFFS All four remaining teams with a shot at the Lombardi Trophy go to battle on Sunday. In order to repeat last year\u2019s victory, Tom Brady and the New England Patriots will have to go through the Jacksonville Jaguars (3:05 p.m. on CBS), who along with their erratic quarterback Blake Bortles just scored 45 points against the Pittsburgh Steelers. The Minnesota Vikings, who are here thanks to Stefon Diggs\u2019s game-ending touchdown catch last week, hope to advance to a hometown Super Bowl in Minneapolis; they will face off against the Philadelphia Eagles (6:40 p.m. on Fox), who have already exceeded expectations after their starting quarterback Carson Wentz suffered a season-ending injury.\n\nTHE 24TH ANNUAL SCREEN ACTORS GUILD AWARDS 8 p.m. on TNT and TBS. Last year\u2019s SAG Awards, which took place two days after President Trump\u2019s travel ban, became an impromptu call to arms and show of solidarity for marginalized communities. This year, as the organizers and participants fix their gaze on the #MeToo and Time\u2019s Up movements, Kristen Bell will serve as the award show\u2019s first host, male or female, and all the presenters will be women. The television shows \u201cStranger Things\u201d and \u201cBig Little Lies\u201d will likely take victory laps with four nominations apiece, while \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d is up for four awards as well.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Sunday: \u2018Counterpart\u2019 and \u2018The Resident\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOlivia Munn hosts the Critics\u2019 Choice Awards. And watch a news special on Tonya Harding.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nTHE 23RD CRITICS\u2019 CHOICE AWARDS 8 p.m. on the CW. In his Golden Globes monologue, Seth Meyers joked that future awards show hosts were watching him \u201clike the first dog they shot into outer space.\u201d Well, next up is Olivia Munn, who will host this show, in which the best of television and movies are determined by a panel of critics. \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d leads with 14 nominations, including best picture, while \u201cFeud: Bette & Joan\u201d received six on the TV side. And Gal Gadot will be honored with a #SeeHer Award recognizing women who push boundaries.\n\nTRUTH AND LIES: THE TONYA HARDING STORY 9 p.m. on ABC. Two years ago, \u201cThe People v. O. J. Simpson\u201d forged a path for the Marcia Clark Redemption Story, as the actress Sarah Paulson brought the real-life Ms. Clark around the awards circuit. The next divisive \u201990s figure to have her legacy rehabilitated is Tonya Harding, who was depicted by Margot Robbie in \u201cI, Tonya.\u201d (Don\u2019t you dare compare her to Monica Lewinsky, though.) She was acknowledged by Allison Janney onstage at the Golden Globes, and now is the subject of this investigative special. With current interviews and archival footage, \u201cTruth and Lies\u201d wades into Ms. Harding\u2019s traumatic childhood and tries to uncover how much she knew about the attack on her rival Nancy Kerrigan.\n\nPhoto\n\nS.W.A.T. 10 p.m. on CBS. This Shemar Moore-led drama has performed decently enough in the ratings to be picked up for a full 22-episode season. Mr. Moore plays Daniel Harrelson, a Los Angeles police sergeant who was raised in the area; in Thursday\u2019s episode, his team tries to rescue civilian hostages during a prison riot. But he suspects an ulterior motive behind the uprising.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nCONTACT on Walter Presents. In \u201cThe Mentalist\u201d and \u201cPsych,\u201d detectives pass off observational skills as superpowers as they solve crimes. The central detective in \u201cContact,\u201d however, actually possesses a supernatural ability: He can read the secrets and memories others have left behind on objects. Thomas Jouannet stars in this French-language series, which moves from New York to France after the protagonist discovers that someone plans to kill his brother.\n\nPhoto\n\nMARIE ANTOINETTE (2006) on Netflix. Few movies have more entrancing and decadent costume work than \u201cMarie Antoinette,\u201d which captures 18th-century Versailles in all of its gaudy splendor, and won the Academy Award for costume design. But the movie, directed by Sofia Coppola, is more than a parade of frills; it\u2019s a humanizing character portrait (Kirsten Dunst plays the title role) and a critique of social norms and rituals. In his review in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called it \u201ca thoroughly modern confection, blending insouciance and sophistication, heartfelt longing and self-conscious posing with the guileless self-assurance of a great pop song.\u201d The anachronistic soundtrack is driven by new-wave anthems; Jason Schwartzman plays the lonely and overwhelmed Louis XVI.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Thursday: The Critics\u2019 Choice Awards and \u2018S.W.A.T.\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cPortlandia\u201d returns for its eighth and final season. And the new Paramount Network offers a lip-sync tribute to Michael Jackson.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nPORTLANDIA 10 p.m. on IFC. Fred Armisen and Carrie Brownstein\u2019s absurdist tribute to America\u2019s hippest city \u2014 with its cat bands, artisanal knots and Eddie Vedder tattoos \u2014 will wrap up after eight seasons. The pair have displayed a delightfully offbeat chemistry and improvisational fearlessness, whether they\u2019re playing versions of themselves, militantly feminist bookstore owners, or the gender-bent couple Nina and Lance. And their real-world creative networks (Mr. Armisen is an \u201cS.N.L.\u201d alum, while Ms. Brownstein fronts the indie-rock band Sleater-Kinney) constantly stock the show with cameo talent, from Jeff Goldblum to Joanna Newsom to Kumail Nanjiani. The upcoming season includes riffs on escape rooms and intrusive NPR podcasting.\n\nPhoto\n\nDJANGO UNCHAINED (2012) 5:50 p.m. on BET. You wouldn\u2019t be at fault if you flew into a silent rage upon seeing the face of Christoph Waltz after \u201cInglourious Basterds\u201d: In that 2009 Quentin Tarantino movie, he played one of the most terrifying and cruel villains of the last decade. But he flips 180 degrees in Mr. Tarantino\u2019s follow-up, \u201cDjango Unchained,\u201d as a charming bounty hunter railing against slavery. He mentors the title character (Jamie Foxx) and eventually works to save Django\u2019s wife from the clutches of Calvin Candie (Leonardo DiCaprio), a cunning and sadistic villain not unlike Mr. Waltz\u2019s previous character. This being a Tarantino flick, there\u2019s a gruesome surplus of bloodshed and brash stylistic shifts. \u201cIt is digressive, jokey, giddily brutal and ferociously profane. But it is also a troubling and important movie about slavery and racism,\u201d A. O. Scott wrote in his Times review.\n\nLIP SYNC BATTLE LIVE 9 p.m. on Paramount Network. Michael Jackson gave maybe the most famous lip-sync performance ever \u2014 when he moonwalked across the stage to \u201cBillie Jean\u201d in 1983 \u2014 so it makes sense that this show would pay tribute to him with a full hour special. LL Cool J and Chrissy Teigen host this irresistibly silly series, while Taraji P. Henson, Hailee Steinfeld and Neil Patrick Harris are among the pantomimers for this episode. You can bet that there will be plenty of fedoras, sequined gloves, red leather jackets and zombie makeup to go around. (And if you don\u2019t recognize the network name, it\u2019s the new moniker of Spike TV.)\n\nGREY\u2019S ANATOMY 8 p.m. on ABC. The medical drama resumes after a cliffhanger that saw the return of a malicious, estranged character. The hospital works with the F.B.I. after a hacker compromises the computer system.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nJORDSKOTT on Shudder. A policewoman named Eva (Moa Gammel) returns to her Swedish hometown carrying the weight of a torturous family history: Her daughter disappeared, and then her father committed suicide. But things are about to get much worse. The second season of this drama, which is a ratings powerhouse in Sweden, streams on Shudder on Thursday; it mixes supernatural elements with Swedish folklore and ecological themes.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Thursday: \u2018Portlandia\u2019 and \u2018Grey\u2019s Anatomy\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWatch past performances from this year\u2019s Oscar-nominated actors. And \u201cRuPaul\u2019s Drag Race All Stars\u201d returns.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nBYZANTIUM (2012) on Netflix. Saoirse Ronan will contend for an Oscar in March thanks to her delicate but fiery performance as a Sacramento teenager in \u201cLady Bird.\u201d She played another teenager, albeit an eternal one, in the vampire flick \u201cByzantium,\u201d which is inspired by Caribbean folklore and takes place across centuries. Ms. Ronan stars alongside Gemma Arterton as a deathly mother-and-daughter duo who hunt by day and hide out from other vampires in a rundown hotel. Manohla Dargis named it a Times Critic\u2019s Pick.\n\nPhoto\n\nBURN AFTER READING (2008) on Netflix. Frances McDormand and Richard Jenkins both stole scenes on the big screen last year, but in very different ways: Ms. McDormand was the engine behind the caustic drive of \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri,\u201d while Mr. Jenkins lent heartbreak and empathy to the prickly \u201cThe Shape of Water.\u201d They\u2019re both nominated for 2018 Oscars (his second nomination, her fifth), and they\u2019re paired in the Coen brothers\u2019 \u201cBurn After Reading,\u201d which mixes loopy humor with gratuitous violence. She plays a ditsy gym employee who gets in way over her head in an international espionage plot; he plays her kindly manager, who yearns for her affection and tries to help her.\n\nEYEWITNESS (1981) on Netflix. In November, nobody expected Christopher Plummer to be in the Oscar race for \u201cAll the Money in the World\u201d \u2014 because he wasn\u2019t yet in the movie. His frantic nine-day gig landed him a nomination, making him the oldest acting nominee in Oscar history. Revisit another one of his acclaimed roles from 37 years ago, in which he plays an Israeli intelligence agent working to smuggle Jews out of the Soviet Union.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nPhoto\n\nRUPAUL\u2019S DRAG RACE ALL STARS 8 p.m. on VH1. This campy and exuberant competition show is back for its third season, with contestants returning from across the nine seasons of \u201cRuPaul\u2019s Drag Race.\u201d \u201cIt makes me laugh, it makes me cry,\u201d said Marc Jacobs, who will be a guest judge this season along with Todrick Hall and Vanessa Williams. Contestants sing, dance, make their own dresses, roast one another and even spoof \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale.\u201d\n\n\n\nTHE GOOD PLACE 8:30 p.m. on NBC. Ted Danson sure seems to be having a blast on \u201cThe Good Place\u201d: He swings wildly from depraved mastermind to dunce to contemplative egghead with nuance and panache. It\u2019s unsurprising, then, how many stories have come from his castmates about his gleeful onset antics, from snorting Swedish Fish out of his nose to pretend farting. \u201cHe\u2019s just joy personified,\u201d said the castmate Kristen Bell. In the second season\u2019s penultimate episode, Mr. Danson\u2019s character must deal with the consequences of his recent actions as the rest of the gang tries to escape to the Good Place.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Thursday: \u2018RuPaul\u2019s Drag Race All Stars\u2019 and \u2018The Good Place\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nZach Galifianakis reprises his role as twin brothers in FX\u2019s \u201cBaskets.\u201d And the fifth season of Comedy Central\u2019s \u201cDrunk History\u201d shakily mythologizes Rose Valland and Clara Barton.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nBASKETS 10 p.m. on FX. The comedian Zach Galifianakis returns to his dual roles as Chip Baskets, a rodeo clown with lofty dreams and powerful-yet-unspecific artistic ambitions, and Chip\u2019s rival twin brother, Dale, in this straight-faced comedy series set in Bakersfield, Calif. In addition to Mr. Galifianakis, the show\u2019s cast includes the comics Louie Anderson (who, in drag, plays the Baskets\u2019 mother, a role for which he won an Emmy) and Martha Kelly, whose character is an insurance claims adjuster with a deadpan sense of humor.\n\nPhoto\n\nDRUNK HISTORY 10 p.m. on Comedy Central. For those who don\u2019t get their fill of intoxicated raconteurs on weekend nights, Derek Waters\u2019s series takes a cast of all-stars, feeds them alcohol, and has them do their best to provide detailed commentary about moments in history. Their slurred stories are paired with low-budget historical re-enactments. The storytellers in this first episode of the series\u2019 fifth season include the comedian Tiffany Haddish, who describes the art historian Rose Valland saving artworks from the Nazis; the actress Paget Brewster, who gives a biography of Deborah Sampson (played by Evan Rachel Wood), the Massachusetts woman who disguised herself as a man to serve in the Revolutionary War; and the comedian Amber Ruffin, who sketches the history of the American Red Cross founder Clara Barton (Mandy Moore).\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nINGRID GOES WEST (2017) on Hulu. Matt Spicer\u2019s debut feature is a sendup of social media culture. Aubrey Plaza stars as Ingrid, a smartphone-addicted young woman whose obsession with digital timelines and appearances amplifies her envious personality. After Ingrid moves to the West Coast (and kidnaps a social media influencer\u2019s dog in order to meet her), it becomes clear that Ingrid curates her life with the same destructive care that many spend on their Instagram profiles \u2014 though, at least for her, the separation between profile and person is slim. \u201cMs. Plaza is a whiz with timing and does a deft job of shifting viewers\u2019 sympathy,\u201d Ben Kenigsberg wrote in his review for The New York Times. \u201cStill, Mr. Spicer cops out by going with the obvious ending.\u201d\n\nZODIAC (2007) on Amazon and Hulu. For a different kind of ruthless obsession, see David Fincher\u2019s thriller about a team of San Francisco journalists who hunted the infamous California serial murderer known as the Zodiac killer. The team, played by Jake Gyllenhaal, Robert Downey Jr. and Mark Ruffalo, is led primarily by Mr. Gyllenhaal, who portrays a cartoonist who becomes immersed in the investigation. In her review for The Times, Manohla Dargis wrote that those actors are \u201call at the top of their performance game,\u201d and that the story\u2019s structure, which includes flashbacks and other narrative flourishes, is \u201cas intricate as the storytelling is seamless.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Tuesday: \u2018Baskets\u2019 and \u2018Drunk History\u2019", "authors": ["Gabe Cohn"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe \u201cMudbound\u201d actor Jason Mitchell appears on \u201cDesus & Mero.\u201d And \u201cTake My Nose \u2026 Please!\u201d offers a fresh take on plastic surgery.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nDESUS & MERO 11 p.m. on Viceland. The actor Jason Mitchell will be a guest on this freewheeling late-night show. His recent projects include \u201cMudbound,\u201d \u201cPhilip K. Dick\u2019s Electric Dreams\u201d and \u201cThe Chi.\u201d Expect something looser than the traditional interview; this show was one of Viceland\u2019s early forays into late-night (it\u2019s since added more, including \u201cThe Untitled Action Bronson Show\u201d) and is an example of the casual structure that the network\u2019s fare tends to offer. \u201cLate night as a structure of programming does not matter,\u201d Mero told The New York Times in 2016. \u201cIt shouldn\u2019t feel like \u2018Yo, here\u2019s the news.\u2019 It should feel like you\u2019re looking on the internet with your friends. \u2018Yo, you saw this video? That\u2019s wild!\u2019\u201d\n\nMAJOR CRIMES 9 p.m. on TNT. A major twist related to the main character (played by Mary McDonnell) of this crime series has had reverberating consequences. Since its 2012 premiere, this spinoff of \u201cThe Closer\u201d has followed a fictional unit of the Los Angeles Police Department that investigates, yes, major crimes. This episode will wrap up the series\u2019 sixth and final season.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nTAKE MY NOSE \u2026 PLEASE! on iTunes and Amazon. As an editor at Allure, the journalist Joan Kron (also a former reporter for New York magazine, The Wall Street Journal and The Times) spent years covering the business and culture of the plastic surgery industry. This documentary, her first, looks at that industry by way of an unexpected source: comedians. Directed by Ms. Kron, the film centers primarily around a conversation between the improv performer Emily Askin and the actress and comedian Jackie Hoffman. Interspersed throughout the film is commentary and stand-up material from other comedians, including Margaret Cho, Phyllis Diller, Lisa Lampanelli, Judy Gold and Joan Rivers. Speaking with The Times about plastic surgery in a 2012 article, Ms. Kron said, \u201cI never want to be seen as an advocate for or against it.\u201d Her film explores its topic with an open \u2014 and comedic \u2014 mind.\n\nFOOD FORECAST WITH GINGER ZEE on ABCNews.com and ABC streaming platforms. This food-focused digital series from ABC News is hosted by the meteorologist Ginger Zee. In each episode, Ms. Zee explores a different food, speaking to farmers and researchers about the science behind the foods we eat and the ways in which climate and environmental changes might affect them. The second season includes episodes on truffles, olive oil and oranges.\n\nPhoto\n\nMARVEL\u2019S RUNAWAYS on Hulu. The Times critic Mike Hale had a mixed response to this Hulu show, based on a comic book series of the same name in which a group of teenage superheroes come of age. In this final episode of the first season, the teenagers battle their parents \u2014 though not in the traditional way. (Small spoiler: the parents are supervillains.)", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Tuesday: \u2018Desus & Mero\u2019 and \u2018Take My Nose \u2026 Please!\u2019", "authors": ["Gabe Cohn"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "What\u2019s on TV\n\nBLACK LIGHTNING 9 p.m. on CW. While its premise of a reluctant hero being ripped out of retirement might be familiar, this new series, based on the DC Comics offering, has plenty new to say. When it opens, its central vigilante, Jefferson Pierce (Cress Williams), a middle-aged African-American man, has retired from his crime-fighting past and taken up a different kind of community service: working as a high school principal. But duty calls, and Black Lightning has to put on his hero cape once again, carrying with him electrically charged superpowers that energize this show, particularly for those viewers whose own identities have been traditionally underrepresented onscreen. \u201cIt just got boring, reading about all these really powerful and heroic white guys,\u201d the showrunner Salim Akil told The Times. \u201cI never saw a true representation \u2014 an iconic hero \u2014 for myself.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Tuesday: \u2018Katt Williams: Great America\u2019 and \u2018Black Lightning\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cTesla\u2019s Death Ray\u201d investigates an ominous 20th-century invention. And \u201cThey Shall Not Perish\u201d focuses on the humanitarian efforts after the Armenian Genocide.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nTESLA\u2019S DEATH RAY: A MURDER DECLASSIFIED 10 p.m. on Discovery. No, Elon Musk hasn\u2019t started a new venture \u2014 this Discovery series is about Nikola Tesla, the 20th-century inventor with enduring outcast credibility. The primary concern here is with a weapon that Tesla said he had invented and that, according to a 1934 article in The New York Times, he asserted could \u201ccause armies of millions to drop dead in their tracks.\u201d In this series, the military analyst Jack Murphy and the Tesla historian Cameron Prince look into the shrouded-in-mystery death ray. They question whether the invention could have played a role in Tesla\u2019s mysterious death. Along the way, they work with a team of engineers who, in a somewhat concerning move, attempt to reconstruct the weapon.\n\nI AM JAZZ 10 p.m. on TLC. This reality series stars Jazz Jennings, an outspoken YouTube personality and transgender teenager. The series\u2019 fourth season continues her story, as she navigates high school life and prepares for gender confirmation surgery.\n\nPhoto\n\nHER (2013) 11:30 p.m. on Cinemax. Apple\u2019s Siri was less than three years old when Spike Jonze released this film about an elegiac man (Joaquin Phoenix) who falls in love with his digital assistant (voiced by Scarlett Johansson). Now that we also have Amazon\u2019s Alexa and Microsoft\u2019s Cortana, the movie\u2019s vision of digital love in a Los Angeles from the not-too-distant future feels even less distant. In her review for The Times, Manohla Dargis called the story a \u201cneo-classic boy-meets-operating-system romance,\u201d and said that its central question \u201cisn\u2019t whether machines can think, but whether human beings can still feel.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nTHEY SHALL NOT PERISH: THE STORY OF NEAR EAST RELIEF on Netflix. In the early 20th century, an American charity group was formed to offer humanitarian relief to the victims of the Armenian genocide. One of its purposes was to save a generation of orphans whose families had been killed. This documentary, narrated by the actor Victor Garber, tells the story of the relief efforts.\n\nTHE GODFATHER PARTS I, II & III on Netflix. Francis Ford Coppola\u2019s mobster epic about the transfer and violent shifting of power within the fictional Corleone family likely needs no introduction; in addition to occupying a prominent place in American cinema, these three films are also frequently shown on television. They\u2019re better streaming, without the commercial breaks.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Tuesday: \u2018Tesla\u2019s Death Ray\u2019 and Near East Relief", "authors": ["Gabe Cohn"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "A family finds Alaska to be a fresh source of dysfunction in \u201cThe Detour.\u201d And the actress and activist Rose McGowan is the subject of \u201cCitizen Rose.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nTHE DETOUR 10:30 p.m. on TBS. When audiences were introduced to the Parkers, that family at the center of this TBS comedy was en route to Florida for a vacation. In Season 2, the Parkers moved to New York. Now in Season 3, the four Parkers have become one of TV\u2019s most endearingly dysfunctional families. This season finds them in Alaska, where residents have plenty of guns \u2014 and surprisingly forward-thinking attitudes toward gender and sexuality. Nate (Jason Jones) struggles to accept his new place in the family when Robin (Natalie Zea) becomes the breadwinner by getting a job in a Hooters-like bar. \u201cIt\u2019s not called \u2018The Road Trip,\u2019\u201d Mr. Jones said of the show in an interview with The New York Times last year. \u201cIt\u2019s called \u2018The Detour\u2019 for a reason. It\u2019s a metaphor, if you will.\u201d\n\nCITIZEN ROSE 8 p.m. on E! The actress Rose McGowan\u2019s allegations against Harvey Weinstein helped spark the current national conversation around sexual harassment and abuse in the workplace, and her activism shows no signs of stopping: She is now starring in a documentary series about her work on behalf of women. \u201cCitizen Rose,\u201d produced by the company behind the reality shows \u201cKeeping Up With the Kardashians\u201d and \u201cThe Real World,\u201d gives a behind-the-scenes look at Ms. McGowan\u2019s life. \u201cI wanted really to be like Gertrude Stein and have a conversation with the world,\u201d Ms. McGowan said at a Television Critics Association media event this month. \u201cInstead of in my living room.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Tuesday: \u2018The Detour\u2019 and \u2018Citizen Rose\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA new procedural from Ryan Murphy stars Connie Britton and Angela Bassett. And a young cast member of \u201cblack-ish\u201d gets a spinoff.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\n9-1-1 9 p.m. on Fox. Ryan Murphy has tackled everything from glee clubs to plastic surgery to freak shows to haunted hotels. But he\u2019s never done a procedural \u2014 until now. \u201c9-1-1\u201d follows a group of emergency workers in Los Angeles. Played by a high-wattage cast that includes Connie Britton, Angela Bassett and Peter Krause \u2014 portraying a dispatcher, a patrol officer and a firefighter respectively \u2014 they grapple with crises both inside of work hours (a pet-snake accident) and outside of them (sex addiction). The soapy tension builds in waves, but especially right before commercial breaks.\n\nPhoto\n\nGROWN-ISH 8 p.m. on Freeform. Yara Shahidi has long been an anchor on \u2018black-ish\u2019 as Zoey. In 2016, a tense legal battle ensued in federal court in California over the ownership of a selfie taken by a monkey. (The case was eventually settled with a charitable donation.) The animals in this series won\u2019t be getting checks for this documentary, in which they are equipped with body cameras. Regardless, the audience benefits, getting glimpses into animal life that had previously been out of reach. The show stars the pair as exaggerated versions of themselves navigating millennial life in Los Angeles; they deal with disastrous romantic encounters, unfulfilling jobs and plenty of questions about why they aren\u2019t dating.\n\n\n\nNOVA: BLACK HOLE APOCALYPSE 9 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). This two-hour special isn\u2019t as sensationalist as its title. The astrophysicist and author Janna Levin leads an in-depth exploration of black holes and what they can tell us about the nature of space, time and gravity. Interviews are conducted with prominent scientists, including Paul Murdin, who helped discover the first confirmed black hole, and Neil deGrasse Tyson.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nCAPOTE (2005) on Hulu. Philip Seymour Hoffman won an Oscar for his mesmerizing portrayal of Truman Capote in this film. It follows the genesis of Mr. Capote\u2019s true-crime book, \u201cIn Cold Blood,\u201d a meticulously researched and gripping narrative published long before the genre was in vogue, as Mr. Capote and Harper Lee, his close friend, head to Holcomb, Kan., to investigate four 1959 murders. The deeper he digs into the sordid tale, the more it threatens his mental well-being. \u201c\u2018Capote\u2019 unflinchingly faces the moral abyss at the heart of the journalistic enterprise,\u201d A.
