Chow"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "DAVID ATTENBOROUGH\u2019S GREAT BARRIER REEF 8 p.m. on Smithsonian Channel. Mr. Attenborough has lent his dulcet voice to all sorts of animal encounters \u2014 an iguana-snake chase scene perhaps being the most famous \u2014 but he has a particular expertise and interest below the water. This week he narrated \u201cPlanet Earth: Blue Planet II\u201d; now, he appears onscreen to explore the Great Barrier Reef off Australia. He dives into shark-infested waters, sees baby sea turtles and whales, and looks for evidence of how climate change is affecting a delicate ecosystem.\n\nTHE GOLDBERGS 8 p.m. on ABC. This family sitcom delights in its commitment to its \u201c1980-something\u201d time period (as the narrator announces every episode), with Reebok Pumps, Atari and Garbage Pail Kids galore. But this episode will need a new set of cultural touch points, as the scene jumps forward a decade to \u201c1990-something.\u201d The Goldberg children have graduated, but the teachers of William Penn Academy remain, and Beverly Goldberg (Wendi McLendon-Covey) unsurprisingly continues to throw herself into school affairs. The episode was originally meant to be the pilot of a spinoff series, but ABC declined; Tim Meadows, Nia Long and Bryan Callen star as the school\u2019s staff.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Wednesday: \u2018Waco\u2019 and \u2018The Goldbergs\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "Critics say such views are antiquated and alarming in an era when democracies around the globe appear to be imperiled. The count and his band of fellow monarchists, however, are determined to make their case at conferences, in editorials and at fancy balls.\n\nA recent study that examined the economic performance of monarchies versus republics bolsters their views. Led by Mauro F. Guill\u00e9n, a management professor at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, the study found \u201crobust and quantitatively meaningful evidence\u201d that monarchies outperform other forms of government.\n\nPhoto\n\nFar from being a dying system, the study said, \u201cmonarchies are surprisingly prevalent around the world.\u201d They provide a \u201cstability that often translates into economic gains\u201d; they are better at protecting property rights and checking abuses of power by elected officials; and they have higher per-capita national incomes, the study said.\n\nMr. Guill\u00e9n says he was \u201cshocked\u201d by the results, which have not yet been published. \u201cMost people think monarchies are something anachronistic,\u201d he said. \u201cThey think that modern forms of government are superior and have trouble accepting that monarchies have advantages.\u201d\n\nWhen he presents his findings, \u201cthere is more skepticism in the room than with the average paper,\u201d said Mr. Guill\u00e9n, who is not a monarchist. \u201cIt\u2019s been an uphill battle.\u201d\n\nHis findings come as no surprise, however, to monarchists, who aim to preserve existing monarchies and to support royals who live in exile. They believe that countries with exiled royals should return them to the throne, and that nations without monarchies should consider a switch.\n\n\u201cWe support the retention and restoration of monarchies anywhere in the world,\u201d Count Tolstoy said. \u201cOur goal is to persuade people.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHistory books, of course, are replete with examples of monarchies that became symbols of repression and rapacious, cloistered wealth. Some were ousted by bloody rebellions (the American and French Revolutions) or collapsed in ruins (the Hapsburg Empire), and many have ruthlessly marginalized whole classes of people.\n\nConstitutions, Not Absolute Control\n\nBut Count Tolstoy insists that monarchists are not pining for the days of absolute rulers and the divine right of kings, when Henry VIII of England could order up the execution of unwanted wives and political foes.\n\nPhoto\n\nInstead, his group advocates constitutional monarchies, in which a king or queen is head of state and the real power rests with an elected Parliament \u2014 much like those in Belgium, Britain, Denmark, Japan, the Netherlands, Norway and Spain (although demonstrators in 2014 demanded a referendum on the Spanish royal family after King Juan Carlos abdicated).\n\nAll of those countries, the monarchists note, have relatively strong economies.\n\nMr. Guill\u00e9n\u2019s study shows that since 1900, 22 countries have abandoned royal leaders, while 35 others adopted them. Forms of constitutional monarchies took root, at least for some time, in emerging economies like Malaysia and Thailand.\n\nStill, the study noted that some current monarchies lack basic democratic freedoms, including in Brunei, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and Swaziland.\n\nAfter the Arab Spring, some analysts noted that monarchies like Morocco, Jordan and the Gulf States demonstrated much more stability than countries like Iraq, Libya and Egypt.\n\nBut Sean L. Yom, a political-science professor at Temple University who studies Middle Eastern governments, said that stability might be fleeting: With some of those monarchies propped up by oil money rather than a love of any royal family, \u201cmonarchies are on their way out,\u201d Mr. Yom said.\n\n\u201cThose surviving in the Middle East are the very lucky survivors of history, and it is just taking more time,\u201d he said. \u201cThese countries look so good only because their neighbors look so bad.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nContesting the Throne\n\nFinding people to reject the monarchists\u2019 vision is not hard, even in Britain, where Queen Elizabeth II is revered by many.\n\nPhoto\n\nA London-based grass-roots organization called Republic, which wants the country to hold a referendum on the monarchy when the queen dies, says bluntly on its website, \u201cThe monarchy isn\u2019t fit for purpose. It is corrupt and secretive.\u201d\n\nThe group has a clear mandate: \u201cWe want to see the monarchy abolished and the queen replaced with an elected democratic head of state,\u201d it says.\n\nGraham Smith, Republic\u2019s chief executive, said that current polls showed about 20 to 25 percent of Britons to be anti-royalty, and that it had been hard to win broader support. \u201cOur job is to keep raising that number,\u201d he said, adding that \u201cpublic opinion takes time to shift.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs for the Monarchist League, Mr. Smith dismisses it as \u201ca crank organization.\u201d He said: \u201cThey are going against the general direction of history. You cannot just pluck a family out of obscurity and put them in charge of a country.\u201d\n\nCount Tolstoy acknowledges that the International Monarchist League had turned into a \u201cleague of eccentrics\u201d under its former chancellor, Victor Hervey, who had been jailed for a jewel heist, worked as an arms dealer and sought tax exile in Monaco.\n\nIt was founded in 1943 on the belief that the monarchies of Eastern Europe could be a bulwark against Soviet expansion. Count Tolstoy took over in the mid-1980s, and says the current members are \u201csensible, run-of-the-mill people.\u201d\n\nCount Tolstoy has written books on ancient and postwar British history. He has also run, unsuccessfully, as a parliamentary candidate for the far-right U.K. Independence Party in four general elections.\n\nPhoto\n\nKing of the United States\n\nWhen he considers the United States, Count Tolstoy is certain it would be better off without a presidency.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere is an alternative,\u201d he wrote in an opinion article for The New York Times before the 2016 election. He noted that neither candidate \u201cappears to be a Washington or a Lincoln,\u201d and pointed to a neighbor as an example: Canada, he wrote, \u201cdemonstrates that democracy is perfectly compatible with constitutional monarchy.\u201d \u201c\n\nBut being an American monarchist can be a tough sell. The country, after all, was born of rebellion against a British king.\n\nCharles A. Coulombe of Los Angeles, a former stand-up comic and a monarchist, said, \u201cIf you say you are a monarchist, there is a strain of disloyalty or treason.\u201d\n\nThere are no reliable estimates of how many monarchists there are in the United States. But to help disseminate their message, a Washington think tank, the Center for the Study of Monarchy, Traditional Governance and Sovereignty, opened this past year.\n\nAmerican monarchists also find ways to help the cause abroad. Thomas R. Hutson, a retired State Department diplomat who was posted in Belgrade, has been advocating the restoration of Alexander, the crown prince of Yugoslavia, as the monarch of Serbia.\n\nOn his own dime, Mr. Hutson has repeatedly traveled to Serbia to promote the prince, who was born in exile in London and later moved to Belgrade. But Mr. Hutson admits that he is making little headway.\n\n\u201cI tell people I\u2019m a monarchist and the conversation lasts three seconds,\u201d he said. \u201cThere is resoundingly no interest in him coming back as king. It\u2019s a generational thing. The monarchy completely goes by young people who lack of a sense of history.\u201d\n\nHe insists, however: \u201cI\u2019m not giving up.\u201d\n\nThe Rev. Canon Kenneth W. Gunn-Walberg, the rector of St. Mary\u2019s Anglican Church in Wilmington, Del., and leader of the Monarchist League\u2019s chapter for the Eastern states, said the appeal of monarchies was simple.\n\n\u201cThere is style, a mystery and ethos with a monarch,\u201d he said. \u201cPresidents come and go. There\u2019s continuity, a sense of history with a monarchy.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s the Cure for Ailing Nations? More Kings and Queens, Monarchists Say", "authors": ["Leslie Wayne"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "But the vagueness of the concept served only to heighten hysteria. \u201cMenticide,\u201d announced the Columbia University psychiatrist Joost Meerloo, was a crime against humanity analogous to \u2014 or even worse than \u2014 genocide. The conceit spawned an array of nightmare scenarios. The worst of them appeared to be confirmed when 21 American prisoners refused repatriation after an armistice halted the Korean War in July 1953. Since a preference for \u201cRed China\u201d over America seemed inconceivable to many contemporaries, the conclusion was that the men must have been brainwashed. An unequivocal New York Times editorial in January 1954 evinced no doubt whatsoever. The \u201cnon-repatriates\u201d offered \u201cliving proof that Communist brainwashing does work on some persons,\u201d The Times informed its readers.\n\nFixated on these \u201cturncoat G.I.s,\u201d United States commentators tended to forget that an inordinately greater number of North Korean and Chinese P.O.W.s had refused repatriation to their side. What might have registered as a symbolic victory for the \u201cfree world\u201d \u2014 22,000 to 21 \u2014 was lost in heated contention over how brainwashing was performed and why Americans had seemingly succumbed en masse.\n\nA vast majority of American P.O.W.s who survived captivity did return home \u2014 as, eventually, did almost all of the 21 men supposedly lost to brainwashing. But many found themselves suspected as traitors or ideological termites, sent back by their Communist captors to hollow out American society from within. Insidious plots subsequently made popular by fiction \u2014 think \u201cThe Manchurian Candidate\u201d \u2014 appeared first in the pages of serious newsmagazines. In The Saturday Evening Post, Rear Adm. D. V. Gallery speculated that the Communists had expended so much energy on brainwashing American P.O.W.s to create a network of sleeper saboteurs awaiting activation. The Chinese, according to Admiral Gallery, had sown mental seeds they anticipated would \u201ctake root\u201d and sprout in 10 or 20 years should another depression grip America. \u201cThis may seem far-fetched to those of us who live from year to year,\u201d he acknowledged, before adding an Orientalist twist to his scenario. \u201cBut it isn\u2019t to Asiatics, who look at centuries as we do months.\u201d\n\nWhy did people take \u201cbrainwashing\u201d so seriously, despite the best efforts of prominent social scientists to debunk outr\u00e9 Pavlovian notions and the racist stereotypes often used to buttress them? And why does \u201celection hacking\u201d exert a comparable allure? Anxieties about external manipulation are not, of course, divorced from the demonstrable efforts of other powers to sway Americans\u2019 politically consequential behavior: The theft and distribution of Democratic National Committee emails was real enough, as was the Chinese effort to win converts among captive Americans imprisoned in North Korea. But \u201celection hacking\u201d and \u201cbrainwashing\u201d share an aura of dark magic that obscures the precise mechanics believed to be at work in shaping the thoughts and actions of freethinking adults. And obscurity provides fertile soil in which conspiracy theories flourish. When everything is, or may be, a form of \u201celection hacking,\u201d the techniques appear worrisomely diffuse. So, too, do the agents of a phenomenon variously attributed to Russian trolls, Twitter-bots, Facebook ads, a \u201cuseful idiot\u201d in the White House or American idiocy more generally.\n\nAnxiety over new technology also helps explain how concerns over foreign mental meddling metastasized in both the 1950s and present-day United States. Then as now, Americans fretted not only over the Kremlin\u2019s machinations but also over the ways in which a pervasive new medium was simultaneously bringing people closer while turning living rooms into isolated bubbles. Where today we devote acres of type to parsing the antisocial pitfalls of social media, anatomists of the \u201950s rued the destructive potential of television \u2014 whether to empower populist maniacs or induce Americans to crave new consumer goods they neither wanted nor needed. Now we ponder mysterious algorithms that mine our every online keystroke for lucrative potential; then, Americans got wise to techniques of \u201csubliminal suggestion\u201d that advertising wizards apparently employed to turn psychic soft spots into sales.", "title": "Opinion | When Americans Were Afraid of Being Brainwashed", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHe\u2019ll have to call me and explain the situation,\u201d he said of the dog\u2019s owner, who would eventually be fined 150 euros for animal neglect.\n\nSergeant Smit is one of roughly 250 full-time members of the animal police force in the Netherlands (many more are trained but do not carry out the function exclusively). Of the approximately three million calls made to The Hague area police each year, roughly 3,000 involve animals.\n\nLike a Humane Society with guns, handcuffs and badges, members of the animal police force are regular officers with extra training and special equipment. A 911-type emergency line for animals \u2014 dial 144 from any phone in the Netherlands \u2014 dispatches the officers and supplies the vast majority of their leads.\n\nThe work is a mix of animal protection and human social services, finding practical solutions \u2014 like monthly visits to a troubled dog and its owner to ensure all is well \u2014 and judicial procedures like fines.\n\n\u201cObviously, the first thing I do is to look after the animals, but often when you look further, you see the things aren\u2019t going so well for the owner of the animals,\u201d said Sergeant Smit, who estimates he sees malicious intent in only about 20 percent of cases.", "title": "When Animals Are at Risk, Special Netherlands Police Force Defends Them", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "My stars were Karen Carpenter, Tracy Gold and my favorite, Jennifer Jason Leigh, who, in the 1981 movie \u201cThe Best Little Girl in the World,\u201d appeared appealingly helpless in high-waisted jeans.\n\nWith one exception, these movies wrapped up anorexia in tidy boxes where therapy, feeding tubes, weight gain, finding release from a controlling mother\u2019s grip and discovering the joys of food led to a happy ending. I was a kid who no longer ate dessert when I watched Ms. Leigh\u2019s character jovially lick an ice cream cone beside her therapist. But even I knew then that ice cream was neither the problem nor the solution.\n\nThe only other outcome for anorexics was the one the singer Karen Carpenter suffered \u2014 the one that would never happen to me: death at age 32. So old, I remember thinking. How could she let that happen when everyone else found the cure?\n\nThe aging anorexic doesn\u2019t make for a compelling movie. Adults with the disorder aren\u2019t represented in pop culture and news outlets, so I assumed we were either supposed to outgrow our eating disorders or die.\n\nBut in 2003, one-third of inpatient admissions to a specialized eating disorders treatment center were for people over age 30, according to the National Eating Disorders Association. In an online survey published in the International Journal of Eating Disorders, 13 percent of women over age 50 were found to have eating disorder symptoms. And many older sufferers of eating disorders, some of whom have been battling the disorder since they were young, feel shame at having a \u201cteenager\u2019s problem\u201d and are reluctant to get help.\n\nAfter decades of therapy \u2014 of great days and good years, relapses and starting over from scratch \u2014 I realize there\u2019s an ending these movies fail to capture. Some of us are never going to be fully cured.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat doesn\u2019t mean we return to our anorexia rock bottom.\n\nFor me, that was when I was 20 and had become so ill that heart palpitations kept me up at night. It was when I walked down Bayswater Road so weak from hunger that traffic sounds and accents blend into a single white noise loop. It was when two photographers stopped me on the same afternoon to ask if I wanted to model while my chest rattled from walking pneumonia.\n\nLiving with eating disorder thinking means actively ignoring a voice in my head that tells me it\u2019s dangerous to have a favorite restaurant (Tanoreen in Brooklyn) or to lick my lips while savoring sumac shredded chicken. It\u2019s forcing myself to use positive adjectives to describe my 5-year-old\u2019s mac and cheese after she proclaims it\u2019s the \u201cbest thing ever.\u201d It\u2019s never being able to engage in conversations with other women \u2014 and, boy are there many \u2014 about losing weight or trying out a fad diet. And it\u2019s feeling their eyes on me when I won\u2019t join in the ritual of bashing my own thighs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey suspect it\u2019s because I think I\u2019m better than everyone else; I know it\u2019s because my weak mind can\u2019t afford dabbling in this sport.\n\nI feel anxiety every time I realize my body is going to change as I age, with or without my consent, whether I weigh 89 pounds or 289 pounds. I don\u2019t trust the body and fear the ways it can turn on you. At an early age I decided that the only way to stall death or pain, or both, is to wield a lion tamer\u2019s whip and keep cracking at the body, change after change.\n\nFor me, change is as much an enemy as weight gain and the body itself. Puberty is one of the most frequently discussed risk periods for the development of eating disorders. The frustration I have with the focus on puberty and eating disorders is that it doesn\u2019t address the fact that every stage of life for a person with an eating disorder presents enormous changes.\n\nMy triggers have included puberty, leaving home for the first time, and getting pregnant. As I age, they may include watching my own children leave the nest and confronting my mortality.\n\nMy heart hurts thinking about a teen anorexic sitting in her suburban bedroom, one change down and hundreds more to go. She may believe that eating dessert one day means she\u2019s saved. That she can then bid farewell to therapy and go enjoy a banquet of delicious foods for the rest of her life. I hope that\u2019s her fate, but for an anorexic, it isn\u2019t always the resolution.\n\nI refuse to call myself fully healed because there is still work to do. Some days it\u2019s easy work, other days it\u2019s work that makes me break down in tears on my husband\u2019s lap. But it\u2019s work that must be done every morning, every evening, at every meal.\n\nThis is the way I keep healing.", "title": "When Anorexics Grow Up", "authors": ["Lisa Fogarty"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "They appear to work best under certain conditions: The leave is uninterrupted and entails little or no contact between the leader and his or her organization. A staff member, as opposed to an outsider, leads in the interim. The staff, as a whole, has access to additional professional development. Durfee gives $45,000 to the recipient\u2019s organization to cover the cost of the leader\u2019s salary, and also provides $3,000 to the interim leader and $5,000 for organization-wide professional development.\n\nIt\u2019s pretty radical when you think about it. Nonprofit leaders, who are normally forced to paint the rosiest picture possible when describing their work to foundations, are instead invited to be honest about the challenges they face professionally and personally.\n\nDurfee\u2019s president, Carrie Avery, recalls one sabbatical seeker who entered the foundation\u2019s office for his interview in a starched shirt and tie, his game face firmly in place, and then melted down when he started being asked questions: \u201cHe sobbed while rapidly consuming five cookies,\u201d she said. \u201cHe was in a really big position and it was like he finally had a chance to be vulnerable. He got a sabbatical and it had a huge impact on his leadership.\u201d\n\nAvery says that leaders are encouraged to become \u201crigorously unproductive\u201d during their sabbaticals, which is easier for some than others. \u201cChildren of immigrants seem to have a particularly hard time with this,\u201d she observed. \u201cOn top of the twisted nonprofit sector message that every E.D. has to be self-sacrificing and overworked, they\u2019ve got parents who worked multiple jobs while they were growing up. A sabbatical can feel very privileged.\u201d\n\nOther foundations are following in Durfee\u2019s footsteps, notably the Barr Foundation, the California Wellness Foundation, the Rasmuson Foundation and the Meyer Foundation. Linnell estimates that more than a dozen foundations now have official sabbatical funding available. Nevertheless, that is a very small proportion of the more than 86,000 foundations in the United States, by the count of the Foundation Center.\n\nIt\u2019s easy to misunderstand sabbaticals as little more than extended vacations. After working in the nonprofit sector for nearly 40 years, Linnell believes that sabbaticals are one of the most effective investments a foundation can make in an organization or a cause.\n\nThe biggest payoff? The capacity to think clearly and expansively. \u201cLeaders who are stuck in reactive or even adaptive leadership mode have a chance to refresh themselves and reconnect with their original passion for their cause,\u201d Linnell explained. \u201cThey are able to do catalytic generative thinking again.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | When Being Unproductive Saves a Career", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWith Red Tape Losing Its Grip, Firms Ante Up\u201d (front page, Jan. 2):\n\nThe examples cited as producing a \u201cwave of optimism\u201d that has \u201cswept over American business leaders\u201d show exactly why we should not set policy based on the preferences of corporate chiefs.\n\nThe article\u2019s examples of regulations to be overturned include limiting mining debris in streams; requiring broadband providers to obtain permission from customers to collect and use online information; banning plastic bottles from national parks, and restricting housing development in wetlands. The prospect of removing this \u201cred tape\u201d is, according to a Moody\u2019s economist, \u201clifting everyone\u2019s spirits.\u201d\n\nNot mine. Every one of these changes would have the effect of increasing short-term profits at long-term cost to us all.\n\nIt is the job of government to weigh all factors and write rules that do not overly constrain business plans, but whose primary motivation is to consider the consequences to society as a whole. The views of corporations are just one highly self-interested pole of that debate; only regulation can balance their incentives away from short-term profit.", "title": "Opinion | When C.E.O.s Cheer Weaker Regulations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Finally, Armando Torjes, a community activist in the working-class suburb of Guadalupe, cleared it up for us.\n\nNo one much minded business people acting like politicians because, he said, the real problem was politicians acting like business people.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not that businessmen are bad people, they\u2019re just getting all the privileges. They should be giving back,\u201d he said as his mother, also an activist, served us lemonade in his living room.\n\n\u201cWe have this political class that totally forgets why they are there. Suddenly it\u2019s all about the possibility of business,\u201d he said, referring to rampant political corruption.\n\nWe were starting to see what he meant. Monterrey\u2019s problem wasn\u2019t just crime. It was institutional breakdown at nearly every level of government, which allowed corruption to become the norm, including among police officers who sometimes beat citizens and extort money from them just as brazenly as did the drug gangs.\n\nFixing crime required fixing corruption, which required fixing the state.\n\nThat was also the conclusion reached by Monterrey\u2019s business leaders. Except instead of fixing the state, they would cut it out.\n\nJorge Tello, a former head of Mexico\u2019s intelligence agency and now a big man about town, met us at his private lunch club, just across from city hall, to tell us how it\u2019d all happened.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe first meeting I remember was with the governor at Lorenzo\u2019s office,\u201d Mr. Tello said, referring to Lorenzo Zambrano, the head of Cemex and unofficial leader of Monterrey\u2019s business community until his death in 2014.\n\nDrug cartels, after years of ravaging poorer communities, had begun to target the richest of the rich.\n\n\u201cThe governor was the one to say: \u2018You need to help me. I cannot do it by myself,\u2019\u201d Mr. Tello recounted. It was a tacit admission of the state\u2019s weakness.\n\nPhoto\n\nTo get what happened next, you need to understand Monterrey\u2019s peculiar corporate culture. It is one part worldly Davos elite, one part 1980s Wall Streeters working from their beach home in Florida (lots of men with tan suits, manicures and perfect hair) and three parts cowboy culture, which suffuses this part of Mexico.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Interpreter Newsletter Understand the world with sharp insight and commentary on the major news stories of the week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Zambrano, who was peppery but aristocratic, agreed to lead a reform effort that grew into a takeover of local police forces. But first he would ensure that Monterrey\u2019s executives would remain to help lead \u2014 and, crucially, to fund \u2014 the effort. Some were already considering a move to nearby Houston.\n\nSo Mr. Zambrano posted a tweet that Monterrey\u2019s business leaders still cite as a call to arms. It read, translated into English: \u201cWhoever leaves Monterrey is a coward. They must fight for what we believe. We must return to our great city!\u201d\n\nAfter a few years, community leaders like Mr. Torjes saw an improvement. As an experimental new police force moved into the streets, backed by the executives, crime and reports of police brutality dropped.\n\nThe reforms were an academic\u2019s dream. Juan Salgado, a governance expert at the CIDE, a Mexico City university, called the new force \u201cvery impressive.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhat they did was create comprehensive community police services,\u201d he said, detailing reforms that benefited from the C.E.O.s\u2019 largess and as well their ability to skip the usual political corruption and horse trading.\n\nBut then, he said, \u201cthere was a change in the government.\u201d\n\nNo one in official or corporate Monterrey likes to talk about what happened in 2015. No one except for Mr. Tello, who said it was important that the city face what had happened.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m getting mad,\u201d he said, remembering it.\n\nThe governor left office that year. (He later faced embezzlement charges, which we mention only to underscore that official corruption is just pervasive.) Monterrey\u2019s executives, maybe a little taken with their newfound autonomy, backed an independent candidate whom they expected would be even more pliant.\n\nBut the new governor, Jaime Rodr\u00edguez Calder\u00f3n, turned out not to be pliant. He has mixed fiery populist language with old-style patronage. Reforms have lapsed and crime has returned.\n\nMr. Torjes, the activist from the working-class suburb, argued that the real problem wasn\u2019t the governor himself but a political system in which reforms never seem to stick.\n\n\u201cEvery politician comes in and brings something new,\u201d he said; a complaint we heard from activists and academics across Mexico. \u201cYou never know if something is going to last past the next election.\u201d\n\nThis was our big realization from our time in Monterrey. The Mexican state \u2014 which oversees the world\u2019s tenth-largest population and 14th largest landmass \u2014 is perilously weak.\n\nIts institutions are too weak to fix the crime and corruption tearing away at society. They are too weak even to maintain a fix that, as in Monterrey, is already working.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s quite different than if you talk about well-developed countries with strong institutions,\u201d Mr. Tello said. In countries like the United States, he added, \u201cit doesn\u2019t matter what kind of mess you have at the top of the political structure because you have strong institutions.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMonterrey\u2019s business leaders had tried to install their corporations as replacement institutions. But they fell victim to the same institutional weaknesses they\u2019d tried to fix. With little in the way of a civil service, a simple change in governor destabilized everything.\n\nThat might seem like a technical or abstract lesson, but it\u2019s one that should concern everybody, and not just in Mexico. We don\u2019t spend a lot of time thinking about the health of our institutions; they\u2019re boring, opaque and largely unseen. But maybe we should think about them.\n\nMany of the biggest stories in the last year \u2014 ethnic cleansing in Myanmar, democratic backsliding in Turkey and in Venezuela, regime change in Zimbabwe, a destabilizing power struggle in Saudi Arabia \u2014 come down, in part, to weak institutions. They are the guardrails meant to keep government orderly, capable and self-policing. Without them, you have corruption, instability, power grabs and leaders whose incentives do not align with the public good.\n\nEven in the developed countries that Mr. Tello called categorically different, institutional health can\u2019t be taken for granted. Spain has been destabilized by a secession movement led by some of its own regional institutions. Hungary and Poland, unchecked by courts and legislatures that have grown weak, are backsliding into authoritarianism. American diplomats, aghast at the gutting of the State Department, warn that American power in the world could be set back by a generation.\n\nMany of Mexico\u2019s leaders, like Monterrey\u2019s business elite, hardly noticed their country\u2019s institutional decline until they started feeling the effects personally. By then, it was too late.", "title": "When Corporate Elites Won Partial Control of a Mexican City \u2014 and Then Lost It", "authors": ["Max Fisher", "Amanda Taub", "The Interpreter"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "As they still do, General Motors cars cruised the streets in the shadow of Detroit\u2019s Harper Hospital in 1952. Above them was the room of Henry Opitek, a cardiac patient who would come to owe his life to the engineers who built those cars \u2014 and who helped foster a partnership between the automotive and medical industries that continues today.\n\nThe combined efforts of Harper doctors and G.M. engineers would produce a miraculous machine \u2014 a mechanical device that would temporarily replace Mr. Opitek\u2019s heart.\n\nThe operation was performed by a team led by Dr. Forest D. Dodrill, who had approached G.M. about a partnership after reasoning that pumping blood would be much like pumping fuel. Not only did it save a life, but it paved the way for the heart procedures carried out today. And as the car world descends on Detroit this week to catch a glimpse of the future at the North American International Auto Show, visitors could spare a moment for a look at history inside Harper Hospital, where one of the mechanical hearts remains on display.", "title": "When Detroit Muscle Powered a Breakthrough in Heart Surgery", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "1999 print headline: \u201cAt a Wedding, It\u2019s Still Not In to Be Out,\u201d published here in July 1999.\n\nThe story: By 1999, being gay suddenly seemed mainstream. \u201cWill and Grace\u201d was riding high on television. Ellen DeGeneres had silenced the whispers, declaring \u201cYep, I\u2019m Gay\u201d on the cover of Time magazine. And RuPaul represented M.A.C. Cosmetics.\n\nNot so with weddings, however. In the years before same-sex marriage was legalized, some gay men and women considered weddings to be the ultimate celebration of heterosexuality itself, leading them to feel awkward, and sometimes unwelcome, when invited to a straight couple\u2019s nuptials, argued Bob Morris, a longtime Styles contributor. Indeed, change was a long time coming on the gay marriage front. Just three years before the article appeared, President Bill Clinton had signed into law the Defense of Marriage Act, which defined marriage as \u201ca legal union between one man and one woman as husband and wife.\u201d\n\nNew frontiers, old taboos: Progress was not limited to pop culture. Gay rights were advancing in the courts too. The Supreme Court\u2019s Romer v. Evans ruling in 1996 was a landmark gay rights decision that struck down Colorado\u2019s anti-gay amendment.\n\nEven so, gay marriage still seemed like a distant dream, which is why some gay invitees told Mr. Morris that they felt less than welcome at their straight friends\u2019 weddings. As Mr. Morris wrote, weddings represented \u201cthat increasingly rare opportunity to feel ashamed, or at least self-conscious.\u201d One gay man interviewed said that \u201coften one of the families doesn\u2019t want you there, so you end up feeling like pariahs.\u201d", "title": "When Gay People Dreaded an Invitation to Straight Weddings", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor years, a college friend (in her 50s) has forbidden me from telling anyone we went to school together. Since moving to Hollywood, she deducted 10 years from her age (some of it with cosmetic surgery) to preserve her writing career, she claims. She is afraid that my salt-and-pepper hair will \u201cbust\u201d her. Lately, she has been mostly out of touch. But the implication that I look so much older than her has rankled for years. When I confided my hurt feelings to her, she was unapologetic. Blame the industry and ageism, she said, not her. Do I have a right to feel hurt?\n\nANONYMOUS\n\nAge, as fantasists have long told us, is just a number. But patterns of numbers have meaning. If 50-year-old leading men routinely win the hearts of 30-year-old actresses in Hollywood films (as demonstrated by a totally nonscientific survey of movies watched on a recent cross-country flight), what happens to 50-year-old women? Who knows if this invisibility also pertains to writers? In any event, your friend is living in never-never land: It takes about three minutes to learn anyone\u2019s age these days.\n\nAs for your hurt feelings, they seem reasonable. Personally, I would be less hurt by her assessment of my looks (until I inspected her cosmetic surgery, anyway) than by her shame at associating with me. Still, you have shared your honest feelings, and she rejected them. If you are committed to this friendship, I would never dissuade you from trying again. But as my (brutally efficient) nana used to say: \u201cNo use watering dead flowers.\u201d And don\u2019t out her as 50-something. Two wrongs. \u2026\n\nRelease the Date?\n\nI am the eldest of five adult children. While packing up the family home after our father died (our mother predeceased him), I came across a copy of my parents\u2019 marriage certificate. They celebrated their anniversary on Jan. 12, so I was surprised to see the actual date was Jan. 6. But I was even more surprised to see the year: 1962 \u2014 after the first three children were born. I\u2019m smiling just writing this. Good on them! Question: Should I tell my siblings?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nK. J.\n\nPay dirt! As reward for the dreary labor of clearing out the family digs, you were given a morsel that will enliven family gatherings for years to come. Was there a ceremony years before the state certificate was issued? Did they take sly pleasure in their secret? Was a Montague-and-Capulet drama afoot? Your parents have underscored the wonderful mystery of mankind, even for folks we think we know inside out.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Your parents had more than 50 years to destroy this public document if they wanted to. And you probably couldn\u2019t stop yourself from telling your brothers and sisters even if you tried. (I couldn\u2019t.)", "title": "When Hollywood Ageism Hits Close to Home", "authors": ["Philip Galanes", "Social Q S"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cNot the Death He Wanted,\u201d by Karen Brown (Sunday Review, Jan. 7):\n\nI am a palliative care physician and an ardent proponent for hospice care. At its best, hospice care is nearly miraculous in its ability to alleviate suffering and enable people to die in gentle and dignified ways. But the account that Ms. Brown gives of her father\u2019s last days rings true. I\u2019ve heard far too many similar stories to believe that it is an aberration. The appropriate term for what she describes is \u201cbad care.\u201d\n\nPeople need to understand that there are no medical reasons for a patient in Ms. Brown\u2019s father\u2019s situation to suffer in agony. Intensive symptom management is effective and can be delivered in people\u2019s homes.\n\nHospice programs care for the sickest patients. They must have nurses \u2014 and doctors \u2014 available at all hours of the day or night. Those clinicians must have immediate access to the same symptom-relieving medications that would be administered in an emergency department or hospital.\n\nHospice staff must be trained and regularly drilled on responding to pain crises, analogous to the way that hospital personnel are routinely recertified in cardiac life support. Nothing less will suffice.", "title": "Opinion | When Hospice Care Falls Short", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Indeed, what gives some parents pause is the possibility of a diversion \u2014 when a plane lands someplace other than its origin or destination airport and the child has to spend the night there. How often does that happen, and what happens to minors in that situation?\n\nFor the year that ended in October, 22 of every 10,000 flights were diverted on average, according to the Department of Transportation. But many of those flights did not require an overnight stay at the unexpected stop because the planes eventually took off again and got where they were going. American said six in 10,000 diverted during the evening in 2017 and spent the night in that spot; Southwest did not provide a figure. Meanwhile, there are not minors flying without parents on every flight.\n\nStill, stuff happens, as Thursday\u2019s powerful storm proved. Most carriers try to keep unaccompanied minors off the last flights of the day. Indeed, I worried a bit about this as my daughter\u2019s early-evening flight home from Chicago was delayed for hours, even though we had rehearsed a sort-of Buffalo scenario in which she ended up on the ground in a city between Chicago and New York where no one we knew could go pick her up. It involved first calling us on her cellphone, the existence of which makes solo flying more comfortable for everyone.\n\nMy mind also wandered to Susan Burton\u2019s poignant segment on the radio program \u201cThis American Life,\u201d about being snowed in at O\u2019Hare with other children of divorce when she was younger, which is the very next thing you should listen to on whatever device you have nearby.\n\nWhen things do go awry, Mr. Taylor said, Southwest will not take kids out of the airport and will instead keep watch over them through the wee hours. If my 12-year-old had been in that situation even outside its unaccompanied minor service, she would have been free to hang out with the kids whose parents had paid the fee, but could also have left the airport on her own. My wife and I probably would have told her to stay rather than trying to find a hotel room late at night.\n\nA spokesman for American, Ross Feinstein, offered more options for the airline\u2019s younger travelers. He said it would try to call parents and see if they wanted their kids to go to a hotel, perhaps with an airline staff member staying next door or even in the same room if the family was comfortable with that.\n\nFor all of Ms. Skenazy\u2019s professional bravado, she gets that diversions are a part of life. Maybe even a good part, the part where the kids wander around the terminal and eat caramel corn for dinner instead of the emergency sandwich in their bag and then band together with strangers to make the best of a bad situation.\n\n\u201cWhen I ask people about their best childhood memories, it\u2019s often about when something went wrong,\u201d she said. \u201cWhen you\u2019re thrown off your game and you handle it, it\u2019s the wind beneath your wings forevermore.\u201d", "title": "When It Costs Double to Let Your 12-Year-Old Fly Alone", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "One of the most high-profile cases I worked on took place just after 2 a.m. on Jan. 10. Eight armed men invaded the Bulo Bacley settlement in Galkayo, kidnapped four women and raped two of them, and tried to drag other women from their homes.\n\nSome of the men were recognized as members of the local police force. Despite efforts by my organization and others to ensure sufficient evidence is gathered, including the in-depth testimonies of the survivors themselves, only one suspect was brought into custody and then was released soon afterward under suspicious circumstances. The lack of basics such as forensics facilities and a qualified team of investigators means that the case is likely to be dropped soon.\n\nOther, less-noticed cases have been equally egregious. In mid-December, a 16-year-old girl with mental disabilities was raped by a group of marines in the town of Garacad. She had been on her way to collect firewood. Four men were arrested but were freed shortly after they swore on the Quran that they were innocent. The victim was told that she would need to provide four witnesses \u2014 an effectively impossible task.\n\nThose are just two of over a dozen recent cases in which we were able to step in to provide urgent medical, psychological, legal and financial support for the survivors. It\u2019s hard to get accurate statistics on the prevalence of rape in Puntland or in Somalia in general, but anecdotally, the law appears to have had little impact.\n\nThat the law has not had the results we expected is not entirely surprising, even though Puntland\u2019s institutional capacity compared with that of the southern part of Somalia is relatively strong. Policemen are often unaware that the law against sexual violence even exists. Even when officials are aware, they can be hesitant to enforce it. A judge recently told me that since the law was not agreed upon by everyone, not everyone would use it \u2014 a shocking statement from somebody who is representing our government.", "title": "Opinion | When Laws Against Rape Aren\u2019t Enough", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "One afternoon several months ago, a friend invited me to come to her house to pick from her tree brimming with Meyer lemons, my favorite. It was the magical week in Oakland, Calif., when lemons are ripe and fat.\n\nThis decision was not as simple as it might seem. My panic disorder made it a daunting one.\n\nCome on, I thought, I should be able to drive eight minutes for free fruit. I weighed both sides \u2014 go and experience excruciating fear and physical discomfort, or stay home and let yet another activity be slashed from my repertoire. I asked a friend to come with me; she couldn\u2019t. My boyfriend was away. I could have waited another day or until later that night when more friends were home. But I wanted them, now, and I wanted my life back.\n\nI could no longer teach, or stay home alone. I could no longer drive, sleep, shop, shower, wait in any kind of line, eat at a restaurant, or sometimes eat anything at all. I couldn\u2019t make it to therapy anymore, or sometimes even to the kitchen for a glass of water. Everyday activities went through an exhaustive cost-benefit analysis. Was it worth the panic attack I\u2019d endure to return the book to the library? After too many panic attacks at Trader Joe\u2019s, I stopped shopping. After too many while driving, I didn\u2019t drive. But the lemons were calling.\n\nI sat in my car, gathering courage to turn the key. Sweat drenched the armpits of my thin T-shirt, my breathing grew shallow and short. I turned the key and my heart sped. I started driving, and dizziness and nausea clawed at my throat, threatening to blur my vision. I quickly pulled over, gulped some water, spilling half of it down my shirt, and turned the car around. It\u2019s not worth it, I said aloud. It\u2019s O.K., go home. I drove home, got in bed and didn\u2019t get up for weeks.", "title": "Opinion | When Life Gave Me Lemons, I Had a Panic Attack", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "What he did \u2014 on a half-dozen occasions, by his count \u2014 was to let homeless people sleep on cots in his basement when the windchill factor dipped below 15 degrees. Mr. Schiller provided hot drinks and simple meals like ramen. He showed movies, G-rated fare like old \u201cLassie\u201d films and Christian-themed works. Typically, he said, 10 people stayed overnight. Come morning, they had to leave. There were no untoward episodes during the sleepovers, he said. \u201cThese people are my friends,\u201d he told a Chicago radio station, insisting on his right to have friends over to spend the night.\n\nThat\u2019s not how Elgin officials viewed it. To them, Mr. Schiller in effect had created a shelter of his own and blatantly flouted various ordinances, for instance by not having enough exits from the basement in case of a fire. \u201cWe understand where he\u2019s coming from,\u201d Laura Valdez, the assistant city manager, said, \u201cbut we do have shelters for the homeless.\u201d At any given time, she said, her city of about 110,000 has about 100 men and women in need of shelter.\n\nNot everybody in need, though, wishes to spend the night in a municipally sanctioned facility, whether out of safety fears or out of innate resistance to the rules. That is as true in Elgin as it is in a vastly larger city like New York. So a fair question would seem to be whether Mr. Schiller\u2019s offer of a place for these people to lay their heads in severe weather outweighs city codes governing full-time shelters.\n\nOne person who thinks so is Jeff Rowes, a lawyer at the Institute for Justice, a public-interest firm in Arlington, Va., with a libertarian bent. He has been in touch with Mr. Schiller. \u201cFundamentally,\u201d Mr. Rowes said, \u201cyou have a right to rescue people unless there\u2019s evidence you\u2019ll do more harm than good.\u201d He called it \u201cthe right to be a good Samaritan.\u201d\n\nAfter this dispute became the focus of news articles, Mr. Schiller and Elgin officials discussed ways in which the city might work harder to shelter all the homeless on the coldest nights, perhaps even allowing them to sleep in the lobby of a police station. Satisfied for now, Mr. Schiller said he would drop his plan to sue the municipality. In a way, that\u2019s too bad, because a court case might help clarify how far the sanctity of one\u2019s castle extends.\n\n\u201cI respect the city codes,\u201d he said. \u201cBut I do believe a little leeway, a little grace, could have been in order.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | When Mercy Collides With the Law", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "The people in the series became more than story subjects. They shared intimate thoughts about life and, quite often, death. I went to a jazz club to see Jonas Mekas; a podiatrist appointment with Fred Jones; a dim sum restaurant in Chinatown with Ping Wong; a New Jersey beach house with Ruth Willig. I told them about my mother, who turned 89 last month, and about my impending divorce. They gave me chocolates and writings and showed me photographs of themselves in their youth. They had complaints, sometimes quite a lot of them. But as often as not they shared thoughts about things that brought them joy.\n\nOne day in his apartment, Fred Jones asked me my definition of happiness, then gave me his own. \u201cHappiness to me is what\u2019s happening now,\u201d he said. The apartment, a cluttered wreck that was up two flights of stairs he could barely climb, was an unlikely place to look for happiness, and Mr. Jones, whose health was failing, was an unlikely spokesman. But he never dwelt on his problems. \u201cIf you\u2019re not happy at the present time, then you\u2019re not happy,\u201d he said. \u201cSome people say, if I get that new fur coat for the winter, or get myself a new automobile, I\u2019ll be happy then. But you don\u2019t know what\u2019s going to happen by that time. Right now, are you happy?\u201d Whenever I asked him the happiest time of his life, he said without hesitation, \u201cRight now.\u201d\n\nThe six became models for the challenges in my own life, living examples of resilience, gratitude and the wisdom that comes from living through ups and downs in history. Even amid the very real hardships of old age, all found reasons or opportunities to be happy.\n\nIn early 2016, I wrote the words \u201cHappiness Is a Choice You Make\u201d on a sheet of paper and taped it to the wall by my nightstand. It was Mr. Jones\u2019s wisdom filtered through that of all the others. Right now, are you happy?\n\nThey were words to live by, at any age. Why not? In the rest of the year I wrote a book by that title, due out this month, with a subtitle giving credit where it is due: \u201cLessons from a year among the oldest old.\u201d This time, I tell the story that is not in the Times series.", "title": "When Old News Is Good News: The Effect of 6 Elderly New Yorkers on One Middle-Aged Reporter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHE LAST GIRL\n\nMy Story of Captivity, and My Fight Against the Islamic State\n\nBy Nadia Murad with Jenna Krajeski\n\nIllustrated. 306 pp. Tim Duggan Books. $27.\n\nHow to approach a memoir of a war still being waged? \u201cThe Last Girl: My Story of Captivity, and My Fight Against the Islamic State\u201d contains open wounds and painful lessons, as the Yazidi activist Nadia Murad learns how her own story can become a weapon against her \u2014 co-opted for any number of political agendas. In August 2014 Islamic State militants besieged her village of Kocho in northern Iraq. They executed nearly all the men and older women \u2014 including Murad\u2019s mother and six brothers \u2014 and buried them in mass graves. The younger women, Murad among them, were kidnapped and sold into sexual slavery. Raped, tortured and exchanged among militants, 21-year-old Murad finds an escape route when she is sold to a jihadist in Mosul who leaves a front door unlocked. She flees into Kurdistan by posing as the wife of a Sunni man, Nasser, who risks everything to escort her to safety.\n\nPhoto\n\nJust when Murad, and the reader, expect a flood of relief, there is another sinister turn: Murad and Nasser are detained by Kurdish officials who force them to testify about their escape with cameras rolling. The officials are eager to hear how peshmerga fighters from a rival Kurdish faction \u2014 the two groups fought a civil war in the 1990s \u2014 had abandoned the Yazidi communities they were supposed to protect. The officials swear no one will ever see the tape, but it appears on the news that same night, putting Nasser and his family in grave danger. \u201cI was quickly learning that my story, which I still thought of as a personal tragedy, could be someone else\u2019s political tool,\u201d Murad writes.\n\nFreed from captivity, Murad remains trapped inside politics. To publish \u201cThe Last Girl\u201d right now, in the United States, means there are tricky issues of sensationalism to navigate; in a threatening climate of Islamophobia, Muslims of all kinds are vilified for the actions of one group. Yet Murad, and the team of translators and writers with whom she worked, hedge against this response with a book intricate in historical context. Visible throughout are the disastrous legacies of the American intervention that dismantled Baathist institutions and bred a generation of Iraqis raised on violence and with few prospects. In a childhood flashback, a young Nadia receives a ring from one of the many American soldiers who arrived in Kocho in the mid-2000s bearing trinkets and empty promises. During the Iraq war, Yazidis became increasingly isolated from their Sunni Arab neighbors, caught in cross hairs of sectarianism in the wake of the \u201ccoalition of the willing.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Last Girl\u201d is also a primer on the ancient Yazidi faith that sustains Murad throughout her ordeal: its creation myths, visions of the afterlife and idiosyncratic customs. (Many Yazidis avoid eating lettuce, and consider blue a color too holy for humans to wear.) Yazidis pray to Tawusi Melek, an archangel who, at the creation, took the form of a peacock, and painted a desolate earth with the colors of his feathers. Over the centuries, misunderstandings surrounding the mysterious religion have fueled genocide \u2014 73 times, Murad writes, a figure eerily exact. According to a pernicious myth, Tawusi Melek refused to bow before Adam and was condemned to hell, echoing Satan\u2019s behavior in the Quran. Branding them \u201cdevil worshipers,\u201d ISIS legitimized the massacre and enslavement of Yazidis, singling them out among Iraq\u2019s many minorities for particularly inhumane treatment.\n\n\u201cI want to be the last girl in the world with a story like mine,\u201d Murad concludes. Despite recent gains against ISIS in Iraq, many Yazidis still remain in captivity. As a story that hasn\u2019t yet ended, \u201cThe Last Girl\u201d is difficult to process. It is a call to action, but as it places Murad\u2019s tragedy in the larger narrative of Iraqi history and American intervention, it leaves the reader with urgent, incendiary questions: What have we done, and what can we do?", "title": "When Rape Becomes a Weapon of War", "authors": ["Anna Della Subin", "Nadia Murad"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Companies, Reed added, have to ask, \u201cIs it worth it to dilute my target market at the expense of possibly diluting my brand?\u201d\n\nBrooks said its holiday catalog had helped sales, but the company declined to provide figures. The company also said it planned to continue the theme in its March catalog, conveying inspirational stories through real runners.\n\nOne is Gabriele Grunewald, a professional middle-distance runner sponsored by Brooks who is being treated for a rare cancer, adenoid cystic carcinoma, but continues to compete. Another is Julie Lam, an Ironman triathlete who began running in her 40s after a six-month period in which her father and grandfather died and she got divorced.\n\nCarey, a communications and marketing manager for a nonprofit, said that members of her group were not paid in cash for appearing in the catalog, but that they got to keep the clothes they wore. And they got to impart the mission of Black Girls Run in a way they had not expected.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. He\u2019s covered Kobe.
