View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nShe and Kline have no doubt that Brooks was wise to focus on how running can build communities. \u201cOh my God, these brands are actually getting it,\u201d Carey said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKline, an investment adviser for Merrill Lynch in Bellevue, Wash., said: \u201cI think it\u2019s genius. I have no financial interest in Brooks, but I hope they blow the doors off.\u201d\n\nLike Carey, he said that he and his group had not received compensation for appearing in the catalog, and he added that he would not have accepted cash if it had been offered.\n\nKline remembers being dismissed when he initially approached various philanthropic organizations about finding young people with disabilities that prevented them from pushing themselves through the typical wheelchair division of a marathon.\n\nHe said the charities \u201ctold me it was a dumb idea\u201d and insisted that their clients would prefer visiting a theme park to being pushed through a marathon.\n\nBut Kline knew he needed a new approach to running. He was getting almost bored after competing in marathons for more than a decade. He had qualified for and run in the Boston Marathon, and he had done ultras \u2014 races even longer than marathons. But the goals he had set for himself no longer seemed all-consuming.\n\nSo Kline persisted in seeking a rider-athlete \u2014 his preferred term for Marathons With Meaning partners \u2014 and found Taylor Little. Their time in that debut race in Las Vegas was more than an hour and a half slower than Kline\u2019s best as a solo marathoner: 3:55 at the same event five years earlier. But speed was beside the point. He had rediscovered his passion.\n\nLittle\u2019s mother, Eden Capsouto, said she too had felt the emotional tug of inclusion.\n\n\u201cI was waiting at the sideline as the mother of an athlete,\u201d she said. \u201cIt was very cool.\u201d", "title": "When Running Is More Than a Sport", "authors": ["Gina Kolata"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Likewise, if you suffer a loss, that should also be reported on your tax return.\n\nI\u2019ve successfully \u2018mined\u2019 Bitcoins. Now what?\n\nAll Bitcoin transactions are recorded in a public ledger maintained by a decentralized network of computers. Mining refers to the process in which new Bitcoins are created and then awarded to the computers that are the first to process these transactions coming onto the network. The people whose computers do this most quickly collect a fresh helping of Bitcoins.\n\nThese virtual miners must report the fair market value of the currency (on the day they received it) as gross income. Miners are also required to pay self-employment tax \u2014 that is, Social Security and Medicare taxes \u2014 if the mining \u201cconstitutes a trade or business,\u201d according to the I.R.S.\n\nI was paid in Bitcoin. Are there any special tax consequences?\n\nReceiving wages from an employer in a virtual currency is like being paid in dollars: It is taxable to the employee, must be reported by the employer on a Form W-2 and is subject to federal income tax withholding, according to Wolters Kluwer.\n\nIndependent contractors paid in digital currency must also treat that as gross income and pay self-employment taxes.\n\nWhat if I paid someone else in Bitcoin for their services?\n\nWhen you pay an independent worker (not on your payroll) in excess of $600 for services performed for your \u201ctrade or business,\u201d that should be reported to the I.R.S. and the person receiving the payment (generally using Form 1099-MISC). The same rules apply when an individual is paid in virtual currency with an equivalent value.\n\nCan I reduce my tax bill by donating my cryptocoins?\n\nPotentially. Only people who itemize their tax returns can deduct their charitable contributions. But under the new tax code, far fewer people are likely to itemize starting with their 2018 return.", "title": "When Trading in Bitcoin, Keep the Tax Man in Mind", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cTrump Ordered Mueller\u2019s Firing but Was Refused\u201d (front page, Jan. 26):\n\nNow we know that President Trump tried to fire the special prosecutor, Robert Mueller, back in June, but the White House counsel, Donald McGahn, threatened to quit if Mr. Trump followed through with the firing. Does that surprise anyone? No. The only thing that is surprising is that it took us so long to find out about it.\n\nMr. McGahn obviously knew that in firing Mr. Mueller, the president would be playing political Russian roulette (pun intended), and it would be reminiscent of the Watergate Saturday Night Massacre in 1973, when President Richard Nixon told Attorney General Elliot Richardson to fire the special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, and Mr. Richardson and his deputy resigned rather than do so.\n\nDoes anyone think that Mr. Trump will actually face Mr. Mueller and answer all the questions that Mr. Trump\u2019s misconduct demands? Very unlikely. What if Mr. Mueller issues a subpoena and Mr. Trump refuses to comply? As damaging as it would be, I believe that Mr. Trump will refuse to answer any questions on the grounds that it may tend to incriminate him.\n\nThe Republicans supporting Mr. Trump will never impeach him, no matter what he does. But if the Democrats take both houses of Congress after the 2018 midterm election, Mr. Trump\u2019s presidency will be over.", "title": "Opinion | When Trump Tried to Fire Mueller", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Reviving downtown would mean looking past financial services. Many older skyscrapers along Wall Street and lower Broadway, unappealing to commercial tenants, were rezoned as residential towers, their conversion accelerated by some sweet tax abatements engineered by Mr. Giuliani and the New York State Senate. New York Magazine trumpeted a \u201cWall Street Wonderland,\u201d and cooed that stodgy Wall Street would soon have blazing web speeds of 128 kilobits per second, accessible somewhere called a \u201ccyber cafe.\u201d Lagging construction on the landfill of Battery Park City, first planned by the architects Alexander Cooper and Stanton Eckstut as a tree-lined antithesis to the World Trade Center superblock, started to accelerate. The arrival of Stuyvesant High School in 1992 preceded the erection of more than a dozen condominium buildings on the far side of the West Side Highway; a large 3-D model of the island\u2019s southern tip at the museum lets you follow their construction.\n\nLower Manhattan also began to embrace its own heritage, as landlords who once valued only commercial viability now saw the buildings\u2019 residential and touristic appeal. No fewer than 20 towers were declared landmarks in the neighborhood in the latter half of the 1990s, among them the opulent Standard Oil building at 26 Broadway, the Art Deco Downtown Athletic Club at 20 West Street and the home of Delmonico\u2019s steak house at 56 Beaver Street. Stanchions erected along Broadway and other thoroughfares plotted a new sequence of Heritage Trails, which were proposed by the recently deceased architect Richard D. Kaplan, and presented the area\u2019s Dutch and British colonial history and legacy of commercial construction.\n\nIf you want to see the true ethos of 1990s Manhattan, though, it\u2019s the unrealized projects in \u201cMillennium\u201d that speak loudest. Along with Kaplan, the architect James Sanders proposed a retrofitting of Liberty Plaza Park (now Zuccotti Park, the site of the Occupy Wall Street protests in 2011) that aimed to flush financial data out of the skyscrapers and onto the streets. An axonometric rendering here shows massive, Tokyo-style LED screens promoting GeoCities, Lycos and other children of the dot-com bubble, as well as a live broadcast from the stock exchange floor by a young Maria Bartiromo. Though never built, the Liberty Plaza project encapsulated a newly digitized, 24-hour economy; the architects even imagined that passers-by could buy and sell stock on their newfangled flip phones.", "title": "When Wall Street Was Unoccupied", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.\n\nI have been with the same company for 20 years, rising through the ranks in that time. However, I have been planning to leave, and even started working toward a professional certification in another field. Then my supervisor got promoted, and most colleagues assumed that, based on my position and experience, I would be the replacement. Every bone in my body told me not to apply \u2014 but every friend, family member and colleague (especially the ones who knew I was plotting an escape) said I would be passing up an opportunity to make my r\u00e9sum\u00e9 look better. I applied, and got the job. I can\u2019t stand it. There are not enough hours in the week to get everything done, and I end up doing my work poorly and neglecting my family in the process. My supervisor says I knew what I was getting into. But now I want out even more. I finished that certification, but is it best to wait a year before I bail? If not, how do I explain a short stint in a new position to potential employers, without sounding negative? \u2014 ANONYMOUS\n\nIf you cannot stand your job, you should be looking for a new one, as actively as possible. Don\u2019t waste time being hard on yourself. It\u2019s often the case that someone who has decided to switch fields entirely must overcome the urge to delay making such a big move.\n\nAnd sure, in retrospect, you probably should have trusted your instinct and ignored everyone else. But that\u2019s hindsight. It\u2019s often good to get the advice of others who know you and your situation and who might be able to offer a useful perspective. Maybe you would have regretted it if you hadn\u2019t given the new position a shot. Who knows?\n\nThe point is that now you know: Taking the promotion was a mistake. Not only are you unhappy, but it sounds like your supervisor and your family aren\u2019t pleased, either. Why prolong this a single minute longer than necessary? If you\u2019re really ready to jump to a new path, get on with it!\n\nTo answer questions about a short stint on your r\u00e9sum\u00e9, just tell the truth, but with a forward-looking focus: You had been planning this change for a while and delayed it when you were offered a promotion. But that has only underscored your certainty that it\u2019s time to move on, and you\u2019re way more excited about what lies ahead in your new chosen field.", "title": "When You Take a Promotion, but Still Want to Move On", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Last fall, Energy Secretary Rick Perry proposed to slow this trend by shielding some coal and nuclear plants from market forces in order to protect the \u201creliability and resiliency of our nation\u2019s grid.\u201d\n\nHis idea was fiercely opposed, partly because it was clumsy and legally dubious, but also because propping up coal plants would only hurt natural gas and renewable energy. Those industries made their displeasure known. (On Monday, federal regulators rejected Mr. Perry\u2019s proposal.)\n\nYou see this zero-sum competition pop up everywhere. Some states have worried that letting their nuclear plants retire in favor of natural gas would increase greenhouse gas emissions. Many lawmakers have proposed subsidies to keep those reactors running. But in states like Pennsylvania, the gas industry has lobbied hard against this idea.\n\nAnd some local utilities have fought policies that encourage homeowners to install solar panels on their roofs, not least because it would cut into their own already-stagnating sales.\n\nEconomists have long argued that there\u2019s a simple solution to this mess: Let\u2019s just price greenhouse gas emissions to account for the damage caused by global warming (say, with a carbon tax) and then let the market sort out the appropriate energy mix. But, of course, the United States doesn\u2019t have a carbon tax \u2014 instead we have a complicated patchwork of energy policies that are endlessly tweaked and lobbied over. And now that electricity use has stopped growing quickly, everyone\u2019s left fighting over crumbs.\n\n\u2018Climate change\u2019 disappears", "title": "When You\u2019ve Seen Fire and You\u2019ve Seen Rain, Expect Mudslides", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Elections are really the only way to change a board, said Mary Ann Rothman, the executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums. \u201cDemocracy is hard work,\u201d she said. \u201cYou have to attend meetings, vote in elections and consider serving on the board.\u201d\n\nBut even fully engaged shareholders can sometimes find their votes undermined.\n\nSteven Gursky and his wife were well aware of the conflicts that can arise when they moved into the co-op at 35 Sutton Place on the Upper East Side of Manhattan eight years ago. \u201cWe made a commitment to each other to stay out of the co-op fray,\u201d he said. That vow didn\u2019t last long.\n\nMr. Gursky said that some residents did not get along with the board president, Stanley Bell, and were trying to replace board members aligned with him. In the 2015 election, an opposition group had an opportunity to flip the balance of power. But when the vote totals were released, one insurgent candidate lost by 1,403 votes, according to a lawsuit filed against the co-op. (Just as with any corporation, each shareholder receives one vote for each share owned, with owners of larger apartments receiving more shares.)\n\nThe lawsuit also claimed that the building superintendent tried to pressure a shareholder to vote for the incumbent by suggesting that the election of new board members could delay her apartment renovation. And Mr. Gursky, a partner at the law firm Olshan Frome Wolosky, had a hunch that the 4,560 votes of that shareholder, who supported the insurgent candidate, had not been counted.\n\nA group of shareholders decided to sue when the managing agent confirmed that the votes in question were never counted. Since shareholders have to fund any legal action on their own, Mr. Gursky\u2019s firm took on the case at a reduced rate.\n\nA State Supreme Court judge in Manhattan ruled that all the votes had to be counted, giving the insurgent candidate the victory. Mr. Bell, who eventually left the board, did not respond to requests for comment. The superintendent was let go, and Mr. Gursky believes that the building, which has a new roof deck and a renovated lobby, is now much better managed.", "title": "When a Co-op Board Misbehaves", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "About a dozen sessions later, my friend came away with critical insights: \u201cI know I\u2019m not perfect. I was very focused on taking care of my son, and my husband wasn\u2019t getting from me whatever he needed. Everybody should be allowed to make mistakes and learn from them. We learned how to talk to each other and really listen. I love him and respect him, I\u2019m so happy we didn\u2019t split apart. He\u2019s a wonderful father, a stimulating partner, and while our marriage isn\u2019t perfect \u2014 whose is? \u2014 we are supportive and nurturing of each other. Working through the affair made us stronger.\u201d\n\nAs happened with my friend, most affairs result from dissatisfaction with the marital relationship, fueled by temptation and opportunity. One partner may spend endless hours and days on work, household chores, outside activities or even social media, to the neglect of their spouse\u2019s emotional and sexual needs. Often betrayed partners were unaware of what was lacking in the relationship and did not suspect that trouble was brewing.\n\nOr the problem may result from a partner\u2019s personal issues, like an inability to deal with conflict, a fear of intimacy, deep-seated insecurity or changes in life circumstances that rob the marital relationship of the attention and affection that once sustained it.\n\nBut short of irreversible incompatibility or physical or emotional abuse, with professional counseling and a mutual willingness to preserve the marriage, therapists maintain that couples stand a good chance of overcoming the trauma of infidelity and avoiding what is often the more painful trauma of divorce.\n\nMs. Weiner-Davis points out that \u201cexcept in the most severe cases such as ongoing physical abuse or addiction,\u201d divorce often creates more problems than it solves, an observation that prompted her to write her first book, \u201cDivorce Busting.\u201d\n\nMs. Weiner-Davis readily admits that recovering from infidelity is hard work and the process cannot be rushed. Yet, as she wrote in her new book, \u201cmany clients have shared that had it not been for their partner\u2019s affair, they\u2019d never have looked at, discussed, and healed some of the underlying issues that were broken at the foundation of their relationship.\u201d\n\nRather than destroying the marriage, the affair acted as a catalyst for positive changes, Ms. Weiner-Davis maintains. In her new book, she outlines tasks for both the betrayed spouse and the unfaithful one that can help them better understand and meet the emotional and physical needs of their partners.", "title": "When a Partner Cheats", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "By the time the term ends in June, the justices will decide whether people can be forced to choose between their right to express themselves and their right to vote.\n\nThe case started when members of the Minnesota Voters Alliance, which says it works to ensure \u201celection integrity,\u201d turned up at Minnesota polling places wearing T-shirts bearing Tea Party logos and buttons saying \u201cPlease I.D. Me.\u201d\n\nThey were told to cover the messages and were allowed to vote even if they refused. But they risked prosecution for disobeying polls workers\u2019 orders.\n\nThe group and two individuals challenged the law on free speech grounds, and they lost in the lower courts. A trial judge said the \u201cPlease I.D. Me\u201d buttons were particularly problematic because they were \u201cpart of an orchestrated effort to falsely intimate to voters in line at the polls that photo identification is required in order to vote in Minnesota.\u201d\n\nThe United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, in St. Louis, upheld the law.\n\n\u201cEven if Tea Party apparel is not election-related, it is not unreasonable to prohibit it in a polling place,\u201d Judge Duane Benton wrote. \u201cIn order to ensure a neutral, influence-free polling place, all political material is banned.\u201d\n\nThe Supreme Court case is not centered on the particular items the challengers wanted to wear. It is instead a general challenge to the law, saying it is overbroad and vague even if the particular items could constitutionally be barred.\n\nThe Minnesota law is certainly written in broad terms. \u201cA political badge, political button or other political insignia may not be worn at or about a polling place on primary or election day,\u201d its key provision says.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nState officials have interpreted the law to bar not only campaign buttons and the like but also any apparel that takes a position on a contested political issue or promotes \u201ca group with recognizable political views (such as the Tea Party, MoveOn.org and so on).\u201d\n\nWhen the case was argued in the Eighth Circuit, the state\u2019s lawyer said the law could apply to T-shirts bearing the logos of the Chamber of Commerce or a labor union.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn dissent, Judge Bobby E. Shepherd wondered why \u201cthe presence of a passive and peaceful voter\u201d wearing a T-shirt would disrupt polling places. Among the T-shirts banned by the law, Judge Shepherd said, were ones promoting the American Legion, Veterans of Foreign Wars, the National Rifle Association, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the N.A.A.C.P.\n\nThe state has an important precedent on its side.\n\nIn a 1992 decision, Burson v. Freeman, the Supreme Court upheld a Tennessee law that created a 100-foot buffer zone around polling places. But that law was aimed at traditional campaign signs and posters, not apparel bearing more general messages.\n\nThe Supreme Court upheld the Tennessee law. Justice Harry A. Blackmun, writing for a four-member plurality, said it was needed to combat \u201cvoter intimidation and election fraud.\u201d\n\nLaws like the one in Tennessee are fairly easy to enforce. The Minnesota law, and similar ones in at least nine other states, require difficult on-the-spot judgments about what apparel qualifies as political. Those decisions, moreover, are often made by temporary poll workers rather than seasoned government officials.\n\nSuch workers can make odd calls. In 2012, a young woman wearing an M.I.T. sweatshirt was stopped by a confused Denver poll worker who thought she was electioneering on behalf of Mitt Romney, a presidential candidate.\n\nA supervisor intervened, explaining that the initials on the shirt stood for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.\n\n\u201cThere was only one \u2018T,\u2019 so the voter was not electioneering,\u201d Alton Dillard, a spokesman for the Denver Clerk and Recorder\u2019s Office, explained.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnother poll worker tried to stop a Houston woman from voting in the 2008 election because she was wearing an Alaska T-shirt. Sarah Palin, then the state\u2019s governor, was running for vice president.\n\nAgain, cooler heads prevailed.\n\nSimilar problems have arisen in the Supreme Court\u2019s backyard. A few years ago, I saw a court police officer order a man wearing a \u201cGuns Save Lives\u201d button on the Supreme Court plaza to remove it.\n\n\u201cNo political logos on the plaza,\u201d an officer said.\n\nI asked the officer for his reasoning. \u201cYou can\u2019t interview people on the plaza,\u201d he responded.\n\nHe was part of a long tradition. A Supreme Court police officer once threatened a woman with arrest for displaying a sign bearing the verbatim text of the First Amendment.\n\nWhether at a polling place or on the Supreme Court plaza, decorum is a worthy goal. But so is the robust debate protected by the First Amendment.", "title": "When a T-Shirt Gets You in Trouble at the Voting Booth", "authors": ["Adam Liptak"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "While it\u2019s in keeping with his previous work, tonally and substantively, it holds a distinct place in the author\u2019s mind. It was inspired, in part, by the 2008 death of his father, Franklin H. Epstein, an academic physician, from brain cancer at 84.\n\nIn the weeks after his father\u2019s disease had been diagnosed, Mr. Epstein said, \u201cI realized that I had never had a direct conversation with him about any of what I had learned from Buddhism. He was proud of me as a doctor and liked my books, but he wasn\u2019t drawn to it. But then I thought, \u2018Oh no, he\u2019s going to die and I\u2019ve never even really tried to convey what\u2019s helped me about anticipating death from meditation, from Buddhism.\u2019 \u201d\n\nThat worry drove Mr. Epstein to pick up the phone and call his father. It was also the first germ for the contents and the title of \u201cAdvice Not Given,\u201d in which he offers counsel that he might previously have kept to himself. \u201cThis stuff has helped me so much, I don\u2019t want to be withholding it\u201d from patients \u201cout of some sense of not being too pushy,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Epstein, 64, lives in TriBeCa with his wife, the sculptor Arlene Shechet, and he sees patients in the same building, in the unassuming basement office in which we spoke on a frigid afternoon in late December. The office\u2019s walls, a pale blue, are unadorned. Mr. Epstein\u2019s desk and the books that surround it are tucked away from the uncluttered space in which he sits with patients.\n\nMr. Epstein, who has had his private practice since 1986, was in his teens when he first felt drawn to the spiritual and professional paths he would pursue.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome young men join rock bands to meet young women. Mr. Epstein took an introduction to world religions class. His romantic interest in one particular classmate at Harvard didn\u2019t last, but he fell for some lines in a book of Buddhist scripture called the Dhammapada. \u201cThere was a verse, something like: \u2018Look to your mind, wise man \u2014 it is subtle, invisible, treacherous,\u2019 \u201d he said.\n\nThere were \u201clittle bits of Buddhism floating around\u201d at Harvard in those days, Mr. Epstein said, as the age of psychedelia gave way to the age of consciousness studies. He befriended fellow travelers, including Daniel Goleman, later a science writer for The Times who was then a graduate student and teaching fellow. Mr. Goleman had visited India to study meditation. \u201cI knew he knew something that I wanted to know,\u201d Mr. Epstein said. \u201cMostly, he was wearing these purple bell-bottom pants that I thought were really cool.\u201d\n\nMr. Epstein flashes a sense of humor with some frequency in person, one that mischievously cuts against the soberly reflective presence you might expect from the books (and that you also get). He has the wiry frame of a regular yoga practitioner, and an enviable thicket of gray hair. You might feel torn, sitting across from him, between asking for advice on how to cope with the transient nature of reality and for advice on high-quality conditioning products.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIn person he is gentle and insightful in a quiet and humorous way,\u201d said Robert Thurman, an expert on Tibetan Buddhism and a professor at Columbia University, in an email interview. Mr. Thurman is a longtime friend of Mr. Epstein, and has taught and lectured alongside him. \u201cPeople are automatically drawn to him, wishing they had a shrink like that. Other shrinks also seek him out in personal workshops, and I think tend to emulate him.\u201d\n\nDespite his gentle disposition, Mr. Epstein is tough-minded. \u201cPeople expect too much from meditation,\u201d he said. He doesn\u2019t peddle a version of Buddhist insight for Westerners eager to utilize it for quick-acting self-help or self-actualization. As he wrote in \u201cGoing to Pieces Without Falling Apart\u201d (1998): \u201cWhat I had learned from Buddhism was that I did not have to know myself analytically as much as I had to tolerate not knowing.\u201d\n\nThe problem with the ego, according to Mr. Epstein, is that it wants so badly to know. \u201cThe ego comes into being when we\u2019re two or three or four years old,\u201d he said, \u201cjust feeling our own separateness and how difficult it is to navigate the external pressures from parents and teachers, and the internal pressures of one\u2019s biology, one\u2019s drives and so on. The ego wants security and stability and coherence. It\u2019s rooted in the intellect, so it tells stories. It fastens on to the first stories that start to make sense, both positive and negative.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWe then incessantly repeat these stories to ourselves \u201cunder our breath,\u201d as Mr. Epstein writes in the new book. The classic stubborn story dealt with in therapy, he said, can be summarized in four words: \u201cThe problem is me.\u201d And the low self-esteem reinforced by such stories \u201cis as much ego as the puffed-up, \u2018I\u2019m the best,\u2019 competitive, American way we ordinarily think of the ego.\u201d\n\nDespite his good shape (and his good genes; his mother, Sherrie Epstein, is 93), Mr. Epstein, in the middle of his seventh decade, is not far from the phase of life about which he counseled his father. Asked how he feels about the prospect of his own ultimate impermanence \u2014 death, to the rest of us \u2014 Mr. Epstein said with a laugh: \u201cI feel frightened about ultimate impermanence. But with a little bit of a sense of humor, somehow. There\u2019s something a little bit exciting, even within all the fear, about literally not knowing what\u2019s going to come next.\u201d\n\nAnd what did he tell his father about what comes next?\n\n\u201c \u2018I don\u2019t know if you want to hear this or not, but I don\u2019t want to keep it from you either,\u2019 \u201d Mr. Epstein recalls saying. \u201c \u2018You know that place in yourself that hasn\u2019t really changed subjectively from when you were a young man, or 20, 40, 60, 80? You still sort of feel the same to yourself inside, but if you try to find that place you can\u2019t really put your finger on it?\u2019 \u201d He then told his father what he believed he had learned about how to relax the mind into that \u201cinvisible space where you are who you\u2019ve always been\u201d as the body fades away. \u201cHe was very nice. He said, \u2018O.K., darling. I\u2019ll try.\u2019 \u201d", "title": "When a Therapist Puts Buddhism Into Practice", "authors": ["John Williams"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Even before LeBron James publicly chided the Knicks this fall for not drafting Smith at No. 8, Ntilikina and Smith were unavoidably linked. It all started back in May, when the Mavericks made a public show of their interest in Ntilikina, a French teenager, and were thus widely expected to select him at No. 9.\n\nThe team did little to mask the troop of scouts it sent in to see Ntilikina play for his French club (SIG Strasbourg) in May. The delegation featured Donnie Nelson, the president of basketball operations, and his top aide, Tony Ronzone. Cuban then traveled to Italy to have breakfast with Ntilikina in June at a pre-draft camp in Treviso and posed with the lanky guard for a photograph that quickly circulated.\n\nWhen it subsequently emerged that the Mavericks had arranged for Vincent Collet, Ntilikina\u2019s club coach at Strasbourg and the coach of the France national team, to become the head coach of their summer-league squad in Las Vegas in July, Dallas appeared to be going to extremes to welcome Ntilikina to North Texas.\n\nYet it was all something of a ruse. That whole time Dallas was growing infatuated with Smith, a 6-foot-3 North Carolina State freshman, despite well-publicized concerns about a knee injury he had suffered in high school and whispers of selfishness and moodiness when the Wolfpack struggled. With Nowitzki, the future Hall of Fame big man, heading into his 20th season and the Mavericks openly desperate for new players to build around, Smith became the preference because of a perceived higher ceiling.\n\nSo when Jackson, in the last major move of his rocky three-year tenure as the Knicks\u2019 president, leaned on his long-held fondness for big guards and took Ntilikina with the eighth pick, Cuban and his staff celebrated in the Dallas draft room at a pitch unrivaled since the Mavericks\u2019 championship season of 2010-11.\n\nThe club seems even giddier about its draft pick after having him for a half-season. The Mavericks market Smith, 20, and his uber-athleticism as aggressively as they promote Nowitzki, with confidence that Smith\u2019s recent triple-double against New Orleans was merely a glimpse of the future.", "title": "When the Knicks Visit Dallas, Only One Thing Will Be Missing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "On Oct. 15 at 8 a.m., Andy Lindsay stood atop 21,247-foot Mera Peak in Nepal, a wildly improbable place for him to be both athletically and medically.\n\nAndy, a veteran climber and a friend of mine, had been living with Stage IV lung cancer for three years. \u201cTo live one year was statistically unlikely, and two years looked like a miracle,\u201d he said.\n\nHe was able to make the climb thanks to the success of a cutting-edge targeted therapy clinical trial. It targeted his specific lung cancer mutation, shutting off the fuel to his tumor\u2019s growth and shrinking the tumor. He wasn\u2019t cured, but his scans were strikingly improved and he was almost symptom-free.\n\nThe trip illustrates a shifting landscape both for oncologists and cancer patients exploring a return to active lifestyles. Dr. Tomas Neilan, the director of the cardio-oncology program at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, and part of Andy\u2019s medical team, said the recent success of these targeted therapy treatments alters the way specialists like him view and treat advanced cancer patients.", "title": "When the Lung Cancer Patient Climbs Mountains", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn their first documentaries, the brothers Albert and David Maysles portrayed media stars like Truman Capote, Marlon Brando and the Beatles. Then they realized the movie camera might make anyone a star. The feature documentary that cemented the Maysles\u2019s reputation centered on a middle-aged huckster selling Bibles door-to-door and seemingly at the end of his road. Attention must be paid.\n\n\u201cSalesman,\u201d playing for a week at Metrograph in a new digital restoration, was not without controversy when it opened in 1969. The Village Voice critic Jonas Mekas, an early defender of the American version of cin\u00e9ma v\u00e9rit\u00e9 \u2014 or what the Maysles called direct cinema \u2014 found the movie pointlessly bleak. Vincent Canby, who reviewed it in The New York Times, confessed to having seen \u201cSalesman\u201d three times and to being increasingly impressed with each viewing.\n\nIn a way, \u201cSalesman\u201d moved into the territory opened up a decade before with the publication of Robert Frank\u2019s 1959 collection of photographs, \u201cThe Americans.\u201d Mr. Frank was subjected to critical abuse for his downbeat vision of seedy bus depots, all-night diners, garish billboards and empty highways. \u201cSalesman\u201d might be a feature-length elaboration of a Frank photograph.\n\nThe movie\u2019s designated star, Paul Brennan, is part of a four-man team working for the Mid-American Bible Company. His sales are off, but with a gift of gab and a clich\u00e9 for every occasion, his performance seldom flags. As every sale is a drama in which the salesmen basically sell themselves, the movie has a grim absurdist quality, not least at a company sales meeting in which a motivational speaker tells them that, like Jesus, they are doing \u201cthe Father\u2019s business.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nReligion, per se, never enters the salesmen\u2019s private conversations and is not crucial to their spiels. \u201cThe best seller in the world is the Bible,\u201d Paul begins his pitch, pushing an illustrated version that, although not inlaid with pearl, costs $50 (about $350 today when adjusted for inflation). \u201cIt\u2019s the greatest piece of literature in the world.\u201d And you can buy it on time.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOpening in snowy Boston (where the Maysles themselves once sold encyclopedias), \u201cSalesman\u201d moves to southern Florida. The most surreal episode has Paul lost in Opa-locka, a Miami neighborhood developed around an Arabian Nights theme. \u201cI was in the Muslim district,\u201d he explains to his colleagues. \u201cIf I told anybody about it, they\u2019d think I was drinking again.\u201d\n\n\u201cSalesman\u201d is edited by Charlotte Zwerin, whom the Maysles list as a co-creator, to conclude with a cascade of failures, among them a futile attempt to sell a Bible to a salesman of vacuum cleaners. Hoberman"]} {"date": "2017-12-31 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWhen Families Fall Out\u201d (Science Times, Dec. 26): I have experienced the heartbreaking trauma that results when a daughter cuts off herself and her three children from her parents and her entire extended family, without a clear reason. One of the main pillars of our Muslim-Judeo-Christian heritage is forgiveness. When all communication is cut off, there is no opportunity for understanding, apology or a plea for forgiveness.\n\nOur daughter was raised in a warm and loving family with all of her needs lovingly provided. There was no abuse, no addiction, no neglect. Right now it appears that my seriously ill husband and I will die without ever seeing her again.\n\nIt has obliterated trusting family communication because of the pain and hurt experienced by her immediate and extended relatives. Holidays become torture. Nine years have gone by without a word or a response to our many attempts to reach out. In some ways, a death would be easier: There would be no wondering or hoping that the separation might be reversed.\n\nMARTHA R. BIRNBAUM\n\nTAMPA, FLA.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nOur cultural myths about motherhood \u2014 that all women are nurturing, that mothering is instinctual, that all mothers are loving \u2014 are the bedrock on which the myths about estrangement rest. The culture puts the adult child who initiates a cutoff or goes \u201clow contact\u201d on trial and labels him or her an ingrate, disrespectful or impulsive.", "title": "Opinion | When the Parent-Child Bond Is Cut", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "As the global governing elite gathered in Davos, Switzerland, for the annual World Economic Forum this week, a classic horror movie came to my mind. Perhaps you remember the scene from \u201cWhen a Stranger Calls\u201d where a panicked babysitter, stalked by phone, gets on the line with a police officer. The quiet terror of the officer\u2019s words: \u201cWe\u2019ve traced the call. It\u2019s coming from inside the house.\u201d Then: \u201cJust get out!\u201d\n\nAt Davos, the stranger in the house was President Trump, an internationalist\u2019s nightmare from whom there is no near term escape. The high priests of globalism hoped that by inviting Mr. Trump into their home and treating him with respect, they could exorcise his demonic worldview. For a day at least, they succeeded. Mr. Trump\u2019s uncharacteristically sober speech on Friday focused on \u201can America that is open for business.\u201d He played effectively to a subset of the Davos community, business executives, that likes Mr. Trump\u2019s corporate tax cuts and deregulatory zeal.\n\nStill, Mr. Trump\u2019s restrained performance could not overcome the widespread conviction that he remains possessed by the dark forces of nationalism, populism, protectionism, unilateralism and xenophobia. And his remarks failed to address the issues of greatest concern to the Davos die-hards.\n\nEvery year, the forum asks its members what keeps them up at night. This year\u2019s winners: cybersecurity breaches, self-defeating trade wars, disruptive climate change and the rising danger of military conflicts in which large countries are drawn into regional battles.", "title": "Opinion | When the Stranger Who Calls Is the American President", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "The word \u201cgentrification\u201d was coined almost offhandedly in 1964, by the British sociologist Ruth Glass, in an essay about postwar London. Looking around her, she saw a city becoming more modern and affluent. This came with certain ills: Commutes were getting longer, traffic worse, middle-class jobs more specialized (\u201cproject engineer\u201d; \u201csystem analyst\u201d) and menial ones more scarce. And something striking was happening in the working-class parts of town. They were being \u201cinvaded by the middle classes \u2014 upper and lower.\u201d These newcomers were buying up the \u201cshabby, modest mews and cottages\u201d and turning them into \u201celegant, expensive residences.\u201d \u201cOnce this process of \u2018gentrification\u2019 starts in a district,\u201d Glass writes, \u201cit goes on rapidly until all or most of the working-class occupiers are displaced, and the whole social character of the district is changed.\u201d\n\nHer coinage contained within it an ambiguity that persists to this day. The root of \u201cgentrification\u201d \u2014 \u201cgentry\u201d \u2014 can refer either to those of not-quite-aristocratic birth or to those who profit from land ownership; either to the well-off in general or to the rentier class in particular. This lack of clarity is fitting: In a gentrifying neighborhood, title to the land is transferred first in the literal sense and then in the spiritual one, as local businesses and institutions change to serve the tastes of wealthier arrivals. To use \u201cgentrification\u201d to describe lifestyle trends is to focus on that second step rather than the first one \u2014 to focus on class signifiers instead of class itself.\n\nLast year, the academics Jason Patch, John Joe Schlichtman and Marc Lamont Hill published a book about gentrification that examined their own roles in the process, branding themselves right in the title: \u201cGentrifier.\u201d This is another fascinating new twist on Glass\u2019s term. After all, Britain\u2019s rigid class system made it easy enough for her to clearly identify the people doing the gentrifying: It was the gentry. Here in the States, though, we\u2019ve adopted a novel word meaning \u201cone who gentrifies\u201d \u2014 the active colonist, someone who tries on neighborhoods like shirts at a thrift shop. This turns gentrification into a lifestyle choice. Hence the scores of listicles that have cropped up on websites that cater to well-meaning millennials, working either to steer the budding gentrifier in a noble direction (Thought Catalog\u2019s \u201c10 Rules for Being a Good Gentrifier From an Urban Planner in Brooklyn\u201d) or to suggest that she might avoid the epithet while still participating in the process (AlterNet\u2019s \u201c20 Ways Not to Be a Gentrifier\u201d). Invariably these articles suggest shopping locally, talking to your neighbors and, above all, being self-aware about your impact. Befriending your bodega guy is a great thing to do, but it\u2019s of limited assistance when the landlord triples his rent.\n\nIf the logic of conscious consumerism has come to infect what we mean by \u201cgentrification,\u201d perhaps it\u2019s because the process always begins with people who are expected to know better: the \u201ccreative class.\u201d In a 1979 book called \u201cNeighborhood Renewal,\u201d the urban theorist Phillip L. Clay outlined four stages of gentrification: In the first, \u201cpioneers\u201d \u2014 often bohemians and artists \u2014 move to dilapidated or abandoned areas in search of cheaper rents; in the second, the middle classes follow; in the third, their numbers displace the original population; and in the final stage, the neighborhood is fully turned over to banks, developers and the wealthy. By this point, the artists are being priced out to another subway stop or another city \u2014 where they will be greeted as though they\u2019ve come seeking adventure.\n\nBut the journalist Peter Moskowitz, in the 2017 book \u201cHow to Kill a City,\u201d suggests a fifth stage should be added to Clay\u2019s list, so we can accommodate arrangements like those in Midtown Manhattan, where multimillion-dollar condominiums are built and sold to shell corporations, presumably owned by foreign billionaires, and often left vacant. \u201cThe fifth and last phase of gentrification,\u201d he writes, \u201cis when neighborhoods aren\u2019t just more friendly to capital than to people but cease being places to live a normal life.\u201d New York\u2019s skyline is erupting with buildings like these \u2014 stacks of cash-stuffed mattresses teetering in the wind. And The Times reported last year that the West Village\u2019s Bleecker Street had fallen victim to \u201chigh-rent blight,\u201d with commercial space becoming so expensive ($45,000 a month) that even Marc Jacobs couldn\u2019t keep his stores open; shops that once catered to the wealthy now sit empty, waiting for a tenant who can foot the bill. When the heist is done and it\u2019s time to split the loot, capital snuffs out culture.\n\nAnd yet it\u2019s culture \u2014 and its perceived appropriation \u2014 that has ingrained itself in the way we think about gentrification. It\u2019s almost as though, in the face of unstoppable, invisible forces, we\u2019ve grabbed hold of what we can see and control. Investors could buy and sell every building on your block without your ever noticing, but the coffee shop where the staff is mean to everybody is right in front of you. All the while, global flows of capital course through your metropolis, wearing down every bump and cranny. They will continue until the day it\u2019s finally as smooth and featureless as a river rock \u2014 and you\u2019re shopping around for a reasonably cozy van.", "title": "When \u2018Gentrification\u2019 Isn\u2019t About Housing", "authors": ["Willy Staley", "First Words"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "The company, which is based in Seattle, plans to invest $5 billion in development and create up to 50,000 jobs wherever it builds its newest hub. Among its criteria: more than one million residents, proximity to an airport, manageable commutes, diverse demographics, connectivity and local schools churning out potential employees.\n\nWith the kind of enthusiasm normally reserved for bids to host the Olympics, governors, mayors, business leaders and others have pulled together proposals promoting the potential of their cities and regions, sometimes going to outlandish lengths.\n\nThese are the places that caught Amazon\u2019s attention.\n\nAtlanta\n\nWhere the rare prospect of snow brings chills", "title": "Where Amazon May Build Its New Headquarters", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFRIDAY PUZZLE \u2014 I always enjoy solving Erik Agard\u2019s puzzles, and the fact that this puzzle is a nod to another constructor\u2019s style made me enjoy it even more. Mr. Agard gives a very nice shout out to that constructor in his notes below.\n\nExperimentation is the mother of innovation, and Mr. Agard has decided to try his hand at building a quad stack, which is composed of four rows of grid-spanning entries. The trick here is to make each one of these entries as interesting as possible, while also keeping an eye on the crossings. Constructors try their best to make these shorter crossings legitimate words, without too many partials or abbreviations. Mr. Agard did an excellent job, in my opinion. All four of the Across entries sparkle, and there are only two partials (A CAKE and AN IF). That\u2019s not bad for a 15-letter span.\n\nAnother thing that impressed me was the whopping 13 debut entries that Mr. Agard managed to get into his puzzle. But it\u2019s not the number of debuts alone; it\u2019s the quality of those entries that I like. THAT\u2019S A TALL ORDER, EACH ONE TEACH ONE, MAKE A FRESH START ... these are all terrific, and while A RAISIN IN THE SUN is not a debut, that\u2019s a terrific entry as well.\n\nIn addition, we have SPARE NO EXPENSE, VICTORIA\u2019S SECRET and INDEPENDENCE AVE, all great entries.\n\nTricky Clues\n\n35A: I didn\u2019t know what \u201clong john doughnuts\u201d were, but it wasn\u2019t hard to guess that the answer was ECLAIRS.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n40A: Tricky one! In today\u2019s puzzle, \u201cBig Apple?\u201d is not New York City, but the larger of the Apple products, the IMAC.\n\n55A: Not the gym. \u201cWhere people may order push-ups\u201d in today\u2019s puzzle is VICTORIA\u2019S SECRET.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nAlways wanted to do a quad stack. Probably won\u2019t go for the quint. Love and appreciation to the stack god Martin Ashwood-Smith, one of my favorite constructors to solve.\n\nNicely done, Mr. Agard.", "title": "Where Berber Is Spoken", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Hamoud and Ms. Labaki belong to a long line of women in Arab cinema. One of the most surprising things for me when I began to study the history of Arab cinema was how far back women\u2019s contributions to the medium goes. Since the early days of cinema in the Middle East, women have been active participants onscreen and behind the scenes. In the 1920s and \u201930s, women served as studio executives, writers and producers. In the 1970s and \u201980s, a number of the groundbreaking auteur filmmakers were women. The subjects that Ms. Hamoud and Ms. Labaki are taking on might seem pioneering and progressive, but in fact the previous generation of female directors tackled many of them.\n\nTake, for instance, the works of the Lebanese trio Heiny Srour, Randa Chahal Sabbag and Jocelyne Saab. Ms. Srour\u2019s first and only feature film, \u201cLeila and the Wolves\u201d (1984), spotlighted women\u2019s active participation in the wars in Israel-Palestine and Lebanon, both as facilitators and combatants, all the while touching on hot buttons such as honor killings, abusive marriages, the stigma of divorce and educations curtailed because of forced marriages. Ms. Srour was also the first Arab woman to have a film selected for Cannes (in 1974, for a documentary).\n\nSet and shot amid the Lebanese civil war, Ms. Saab\u2019s feature debut, \u201cA Suspended Life\u201d (1984), follows Samar, an independent-minded young girl reveling in the freedom afforded by warfare chaos. She thinks herself \u2014 and proclaims herself \u2014 \u201cfree\u201d and able to \u201cdo whatever I want,\u201d but the cost of her spirited wandering is a hymen-restoring operation imposed by her family.\n\nMs. Sabbag, who died in 2008, was equally provocative. Her early films include \u201cSand Screens\u201d (1991), a drama centering on a woman determined to lead an uninhibited life in a deeply conservative society, and the sarcastically titled \u201cA Civilized People\u201d (1999), which touches on such discomfiting topics as homosexuality, the ill treatment of immigrant house servants and religious acrimony in Lebanese society. (The Lebanese government banned the film.)\n\nMs. Srour, Ms. Saab and Ms. Sabbag are among the women featured in Rebecca Hillauer\u2019s \u201cEncyclopedia of Arab Women Filmmakers.\u201d Ms. Hillauer notes in the preface that the book started with an investigation into the question \u201cArab women filmmakers \u2014 do they exist?\u201d By the time she completed her research, she had enough material to expand what she had conceived as a small reference work into a tome of some 400 pages, covering women from Iraq to Egypt to Tunisia.", "title": "Opinion | Where Can Women Make Movies? The Middle East", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "He wrote that officials imprisoned about 700 herders around Jinyintan, accusing them of joining counterrevolutionary gangs. Seventeen died under brutal interrogation. Up to 9,000 herders were expelled in forced marches, given only a day or so to prepare and allowed to take just a few yaks per family. Hundreds died on the journey, beaten and abused by guards, Mr. Yin wrote.\n\n\u201cPeople were no better than beasts of burden,\u201d a surviving herder told an ethnic Mongolian researcher who published their accounts in a small Chinese magazine in 2007. \u201cWe weren\u2019t counted as humans.\u201d\n\nThe thousands of scientists, technicians and soldiers who poured into Project 221 knew little about what had preceded them. At its peak, Plant 221 had 18 workshops, labs and buildings scattered across 220 square miles, and up to 30,000 scientists, workers and guards lived there.\n\nBut even as the secret city forged ahead to build a hydrogen bomb, it was not immune to the political storms tearing China apart. In 1966, Mao launched the Cultural Revolution to purge and purify his movement, and the nuclear site \u2014 now politically suspect, having been built with the help of the hated Soviets \u2014 erupted in purges, interrogations and fighting between rival radical factions.\n\nMr. Wei, the retired physicist, said he watched as one of Plant 221\u2019s top scientists, Qian Jin, was clubbed by interrogators. Mr. Qian died a few days later. Officials detained and interrogated about 4,000 workers in the nuclear project, and about 50 were executed, beaten to death or killed themselves under the relentless accusations, according to Mr. Wei.\n\nThose events go unmentioned in the museum, and some former officials from the plant have urged Mr. Wei not to dwell on such tragedies, he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut he tells them there is no getting away from the past.\n\n\u201cI emphasize that we should reflect on it,\u201d Mr. Wei said. \u201cI still have dreams of 221.\u201d", "title": "Where China Built Its Bomb, Dark Memories Haunt the Ruins", "authors": ["Chris Buckley", "Adam Wu"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "With a nearly impenetrable hide covered in spikes, the ankylosaurus was like a dinosaur version of an armored tank. And like any battlefield behemoth, it boasted a fearsome weapon: a bone-crushing clubbed tail.\n\nThe ankylosaurus was not the only prehistoric beast to have an intimidating backside. Stegosaurus sported spear-like spikes on its tail. Some sauropods flailed fused clumps of bones from their posteriors toward predators.\n\nBut in living animals today, formidable tail weaponry is nearly absent. Though porcupines have quills and some lizards lash their tails when threatened, neither animal has the bony armaments seen millions of years ago. To help figure out why, a pair of paleontologists has pieced together a series of traits shared among extinct species that had weaponized their fifth extremity. Their study may help explain why tail weaponry has gone missing since dinosaurs and some ice age animals went extinct.", "title": "Where Did Animals With Tail Weapons Go? Here\u2019s a Back Story", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Are you someone who likes to travel \u2014 to other countries, neighboring cities or just to new sites in your hometown? If so, why do you enjoy traveling? If not, why not?\n\nEach year, The Times Travel section publishes a list of \u201c52 Places to Go.\u201d Here are a few of the destinations the editors suggest visiting in 2018:\n\nNew Orleans, Louisiana\n\nThere is no city in the world like New Orleans. Influences from Europe, the Caribbean, Latin America, Africa and indigenous peoples have made it the ultimate melting pot. And that diversity expresses itself in a multitude of ways that define New Orleans in the American imagination: music, food, language, and on and on. Though it\u2019s been a long recovery from Hurricane Katrina, New Orleans isn\u2019t just back on its feet, it is as vibrant as ever \u2014 particularly impressive for a 300-year-old. Colombia\n\nAfter over a half-century of civil war coming to a close, Colombia is eager to become the adventurous, cosmopolitan hot spot it deserves to be. While much work is needed to integrate former rebels back into society, foreign tourism rose 250 percent during the past decade. In the pulsating capital of Bogot\u00e1, dozens of luxe hotel chains have opened, while the food scene has gotten a boost from spots like Leonor Espinosa\u2019s restaurant Leo. Elsewhere, you will find coffee fincas turned into luxury hotels, eco-resorts on isolated desert peninsulas and colonial buildings transformed into spa retreats. Once off-limit attractions like Pacific Coast rain forests and the rainbow-color river Ca\u00f1o Cristales are now in every guidebook. Basilicata, Italy\n\nThis is a chance to visit Italy\u2019s southern region before the world catches on. Between the heel that is Puglia and the toe that is Calabria, you will find Basilicata, the arch of Italy\u2019s foot. Despite a storied and ancient past, the region has been overlooked in modern times. Easily Italy\u2019s best-kept secret, Basilicata is revered for beautiful beaches, ancient towns and a dearth of organized crime. In 2019, the town of Matera, a Unesco site, will host the European Capital of Culture. It is also known for its ancient caves \u2014 once used for livestock, later as primitive homes, and today, as private residences and hipster, beautifully restored, Flintstone-esque hotels. But for now at least, the secret is still safe. The Caribbean\n\nHurricanes Irma and Maria delivered a one-two punch to the Caribbean in 2017, battering many islands, including Dominica, Puerto Rico, Saint Martin and the United States Virgin Islands. While more than 70 percent of the tourism-dependent region was unaffected, hoteliers and tourism agencies across the islands banded together to help their neighbors and spread the word that business for one means survival for all.\n\nFor the first time this year, The Times has hired a travel writer to visit all 52 places on the list and write about them. The Travel editor received over 13,000 applications for the job from an amazing variety of people, from a father-daughter team to a best-selling author.", "title": "Where Do You Want to Travel?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPHILADELPHIA \u2014 This city\u2019s favorite sculpture is coming back to town in time for Valentine\u2019s Day after a yearlong renovation \u2014 and it will have a restored color scheme that may surprise some Philadelphians.\n\nThe \u201cLOVE\u201d sculpture, an 830-pound aluminum structure that has been the backdrop for countless marriage proposals and tourist selfies, stood on a downtown street corner for 41 years until last winter, when it was removed for repair and repainting, and to allow the rebuilding of the park where it is stationed.\n\nThe work by Robert Indiana was first installed on loan for the U.S. bicentennial celebrations in 1976 and was repainted twice using \u2014 in addition to its dominant red and green \u2014 a blue paint that turned out to be the wrong color.\n\nDuring the latest repainting, Mr. Indiana\u2019s representatives informed the conservators and the City of Philadelphia, which now owns the work, that the sections that had been painted blue should actually have been purple \u2014 a color that distinguishes Philadelphia\u2019s \u201cLOVE\u201d from the dozens of other versions in other American cities and around the world.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat was a head-scratcher for city officials because they couldn\u2019t remember purple anywhere on the sculpture, and the idea of repainting the iconic work in any way that was inauthentic verged on sacrilege.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI was astounded because no one here remembered it as anything but red, green and blue,\u201d said Margot Berg, the city\u2019s public art director. \u201cWe didn\u2019t have any photographs in the file of anything but red, green and blue.\u201d", "title": "Where Is the Love, Philadelphia? (It\u2019s Just Being Repainted)", "authors": ["Jon Hurdle"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Most intriguing were the mammal tracks.\n\n\u201cThe mammal track shape is very distinctive,\u201d Dr. Lockley said. \u201cActually they look a little bit like very, very small pads.\u201d\n\nFor most of the mammals that lived during this era, scientists have rarely found complete skeleton fossils. Instead, their knowledge is, more often than not, based on a scattered bone or tooth. Footprints have been found before, but usually a single impression on a stray piece of rock.\n\nHere, there are pairs of prints that show the left and right feet of the mammal in a sitting position. The scientists gave to these prints the name of Sederipes goddardensis, which \u201cliterally means sitting footprint,\u201d Dr. Lockley said.\n\nDr. Lockley said this was one of only two known sites where dozens of dinosaur-era mammal footprints had been found.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJohn Foster, executive director of the Museum of Moab in Utah, who was not involved in the research, said the findings were \u201cvery interesting to me, especially the mammal tracks and what they show about structure and probable behavior.\u201d\n\nThe discovery was made by serendipity and almost lost forever.\n\nRay Stanford, an amateur paleontologist who has become an expert on dinosaur tracks, had just dropped off his wife, Sheila, who worked at Goddard, after the two went for lunch in 2012.\n\nA few years earlier on the grounds of Goddard, Mr. Stanford had come across a loose rock with the footprint of a small three-toed theropod, and the brownish stone was the type of iron-rich sedimentary material that often preserves such prints.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs he was leaving the parking lot, he noticed rock of a similar color sticking out of the grass on a hill about 90 feet away. Mr. Stanford stopped the car and went to take a look, and spotted a prominent dinosaur footprint. \u201cLo and behold,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s a perfect large nodosaur. This one was beautiful. I was in ecstasy as a tracker.\u201d\n\nBut there was a problem. Goddard was about to rip up the parking lot and the hill and put a $31 million office building there. Officials called Compton J. Tucker, a Goddard scientist who has participated in geophysical surveys to find buried ruins at archaeological sites. Dr. Tucker recalled that as he listened, he thought, \u201cThis sounds kind of strange but it sounds interesting.\u201d\n\nAdditional examination revealed the baby nodosaur\u2019s footsteps and the sauropod print at the other end of the slab.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBefore construction of the building started, Dr. Tucker used ground-penetrating radar to search for other promising pieces of sandstone. Then an army of volunteers dug up those areas. But none of the other pieces turned out to be as interesting as the one Mr. Stanford had first spotted.\n\nStephen Godfrey, curator of paleontology at the Calvert Marine Museum in Solomons, Md., cleaned the rock and made a fiberglass cast of it. A couple of years later, the cast ended up in Mr. Stanford\u2019s basement, where he took a more careful and closer look.\n\nHe spotted the tracks of the four small theropods, all headed in the same direction, walking slowly. \u201cWhy were the theropods walking slowly?\u201d Mr. Stanford said. \u201cThese things were moving at less than half a mile per hour.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe then saw the steps of the mammals. \u201cThis was the real thing that hit me for a loop,\u201d Mr. Stanford said. \u201cTo see them with their potential predators.\u201d\n\nDr. Lockley came to Maryland about a year ago and stayed with Mr. Stanford to pore over the slab. After 80 footprints had been mapped, Mr. Stanford thought he was done. Then his wife walked up behind him, and pointed out a pterosaur footprint he had missed. She is a co-author on the paper.\n\nNone of the footprints on the slab overlap, indicating that the animals all passed in a short period of time, perhaps over a few hours or days, not likely more than a week or two. The patterns are suggestive of what each animal was doing, but it is impossible to know for certain that the dinosaurs were hunting the mammals.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s definitely a possibility,\u201d Dr. Lockley said.\n\nMore Reporting on Paleontology\n\nThe hill is now gone. So far, no other such slabs have been found elsewhere at Goddard. \u201cStudying dinosaurs is not NASA\u2019s primary, secondary or tertiary forte,\u201d Dr. Tucker said.\n\nOn Wednesday, a replica of the slab was unveiled in the atrium of the center\u2019s earth sciences building.\n\nNASA usually does not search for signs of life in its backyard, but instead elsewhere in the solar system and universe. \u201cThe fact this is found right under their nose,\u201d Mr. Stanford said, \u201cmaybe it\u2019s an omen they\u2019re going to start finding fossil and extant life out there.\u201d", "title": "Where NASA Put a Parking Lot, Dinosaurs and Mammals Once Crossed Paths", "authors": ["Kenneth Chang"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Applying for a Safe Harbor checking account is an invasive procedure. The credit union first tries to learn as much as it can about the company and its owners, beginning with an hourlong interview, followed by the document collection that Behzadzadeh found so aggravating: lists of owners, investors, vendors and customers; financial statements and tax forms; the business\u2019s organizing documents; state licenses; leases, handbooks and more. The documents can multiply quickly, because marijuana businesses are often a web of affiliated companies with overlapping ownership. Each often gets its own bank account.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOnce the accounts are opened, Safe Harbor\u2019s bankers inspect the business and its premises as frequently as every three months, to confirm that it hews to all of Colorado\u2019s rules. Treasury\u2019s guidance implies that a bank can\u2019t properly make sure that a client stays on the right side of the Cole memo without a rigorous state licensing and regulatory plan in place, according to McVay, the Seattle lawyer. This, he says, explains why California\u2019s large medical-marijuana sector mostly lacks access to banking services: Local governments oversee the business, and with a very light touch. The state won\u2019t implement comprehensive regulations until later this year at the earliest.\n\nSafe Harbor bankers spend most of their time monitoring client transactions, tying every dollar the bank takes in to a legitimate sale and making sure that no dollar withdrawn disappears into the illicit economy. Each month, they reconcile the account activity to a company\u2019s ledger and the sales it reports, as well as to all the other information they\u2019ve gleaned about a client, such as which companies it normally trades with. The credit union has compiled reams of data about how money moves around the marijuana industry, and bankers regularly compare notes about the transactions they see. When an unusual deposit arrives \u2014 larger than typical, say, or from a new source \u2014 the banker holds the money until the client can account for it.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSeefried recalls how a banker noticed that one dispensary seemed to have customers with unusually deep pockets: its sales averaged $300 to $400 each, while medical-marijuana patients generally spend less than $100 at dispensaries. The banker interrogated the client and, from the parking lot, even staked out the dispensary and studied its customers. In the end, still mystified by how the dispensary made its money, Safe Harbor closed the account. \u201cYou cannot bank what you don\u2019t understand,\u201d Seefried says.\n\nSafe Harbor has closed three other accounts after members broke various credit-union rules, indicating that they weren\u2019t willing to be fully transparent with their bankers. Late last summer, Seefried ejected three more members after bankers, working with money-laundering experts, detected suspicious activity. And another three closed their accounts rather than comply with her increasingly strict requirements, including one that customers deposit 90 percent of their receipts. The rule, she acknowledges, was mainly intended to weed out less-committed clients: Only a business trying to hide its transactions would be put off by it.\n\nLast June, the National Credit Union Association, Partner Colorado\u2019s federal regulator, conducted its annual examination of the credit union\u2019s books and practices, and for the third year in a row, had no complaints about Safe Harbor. Today the program consists of 13 people, including five responsible solely for compliance. Most are women. (Women manage more than half of all credit unions.) When Seefried hires bankers for Partner Colorado, she gravitates toward sociable people. For Safe Harbor, she says she prefers introverts or, at the very least, people who evince precision and curiosity.\n\nThis sort of meticulous banking isn\u2019t cheap. For each $100,000 deposited at Safe Harbor, a client pays $450 in fees in the first year and $300 thereafter. (Client companies that serve the marijuana industry but don\u2019t actually sell the drugs, like laboratories, require much less vetting and so pay much lower fees.) Seefried says the Safe Harbor program made a modest profit in its first year \u2014 less than $200,000. It became much more lucrative for the credit union in 2016, but Seefried won\u2019t reveal specifics. According to federal data, most of the institution\u2019s sources of income have stayed relatively steady since 2014, but fee income has grown to a projected $5 million in 2017 from nearly $3 million.\n\nSeefried says that about three-quarters of Safe Harbor\u2019s marijuana-selling clients pay less than $1,000 a month per account, considerably less than they would pay at banks, where monthly account fees are said to start at $1,500. Many observers assume that the opportunity to assess lucrative fees is what entices small banks to take on these risky accounts. Federal data show that at Champion Bank, in suburban Denver, which began explicitly working with marijuana businesses in 2014, annual fee revenue on deposit accounts increased by a factor of 68 from 2013 to 2016, to $752,000 from $11,000, even as its main line of business, providing loans, shrank. At Colorado Bank and Trust in La Junta, fees grew elevenfold to $2.9 million.\n\nFor marijuana businesses, engaging with the financial mainstream has kept them mostly free from legal trouble. Safe Harbor has received subpoenas for the bank records of only four of the just over 200 clients it has had. None has yet been indicted. John Walsh can recall prosecuting one case against regulated dispensaries and none against a business serving the industry. But working without a checking account makes even an otherwise law-abiding business look evasive, says Lewis Koski, who served as the first director of the state\u2019s Marijuana Enforcement Division, which collects marijuana taxes and regulates the industry, before he joined Andrew Freedman in a consulting venture. A cash-management technique like personal deposits structured to evade notice can legally amount to money laundering. \u201cBanking,\u201d Koski says, \u201cjust provides a really clear picture of where money is coming in and where money is going out.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOn the last Wednesday of last March, Kim Oliver, Partner Colorado\u2019s executive vice president, pulled her old, mud-streaked silver Jetta into Avicenna\u2019s parking lot. She had come from her ranch, east of Denver. She was dressed formally and seemed intently focused on the business at hand. Seefried had reviewed all of Behzadzadeh\u2019s paperwork; now only an inspection stood between him and a bank account. Behzadzadeh gave Oliver a warm welcome, and Elsberg took her ID, signed her in and gave her a visitor badge. Oliver made a mental note: the first small compliance test, passed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOliver, who is 59, has worked in credit unions all her adult life. Earlier she had confided to me a lifelong hostility to marijuana and rage when she discovered that her son-in-law, a veteran suffering from PTSD and living in her house, was cultivating a small crop in her basement. But working on Safe Harbor had forced her to reconsider her views on medical marijuana. \u201cI found out that he wasn\u2019t blowing smoke,\u201d she told me. (I couldn\u2019t tell if she intended the pun.) \u201cThat was my whole thing: You\u2019re just trying to have an excuse to smoke dope.\u201d She now supplies her arthritic mother with topical creams that contain cannabidiol, a chemical compound in the marijuana flower that doesn\u2019t produce a high but that medical-marijuana advocates believe reduces inflammation.\n\nOliver sat down with Behzadzadeh and Elsberg at a gray marble table in the kitchenette just inside the employee entrance. She began the formal inspection by going through a checklist: six pages long, scores of questions. The first series delved into Behzadzadeh\u2019s financial practices and the second into business procedures. These were meant to assess Behzadzadeh\u2019s compliance with state regulations. Then she read five or six questions about each of the eight Cole memo priorities. After a response, Oliver made a check \u2014 almost always \u201cyes\u201d \u2014 and sometimes wrote a little note beside it. \u201cIf you had an employee, and they cut a bud off,\u201d she asked at one point, \u201chow would you catch who did that?\u201d\n\n\u201cCut a bud off\u201d \u2014 the phrase in Oliver\u2019s Great Plains twang was disorienting. One of the incongruities in Colorado\u2019s marijuana business is how professionals new to the trade adopt the Mendocino idiom without either irony or any particular reverence, the way their clothes absorb the plant\u2019s scent after a few hours on site. The industry\u2019s brand-builders prefer more sanitized language when talking to the public: \u201cadult use\u201d for \u201crecreational\u201d and \u201ccannabis\u201d for \u201cmarijuana.\u201d\n\nElsberg replied, \u201cThat\u2019s the beauty of it \u2014 we have cameras on everything.\u201d The questions, and especially the answers, occasionally delved into minutiae, as when Behzadzadeh noted that he had hired a man to drive the perimeter of his two buildings hourly every night. Oliver raised an eyebrow. \u201cHe\u2019s legal,\u201d Behzadzadeh said. \u201cI checked his sosh\u201d \u2014 Social Security number. \u201cI checked his driver\u2019s license.\u201d He deadpanned, \u201cI sent a copy to Jeff Sessions, too.\u201d\n\nNext, Oliver went about documenting compliance, snapping photos of the cameras, the safes, the locks on cabinets and other equipment, the bars blocking the windows and even the eyewash station. She walked over to a bakery-bun rack and photographed the RFID tag lying next to a brittle sheet of an extract known as shatter. Then she had an employee type the tag number into the state record system to call up that batch\u2019s history. She visited the grow next door (\u201cI\u2019m surprised they have as many cameras that they do,\u201d she remarked approvingly afterward) and then followed Behzadzadeh and Elsberg up to the dispensary in Federal Heights.\n\nThe dispensary inspection got off to a rocky start when Oliver noticed the A.T.M. near the entrance. Cash-machine companies often rent them to dispensaries and stores, because so few can accept credit cards, but Behzadzadeh owned his and each week filled it with $2,000 in cash taken from the register. \u201cThat\u2019s got to change,\u201d Oliver said matter-of-factly. \u201cThe biggest way of laundering money is through the A.T.M.\u201d\n\nBehzadzadeh\u2019s machine was tied to a personal bank account; every time a customer withdrew cash, that account received a credit. But the register money was unaccounted for; it could come from anywhere. Now, Oliver told him, he would have to withdraw money from Safe Harbor and hire an armored car to deliver the cash and fill the A.T.M.; he couldn\u2019t even touch it himself.\n\nA look of incredulity crossed Behzadzadeh\u2019s face. \u201cWait \u2014 I\u2019m not going to give my business to somebody else!\u201d he said. As a start-up entrepreneur, Behzadzadeh nursed a swelling grudge against the contractors and vendors who nickeled and dimed him, he thought, at every turn \u2014 maybe even Safe Harbor. The cost of banking was one thing, but the prospect of trading the satchel for an armored car from a company like Blue Line, another niche player that charged a premium in a niche industry, especially galled him. \u201cI have no problem doing business with you guys, and I appreciate the banking, but I\u2019m not going to pay Blue Line to take my money,\u201d he said, his voice rising. \u201cThere\u2019s no way.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOliver kept pressing. \u201cAll they\u2019re doing is loading the machine for you,\u201d she said. \u201cIf I wanted to be on the black market, I would come in here and fill this machine all the time to clean the money.\u201d\n\n\u201cAh,\u201d Behzadzadeh said. Now he understood. He thought out loud: He would bring cash from Avicenna to the dispensary and give it to a courier, who would put different cash, which he had brought with him, into the A.T.M. \u201cWhile you\u2019re doing that\u201d \u2014 Behzadzadeh addressed the imaginary courier \u2014 \u201cI\u2019ll make you coffee.\u201d\n\nBehzadzadeh\u2019s dogs were barking ferociously when he and his wife returned home from dinner late one night in September. They didn\u2019t think anything of it, but several hours later, the couple heard noises in their house. Behzadzadeh gathered his wife and children in a bedroom and raced downstairs with a laser-sighted pistol. But the intruders were gone, along with his cellphone \u2014 and the satchel.\n\nThe robbery could have been a financial disaster. A month earlier, the Denver Fire Department had determined that the extraction room at Avicenna was not sufficiently blastproof, shutting down the factory for two months. \u201cIf they had taken $30,000 or $40,000,\u201d Behzadzadeh said, \u201cit would have literally broken my back.\u201d But the satchel held no money that night.
