Behzadzadeh had opened his bank accounts the morning after the inspection. It had taken him a few months to fully embrace them \u2014 Seefried had predicted as much \u2014 but now around two-thirds of his trading partners also accept or write checks. What cash remains in Behzadzadeh\u2019s business waits in safes, secured to the floor, for the armored truck.\n\nYet despite Safe Harbor\u2019s efforts and those of its competitors, bank accounts remain out of reach for many Colorado marijuana companies. The high fees put off smaller businesses at the same time as banks seem to be pulling back. Seefried didn\u2019t want Safe Harbor deposits to swamp the credit union, so last January she reduced the number of new monthly clients from five to three and then closed the door altogether in August after deposits ballooned over the summer. As the state Marijuana Enforcement Division granted licenses to about 220 additional companies last year through November, Safe Harbor\u2019s waiting list swelled to 96 businesses, or two-and-a-half-years\u2019 worth of new clients, before the credit union stopped adding names to it. The five banks have become very stingy about granting new accounts, according to three C.P.A.s who have marijuana-industry clients. The parent company of one of those institutions, Colorado National Bank, declared bankruptcy in November, putting its future as a marijuana banker in doubt.\n\nMarijuana banking has always depended entirely on forbearance from Washington, and the Trump administration seems decidedly less tolerant than its predecessor. In March, Attorney General Jeff Sessions declared before a gathering of law-enforcement officials that marijuana is \u201conly slightly less awful\u201d than heroin. \u201cI reject the idea that America will be a better place if marijuana is sold in every corner store,\u201d he said. A task force assembled in February by the Justice Department to combat violent crime didn\u2019t recommend any changes to the Cole memo when it delivered its initial findings last summer, but the agency is very likely revising it. (The Justice Department wouldn\u2019t comment on its deliberations.) [Update: After this article went to press, the Justice Department rescinded the Cole memo, giving U.S. attorneys more latitude to enforce federal marijuana laws in their districts.]\n\nSeefried had hoped to begin making loans to and processing credit-card transactions for Safe Harbor\u2019s existing clients, but for the foreseeable future, she has put those plans on hold. Until federal law catches up to public sentiment, marijuana banking is unlikely to keep pace with the industry \u2014 the vetting is too expensive. Just last month, after a client was caught up in a police investigation, Safe Harbor had to review the account to make sure bankers hadn\u2019t missed any suspicious activity. \u201cIt cost me $30,000: $20,000 to bring in investigators for three days and $10,000 for legal fees,\u201d Seefried told me. \u201cThat\u2019s one client, with one problem.\u201d She plans to raise fees in the next couple months.\n\nYet she still hopes to position Safe Harbor as a model for banking the marijuana industry elsewhere. In November, Safe Harbor began licensing its name and protocols to financial institutions nationwide. Six banks and credit unions in six states will begin taking on customers this month, including a credit union in Colorado to serve the customers that Safe Harbor no longer can. Three more will join each quarter. Safe Harbor is also testing a mobile-phone app for buying marijuana in Hawaii\u2019s handful of state-licensed dispensaries.\n\nIn June, the National Credit Union Association, Partner Colorado\u2019s regulator, advised Seefried that it would begin examining the institution quarterly rather than yearly, which she attributes to the national expansion. She has hired two full-time employees just to manage the increased compliance. \u201cWe are bringing more credit unions to the table, and they don\u2019t want us teaching them incorrectly,\u201d she says.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne industry investment facilitator, the Arcview Group, estimates that legal marijuana sales in the United States will more than double to roughly $21 billion by 2021 from nearly $9 billion last year. Walsh, the former prosecutor, has concluded that the tension between the federal government and liberalizing states is unsustainable. \u201cI came in as U.S. attorney in 2010 assuming that it was my job to enforce the federal marijuana laws regardless of what state legalization efforts would look like,\u201d he says. \u201cThe longer I worked on the issue, and we struggled with it, the more I realized that a simple shut-it-down approach was not practical. The notion that you can put this genie back in the bottle today is not realistic.\u201d", "title": "Where Pot Entrepreneurs Go When the Banks Just Say No", "authors": ["Robb Mandelbaum"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Like Broadway in New York and Ocean Drive in Miami, Sunset Boulevard in Los Angeles is both a real street and a myth. It\u2019s where you go to gas up at the Arco station (5007 Sunset Boulevard) or grab a meal at In-N-Out Burger (7009 Sunset), and also to chase the dream of fame and eternal sunshine. Remarkably, Sunset lives up to the postcard.\n\nDrive east to west, from where the street begins downtown to where it ends 22 twisting miles later at the Pacific Ocean, and at any point along the route, you will see the images that movies, TV shows and magazines have implanted in your brain.", "title": "Where the Real Los Angeles Meets the Dream", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s a big year for civic tricentennials, artistic anniversaries, wilderness salutes and one baseball birthday party where the fans will get the presents.\n\nIn 1718, the French explorer Jean-Baptiste Le Moyne, Sieur de Bienville found a bit of high ground 100 miles from the mouth of the Mississippi River and founded New Orleans where today Jackson Square sits. The city \u2014 our No. 1 pick for 52 Places to Go this year \u2014 will celebrate its 300th anniversary throughout 2018 in signature colorful style with parties, fireworks and concerts. The tricentennial has kicked off several major infrastructure improvements, including a remodeling of popular Bourbon Street, which hasn\u2019t been done since 1928, and a new airport terminal that is due in 2019.\n\nSan Antonio, too, will be blowing out 300 candles on its virtual birthday cake. A year\u2019s worth of programming includes concerts, historic tours, museum exhibits and more with a concentration of events, including public art unveilings, formal balls and military flyovers taking place during Commemorative Week, May 1 to 6.\n\nIn 1768, the explorer James Cook sailed the ship Endeavour down the River Thames in England, embarking on the first of three voyages to the Pacific region. The website JamesCook250.org is tracking multi-year anniversaries of these journeys to Canada, New Zealand, the South Pacific and Hawaii. This year, the National Maritime Museum in Greenwich will open its Exploration Wing, with four galleries devoted to Captain Cook and other explorers.", "title": "Where to Celebrate a Centennial (or 3) in 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "What aspect of the travel industry won\u2019t wellness touch in 2018?\n\nPerhaps none.\n\nFrom hotels and cruises to airports, airlines, safaris and group tours, wellness promises to be everywhere in the world of travel. Five years ago wellness on the road meant heading to a destination spa to embark on a specific program such as weight loss or staying at a hotel with a nice gym; more recently, the concept has evolved to include all categories of travel, and encompasses overall physical and emotional health.\n\nThe data to support the rising interest in wellness travel abounds.\n\nAccording to the Global Wellness Institute, a nonprofit organization for the wellness industry, the wellness travel market grew to $563 billion in 2015 from $489 billion in 2013, and is expected to grow another 43 percent to $808 billion between 2015 and 2020. Travelers made 691 million trips with a wellness component, such as healthy eating or fitness, in 2015, 104.4 million more than in 2013.\n\nIn addition, in 2016, the luxury travel network Virtuoso launched Virtuoso Wellness, a portfolio of 42 hotels and cruise lines. The company\u2019s sales for these wellness partners (Rosa Alpina, in Italy\u2019s Dolomites Mountains, and Uniworld River Cruises are examples) were up 20 percent last year compared with sales for the company\u2019s other suppliers, which increased nine percent.\n\nBeth McGroarty, the research director for the Global Wellness Institute, said that the profusion of wellness programs in travel has redefined the purpose of a vacation.", "title": "Where to Get Healthier in 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Where will the sounds of music take travelers in 2018? The destination may depend on your favorite song, but whether that means jazz, Afropunk, rock or another rhythm entirely, there\u2019s definitely a place to go.\n\nFor blues fans, the Tremblant International Blues Festival (July 6 to 15), in the village of Mont Tremblant, in Canada, is celebrating its 25th anniversary in a big way. The 10 days of festivities will include more than 100 indoor and outdoor concerts \u2014 most of them free \u2014 from both blues legends and emerging musicians from around the world. And for festivalgoers seeking a more intimate immersion into the blues, the event includes several freestyle jam sessions at restaurants and bars around town.\n\nDespite the name, it\u2019s not only about jazz: the music and cultural party known as the New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival (April 27 to May 6) is going all out for the Big Easy\u2019s Tricentennial in 2018 with performances from over 500 bands, playing virtually every style of music. The lineup for this year is still in the works, but it\u2019s likely to be as diverse as in the past when artists have included Bruce Springsteen, Pearl Jam, Snoop Dogg and Louisiana locals Trombone Shorty and Dr. John.\n\nIt\u2019s also a big year \u2014 the 60th, to be exact \u2014 for Festival di Spoleto (June 29 to July 15), in Spoleto, in Italy\u2019s Umbria region. The event includes more than 100 classical and opera concerts at venues around town, and the opening night show of the tragic opera \u201cJeanne d\u2019Arc au Bucher\u201d by Arthur Honegger, held in the grand Piazza del Duomo, is a way to get into the listening mood.", "title": "Where to Hear Music in 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nHollywood\u2019s wordiest wordsmith has made his way to the director\u2019s chair. In his feature-film directorial debut, \u201cMolly\u2019s Game,\u201d the screenwriter and producer Aaron Sorkin forsakes his career-long obsessions with politics, journalism and professional sports in order to explore another exclusive world: high-stakes, underground poker.\n\nThe film, a biopic of the disgraced poker entrepreneur Molly Bloom, has already picked up two Golden Globe nominations \u2014 for Sorkin\u2019s screenplay and for Jessica Chastain\u2019s performance as Bloom. If you\u2019d like to take a walk-and-talk through Sorkin\u2019s chatty oeuvre before seeing the movie, here\u2019s a guide to his best films and TV shows available for streaming.\n\nBig Screen Sorkin\n\nMichael Douglas and Annette Bening in \u201cThe American President.\u2019' Castle Rock Entertainment\n\n\u2018The American President\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Rent it on Amazon,\n\nRent it on YouTube Vudu or Google Play Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe White House tends to bring out Sorkin\u2019s romantic side, in plots that dramatize the inevitable conflicts between politicians\u2019 personal lives, their lofty ideals and the expedient decision-making their jobs require. \u201cThe American President,\u201d directed by Rob Reiner, brings those competing pressures to bear on an actual love story: A popular, widowed president (Michael Douglas) sees his approval ratings plummet after the public gets wind of his budding relationship with a charming environmental lobbyist (Annette Bening). The result is a rare combination of giddy romantic comedy and meaty political drama.\n\n\u2014\n\nTom Hanks in \u201cCharlie Wilson\u2019s War.\u201d Francois Duhamel/Universal Pictures\n\n\u2018Charlie Wilson\u2019s War\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Stream it on\n\nStream it on Showtime Anytime , or rent it on Amazon or Vudu Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nSorkin teamed up with the director Mike Nichols (\u201cThe Graduate,\u201d \u201cAngels in America\u201d) to make this slick, sharp political comedy that turned out to be Nichols\u2019s last feature before his death in 2014. Tom Hanks stars as Charles Wilson, the debauched real-life congressman whose efforts to end the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan in the 1980s made him an unlikely hero \u2014 and then an unwitting poster boy for the Reagan Doctrine. Wilson\u2019s pivot from cocaine and womanizing to shrewd interventionist scheming is catalyzed by his growing fondness for a virulently anti-Communist socialite played by Julia Roberts. Philip Seymour Hoffman, Amy Adams, Emily Blunt and John Slattery round out the extraordinarily charismatic cast.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nAndrew Garfield, left, and Jesse Eisenberg in \u201cThe Social Network.\u201d Columbia Pictures\n\nLeave it to Sorkin and the director David Fincher (\u201cFight Club,\u201d \u201cZodiac\u201d) to shape Facebook\u2019s dorm-room origin story into a taut thriller whose quippy, Oscar-winning script is intensified by a jittery, Oscar-winning score from Trent Reznor. Jesse Eisenberg gives the most chilling performance of his career as a twitchy, brilliant and ruthless Mark Zuckerberg. Andrew Garfield and Justin Timberlake are among a colorful cast of back-stabbing tech bros, which also includes Armie Hammer in the delightfully campy dual role of Zuckerberg\u2019s strapping twin rivals. Amid all that geeky machismo, be sure to keep an eye out for Rooney Mara\u2019s small but fierce breakout role as Zuckerberg\u2019s ex-girlfriend.\n\n\u2014\n\nBrad Pitt in \u201cMoneyball.\u201d Melinda Sue Gordon/Columbia Pictures\n\n\u2018Moneyball\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Rent it on YouTube,\n\nRent it on Amazon Google Play or Vudu Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAfter transforming brainy tech founders into dynamic antiheroes, Sorkin turned his attention to the unheralded front-office eggheads of Major League Baseball. Adapted from the nonfiction book by Michael Lewis and directed by Bennett Miller (\u201cCapote,\u201d \u201cFoxcatcher\u201d) \u201cMoneyball\u201d tells the true story of how the general manager of the Oakland Athletics (Brad Pitt) and his assistant (Jonah Hill) used statistical analysis to turn a struggling team into a well-oiled winning machine. The Oscar-nominated screenplay, which Sorkin wrote with Steven Zaillian and Stan Chervin, makes for a funny and often profound film that is far more cerebral than the typical underdog sports flick.\n\n\u2014\n\nSmall Screen Sorkin\n\nClockwise from left: Peter Krause, Felicity Huffman, Josh Charles and Robert Guillaume in \u201cSports Night.\u201d Touchstone Pictures\n\n\u2018Sports Night\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Stream it on\n\nStream it on Hulu Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAlthough he\u2019d seen plenty of success as a playwright and screenwriter by the mid-1990s, the cult of Aaron Sorkin didn\u2019t take root until he created his first TV series, the comedy \u201cSports Night.\u201d The series, which premiered on ABC in 1998, follows the earnest yet witty staff of a \u201cSportsCenter\u201d-like program as they debate professional ethics, embark on ill-advised romances and scramble to satisfy a ratings-hungry network. Sadly, the critically beloved \u201cSports Night\u201d was itself a victim of poor ratings, and ABC pulled the plug after just two seasons. But the show\u2019s influence transcended its short run, bolstering the careers of talented cast members including Felicity Huffman, Peter Krause and Joshua Malina while solidifying Sorkin\u2019s reputation for smart, rapid-fire dialogue.\n\n\u2014\n\nJames Brolin, left, and Martin Sheen in \u201cThe West Wing.\u201d Marcia Reed/NBC\n\n\u2018The West Wing\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Stream it on\n\nStream it on Netflix Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nJust a year after the premiere of \u201cSports Night,\u201d Sorkin unveiled the show that remains his most celebrated TV project. NBC\u2019s \u201cThe West Wing\u201d is a portrait of a presidency through the lives of White House senior staffers, from the tough press secretary (Allison Janney) to the cocky deputy chief of staff (Bradley Whitford). Based in part on Bill Clinton, Martin Sheen\u2019s benevolent yet imperfect commander-in-chief, Josiah Bartlet, and his idealistic underlings soothed liberal souls as the Clinton \u201990s gave way to the Bush years. More than a decade after its finale, \u201cThe West Wing\u201d remains a comforting relic of a more innocent political era and a forerunner of the so-called prestige dramas that now dominate cable TV.\n\n\u2014", "title": "Where to Stream Aaron Sorkin\u2019s Best Work", "authors": ["Judy Berman"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "After years of planning and construction, the Winter Olympics and the World Cup are generally regarded as the marquee sporting events of 2018. But there is an abundance of events throughout the year for sports enthusiasts around the globe, from the British-centric Commonwealth Games to the rough-and-tumble Rugby World Cup Sevens to the refined World Equestrian Games.\n\nSuper Bowl LII, or 52, will be played on Feb. 4 at the U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis. The city, which previously hosted the Super Bowl in 1992, will offer a range of fan-friendly events over the course of the 10 days leading to the game. The singer Justin Timberlake will headline the halftime show.\n\nPyeongchang, South Korea, will be the site of the Winter Games from Feb. 9 to 25. Spectators can take in skiing, snowboarding and bobsledding among the 102 events, a record number for a Winter Olympics. Curling, ice hockey, figure skating and speed-skating competitions will be held in the nearby city of Gangneung, but the activities don\u2019t stop there. The Paralympic Games, which follow the Winter Games in Pyeongchang, are set for March 9 to 18.\n\nFrom April 4 to 15, the Commonwealth Games will be held on the Gold Coast in Queensland, Australia. The competition, which features badminton, basketball, artistic gymnastics and squash, among other sports, features athletes from 70 Commonwealth countries and territories.", "title": "Where to Watch Sports in 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Donald Trump poses a huge dilemma for commentators: to ignore his daily outrages is to normalize his behavior, but to constantly write about them is to stop learning. Like others, I struggle to get this balance right, which is why I pause today to point out some incredible technological changes happening while Trump has kept us focused on him \u2014 changes that will pose as big an adaptation challenge to American workers as transitioning from farms to factories once did.\n\nTwo and half years ago I was researching a book that included a section on IBM\u2019s cognitive computer, \u201cWatson,\u201d which had perfected the use of artificial intelligence enough to defeat the two all-time \u201cJeopardy!\u201d champions. After my IBM hosts had shown me Watson at its Yorktown Heights, N.Y., lab, they took me through a room where a small group of IBM scientists were experimenting with something futuristic called \u201cquantum computing.\u201d They left me thinking this was Star Wars stuff \u2014 a galaxy and many years far away.\n\nLast week I visited the same lab, where my hosts showed me the world\u2019s first quantum computer that can handle 50 quantum bits, or qubits, which it unveiled in November. They still may need a decade to make this computer powerful enough and reliable enough for groundbreaking industrial applications, but clearly quantum computing has gone from science fiction to nonfiction faster than most anyone expected.\n\nWho cares? Well, if you think it\u2019s scary what we can now do with artificial intelligence produced by classical binary digital electronic computers built with transistors \u2014 like make cars that can drive themselves and software that can write news stories or produce humanlike speech \u2014 remember this: These \u201cold\u201d computers still don\u2019t have enough memory or processing power to solve what IBM calls \u201chistorically intractable problems.\u201d Quantum computers, paired with classical computers via the cloud, have the potential to do that in minutes or seconds.", "title": "Opinion | While You Were Sleeping", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI blame everybody,\u201d said Billy Young, a federal correctional officer in Texas.\n\nMany workers still had fresh memories of the 16-day government shutdown in 2013, and recalled having to plead with creditors and decide which bills to pay. While this shutdown lasted just three days \u2014 and only one workday for many \u2014 some federal workers said it had further frayed their faith in Congress, and made them second-guess the careers they had chosen.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m a die-hard civil servant,\u201d Mr. Young said. \u201cThe reason I got this job was for the stability, and for the past several years we haven\u2019t had it.\u201d\n\nUncertainties still loomed. Some furloughed workers said they still did not know when they would be going back to work. Some who had kept working because their jobs were deemed to be essential said they did not know whether they would get back pay for the time they had worked.\n\nAnd in interviews, federal workers said they were worried they would find themselves back in the same position on Feb. 8, when the latest temporary compromise to fund the government expires.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not holding my breath,\u201d said Paul M. Rinaldi, president of the National Air Traffic Controllers Association, a labor union that represents 20,000 members, including 14,000 air traffic controllers. \u201cYou know and I know: Congress is not going to start working well tomorrow.\u201d\n\nFederal workers said that the shutdown had loomed like a storm cloud over their lives for the past week, and that the protracted process of shutting down and reopening their offices, sending workers home and recalling them, was a waste of time and money.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Monday, union officials at military bases in Colorado Springs, Colo., and Ogden, Utah, said that civilian employees had to report to work and wait around for agency meetings just to determine whether they would be working that day or going home.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Rinaldi said that every day the Federal Aviation Administration spends handling a shutdown hurts the agency\u2019s ability to operate.\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t do any long-term planning,\u201d he said. \u201cThey\u2019re all focused on shutdown procedures. Today, you have a whole F.A.A. that\u2019s not working on anything that is modernizing our system. They\u2019re all working on who\u2019s exempt, who\u2019s not exempt.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile air traffic controllers, the military and law-enforcement agents all kept working, so, too, did thousands of everyday civilians like Celia Healy, who works for AmeriCorps in Indianapolis.\n\nShe said she was told to come to work on Monday, though she would not be paid. At lunch, she ducked out of the office to watch the news from Washington and eat the rice and lentils she had prepared to tide her over until her paychecks resumed.\n\nOne of the ironies of dysfunctional politics is that the government actually seemed to be getting better at shutting itself down, said Tom Heutte, a program manager at the Tongass National Forest in Ketchikan, Alaska.\n\nOn Monday, the employees in his Forest Service office showed up to work, and Mr. Heutte said they all followed instructions to conduct an \u201corderly shutdown.\u201d They read a four-page document, signed a furlough order and were then told to go home and not do any work, Mr. Heutte said. The process took about an hour.\n\n\u201cEverybody knew what the drill was,\u201d he said. \u201cThese things kind of dump on our morale.\u201d\n\nAt NASA\u2019s Johnson Space Center in Houston, David Draper\u2019s workweek of running an office that studies moon rocks, meteorites and other extraterrestrial collections began with a far more earthbound subject: an all-hands meeting where employees were advised of furlough rules.\n\nHe said he and other employees were told to turn their cellphones off, not check work emails and go to a website \u2014 the same one used during Hurricane Harvey \u2014 to find out when work will resume.\n\n\u201cWe are very used to operating at the whims of Congress,\u201d said Mr. Draper, 57.\n\nHe spent about four hours at the office winding things down. He told an investigator who had been traveling to come back. He made sure the office\u2019s state-of-the-art analytical instruments could \u201csurvive a few days of no one being there.\u201d Mr. Draper went home, frustrated.\n\nBut the ups and downs weren\u2019t enough to make him quit \u2014 not yet. \u201cNone of us gets into science for the money,\u201d he said. \u201cWe do it just because we\u2019re totally driven to do it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEven when things are as frustrating as they ever get, like now, I still love going to work every day,\u201d he went on. \u201cI still can\u2019t wait to do the things I get to do.\u201d", "title": "Whiplash for Federal Workers: Go Home! Wait! Come Back!", "authors": ["Jack Healy", "Patricia Mazzei"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "The statistics also included terrorism-related charges for attacks or other offenses carried out overseas, rather than in the United States. Additionally, they omitted domestic terrorism episodes that have accounted for a substantial number of terrorism-related deaths over the same 15-year period. During Capitol Hill testimony last year, the F.B.I. director, Christopher A. Wray, told lawmakers that the bureau had \u201cabout 1,000\u201d open domestic terrorism investigations and an equal number into terrorist groups such as the Islamic State. In a bulletin released last May, the F.B.I. reported that white supremacist groups were responsible for 49 homicides in 26 attacks from 2000 to 2016, \u201cmore than any other domestic extremist movement.\u201d\n\nTuesday\u2019s report highlighted cases in which the offender entered through the diversity lottery or because of family ties to legal immigrants, but the White House official could not say what proportion of people in each of those categories had been convicted of terrorism.\n\nDemocrats and civil liberties groups, including the Council on American-Islamic Relations, called the report flawed and politically motivated.\n\n\u201cThis misleading report relies on manufactured data to perpetuate a myth that immigrants \u2014 specifically, those from Muslim countries \u2014 are dangerous elements within our country,\u201d Representatives Jerrold Nadler of New York and Bennie Thompson of Mississippi, the top Democrats on the Judiciary and Homeland Security Committees, said in a joint statement. \u201cThe administration then uses these falsehoods as reasoning and license for policies that promote the continued abuse of our rights and civil liberties.\u201d\n\nThe report was drawn up to comply with an executive order that Mr. Trump issued in March to ban foreigners from six predominantly Muslim countries from entering the United States. The order, which has since expired and been replaced with a new travel ban, required the Justice and Homeland Security Departments to collect and publicly release information on the number of foreign nationals in the United States who had been charged with terrorism-related offenses.\n\nDrawing on a Justice Department database, the report found that at least 549 individuals had been convicted of international terrorism-related charges in federal courts between Sept. 11, 2001, and Dec. 31, 2016.\n\nA homeland security analysis said 402 of those, or about 73 percent, were foreign-born. That included 254 who were not American citizens, 148 who were naturalized and became citizens and 147 who were citizens by birth.", "title": "White House Fuels Immigration Debate With Terrorism Statistics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Durbin, who said he would continue the bipartisan talks with his Senate colleagues \u201cin good faith,\u201d made the documents public late Friday afternoon, setting off an intense reaction from his fellow Democrats. Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the Democratic House leader, wrote on Twitter, \u201c@realDonald Trump, that border wall funding you are asking for (again) could do so much more good in other places .... #NoWall\u201d\n\nThe White House issued the demands as Mr. Trump departed for Camp David, where he was meeting with Republican congressional leaders to address a series of issues \u2014 including keeping the government open past Jan. 19.\n\nBut part of the discussions were also expected to center on how to reach an accord with Democrats over protections for the undocumented immigrants brought to the country as children, those known as Dreamers, as well as how to fund a major children\u2019s health care program that is in danger of running out of funds. The president met with Republicans at the White House on Wednesday, but the meetings at Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland, are designed to come up with a clearer strategic approach.\n\nThe administration and Congress must also strike a deal to raise statutory limits on military and domestic spending before Jan. 19, when the current stopgap spending bill expires.\n\nIf they cannot reach a deal, the government could be forced into a partial shutdown almost a year to the day after Mr. Trump was sworn into office.\n\nHow Mr. Trump works with Congress over these critical domestic issues will set a tone for his second year in office, and could shape the 2018 midterm election landscape. Republicans are deeply concerned that their majorities in the House and Senate may be in jeopardy.\n\nBefore leaving for Camp David, the president continued to play head economic cheerleader. \u201cThe stock market is up very, very big today,\u201d he told reporters. \u201cWe\u2019ve set new records, and I think they\u2019ll be continued to set.\u201d The Dow Jones industrial average broke the 25,000 barrier for the first time on Thursday.", "title": "White House Immigration Demands Imperil Bipartisan Talks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "The leaders of 21 global aid organizations asked the Trump administration on Wednesday to restore withheld funds to the United Nations agency that helps Palestinians, calling the funding cut a \u201cdangerous and striking departure\u201d from a history of American generosity.\n\nIn a letter to top administration officials, the groups\u2019 leaders expressed concern that the White House\u2019s decision to withhold more than half of the planned contribution to the agency, if maintained, would disrupt Palestinian access to food, health care, education \u201cand other critical support to vulnerable populations.\u201d\n\nThe administration announced last week that it was withholding $65 million from a scheduled payment of $125 million to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East, which aids more than five million Palestinians in refugee camps across the Middle East.\n\nThe announcement came after Palestinian leaders had accused the administration of blatantly siding with Israel in the protracted Israeli-Palestinian conflict and dimming prospects for a Palestinian state that would exist side by side with Israel.", "title": "White House Urged to Restore Aid to U.N. Palestinian Refugee Agency", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "I assumed I\u2019d be watching the wolves from 20 feet away, squinting through glass and chain-link fences, desperately trying to get a selfie. No, no. At Wolf Connection, you go right into the enclosures with the animals. I was surprised that their hair was so coarse, that their musty smell was actually calming, and that I did not wet my pants.\n\nEach wolf was doing something different. One was digging, one was pacing, one was howling, one was eating, one was grooming itself, one was sleeping, one was hiding, one was hanging out in its den, one was digging on top of its den and one was intently and seemingly menacingly staring at us.\n\nCate Salansky, our wolf expert and guide, asked me, \u201cWhich one do you think is the alpha?\u201d\n\nDuh, I thought. This woman really took me for an idiot. \u201cThe one who\u2019s howling,\u201d I said. \u201cThat\u2019s obviously the leader.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cNope.\u201d\n\nAll right, I thought, then it must be the one that is eating.\n\nWrong again.\n\nI went on to guess every wolf except the alpha. Turns out, the alpha wolf can usually be found sleeping. Sleeping. Didn\u2019t it need to bark and growl and intimidate people to show everyone that it was the alpha? No; overcompensating is more of a people thing. Ages ago, I read somewhere, probably in a self-help book I bought after a nasty breakup, that truly powerful beings don\u2019t need to prove how powerful they are. This made no sense to me until I saw it in action with the wolves. When you\u2019re truly in control, you don\u2019t need to tap on people\u2019s shoulders constantly to remind them how in control you are.\n\nCate explained to me what every role in the pack entails. I was especially fascinated by the way the current alpha trains the burgeoning alpha, as if it were so at peace with death that it instinctively knew to train its replacement. That was the kind of surrender I needed to navigate the grief in my chest. It also comes in handy in a business where you constantly feel as if you were being replaced by people who are younger and prettier and got famous by posting bikini pictures on Instagram.\n\nMy ego doesn\u2019t love being wrong, so I snooped around for some information that would make me seem less incorrect about the alpha thing. I know quite a bit about dogs, and some of the rescued wolves at the sanctuary had been bred with dogs. I tried to figure out a way to manipulate the conversation to a topic I know something about. I asked, \u201cWhich ones have the highest dog content or the highest wolf content?\u201d I could tell that she was asked this question a lot. \u201cDo you give them blood tests to find out which are more wolf than dog?\u201d\n\nCate explained that they don\u2019t give the wolves blood tests. They focus on their behavior. Some wolves were not raised with other wolves, so they never learned certain behaviors, and some that looked less like them were raised with wolves and hence more wolflike. Hang out with a wolf, and you\u2019ll become more like one.\n\nI had just spent two years putting all my time and sweat into making \u201cThe Female Brain,\u201d a film that explores how much of our behavior is nature versus nurture, and after five minutes with wolves, it all made sense. The death of a parent tends to make you wonder if you were destined to follow in his footsteps or repeat his mistakes, but the wolves showed me that maybe the apple can fall far from the tree.\n\nIn a culture that makes me feel that I have to compete, audition, peacock, post and posture constantly, observing the effortless functionality of the wolf pack pushed \u201cPause\u201d on those impulses. The alpha wolf showed me that when I\u2019m feeling as if I need to work more, make more, fight more or tweet more, maybe the best thing I can do for myself and everyone around me is to go take a nap.", "title": "Whitney Cummings: The First Time I Hung Out With Wolves", "authors": ["Whitney Cummings"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Yes, it appears: Another season, another Patriots Super Bowl.\n\nYet there must be some way to beat New England. Let\u2019s try to find one.\n\nFirst, we\u2019ll convince you that the oddsmakers are right that the Patriots are the big favorites.\n\nThis week, while the Vikings are 3-point favorites in Philadelphia, the Patriots are a comfortable 9.5-point pick over the Jaguars in the A.F.C. Championship game. It\u2019s nothing new. The Patriots were favored in every game this season, with spreads from 2.5 to 17 points.\n\nThe Patriots have won two of the last three Super Bowls and a minimum of 10 games for 15 consecutive seasons. The other contenders don\u2019t have anything like that record of success. Entering this season, the Jaguars had six consecutive seasons with five or fewer wins. The Eagles were coming off back-to-back 7-9 seasons. Last week\u2019s miracle victory over the New Orleans Saints was the Vikings\u2019 first playoff win in eight years.\n\nAnd Super Bowl wins? The three other teams that hope to win the trophy this year have a grand total of zero among them.", "title": "Who Can Beat the Patriots?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "People magazine\u2019s Sexiest Man Alive has always been less beholden to the bold strokes of bodily divinity. Mel Gibson, Tom Cruise, Harrison Ford: It\u2019s their faces that have occupied each cover, not their bodies. The most recent winner, the country musician Blake Shelton, was an aw-shucks vision of the homespun white American male: plaid and beer and love handles, the kind of guy whose response to his win was \u201cY\u2019all must be running out of people.\u201d When his selection was announced in the fall, many women shared that perspective \u2014 and mobilized, offering \u201csexy\u201d alternates in lighthearted protest. The issue wasn\u2019t how Shelton looked so much as how he presented: as the Everyman, prized not in spite of his everyday appearance but because of it. (As Entertainment Weekly\u2019s Dana Schwartz tweeted, \u201cBlake Shelton is, at best, the sexiest divorced dad at this barbecue.\u201d) The consensus replacements were the actors Idris Elba and Mahershala Ali, each more conventionally attractive, each also black. Other suggestions included Taika Waititi (sartorially exceptional, Maori) and Jeff Goldblum (charming, eccentric, 65 years old).\n\nThese women were laying their own claim to \u201csexy,\u201d an adjective that \u2014 amid an endless stream of reports about sexual assault and harassment \u2014 has more often been wielded as a weapon. See, for instance, Roger Ailes, the former chairman of Fox News, reportedly telling Megyn Kelly that he wished to see her in the \u201cvery sexy bras\u201d he assumed she possessed. For certain men, \u201csexy\u201d means sex. It is not the human being; it is the human body. The women exuberantly rejecting Shelton were declaring: We are the subject, not the object. We\u2019ll decide what\u2019s \u201csexy.\u201d\n\nOriginally, that which was \u201csexy\u201d merely contained sex. The Oxford English Dictionary traces the word back to the British author Arnold Bennett and an 1896 letter about a work of art deemed too \u201cseksy\u201d to display. (Spelling aside, the word offered a much sleeker substitute for \u201csexful,\u201d which appeared in print two years earlier.) Impregnating material with sexuality would soon prove itself a potent tool for advertisers. A landmark 1911 ad for Woodbury\u2019s Facial Soap Company featured a man caressing a woman in a low-cut dress, with the tagline \u201cA skin you love to touch.\u201d Five years later, the ballerina Flores Revalles was front-page news after being photographed at the Bronx Zoo in a form-fitting gown with a snake coiled around her \u2014 her beauty, the story went, had tamed it.", "title": "Who Decides What\u2019s \u2018Sexy\u2019 \u2014 And Who Pays for It?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "The gymnastics federation\u2019s failure to safeguard young girls was graver than financial instability or ineptitude on the playing field, which were reasons the Olympic committee used to decertify other governing bodies.\n\nIt\u2019s a rare move \u2014 the Olympic committee has decertified governing bodies only three times in recent years \u2014 but it\u2019s necessary. If not now, when more than 150 girls and families have been hurt by a sport that turned its back on them, then when?\n\nIf the Olympic committee needs encouragement to make the move, it should just listen to the piercing words of the women who spoke at Dr. Nassar\u2019s sentencing hearing last week. About 120 were expected to face Dr. Nassar or provide statements regarding their abuse.\n\n\u201cI was not protected,\u201d Jordyn Wieber, a 2012 Olympic gold medalist, said on Friday, as she said in public, for the first time, that Dr. Nassar abused her. \u201cMy teammates were not protected. My parents trusted U.S.A. Gymnastics and Larry Nassar to take care of me, and we were betrayed by both.\u201d\n\nIn tears, Ms. Wieber described how Dr. Nassar began grooming her with food and gifts when she was 8, and began molesting her when she was 14. How much more does the Olympic committee need to bulldoze U.S.A. Gymnastics, so the organization can be rebuilt without the people who couldn\u2019t see, or didn\u2019t want to see, a monster right before them?\n\nScott Blackmun, chief executive of the Olympic committee, wasn\u2019t available for comment for this column, but here\u2019s a primer for him:\n\nBecause of U.S.A. Gymnastics\u2019 decades-long practice of failing to report sexual-abuse accusations in the sport to law enforcement, Congress decided there needed to be a federal law to remedy it. In the wake of the Nassar case, Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, introduced a bill that would make it mandatory for the national governing bodies of Olympic sports to report sexual assault to the police. The bill passed the Senate in November and is expected to be passed in the House in the next few weeks.\n\nA majority of the gymnastics federation\u2019s officials and board members have remained in their posts throughout the Nassar scandal, even though many of the women molested by Dr. Nassar \u2014 including the Olympic gold medalist Aly Raisman \u2014 have repeatedly called for the officials to step down or be removed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThree days after Simone Biles said she was abused by Dr. Nassar and added that she dreaded going back to the national training center in Texas because she was abused there, the gymnastics federation said it wouldn\u2019t return to that site. That change came because of the power of Ms. Biles and other women speaking up.\n\nNow, the Olympic committee should listen to the athletes, too.\n\n\u201cIf they really cared, then there would be a lot of change,\u201d Ms. Raisman told ESPN, referring to the gymnastics federation, last week. \u201cAnd there hasn\u2019t been enough change.\u201d\n\nMs. Raisman and other gymnasts have called for Paul Parilla, the federation\u2019s chairman, to step down, but Mr. Parilla \u2014 a lawyer and retired Marine Corps colonel \u2014 has only dug in.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn a statement last March, Mr. Parilla \u2014 whose daughter, Jennifer, is a two-time Olympian in trampoline \u2014 said, \u201cThe entire leadership of U.S.A. Gymnastics shares the U.S.O.C.\u2019s commitment to promoting a safe environment for athletes, and we take its views very seriously.\u201d\n\nYet in an investigative review paid for by the federation, the former federal prosecutor Deborah J. Daniels described the weaknesses of U.S.A. Gymnastics. One of them was that the board didn\u2019t adequately address the sport\u2019s sexual-abuse problem.\n\nHer report criticized the board because it didn\u2019t hold management accountable for protecting children, failed to routinely question management about the issue and spent \u201cvery little time\u201d discussing child-abuse prevention.\n\nMs. Daniels also saw a problem with how long some members have been serving on the board because it could lead to insularity. There is a provision in the federation\u2019s bylaws for members to serve only two four-year terms, but Mr. Parilla has been there for 19 years.\n\n\u201cWhen a sexual-abuse case came up during my time on the board, the concern was about the reputation of the coach \u2014 not the accusation of the athlete,\u201d Jessica Howard, a national champion in rhythmic gymnastics who was abused by Dr. Nassar, wrote in a first-person piece for a New York Times blog. She, too, wants wholesale changes to the board that failed in its mission to oversee the federation.\n\nThe leaders of U.S.A. Gymnastics fought to keep the abuse secret.\n\nMcKayla Maroney, an Olympic gold medalist, said she signed a nondisclosure agreement in 2016 and, according to The Wall Street Journal, received $1.25 million from the federation in exchange for her promise to remain quiet about Dr. Nassar\u2019s abuse. The problem is, according to her lawyer, John Manly, that forcing a witness in a felony sexual-assault case to remain silent about her abuse might be illegal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Raisman has also said the federation prodded her to keep her abuse from the public.\n\nThe evidence is there that the gymnastics federation is in need of substantial change, though I acknowledge that decertification presents some complications.\n\nIf the federation is no longer recognized as the governing body of gymnastics, top gymnasts can lose their funding. Their status as athletes training at the Olympic training center in Colorado Springs might be revoked. They might not be able to compete internationally because the international federation of gymnastics only recognizes athletes from a nation that has an official governing body.\n\nStill, all of these issues can be worked out in the interest of the athletes \u2014 the people who should matter most.\n\nThe Olympic committee could also put the gymnastics federation on probation, which would be a way to warn it that it needs to change.\n\nThe Olympic committee needs to do something, anything, to signal to gymnasts that it cares about their safety \u2014 and not just about money and medals.\n\nWhich brings us back to Ms. Raisman.\n\n\u201cI have represented the U.S.A. at two Olympics and have done so successfully,\u201d she said on Friday in the Ingham County, Mich., courthouse, facing Dr. Nassar. \u201cAnd both U.S.A. Gymnastics and the United States Olympic Committee have been very quick to capitalize and celebrate my success. But did they reach out when I came forward?\n\n\u201cNo.\u201d\n\nNot a good look for this country\u2019s Olympic officials. After everything we heard last week, why are they still propping up U.S.A. Gymnastics?", "title": "Who Has U.S.A. Gymnastics\u2019 Back at This Point? The U.S.O.C., for Some Reason", "authors": ["Juliet Macur", "Sports Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "NASUGBU, The Philippines \u2014 Pock. Pock. Pock.\n\nIt was late December and I was on a beach south of Manila with relatives, including my sister, who had just been diagnosed with breast cancer. \u201cCarcinoma Christmas,\u201d our scattered family calls these gatherings, convened when disease strikes and we change our holiday plans to reunite.\n\nI have the genetic mutation BRCA2, a disorder that killed my mother, and four years ago it heralded super-duper, triple-negative, basal-like carcinoma in my breasts. This year, as my sister was awaiting her genetic test results, we took stock of her options in the vacation home of a friend of a friend on a pristine beach along the Verde Island Passage, in a cove of rippled sand hedged by sugar cane fields and coconut and banana trees.\n\nI imagined the Spanish adventurer Martin de Goiti, who in 1570 sailed to Lake Taal, just east of us, and Manila Bay, to the north, looking at this place and thinking: \u201cI want it.\u201d\n\nIn 1902, the Americans razed this land, using scorched-earth tactics against Filipino revolutionaries: Brigadier General J. Franklin Bell had come \u201cto make peace,\u201d he claimed, even if that peace \u201cmust be the peace of desolation.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Who Hits Golf Balls Into the Sea?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Also troubling is how little choice the stateless people have had in the matter. According to interviews with Comoran officials, immigration lawyers and activists, the United Arab Emirates not only pays for the papers but also helps Comoran officials summon and document the bidoon. Officials from the Emirates\u2019 Interior Ministry have also been known to pressure applicants into becoming Comoran by refusing them driver\u2019s licenses and threatening not to let their children enroll in school.\n\nMany small countries, like Vanuatu and Malta, have recently put passports up for sale. This citizenship market paved the way for the Comoran scenario by turning passports into something that can be bought like any other commodity. But most of those countries market their citizenship to wealthy people seeking another passport to make international travel or banking easier. With Comoros, it\u2019s the Emirati state paying a poorer country for something it chooses not to provide itself.\n\nA Comoros passport does help stateless people travel and deal more easily with everyday bureaucracy. But it also sets a frightening precedent. It\u2019s easy to imagine a scenario in which large groups of displaced people, or minorities in a country that would sooner see them gone, are forced to take a foreign nationality under duress and are then sent away, absolving their home country of any legal responsibility.\n\nWhat\u2019s more, the size of the program is a security liability. Due diligence on passport applicants is bare-bones, and some officials have been caught selling passports on the side, with thousands of documents sold through parallel networks, according to a new analysis by members of the Comoran Parliament. Other documents show recent Comoran passport recipients aren\u2019t just Emirati-born stateless people but also individuals born in Burma, Bangladesh, Iran and other countries, as well as a handful of Westerners. (It\u2019s unclear whether they signed on covertly as bidoon under the Emirati program or bought new papers for themselves through middlemen.)\n\nMore worrying still is uncertainty over whether the new Comorans even have a right to settle in \u201ctheir\u201d country, should they ever need to. When Comoran members of Parliament voted for the controversial economic citizenship law in 2008, they assumed no economic citizens would physically relocate to the islands. So far, none have. But their right of return becomes significant if or when those individuals seek refuge outside the Emirates.\n\nIn 2012, a man named Ahmed Abdelkhaleq was expelled from the United Arab Emirates for his activism defending the rights of stateless people. He held a Comoran passport but was ultimately granted asylum in Canada rather than being sent \u201chome\u201d to Comoros. In this isolated incident, \u201ceconomic\u201d citizenship did not stand in his way, but no jurisprudence exists to determine how Comoran \u201cexpatriates\u201d will be treated by foreign countries and courts. Nor is there any decisive international law on the matter.\n\nComorans are Muslim, and many wish to visit Mecca, but permits are set aside for would-be pilgrims according to their nationality. In a letter to his colleagues, the head of the Comoros Parliament complained that \u201ceconomic citizens\u201d routinely fill this quota, leaving \u201creal\u201d Comoran pilgrims in a spiritual lurch. And a few years ago I asked a visiting demographer about whether he would count the Emirati Comorans in coming population surveys. He didn\u2019t have an answer; there isn\u2019t even language to describe that category of person.", "title": "Opinion | Who Loses When a Country Puts Citizenship Up for Sale?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "SPECIAL POST \u2014 There are many solvers who sit down to do a crossword puzzle (or, as I\u2019ve said, maybe you stand; who am I to judge?) without even a thought as to the puzzle maker behind the grid. Some people still believe that crosswords are made solely by computers, and while most constructors have some software-based help these days, nothing could be farther from the truth.\n\nRest assured, there will never be any substitute for the human touch in puzzles. From the constructor who conceives of and builds your puzzle, to the editors who pore over every clue and entry to make them sparkle, this pastime of ours is far from computer-generated, and it is an artform that has almost as many genres and styles as music. You will find constructors who focus on wordplay, constructors who excel at including the edgiest entries and constructors who thrill us with innovative grid design and other forms of visual derring-do.\n\nPhoto\n\nWelcome to a new Wordplay feature where we will meet these constructors. Our inaugural spotlight is on the very prolific and innovative constructor Patrick Berry, whose \u201cConstructor\u2019s Handbook\u201d (formerly known as \u201cCrossword Puzzle Challenges for Dummies\u201d) is an indispensable tool for learning the art of crossword puzzle making.\n\nMeet Patrick Berry\n\n1. Where do you currently reside?\n\nAthens, Georgia.\n\n2. Where and when was your first puzzle published?\n\nThe April 1993 issue of Games. It was a variety puzzle called \u201cOn the Right Track,\u201d appropriately enough.\n\n3. When was your first New York Times crossword published?", "title": "Who Made My Puzzle?: Patrick Berry", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHow do I love thee?\u201d Count the ways, or better, it\u2019s time to count the days because Valentine\u2019s Day nears.\n\nWhether you\u2019re looking for something special for a new spouse, a loved one who is not a spouse, or a wedding present for newlyweds, here are 10 gifts to express yourself.", "title": "Who Needs Chocolate? 10 Gifts for the Ones You Love", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "We are all familiar with the maxim \u201cThere\u2019s no such thing as a free lunch,\u201d but a sticking point is who will foot the bill when one side has to put up the money.\n\nThe issue of who pays for compliance is taking on added urgency with new financial regulations to fight money laundering and foreign corruption through increased transparency set to take effect in May. Complying with these rules, it turns out, is not a cheap proposition, and the banks want to shift at least some of those added costs to the federal government.\n\nThe new rules from the Treasury Department\u2019s Financial Crimes Enforcement Network will require banks, credit unions, mutual funds, and securities and commodities brokers to undertake greater due diligence into the ownership of corporate shells \u2014 usually limited liability companies or partnerships created under state law \u2014 when they open accounts. The purpose is to identify who is putting up the money, beyond just the names that appear on the formal documents but have no real connection to the assets.\n\nThe problem of shielding an owner\u2019s identity through a corporate facade has been especially acute in expensive real estate transactions. An article in USA Today showed that President Trump\u2019s companies sold more than $35 million in property last year, mostly to shell companies. The New York Times reported that many condominiums on the so-called billionaires\u2019 row of residential towers in Manhattan were purchased through limited liability companies that hide the identities of the owners, many of whom are foreigners.", "title": "Who Should Pay for Financial Transparency? Banks or Government?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "There is a significant impediment, however, and that is President Trump and the congressional leaders who enable him. Mr. Trump persists in his bizarre fascination with Mr. Putin and refuses to acknowledge that Russia poses a security threat, even though his own recently released national security strategy says Russia, along with China, seeks to \u201cchallenge American influence, values and wealth.\u201d Republicans in Congress have expressed more concern about those who revealed Russia\u2019s meddling than about the meddling, and have done nothing to ensure it cannot be repeated.\n\nAccording to the report, the Kremlin is spending far more on foreign propaganda outlets, and on nongovernmental groups and political parties opposed to the European Union and NATO. It enlisted organized crime groups to launder money and commit other crimes, and used its control of energy supplies to spread corruption, the report said.\n\nRussia used cyberwarfare, disinformation and military force to inhibit ties to the West by Georgia and Ukraine. The Kremlin is also trying to undermine Serbia\u2019s efforts to integrate with the West by exploiting connections between the Russian Orthodox Church and Serbians and through its near monopoly on energy supplies.\n\nRussia has weakened democracy in Hungary and Bulgaria, both members of the European Union and NATO, and has drawn them closer to Mr. Putin\u2019s orbit. The Kremlin is spreading its reach into Mexico and the Middle East.\n\nThis activity would be troubling at any time, but more so now when the president has denied there has been Russian meddling, refused to criticize Mr. Putin and has seemed more interested in rewarding Moscow than confronting it.", "title": "Opinion | Who Will Listen to Democrats\u2019 Warning on Russia?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 The smallest city is Newark, N.J., whose estimated 2016 population in 2016 was 281,764.\n\n\u2022 This:\n\n\u2022 Also, this:\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nApple is bringing cash home. What comes next?\n\nAs it repatriates most of its $252 billion cash hoard from foreign subsidiaries, Apple has become a triumphant example for Republicans of what the new tax law can do.\n\nPresident Trump\u2019s reaction:\n\nPhoto\n\nPerhaps more important than the one-time $38 billion that Apple will pay in tax is what said it would do with the rest of the money: 20,000 jobs and a new domestic campus, among other initiatives.\n\nTim Cook said in a statement:\n\n\u201cWe have a deep sense of responsibility to give back to our country and the people who help make our success possible.\u201d\n\nThe big question: How much of an economic effect will this have? The company says more than $350 billion over the next five years, but how much of that goes beyond what it would have spent anyway is unclear. (For starters, its new campus won\u2019t be as ambitious as Amazon\u2019s planned HQ2.)\n\nThe tax flyaround\n\n\u2022 Verizon will save nearly $17 billion because of the new tax code\u2019s effect on its deferred tax liabilities. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 What corporate America says will come of the tax overhaul: more annual savings, bigger pension contributions and larger stock buybacks. (WSJ)\n\nC.F.P.B.\u2019s latest budget request: $0\n\nMick Mulvaney, the acting director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, is continuing his efforts to rein in the agency.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis latest tactic: starve it of cash, reports the NYT\u2019s Stacey Cowley.\n\nHere\u2019s what he did:\n\n\u2022 The consumer bureau is funded directly by the Federal Reserve. Each quarter the watchdog requests money for its operations from the central bank.\n\n\u2022 On Wednesday, Mr. Mulvaney requested $0 for the current quarter.\n\n\u2022 Mr. Mulvaney said the bureau is sitting on a $177.1 million reserve fund. He plans to use that to cover the bureau\u2019s projected quarterly expenses of $145 million.\n\nWhile the move is largely symbolic, it follows other recent moves by Mr. Mulvaney that spotlight the Trump administration\u2019s desire to shift the consumer bureau\u2019s trajectory.\n\nHow will banks share their tax reform windfall?\n\nIgnore all the one-time charges related to the new tax law that banks announced this week, the industry, long-term, should be among the biggest winners.\n\nBut how much of the windfall will end in the pockets of employees and customers?\n\nSince the tax overhaul became law last month, banks have rushed to shower employees with bonuses and raises.\n\nYet despite this largess, \u201cthe industry stands to retain more than 75 percents of the savings\u201d from the tax law, according to S&P Global Market Intelligence. In fact, the total cost of the wage increases and bonuses \u201cwill amount to just 1.75 percent of the banking industry\u2019s noninterest expenses in 2018.\u201d\n\nThe last big bank reports, and ...\n\nMorgan Stanley reported a profit of $686 million, including a one-time charge on $990 million related to the new tax law.\n\nThe Numbers\n\n\u2022 84 cents. Morgan Stanley\u2019s earnings per share excluding the tax charge. Wall Street expected the firm to report earnings of 77 cents a share.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 $9.5 billion. The bank\u2019s fourth-quarter revenue, up 5.3 percent from a year ago.\n\n\u2022 $37.9 billion. Morgan Stanley\u2019s full-year revenue, up 10 percent from 2016. By comparison, the firm\u2019s five rivals reported revenue rose 2 percent and 5 percent, the WSJ pointed out.\n\n\u2022 $808 million. The firm\u2019s revenue from fixed-income trading, down 45 percent from a year ago. It marked the first time in two years revenue in the division failed to reach $1 billion. Still, the decline was not as severe as Goldman\u2019s. Morgan Stanley\u2019s longtime rival reported a 50 percent drop in fixed-income trading revenue.\n\n\u2022 $1.92 billion. Morgan Stanley\u2019s fourth-quarter equity trading revenue, off 2 percent from a year ago.\n\n\u2022 $522 million. The bank\u2019s fourth-quarter advisory revenue, down 6 percent \u201con lower levels of completed M&A activity.\u201d Goldman reported 9 percent decline in advisory revenue.\n\nShares of Morgan Stanley gained 1.5 percent in early trading and are up 29 percent over the past year.\n\nThe stock market\u2019s hot start.\n\nYes, stock\u2019s are down a bit Thursday, but that doesn\u2019t obscure the fact that major equity indexes are off to their best start in years.\n\nWednesday, shares of the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 26,000, the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500 index finished above 2,800, and the Nasdaq Composite surpassed its inflation-adjusted peak from the dot-com boom.\n\nInvestors have piled into stocks to start 2018. It took the Dow industrials just eight trading sessions to go from 25,000 to 26,000, the fastest move between millennial markers on record.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them.
