Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter a soccer practice in May 2017, Ms. Gutierrez skipped the team\u2019s postgame burrito hangout in favor of buying healthy groceries; despite her athleticism, her diet default was often tacos and ice cream. Mr. Hinshaw asked to tag along.\n\nAt the grocery store, Ms. Gutierrez, who is fearless against players twice her size on the soccer field, confessed a secret: a fear of grocery shopping. As she snaked through the aisles of colorful food products, her anxiety would speak. \u201cThe choices! The packaging! Why are people dying of hunger with all this food! How much of this will I waste?\u201d she said.\n\nWith her cart filling and her agony lessening, Ms. Gutierrez saw her sweet and reliable teammate in a new light: He possessed a dry wit and charm. Mr. Hinshaw, known for his steady demeanor, eased her angst with conversation that gradually revealed their many similarities. He had earned a degree in neuroscience from Gordon College, also a Christian institution. He, too, was passionate about great books.\n\nSeveral nights later, Mr. Hinshaw texted Ms. Gutierrez to see if she had followed through on her healthy meal plan. Indeed, Ms. Gutierrez was doing just that. When Mr. Hinshaw asked if she needed help, she invited him to come over but wondered if \u201chelp\u201d was a euphemism for booty call.\n\nPhoto\n\nWell after midnight their conversation was still percolating when Mr. Hinshaw took leave without even a kiss. A shocked Ms. Gutierrez texted her best pal: Great conversation but no moves? A guy who genuinely wants to pet my dog and help me cook?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe inadvertently included Mr. Hinshaw on the text string, but the good-natured medical student wasn\u2019t offended.\n\n\u201cI was just out of a seven-year relationship and not equipped with much game,\u201d Mr. Hinshaw said. However, the next week after soccer practice, the two spent the night together. Talk of relationships, sex, soccer, dogs, careers, Christianity, God and their shared frustration with secular life lasted until dawn.\n\n\u201cMelissa was totally herself, she wasn\u2019t trying to sell me anything,\u201d Mr. Hinshaw said. Upon leaving the next morning, he said, \u201cThis is not just a physical thing for me.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Gutierrez said, \u201cGuys had said that before, but their actions didn\u2019t bear it out.\u201d\n\nBut the next night she was at a concert by herself when Mr. Hinshaw texted, \u201cHow\u2019s the show?\u201d which brought Ms. Gutierrez to an epiphany. \u201cThis is what it\u2019s like when someone cares about you,\u201d she said. \u201cThere are a lot of \u2018three little words\u2019 I\u2019d wanted to hear besides \u2018I love you.\u2019\u201d\n\nMr. Hinshaw even asked about the meaning and origin of the many bumper stickers on her beloved truck. \u201cHe cared about who I was and wanted to know my stories,\u201d she said.\n\nFor two weeks, they spent every free moment together, talking through politics (socially progressive), deep beliefs like creation or evolution (both are possible) and Jesus (both a savior and a guy who lived in a way that puts life into perspective).\n\nThey also shared worries. Ms. Gutierrez, a fan of \u201cGrey\u2019s Anatomy,\u201d wondered if Mr. Hinshaw may someday leave her for a nurse. (\u201cLaughable,\u201d Mr. Hinshaw said.) And how would Ms. Gutierrez handle the time constraints of his medical training and what if his residency was elsewhere? (She relished alone time and if a move was in his plan, she\u2019d move, too.)\n\nPhoto\n\nInside of those two weeks Mr. Hinshaw floated the other what-if that was on both their minds: marriage.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn my slightly heathen way, Trevor was the answer to my prayers,\u201d Ms. Gutierrez said.\n\nFor a few weeks they kept their engagement private, knowing some might balk at the speed of their decision, but as they met each other\u2019s families and friends, it was soon evident to all that this was a match made in heaven, or close to it.\n\nBoth sets of parents initially had concerns about the rapidness of the engagement of their 20-something children. \u201cBut they weren\u2019t teenagers,\u201d said Linda Hinshaw, Mr. Hinshaw\u2019s mother. \u201cThey both had life experience and seemed to know what they wanted.\u201d\n\nDaniel Gutierrez said his daughter has \u201calways been all-in about everything. But we quickly saw that Trevor was just as committed and serious.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Dec. 30, the couple married in a chilly tent in Sunol, Calif., outside the Casa Bella Event Center. With skies threatening rain, Ms. Gutierrez, on the edge of tears, walked toward her calm and steady beau on the arm of her father.\n\nMany of the 200 guests raised their hands in a prayer of blessing and support before a ceremony that blended the couple\u2019s quirky mix of secular and spiritual.\n\nIn her vows, Ms. Gutierrez admired Mr. Hinshaw\u2019s \u201cdedication to doing things well and wholly,\u201d while noting the difference in their approach to a soccer match. She barely makes it to a game on time, and Mr. Hinshaw leaves early to allow for traffic snafus and a proper warm-up. While not quite promising to agree to his timing, Ms. Gutierrez pledged to \u201cshow up to everything, whether it\u2019s our daily conversations or our biggest hard decisions, in a way that counts.\u201d\n\nMr. Hinshaw lauded Ms. Gutierrez\u2019s \u201cdogged defending\u201d and determination both on the soccer field and elsewhere, and promised to \u201calways try again\u201d when he doesn\u2019t get it right in their relationship.\n\nKyle Cummins, a friend and pastor for Young Life ministry, gave the couple communion before pronouncing them married. \u201cEvery team has a coach, and yours is God,\u201d he said.", "title": "Why Wait? When You Know, You Know", "authors": ["Louise Rafkin"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "In the mid-1990s, the government started deporting the immigrant gang members, which helped grow its leadership base in El Salvador. At the same time, MS-13 migrated to other areas of the country with large immigrant populations. Today, it is considered transnational, existing in countries like Honduras and Mexico.\n\nThe gang draws heavily on teenage boys \u2014 or younger \u2014 for recruits, and generally does not survive on the global trafficking of drugs, guns or people. The members recruit through extortion and intimidation, and often to be initiated, they must kill. Not all members are immigrants, however. But many of the their targets are.\n\nVideo\n\nThe girls killed on Long Island, Kayla and Nisa, were American-born. But the four Latino young men murdered in 2017 all came from immigrant families. Two of those victims had fled gang violence in Honduras and had pending asylum applications.\n\nAs federal prosecutors on Long Island said of MS-13\u2019s methods: \u201cMuch of what they do and how they behave boils down to violence for the sake of violence.\u201d\n\nWhat Is the Connection to Illegal Immigration?\n\nThe \u201cloophole\u201d in Mr. Trump\u2019s speech has been immigration authorities\u2019 approach to children who arrive at the border alone \u2014 \u201cunaccompanied alien children,\u201d in government parlance, who are eligible for special protections. Children who are fleeing violence in their home countries can apply for asylum. Others, after a lengthy court process, would be eligible for legal residence if they prove they were abused, neglected or abandoned by a parent in their home country.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nYoung migrants have surged across the border in recent years because of the gangs and poverty in Central America. They often end up living with family members or court-appointed guardians while their cases are adjudicated.\n\nIn Brentwood, where Kayla and Nisa went to school, more than 4,000 school-age migrants entered the district over the past several years, officials have said.\n\nMr. Trump, and the attorney general, Jeff Sessions, visited the area last year, vowing to decimate the gang. Mr. Sessions said that MS-13 smuggled members into the country using the unaccompanied minors program. And yet, local authorities and community activists say, the reality is many gang members were recruited in the United States as vulnerable new arrivals.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow Is the President Proposing to Stop It?\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s proposal did not make clear what would happen with unaccompanied minors crossing into the United States, other than increasing border security to no longer allow gang members \u201cto break into our country.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump also singled out Homeland Security Investigations Special Agent Celestino Martinez for his efforts in fighting gang violence, saying Agent Martinez \u201ccommanded an operation to track down gang members on Long Island. His team has arrested nearly 400, including more than 220 from MS-13.\u201d\n\nAgent Martinez was part of an effort called Operation Matador, which started in May 2017.\n\nSince September 2016, Suffolk County police said they have arrested more than 300 gang members, and for those they cannot charge locally or federally, they cooperate with Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents who arrest gang members who are in the country undocumented.", "title": "Why Was MS-13 Targeted in Trump\u2019s Speech?", "authors": ["Liz Robbins"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nQ. Are plants aware of fire? Do they react to it?\n\nA. It is generally agreed that plants do not have \u201cawareness\u201d in the conventional sense, since they lack a nervous system and a brain. But they do react to the damage a fire can inflict.\n\nIn Australia, for example, plants have evolved a variety of mechanisms that help them recover from brush fires. The eucalyptus has woody storage vessels called lignotubers that shelter tissues that can sprout after a fire.\n\nSome plants, like banksia, release seeds out of woody capsules when heated, while others, including some orchids, flower after stimulation by a fire. Still other plants, like acacia, have seeds that germinate only after exposure to fire or smoke.\n\nIn California, too, a few species \u2014 including maple, aspen and pinegrass \u2014 sprout again after a fire from buds that grow at least partly protected under the soil line. Some pine trees have cones sealed by tar that open to release seeds only when a fire\u2019s heat melts the tar. And as in Australia, some native species that produce seeds must be exposed to fire to germinate.", "title": "Why the Forest Doesn\u2019t Fear the Fire", "authors": ["C. Claiborne Ray", "Q A"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "If cryptocurrencies were to replace cash as the preferred anonymous medium of exchange, they could significantly expand the underground economy because they are so much more convenient than cash. There is no need to visit an A.T.M., and you can securely pay people regardless of their location. No wonder Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, expressed concerns recently that Bitcoin could become \u201cthe next Swiss bank account.\u201d\n\nThe I.R.S. understands this, which is why it has been pushing to break the anonymity of cryptocurrencies. In November, it persuaded a federal judge to order Coinbase, a popular Bitcoin exchange, to reveal the identity of the customers for more than 14,000 accounts (representing nearly nine million transactions).\n\nBlockchain technologies can also make it difficult for the I.R.S. to tax cryptocurrency trading profits. Here is a simple tax dodge that would be hard for the I.R.S. to prove: Suppose A, B and C are electronic addresses you own. You let the I.R.S. know you own A, but not B and C. You buy one Bitcoin at $15,000 and park it at A, expecting the price to go up. Just a few hours later, when a Bitcoin is worth $15,500, you send that Bitcoin to B and then to C.\n\nA few months later, when your Bitcoin is now worth $25,000, you send it from C to A and tell the I.R.S., \u201cI sold a Bitcoin to an anonymous counterparty at B back at $15,500 and just now bought a Bitcoin from another anonymous counterparty at C for $25,000.\u201d As a result, you owe taxes on capital gains of just $500 rather than $10,000.\n\nThe I.R.S. can observe all the transactions between A, B and C on the Bitcoin blockchain, but it cannot disprove that B and C are \u201carm\u2019s length\u201d counterparties (that is, independent and not colluding). Rules in the United States that require financial institutions to verify the identity of address holders do not solve the problem, because as far as the I.R.S. knows, B and C could have been set up by a foreign institution that does not comply with such rules.", "title": "Opinion | Why the I.R.S. Fears Bitcoin", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Who are the men going to the United States?\n\nA vast majority of the 58 men leaving Papua New Guinea on Tuesday are from three countries: Myanmar, Afghanistan and Pakistan.\n\nThey were all vetted extensively by American officials who conducted background checks and interviews, and they range in age and educational background. Many of them learned English while detained on Manus, and they are the third and largest group to have left Manus since Mr. Trump took office.\n\nA few months ago, 54 refugees from Manus were resettled in various parts of the United States.\n\nWhy are they going now?\n\nAmerican officials in Australia have been saying for months that they were proceeding cautiously and deliberately, and the plan for the men who left Tuesday has been in the works for months.\n\nSeveral refugees told me in November that they were told they would be departing in January \u2014 not anticipating the battle over immigration that has gripped Washington over the past few weeks.\n\nSome of the men said they were afraid to be quoted talking about the process until they reached their new homes; after years of being stuck in limbo, they said they feared having their dreams of departure denied at the last second.", "title": "Why the U.S. Is Taking 58 Refugees in a Deal Trump Called \u2018Dumb\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "You\u2019d expect some growth in health care spending over this span from the increase in population size and the aging of the population. But that explains less than half of the spending growth. After accounting for those kinds of demographic factors, which we can do very little about, health spending still grew by about $574 billion from 1996 to 2013.\n\nDid the increasing sickness in the American population explain much of the rest of the growth in spending? Nope. Measured by how much we spend, we\u2019ve actually gotten a bit healthier. Change in health status was associated with a decrease in health spending \u2014 2.4 percent \u2014 not an increase. A great deal of this decrease can be attributed to factors related to cardiovascular diseases, which were associated with about a 20 percent reduction in spending.\n\nThis could be a result of greater use of statins for cholesterol or reduced smoking rates, though the study didn\u2019t point to specific causes. On the other hand, increases in diabetes and low back and neck pain were associated with spending growth, but not enough to offset the decrease from cardiovascular and other diseases.\n\nDid we spend more time in the hospital? No, though we did have more doctor visits and used more prescription drugs. These tend to be less costly than hospital stays, so, on balance, changes in health care use were associated with a minor reduction (2.5 percent) in health care spending.\n\nThat leaves what happens during health care visits and hospital stays (care intensity) and the price of those services and procedures.\n\nDid we do more for patients in each health visit or inpatient stay? Did we charge more? The JAMA study found that, together, these accounted for 63 percent of the increase in spending from 1996 to 2013. In other words, most of the explanation for American health spending growth \u2014 and why it has pulled away from health spending in other countries \u2014 is that more is done for patients during hospital stays and doctor visits, they\u2019re charged more per service, or both.\n\nThough the JAMA study could not separate care intensity and price, other research blames prices more. For example, one study found that the spending growth for treating patients between 2003 and 2007 is almost entirely because of a growth in prices, with little contribution from growth in the quantity of treatment services provided. Another study found that U.S. hospital prices are 60 percent higher than those in Europe. Other studies also point to prices as a major factor in American health care spending growth.", "title": "Why the U.S. Spends So Much More Than Other Nations on Health Care", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "But the barriers women face in this long male-dominated field extend well beyond online harassment. Women must be significantly clearer writers than men to have their work accepted to major economic journals, according to a paper, titled \u201cPublishing While Female,\u201d that Erin Hengel, a University of Liverpool economist, reported at the conference. They must also wait longer to have their papers published in journals.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe bias creeps into the most popular introductory economics textbooks, which refer to men four times as often as they do women. Ninety percent of the economists cited in those textbooks are men, Betsey Stevenson, a University of Michigan economist, told the panel on gender issues in economics, based on a paper she is about to complete. When women are mentioned in textbook examples, they are more likely to be shopping or cleaning than running a company or making public policy.\n\nMissing From Economics Textbooks: Women An analysis presented at a January gathering of economists found that men make up the vast majority of people mentioned in economics textbooks, even dominating references to business leaders and policy makers. Men Women Real business leader Policy maker Economist Public figure\n\nMade-up and\n\nordinary person 94% 93 7 92 8 76 24 59 41 Men Women Real business leader Policy maker Economist Public figure\n\nMade-up and\n\nordinary person 94% 6 93 7 92 8 76 24 59 41 Men Women Real business leader Policy maker Economist Public figure\n\nMade-up and\n\nordinary person 94% 6 93 7 92 8 76 24 59 41\n\nThe reckoning in economics comes amid a larger national examination of bias and abuse toward women in the work force, across industries including entertainment, manufacturing and journalism. But the existence of bias in the field of economics is rattling a profession that, at its core, functions through objective interpretation and extrapolation of data, statistics and evidence.\n\nLeaders of the American Economic Association announced on Friday night that they would begin to address bias concerns more seriously, by setting up an alternative to the online jobs site and drafting a code of conduct for economists. But many economists said that those steps were late, and that they left much work to be done to ensure fairness for women in the field, where the rate of entry for women lags that of math, engineering and other hard sciences.\n\n\u201cThe time had come for the organization to make a more proactive statement,\u201d said Peter L. Rousseau, the chairman of the economics department at Vanderbilt University and the association\u2019s secretary-treasurer. He cast the decision as responding to evidence in a way that was natural for the profession. \u201cEconomists, I think, are just very objective in their view of the world,\u201d he said.\n\nIn interviews during and after the conference, prominent women in economics described how their profession throws barriers in their professional paths, and they criticized the male-dominated leadership in the field for moving slowly to tear those barriers down.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think it\u2019s because we don\u2019t know what is implicit bias. We know,\u201d said Rhonda Sharpe, the president of the National Economics Association, which was founded to promote the professional development of minorities in the field. \u201cIt\u2019s whether we stand up and call it out, and usually we don\u2019t.\u201d\n\nThe annual conference brings together several economics groups, the largest among them the American Economics Association. Before this year\u2019s conference, two economists \u2014 Heidi Hartmann, the president of the Institute for Women\u2019s Policy Research, and Michael Reich, a labor economist at Berkeley \u2014 circulated a petition calling on the association\u2019s leaders to establish their own job market website where comments would be moderated and sexist postings blocked. The petition was eventually signed by more than 1,000 economists, and, on Friday, the association agreed to start its own job site.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI see this as a big deal,\u201d Abigail Wozniak, an economist at Notre Dame who was active in advocating a new job market site, said by email. \u201cI think the reaction of the A.E.A. was driven in part by a recognition that economics can become more inclusive on a number of dimensions.\u201d\n\nJanet Currie, chairwoman of Princeton\u2019s economics department, and Claudia Goldin, an economist at Harvard, pointed to a recent study that found that women get significantly less credit than men when they co-write papers with them, as reflected in the way the paper affects their chances of receiving tenure.\n\nWhen the co-author is a man, \u201cpeople don\u2019t say anything about it, it\u2019s just normal,\u201d Ms. Currie said. \u201cWhen it\u2019s a woman, it\u2019s: \u2018Oh, everything she wrote is with co-authors. How do we know she\u2019s any good?\u2019\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nShe said the behavior, detailed in a paper by Heather Sarsons of Harvard, was related to a more widespread phenomenon. \u201cThere are lots of examples of when a woman says something, no one pays attention,\u201d Ms. Currie said. \u201cA man says the same thing, everyone says it\u2019s great. It happens a lot.\u201d\n\nSarah A. Jacobson, an environmental economist at Williams College, recounted an experience during graduate school that she said was indicative: A well-respected female economist delivering a talk at her department was repeatedly interrupted by male economists when trying to answer questions from the audience.\n\n\u201cIn the middle of the seminar, a male economist I respect turned around \u2014 they\u2019re in the audience \u2014 and they were explaining the answer for her, on her behalf,\u201d Ms. Jacobson said.\n\n\u201cYou see it all the time,\u201d she added. \u201cYou occasionally see it if a male is presenting. You see it pretty often if a woman is presenting.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nKate Bahn, an economist at the Center for American Progress, said that when she was in graduate school, she was told she was not invited to a regular poker game with her male cohorts, because it included \u201clocker-room talk.\u201d She also noticed that her specialties, labor and gender economics, were viewed as more associated with women, and thus less rigorous.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhat there really needs to be is a broader cultural change,\u201d she said.\n\nMs. Hengel, the University of Liverpool economist, used readability tests to conclude that papers written by female economists are on average up to 6 percent better-written than those of men, and that those by women languish in peer review a half-year longer than those of men.\n\nShe became interested in the topic as a graduate student, she said, when watching a male friend teach a course and noticing the difference in how students reacted to him compared with how they reacted to her.\n\n\u201cWhen you\u2019re teaching something, when you really nail an explanation, the front row just lights up,\u201d she said. But she watched her friend\u2019s class light up, \u201ceven though he wasn\u2019t nailing it.\u201d\n\nMs. Sharpe, of the N.E.A., said the bias against African-American women, who continue to make up a tiny slice of the economics profession, was especially pronounced. Ms. Sharpe\u2019s data show that only 52 black women earned economics doctorates between 2006 and 2015, a slight increase from the 46 who earned them in the previous decade.\n\n\u201cAll of this conversation about misogyny with women is not having a conversation about black women,\u201d she said. \u201cI think of us as the incredible invisible woman.\u201d\n\nMs. Stevenson\u2019s analysis of the seven leading introductory economics textbooks found that female economists were all but invisible. More than 90 percent of real-world business leaders mentioned in the books were men. Three in five fictional characters whom the authors invented to illustrate a concept were men.\n\nOnly 6 percent of the policymakers referred to in the textbooks were women. One woman accounted for more than half of those references: Janet L. Yellen, the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, who is about to be replaced by a man.", "title": "Wielding Data, Women Force a Reckoning Over Bias in the Economics Field", "authors": ["Jim Tankersley", "Noam Scheiber"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "GAJAH MAKMUR, Indonesia \u2014 This small agricultural village in the hills of Sumatra island, in the province of Bengkulu, is a testament to happy days in human-elephant relations: When the village \u2014 whose name translates to \u201cProsperous Elephant\u201d \u2014 was founded in 1991, residents nursed an injured wild elephant back to health until it one day disappeared into the forest, never to be seen again.\n\nBut when wild elephants raided, villagers organized into brigades and used everything they could gather \u2014 pots and pans, a megaphone \u2014 to scare off the rampaging giants, forcing them to a palm oil plantation elsewhere.\n\nIt was just one example of how the rapid expansion of palm oil plantations into elephant territory here has brought humans and elephants into more frequent conflict, especially in remote villages far from ranger bases. Increasingly, that conflict is deadly.\n\nSumatra, in western Indonesia, has one of the largest populations of Asian elephants outside India. But their numbers are decreasing quickly, from an estimated 2,800 in 2007 to around 1,700 in 2014, the most recent year there was a thorough count. Along with habitat destruction, poaching is considered a major threat to the species.", "title": "Wildlife Detectives Pursue the Case of Dwindling Elephants in Indonesia", "authors": ["Jon Emont"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "An alleged kingpin of wildlife trafficking, suspected of fueling much of Asia\u2019s illegal animal trade for over a decade, has been arrested in Thailand, local police officials said Saturday.\n\nBoonchai Bach, 40, was arrested in Thailand\u2019s northeastern border province of Nakhon Phanom, in connection with the smuggling of 14 rhino horns worth over $1 million from Africa into Thailand last month. The case also implicated a Thai official and a Chinese and a Vietnamese courier, the Thai police said.\n\nMr. Boonchai allegedly ran a large trafficking network on the Thai-Laos border that spread into Vietnam. According to the anti-trafficking group Freeland Foundation, he and his family played a key role in a criminal syndicate that has smuggled poached items including ivory, rhino horns, pangolins, tigers, lions and other rare and endangered species for over a decade.\n\nPolice said Mr. Boonchai denied the charges against him. Under the country\u2019s wildlife law, he could face up to four years in prison and a $1,300 fine, but authorities said they are also considering money-laundering and customs violation charges that carry up to 10 years in prison.", "title": "Wildlife Trafficking Kingpin Arrested in Thailand", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "The results of the investigation aren\u2019t due until August, but trade analysts say they could arrive within weeks. They suggest that the administration might consider restrictions on Chinese investment in the United States, as well as tariffs on Chinese products.\n\nIn an interview with The New York Times on Dec. 28, the president said that he had been \u201csoft on China\u201d to gain the country\u2019s help on North Korea, but that he was now intent on cracking down.\n\n\u201cChina on trade has ripped off this country more than any other element of the world in history has ripped off anything,\u201d he said. \u201cIf they don\u2019t help us with North Korea, then I do what I\u2019ve always said I want to do.\u201d\n\nThe United States typically takes cases against foreign competitors after investigations like these to the World Trade Organization. But the Trump administration has suggested that it may not want to wait for the World Trade Organization. If the United States acts alone, it may violate the organization\u2019s rules. In that case, China could gain the support of other World Trade Organization members and retaliate against the United States with its own trade restrictions, potentially triggering a trade war between the world\u2019s two largest economies.\n\nSolar Products\n\nThe president must decide by Jan. 26 whether to impose tariffs or quotas on imports of solar cells and modules. Imposing restrictions could make solar products more expensive, slowing the adoption of solar power. But the domestic manufacturers argue that without protection from cheap Chinese products, American solar manufacturing will disappear.\n\nTwo companies, Suniva and SolarWorld, have asked for broader protections by bringing a so-called \u201csafeguard case\u201d \u2014 a rarely used measure that gives the president broad power to help a struggling industry. This type of power has not been used to levy tariffs since 2002, when President George W. Bush restricted imports of steel .\n\nOn Oct. 31, a panel of trade officials who had studied the case recommended that the president impose restrictions, with some arguing for tariffs of up to 35 percent on some products. The final decision rests with the president.", "title": "Will 2018 Be the Year of Protectionism? Trump Alone Will Decide", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "The problem with lying, obfuscation and making excuses, though, is that one is often forced to tell more lies, cloud the truth, make more excuses. These words from Mr. Trump are a blight on this nation, a dagger in the very heart of what we claim to be \u201cnoble\u201d about America, a verbal drone fired at our fragile democratic experiment. And if we are honest, we will agree that the national and international damage done by Mr. Trump\u2019s recent white-racist virulence is a heavy moral price to pay, a profound moral tragedy. And for those who remain silent, you also stand accused.\n\nWith his latest display, Mr. Trump has pulled deeply from the white-racist imagination. \u201cShithole\u201d refers either to a toilet or the anus. Then again, in Mr. Trump\u2019s mouth, it could mean both. So, let\u2019s get this right. Places like Haiti, El Salvador and African countries are indicative of places where feces are deposited or places from which feces are expelled. Either way, Haitians, Salvadorans and Africans function, in Mr. Trump\u2019s white racist imaginary, as \u201cdirt,\u201d \u201ccrap,\u201d that which \u201cstinks,\u201d is \u201cfoul\u201d and \u201cnasty,\u201d that which causes us typically to recoil.\n\nThese are the people who bring with them \u201ccontamination,\u201d (Haitians who \u201call have AIDS\u201d) which functions as a trope for uncleanness, pollution, corruption. This supports Mr. Trump\u2019s white nativist narrative regarding making America great again; it is to make America white, \u201cpure,\u201d \u201cclean,\u201d \u201cunsullied\u201d and \u201cmoral\u201d again. It is not by accident that those who Mr. Trump prefers are from Norway. After all, for Mr. Trump, they are \u201cpure,\u201d \u201cclean,\u201d and \u201cmoral\u201d \u2014 tropes for whiteness.\n\nMr. Trump could have taken this from a Nazi handbook. Nazi ideology embraced Nordicism, which held that whites in Northern Europe were \u201csuperior,\u201d \u00dcbermenschen. Clearly, Mr. Trump, like Hitler, has a preference for Nordic types. This isn\u2019t just ignorance on the president\u2019s part; this is moral transgression of the highest order. As Dr. Ibram X. Kendi powerfully pointed out in The Times yesterday, Mr. Trump is clearly not the first racist president, but we should rise up now to demand forcefully that this ideology has no place in the Oval Office.\n\nThen again, philosophically, Mr. Trump is not far-off from the anthropological \u201cgenius\u201d of Immanuel Kant who, in \u201cOn the Different Races of Man,\u201d held that the first race, which was obviously white, was \u201cvery blond (Northern Europe), of damp cold.\u201d Unsurprisingly, Kant held that black people, because they are black, are stupid. These are the same black people whom Mr. Trump characterized by saying: \u201cYou live in your poverty, your schools are no good. You have no jobs. What the hell do you have to lose?\u201d The answer is clear: Our souls to a racist.\n\nStrange, isn\u2019t it? From the \u201cshithole\u201d of Africa, human life evolved. I guess Mr. Trump knew this, though. After all, he is \u201ca very stable genius.\u201d\n\nThe sociologist Joel Kovel wrote that \u201caversion is the cardinal manifestation of modern American racism.\u201d This is why we had de jure segregation. White people didn\u2019t want to be \u201ccontaminated\u201d by black bodies by mixing with \u201cbad blood.\u201d White people expressed an aversion toward those of us who were racialized as black. We were considered \u201cdirt\u201d; stuff that needed to be removed, kept in its place. Like a shithole, like feces. It is better to be flushed away, kept at a distance. White people refused to touch Black people unless it was on their white perverse terms. Like feces, we were expelled from white spaces, we were deemed \u201cuncivilized\u201d (meaning, not white). Mr. Kovel added: \u201cOf all prejudiced-against people, none have suffered the appellation of filthiness so much as Negroes.\u201d\n\nTragically enough, Kant, our towering philosopher of the Enlightenment, also held that \u201call Negroes stink.\u201d As the scholar Jan Nederveen Pieterse notes, \u201cIt is no wonder then that soap became both a symbol and yardstick of civilization.\u201d Dove advertisers should have known this history.", "title": "Opinion | Will America Choose King\u2019s Dream or Trump\u2019s Nightmare?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "The harm goes beyond just the people who might have been resettled to the United States. Countries like Kenya, Lebanon and Jordan \u2014 each of which shelters hundreds of thousands who have fled persecution in neighboring countries \u2014 face domestic pressure to turn away those who need refuge. As the United States takes in far fewer refugees, Americans have lost the moral credibility to insist that those countries continue to take in asylum-seekers.\n\nThe limits to refugee resettlement were imposed, ostensibly, to protect national security. Mr. Trump tweeted just this month that further limits to immigration were necessary for security.\n\nIn reality, as an analysis by the conservative Cato Institute reveals, 78 percent of all murders in terrorist attacks in the United States since 2002 have been perpetrated by native-born Americans. Refugees, who are subjected to a more thorough vetting process than that of any other visitors or immigrants, have not taken a single American life in a terrorist attack since the Refugee Act of 1980 was passed into law.\n\nOne of Mr. Trump\u2019s executive orders mandated a report on the fiscal impact of refugee resettlement. But the administration never released that report, perhaps because the results did not suit its agenda.\n\nA draft of the report from the Department of Health and Human Services obtained by The New York Times found that, over the past decade, refugees have contributed $63 billion more in government revenues than they cost. That\u2019s consistent with the findings of economists, such as a recent study that found that refugees, on average, are paying more in taxes than they receive in governmental services and benefits by the ninth year after arrival.\n\nThe past year has been a disaster for refugees and for those of us who are deeply concerned \u2014 many because of the convictions of our faith \u2014 with their well-being. But, because of my Christian faith, I also believe that people can repent, turning from a wrong direction and moving in the right way.\n\nIt\u2019s not too late for our leaders to examine the facts, apply the values of the faith traditions that inspire many Americans\u2019 concern for refugees, and change course.", "title": "Opinion | Will America Stand Again With the World\u2019s Refugees?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHarvey Weinstein helped build the awards circuit as we know it. He\u2019ll be gone from this year\u2019s Golden Globes \u2014 derided, decried, joked about \u2014 but his presence, and questionable legacy, will be everywhere.\n\nBack in the days of VHS, he helped pioneer the practice of sending out screener copies of his movies, asking his staff to hunt down the addresses of members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Disney acquired his company, Miramax, partly because it wanted the Oscars that Mr. Weinstein would win; the 1993 sale gave Mr. Weinstein vastly more cash and power.\n\nHe ran awards campaigns like wars, winning six best picture Oscars along the way. Even in recent years, when his power began to wane, Mr. Weinstein threw one of the splashiest parties after the Golden Globes ceremony.\n\nWhat no one knew was that Mr. Weinstein allegedly used the awards as an instrument of harassment \u2014 luring the French actress Judith Godreche to a Cannes hotel room, for instance, on the pretext of discussing his strategy to pursue an Oscar for her.\n\nPhoto\n\nSo now that Mr. Weinstein has fallen, what else about the awards circuit goes? Can ultra-revealing dresses be enjoyed as pure fashion confections? Does knowing that men reliably dominate the directing and producing awards, while many women are noted largely for what they wear, cut into the popcorn pleasure of the night?\n\nCould the red carpet in some sense collapse after Weinstein, the producer taking his own creation with him?", "title": "Will Awards Season Ever Be the Same?", "authors": ["Jodi Kantor"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "But when buying into the world of cryptocurrencies, it can be difficult to determine what is real.\n\nConsider this Twitter post from Mr. Prince on Jan. 6:\n\nIn fact, Distributed Gallery had no connection with the American artist. This virtual dealership and its \u201cReady Made Token\u201d are instead a playful experiment devised by Olivier Sarrouy, a philosophy and sociology lecturer at the University Rennes 2 in France, along with three friends.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe were trying to explore how a cryptocurrency could relate to scarcity in the art market,\u201d Mr. Sarrouy, 32, said in a telephone interview. \u201cIt reinterpreted Marcel Duchamp\u2019s gesture of the ready-made in a radical way.\u201d\n\nBut why Richard Prince?\n\n\u201cTo make a ready-made we needed a signature, but we were no one in the art world,\u201d Mr. Sarrouy said, adding that he and his friends had chosen Richard Prince \u201cbecause he is the king of appropriation art.\u201d\n\n\u201cOur artwork has been created by our own Richard Prince,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd then there is the famous Richard Prince.\u201d\n\nThe appropriation of this name was certainly mischievous, given that the \u201cfamous\u201d Richard Prince continues to be involved in a lawsuit concerning his appropriation of an Instagram-sourced photograph for a 2014 exhibition. Adding further confusion, Mr. Prince\u2019s most recent show of paintings at the Gladstone Gallery was titled \u201cRipple,\u201d which also happens to the name of a high-rising cryptocurrency.\n\nMr. Prince declined to comment for this column.\n\n\u201cThe project is interesting,\u201d said Judy Mam, an organizer of the Rare Digital Art Festival, referring to the Distributed Gallery\u2019s Duchampian token. \u201cBut we\u2019re talking about people who are putting up money,\u201d she added. \u201cThat\u2019s when the theoretical aspect of the project comes crashing down.\u201d It no longer features in the festival program.\n\nAs of Wednesday, Distributed Gallery\u2019s auction had attracted four participants, who bid in Ether up to a value of about $2,600. Three bidders who thought they were competing for a work by the \u201cfamous\u201d Mr. Prince have received or are in the process of receiving a refund, according to Mr. Sarrouy. \u201cThe last one has bet knowing what this project was all about,\u201d he said, \u201cand is still the highest bidder.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMeanwhile, delegates at the Rare Digital Art Festival planned to discuss how to take memes and the other infinitely copyable stuff of the internet and turn them into \u201crare, tradable blockchain assets.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSince late November, the most spectacular proof of this concept has been CryptoKitties. These cute virtual felines have a collectibility \u2014 and tradeability \u2014 that has attracted more than 235,000 registered users and more than 37,000 Ether, or about $52 million in transactions, according to the company. Cryptokitties.co charges 3.75 percent every time a cat \u201cbreeds\u201d with another or is sold in its own marketplace. In December, one of the 100 \u201cFounder Cats\u201d traded for 253.3368 Ether, equivalent at the time to about $111,000. (It would now be more than $300,000.)\n\nMack Flavelle, co-founder of CryptoKitties, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia, thinks that digital art could be a major beneficiary of the explosion in virtual wealth.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s not that much that people can do with cryptocurrency,\u201d said Mr. Flavelle, 37, who planned to attend the festival on Saturday. \u201cWe gave them something fun and useful to do with their Ethereum. It\u2019s early days, but this could happen in the blossoming art space as well. The blockchain is an entirely new medium for art.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMatt Hall and John Watkinson, creators of CryptoPunks, also plan to be at the festival. CryptoPunks are 10,000 unique algorithm-generated characters, 9,000 of which were given away in June 2017 for collecting and trading on the Ethereum platform. Coveted \u201cpunks\u201d are now selling for 10 Ether, or about $13,500 as of Wednesday, lifting the investment value of the founders\u2019 retained 10 percent.\n\nBeing pegged to cryptocurrencies, digital collectibles have risen (and fallen) in value at a far faster rate than just about everything in the analogue art world. They can be bought for a few dollars and sold for nominal fees. There\u2019s no need to enter the intimidating world of galleries and auction houses to acquire them. True, the buyer doesn\u2019t get to own a physical work of art, but then consumer research increasingly reveals that millennials are less hung up about possession.\n\n\u201cIf you can create a market for kittens, you can do it for digital art,\u201d said Anders Petterson, author of the Hiscox Online Art Trade Report. \u201cMillennials are comfortable with this kind of technology. There is the potential to open up an entire new ecosystem outside the traditional art world.\u201d\n\nPlenty of people think cryptocurrencies will collapse under the weight of financial speculation. But if they don\u2019t, they might just turn out to be the art world\u2019s big game-changer.", "title": "Will Cryptocurrencies Be the Art Market\u2019s Next Big Thing?", "authors": ["Scott Reyburn"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Then again, Levitsky and Ziblatt are political scientists, for whom being a serial norm breaker is serious stuff indeed. Norms are what have sustained American democracy \u201cin ways we have come to take for granted.\u201d They identify two in particular: \u201cmutual toleration,\u201d or the understanding among competing parties and politicians that they are legitimate rivals rather than existential enemies; and \u201cforbearance,\u201d or the understanding among politicians that just because they technically have the power to do something doesn\u2019t mean they ought to use it. The erosion of these two norms can lead to a partisan death spiral. The authors argue that Trump has tried to eviscerate both.\n\n\u201cHow Democracies Die\u201d is a lucid and essential guide to what can happen here. Levitsky and Ziblatt show how democracies have collapsed elsewhere \u2014 not just through violent coups, but more commonly (and insidiously) through a gradual slide into authoritarianism. Autocrats often come to power through democratic elections rather than at the point of a gun. Establishment elites can inadvertently assist would-be despots, as insiders delude themselves into believing they can invite an outsider into power and then pull the puppet strings. As one German aristocrat boasted in 1933: \u201cWithin two months, we will have pushed Hitler so far into a corner that he\u2019ll squeal.\u201d\n\nImage Steven Levitsky, left, and Daniel Ziblatt. Credit Stephanie Mitchell\n\nA \u201cprofound miscalculation,\u201d is how Levitsky and Ziblatt describe this attempt to share power with the Nazis. When presenting the most distressing historical analogies, the authors\u2019 understatement is so subdued it verges on deadpan. But our current moment is so fraught that \u201cHow Democracies Die\u201d is never dull, even if the writing can be. \u201cIf partisan animosity prevails over mutual toleration, those in control of congress may prioritize defense of the president over the performance of their constitutional duties.\u201d This might be blanched prose, but it also sounds like a sly subtweet of the Republican Party.\n\nIn one of the most original turns in the book, Levitsky and Ziblatt assiduously dismantle the myth of American exceptionalism. Even during the supposed heyday of 20th-century bipartisan cooperation, \u201cthe norms sustaining our political system rested, to a considerable degree, on racial exclusion.\u201d Jim Crow was allowed to flourish in a South that was \u201cprofoundly undemocratic.\u201d The post-Confederate states had changed their constitutions and laws to deprive African-Americans of the vote, while Democrats and Republicans found common cause in a political system that was largely restricted to white people.\n\nThe authors hazard that most of the norm-breaking in the last few decades has been conducted by the Republican Party because, unlike its rival, it \u201chas remained culturally homogeneous.\u201d The Democrats have had to negotiate among varying interests in their ranks; the Republicans have not, allowing them to be more single-minded \u2014 and reckless, this book suggests \u2014 in their pursuit of power. But Levitsky and Ziblatt oppose those liberals who advise compromising the concerns of ethnic minorities in order to make Democrats more appealing to Trump\u2019s white working-class base: \u201cIt would repeat some of our country\u2019s most shameful mistakes.\u201d\n\nEach of these books ends on a characteristic note. Frum has prepared us for a grand finale, full of clashing cymbals and swelling violins: \u201cWe are living through the most dangerous challenge to the free government of the United States that anyone alive has encountered. What happens next is up to you. Don\u2019t be afraid. This moment of danger can also be your finest hour as a citizen and an American.\u201d This kind of exhortation is as vague and bombastic as old calls for regime change in Iraq. Levitsky and Ziblatt are drier and more circumspect. There is no democratic paradise, no easy way out. Democracy, when it functions properly, is hard, grinding work. This message may not be as loud and as lurid as what passes for politics these days, but it might be the one we need to hear.", "title": "Will Democracy Survive President Trump? Two New Books Aren\u2019t So Sure", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "In July 2003, I was covering a protest near the Tehran University dormitory. The demonstrators felt invincible: Their numbers had swelled night after night despite orders from the authorities to withdraw. They chanted slogans demanding more freedom; \u201cDeath to the Dictator,\u201d a reference to the country\u2019s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who still has the final word on all state matters; and \u201cForget About Palestine, Give Us a Thought,\u201d to express their anger at their country\u2019s foreign policy, which came at a cost to domestic investments that could have created jobs for unemployed youth.\n\nLater that night, the protests were crushed. I watched members of the Basij, the paramilitary arm of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, beat and stab civilians. I\u2019ll never forget seeing two Basij soldiers throw the limp body of one young man into the trunk of a car. By 3 a.m., the vigilantes were drumming on their trucks in a show of victory. Hundreds of protesters had been arrested and tortured.\n\nAs I followed news of the protests in Iran last week, I remembered that July night.\n\nEven more than the Green Movement of 2009, the recent protests \u2014 and the reaction to them \u2014 recalled those of the early 2000s. Both then and now, moderate political forces controlled Iran\u2019s presidency and its Parliament. And in both cases, the country\u2019s conservatives deployed intimidation, violence and deceit to undermine the moderates.\n\nThe question now is whether the conservatives will succeed in dominating politics and crushing the Iranian people\u2019s desires for reform. This time, they have some help on the world stage \u2014 from an American president with a prolific Twitter account. But they also face a persistent challenge: The people seem more determined than ever.", "title": "Opinion | Will Iran\u2019s Protests Help the Hard-Liners?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "The president of Michigan State has resigned under pressure.\n\nSo have several members of the board of U.S.A. Gymnastics.\n\nNow the heat turns to full boil on the United States Olympic Committee, whose officials did not even bother to sit in the Michigan courtroom to hear the grim, brave testimony of more than 150 girls and women, some of them Olympic champions, about how Dr. Lawrence G. Nassar molested them when he was supposed to be healing them.\n\nScott Blackmun, the chief executive of the Olympic committee, apologized in an open letter on Wednesday, saying the committee \u201cshould have been there to hear it in person, and I am deeply sorry that did not happen.\u201d\n\nThe Olympic committee had been expecting to celebrate its medal haul at the Winter Games, which begin in two weeks in South Korea. Instead, it finds itself defending accusations that it did too little too late; that it was more concerned with protecting its image than its athletes; and that it did not even offer solace to victims, much less safeguards.", "title": "Will Larry Nassar Take Down the U.S. Olympic Committee?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "In a pretrial request last year, prosecutors asked Judge O\u2019Neill to allow testimony from 13 other female accusers. The judge would only allow one of them to join Ms. Constand in testifying. On Thursday, the prosecutors, citing a fresh legal argument, asked him to reconsider and allow testimony from all those women, plus accounts from six more.\n\nOrdinarily, prosecutors cannot introduce evidence or accusations of prior bad behavior from other cases because a jury is supposed to focus on the facts of the case before it. But Pennsylvania, like other states, allows for corroboratory statements if they show intent or conduct so similar it can be argued that it demonstrates a common scheme or plan, a kind of unique signature of the defendant. In this case, prosecutors say the various accounts match Ms. Constand\u2019s in that all the women say they too were given an incapacitating substance and then assaulted.\n\nDuring the first trial, the defense hammered at Ms. Constand\u2019s credibility and argued the sex had been consensual. The other woman who testified, Kelly Johnson, said Mr. Cosby had attacked her in a hotel bungalow in Los Angeles in 1996 after having her swallow a large white pill, but she seemed hesitant on the stand.\n\nOnce deliberations began, jurors asked for a definition of several terms like \u201cunconscious\u201d as they sought to parse Ms. Constand\u2019s testimony, in which she said she had woken intermittently during what she called Mr. Cosby\u2019s assault.\n\nProsecutors seemed to take note of that issue Thursday as they argued for the introduction of additional witness testimony, saying it would \u201cestablish that an individual who, over the course of decades, intentionally intoxicated women in a signature fashion and then sexually assaulted them while they were incapacitated, could not have been mistaken about whether or not Ms. Constand was conscious enough to consent to the sexual contact.\u201d", "title": "Will the #MeToo Moment Shape the Cosby Case?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "At the Golden Globes three weeks ago, black dresses on the red carpet helped draw the world\u2019s attention to abuses against women. Can white roses do the same at the Grammys?\n\nBeyond the big contests featuring Jay-Z, Kendrick Lamar and Bruno Mars at the 60th annual music awards on Sunday, the broader cultural question is how the show \u2014 and, by extension, the music industry itself \u2014 will address the #MeToo movement over sexual misconduct. While Hollywood has presented a united front, raising the bar for award-show activism with the flashy debut of the Time\u2019s Up campaign, the music world has so far lacked any similar momentum.\n\nOutside of a Grammy performance by Kesha that is expected to allude to current conversations around gender \u2014 and the possibility of an impromptu headline-grabbing speech \u2014 there was little planned for the show before a grass-roots email campaign started on Wednesday, urging attendees to wear a white rose as a symbol of \u201chope, peace, sympathy and resistance.\u201d", "title": "Will the Grammys Have a #MeToo Moment?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "The powerful Father Karadima had spiritually groomed thousands of Chileans in the ruling elite, including many who were major sustainers and accomplices of Augusto Pinochet, the dictator who misruled the country from 1973 to 1990.\n\nA Vatican investigation in 2011 found Father Karadima guilty of sexual abuse. Investigations by journalists found evidence of financial corruption as well. He had accumulated a fortune for himself and his family by bilking his followers.\n\nFather Karadima was not the only Chilean or Latin American priest to be accused of abuse. Yet authorities in the Catholic Church turned a blind eye. Among those suspected of ignoring the assaults by the priests was Juan Barros Madrid, whom Pope Francis named Bishop of Osorno, a city some 500 miles south of Santiago, despite vocal protests from people in the diocese. Father Barros was the disciple and right-hand man of Father Karadima.\n\nWhen Father Karadima was found guilty by a Vatican commission, he was not defrocked but ordered to spend the rest of his life in prayer and penitence. But although the Vatican barred him from celebrating Mass in public, he has been photographed doing so. And he certainly has shown no signs of repentance, even declaring his innocence in court.\n\nChileans of all kinds see the way the pope addresses the Karadima case as a litmus test. Pope Francis will be welcomed in Chile as a reformer, as an important voice for the vulnerable and the neglected. The faithful and the nonbelievers alike respect the Catholic Church because some of its most prominent leaders championed human rights during Pinochet\u2019s dictatorship, defying threats, death squads and persecution.\n\nAnd yet the daring Chilean church is now scarred and discredited by Father Karadima\u2019s depredations, by the fact that he was sheltered by those who should have judged and punished him. A criminal case was opened, as in almost 75 other cases of priestly abuse, but the judges indicated that the statute of limitations barred them from indicting Father Karadima.\n\nPope Francis needs to deal with this lack of accountability and justice in the next few days. He should see this crisis as a great opportunity for him, even as a form of redemption for his silence in Argentina during its years of tyranny and horror, a silence that has reportedly caused him anguish and remorse.\n\nBy siding with the victims of the church rather than with its conservative and self-serving hierarchy, by publicly condemning Father Karadima by name and denouncing each of those who shielded this malefactor, Pope Francis could, during this visit, help exorcise our ghosts and salve the wounds of Chile. Or does he want to leave the country without having been true to the liberating message of Jesus?", "title": "Opinion | Will the Pope Address Sexual Abuse in the Chilean Church?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "William W. Bain Jr., who founded the business consulting firm Bain & Company and was an early mentor to Mitt Romney, died on Tuesday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 80.\n\nHis wife, Ann Dean Bain, said the cause was complications of Alzheimer\u2019s disease.\n\nA native Tennessean who started his professional life as a development officer at his alma mater, Vanderbilt University, Mr. Bain at first seemed an unlikely candidate for the role of chief executive. Nevertheless, he made Bain & Company a fearsome competitor to McKinsey & Company, the Boston Consulting Group and Booz-Allen Hamilton. Along the way, he opened a venture capital firm, Bain Capital, which remains a leader in its field.\n\nThe Boston-based Bain & Company worked with some of the biggest companies in the United States, among them Texas Instruments, Black & Decker, Monsanto and Wells Fargo.\n\n\u201cChief executives have come to the very strong feeling that a small number of decisions, regarding a small percentage of policies they deal with, in the end determine 90 percent of their success or failure,\u201d Mr. Bain said in a 1979 interview with The New York Times. \u201cThey are swamped with studies and information.\u201d", "title": "William Bain Jr., 80, Business Consultant and Romney Mentor, Dies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhen you make decisions in a bank you don\u2019t sit around,\u201d said Peter R. Fisher, a top official at the New York Fed at the time who worked closely with Mr. McDonough during the Long Term Capital rescue. \u201cHe was a man of action.\u201d\n\nAt the time of the Sept. 11 attacks, Mr. McDonough was at a meeting for central bankers in Basel, Switzerland. Seeing the disarray around the bank\u2019s headquarters in Lower Manhattan on television, he ordered that the building\u2019s large garage doors be opened and that shelter and medical care be provided to those fleeing the disaster. Within 24 hours, he was behind his desk on the building\u2019s 10th floor.\n\nHe also guided the New York Fed through the Asian financial crisis in 1997 and the institution\u2019s preparations for guarding against a so-called Y2K computer-driven market failure at the onset of the year 2000. He spent the last day, and night, of 1999 at Fed headquarters to ensure there were no glitches.\n\nWilliam Joseph McDonough was born on April 21, 1934, on Chicago\u2019s West Side to first-generation immigrants from Ireland. His mother died when he was 10, and his father, who sold insurance, died within a year. He was sent to live with an aunt, but had to fend for himself financially by delivering newspapers.\n\nHis three sisters chipped in to pay tuition for his first year at Campion High School in Prairie du Chien, Wis. He finished first in his class four straight years. The distinction earned him admission to the College of the Holy Cross, in Worcester, Mass., where he graduated in 1956. He received a master\u2019s degree in economics from Georgetown University in 1962. Later, he served in the Navy, and then joined the State Department, where he became fluent in Spanish and French.\n\nIn 1967, while serving as a diplomat in Uruguay, he met the chairman of the First National Bank of Chicago, who, impressed with Mr. McDonough\u2019s mix of math skills and international polish, offered him a job.\n\nHe rose to vice chairman before retiring in 1989 at 55. He arrived at the New York Fed after another serendipitous encounter: sitting next to E. Gerald Corrigan, the institution\u2019s president at the time, on a plane in 1992. Mr. Corrigan soon asked him to join the New York Fed as head of markets. A year later, he was named president.", "title": "William McDonough, Who Guided New York Fed Through Crises, Dies at 83", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "R. T. Rybak was the mayor of Minneapolis for 12 years, including when the City Council narrowly approved contributing $150 million to build U.S. Bank Stadium. \u201cI hate sports economics, but I love my city,\u201d he said, \u201cand we ended up crafting a deal that ended up being a financial bonanza for Minneapolis.\u201d\n\nHe explained that in addition to helping build U.S. Bank Stadium, the deal also fixed up the Target Center arena and provided funds to operate the convention center. It also spurred Wells Fargo to build two office towers near the stadium and has led to immense development in the Downtown East neighborhood, though the construction mirrors a trend seen across the country and cannot be credited simply to construction of the new stadium.\n\n\u201cI would not have done a deal just for the football stadium,\u201d Rybak said, adding, \u201cYou don\u2019t build a stadium for the Super Bowl.\u201d\n\nGood thing he didn\u2019t. When cities bid to host the Super Bowl, they agree to an extensive list of specifications, which include providing goods and services worth millions of dollars to the N.F.L., all at no cost to the league. The Star Tribune of Minneapolis obtained a copy of the 153-page bid book the N.F.L. sent to prospective hosts, and the bid committee told The Star Tribune it had agreed to a majority of the conditions laid out, thought it did not specify what it had rejected.\n\nThe bid book shows the host city must provide the N.F.L. with 35,000 parking spaces, thousands of hotel rooms, hundreds of buses and limousines, billboards, security, food and an exemption on paying all sales taxes, among hundreds of other specifications.\n\nThe phrase \u201cat no cost to the N.F.L.\u201d appears in the book 65 times.\n\nAll of these costs, at least in theory, are borne by the host committee. Minneapolis raised $30 million in pledges from the private sector before even bidding on the Super Bowl. According to Langley, of the regional economic development agency, the committee has now raised more than $50 million to put on the game. Enough is budgeted to pay for police overtime, emergency snow removal or any other cost overruns, he said.\n\n\u201cThis is a really professional group,\u201d Langley said.\n\nIf so, it is the rare Super Bowl host committee that has budgeted for extras. The city of Santa Clara, Calif., had its costs to host the 2016 Super Bowl reimbursed, but the game cost nearby San Francisco almost $5 million, mostly in police and transit services. Mayor Jerry Weiers of Glendale, Ariz., told ESPN that the city lost money hosting the game in both 2015 and 2008. New Jersey gave the N.F.L. an $8 million tax break, and state-owned New Jersey Transit lost $5.6 million when the game was played there in 2014.", "title": "Windfall for Super Bowl Hosts? Economists Say It\u2019s Overstated", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt has created an incentive to lose, and we now have a process where teams are not seeking competitiveness and therefore they\u2019re not seeking players to be competitive,\u201d Boras said this week, adding later: \u201cTo make baseball what it should be \u2014 a league of 30 that are incentivized to compete \u2014 we need to address these rules to say: You get more money in the draft if you win x number of games, and if you finish below a certain standard, you don\u2019t get a top-five or top-10 pick. That will make the league more entertaining and make baseball better, because we want to wake up every day and know that every team has an incentive to win, not an incentive to lose.\u201d\n\nSeveral divisions appear to have clear favorites: the Astros, the Indians, the Dodgers and the Washington Nationals all finished first by at least 11 games last season, and all look strong again. Those teams may feel little pressure to spend, and others may believe they are too far away for a free agent to make much difference.\n\nAnother factor is Boras, who represents Hosmer, Moustakas, Arrieta, Martinez, Holland and Gomez. He has waited until deep into the off-season before, finding deals worth more than $200 million for Prince Fielder and Max Scherzer in the second half of January. A slow-moving market does not worry him.\n\n\u201cFans know that talent is there,\u201d Boras said. \u201cThey know that without that talent, the probability of the team winning is dramatically altered. So I have always trusted the fact that the credibility of that ethic will serve both the teams and the players.\u201d\n\nOnce Boras\u2019s elite clients sign, perhaps, the rest of the market will sort itself out. In contrast to the joint bid of the U.S., Mexico and Canada, Morocco hasn\u2019t shared its plans for the world\u2019s biggest sporting event.\n\n\u2022 Finally, here\u2019s an image of Wednesday\u2019s front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nDouble your money in just 90 days. Better yet, make it 45.\n\nThat\u2019s what Charles Ponzi, who died 69 years ago today, promised investors. In the end, Ponzi swindled more than $15 million in 1920, the equivalent of $191 million today.\n\nThe trickery earned Ponzi his own namesake scheme, made notorious by Bernard Madoff, who defrauded clients of more than $50 billion. But the original scheme centered on postal notes.\n\nPonzi took advantage of international postal reply coupons, which allowed postal customers in one country to buy a coupon redeemable for stamps in another country.\n\nMoney was invested through Ponzi\u2019s Security Exchange Company with the idea that he would take investor\u2019s dollars, use them to buy foreign postal coupons, convert each coupon into a 5-cent stamp, and convert the stamps into cash.\n\nBut Ponzi never invested in the coupons.\n\nInstead, he collected the money and paid off his investors while waiting for another influx of cash to come in. Millions of dollars began arriving every week from working-class people.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPonzi\u2019s scheme was eventually exposed, and he later died in a charity hospital in Brazil, with only $75 to his name.\n\nRemy Tumin contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. Browse past briefings here.\n\n\n\nWe have briefings timed for the Australian, Asian, European and American mornings. And our Australia bureau chief offers a weekly letter adding analysis and conversations with readers. You can sign up for these and other Times newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? He lost support among conservative backers after he was denounced by Mr. Trump.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 India\u2019s Supreme Court ordered a review of a colonial-era law that criminalizes sex between men. The law was briefly rescinded, but restored in 2013.\n\nGay rights activists said they were elated but still cautious. Public opinion on homosexuality has shifted in some parts of India, where marriage is often viewed as a social pact and attitudes remain deeply conservative.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 President Emmanuel Macron of France came to China bearing gifts. He tried his hand at Mandarin and visited an ancient capital.\n\nMr. Macron, who called for \u201ca new relationship\u201d with China, is using the three-day visit to reinvigorate ties as the two countries grapple with the strident nationalism of President Trump.\n\nHe and President Xi Jinping outlined a vision that is sharply at odds with Mr. Trump\u2019s worldview: They spoke of a need for free trade, embraced multilateralism and emphasized cooperating to combat climate change.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\n\u2022 A former Hong Kong government official, Chi Ping Patrick Ho, pleaded not guilty to charges that he tried to bribe top officials in Chad and Uganda for oil rights.\n\nProsecutors say Mr. Ho was involved in two bribery schemes for a Chinese energy company. The governments of Uganda and Chad have denied the charges. If convicted, Mr. Ho could face more than a decade in prison.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 \u201cAsk this guy,\u201d Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha of Thailand told reporters, walking off and leaving them with a life-size cutout of himself.\n\nIt was not the first time that Mr. Prayuth had dumbfounded the news media. In the past, he has touched the ear of a sound technician, flung a banana peel at cameramen and threatened, with gruff humor, to execute any journalist who criticized his government.\n\n_____\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Morning Briefing What you need to know to start your day in Asia, delivered to your inbox.
