[The Guardian]\n\n\u2022 The Japanese astronaut Norishige Kanai said he had grown more than 3.5 inches since arriving at the International Space Station three weeks ago. [BBC]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSmarter Living\n\nTips, both new and old, for a more fulfilling life.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Recipe of the day: Use our basic template to make soup with whatever you want.\n\n\u2022 That game on your phone is tracking your TV-watching habits.\n\n\u2022 Learn to manage your career.\n\nNoteworthy\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 More than 13,000 people applied to visit every destination on our Travel section\u2019s annual list of 52 Places to Go. Meet a few of them in this video. (We\u2019ll announce the winner and the destinations this week.)\n\n\u2022 New videomicroscopes are giving surgeons at a Manhattan hospital \u201cSuperman eyes,\u201d making delicate operations easier to navigate.\n\n\u2022 And an Italian law requiring customers to pay for plastic bags has prompted a flood of protests. But the anger is about more than a 2-cent surcharge.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nNinety years ago this month, Leon Trotsky, above, one of the early leaders of the Communist Party, was exiled by his rival Joseph Stalin to what is now Kazakhstan, clearing the way for Stalin\u2019s complete control of the Soviet Union.\n\nAn ever-wandering revolutionary, Trotsky was no stranger to exile.\n\nMore than a decade before, in January 1917, The Times noted his arrival in New York City: a \u201cRussian journalist and Socialist\u201d who had been \u201cexpelled from four lands.\u201d\n\nTrotsky and his family lived only briefly in New York \u2014 what he called \u201cthe city of prose and fantasy, of capitalist automatism, its streets a triumph of Cubism\u201d \u2014 before he returned to Russia to help lead the Bolshevik Revolution.\n\nAfter the death of Vladimir Lenin in 1924, Stalin and his faction propounded \u201csocialism in one country.\u201d Trotskyists bristled, calling for a \u201cpermanent revolution,\u201d global in scope, and accused Stalin of betraying Lenin\u2019s vision.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe feud between Stalin and Trotsky would culminate in the anti-Trotskyist show trials in Moscow and the terrifying purges of the 1930s. It ended in Mexico City, where Trotsky settled, when he was killed by an ax-wielding assassin in 1940.\n\nPenn Bullock contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. Browse past briefings here.\n\n\n\nWe have briefings timed for the Australian, Asian, European and American mornings. And our Australia bureau chief offers a weekly letter adding analysis and conversations with readers. You can sign up for these and other Times newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Contact us at asiabriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Winter Olympics, Macron, H&M: Your Wednesday Briefing", "authors": ["Inyoung Kang", "Charles Mcdermid"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "In winter, momos are salvation: hot dumplings with swirled pleats, fresh from the steamer, arriving in a cloudy rush of ascending souls.\n\nTo eat them outdoors in winter, shivering, with numb, fumbling fingers, is even more of a wonder. At the Amdo Kitchen food truck in Jackson Heights, Queens, momos come huddled unceremoniously, eight for $5 on a disposable plate; bow your head over them and the steam kisses your face.\n\nThubten Amchok, the owner and chef, grew up in the Amdo region of Tibet and fled to Nepal and then India before settling in the U.S. in 1995. A former monk, he started selling momos from a pushcart six years ago. Now his truck \u2014 emblazoned with Tibetan and American flags, snow lions alongside stars and stripes \u2014 rolls out daily, weather permitting. (Snowdrifts from the recent storm piled up so high, he couldn\u2019t park on the street for two weeks.)", "title": "Winter Salvation, Fresh From the Dumpling Steamer, in Queens", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Across the country, travelers shared similar stories, in some cases venting on Twitter.\n\nMatthew Hashiguchi, a college professor in Georgia, said his flight from Cleveland to Washington on Thursday morning arrived on time. But once he got there, he discovered that his connecting flight home to Savannah, Ga., had been canceled and that it could take days to get back.\n\nPhoto\n\nSavannah, which had an unusual blast of icy weather this week, closed its airport runways until Thursday afternoon. Mr. Hashiguchi said he eventually decided to fly to Atlanta and drive the rest of the way home.\n\nMr. Hashiguchi, a former resident of Ohio and Massachusetts, where a little snow is no big deal, said by phone from Dulles International Airport that \u201cmost of my frustration right now is with the South.\u201d\n\n\u201cGeorgia gets two inches of snow and they shut down the whole region,\u201d he said. \u201cThey\u2019re not prepared.\u201d\n\nSavannah wasn\u2019t the only southern airport struggle to cope with rare weather conditions. In Orlando, airport officials said their \u201cde-icing truck had to be dusted off and put to work\u201d on Thursday.\n\nIn New York, where both John F. Kennedy and LaGuardia airports temporarily suspended flights Thursday morning \u201cdue to strong winds and whiteout conditions,\u201d Pawandeep Singh found out that his evening flight to Texas was among the casualties.\n\nMr. Singh, a medical student from Queens who had planned to visit friends and tour the Alamo, said the trip was \u201cmy last available vacation\u201d before he would have to buckle down and focus on exams. He was thinking about accepting a refund and trying to find a Friday flight on another airline.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cGiven the circumstances, I think they\u2019re doing fine,\u201d Mr. Singh said of his airline. \u201cIt\u2019s not a controllable event right now. At least they got the information out before I had to leave the house.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTaishi Thompson had the opposite problem. He was trying to get back to New York after a vacation in Canc\u00fan, Mexico, where it was 73 degrees and partly cloudy on Thursday afternoon.\n\nMr. Thompson said he had been booked on a canceled flight to New York, and that he was just trying to get on a plane heading somewhere in the eastern United States: Philadelphia, Miami, anywhere would suffice.\n\nStill, he conceded that Cancun was \u201cnot the worst place to get stuck.\u201d\n\nMat Piscatella, a businessman from San Diego, also tried to put a positive spin on the inconvenience. He had planned to fly home on Thursday after a work trip on Long Island. But his flight was canceled, so he witnessed a meteorological treat unheard-of in Southern California.\n\n\u201cTo be honest, I\u2019ve never been in weather like this in my life,\u201d said Mr. Piscatella, 44, who was planning an evening snowball fight with colleagues. \u201cThis is the first time I\u2019ve seen snow come down sideways.\u201d\n\nBut in sunny Miami, a Bronx resident, Jamie Adorno, said she was content to stay on vacation a bit longer. After learning the airline scrapped her flight, she and her family rented a car, drove to South Beach and enjoyed Cuban cuisine for lunch.\n\n\u201cIt looks bad\u201d in New York, Ms. Adorno said. \u201cMy friend sent me a video. My mom told me it\u2019s freezing. We\u2019re not too sad that we\u2019re here.\u201d", "title": "Winter \u2018Bomb Cyclone\u2019 Snarls Air Traffic Up and Down East Coast", "authors": ["Mitch Smith"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "A Wisconsin Democrat won a State Senate seat on Tuesday night that had been held by a Republican for 17 years, setting off a flurry of political predictions across a state that President Trump won. Republicans warned that it was a \u201cwake up\u201d call for their party as elections loom in the fall, while Democrats cheered the upset victory as a sign of hope that Wisconsin was back in contention.\n\nIn the state\u2019s first special election of 2018, Patty Schachtner, a Democrat and the St. Croix County medical examiner, beat Representative Adam Jarchow, a Republican member of the State Assembly, by 11 percentage points, according to preliminary election returns, decisively taking the seat in a rural western region near the Minnesota border.\n\n\u201cEverything is in play now,\u201d Melanie Conklin, a spokeswoman for the Democratic Party of Wisconsin, said on Wednesday. \u201cThis is a district that has been a very red district for a long time, and the numbers last night were very blue.\u201d\n\nThe election comes at a tense political moment for the state, with a governor\u2019s race and United States Senate seat at stake in the fall; questions about gerrymandering of state political maps in the courts; and with political observers around the nation watching all sorts of local and state races for signs of what 2018 races may bring for both parties.", "title": "Wisconsin Upset Raises Hopes for Democrats in 2018 Races", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "It is inconceivable, in light of the Americans With Disabilities Act, that our subways have not been required to provide these amenities, which are essential for so many people.\n\nHow many times have you located the rare platform escalator and found the dreaded orange traffic cone in front of it, indicating that it is, once again, out of order?\n\nWe should be ashamed to subject our citizens and visitors to such conditions. I recently visited Paris and was blown away by the improvements in its subway amenities. There are many more escalators (no traffic cones in sight!) and moving sidewalks! We can certainly do as well or better.\n\nIRENE BERNSTEIN-PECHM\u00c8ZE\n\nWHITESTONE, QUEENS\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nWhile many of the ideas put forth by transit experts sound great, the rush to automated self-driving trains is not realistic or safe for New York City. Neither is the idea of permanently shutting down service at night. How many of these experts consistently ride the trains? Ignorance is not bliss in this situation.\n\nThe main focus should be on modernizing the signals, properly maintaining subway cars and rehabilitating stations. Over the years, the MetroCard has done well by the M.T.A. Amid all the chaos plaguing the system, is now the time to replace it? Wouldn\u2019t that money be better spent modernizing signals?", "title": "Opinion | Wise (and Not So Wise) Subway Fixes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Receiving one of the eight wild cards is a financial windfall, and they do increase the opportunities for French, American and Australian players at the expense of those from less privileged tennis nations.\n\nI would argue that eight wild cards \u2014 more than 6 percent of the draw \u2014 is too many unless they are genuinely going to be used to enhance a major\u2019s global appeal or serve some higher purpose. That is rarely how they are deployed.\n\nIf the Australians want to use their wild cards on Australians, that seems logical, even if the record shows that most home-nation wild cards are quickly eliminated. But extending that advantage to other Grand Slam nations is nothing more than mutual back scratching.\n\nPhoto\n\nBetter use? Follow the Wimbledon example and be more open to bestowing wild cards on rising players, irrespective of their nationalities, who have proven in recent months that they have great potential. Or on stars, irrespective of their nationalities, who have dropped in the rankings.\n\nAnother option: organize a wild-card playoff for the top-ranked players from underrepresented tennis nations or regions and grant the winner a spot in the main draw. The Australian Open already does a version of this, offering a men\u2019s and women\u2019s singles wild card to the winners of its Asia-Pacific playoff.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat seems the right message considering that Australia is part of the Asia-Pacific region and drawing an increasing number of spectators from that zone. What seems considerably less fair is to hand over free passes to French and American players simply because they come from far-away nations who can return the favor.\n\nOther tennis wishes for 2018:\n\nReal, unbiased scientific research on the injury issue. It has become the dominant theme in the game and not just because the Big Five are all in their 30s. Younger men\u2019s and women\u2019s talents have suffered, too: Borna Coric, Milos Raonic, Belinda Bencic, Sloane Stephens and others. Do strings, balls, racket frames, court surfaces or the speed of the game need to be modified? Does the schedule need to be further shortened or restructured? Let\u2019s let a task force stocked with experts from medicine to physics to coaching find out.\n\nA ban on opponents wearing the same outfit. Sponsors might like the double opportunity to showcase their wares, but tennis has enough television challenges without viewers having to struggle to figure out who is who in a match.", "title": "Wishes for Tennis in 2018", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey", "On Tennis"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nRipple takes a big hit.\n\nOnly last week, Ripple appeared to lay claim to the biggest alternative to Bitcoin. That isn\u2019t the case anymore.\n\nThe price of Ripple\u2019s XRP virtual currency has plunged about 27 percent over the past 24 hours, reaching $2.47 this morning, according to CoinMarketCap. Ripple\u2019s total market capitalization has fallen back below that of Ethereum.\n\nTo be fair, other virtual currencies \u2014 including Bitcoin \u2014 are falling as well.\n\nIt was only last week: Investors breathlessly touted Ripple co-founder Chris Larsen, who owns a significant amount of XRP, as richer than Mark Zuckerberg.\n\nThe breathlessness hasn\u2019t abated: Shares in Seagate were briefly up more than 10 percent on Monday amid excited speculation that the hard drive company owned a huge stake in XRP as part of its investment in Ripple almost three years ago. (It\u2019s not clear that\u2019s actually the case.)\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nGoPro\u2019s woes continue to grow.\n\nIts announcement of preliminary fourth-quarter results today compounds the troubles for what has been one of the most disappointing market debutantes in recent years.\n\nThe company issued a revenue forecast that was lighter than analysts were expecting. And the action-camera maker announced its latest efforts to turn around its business:\n\n\u2022 Laying off at least 254 employees, bringing its headcount to under 1,000 worldwide\n\n\u2022 Its founder and C.E.O., Nick Woodman, reducing his cash compensation this year to $1.\n\n\u2022 Getting out of the drone market amid \u201ca hostile regulatory environment\u201d in Europe and the U.S.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOver all, GoPro\u2019s shares have fallen 79 percent since the company\u2019s I.P.O. three-and-a-half years ago.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nHow much of its tax windfall will Apple spend on buybacks?\n\nSteven Milunovich, an analyst at UBS, expects the iPhone maker to use the overseas cash it repatriates to buy back $122 billion in stock through 2019.\n\nThe company holds about $252 billion cash offshore. Mr. Milunovich via CNBC writes:\n\n\u201cRepatriation of ~$250bn of offshore cash should increase the rate of Apple\u2019s share buybacks since the company believes the stock remains attractive in that its services business is undervalued.\u201d\n\nApple has bought back more than $165 billion of stock over the past five years.\n\nPhoto\n\nIs 2018 the year that Twitter is sold?\n\nThe analyst Rich Greenfield of BTIG thinks so. Leading his list of predictions for the year is speculation that the social network would finally become the target of deal-making. (Remember that Salesforce had held talks to buy the company in the fall of 2016.)\n\nFrom Mr. Greenfield\u2019s note:\n\nTwitter offers a unique acquisition opportunity for any company looking to own breaking news, politics and sports, infused with video on mobile devices with tens of millions of daily active users across the world. Add to that a vast treasure trove of data on its users and a Twitter acquisition becomes compelling for many companies across the TMT universe.\n\nWho would buy Twitter? Maybe Salesforce comes back. Or maybe Google does. Or Microsoft.\n\nOther predictions\n\n\u2022 AT&T will defeat the Justice Department in the court battle over Time Warner.\n\n\u2022 CBS and Viacom finally combine.\n\n\u2022 Spotify will go public this year, but may sell itself down the road.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nHow long can Nvidia\u2019s rally last?\n\nThe chip-maker\u2019s stock is up 2.5 percent Monday. The driver? News that Nvidia will partner with Uber and Volkswagen on autonomous driving projects.\n\nReuters reports:\n\n\u2022 \u201cNvidia CEO Jensen Huang said at the CES technology conference in Las Vegas that Uber\u2019s self-driving car fleet was using their technology to help its autonomous cars perceive the world and make split-second decisions.\u201d\n\n\u2022 \u201cWith Volkswagen, Nvidia said it was infusing its artificial intelligence technology into the German automakers\u2019 future lineup, using their new Drive IX platform. The technology will enable so-called \u201cintelligent co-pilot\u201d capabilities based on processing sensor data inside and outside the car.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome context: Shares of Nvidia more than doubled over the past 12 months after a roughly 200 percent gain in 2016. The rally in Nvidia\u2019s shares has come as demand for chips to power data centers, artificial intelligence, autonomous driving and gaming has surged.\n\nNvidia said that \u201c320 companies involved in self-driving cars - whether software developers, automakers and their suppliers, sensor and mapping companies - are using Nvidia Drive, formerly branded as the Drive PX2,\u201d Reuters reports.\n\nDeutsche Bank\u2019s woes continue.\n\nThe German bank is down seven percent the past two days after it said it would post a small loss for 2017, its third consecutive annual. Weak trading and a $1.8 billion hit from the United State\u2019s tax overhaul are the main culprits.\n\nOf those, Deutsche Bank\u2019s trading woes should be more concerning to shareholders, writes Christopher Thompson of Breakingviews.\n\nThe bank said sales and trading revenue was expected to decline 22 percent in the fourth quarter from a year ago. While Deutsche Bank\u2019s trading performance has not be appreciably worse than its European rivals, the decline in its shares \u201cis that it is more dependent on this revenue than other big investment banks.\u201d\n\n\u201cEquities and fixed income sales and trading brought in more than 31 percent of Deutsche\u2019s total revenue in the third quarter of 2017, compared with around 28 percent at Credit Suisse and 19 percent at Barclays. The German group also lacks a consistent source of stable earnings similar to Credit Suisse\u2019s wealth management franchise or Barclays\u2019s UK retail bank.\u201d\n\nThat means that \u201cwithout a pickup in volatility or client activity, trading revenues \u2013 and shareholders \u2013 remain stuck in a rut,\u201d Mr. Thompson writes.\n\nPhoto\n\nIf your business flight to New York was disrupted this weekend, here\u2019s why.\n\nJason Rabinowitz of The Points Guy explained how John F. Kennedy International Airport in particular functions \u2014 and why its operations were severely disrupted even after the \u201cbomb cyclone\u201d of last week.\n\nAmong the interesting pieces of trivia to emerge from the piece:\n\nEssentially, each terminal at JFK is its own little fiefdom with separate operations, management and employees. If an airline calls Terminal 7 home, that\u2019s the only terminal it\u2019s allowed to use. Even if Terminal 4 has a dozen empty gates, an airline slated for Terminal 7 may have to wait hours for a gate to open at Terminal 7.\n\nHere\u2019s Mr. Rabinowitz\u2019s concluding thought:\n\nSavvy travelers all know to avoid NYC area airports whenever possible, and this winter storm drove that point home once again.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nIntel\u2019s C.E.O. is in the hot seat, just in time for CES.\n\nQuestions Brian Krzanich is likely to face about as he prepares for a keynote speech at the biggest convention in consumer electronics:\n\n\u2022 How well will planned fixes work against Meltdown and Spectre, the two computer chip security flaws that affect most of the world\u2019s processors?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Can Intel design new chips without either of the problems?\n\n\u2022 Were the $39 million worth of stock sales he made in November, after the flaws were discovered but before they were disclosed, really just part of a prearranged trading plan?\n\nWhat he would prefer to talk about: Augmented reality and self-driving cars.\n\nToday\u2019s talking point, from Nathaniel Fick, the C.E.O. of the cybersecurity company Endgame, in an NYT Op-Ed:\n\nFrom a corporate governance and accountability perspective, cybersecurity today is being treated like accounting was before the fallout from the Enron scandal inspired the Sarbanes-Oxley Act\u2019s increased standards for corporate disclosures.\n\nThe tech flyaround, CES edition\n\n\u2022 The convention\u2019s organizers said they were seeking more women speakers. (CNET)\n\n\u2022 Google is preparing to step up its fight against Amazon\u2019s Echo. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Amazon isn\u2019t sitting still and wants to put its Alexa virtual assistant in more and more devices. (Recode)\n\n\u2022 Superfast 5G wireless internet will be a big focal point of the convention. (Business Insider)\n\n\u2022 The proliferation of next-generation streaming services is a reminder of how far online video has come since the debut of Web TV 20 years ago, Neal Mohan, YouTube\u2019s chief product officer writes. (Variety)\n\nPhoto\n\n#MeToo and Oprah take center stage at the Golden Globes.\n\nAmong the highlights from last night\u2019s awards, where the uniform was black to acknowledge systemic harassment and sexism in Hollywood:\n\n\u2022 Oprah Winfrey, who received the Cecil B. DeMille Award for lifetime achievement, used her acceptance speech as a call to arms, saying, \u201cA new day is on the horizon.\u201d Speculation has arisen about whether she might run for president.\n\n\u2022 The actresses Debra Messing and Eva Longoria used red-carpet interviews to chastise the E! network on gender pay inequity.\n\n\u2022 Several actresses arrived with activists as their guests.\n\n\u2022 The actress Natalie Portman, introducing the best director award, said, \u201cHere are the all-male nominees.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe host Seth Meyers quipped, \u201cIt\u2019s been years since a white man was this nervous in Hollywood.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe misconduct flyaround\n\n\u2022 An array of start-ups is offering resources for women and companies to halt harassment at work. (Deadline)\n\n\u2022 The National Limousine Association cited #MeToo in its latest ad attacking apps like Uber and Lyft. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Carrie Gracie, a senior editor for BBC News, stepped down from as China editor in a protest against pay inequality, calling the broadcaster\u2019s salary system \u201csecretive and illegal.\u201d (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nWill Jared Kushner have to sell more stakes?\n\nRevelations about more ties between the Kushner Companies and Israeli businesses like the insurer Menora Mivtachim have raised questions about Jared Kushner\u2019s wealth and the complicated relationships that his family\u2019s company has around the world. (Particularly given Mr. Kushner\u2019s role as a top envoy for Middle Eastern peace, as well as a senior adviser in his father-in-law\u2019s White House.)\n\nCaveat: The NYT says that recent deals don\u2019t appear to violate federal ethics laws, and Mr. Kushner appears not to have been personally involved. He has sold stakes in some Kushner Companies properties, like the 666 Fifth Avenue office building in Midtown Manhattan.\n\nThe pull quote, from Robert Weissman of the nonprofit government ethics group Public Citizen:\n\n\u201cNo one could ever imagine this scale of ongoing business interests, not in a local peanut farm or a hardware store but sprawling global businesses that give the president and his top adviser personal economic stakes in an astounding number of policy interests.\u201d\n\nThe Washington flyaround\n\n\u2022 Steve Bannon has backed away from remarks quoted in \u201cFire and Fury,\u201d Michael Wolff\u2019s book on the Trump White House. (NYT)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 \u201cFire and Fury\u201d leads Amazon\u2019s list of best-selling books. (Amazon)\n\n\u2022 Breitbart appears to need Mr. Bannon less than he needs it. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Which big companies have been trying to poach Rob Porter, the White House\u2019s staff secretary? (Axios)\n\n\u2022 The Brookings Institution will hold a discussion today, led by Ben Bernanke, on whether it\u2019s time to permanently replace the 2 percent inflation target. (Brookings)\n\n\u2022 \u201cMr. Trump does not know how to use bilateral trade negotiations to create pressure for stronger multilateral rules,\u201d argues Robert Zoellick, the former World Bank president who served in both Bush administrations. (WSJ)\n\nPhoto\n\nUnintended consequences of the tax law, farming edition.\n\nMr. Trump will head to Tennessee today to promote the tax overhaul. But the farm industry has reason to dislike some of his economic policies.\n\nFrom Ana Swanson and Jim Tankersley of the NYT:\n\nNew analyses of the tax law by economists at the Department of Agriculture suggest it could actually lower farm output in the years to come and effectively raise taxes on the lowest-earning farm households, while delivering large gains for the richest farmers.\n\nAn industry breathing a sigh of relief: Analysts expect a tax windfall for retailers, especially domestically focused ones like Nordstrom and those targeting high-end consumers, according to the WSJ.\n\nThe M. & A. flyaround, second week of January edition.\n\n\u2022 Celgene agreed to buy Impact Biomedicines, which makes blood disease drugs. It will pay between $1.1 billion and $7 billion, depending on performance. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Hershey and Ferrero are among those vying for Nestl\u00e9\u2019s American candy business, according to unidentified people. (CNBC)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 KKR sold its stake in Valinge, a Swedish maker of flooring parts, to the family that controls Lego, for about $500 million. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Expect buying sprees from big tech companies this year, but relatively few I.P.O.s from Silicon Valley start-ups. (CNBC)\n\n\u2022 \u201cDeal makers are now on the clock, especially if you believe that the bull market is in its waning stages and the Federal Reserve is serious about interest-rate hikes.\u201d (Barron\u2019s)\n\nPhoto\n\nJana starts its corporate do-gooder push with Apple.\n\nThe hedge fund\u2019s first campaign for its Jana Impact Capital fund: Prod Apple into finding ways to reduce children\u2019s addiction to iPhones.\n\nFrom the campaign\u2019s public letter to the tech titan:\n\nThe only difference between the changes we are advocating at Apple now and the type of change shareholders are better known for advocating is the time period over which they will enhance and protect value.\n\nWho\u2019s helping Jana: The big California pension fund known as Calstrs. Also on board as advisers are the musician Sting and his wife, Trudie Styler; Sister Patricia Daly, a nun who took on Exxon Mobil over environmental issues; and Robert Eccles, a sustainability expert.\n\nThe bigger picture: Jana is wading into corporate social responsibility, an area that Wall Street has only recently started dabbling in, the WSJ reports. Firms like TPG have raised social impact funds, but no major activist fund has started campaigns focused specifically on getting companies to act better from a social standpoint.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhy Warren Buffett is optimistic about the U.S.\n\nHe explains with some math in this week\u2019s Time, guest-edited by Bill Gates:\n\n\u2022 America\u2019s population should grow by about 0.8 percent a year, between births and immigration.\n\n\u2022 Assuming annual gains in real GDP continue to be about 2 percent, that means the U.S. will deliver about 1.2 percent growth in per-capita GDP.\n\nWhat that means in real terms: In 25 years, GDP per head would go from $52,000 to $79,000.\n\nThe pull quote:\n\nThis game of economic miracles is in its early innings. Americans will benefit from far more and better \u201cstuff\u201d in the future. The challenge will be to have this bounty deliver a better life to the disrupted as well as to the disrupters. And on this matter, many Americans are justifiably worried.\n\nSpeaking of Mr. Buffett: Now that class A shares in his Berkshire Hathaway conglomerate have surpassed $300,000 each \u2014 they closed on Friday at $301,525 \u2014 the WSJ looked at which of its products that could buy you.\n\nPhoto\n\nIf you can\u2019t buy Bitcoin \u2026\n\nThen Dogecoin \u2014 the parody virtual currency inspired by an animal meme \u2014 may be your ticket to digital riches. Its market capitalization surpassed $2 billion on Saturday and was hovering just under that level this morning.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA potentially big initial coin offering: The messaging app Telegram plans to create its own virtual currency and hopes to raise as much as $500 million in a pre-sale I.C.O., according to TechCrunch.\n\nRevolving Door\n\n\u2022 Marcelo Claure, the C.E.O. of Sprint, and Rajeev Misra, the head of SoftBank\u2019s Vision Fund, will join Uber\u2019s board following the ride-hailing giant\u2019s share sale to a SoftBank-led group.\n\nThe Speed Read\n\n\u2022 What happened when the U.S. tried to hold a Swiss banker personally accountable for creating accounts for Americans hiding money from tax collectors. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Saudi Aramco, along with some of the kingdom\u2019s biggest companies, will raise pay after a royal order extended handouts to government workers to ease discontent over prices. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Martin Shkreli is no longer around to deflect attention from a play by drug companies: to start prices high, then raise them incrementally. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Mexico is rejecting one of the Trump administration\u2019s Nafta demands: a provision that could block its truckers from making deliveries into the middle of the U.S. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Indians are proving reluctant to switch to digital payments, despite intensive efforts by the government and global technology companies. (Deadline)\n\n\u2022 The latest to be punished in the Libor benchmark-manipulation scandal is a former Royal Bank of Scotland trader, Neil Danziger. He was fined $338,000 and banned from working in finance. (Bloomberg)\n\nWe\u2019d love your feedback as we experiment with the writing, format and design of this briefing. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "With Apple, the Tech Reckoning Gains Momentum: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Almost a decade after the financial crisis, economies in just about every corner of the world \u2014 the United States, Europe, even perennially sluggish Japan \u2014 are growing in unison.\n\nBut can the expansion last?\n\nMany economists predict it will \u2014 at least into this year. But they also fret that unresolved problems embedded in the global economy, including income inequality and stagnant productivity, could hamper further gains and stall growth once again. As the world\u2019s business leaders gather this week at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, confronting these issues will be high on the agenda.\n\n\u201cWe will see the momentum created by the recovery continuing into 2018,\u201d said Shanta Devarajan, senior director for development economics at the World Bank. \u201cBut the biggest question is how sustainable that is going to be. That is what we are mostly concerned about.\u201d\n\nThe World Bank forecasts that global growth this year will reach 3.1 percent, a slight improvement from its estimated 3 percent rate for 2017. That would be the fastest pace since the post-economic-crisis bump in 2011. While the world\u2019s advanced nations are expected to slow marginally, the World Bank projects emerging economies will gain speed, with 4.5 percent growth this year compared with an estimated 4.3 percent in 2017.", "title": "With Davos Approaching, the Global Economy Is Surging, but Growth Could Stall", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 In late summer, Verizon Communications came to Rupert Murdoch with a surprise acquisition offer.\n\nVerizon \u2014 locked in battle with AT&T, which was then finalizing its $85.4 billion takeover of Time Warner \u2014 wanted to buy pieces of 21st Century Fox, Mr. Murdoch\u2019s television and film conglomerate. Representatives of the two companies secretly met at least once to discuss a merger.\n\nMr. Murdoch, 86, shrugged off the talks as uninspiring, according to an associate, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because he wanted to maintain his access to the media titan. Verizon declined to comment, but the overture prompted Mr. Murdoch to start to think seriously \u2014 for the first time \u2014 about selling his Hollywood treasures.\n\nNot only would a sale solve a business problem, it could solve a family one.\n\nSeveral months later, Mr. Murdoch agreed to sell much of 21st Century Fox to the Walt Disney Company. The proposed $52.4 billion deal, which is subject to regulatory approval, has the potential to radically reshape the entertainment world, but it also has many wondering what the future holds for Mr. Murdoch and the two sons who seemed to be on the cusp of taking over his vast media holdings.", "title": "With Disney Deal Looming, Murdoch\u2019s Empire Is Fractured", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Responding to Mr. Blackmun late Thursday, U.S.A. Gymnastics, the sport\u2019s governing body, said it \u201ccompletely embraces the requirements\u201d outlined in the letter. The organization\u2019s unsigned reply said U.S.A. Gymnastics would \u201cwork with the U.S.O.C. to accomplish change for the betterment of our organization, our athletes and our clubs.\u201d\n\nAt Michigan State, university officials are already facing the prospect of legal judgments and fees from lawsuits filed by dozens of victims. At Penn State, where a former football coach was found to be a serial child molester, those costs have reached nearly a quarter of a billion dollars.\n\nThe lawsuits and the legislative inquiries center on what Michigan State knew about Dr. Nassar\u2019s behavior during the two decades he worked there. Several victims have alleged that they had told Michigan State employees, as far back as the late 1990s, about being molested under the guise of treatment.\n\nIn 2014, after a complaint from a patient, the university conducted an internal investigation that cleared him, after which he continued to prey on more patients. On Thursday, ESPN reported that Michigan State had neglected to tell federal authorities, who were investigating the college\u2019s handling of other sexual misconduct complaints, about the 2014 case until the accusations against Dr. Nassar became widely known in 2016.\n\n\u201cI feel like every day we are peeling back another layer of a very deep mystery,\u201d said State Representative Adam Zemke, a Democrat who introduced a resolution that passed by a wide margin on Wednesday and called for the resignation of the university president, Lou Anna K. Simon. Hours later, she resigned.\n\nMr. Zemke said he saw parallels between what happened at Michigan State and the \u201cwillful negligence\u201d during the water crisis in Flint, for which government officials have been charged with felonies and accused of covering up evidence.\n\nIn her resignation message, Ms. Simon wrote, \u201cTo the survivors, I can never say enough that I am so sorry that a trusted, renowned physician was really such an evil, evil person.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe added: \u201cAs tragedies are politicized, blame is inevitable. As president, it is only natural that I am the focus of this anger.\u201d\n\nThe Legislature\u2019s deepening interest reflects the importance of Michigan State to the state and the realization that the scandal can easily become a political liability if not handled correctly. It has also become a subplot in this year\u2019s race for governor. Among those who have had a role in the investigations are two candidates \u2014 the Republican attorney general, Bill Schuette, whose office prosecuted the state criminal cases, and a Democrat, Gretchen Whitmer, who was the county prosecutor in Lansing during part of the time that Dr. Nassar was being investigated.\n\nBoth Mr. Schuette and Ms. Whitmer have faced criticism by some for their work on the case, and both have strongly defended their record.\n\nWhen The Detroit News wrote in an editorial this month that Mr. Schuette\u2019s \u201cindifference borders on dereliction of duty,\u201d he called for a retraction and said \u201cnothing could be further from the truth.\u201d And after a foe in the Democratic primary race suggested Ms. Whitmer did not act aggressively enough on the case, she said that she was \u201cproud of my record\u201d and that \u201cthis is an issue that is incredibly close to my heart.\u201d\n\n\u201cI think the system worked the way that it\u2019s supposed to,\u201d Ms. Whitmer said of the prosecution in an interview on Thursday. She also called for \u201ca housecleaning\u201d in Michigan State\u2019s administration.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJason Cody, a spokesman for the university, noted that its trustees had asked the state attorney general to investigate, and Mr. Cody said that the school would fully cooperate. The university has created a fund to help survivors get counseling and mental health services, he said.\n\n\u201cMany at M.S.U. viewed the brave women who came forward to tell their stories at Nassar\u2019s sentencing hearing,\u201d Mr. Cody said. \u201cWords cannot express the sorrow we feel for Nassar\u2019s victims; the thoughts and prayers of the entire M.S.U. community are with these women as we listen to their heartbreaking testimony.\u201d\n\nDr. Nassar, 54, was sentenced on Wednesday for sexually abusing seven girls, though he had been accused by many more. His seven-day sentencing hearing drew more than 150 women, including Olympic gymnasts who are household names, to give wrenching testimony about what he had done to them.\n\nDozens of women, including gymnasts, swimmers, figure skaters, runners and basketball players, are now suing Dr. Nassar, Michigan State and U.S.A. Gymnastics, alleging abuse going back two decades. In court papers, they have said that they trusted Dr. Nassar because he was a renowned sports doctor, and the team physician for the United States gymnastics team.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome of his patients said they complained to Michigan State employees, including the women\u2019s gymnastics coach at the time, Kathie Klages, in the late 1990s, according to court papers, but were met with disbelief. A lawyer for Ms. Klages has not commented on the allegations.\n\nIn 2014, a recent graduate filed a complaint against Dr. Nassar under Title IX, the federal law governing sexual harassment and assault on campus. She said that she had sought out Dr. Nassar for hip pain, and that he molested her and became sexually aroused until she removed his hands from her body, according to court papers in the civil cases filed against him.\n\nBut after consulting with other medical professionals, including Dr. Nassar\u2019s colleagues, the university\u2019s investigation concluded that his treatment had been \u201cmedically appropriate,\u201d the court papers said.\n\nThe abuse continued until 2016, when Rachael Denhollander, a former gymnast, told her story to The Indianapolis Star, and a police investigation soon began.\n\nOn Thursday, ESPN reported that Michigan State had failed to turn over its file on Dr. Nassar in 2014, when the Education Department was investigating unrelated complaints about the way the university had handled sexual assault and harassment cases. The university began turning over records in late 2016, ESPN reported, saying that the failure had been an oversight.\n\nOn Thursday, the education secretary said her agency would review Michigan State\u2019s handling of the complaints against Dr. Nassar. \u201cWhat happened at Michigan State is abhorrent,\u201d Ms. DeVos said. \u201cStudents must be safe and protected on our nation\u2019s campuses. The department is investigating this matter and will hold M.S.U. accountable for any violations of federal law.\u201d\n\nBut in a December letter to Mr. Schuette, the Michigan attorney general, the university\u2019s lawyer, Patrick Fitzgerald, said he believed that evidence would show that no Michigan State official believed that Dr. Nassar committed sexual abuse before the newspaper reports in 2016. The university is also arguing that it cannot be held liable because of Michigan\u2019s sovereign immunity law, which protects state agencies from lawsuits in most circumstances and \u201cprotects the state\u2019s citizens by safeguarding its fiscal stability,\u201d the school said in a court filing.\n\nJohn Manly, a lawyer for some of the women in the civil cases, said the university\u2019s response to the lawsuits reminded him of the way the Roman Catholic Church had responded to allegations of child sex abuse by priests. \u201cIt\u2019s a page right out of the bishops\u2019 playbooks,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf Michigan State is ruled to be not immune, the cost could be significant. One state representative, Klint Kesto, a Republican, said he has drafted legislation that would prevent state funds from being used for payouts. If that bill is passed, it would force Michigan State to use tuition or endowment money. \u201cThe school should use all its assets, all its income from other sources first before they go into the pockets of taxpayers,\u201d Mr. Kesto said.\n\nOn Thursday, Senator Gary Peters, a Democrat, called for congressional oversight and investigations of the scandal and said in a statement that it was \u201ctime for us to find out who is responsible at Michigan State University and U.S.A. Gymnastics for enabling and failing to stop this criminal.\u201d\n\nState legislators requested that university trustees provide investigative documents about Dr. Nassar dating back to 2014.\n\n\u201cIt is our sincere hope that the university will cooperate with our request and inquiries without the need to employ means of compulsion,\u201d the lawmakers wrote, adding that they may issue subpoenas if the records were not received by 5 p.m. on Feb. 9.", "title": "With Larry Nassar Sentenced, Focus Is on What Michigan State Knew", "authors": ["Mitch Smith", "Anemona Hartocollis"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "For the first time in nearly two decades, Essence magazine is once again a fully black-owned publication.\n\nThe magazine, a mainstay of black culture for almost half a century, was bought by Richelieu Dennis, the founder of Sundial Brands, a large personal-care products company, from Time Inc., Essence Ventures announced on Wednesday. Garland for almost a year in hopes that a Republican would be elected to the White House.\n\nAsked Monday morning how much of an issue that mistrust was, Mr. Manchin was clear. \u201cUh, most of it,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Schumer asked Ms. Collins to meet him in his office late Sunday after Mr. McConnell\u2019s remarks and said he needed more clarity and assurance from the majority leader. Saudi Arabia and Iran have been locked in what is essentially a proxy war in Yemen, and human rights groups say both sides are guilty of abetting a colossal humanitarian disaster.\n\nSaudi Arabia, which has backed the Yemeni government, leads a military coalition that has conducted a campaign of punishing airstrikes on Yemen since March 2015.\n\nThis month, a United Nations panel concluded in a confidential report that Iran had violated the arms embargo imposed on Yemen by failing to prevent Houthi rebels from obtaining Iranian-made missiles, including a missile that crashed near an airport outside the Saudi capital, Riyadh, in November.\n\nBut the report stopped short of accusing Iran of actually supplying the weapons.", "title": "With Tour and White House Lunch, Trump Presses U.N. Ryan.\n\nFurther, a group of well-financed outside Republican groups is planning to unleash a biting advertising campaign against Conor Lamb, the Democratic nominee and a Marine Corps veteran. A pair of conservative organizations have already broadcast about $700,000 worth of commercials in the district and the best-funded House \u201csuper PAC,\u201d the Congressional Leadership Fund, is preparing to go on the air next week with a spot blistering Mr. Lamb.\n\n\u201cWe will attack Conor Lamb, we will define Conor Lamb, and we will explain why he is a Nancy Pelosi rubber stamp,\u201d vowed Corry Bliss, who runs the Congressional Leadership Fund and had already opened two field offices in the district, referring to the House Democratic leader.\n\nBut Mr. Lamb, a former prosecutor, may not be so easy to link to Ms. Pelosi.\n\n\u201cThey can throw anything they want at him, but he\u2019s already said he\u2019s not voting for Pelosi as speaker,\u201d said Marcel L. Zwilling, the German cutlery maker, has introduced a small, sturdy cleaver, with a blade just 4\u00bd inches long, in their Pro line. It\u2019s good for disjointing a chicken, smashing cucumbers for a Sichuan salad or making short work of garlic: Zwilling Pro Mini-Cleaver, $59.99 (sale price), williams-sonoma.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "With a Cleaver, Bigger Is Not Always Better", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Moreover, only one of those loans puts your home at risk. Buz Livingston, a financial planner in Santa Rosa Beach, Fla., recalls counseling two families that approached him after borrowing against their homes in part to pay for college, only to have the home values drop significantly. \u201cI don\u2019t recommend using home equity to fund college,\u201d he said. Both families lost their homes after unemployment compounded the problem.\n\nIndeed, a home equity line of credit can often serve as gateway debt that threatens retirement goals, according to Milo M. Benningfield, a financial planner in San Francisco. He recalls one couple who drew down an equity line for college; the husband was self-employed. Then, they used the line for other things, even as their income fluctuated and they refinanced the entire mortgage to try to keep up. By the time they came to see him, they had to sell their home and move into an apartment in order to retire at all.\n\nPerhaps you have more self-control and work in a reasonably secure field. Then, you might follow the example of Jen Mouer, the mother of twin 16-year-old girls who are high school juniors. She and her husband are both government employees living in Richmond, Va., and they\u2019ve been saving in a 529 account since the girls were young.\n\nTheir college budget is about $20,000 per year, per daughter. Half of that will come from those 529 savings, another $4,000 to $6,000 per child will come from Ms. Mouer and her husband, and the girls will cover the rest with federal student loans.\n\nThe parents had planned to use a home equity line of credit to pay their share of the annual college bills all at once, and then repay the debt in full each year. They would capture one deduction on their home equity interest while getting another for deposits in their state\u2019s 529 plan.\n\nThe removal of the home equity deduction takes a bit of wind out of the Mouers\u2019 sails, but the family hopes to stick with the plan. At the same time, they are resolute about not threatening their own retirement security by reaching too high for expensive private schools that don\u2019t offer merit scholarships.\n\nAs for their daughters and their debt, it will be cheap, flexible federal student loans for them and nothing else, in part because one of the family\u2019s goals is to promote independence once college is over. So how much debt is acceptable for the twins? \u201cNot so much that they have to live with us after graduation,\u201d Ms. Mouer said.", "title": "With a Tax Deduction Gone, Is Home Equity a Smart Way to Pay for College?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "In October , the Trump administration announced that the United States would withdraw from Unesco, the United Nations cultural organization known for its World Heritage sites program, by the end of 2018. But that rejection, tied to perceptions of anti-Israel bias, has not stopped Unesco from naming a number of American cities to its Creative Cities Network.\n\nIn November, Kansas City, San Antonio and Seattle joined a class of 64 cities inducted into the program which evaluates applicants in seven different creative fields, including crafts and folk art, design, film, gastronomy, literature, media arts and music. The network, which now includes 180 cities from 72 countries, aims to encourage members to share best practices \u201cto promote creative industries, strengthen participation in cultural life, and integrate culture into sustainable urban development policies,\u201d according to a statement announcing the new members.\n\n\u201cBeing a member of the U.C.C.N. is the starting point of a long journey to which Unesco invites all cities wherever they may be, provided they share the vision of working together to stimulate culture and creativity as motors for sustainable urban development,\u201d Emmanuelle Robert, Project Manager for the Unesco Creative Cities Network, wrote in an email.\n\nUnlike Unesco\u2019s World Heritage Center, which singles out cultural and natural landmarks like the Great Wall of China or the Great Barrier Reef for their universal value to humanity, the Creative City designation is looser and more dispersed.", "title": "With or Without U.S. Funding, Unesco Celebrates American Cities", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "When filmmakers and TV showrunners want to drop viewers into a paranoid but all-too-believable future, they return again and again to the same material: the dozens of novels and stories by the science fiction writer Philip K. Dick.\n\nFrom \u201cBlade Runner\u201d (1982), inspired by the 1968 novel \u201cDo Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?,\u201d to Amazon\u2019s \u201cThe Man in the High Castle,\u201d based on the 1962 novel of the same name, the adaptations reveal Dick\u2019s stories to be endlessly adaptable tales for modern-day concerns: privacy, corporate control, free will and what it means to be human.\n\nNow Amazon, in partnership with Channel 4 in Britain and Sony Pictures Television, has found perhaps the most natural form to tackle the prolific writer\u2019s catalog: \u201cPhilip K. Dick\u2019s Electric Dreams,\u201d a 10-episode anthology show that adapts the writer\u2019s short stories for the first time on TV. (All 10 will be made available to Amazon Prime subscribers on Jan. 12.) The timing couldn\u2019t be better. Not only does the series grapple with questions evermore relevant in our increasingly technologically augmented times, but it is tailor-made for a format that\u2019s helped TV enter a new golden age.", "title": "With \u2018Electric Dreams,\u2019 Philip K. Dick Gets the TV Anthology Treatment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "The show\u2019s honesty was also appealing to the cast of \u201cThe Chi.\u201d \u201cIt\u2019s not one of those shows that\u2019s all glitz and glamour, all Skittles and quinoa,\u201d Mr. Mitchell said. \u201cIt\u2019s the real truth.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHaving lost close friends to gun violence when growing up in New Orleans, the actor said appearing in the drama \u201cwas one of those times where it\u2019s more therapy than acting.\u201d\n\nCommon, a fellow Chicago native who is an executive producer and one of the stars of \u201cThe Chi,\u201d said Ms. Waithe stressed during filming how important it was for the show to pay homage to her city. \u201cAnd so we\u2019ve got a mission to be as authentic as we can,\u201d he said. They employed a crew comprised almost entirely of locals, shot on location and filled the soundtrack exclusively with music by Chicago artists like Chance the Rapper and Kanye West.\n\nThanks to the new show, and acting roles on \u201cMaster of None\u201d and \u201cTransparent,\u201d she\u2019s slowly becoming a Chicago celebrity, too. Late that afternoon in October, as Ms. Waithe stood in front of her elementary school and gazed at the large blue sign outside its main entrance, a burly security guard approached as if to make sure she wasn\u2019t causing any trouble. But as he got closer, he recognized Ms. Waithe and yelled to the principal, \u201cIt\u2019s all good! I knew she was famous!\u201d\n\nThat evening, Ms. Waithe enjoyed one of the perks of her newfound celebrity, joining a panel discussion entitled \u201cThe Power of Black Women\u201d with the editor in chief of Teen Vogue, Elaine Welteroth; and Uber\u2019s chief brand officer, Bozoma St. John. Ms. Waithe said the topic was timely. She first noticed Hollywood was becoming more open-minded to racial diversity when, in early 2017, driving down Sunset Boulevard, in Los Angeles, she saw a towering billboard for the HBO comedy \u201cInsecure,\u201d starring the African-American actress Issa Rae. That it sat next to a minuscule ad for the same network\u2019s Sarah Jessica Parker-led series \u201cDivorce\u201d signaled to her a reshaping of a powerful network\u2019s priorities.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Watching Get the most out of your screen time with movie and TV recommendations, news and commentary from New York Times experts. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe are not in the same world anymore,\u201d she said. \u201cEven white people are tired of watching white people\u2019s shows.\u201d\n\nThough Mr. Ansari said he agreed \u201cthings are kind of going in the right direction, I don\u2019t think it\u2019s a tidal wave of change\u201d in terms of more stories starring or written by minorities being greenlit. \u201cWe\u2019re all kind of chipping away,\u201d Mr. Ansari said, referring to Ms. Waithe, Ms. Rae, and Donald Glover (FX\u2019s \u201cAtlanta\u201d). \u201cThere\u2019s a responsibility for me to use the platform I have to pull in other people. I\u2019m black! Hang your dreams on me. Hang your hopes on me. I\u2019ll carry them to the best of my ability. \u2019\u201d\n\nAlthough she no longer lives in Chicago, she said working on such a personal show like \u201cThe Chi\u201d felt fitting.\n\n\u201cBecause wherever I go, the Chi goes with me,\u201d Ms. Waithe said of her hometown. \u201cPeople always go \u2018Damn, how you got all this happening at once?\u2019 \u201d She laughed. \u201cI tell them it\u2019s the Chicago in me.\u201d", "title": "With \u2018The Chi,\u2019 Lena Waithe Heads Home in Search of the Real Chicago", "authors": ["Dan Hyman"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSAN FRANCISCO \u2014 For more than a year, Twitter has faced censure for allowing President Trump to use its service to say whatever he wants. And for more than a year, the company has not addressed the criticism definitively.\n\nOn Friday, the company tackled the matter head on. Without ever mentioning Mr. Trump by name, Twitter said in a statement that he would remain on the social media service.\n\n\u201cElected world leaders play a critical role in that conversation because of their outsized impact on our society,\u201d Twitter said in the statement, which was posted to its site. \u201cBlocking a world leader from Twitter or removing their controversial tweets would hide important information people should be able to see and debate.\u201d\n\nTwitter made the statement after a swell of outrage over Mr. Trump\u2019s tweets this week, in which he boasted that he had a \u201cnuclear button\u201d that was \u201cmuch bigger\u201d and \u201cmore powerful\u201d than North Korea\u2019s, denounced his former strategist Stephen K. Bannon and derided the mainstream media.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMany critics said they believed Mr. Trump\u2019s recent posts violated Twitter\u2019s terms of service, which prohibit messages that threaten violence, death or physical harm. Belichick has more than a dozen assistant coaches, but few approach him. There are nearly 50 players, but they tend to scrupulously avoid their head coach.\n\nTypically, there is a buffer of about 20 feet between Belichick and any other person for most of the three hours it takes to play an N.F.L. game.\n\nStanding near the sideline throng, Belichick is amid his team but apart as well.\n\nOn Saturday night, as the Patriots hosted the Tennessee Titans in a divisional-round playoff game, there was no moment when Belichick appeared more alone than late in the first quarter.\n\nThe Titans had just silenced the raucous New England crowd, scoring the game\u2019s first points on a methodical 11-play touchdown drive.", "title": "Without a Word, Bill Belichick Can Say a Lot", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "But even as prosecutors have shown how power players like Mr. Percoco navigated \u201cthe Albany game,\u201d as one witness put it, they have also shown how minor players in the game \u2014 Mr. Aiello and Joseph Gerardi, another executive in Mr. Aiello\u2019s company \u2014 could get caught up in it.\n\nText messages, emails and testimony over the last few days have shown men who were eager for the attention of state officials, gleeful at the thought of outsmarting bureaucratic regulations, and indignant when they thought they had been overlooked.\n\n\u201cThe administration has embarrassed me in my community,\u201d Mr. Aiello wrote in a text message in September 2015 to Todd R. Howe, a lobbyist with ties to Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Percoco, after Mr. Aiello\u2019s son, who worked in state government, did not receive as large a raise as he had expected. \u201cI have been loyal as the day is long. They insult us like this. I\u2019m finished!!!\n\n\u201cEverybody else gets what they need and want. I keep giving,\u201d he continued. \u201cIt\u2019s a sad statement!\u201d\n\nMr. Howe passed the message to Mr. Percoco, who sent an email to administrative staff members demanding that they give Mr. Aiello\u2019s son a 10 percent raise. They complied.\n\nMr. Percoco, Mr. Aiello and Mr. Gerardi, along with a fourth co-defendant, Peter Galbraith Kelly Jr., of Competitive Power Ventures, are on trial together. They have all denied any wrongdoing. Mr. Howe is expected to be the prosecution\u2019s star witness. In 2014, Mr. Aiello and Mr. Gerardi had emailed back and forth for weeks with state officials, trying to avoid a state requirement that might have forced them to hire union employees for a project. They were unsuccessful. They turned to Mr. Howe, who asked Mr. Percoco to intervene. Soon after, state lawyers reversed the requirement.\n\nEmails from Mr. Aiello and Mr. Gerardi show they were in awe of \u2014 and more than a little giddy about \u2014 the victory.\n\n\u201cTotally Amazing,\u201d Mr. Aiello wrote in an email to Mr. Howe. Of the official who had tried to enforce the requirement, he added: \u201cHe underestimated the power of TH, JP!\u201d, a reference to Mr. Howe\u2019s and Mr. Percoco\u2019s initials.\n\nLawyers for Mr. Aiello and Mr. Gerardi on Wednesday cast them as amiable, well-intentioned executives who had been frustrated by the state government\u2019s bureaucracy even as they admired the governor. (Mr. Aiello once organized a campaign fund-raiser for Mr. Cuomo, because he believed in his \u201cwhole philosophy and what he was doing,\u201d an F.B.I. special agent testified on Tuesday that he had told her.)\n\nBut the lawyers also acknowledged the lengths to which the men went to try and earn the approval and recognition of top state officials.\n\n\u201cYou see this green little carpet there,\u201d Mr. Aiello\u2019s lawyer, Stephen Coffey, asked Mr. Kennedy, referring to the photo of Mr. Aiello and the governor in the Syracuse hotel. \u201cWere you aware that for two days prior to this, employees had worked day and night getting that \u2014 that\u2019s the Aloft Hotel, right?\u201d\n\n\u201cGetting that ready for the governor, were you aware of that?\u201d\n\nWhen Mr. Kennedy said no, Mr. Coffey asked what he had thought was the reason for Mr. Aiello\u2019s displeasure.\n\n\u201cAt the time, I thought it was because he wasn\u2019t invited out for drinks,\u201d Mr. Kennedy replied.", "title": "Witnesses Tell How Percoco Gave Developers Access to the \u2018Albany Game\u2019", "authors": ["Vivian Wang"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "On a whiteboard, they brainstormed together a list of ideal characteristics for a statewide Republican candidate, among them: resources (i.e. having money or the ability to raise vast sums), being a woman, being a political outsider, speaking Spanish and having a political base in downstate New York.\n\nThe problem? Nassar their advocate, a sports medicine \u201cguru\u201d who would help cure them of their pain.\n\nBut on Monday in a Michigan courtroom, on the fifth day of Dr. Nassar\u2019s sentencing hearings, dozens of women spoke out or had their statements read aloud for them \u2014 statements about how, after winning their trust, he sexually molested them. They described being misled as children and teenagers, saying that they saw Dr. Nassar as a trustworthy savior who consoled them or wiped blood from their faces, and as a man they looked up to as a prominent doctor in gymnastics.\n\nAs nearly 100 women did last week, they offered remarks that went beyond the emotional and graphic stories of sexual abuse by Dr. Nassar when they were sent to him as young athletes. On Monday, more than a dozen asked how the abuse could have gone on for decades, and why organizations \u2014 such as the national gymnastics governing body and Michigan State University, his employer \u2014 enabled him or turned a blind eye.\n\nOn Monday, several top board members of U.S.A. The film\u2019s star, Chlo\u00eb Grace Moretz, dedicated the award to survivors of the discredited practice. \u201cWe want this movie to shine a light that it is only illegal in nine states out of the 50 states of this country to practice sexual conversion therapy,\u201d she said in her acceptance speech.\n\nBecause of technical difficulties, Ms. Akhavan\u2019s video acceptance speech was not broadcast.\n\nSara Colangelo was the recipient of the U.S. Dramatic Directing Prize for her film \u201cThe Kindergarten Teacher,\u201d a remake of the 2014 Israel film of the same name about an educator\u2019s obsession with a gifted student. Rudy Valdez\u2019s documentary \u201cThe Sentence\u201d won the audience documentary prize for an American film.", "title": "Women Dominate Sundance\u2019s Winners List", "authors": ["Peter Libbey"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Things are different in the elite universities in America. Harvard\u2019s current freshman class, for instance, is just under 50 percent female, while Stanford\u2019s is 51 percent female.\n\nThomas A. DiPrete, the Giddings professor of sociology at Columbia University and co-author of \u201cThe Rise of Women\u201d on the gender gap in education, said that elite institutions maintain a closer gender balance because they get so many highly qualified applicants that they can select students with the aim of achieving a well-rounded class.\n\nIt is among students from lower-socioeconomic status backgrounds that the ratio of women and men earning college degrees has changed most dramatically in recent decades, Dr. DiPrete said. In the mid-20th century, he said, \u201cthe biggest gender gap in favor of the boys was among the less educated. It was the college educated parents where the gap was small. And that flipped.\u201d\n\nEducation experts welcomed the news about Oxford. \u201cIt is a significant moment,\u201d said Nick Hillman, a former government adviser and director of the Higher Education Policy Institute. \u201cWe don\u2019t know if this is a trend, but it probably is part of one,\u201d he said, adding that results showed girls progressively outperforming boys throughout the education system.\n\nPhoto\n\nSam Smethers, chief executive of the Fawcett Society, a leading gender-equality charity, also hailed the announcement, but said it was only a step in a longer process.\n\n\u201cIt is good to see this progress at Oxford, but what matters is which subjects they are studying and what happens when they leave,\u201d she said. \u201cWe know that women are still underrepresented in math, science and engineering subjects, and that female graduates experience a pay gap on entering the workplace.\u201d\n\nOxford and Cambridge have faced persistent criticism for favoring graduates of Britain\u2019s elite \u201cpublic schools,\u201d expensive private boarding schools like Eton and Harrow. In 2015 nearly one in three Oxford colleges failed to admit a single black British high school graduate, according to David Lammy, a lawmaker for the opposition Labour Party who accused the university of \u201csocial apartheid\u201d over its admissions policies.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOriel College, Oxford, was at the center of highly charged protests from students who campaigned, unsuccessfully, for the removal of a statue of Cecil Rhodes, an imperialist benefactor seen by many as an architect of apartheid. Some black students likened the memorial to erecting a statue of Hitler.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOxford University itself gave the enrollment news a cautious welcome, saying in a statement that it \u201ccan\u2019t say for certain whether this is the first time in history that Oxford has let in more women than men.\n\n\u201cAnd while it\u2019s too early to call this a trend based on one year\u2019s numbers, it is a welcome sign of progress for female applicants to Oxford,\u201d the statement said.\n\nOfficials at Oxford say they are unsure why women have been underrepresented, though Mr. Hillman said that an involved interview procedure may skew the admissions process. After students are evaluated based on grades, predicted examination results and sometimes tests, those making the cut are interviewed by their prospective tutors, who make the final decisions on admittance.\n\n\u201cEverybody thinks they are being totally fair and are choosing on potential,\u201d Mr. Hillman said of the interviews, \u201cbut all the evidence is of unconscious bias \u2014 that we choose people who look and think like us.\u201d\n\nThe changing numbers may therefore also reflect the growing proportion of female academics.\n\nThe first woman to be appointed to a full professorship at Oxford was Agnes Headlam-Morley, who became Montague Burton professor of international relations in October 1948. In 2016 another milestone was passed when Louise Richardson became the university\u2019s first female vice chancellor.\n\nOxford describes itself as the \u201coldest university in the English-speaking world,\u201d and on its website says \u201cthere is no clear date of foundation, but teaching existed at Oxford in some form in 1096 and developed rapidly from 1167, when Henry II banned English students from attending the University of Paris.\u201d\n\nAcademic halls for women were established in 1878, but it was not until 1920 that women were allowed full membership at Oxford, allowing them to graduate. Five of its all-male colleges admitted women in 1974, with all eventually admitting both women and men.", "title": "Women Outnumber Men in Oxford\u2019s Newest Class. It Only Took 1,000 Years.", "authors": ["Stephen Castle"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Among the pants wearers was Alison Brie, nominee for best performance by an actress in a television series for her role in \u201cGlow,\u201d who wore skinny black pants \u2026 under a voluminous sleeveless dress. \u201cTonight is about women wearing the pants so I chose to literally wear the pants,\u201d Ms. Brie said.\n\nDebra Messing, an eight-time Golden Globe nominee and an actress on NBC\u2019s \u201cWill & Grace,\u201d paired her floor-length black pants with an equally long sparkly black-and-silver dress that had a wide opening in the front. \u201cI am wearing black to thank and honor all of the brave whistle-blowers who came forward and share their stories of harassment and assault and discrimination,\u201d Ms. Messing told the E! commentator Giuliana Rancic. \u201cTo stand in solidarity with my sisters all over the globe.\u201d", "title": "Women Wear the Pants This Awards Season", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019m really disappointed,\u201d Ms. Paley said. \u201cI\u2019m getting harassed by his fans for speaking out, like this is something I wanted.\u201d\n\nShe added, \u201cHe had months of opportunity to make it right, and he didn\u2019t. Times that she felt pressured to appear nude in an orgy scene in Mr. Franco\u2019s yet unreleased film \u201cThe Long Home,\u201d and that other actresses who appeared in the scene wore plastic guards covering their vaginas that Mr. Franco removed before simulating sex acts with them.\n\n\u201cI got it in my head pretty quickly that, O.K., you don\u2019t say \u2018no\u2019 to this guy,\u201d Ms. Tither-Kaplan told The L.A. Times.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Franco\u2019s attorney, Michael Plonsker, told The L.A. Times that he disputed all of the women\u2019s allegations in the article. Contacted by The New York Times, representatives for the actor pointed to Mr. Franco\u2019s comments in late-night television interviews in which he said the women\u2019s tweets were inaccurate but that he supported their right to speak out.\n\nThe actress Ally Sheedy, who appeared in a 2014 Off Broadway production of \u201cThe Long Shrift\u201d that Mr. Franco directed, wrote in a Twitter post on Sunday, \u201cJames Franco just won.
