When she showed up for one of her first sessions, a barre class, she settled into a spot next to a woman who told her that there was not enough space, and banished her to a spot across the room.\n\n\u201cIt was in a corner, and we were doing all these bends, and I had to squeeze my body into an awkward angle, otherwise I would be hitting my neighbor\u2019s butt with my butt,\u201d said Ms. Velsey, 33, a freelance writer whose work appears in The New York Times and elsewhere. \u201cIt was really stressful.\u201d The amenities weren\u2019t that impressive, either. \u201cYou\u2019re paying $32 and they don\u2019t even have a shower \u2014 just dry shampoo and wet wipes?\u201d\n\nShe has since started swimming laps at a Parks Department pool.\n\nTo go by the rise of ClassPass and the army of lissome \u201cfitfluencers\u201d on Instagram, one might assume this is an era of peak boutique fitness. \u201cAthleisure\u201d now enjoys Merriam-Webster status, and celebrity gawkers know where their favorite Jenner sister trains. Smaller gyms are the fastest-growing segment of the exercise business, with membership growth of 6.3 percent (double the industry average) from 2015 to 2016, according to the International Health, Racquet & Sportsclub Association.", "title": "Young Fitness Fogies Ditch $40 Classes for Hoops, Laps and Jogs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "The most commonly used A.D.H.D. drugs among women were Adderall, Vyvanse and Ritalin, the study found.\n\nThe report broke down prescription rates by region, finding the largest increases in Southern and Western states. Overall rates were sharply higher in the United States, compared with previous estimates in the United Kingdom or Canada.\n\nThis difference \u201cmight reflect higher A.D.H.D. medication prescribing in the United States or differences in the types of A.D.H.D. medications\u201d used in these countries, the authors concluded.\n\nThe findings come as rising prescription rates for psychiatric drugs are receiving increasing scrutiny.\n\nFor decades, experts have questioned the increase in A.D.H.D. diagnoses among children and adolescents. The rates far outstrip estimated prevalence of the disorder, and the first-line treatment is almost always a prescription for stimulant medication.\n\nThe new study suggests that the increase has happened among adults, too.\n\nRecent changes in diagnostic guidelines have extended the criteria to adults who have experienced inattentiveness and restlessness since childhood. Psychiatrists generally accept longstanding A.D.H.D. as a valid, treatable disorder in adults.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut many also acknowledge that these drugs have wide appeal as performance-enhancers: among students as study aids, and among adults seeking an edge in their work.\n\nYet prevalence studies, using strict criteria, estimate that around 3 percent of adult women overall have A.D.H.D., well under the 5 percent and higher rates recorded in some age groups by the C.D.C.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe new study is also relevant to more recently proposed diagnosis: adult-onset A.D.H.D., in which symptoms emerge out of blue, well after adolescence. Experts fiercely debate whether this diagnosis is valid, and a recent study concluded that the disorder did not exist.\n\n\u201cIf adult symptoms are being reported by patients, it shouldn\u2019t necessarily be immediately classified as A.D.H.D.,\u201d said Margaret Sibley, an associate professor of psychiatry and behavioral health at Florida International University, the lead author of that study.\n\n\u201cA more careful evaluation often finds that there\u2019s something else causing the problems, like depression, or drug use \u2014 which is what we found.\u201d\n\nThe C.D.C. report looked only at numbers of prescriptions and not at the types of diagnoses to justify them.\n\nThe study also raises concerns specific to women, according to Coleen Boyle, director of the C.D.C.\u2019s National Center on Birth Defects and Developmental Disabilities.\n\n\u201cHalf of all pregnancies in the United States are unplanned, and women may be taking prescription medicine early in pregnancy before they know they are pregnant,\u201d Dr. Boyle said in a prepared statement.\n\n\u201cEarly pregnancy is a critical time for the developing baby. We need to better understand the safest ways to treat A.D.H.D. before and during pregnancy.\u201d", "title": "Young Women Are Using A.D.H.D. Drugs in Greater Numbers, C.D.C. Reports", "authors": ["Benedict Carey"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Despite Ms. Brehl\u2019s friendship with Mr. Mallory, she was shocked. \u201cI had no idea that he was writing a book,\u201d she said. Had Mr. Mallory not prudently scheduled a weeklong trip to Palm Springs, which began the day his agent sent the manuscript to publishers, Ms. Brehl imagines she may have walked the book into his office to ask for his thoughts on it.\n\nMr. Mallory had always planned to submit the manuscript under a pseudonym, which is a mash-up of his cousin\u2019s name, Alice Jane, plus the name of another family member\u2019s French bulldog.\n\n\u201cI felt it would be disconcerting for my authors to wander into a bookshop and see their editor\u2019s name writ large across a hardback,\u201d he said.\n\nWhile editors moonlighting as authors isn\u2019t the norm, Mr. Mallory\u2019s crossover is not entirely unique. The novelist David Ebershoff had been working as an editor at Random House two years when his first book, \u201cThe Danish Girl,\u201d was published in 2000. Former children\u2019s book editor Tui Sutherland has published numerous books under her own name as well as multiple pseudonyms, including Tamara Summers, Heather Williams and Rob Kidd. Other recent author/editors of note include former Simon & Schuster editor Greer Hendricks (\u201cThe Wife Between Us,\u201d coauthored with Sarah Pekkanen), Scribner editor in chief Colin Harrison (\u201cYou Belong to Me\u201d), former Riverhead assistant editor Danya Kukafka (\u201cGirl in Snow\u201d), Random House senior editor Anna Pitoniak (\u201cThe Futures\u201d) and Henry Holt senior editor Caroline Zancan (\u201cLocal Girls\u201d).\n\nBut none generated buzz on par with \u201cThe Woman in the Window\u201d which, following its sale, collected blurbs from such authors as Gillian Flynn, who called it \u201ca noir for the new millennium,\u201d and Stephen King, who deemed it \u201cone of those rare books that really is unputdownable.\u201d\n\nWhat impressed Mr. King most was the seamless integration of classic films such as \u201cVertigo,\u201d \u201cRear Window\u201d and \u201cGaslight.\u201d\n\nMr. Mallory, who is 38, has had a near lifelong fascination with psychological thrillers that began 30 years ago, when his parents dropped him off at an art house cinema in North Carolina for the afternoon. The film playing was Dutch director and producer George Sluizer\u2019s \u201cThe Vanishing,\u201d which Stanley Kubrick once called \u201cthe most horrifying film I\u2019ve ever seen.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Mallory said he was terrified, but \u201cI was unable to prize my eyes from the screen.\u201d The dueling emotions \u201cinterested and sort of disturbed me even at that age.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs a teenager, he discovered Alfred Hitchcock\u2019s \u201cPsycho,\u201d which proved a gateway drug to the rest of Hitchcock\u2019s oeuvre, along with film noir and suspense novels like Patricia Highsmith\u2019s Tom Ripley series.\n\nHe majored in literature at Duke University, and went on to pursue a master\u2019s and doctorate at Oxford. There, he wrote about transgressive sexuality in the works of Highsmith, Graham Greene and Henry James, whose novel \u201cThe Turn of the Screw,\u201d with its own unreliable narrator, Mr. Mallory considers the original psychological thriller.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFor several years, Mr. Mallory lived in London and worked at the commercial publishing imprint Sphere, of Little, Brown UK, before returning to New York to spearhead a crime and thriller digital first initiative at William Morrow.\n\nWhile he had long considered writing fiction, it was only when he clocked the popularity of \u201cGone Girl\u201d and \u201cGirl on the Train,\u201d two commercially successful descendants of the classic genre he\u2019d long loved, that he realized the market was ripe for the kind of story he might want to tell. But while his publisher\u2019s eye for a successful trend may have primed him for the idea, the novel\u2019s premise was deeply personal.\n\nThe idea came to Mr. Mallory one night as he sat on his couch watching an old favorite, Hitchcock\u2019s \u201cRear Window.\u201d Out of the corner of his eye, he noticed a lamp switch on in the apartment across the street.\n\n\u201cIt occurred to me, \u2018Oh, how funny, in 1954 Jimmy Stewart is spying on his neighbor, and in 2015, I\u2019m doing the same thing,\u2019 \u201d he said. \u201cVoyeurism dies hard.\u201d\n\nAt the time, after struggling for a decade and a half with severe depression, Mr. Mallory had recently been diagnosed with bipolar II disorder, and was in his third week of almost total isolation as he transitioned from one medication to another.\n\n\u201cI thought, too, as I was watching the woman across the street, about how, despite living in one of the most populous cities in the world, I felt quite lonely,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOver the next two days, Mr. Mallory wrote a 7,500-word outline for a novel about a former child therapist who, trapped in her Harlem townhouse by her crippling agoraphobia, becomes obsessed with the family that moves into the building opposite her own. Once finished, Mr. Mallory sent the outline to his friend Jennifer Joel, a partner and literary agent at ICM, who encouraged him to pursue the project.\n\nFor the next 12 months, Mr. Mallory wrote on nights and weekends, telling nobody but his sister and then-boyfriend, to whom the book is dedicated. His aim throughout the process, he said, was to write a book that felt like a film, and while the plotting came to him in an easy burst, the writing proved more of a challenge.\n\n\u201cGetting a character from a sofa to a window is surprisingly difficult,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Mallory, who describes himself as \u201cconstitutionally cautious,\u201d continued at William Morrow for another 15 months after the sale of his book, but his international publishers hoped to send him on a nine month world tour to promote \u201cThe Woman in the Window,\u201d and the draft of his second novel was due to Ms. Brehl.\n\nFive days before his book hit shelves, he had his final day at his desk job.\n\nWhile Mr. Mallory now describes himself as \u201csignificantly better off financially,\u201d he hasn\u2019t yet found the time to make use of his recent windfall. When he finishes his book tour, he does plan to purchase a larger apartment with a dedicated writing room. And a French bulldog.", "title": "Your Book Editor Just Snagged Your Spot on the Best-Seller List", "authors": ["Keziah Weir"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIs obesity contagious?\n\nResearchers studied 1,519 military families who were assigned to 38 military bases across the country and living in counties with higher or lower rates of obesity.\n\nThe scientists collected data on height and weight of children and parents using questionnaires and in-person examinations. The study, in JAMA Pediatrics, used data on county obesity prevalence from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nCounty obesity rates ranged from 21 to 38 percent, and each 1 percentage point increase in obesity was associated with a 5 percent higher rate of obesity in military parents and a 4 percent higher rate in their 12- or 13-year-old child.\n\nThe researchers controlled for many variables, including age, sex, race, education level, income and \u201cbuilt environment,\u201d that is, whether a county had easily accessible exercise opportunities, good supermarkets and so on.\n\n\u201cSubconsciously, you are affected by what people around you are doing,\u201d said the lead author, Ashlesha Datar, an economist at the University of Southern California. \u201cWhen I travel to the Bay Area, for example, everyone is riding bicycles. You get there, and it seems like you have to buy a bicycle. If you move to a community where a sedentary lifestyle is the norm, you join that. There is this social influence.\u201d", "title": "Your Neighbors, Your Waistline", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "International Flights\n\nInternational flights arrive at Seoul\u2019s Incheon International Airport. From the United States, Korean Air has flights to Incheon from more than a half dozen cities, including New York, Washington D.C., San Francisco and Dallas. Asiana Airlines also has flights to Incheon from five United States cities including New York, Chicago and Seattle.\n\nHotels and Lodging\n\nVisitors have numerous hotel options in and around Pyeongchang. The local Olympic organizing committee has contracted special rates at 35 hotels in the area, for a total of more than 5,300 rooms. According to the committee\u2019s accommodation newsletter, nightly rates average $265 for hotels in Pyeongchang and $90 in satellite cities.\n\nBeyond those hotels, the region has plenty of other resorts. In Pyeongchang, for example, the 214-room Holiday Inn Resort Alpensia Pyeongchang has nightly rates starting at $450 over the Olympic period, while the 419-room Holiday Inn Hotel & Suites Alpensia Pyeongchang has rates starting at $408. Rooms at either property can be reserved by calling 1-888- 465-4329, or visiting the websites for each hotel.\n\nAnother option in Pyeongchang is the 238-room InterContinental Alpensia Pyeongchang Resort; nightly rates during the Olympics start at $450. Reserve by calling 1-888-424-6835 , or by visiting the hotel website.\n\nOlympic Event Tickets\n\nResidents of the host country typically get first crack at Olympic tickets, but at this point they are available to everyone.", "title": "Your Pyeongchang 2018 Travel Guide", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump on Thursday demanded to know at a White House meeting why he should accept immigrants from \u201cshithole countries\u201d instead of those from countries like Norway.", "title": "Opinion | Your Tired, Your Poor, Your Norwegians Only", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "New TV shows, museum openings, film releases and concerts \u2014 it\u2019s a lot to keep track of. Let us help. For the week of Jan. 21, seven events in New York and elsewhere not to be missed:\n\nFilm: Dakota Fanning\u2019s Double Feature\n\nJan. 26; pleasestandbyfilm.com. Jan. 22; tntdrama.com.\n\nDakota Fanning is having a moment, starring in two very different productions this week. In \u201cPlease Stand By,\u201d she plays Wendy, an autistic uber-Trekkie with a thing for Spock, who runs away from her San Francisco independent-living facility on a bold mission of her own: to submit her 500-page script to Paramount Pictures in a contest for the franchise\u2019s next movie.\n\nBut in this sweetly fraught scenario \u2014 directed by Ben Lewin (\u201cThe Sessions\u201d) and opening Friday, Jan. 26 \u2014 deep space is Hollywood, and her transport modes include a long-haul bus and a retirement-village van. And her caregiver, Scottie (Toni Collette), may be the only one who can, um, beam her back to safety.\n\nMs. Fanning can also be seen in \u201cThe Alienist,\u201d TNT\u2019s adaptation, starting Monday, Jan. 22, of the 1994 Caleb Carr best-selling thriller about a crew of serial-killer hunters in Gilded Age New York. Here she plays Sara Howard, a secretary and sleuth trying to thrive in a man\u2019s world without losing her femininity and sexuality, she told The New York Times. KATHRYN SHATTUCK", "title": "Your Week in Culture: Dakota Fanning, Khalid, City Ballet After Peter Martins", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "New TV shows, museum openings, film releases and concerts \u2014 it\u2019s a lot to keep track of. Let us help you. For the week of Jan. 7, seven events in New York and elsewhere not to be missed:\n\nDance: Kosoko\u2019s \u2018S\u00e9ancers\u2019; Moriah Evans\u2019s \u2018Figuring\u2019\n\nJan. 9-16; americanrealness.com.\n\nAmerican Realness, a forward-thinking festival of dance and genre-bending performance, returns to New York for a ninth year. What began as a scrappy response to the annual conference of the Association of Performing Arts Professionals has grown into a January tradition, considerable in scope, influence and ambition.\n\nThis year\u2019s edition includes 17 works at locations in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens, including the festival\u2019s Lower East Side headquarters and original home, Abrons Arts Center. Highlights include three world premieres \u2014 Moriah Evans\u2019s \u201cFiguring\u201d; Marissa Perel\u2019s \u201c(Do Not) Despair Solo\u201d; and Keyon Gaskin\u2019s \u201c[A Swatch of Lavender]: a Self Portrait.\u201d\n\nAnd if you missed them the first time, catch Jaamil Olawale Kosoko\u2019s stirring \u201cS\u00e9ancers\u201d; Mariana Valencia\u2019s wittily introspective \u201cAlbum\u201d; and Nora Chipaumire\u2019s Patti Smith-inspired \u201c#Punk.\u201d SIOBHAN BURKE", "title": "Your Week in Culture: Jaamil Olawale Kosoko, the Killers, a \u2018Lavender Scare\u2019 Opera", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "The Venezuelan actor Edgar Ram\u00edrez portrays a benevolent Versace; Pen\u00e9lope Cruz sweeps in as his sister and muse, Donatella, showing scant mercy to his grieving partner, played by Ricky Martin. And Darren Criss (\u201cGlee\u201d) coolly seethes \u2014 until he viciously erupts \u2014 as Cunanan. The nine episodes, volleying between the dazzling, sexed-up opulence of Versace\u2019s existence and the grimy despair of Cunanan\u2019s, are adapted from Maureen Orth\u2019s 1999 book, \u201cVulgar Favors,\u201d which examines the role that homophobia may have played in the hunt for the serial killer. KATHRYN SHATTUCK\n\nPhoto\n\nTheater: Retrying Malcolm X\u2019s Murder\n\nJan. 14-Feb. 18; theactingcompany.org.\n\nIn the playwright-poet Marcus Gardley\u2019s courtroom drama \u201cX: Or, Betty Shabazz v. the Nation,\u201d the audience serves as jury, but not the kind that\u2019s meant to keep mum. As Mr. Gardley explains at the top of his script, spectators \u201care encouraged to call out to the actors, laugh, sing and even snap their fingers when they agree with something being said.\u201d So that\u2019s one rule to keep in mind in this fantasy trial over the 1965 assassination of the civil rights leader Malcolm X, prosecuted by his widow, Betty Shabazz.\n\nHere\u2019s another. The personas of the characters in \u201cX\u201d \u2014 who include Nation of Islam figures like Louis Farrakhan, one of the accused \u2014 \u201care somewhat fictitious,\u201d Mr. Gardley writes.\n\nLauded in its run last spring Off Broadway, the Acting Company production of \u201cX\u201d returns Jan. 14 to Feb. 18 at the Theater at St. Clement\u2019s. Blending irreverent comedy, soft-focus romance and historical re-examination, Mr. Gardley also draws on Shakespeare\u2019s \u201cJulius Caesar,\u201d whose bloody conspirators have nothing on the plotters here \u2014 and there\u2019s an array of suspects to choose from. LAURA COLLINS-HUGHES\n\nPhoto\n\nClassical: Royal Concertgebouw at Carnegie\n\nJan. 17 and 18; carnegiehall.org.\n\nKicking off a U.S. tour in January, the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra arrives at Carnegie Hall for a two-night stint under the direction of its new chief conductor, the reliably compelling Daniele Gatti. The repertoire is sturdily old-fashioned but should gleam with polished force when performed by the Amsterdam-based orchestra, one of the best in the world.\n\nOn Jan. 17, Mr. Gatti leads the orchestra in Bruckner\u2019s towering, unfinished Symphony No. 9 and excerpts from Wagner\u2019s \u201cParsifal,\u201d and on Jan. 18 he tackles Mahler\u2019s Symphony No. 1. The second concert will feature the riveting violinist Janine Jensen \u2014 in the midst of the \u201cPerspectives\u201d series she has curated at Carnegie \u2014 in Max Bruch\u2019s Violin Concerto No. 1. WILLIAM ROBIN\n\nPhoto\n\nDance: The Coil Festival in the East Village\n\nThrough Feb. 4; ps122.org.\n\nPerformance Space 122 has finally returned to its East Village home, a move that brings with it a new executive director, Jenny Schlenzka, and the final iteration of the Coil Festival. As it continues, the festival hosts \u201cDesert Body Creep,\u201d a New York premiere by the Australian dancer and choreographer Angela Goh, whose work seems to ask, what is there to do when everything\u2019s been done?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn her solo, Ms. Goh explores the idea of horror and decay, fighting \u201crot with rot,\u201d as she writes on her website, and \u201cinsisting on the persistence of imagination even when there is nothing left to imagine.\u201d\n\nAnd later this month, Coil adds two New York choreographers to the lineup. The uncompromising Dean Moss takes inspiration from Rainer Werner Fassbinder\u2019s film \u201cThe Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant\u201d in his new work, \u201cPetra,\u201d while David Thomson explores identity, gender and the black body in the piece \u201che his own mythical beast.\u201d Yes, the days of \u201cNutcracker\u201d are over. GIA KOURLAS\n\n\n\nFilm: Obama\u2019s Foreign Policy, Undone\n\nJan. 19.\n\nEarly in \u201cThe Final Year\u201d \u2014 Greg Barker\u2019s chronicle of the last months of the Obama presidency, opening Friday, Jan. 19 \u2014 Samantha Power, then the United States ambassador to the United Nations, imagines a clock counting down the days until important national security issues are passed on to a new administration.\n\nThe Iran nuclear deal, the Paris climate accord, peace in Syria, the normalization of relations with Cuba: all are at stake. In fact, at one point 17 Republican candidates are promising to undo much of the foreign policy devised by Ms. Power, former Secretary of State John Kerry and then national security adviser Susan Rice and her deputy, Ben Rhodes. But with Hillary Clinton the heir apparent, the team seems blithely unaware that Republican promises might well be fulfilled.\n\nThen came the election of Donald J. Trump and a record-speed dismantling of American diplomacy, rendering the perspective of Mr. Barker\u2019s documentary, captivating if deflated in the final minutes by this turn of events, hauntingly nostalgic. Vanquished, Ms. Power and her colleagues expel any thoughts they might have had about going gently into the night. \u201cWe\u2019re in this for the long haul,\u201d she says. KATHRYN SHATTUCK\n\nPhoto\n\nArt: Neil Goldberg\u2019s Wit and Insight\n\nJan. 14, all day; free; cristintierney.com. Jan. 15, 7:30 p.m.; $15 in advance or $18 at the door; dixonplace.org.\n\nThe observations the artist Neil Goldberg jots down on lined three-by-five index cards range from winkingly self-conscious to disarmingly insightful; most often they are a strange and hilarious combination of the two. (My favorite: \u201cWhat Primo Levi said about the psychology of prisoners saving their cigarettes in Auschwitz, but about me & the olives in a Martini.\u201d)\n\nWatching Mr. Goldberg flip through his deck and read these thoughts aloud is like eavesdropping on a high-concept game of mental solitaire lightly inflected with Henny Youngman. You can catch his all-day performance on Jan. 14 at the Cristin Tierney Gallery in Manhattan. He will also be on stage Jan. 15 at Dixon Place as part of the annual Association of Performing Arts Professionals Conference. WILL HEINRICH", "title": "Your Week in Culture: Lana Del Rey, \u2018Gianni Versace,\u2019 the Murder of Malcolm X Onstage", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "The two-week lineup begins on Friday, Feb. 2, with \u201cSweet Sweetback\u2019s Baadasssss Song,\u201d Melvin Van Peebles\u2019s 1971 action thriller \u2014 set to a soundtrack by Earth, Wind & Fire and dedicated \u201cto all the brothers and sisters who had enough of the Man\u201d \u2014 about a male prostitute dodging the L.A.P.D. while making a run for Mexico. Huey P. Newton of the Black Panthers declared it \u201cthe first truly revolutionary black film,\u201d while The New York Times christened its creator \u201cthe first black man in show business to beat the white man at his own game.\u201d\n\nOther gems: the blaxploitation films \u201cCleopatra Jones,\u201d \u201cFoxy Brown\u201d and \u201cAbar: The First Black Superman\u201d; Sidney Poitier\u2019s revisionist Western, \u201cBuck and the Preacher\u201d; and Ivan Dixon\u2019s anti-white-supremacy cult classic, \u201cThe Spook Who Sat by the Door\u201d \u2014 considered such a potent call to arms that the F.B.I. was rumored to have suppressed it for decades. KATHRYN SHATTUCK\n\nClassical Music: Debussy, 100 Years Later\n\nJan. 30; carnegiehall.org.\n\nThe music of Claude Debussy has been a lifelong fascination of the ever-inquisitive British pianist Stephen Hough: the first LP he ever owned was \u201cThe Girl with the Flaxen Hair.\u201d But Mr. Hough\u2019s dazzlingly lucid new album of Debussy\u2019s solo piano works, released this month on Hyperion, is his first record dedicated exclusively to the composer.\n\nThis year marks the 100th anniversary of the radically prismatic composer\u2019s death, which is being celebrated with recordings, performances and new works commissioned in his memory. On Jan. 30, Mr. Hough arrives at Carnegie Hall for a solo recital that places Debussy\u2019s music \u2014 including both books of the kaleidoscopically ruminative \u201cImages\u201d as well as the famously enchanting \u201cClaire de lune\u201d \u2014 alongside two contrasting landmarks of the 19th century, Schumann\u2019s Fantasy in C Major and Beethoven\u2019s \u201cAppassionata\u201d Sonata. WILLIAM ROBIN\n\nPhoto\n\nTheater: A Comedy Well Timed for #MeToo\n\nJan. 28 to Feb. 25; wptheater.org.\n\n\u201cLardons or anchovies?\u201d the bartender asks the woman who\u2019s just walked in, and already he\u2019s poured her a soothing glass of the red wine she always drinks. This bar is a comfortable place with foodie pretensions, and in Kate Benson\u2019s savory, skewering comedy \u201c[Porto],\u201d it\u2019s where the brainy, funny, lonely heroine goes for a little company \u2014 once she\u2019s talked herself, surely not for the first time, into believing that it\u2019s O.K. for a woman to get a drink by herself.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen \u201c[Porto]\u201d had its world premiere a year ago at the Bushwick Starr in Brooklyn, in a run coinciding with the women\u2019s marches around the world, its thoughtful feminism matched the fervor of that moment. A lyrical play about female desire, pleasure and competing fears \u2014 being alone vs. pairing up with a man and losing oneself \u2014 it seems equally well timed for the #MeToo movement.\n\nIts Off Broadway premiere starts previews on Sunday, Jan. 28, at WP Theater. Watch for a hallucinatory cameo by Simone de Beauvoir highbrow-bickering with Gloria Steinem (nope, not the real one), and a Chorus of Dumb Bunnies, spewing lowbrow imperatives about snaring a man. LAURA COLLINS-HUGHES\n\nPop: Jen Cloher, Backed by Courtney Barnett\n\nJan. 30; roughtrade.com.\n\n\u201cIndie rock is full of privileged white kids/I know because I\u2019m one of them,\u201d Jen Cloher sings on \u201cShoegazers,\u201d a tart, bluesy highlight from the self-titled LP that she released in August. That crackling sense of humor drives much of Ms. Cloher\u2019s songwriting; she likes to lob accusations that, often as not, loop back into self-criticism. The album, her fourth, adds up to a persuasive case that, privileged as she and/or her audience might be, this Australian artist is one of indie rock\u2019s sharpest observers.\n\nMany American fans know Ms. Cloher as the romantic partner of the more famous Courtney Barnett, also an Australian indie-rocker. Ms. Cloher sings about that, too \u2014 some of her most poignant songs deal with the vexed intersections of fame and love. (See \u201cForgot Myself,\u201d the album\u2019s excellently sulky opener, or the softer-hued \u201cSensory Memory.\u201d) Expect the payoff to be high, musically and emotionally, when Ms. Cloher headlines Rough Trade NYC on Jan. 30, with Ms. Barnett playing guitar in her backing band. SIMON VOZICK-LEVINSON\n\nPhoto\n\nDance: Mina Nishimura in Manhattan\n\nFeb. 1-3; danspaceproject.org.\n\nSometimes choreographers slave over dances for months. Others create at the speed of light. This season, Mina Nishimura, the luminous Japanese-born dancer and choreographer, has no choice but to do just that for her latest premiere, \u201cBladder Inn (and X, Y, Z, W).\u201d\n\nThe time crunch comes down to scheduling: In recent weeks, Ms. Nishimura has been busy as a performer, dancing in back-to-back works by Kota Yamazaki, her husband, and Dean Moss. \u201cI\u2019m thinking of what I can do within the condition,\u201d she said in a recent interview. \u201cIt\u2019s good practice to see what you can do in a very limited amount of time.\u201d\n\nHer group work \u201cBladder Inn\u201d refers to Ms. Nishimura\u2019s choreographic pursuit of finding language that relates to internal landscapes. Her plan? To use the architecture of the theater \u2014 which is housed in St. Mark\u2019s Church \u2014 to create a dreamlike scene awash with wandering bodies. GIA KOURLAS\n\nTV: 3 Beloved Actresses in 1 Show\n\nJan. 29; acorn.tv.\n\nThe casting of three beloved actresses around the age of 60 \u2014 Miranda Richardson, Zo\u00eb Wanamaker and Phyllis Logan \u2014 as the leads in a major British network television drama was so remarkable that it made the nightly news in that country last month.\n\n\u201cGirlfriends,\u201d the latest from the writer Kay Mellor, debuting Monday, Jan. 29, on the streaming platform Acorn TV, stars the triumvirate as longtime friends dealing with the challenges, both physical and emotional, of late-middle-age. For Ms. Logan\u2019s Linda, it\u2019s the mysterious death of her husband on their anniversary cruise. For Ms. Wanamaker\u2019s Gail, it\u2019s a pending divorce from the spouse she still loves and the care of assorted family members. And for Ms. Richardson\u2019s Sue, it\u2019s the end of the affair with her son\u2019s father, a married man who claims \u2014 twist that knife \u2014 that she\u2019s no longer relevant. In a news release, Ms. Mellor, 66, called the show her passion project, adding that she longed to give a voice to \u201cwomen of a certain age who feel like they are invisible and unheard.\u201d KATHRYN SHATTUCK", "title": "Your Week in Culture: Outsider Art, Claude Debussy, the Godfathers of \u2018Black Panther\u2019", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "When Kathryn Schipper discovered in December that her iPhone had slowed down because it needed a new battery, she unknowingly walked into the middle of a growing Apple controversy \u2014 and is now mired in the continuing fallout.\n\nLate last year, Apple said a software feature was slowing down iPhones that had aged batteries, immediately drawing accusations that the company was trying to force people to upgrade to its newest iPhones. In response, Apple said customers could get their iPhone batteries replaced at its stores for a discounted price of $29, down from $79.\n\nYet when Ms. Schipper, who lives in Seattle, took her iPhone 6 Plus, purchased in 2014, to an Apple store in early January, she was told that the store was out of replacement batteries for at least two weeks. An Apple representative later left her a voice mail message with a new estimated wait time: up to four months.\n\n\u201cI feel like I\u2019m waiting outside of a club and the bouncer won\u2019t let me in because I\u2019m not fashionably enough dressed,\u201d Ms. Schipper said in a phone interview. \u201cI\u2019m at the back of the line because I don\u2019t have a fancy phone.\u201d", "title": "Your iPhone Slowed Down. Here\u2019s What to Do When the Solution Is Just as Slow.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis is a situation that makes most doctors very uncomfortable,\u201d said Dr. Sei Lee, a geriatrician at the University of California, San Francisco. \u201cSome feel these drugs have been successful used in younger patients, so why not use them?\u201d\n\nSo why not? \u201cWe don\u2019t have good specific data for people without known heart disease over age 75,\u201d Dr. Lee said. \u201cAre statins helpful or harmful for them? The honest answer is, we don\u2019t know.\u201d\n\nTo be clear: Statins make sense for adults of any age who already have heart disease, who have suffered a heart attack or stroke, or who have had arteries unblocked with a procedure like stenting. This is called secondary prevention.\n\nIn 2013, the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association issued a series of statin recommendations for primary prevention, relevant to adults up to age 75 who have high cholesterol or diabetes, or who for other reasons face an estimated 7.5 percent risk or greater of developing heart disease within 10 years.\n\nLast year, the United States Preventive Services Task Force similarly recommended statins for primary prevention in people aged 40 to 75 who had risk factors like high cholesterol, diabetes, high blood pressure or smoking, with a 10-year disease risk of 10 percent or greater.\n\nBut for people over age 75, both panels agreed, there was not sufficient evidence to reach a conclusion. As with many clinical trials, the major statin studies mostly haven\u2019t included patients at advanced ages.\n\n\u201cThe oldest patients enrolled have been up to age 82,\u201d said Dr. Michael Rich, a geriatric cardiologist at Washington University School of Medicine, referring to the PROSPER study published in 2002.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe authors of that study followed 5,800 patients for three years and found that pravastatin provided secondary, but not primary, prevention against cardiovascular events.\n\nBut Dr. Paul Ridker, a self-described \u201cstatin advocate\u201d who directs the Center for Cardiovascular Disease Prevention at Brigham and Women\u2019s Hospital in Boston, gets irked at the argument that we don\u2019t know enough to give statins to older patients without heart disease.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t believe there\u2019s any doubt that statin therapy is effective for primary prevention in older adults,\u201d Dr. Ridker said. He cites a recent reanalysis of data from two major studies showing that patients over age 70 taking statins experienced the same reductions in cardiovascular events and mortality as younger ones.\n\nDr. Orkaby and her Harvard colleagues hoped to help resolve such questions with their recent study, published in the Journal of the American Geriatrics Society, comparing physicians over age 70 who took statins for primary prevention with those who didn\u2019t.\n\nThe team matched each group for 30 variables and found that over an average of seven years, statin-takers had an 18 percent lower death rate, though not a statistically significant reduction in cardiovascular events.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the same issue, though, an editorial co-authored by Dr. Rich called statin use for primary prevention in older patients \u201can unresolved conundrum.\u201d\n\nThe physician study was observational, so can\u2019t establish causes, he pointed out. And it followed a group that was healthier than average, and all male. Moreover, he said, the findings suggest the drugs had more benefit for those under age 77.\n\nWhat\u2019s not debatable is that while statins do effectively lower cholesterol in older people, their advantages and disadvantages add up differently than at younger ages.\n\nA fairly common side effect, for instance, is myalgia, muscle aches sometimes combined with fatigue. Dr. Orkaby estimates that up to 30 percent of statin takers experience this symptom.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSandy Koo, 72, a retired teacher in Los Altos, Calif., began taking Lipitor in her 50s. It lowered her cholesterol, but she found that \u201cI\u2019d walk a block and a half, and I was so achy I had to sit down.\u201d She cycled through other statins for years, looking for one that didn\u2019t make her legs hurt.\n\nMyalgia reverses when people stop taking statins (which also have more serious, but very rare, side effects). Still, many older people already struggle to remain mobile and perform daily tasks.\n\nAt advanced ages, \u201cit\u2019s easier to lose your functional ability and harder to get it back,\u201d said Dr. Lee. (A few small studies report a reversible cognitive impact from statins, too, but he and other researchers didn\u2019t give much credence to the finding.)\n\nFurther, older people often take multiple drugs. Statins interact with scores of them, including proton pump inhibitors (like Nexium), blood pressure and heart medications (like Plavix), and many antibiotics.\n\nComplicating the debate, the 2013 guidelines called for \u201chigh-intensity\u201d statin therapy \u2014 high doses of atorvastatin (Lipitor) or rosuvastatin (Crestor) \u2014 for primary prevention up to age 75, for those who can tolerate it.\n\n\u201cMany patients were doing fine for years on a low-intensity statin, and it was doing the job, reducing their cholesterol,\u201d Dr. Orkaby said. When switched to high-intensity regimens, \u201cthey developed the symptoms you might expect, so they stopped taking them at all.\u201d\n\nAll of which argues for a thoughtful conversation for patients in their late 70s and beyond whose physicians suggest starting \u2014 or stopping \u2014 a statin.\n\nIt can take two to five years for a statin to pay off preventively, so a healthy 80-year-old expected to live that long might well opt to take one or to continue taking one.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a well known, proven therapy that might prevent a devastating illness,\u201d Dr. Orkaby said. By trying different statins at different dosages, she said, patients usually can find a comfortable regimen.\n\nOn the other hand, she routinely stops statins for nursing home residents \u2014 who are already very ill \u2014 or for elders who are frail, have life-limiting diseases, or grapple with an already daunting number of prescriptions.\n\n\u201cThere are a lot of unknowns,\u201d Dr. Orkaby said. \u201cWe don\u2019t want to do harm by prescribing a medication. And we don\u2019t want to do harm by withholding it.\u201d", "title": "You\u2019re Over 75, and You\u2019re Healthy. Why Are You Taking a Statin?", "authors": ["Paula Span", "The New Old Age"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Those who didn\u2019t sign it \u2014 or couldn\u2019t hold up their end of the bargain \u2014 had their benefits cut, and were enrolled in a basic plan that restricted prescription drug coverage, limited access to mental health and substance-abuse services, and excluded weight management or nutrition education programs. Both children and adults were subject to the agreement, which raised a basic fairness question: Children might be at the mercy of unreliable parents or guardians to follow the rules.\n\nLess than 15 percent of those eligible signed the agreement, and more than 90 percent of children with Medicaid had benefits restricted. A central motivation of the program was to reduce emergency department use, but over all, people were more likely to visit the emergency room. There was no clear improvement in health or healthy behavior. The experiment was scrapped in 2010.\n\nThat individuals bear some responsibility for their health is undeniable. Behavior contributes to nearly half of cancer deaths in the United States, and up to 40 percent of all deaths. But viewing personal responsibility as a central driver of longer lives and lower medical costs is problematic.\n\nAmerican life expectancy has increased markedly in the past century, and few would argue it\u2019s because we now lead healthier lives by dint of willpower. It\u2019s also not clear healthful behavior saves money: People who live longer use more medical care. Smoking cessation, for example, may actually increase long-term health care costs. And ensuring that people bear greater financial risk doesn\u2019t seem to help them make better decisions: A RAND study found that making people pay more for care does reduce how much they use, but that they cut out both highly effective and marginally effective services.\n\nPersonal responsibility is not always demanded equally of people at every income level. Many lawmakers want more \u201cskin in the game\u201d for Medicaid recipients, but not as many clamor for higher deductibles for wealthy Americans \u2014 even though they\u2019re more likely to have enough \u201cskin\u201d to meaningfully play \u201cthe game.\u201d\n\nPersonal responsibility is, of course, not a binary construct. When we say unhealthy behavior \u2014 overeating, smoking, excessive alcohol use \u2014 is not your fault, we may rob people of the initiative to change it. When we say that same behavior is all your fault, we fail to recognize a more complex reality: Health is a product of genes, environment, work, education, family, medical care and many other factors.\n\nAlthough it seems we should encourage personal responsibility, punishing the opposite may be heavy-handed and even counterproductive. Breaking down every factor that leads patients to develop cancer or heart disease or Alzheimer\u2019s \u2014 and penalizing or rewarding them based on the share they could in theory control \u2014 seems a herculean and morally suspect task.", "title": "You\u2019re Sick. Whose Fault Is That?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "The brightly colored labels began appearing on bottles and cans of beer, wine and liquor in a government-owned store in Yukon Territory a month before Christmas.\n\nThe brainchild of a research project financed by the Canadian government on how to prevent excessive drinking, the labels warned of the health risks of alcohol consumption and were meant to be in place for eight months as an experiment.\n\nBut within a month, the experiment was halted.\n\nThe government stopped affixing the labels after several alcohol industry lobbying groups challenged both the research study and the legality of the government\u2019s participation.\n\nJohn Streicker, the member of the Yukon government\u2019s cabinet responsible for the territory\u2019s liquor stores, said he believed that the government faced litigation if it continued to use the researchers\u2019 labels.", "title": "Yukon Government Gives In to Liquor Industry on Warning Label Experiment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "MILAN \u2014 If some designers amass vintage clothes to form a personal collection, Alessandro Sartori does so for an entirely different reason: to perform dissections.\n\n\u201cShhhh!,\u201d he said backstage, hours before his Ermenegildo Zegna show held in an underground hall of the Neo-Brutalist Rontgen building at Milan\u2019s prestigious Bocconi University. \u201cI buy vintage clothes and take them apart.\u201d\n\nHis purpose in anatomizing old duds is to find in them methods of stitching and construction that have largely passed out of existence. Here and at factories and workshops throughout Italy, centuries-old craft traditions have dwindled and with them the know-how to produce garments worthy of being labeled Made in Italy.\n\nBefore coming to Milan for the round of men\u2019s wear shows here, a reporter paid a visit to the factory campus of the design house Ermanno Scervino just outside central Florence. Over the last decade, Ermanno Daelli and his partner, Toni Scervino \u2014 they are best known, perhaps, for having dressed Kim Kardashian \u2014 have bought up a series of faltering local specialty manufacturers, hired their employees and installed them in a series of linked workshops devoted to the kind of precise small-scale production that remains a hallmark of Italian design.", "title": "Zegna Gives Fashion an Anatomy Lesson", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "You dance with the one that brung ya, as the saying goes, but Bill de Blasio sees no reason to embrace the maxim. Bill and Hillary Clinton gave him a vital kick-start in politics and, fittingly, Mr. de Blasio chose the former president to swear him in as New York\u2019s 109th mayor four years ago. Times change. For his second inaugural, on Monday, the Clintons were well in his rearview mirror.\n\nInstead, the swearing-in duties fell to Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont by way of Brooklyn, who, not coincidentally, was Hillary Clinton\u2019s chief rival for the 2016 Democratic presidential nomination. It was Mr. de Blasio\u2019s way of saying that even a pretense of Clintonian centrism was in disfavor at City Hall and that \u201ca new progressive era,\u201d as he called it in his remarks, ruled the day. Mr. Sanders may not have brung him to the dance, but he now had the mayor\u2019s heart.\n\nWhat that may mean in terms of policy remains to be seen: How, specifically, will Mr. de Blasio build on the successes of his first term, learn from his mistakes, cope with enduring challenges like homelessness and social inequality, and deal with potential fiscal threats created by a hostile Trump administration? Then again, inaugural speeches are designed for clarion calls, not PowerPoint presentations. There is time for details to emerge.\n\nIt was a self-confident mayor who spoke Monday for 13 minutes on the City Hall steps. (It was also a sniffling mayor, plainly as uncomfortable as everyone else in 14-degree weather.) He had reason to feel proud. The old year ended with a murder total under 300, the lowest in many decades. Job totals in the city are at record highs. Construction continues to boom. And not since Edward Koch\u2019s inaugural in 1986 had a Democratic mayor retaken the oath in one of the bluest cities in the land.", "title": "Opinion | \u2018A New Progressive Era\u2019 in New York City", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "One was the Vietnam War, and the growing opposition to the university\u2019s tangential relationship with the Institute for Defense Analyses, a weapons research think tank affiliated with the federal government.\n\nThe other was Columbia\u2019s apparent tin-ear response to the sensitivities of black New Yorkers, epitomized by the construction of a gym that would usurp a portion of Morningside Park and be accessible to neighboring Harlem residents mainly through an ignominious back door (intended, actually, for their convenience, because of the park\u2019s sloping terrain).\n\nBookended by a foreword (Paul Berman) and an epilogue (Juan Gonzalez), the collection suffers from the absent perspective of Columbia\u2019s embattled administrators at the time. Unlike the students, many of whom were teenagers at the time, 50 years on, most of those school officials are now dead.\n\nAlso, the collection of essays, unlike oral history interviews, lack the give-and-take crossfire with an interlocutor to challenge specifics of what the authors choose to remember about the protests that led to the seizure of five campus buildings and the arrest of more than 700 students.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. the police who responded to the protest.\n\nThe protesters were demonized (including in editorials published in The New York Times) as fractious, self-righteous radicals who resorted to militant disruption when other means of protest were still available and as absolutists, who often stifled dissent and fell short of reaching a consensus about what they stood for.\n\n\u201cWe thought that militancy could become a strategy,\u201d wrote Mr. Rudd, who was chairman of the Columbia chapter of Students for a Democratic Society in the spring of 1968, \u201cwhen really it\u2019s only a tactic Its detractors say the story stereotypes and dehumanizes Arabs and Muslims \u2014 with some roles not even filled by actors of Middle Eastern descent.\n\nIs it Showtime\u2019s \u201cHomeland\u201d? Yet its trailer alone, released this month, generated a backlash, especially across the Middle East.\n\n", "title": "\u2018Beirut\u2019 Trailer Was Supposed to Thrill. Instead It Offended.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "So, what\u2019s this about a \u2018bomb cyclone\u2019?\n\nWhen discussing the storm, some weather forecasters have referred to a \u201cbomb cyclone.\u201d Calling it a bomb sounds dire, but such storms are not exceedingly rare \u2014 there was one in New England recently.\n\nWhat makes a storm a bomb is how fast the atmospheric pressure falls; falling atmospheric pressure is a characteristic of all storms. By definition, the barometric pressure must drop by at least 24 millibars in 24 hours for a storm to be called a bomb cyclone.\n\nHere is how it works: Deep drops in barometric pressure occur when a region of warm air meets one of cold air. The air starts to move, and the rotation of the earth creates a cyclonic effect. The direction is counterclockwise in the Northern Hemisphere (when viewed from above), leading to winds that come out of the northeast \u2014 a Nor\u2019easter.\n\nThat\u2019s what happened at the end of October, when warm air from the remnants of a tropical cyclone over the Atlantic collided with a cold front coming from the Midwest. Among other impacts then, more than 80,000 electric customers in Maine lost power as high winds toppled trees.\n\nA similar effect was occurring Wednesday, as warm air over the ocean met extremely cold polar air that had descended over the East. Pressure was expected to fall quickly from Florida northward.\n\nWhy is it so cold? What\u2019s the influence of climate change?\n\nThe Times\u2019s Henry Fountain takes a look. Read more here.\n\nThe north, too, had begun buckling down for a major blow.\n\nThe Weather Service issued a winter storm warning for parts of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, with heavy snowfall and wind chills of up to -25 degrees expected.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKathryn Garcia, the commissioner of the Department of Sanitation in New York City, encouraged New Yorkers to avoid driving and use mass transit instead.\n\nThe New York City Department of Education announced on Wednesday evening that all public schools would be closed on Thursday. It was the second time in a year that the city made an early call to close schools ahead of a storm. Last March, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced at noon the day before a predicted snowstorm that schools would be closed; in the end that storm was less severe than expected, but the mayor received little criticism for his caution.\n\nChilly gusts of up to 50 m.p.h. are likely to whip eastern Long Island and southeastern Connecticut starting late Thursday morning, with the potential for downed tree limbs and scattered power failures, the National Weather Service said.\n\nFor Bostonians, Wednesday\u2019s forecast high of 28 degrees was almost a welcome relief after days of temperatures that had hovered in or near the single digits. But it was quite literally cold comfort, with Thursday\u2019s storm expected to drop 10 to 14 inches of snow or more on the city and potentially create blizzard conditions along the New England coast.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe storm will follow a long period of deep cold that has already taxed transit systems, fuel supplies and homeless shelters in the region. Residents were preparing while insisting they had been through worse.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s good to have at least four major meals ahead of you,\u201d said Forrest McFarland, a retiree from Cambridge, Mass., as he made the rounds at Market Basket, a busy grocery store in nearby Somerville. \u201cSince \u201978,\u201d he said, referring to the legendary blizzard that ground the Northeast to a halt, \u201ceverybody stocks up.\u201d\n\nSome like the cold: \u2018Right now, 8 degrees is what we want.\u2019\n\nWashington, too, remained firmly in the grip of a winter that has already proved treacherous. The District of Columbia government activated its cold emergency plan on Dec. 27, and on Wednesday, it extended it further. Around an inch of snow is expected in the morning, with a winter weather advisory in effect until 11 a.m. Thursday.\n\nWhile visiting, Hamlet Diaz, 38, said the temperatures were exactly what he was hoping for as his family drove home from an Ontario vacation to Pembroke Pines, Fla.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe wanted to be cold,\u201d he said of his wife, Rachel, and two daughters. \u201cRight now, 8 degrees is what we want.\u201d\n\nSnow even fell on Tallahassee, Florida\u2019s capital. More than 50 miles of Interstate 10 were closed in the Tallahassee area, as well as parts of Highway 90. Mark Wool, a Weather Service meteorologist, said that flurries seemed to come along every few years there. But the snow accumulation Wednesday \u2014 about a tenth to two-tenths of an inch \u2014 had not been seen since 1989.\n\nWhat\u2019s happening to the birds that flew south for the winter?", "title": "\u2018Bomb Cyclone\u2019: Rare Snow in South as North Braces for Bitter Cold", "authors": ["Richard Fausset", "Patricia Mazzei", "Alan Blinder"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Read the latest on the bitter cold along the East Coast with Friday\u2019s live updates.\n\nIn Boston, one of the highest tides on record flooded a subway station near the New England Aquarium. Pipes cracked from New Jersey to North Carolina. Even Florida\u2019s iguanas found themselves stunned by the cold.\n\nFrom the Spanish moss-canopied sidewalks of Savannah, Ga., to icy villages in coastal Maine, emergency officials reckoned with the rages, whims and remains of a storm that shut down schools for more than a million children, flooded roadways, filled homeless shelters and forced the cancellations of thousands of flights.\n\nYet the storm, notable for a steep drop in atmospheric pressure that prompted some forecasters to describe it as a \u201cbomb cyclone,\u201d was but one act in a prolonged run of misery that had already enveloped millions of people in a wintry torment of Arctic air and snow-blown streets.\n\nMajor Developments:\n\n\u2022 Wind chills are expected to repeatedly plunge below zero in some areas, especially in New England, for the next several days. As the storm left most of the East Coast behind on Thursday, utility companies scrambled to restore electricity to tens of thousands of homes and businesses. Read more on how power companies have warned of possible fuel shortages to come.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Gov. By Thursday afternoon, The Associated Press had also reported one death in South Carolina and another in Philadelphia.", "title": "\u2018Bomb Cyclone\u2019: Snow and Bitter Cold Blast the Northeast", "authors": ["Alan Blinder", "Patricia Mazzei", "Jess Bidgood"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Although Ms. Hall Moran\u2019s athletic career never advanced beyond a spot on a local synchronized skating team, she will take to the blades herself for \u201cBreaking Ice,\u201d accompanied by tango skaters from Ice Theater of New York. The performance at Bryant Park is free of charge, while the one at Riverbank costs only the rink\u2019s admission fee ($5 for adults, $3 for children). Anyone who wants to join the action on the ice needs to bring or rent skates and ideally should be capable of navigating the frozen terrain.\n\n\u201cVocalists like to talk about grounded singing,\u201d Ms. Hall Moran said with a grin. \u201cTrying to activate the space between the bottom of your feet and that cold surface is a bit like levitating.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA backing track, at the mercy of each rink\u2019s dubious acoustics, will structure the piece: The mash-up of Carmen\u2019s \u201cHabanera\u201d with Stevie Wonder\u2019s \u201cSigned, Sealed, Delivered (I\u2019m Yours)\u201d on Ms. Hall Moran\u2019s recently released album, \u201cHere Today,\u201d offers a taste of what the music might sound like. But she has also left ample room for improvisation with the taiko drummer Kaoru Watanabe and the saxophonist Maria Grand, who will be stationed in hockey penalty boxes nearby, as well as through the physical interaction with the swirl of bodies watching and surrounding her.\n\nThis kind of imaginative recontextualization of classical singing has long propelled Ms. Hall Moran. She is a trained mezzo-soprano who never tries to sound like anything else, despite the diverse artistic company she keeps. She has participated in a number of residencies, including one with her husband, the jazz pianist and composer Jason Moran, as part of the 2012 Whitney Biennial; toured with the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company; made her Broadway debut as Bess in \u201cPorgy and Bess\u201d; and partnered with jazz musicians like the guitarist Brandon Ross and Mr. Moran. In her work, as in that of the visual artist Kara Walker, historical genres like spirituals and Motown (and even the racialized figure of Bizet\u2019s Carmen herself) take on new, charged meanings in juxtaposition with contemporary forms.\n\nDuring a practice session two weeks ago with Moira North, the artistic director of Ice Theater of New York, Ms. Hall Moran indeed evoked Debi Thomas. In a flowing cardigan, ribbons of hair tied back at the base of her neck, she appeared longer limbed than her old hero, though.\n\nWhile a compact body holds advantages for most skating hopefuls, Ms. Hall Moran\u2019s height was actually an asset when she was the only black member of the Shadows, one of the three synchronized skating teams at Terry Conners Rink in Stamford, Conn., where she grew up in an affluent family. (Her best friend was the daughter of the black mezzo-soprano star Shirley Verrett.)", "title": "\u2018Breaking Ice\u2019 Makes Music From a Classic Skating Rivalry", "authors": ["Lara Pellegrinelli"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "That said, there is a long queue for visas because of numerical limits for family-based immigration each year. As of Nov. 1, more than 3.9 million people were waiting in line.\n\nAfter a petition is filed and approved, would-be immigrants are essentially handed a ticket number called a \u201cpriority date\u201d and can only apply for a green card when the State Department calls their number.\n\nDepending on the country of origin, a sponsor\u2019s immigration status and the applicant\u2019s relationship to their sponsor, the waiting period can last from months to decades.\n\nIn January 2018, for example, most immigrants sponsored by their United States-citizen siblings could begin to apply for a green card if their priority date was before June 22, 2004, a waiting period of 13.5 years. Those from other \u201coversubscribed\u201d countries like India, Mexico and the Philippines would have needed to have an even earlier priority date.\n\nWhat is the relationship between \u201cchain migration\u201d and DACA?\n\nTo apply for the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, immigrants had to be younger than 31 on June 15, 2012, and must have proof of having arrived in the United States before age 16.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTheoretically, the children of those applicants are more likely to be American citizens, and their spouses also legal residents, citizens or Dreamers, according to the liberal Center for American Progress.\n\nIf Dreamers are given a pathway to citizenship through legislation, they in turn could sponsor their parents for legal status as well. But those who entered the United States illegally are required to leave the country and wait three or 10 years before applying for an immigration visa. That\u2019s \u201ca significant barrier most would be unlikely to contemplate,\u201d according to the nonpartisan Migration Policy Institute.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBecause of these factors, the institute estimates that the Dreamers would sponsor, on average, about one family member over their lifetime.\n\nWhere does chain migration come in?\n\n\u201cChain migration\u201d was originally a neutral, if not dry, phrase used by academics to describe the immigration process. For example, an academic paper from 1964 describes the benefit of \u201cinitial accommodation and employment arranged by means of primary social relationships with previous migrants\u201d while discussing the growth of Italian neighborhoods in American cities.\n\nIn scholarship, the term appears to have emerged in the 1960s before tapering off in recent years, and even being eclipsed by the more recently established \u201cfamily reunification.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Chain Migration\u2019 Has Become a Weaponized Phrase. Here Are the Facts Behind It.", "authors": ["Linda Qiu"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Some who admire the creatures balk at the portmanteau name.\n\n\u201cThe word \u2018coywolf\u2019 is kind of freighted, and frankly most wildlife biologists prefer the term \u2018Eastern coyote,\u2019\u201d said Christopher Nagy, a wildlife biologist and co-founder of Gotham Coyote, a New York City-based research project studying the animals in their new habitats. \u201cBecause these buzzwords have an impact, and the word \u2018wolf\u2019 is one of the most loaded in nature.\u201d\n\nBut the name has caught on as the debate intensifies over whether to try to drive them out or let them be, and it is being bandied about in places like Clarkstown, the Rockland County municipality that includes Dr. Davies Farm.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a reason we say \u2018cry wolf,\u2019 \u201d Patricia McCoy-Coleman, Clarkstown\u2019s animal control officer, said. Yet even she is willing to apply the moniker to the right coyote. Ms. McCoy-Coleman calls one that she sees around town \u201cFrankenstein\u201d \u2014 \u201cFrankie,\u201d for short \u2014 because of its odd proportions. \u201cHe has a head that\u2019s very big for his body, and it looks like someone put different parts together,\u201d she said.", "title": "\u2018Coywolf\u2019 Sightings Grip a Rural New York Community", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "The fury was not limited to those countries directly mentioned, however.\n\nEl Salvador\u2019s government sent a formal letter of protest. Earlier in the week, the United States announced it was rescinding Temporary Protected Status for about 200,000 Salvadorans living in the United States.\n\nIn Brussels, a European Union lawmaker, Gianni Pittella of Italy, told The Associated Press that Mr. Trump \u201chad forgotten to engage his brain before talking.\u201d\n\nVicente Fox, a former president of Mexico who has frequently clashed with Mr. Trump, demanded of him: \u201cWith what authority do you proclaim who\u2019s welcome in America and who\u2019s not.\u201d (He also suggested that Mr. Trump\u2019s vulgar word was better used to describe his own mouth.)\n\nMicha\u00eblle Jean, a former governor general of Canada who is now the secretary general of Francophonie, which comprises 84 states that share French as a language, called the comments \u201cdisturbing.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt is such an insult before humanity,\u201d Ms. Jean, a native of Haiti, who after the earthquake became Unesco\u2019s special envoy to the Caribbean nation, told the Canadian Press. \u201cFor the first representative of the United States of America to speak in such a manner is quite troubling and offensive.\u201d\n\nUnsurprisingly, some of the strongest reactions were in Africa.\n\n\u201cI am shocked by President Trump\u2019s comments on Haiti and Africa,\u201d President Macky Sall of Senegal wrote on Twitter. \u201cI reject them and condemn them vigorously. Africa and black people deserve the respect and consideration of all.\u201d\n\nOn Saturday morning Ghana\u2019s president weighed in, tweeting that Mr. Trump\u2019s language was \u201cextremely unfortunate.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cWe are certainly not a \u2018shithole country,\u2019 \u201d wrote the president, Nana Afuko-Addo. \u201cWe will not accept such insults, even from the leader of a friendly country, no matter how powerful.\u201d\n\nBotswana\u2019s government issued a statement calling the president\u2019s remark \u201chighly irresponsible, reprehensible and racist.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump has a growing history of disparaging and ill-informed remarks about both Africa and Haiti. In June, he was reported to have said that Nigerians in the United States would never \u201cgo back to their huts\u201d in Africa.\n\nIn September, he spoke of a country called Nambia, which does not exist. (The White House later clarified that he had meant to say Namibia.)\n\nMr. Trump said in a tweet on Friday that he had a \u201cwonderful relationship with Haitians,\u201d but last June, The New York Times reported, he grumbled in another immigration meeting that Haitians \u201call have AIDS.\u201d The White House denied that report.\n\nThe celebrated Haitian-American writer Edwidge Danticat said that Mr. Trump\u2019s comments gave her chilling memories of arriving to the United States in 1981, the year before federal authorities included being Haitian as one of the four increased risk factors for contracting the new, and at the time fatal, disease, H.I.V. and AIDS.\n\n\u201cAs a kid, I was beaten up in school for being Haitian,\u201d Ms. Danticat said at a literary seminar in Key West, Fla., on Friday. \u201cIn Miami, there was a boy who killed himself when his girlfriend found out he was Haitian.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere are real consequences,\u201d she said. \u201cPeople lose their jobs. People get harassed. It\u2019s like putting a target on our backs.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Haitian ambassador to the United States, Paul G. Altidor, told NPR on Friday it was \u201cquite regrettable that we\u2019re not discussing about the earthquake and how Haiti is moving forward.\u201d\n\n\u201cUnfortunately, we fear, once again Haiti finds itself in the midst of a very negative narrative in the U.S., and we are hoping this conversation will be an opportunity to address the Haiti conversation in the U.S. once and for all,\u201d he said.\n\nAcross social media on Thursday night and Friday, Africans and Haitians shared pictures of beautiful beaches, tree-lined streets and glamorous tourist resorts captioned with the insult.\n\nOnline and offline, in cafes and shops across Africa, some wondered why the United States had spent millions of dollars to build massive embassies in countries which Mr. Trump held in such low esteem. Others speculated that if Mr. Trump visited their countries, he might revise his assumptions. Still others said that Mr. Trump may have had a point, citing the endemic corruption, public health challenges and poverty in many African nations.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Omondi, who lives in the sprawling working-class neighborhood of Kibera, in Nairobi, pointed out that the United States had a long relationship with people from the countries Mr. Trump criticized.\n\n\u201cThe USA,\u201d he wrote in a Facebook message, \u201cwas partly built by slaves from the \u2018shithole\u2019 countries.\u201d But Mr. Omondi said poverty and economic dysfunction across Africa lent support to Mr. Trump\u2019s point.\n\n\u201cDo I care?\u201d Mr. Omondi said. \u201cNot really, but such a statement coming from the leader of the \u2018free world\u2019 should serve as a wake up call for Africans to build Africa.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOyenka Nwenze, 26, a broadcaster, was stocking up on cooking ingredients for the weekend at a supermarket in the Silverbird shopping mall in Abuja, Nigeria.\n\n\u201cFor someone in that position he should know better, and he doesn\u2019t even try, he isn\u2019t attempting to expand his knowledge base,\u201d Mr. Nwenze said. \u201cIn Africa we are normal human beings.\u201d\n\nUnder rainy skies in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, many people were reflecting on the earthquake, remembering loved ones who died.\n\nMichelet Desulme, 31, a motorcycle taxi driver, said he agreed with Trump\u2019s assessment of Haiti. \u201cThe way our country is,\u201d he said, \u201cthe way it\u2019s not functioning, is this what his country is like?\u201d\n\nThe State Department appeared to have gone into damage-repair mode.\n\nWithout directly referring to the president\u2019s contentious statement, the State Department\u2019s main Africa account said on Twitter that \u201cthe United States will continue to robustly, enthusiastically and forcefully engage in Africa, promoting this vital relationship, and to listen and build on the trust and views we share with our African partners.\u201d The tweet was framed as a comment on a meeting of African ministers that the department hosted in November.\n\nNot everyone accepted that gesture, and some people were fearful of speaking in opposition to what they perceived as American policy. In Dakar, Senegal, diners at a beachside restaurant that serves Moscow mules and mojitos declined to express their views about Mr. Trump, fearing they might be denied visas to visit the United States.\n\nBabacar Faye, a tailor in Dakar, tuned his radio to another station Friday morning when discussion of Mr. Trump\u2019s comments was broadcast. His remarks were not surprising, Mr. Faye said.\n\n\u201cWhite people in general don\u2019t like black people,\u201d he said. \u201cThey just pretend to like us, but they don\u2019t.\u201d\n\nPhoebe Mutetsi in Kigali, Rwanda, said she was not falling for it.\n\n\u201cTrump is a troll,\u201d she said. \u201cHe is trolling the world. Don\u2019t feed the troll.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Don\u2019t Feed the Troll\u2019: Much of the World Reacts in Anger at Trump\u2019s Insult", "authors": ["Jina Moore", "Catherine Porter"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe fledgling plan from Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase to create an independent health care system for their American employees is just as bare-bones as it is bold.\n\nThe companies, all titans in their respective industries, gave few details Tuesday when they announced the joint effort. The group said its strategy will focus first on technology as a way to provide simplified, affordable access to medical services.\n\nBeyond that, here are some ideas from health care and medical experts about how the world\u2019s largest online retailer, the largest bank in the United States by assets and the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett\u2019s holding company might reshape an industry.\n\n_______\n\nA.I. for the Simple Things\n\n\u201cAmazon could assume drug distribution. They could start to use voice platforms, like Alexa, to help discuss symptoms and get feedback, to coordinate hospital post-op care through voice-activated A.I., to do these and other rote things.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Dr. Eric Topol, director, Scripps Translational Science Institute in San Diego\n\n_______\n\nEmployers in the Patient-Doctor Relationship\n\n\u201cMaybe they will develop some kind of algorithm that can be loaded onto any company software to help employers identify the low-hanging fruit, the patients that are using the most care or the highest-cost drugs. The Times reviewed Ms. Ma\u2019s case.\n\nFighting bias with history\n\n\u2022 Alarmed by displays of anti-Semitism among some new immigrants to Germany, a lawmaker has suggested requiring visits to Nazi concentration camp memorials.\n\nSeveral prominent Jewish organizations endorsed the idea on Wednesday, but some historians described it as simplistic.\n\n\u2022 Germany has absorbed more than a million immigrants in recent years, many fleeing war and mayhem in Africa and the Middle East.\n\nThe Daily Listen to \u2018The Daily\u2019: A Ticking Clock for DACA President Trump challenged Congress to pass legislation to protect undocumented immigrants brought to the United States as children. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2022 Best of late-night TV\n\nJimmy Kimmel celebrated the 2,000th false or misleading claim from the White House, as tracked by The Washington Post.\n\n\u2022 Quotation of the day\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like watching a telenovela. Every day is different. Now we\u2019re just going to the stressful part of the telenovela where you wonder what will happen to the protagonist.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Francis Madi, 28, who arrived in the U.S. from Venezuela in 2003, on the tension she and other \u201cDreamers\u201d feel as they watch their fate being debated.\n\nBack Story\n\nIn the 1850s, a U.S. Army lieutenant exploring the Grand Canyon made one of history\u2019s less accurate predictions, saying that the area had no financial value and that his party would probably be the last to visit.\n\nFar from it. In 1919, the year the Grand Canyon became a national park, it had more than 44,000 visitors, and it now receives six million a year.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe canyon\u2019s path to national park status began in the 1880s, when Senator Benjamin Harrison of Indiana introduced several bills to designate it a \u201cpublic park,\u201d but without success. Later, as president, he made it a forest reserve.\n\nPresident Theodore Roosevelt proclaimed parts of it a federal game reserve, and then established it as a national monument on this day in 1908.\n\nFive years earlier, on his first visit to Arizona (then still a territory), Roosevelt said he could not describe the Grand Canyon and implored people to preserve it. \u201cYou cannot improve on it; not a bit,\u201d he said.\n\nLike Roosevelt, the environmentalist John Muir was left at a loss for words by the canyon\u2019s beauty, writing in 1902 that no artist could do justice to its colors: \u201cAnd if paint is of no effect, what hope lies in pen-work? Only this: Some may be incited by it to go and see for themselves.\u201d\n\nJennifer Jett contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays at 6 a.m. Eastern and updated all morning.
