Check out our full range of free newsletters here.", "title": "\u2018Dreamers,\u2019 7-Eleven, Michelle Williams: Your Thursday Briefing", "authors": ["Chris Stanford"]} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump again insisted on Saturday that he was not under investigation by Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel investigating Russian influence on the 2016 election, adding that \u201cthere\u2019s been no collusion, there\u2019s been no crime.\u201d\n\n\u201cEverything I\u2019ve done is 100 percent proper,\u201d Mr. Trump said during a news conference at Camp David, where he was asked about a New York Times report that he had pressed Attorney General Jeff Sessions not to recuse himself from the Russia inquiry. \u201cThat is what I do, is I do things proper.\u201d\n\nThe president said the Times article, which reported that Mr. Trump had sought to protect himself by keeping Mr. Sessions in charge of the investigation, was \u201coff,\u201d though he did not elaborate.\n\nThe two primary issues that Mr. Mueller appears to be investigating are whether Mr. Trump obstructed justice while in office and whether there was collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump was at the presidential retreat to meet with Republican congressional leaders and cabinet officials as they fashion a strategy for their 2018 legislative agenda.", "title": "\u2018Everything I\u2019ve Done Is 100 Percent Proper,\u2019 Trump Says of Russia Inquiry", "authors": ["Michael Tackett"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Fake news evolved from seedy internet sideshow to serious electoral threat so quickly that behavioral scientists had little time to answer basic questions about it, like who was reading what, how much real news they also consumed and whether targeted fact-checking efforts ever hit a target.\n\nSure, surveys abound, asking people what they remember reading. But these are only as precise as the respondents\u2019 shifty recollections and subject to a malleable definition of \u201cfake.\u201d The term \u201cfake news\u201d itself has evolved into an all-purpose smear, used by politicians and the president to deride journalism they don\u2019t like.\n\nBut now the first hard data on fake-news consumption has arrived. Researchers last week posted an analysis of the browsing histories of thousands of adults during the run-up to the 2016 election \u2014 a real-time picture of who viewed which fake stories, and what real news those people were seeing at the same time.\n\nThe reach of fake news was wide indeed, the study found, yet also shallow. One in four Americans saw at least one false story, but even the most eager fake-news readers \u2014 deeply conservative supporters of President Trump \u2014 consumed far more of the real kind, from newspaper and network websites and other digital sources.", "title": "\u2018Fake News\u2019: Wide Reach but Little Impact, Study Suggests", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "OTTAWA \u2014 Like many book buyers, Randall Hansen, a professor of political science at the University of Toronto, has been unable to find a copy of \u201cFire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House,\u201d Michael Wolff\u2019s instant best seller.\n\nHis own book, though, a scholarly study about the Allies\u2019 bombing of Germany during World War II, is readily available. It has even found a second life on three Amazon best-seller lists and is back-ordered on the site. Maybe that\u2019s because its title is \u201cFire and Fury: The Allied Bombing of Germany, 1942-1945.\u201d\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know how much of this is a mistake and how much of this is from new interest created by free advertising,\u201d Professor Hansen said in an interview. \u201cThere might be some returns.\u201d\n\nThe professor\u2019s book, published 10 years ago, sold relatively well and received a nomination for one of Canada\u2019s top book awards. It is highly critical of the British-led nighttime firebombing of German cities, finding it both morally dubious and of little strategic value. But precision daylight bombing by the United States late in the war, Professor Hansen said, did undermine Germany\u2019s military.", "title": "\u2018Fire and Fury\u2019 From Canada: It\u2019s Not About Trump. If there is anyone who knows the dangers of trusting a reporter, it might be Mr. Wolff.", "title": "\u2018Fire and Fury\u2019 Is Feted by the Media Elite Trump Excoriates", "authors": ["Shawn Mccreesh"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cFire and Fury\u201d could be coming to the small screen. Or maybe even the big one.\n\nEndeavor Content has acquired the rights to Michael Wolff\u2019s No. 1 best-selling book, \u201cFire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House,\u201d and plans to develop it into a TV show or a feature film.\n\nNo TV network or film studio has been attached to the project.\n\nA \u201cFire and Fury\u201d adaptation could be the first major dramatic portrayal of the Trump White House. HBO had plans to develop a show from a book by Mark Halperin and John Heilemann about the final days of the 2016 campaign, but that project was canceled after Mr. Halperin was accused of sexual misconduct.\n\nNews about the rights to Mr. Wolff\u2019s book being acquired was reported by The Hollywood Reporter, and was confirmed by a spokeswoman for Endeavor Content.\n\nMr. Wolff was expected to be the executive producer of the project, and would be joined by the British television executive Michael Jackson.", "title": "\u2018Fire and Fury\u2019 May Be Coming to a Screen Near You", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 On a bitterly cold morning this month, Wang Fuman, 8, set out for school as he usually did, walking 2.8 miles through mountains and streams until he reached the warmth of his third-grade classroom.\n\nWhen Fuman arrived two hours later, his classmates erupted in laughter. The freezing temperatures had covered his hair, eyebrows and eyelashes with frost, making him look like a snowman. His cheeks were chapped and bright red.\n\nFuman\u2019s teacher at the Zhuanshanbao primary school, in the southern province of Yunnan, snapped a photograph and posted it on WeChat, a popular Chinese messaging app. Soon, the boy became an internet sensation, hailed by commenters as a symbol of the raw determination of rural residents, who make up about 43 percent of China\u2019s population.\n\nThe state-run media called him \u201cfrost boy\u201d and \u201cice boy.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Frost Boy\u2019 in China Warms Up the Internet, and Stirs Poverty Debate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "On Tuesday, Ms. Kelly drew on the trademark spitfire that made her a sensation at Fox News, only this time it was aimed squarely at the Republican president in office.\n\n\u201cI expect very little,\u201d she said before Mr. Trump gave the speech. \u201cBecause these events tend to be utterly forgettable, and this one probably will be, too.\u201d\n\nShe scoffed at the notion, pushed by the White House, that Mr. Trump would take a conciliatory approach. \u201cHow can the man we\u2019ve watched all this time come out and be conciliatory?\u201d Ms. Kelly said. \u201cTo whom? To the 3 percent of Democrats who approve of him right now?\u201d\n\nAlso in the hot seat on Tuesday was Chris Christie, the former governor of New Jersey, who spent his first evening as an ABC political analyst defending Mr. Trump\u2019s remarks as \u201ca traditional State of the Union speech.\u201d He was the sole Trump fan on ABC News\u2019s broadcast, where Matthew Dowd, a political consultant, quipped: \u201cCalling this a healing speech is almost like calling going on a diet by drinking a Diet Coke and eating a pizza.\u201d\n\nConservative media outlets focused on the facial reactions of Democrats in the audience, accusing the scowling Ms. Pelosi and Senator Bernie Sanders \u2014 who was seen looking deeply bored, and halfheartedly clapping \u2014 of disrespecting military veterans and the grieving relatives whom Mr. Trump had invited to the event. Even Gayle King, of CBS, said the Democrats \u201clooked like they had bitten a couple of lemons.\u201d\n\nIn his post-address remarks, Mr. Hannity, incredulous at the Democrats, asked his guest, \u201cHow can you sit down and not want to cheer?\u201d\n\nThe guest, Donald J. Trump Jr., agreed. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t make any sense to me,\u201d he said solemnly.\n\nThe president, a former star of reality TV, knows the value of a grand entrance, and all three cable networks carried footage of him entering a giant black limousine before making the short drive from the White House to the Capitol.", "title": "\u2018Gloomy.\u2019 \u2018Amazing.\u2019 Trump\u2019s Speech Divides the Pundits.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Talk about a death-defying stunt.\n\n\u201cThe Greatest Showman,\u201d a musical about the circus impresario P.T. Barnum, was dismissed by many critics when it arrived in theaters just before Christmas. Uncool. Old-fashioned. Mawkish. And when initial ticket sales were poor, most box office analysts decided \u201cThe Greatest Showman\u201d was a prime example of Hollywood being unable to pry people away from their Netflix accounts. Better stick to the superheroes and sequels.\n\nOver the past four weeks, however, \u201cThe Greatest Showman\u201d (20th Century Fox) has become a rare sleeper hit, lifted by positive word of mouth, stunt marketing (singalong screenings) and a popular soundtrack album. Ticket sales in the United States and Canada now stand at $113.5 million, including an $11 million haul between Friday and Sunday, good for fifth place over the weekend. The movie stars Hugh Jackman and Zendaya and was produced by a team that included Peter Chernin and Laurence Mark.\n\nSimilarly underappreciated movies dominated the weekend box office, with \u201cJumanji: Welcome to the Jungle\u201d (Sony) leading the charge. Derided by most of Hollywood before its release as an act of desperation by a franchise-starved Sony, \u201cJumanji\u201d was No. 1 for a third consecutive weekend, collecting about $20 million, for a new domestic total of $317 million. That astounding result is roughly in line with \u201cSkyfall,\u201d the 2012 James Bond hit, after adjusting for inflation.", "title": "\u2018Greatest Showman\u2019 Becomes a Sleeper Hit as Disrespected Films Flourish", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Mailhot grew up in foster care for a time, and after she aged out, at 17, she married \u2014 she didn\u2019t know what else to do. She had a child, and lost custody of him as she was giving birth to another. The marriage collapsed. Mailhot fell into a messy affair with her writing teacher and a second marriage. (\u201cI wasn\u2019t stable, but men don\u2019t usually care about that.\u201d) It\u2019s to him that the book is addressed. \u201cCasey, I want to be polite and present myself as decent,\u201d she writes early on before, happily, jettisoning that ambition.\n\nImage Terese Marie Mailhot Credit Isaiah Mailhot\n\n\u201cHeart Berries\u201d has a mixture of vulnerability and rage, sexual yearning and artistic ambition, swagger and self-mockery that recalls Chris Kraus\u2019s \u201cI Love Dick.\u201d Mailhot writes of a friend: \u201cShe thinks my husband doesn\u2019t understand how to communicate love, and I think he\u2019s impotent.\u201d Later, of Casey: \u201cI wanted to know what I looked like to you. A sin committed and a prayer answered, you said. You looked like a hamburger fried in a donut. You were hairy and large.\u201d\n\nShe is unsparing to everyone, especially herself. She makes some horrifying admissions: \u201cIsaiah cried all night, and I remembered well that I held a hand over his mouth, long enough for me to know I am a horror to my baby.\u201d She describes blinding rages in which she gave her husband a black eye, broke every glass in the house and some of the windows.\n\nIn a trice she can shift registers, though, and her candor and keenness of eye translate surprisingly well to tenderness. \u201cI wondered if maybe falling in love looked like a crisis to an observer,\u201d she writes. \u201cI found myself caressing my own face.\u201d In every revelation \u2014 of joy or suffering \u2014 there is an unmistakable note of triumph. \u201cI was the third generation of the things we didn\u2019t talk about,\u201d she notes; there is exhilaration in shattering this pattern.\n\n\u201cWe function the way ghosts function in ghost stories,\u201d the Ojibwe writer David Treuer said in 2006 about how indigenous people are represented. \u201cWe sort of hover around to admonish people about what they should be doing, what they\u2019re doing wrong, how they\u2019re destroying nature. We\u2019re always there, but chained to our own deaths, not really alive and active and engaged.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Heart Berries\u2019 Shatters a Pattern of Silence", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nKevin Spacey is out. Diane Lane and Greg Kinnear are in.\n\nThe sixth and final season of \u201cHouse of Cards\u201d will introduce new characters as it tries to move past a sexual misconduct scandal that put the Netflix series in peril and forced out its biggest star.\n\nMr. Spacey, who played the central character, Frank Underwood, a ruthless politician who becomes president, was shown the door amid allegations of sexual misconduct last year.\n\nProduction for the new season, after a three-month hiatus, resumed on Tuesday.\n\nNetflix did not disclose what roles Ms. Lane or Mr. Kinnear will play other than that they will be brother and sister. Mr. Kinnear, 54, and Ms. Lane, 53, are both Academy Award nominees. Robin Wright, the co-star of \u201cHouse of Cards,\u201d will be at the center of the final season.\n\nThe return to production ends a three-month odyssey that began shortly after The New York Times published an investigation detailing sexual harassment and assault allegations against the Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein and a national reckoning on sexual harassment began in earnest.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn October, after Anthony Rapp, an actor, accused Mr. Spacey of inappropriate sexual behavior, Netflix announced that the next season of \u201cHouse of Cards\u201d would be its last, and suspended production not long after. Mr. Spacey apologized to Mr. Rapp, but numerous other allegations against him emerged.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Netflix said it would spend up to $8 billion in content this year, dwarfing all rivals.", "title": "\u2018House of Cards\u2019 Resumes Production, With Diane Lane and Greg Kinnear", "authors": ["John Koblin"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMONDAY PUZZLE \u2014 This was a powerful one for me, and I am so glad I solved it. Today we are celebrating the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and Agnes Davidson and Zhouqin Burnikel collaborated to make a lovely puzzle to honor him.\n\nI don\u2019t know a lot about Ms. Davidson, but this is her second puzzle in The New York Times. It\u2019s possible that this was a true collaboration between Ms. Davidson and Ms. Burnikel, or perhaps Ms. Burnikel, the more experienced constructor, mentored Ms. Davidson on this one. If you have ever dreamed of trying your hand at constructing and you are on Facebook, join Erik Agard, Will Nediger and a ton of constructors in the Puzzle Collaboration Directory group, where aspiring constructors can meet more experienced hands who will work with them to learn the craft of puzzle making.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nKing\u2019s \u201cI Have a Dream\u201d speech, delivered from the Lincoln Memorial on Aug. 28, 1963, was made as part of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, so it\u2019s fitting that we solve a puzzle about that subject today.\n\nFour theme entries that end in a synonym for the hint at 61A are packed into Ms. Davidson and Ms. Burnikel\u2019s puzzle, and while it was relatively easy to figure out, it still left me with a lump in my throat. I was a baby when King was assassinated, but I still remember my mother crying when the news came out.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt 17A, for example, we have the phrase NEW RELEASE, and RELEASE is a synonym for the word FREE in the 61A revealer, FREE AT LAST.", "title": "\u2018I Have a Dream\u2019", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "In contrast to letters from Trump voters that we ran earlier, now we hear from two readers disappointed that their hopes didn\u2019t pan out.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nI voted for Donald Trump, and I regret it.\n\nI thought he would change his divisive rhetoric from the campaign trail and never imagined he would divide this country with lies and racism, bigotry and hate. I see a man working to destroy democracy with the help of Vladimir Putin by using disinformation to frustrate and confuse everyone as they weaken America\u2019s standing in the world.\n\nI fear for my children\u2019s future and see a president and his family profiting off the office just as in authoritarian countries, with zero pushback from the Republican Party. Democracy will die if they continue.\n\nSYDNEY COHAN, WESTWOOD, N.J.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nAdmittedly, my vote for Donald Trump was less for him than it was against his opponent. However, when he won I felt he was in a unique situation to unite the country by showing what an outsider could accomplish if given the chance. I now feel that he\u2019s squandered it. Policywise, I agree with much of what he\u2019s done, but the tax bill could have been much better and broader, and he keeps focusing his attention on inconsequential nonsense.", "title": "Opinion | \u2018I Voted for Donald Trump, and I Regret It\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Hargrave was arrested on Monday at a Vermilion Parish School Board meeting shortly after questioning the board\u2019s decision to give a raise to Jerome Puyau, the superintendent, and renew his contract.\n\nA video showed a city marshal, identified as Reggie Hilts, approaching her as she spoke during a portion of the meeting dedicated to public comment. He escorted her from the meeting, and moments later she was handcuffed on the floor of a hallway.\n\nMs. Hargrave was arrested on charges of \u201cremaining after having been forbidden\u201d and \u201cresisting an officer,\u201d according to Ike Funderburk, Abbeville\u2019s city attorney and prosecutor. But he decided not to pursue charges, as did a lawyer for the school board, Mr. Funderburk said on Tuesday.\n\nVideo\n\nAfter the episode attracted widespread news media attention, the officer involved drew more scrutiny.\n\nIn a lawsuit filed in 2012, Mr. Hilts and another officer in Scott, La., were accused of using excessive force against a 62-year-old man by slamming his head on a concrete slab as he was arrested in 2011. The man, a hepatitis C patient with an enlarged spleen, was \u201cin a very weakened physical condition because of chronic cirrhosis of the liver,\u201d according to the lawsuit.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe officers denied that excessive force was used, saying the man had resisted arrest during a dispute over his lawn. The suit was settled in 2016, according to The Associated Press.\n\nMr. Hilts, a pastor at a local church, is married with two children, according to a biography on his church\u2019s website.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe marshal\u2019s office could not be reached for comment on Thursday.\n\nMs. Hargrave teaches English to fifth- and sixth-grade students at Rene A. Rost Middle School in Vermilion Parish on the southern Louisiana coast. In a video statement on Wednesday, she said she was \u201cappalled by this, and you should be, too.\u201d\n\nShe said she returned to school on Tuesday, hours after being freed from jail, and that her students and their parents had been supportive. She was trying to turn the ordeal into a learning experience, she said.\n\n\u201cPlease don\u2019t let the conversation end with me,\u201d Ms. Hargrave said. \u201cPlease go to your local school board meetings. Speak out, be vocal.\u201d\n\nIn an interview with NBC News, Mr. Puyau, the superintendent, said that he and his family had been \u201cbombarded\u201d with death threats.\n\n\u201cAre there things that we could have done differently? I think the whole world knows we can, you see it,\u201d he said. \u201cHowever, we have to come together and say we have to follow the rules.\u201d\n\nAcross the state, educators and politicians expressed disappointment in the scene.\n\n\u201cDeyshia Hargrave\u2019s expulsion from a public meeting and subsequent arrest are unacceptable and raise serious constitutional concerns,\u201d Jane Johnson, the interim executive director of the A.C.L.U. of Louisiana, said in a statement. \u201cThe Constitution prohibits the government from punishing or retaliating against people for expressing their views, and the fact that a schoolteacher was arrested at a public meeting of the school board is especially troubling.\u201d\n\nJohn Bel Edwards, the Louisiana governor, said on Wednesday that the arrest was \u201cterribly unfortunate,\u201d according to The Times-Picayune.\n\n\u201cIt should not have happened and it cast a negative light on our state and, you know, it\u2019s very regrettable,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTeachers have used her experience as a rallying call.\n\n\u201cWe are all stakeholders who not only have the right to speak up for our students, but we also have a duty to do so,\u201d Suzanne Breaux, president of the Vermilion Association of Educators, said at the rally on Thursday. \u201cWe are relevant, and we will not be silenced any longer.\u201d", "title": "\u2018I Want Change to Come From This,\u2019 Louisiana Teacher Says of Arrest", "authors": ["Daniel Victor"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "In 1993, I came to The Times myself from The Philadelphia Inquirer and have now covered figure skating, off and on, for a quarter-century. There is no sport more fun to write about in an Olympic year. Skating is full of creative people, individuals who are not muzzled by the team ethos. At the same time, their careers are held in constant judgment by others. Somehow this eternal tension between the objective and the subjective is liberating instead of stifling.\n\nIn September, I traveled to Germany to see a pairs team from North Korea qualify for the 2018 Winter Olympics. Even skaters from the world\u2019s most isolated country couldn\u2019t stop talking to reporters.\n\nNor does the sport ever seem to lose its humor. Adam Rippon, an Olympian from Los Angeles, was asked at the U.S. championships this month what it was like to be an openly gay skater. It was the same as being a straight skater, he said, \u201cexcept with better eyebrows.\u201d\n\nAnd did we mention the costumes?\n\nAt the 1992 Winter Olympics, the skating maven Christine Brennan noticed something familiar about the yellow, orange and red outfit worn by Kurt Browning, a four-time world champion from Canada. Then it dawned on Brennan: Browning was dressed like a warm front on the USA Today weather map.\n\nTara Lipinski, then 15, won gold at the 1998 Winter Olympics with a costume that suggested, I\u2019m going to my first Communion and I intend to yodel.\n\nMy favorite skating character is the droll Tamara Moskvina of Russia, perhaps the world\u2019s greatest pairs coach. The first time we met, at a competition in France, I was among a group of reporters who were all inadvertently wearing press passes for the same news organization.\n\n\u201cC.I.A.?\u201d Moskvina asked.\n\nAt the 1994 Winter Olympics, Moskvina uttered what may be the most incisive and poetic thing ever said about the judging of figure skating: \u201cIt seems to me this is the eternal question between, as we say, lyrics and physics. Some prefer the priest, others prefer the priest\u2019s wife, and others prefer the priest\u2019s daughter.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nToday, interest in skating is greatly diminished, except in Japan, where it thrives. At the Winter Olympics, at least we should get to see the sublime strangeness of North Koreans skating to the Beatles. In the United States, though, the only buzz about women\u2019s skating comes from the movies, not the rink, in the form of a mockumentary, \u201cI, Tonya,\u201d about the 1994 knee-whacking of Nancy Kerrigan by associates of Harding.\n\nStereotypes of the sport in those days \u2014 all fur coats, blue blood and white collar \u2014 were not fully accurate. Kerrigan, the supposed ice princess, was the daughter of a welder. And neither is today\u2019s revisionism about Harding scrupulously factual. Yes, she had complicated relationships with her mother and former husband. But Harding was not held back by American skating officials because she did not fit some sequined ideal. Those officials sent her not to one Olympics but to two.\n\nMostly, Harding got in her own way. It happened again last week, when her agent, Michael A. Rosenberg, dissolved their relationship. After promoting the movie and attending the Golden Globes, Harding wanted reporters to sign affidavits and be fined $25,000 for asking about her past, according to Rosenberg.\n\n\u201c \u2018I, Tonya\u2019 is now goodbye Tonya,\u201d Rosenberg wrote.\n\nStill, along with the triple axel, Harding will always have this claim to fame: She is surely the only person ever to report being stalked by professional golfers.", "title": "\u2018I, Figure Skating Reporter\u2019: Full Circle With Tonya Harding", "authors": ["Jer\u00e9 Longman"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "The workers who jumped into these simmering online situations are known as \u201cviolence interrupters,\u201d and their interventions were part of an initiative known as E-Responder. Its goal is to identify and de-escalate social media conflicts before they erupt into violence on the street.\n\nThe program, developed by the Citizens Crime Commission of New York City in partnership with New York University\u2019s Steinhardt School of Culture, Education and Development, was first tested in 2016. It expanded a year ago.\n\nUnder the program, the violence interrupters spend at least two hours a day monitoring social media for signs of risky behavior, like threats of violence, photos with weapons or expressions of grief or emotional stress, Mr. Polanco said. They focus on people ages 16 to 25. If an alarming post or photo is found, a worker reaches out to the young person.\n\nDuring the pilot program, youth workers interrupted 154 social media feuds; more than half were described as medium or high risk, according to the Citizens Crime Commission.\n\nIn all last year, the city\u2019s Cure Violence sites \u2014 organizations, including True2Life, that treat violence as a public health concern \u2014 intervened in 5,273 street and online conflicts, according to the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, which maintains the data. The agency did not have data on what percentage were online interventions. The Citizens Crime Commission is currently working to compile that data.\n\nOn Staten Island, True2Life interrupters focus their outreach on youth in parts of Mariners Harbor and Stapleton, where nearly a third of the residents live below the poverty level, according to a New York City Department of Planning 2016 report.\n\nMichael Perry, 37, a violence interrupter and program supervisor at True2Life, came of age in the 1990s in the Richmond Terrace Development, 10 minutes from Stapleton, where he sold drugs, carried firearms, was arrested, had friends felled by gun violence and was nearly killed himself. It was where \u2014 when Mr. Perry was 9 years old \u2014 his father, who peddled drugs to feed his own addiction, was stabbed to death in a drug feud. Ultimately, Mr. Perry, now a father of two, also found redemption there after praying for a way out.\n\nPhoto\n\nSince joining True2Life four years ago, Mr. Perry has tried to lead by example, telling young people engaged in violence and risky behavior that they, too, can change. In the two years since the pilot launched, Mr. Perry said he intervened in up to 60 online fights that could have led to violence.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMost social media interventions \u2014 97 percent \u2014 performed during the pilot in 2016 had positive outcomes, according to the Citizens Crime Commission.\n\nTo assist in sorting through hundreds of social media posts, the Citizens Crime Commission is awaiting approval from Facebook to use software they developed that will review, analyze and provide real-time alerts about posts containing violent language.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut for now the workers manually browse through social media profiles and, at times, other young people alert them to potentially dangerous messages and photos.\n\nIt was Mr. Perry who spotted the photo on Facebook of the two teenage boys with firearms in May. He recognized one of them as the son of a childhood friend. A week after the disturbing post, the boy was shot in the leg. Mr. Perry visited him at the hospital and has stayed in contact with him. He hopes that in time he can steer the teenager away from a seemingly violent path.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t go preaching \u2014 you build relationships and bond with them,\u201d he said. \u201cIt takes time.\u201d\n\nFrom 2012 to 2015, at least 240 shootings and 24 homicides in New York City started as arguments on social media, according to the Citizens Crime Commission, which examined indictments during that period.\n\n\u201cPeople who feel they\u2019ve been disrespected on social media will take it to the streets,\u201d said Jeff Butts, director of the Research and Evaluation Center at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, who has evaluated violence prevention programs in New York. \u201cIt\u2019s about pride and respect.\u201d\n\nSimilarly, during that same time more than 700 people were indicted based on evidence found on their social media pages.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYoung people commonly use social media to threaten their rivals, and online feuds can lead to retaliation, experts said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not just about identifying posts,\u201d said Desmond U. Patton, an assistant professor of social work at Columbia University and director of SAFE Lab, a research initiative that analyzes the way in which minority youth in Chicago navigate violence online and offline, \u201cbut about how do you take what you want from social media and help people be good stewards of social media?\u201d\n\nMr. Patton began studying the intersection of social media and street violence six years ago after the shooting death of an aspiring Chicago rapper, Joseph Coleman, 18, formerly known as Lil Jojo. Mr. Coleman was killed in the Englewood neighborhood of Chicago after a war of words over social media with several rival rappers, including Chief Keef.\n\nStephanie Ueberall, director of violence prevention at the Citizens Crime Commission, said E-Responder includes a 12-week youth leadership program that encourages participants to engage in positive social media exchanges and activism, while teaching them self-empowerment and how to express and manage their emotions.\n\n\u201cSocial media can greatly accelerate violence,\u201d Ueberall said. \u201cA lot of them don\u2019t have the direction or support they need to get into a healthy lifestyle. The main task is to change the way they think.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Interrupters\u2019 Peek at Social Media to Stop Street Violence", "authors": ["Jan Ransom"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cIs Mr. Trump Nuts?\u201d (editorial, Jan. 11):\n\nIf President Trump were clutching his chest or falling down repeatedly and the medical community were silent, the public would wonder what cardiologists and neurologists thought of the president\u2019s physical health and why they were not speaking up.\n\nIn your editorial you problematically argue that the perspective of the psychiatrist is simultaneously irrelevant because the \u201cobvious\u201d is being stated and dangerous because of public misunderstanding and stereotyping. But these are not the only possibilities.\n\nIt is one thing for psychiatrists to assume the role of the armchair psychoanalyst, presuming to know the deep unconscious conflicts of our president without examining him. It is this kind of (mis)conduct for which the Goldwater Rule was put in place. It is quite a different situation for a psychiatrist to illuminate an aspect of President Trump based on his observable behavior and to raise legitimate concerns about his mental health.\n\nAs a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst I do not presume to know why President Trump has trouble staying in reality. But I do know, and the public should as well, that decision making is seriously affected when \u201creality testing\u201d is impaired, and the consequences can be catastrophic.", "title": "Opinion | \u2018Is Mr. Trump Nuts?\u2019 Analyze This.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAmerica First\u201d is not a new policy. The U.S. has always had its thumb on the scale where trade is concerned. All that has changed is that the policy has now been acknowledged and intensified.\n\nMary MacKay, 70, lives in rural Cape Breton:\n\nWhere I live, our only department store is a Wal-Mart 30 kilometers away, so we\u2019re already held captive by an American enterprise. I like the idea of trading worldwide, easing our way out of reliance on the United States\u2019 mercurial dictates. The free-trade agreement has not always suited Canadians. So why are we determined to hold on to it?\n\nDavid Jorgensen, 61, lives in Edmonton, Alberta:\n\nFriday\u2019s ruling on the Bombardier/Boeing dispute shows how important it is for Canada to have a trade arbitration mechanism that is not dependent on raw power. A set of reliable dispute-resolution protocols are crucial. We Canadians certainly see Trump\u2019s pronouncements as aggressive and bullying \u2014 his \u201cAmerica First\u201d also says to us \u201cCanada Last,\u201d and we\u2019re simply not prepared to put up with that.\n\nJohn Peddie, 71, lives in Toronto:\n\nScandinavian and Swiss models are good examples of what Canada should be doing. As for what I\u2019d like to see from the current Nafta talks: a firm stance against America\u2019s current political leadership, a willingness to walk away from American bullying and a strenuous effort to expand trade with other parts of the world. This would include a bilateral agreement with Mexico.", "title": "\u2018It\u2019s Time for Canada to Grow Up\u2019: As Nafta Talks Close, Canadians Take Stock", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "At the time of the announcement, many Afghan officials feared an immediate escalation in violence in retaliation and wondered whether their shaky government could absorb the blows.\n\nOn Saturday, Mr. Trump issued a statement denouncing the attack. \u201cI condemn the despicable car bombing attack in Kabul today that has left scores of innocent civilians dead and hundreds injured,\u201d he said. \u201cThe Taliban\u2019s cruelty will not prevail. The United States is committed to a secure Afghanistan that is free from terrorists who would target Americans, our allies, and anyone who does not share their wicked ideology.\u201d\n\nIn last weekend\u2019s attack, Taliban militants barged into the highly guarded Intercontinental Hotel, battling security forces in an hourslong siege. At least 14 of their victims were foreign citizens, including Americans, and nine were pilots and flight crew members from Ukraine and Venezuela who worked for a private Afghan airline, Kam Air.\n\nAt the time of Saturday\u2019s attack, Gen. Joseph L. Votel, the commander of the United States Central Command, which oversees military operations in the region, was in Kabul. He met with Mr. Ghani, and officials aware of the discussion said Pakistan was much of the focus.\n\nAnger at the Afghan government for its dysfunction and ineffectiveness in the face of violence was palpable on the streets.\n\nAt the site of the explosion, an old man, his clothes stained with blood, sat on the ground and wailed. He cursed the two leaders of the Afghan government \u2014 President Ghani and his coalition partner, Abdullah Abdullah \u2014 for the security lapses. He said his son was dead.\n\n\u201cMay God punish you, may Allah punish you both,\u201d the old man repeated. \u201cThere is nothing left for me anymore \u2014 come kill me and my family, too.\u201d\n\nSaturday\u2019s explosion occurred on a guarded street that leads to an old Interior Ministry building and several embassies. Many ministry departments still have offices there, and visitors line up every day for routine business.", "title": "\u2018It\u2019s a Massacre\u2019: Blast in Kabul Deepens Toll of a Long War", "authors": ["Mujib Mashal", "Jawad Sukhanyar", "Matthew Sedacca"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Asked about whether he still expects to reach a deal to extend protections for immigrants who were brought to the United States as children, Mr. Trump blamed Democrats for refusing to negotiate in good faith over the program known as DACA.\n\n\u201cHonestly, I don\u2019t think the Democrats want to make a deal,\u201d he said. \u201cI think they talk about DACA but they don\u2019t want to help the DACA people.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump said there were \u201ca lot of sticking points, but they are all Democratic sticking points.\u201d\n\n\u201cThey don\u2019t want security at the border, there are people pouring in,\u201d the president added. \u201cThey don\u2019t want security at the border, they don\u2019t want to stop the drugs.\u201d\n\n\u201cAnd they want to take money away from our military, which we will not do.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump said he hoped there would not be a shutdown of the government over what he said was Democratic unwillingness to compromise on DACA.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know if there is going to be a shutdown,\u201d he said. \u201cThere shouldn\u2019t be, because if there is, our military gets hurt very badly. We cannot let our military be hurt.\u201d", "title": "\u2018I\u2019m Not a Racist,\u2019 Trump Says in Denying Vulgar Comment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "But if Mr. Romney\u2019s Senate candidacy is inevitable, how exactly he would run and serve is less clear.\n\nHis yet-to-be-declared candidacy is already highlighting the enduring fractures over President Trump in this heavily Mormon state, where voters have long been uneasy with Mr. Trump\u2019s conduct. At issue is whether Mr. Romney, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee, should be an overt check on the president, and even use a Senate platform to mount his own White House comeback, or act as an ally and retain access to Mr. Trump the way Mr. Hatch has done.\n\nMr. Trump won Utah but garnered only 45 percent of the vote, the lowest of any Republican nominee for nearly a quarter-century. The state\u2019s largely conservative voters found his coarse language, treatment of women and contempt for many immigrants and refugees to be anathema to a faith centered on rectitude and forged by exile. About 27 percent voted for Hillary Clinton, and 21 percent voted for Evan McMullin, a Mormon political neophyte who ran as a conservative counter to Mr. Trump.\n\nUtahans saw Mr. Trump as a far cry from his predecessor from four years earlier.\n\nStrolling between buildings at the State Capitol complex, the imposing Wasatch Range looming in nearly every direction, Lt. Gov. Spencer J. Cox sought to explain why Mr. Romney is so formidable that nearly every ambitious major Republican, including himself, is standing down.\n\n\u201cWe have a little bit of an inferiority complex in the state of Utah,\u201d Mr. Cox said. \u201cI think it has to do with how we got here. We got kicked out of the country, basically. There was an extermination order. And so we came out here with nothing.\u201d", "title": "\u2018I\u2019m Running,\u2019 Romney Says Privately, but as a Trump Friend or Foe?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Sure enough, the Oxford English Dictionary defines gangster as \u201ca member of a criminal gang, esp. one involved in organized crime,\u201d while it defines gangsta as \u201ca member of an urban territorial gang.\u201d\n\nAlison Shapiro, a spokeswoman for the show, said producers did not consider it a matter of pronunciation or dialect.\n\n\u201cHad we accepted \u2018gangster,\u2019 the other contestants would have a very good reason to complain, in that the title of the song is \u2018Gangsta\u2019s Paradise,\u2019 and we would have accepted something that is not the title,\u201d the producers said, according to Ms. Shapiro. \u201cEvery ruling we make not only affects the contestant who responded, but their opponents as well.\u201d\n\nBut another leading authority came to Mr. Spicher\u2019s defense: Coolio told TMZ he thought the answer should have counted.\n\n\u201cI probably would have gave it to him,\u201d the rapper said.\n\nBut he also offered a linguistic lesson.\n\n\u201cThis is for white people,\u201d he said. \u201cThe E-R will always get you in trouble.\u201d\n\nThere is a history of \u201cJeopardy!\u201d judges being sticklers for pronunciation. In 2015, Rob Russell\u2019s game unraveled on a $2,000 Daily Double because he pronounced \u201cfoliage\u201d as \u201cfoilage,\u201d a common regionalism that was once mocked on \u201cThe Simpsons.\u201d In February 2016, Bill Murphy was originally given credit for naming France\u2019s second-busiest seaport as Le Havre, but it was overturned because he pronounced it in a way that rhymes with the former Green Bay quarterback Brett Favre.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn October 2017, Austin Rogers got an $800 question wrong because he pronounced \u201csherbet\u201d as \u201csherbert.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019m from New York. That\u2019s how we say it,\u201d Mr. Rogers responded.\n\nIt all raises the question: Whose pronunciation does \u201cJeopardy!\u201d consider to be correct? We already know that when it comes to Americans, y\u2019all, youse and you guys talk differently.\n\nMs. Shapiro said some pronunciation disputes are settled by the dictionary. For example, \u201cexpresso\u201d is listed as a variant on \u201cespresso,\u201d so that would be allowed.\n\nBut judges make subjective calls on whether a nonstandard pronunciation is common enough or if it\u2019s just plain wrong, she said.\n\n\u201cAlso, we understand there are regional dialects and accents, and keep that in mind in our judgments,\u201d she said in an email.\n\nAndy Saunders, who runs The \u201cJeopardy!\u201d Fan site, said the judges \u201coften expect general American pronunciation in the general American dialect.\u201d\n\nHe couldn\u2019t recall any times contestants were penalized because of accents, but pronunciations are a frequent topic of debate among the show\u2019s die-hard fans. Earlier in Monday\u2019s episode, there was some dispute over how a contestant pronounced another music/literature mash-up: \u201cwill.i.ambic pentameter,\u201d he said.\n\nAs for the gangsta/gangster mix-up, he agreed with the judges. Titles must be exact, and the two words do have slightly separate meanings, he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cCoolio thought that the judges should have given it to him, but I\u2019m also not entirely sure Coolio is completely aware\u201d of the \u201cJeopardy!\u201d rule book, he said.\n\nThe dispute ended up having little impact on Mr. Spicher\u2019s game; he still triumphed, and he most likely would have won the same amount of money because he would have bet differently in the final round, Mr. Saunders said.\n\nOn Twitter, Mr. Spicher appeared to have a sense of humor about it. He said producers stopped taping \u201cfor what felt like an eternity\u201d before an executive producer came on stage to explain the ruling to him.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s partly why I didn\u2019t have much of a reaction on camera,\u201d he said.\n\nAt first he thought: \u201cDidn\u2019t I say \u2018gangsta?\u2019 \u201d But he figured they had listened closely enough to come up with a definitive answer.\n\n\u201cThey had every right to call me out on it,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd I will be forever proud of the moment that Alex Trebek taught me how to say \u2018gangsta.\u2019 \u201d", "title": "\u2018Jeopardy!\u2019 Tells Contestant: A \u2018Gangster\u2019 Is Not a \u2018Gangsta\u2019", "authors": ["Daniel Victor"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 There is no generational nostalgia for the characters. The January release date allowed piracy to flourish online, cutting into ticket sales. Hollywood imports are losing their luster as local studios become more skilled at making blockbuster-style movies.\n\nWhatever the reason, \u201cStar Wars: The Last Jedi\u201d (Disney) collapsed in China, the world\u2019s second-largest movie market, arriving this weekend to estimated ticket sales over three days of $28.7 million. To compare, \u201cStar Wars: The Force Awakens\u201d took in $53 million over its first two days in Chinese cinemas in 2016. Last year, \u201cRogue One: A Star Wars Story\u201d managed $31 million over its first three days.\n\nDisney promoted \u201cThe Last Jedi\u201d extensively in China, staging a red carpet premiere at the Shanghai Disney Resort, replete with a squadron of Stormtroopers, and securing marketing partnerships with companies like Pepsi, Alibaba, Samsung and Youku. But the efforts fell flat: \u201cThe Last Jedi\u201d was no match for a holdover local comedy, \u201cThe Ex-File 3: The Return of the Exes,\u201d which took in an estimated $86.7 million.\n\nDave Hollis, Disney\u2019s president of distribution, acknowledged on Sunday that the China results were softer than the studio had hoped for. The action movie took in $27 million from Friday through Sunday to bring its domestic total to $283 million after four weeks. \u201cJumanji\u201d also topped the Chinese box office and has made over $550 million worldwide; its success has cemented Kevin Hart and Dwayne Johnson as box office near-guarantees.\n\nLess successful was the Liam Neeson vehicle \u201cThe Commuter,\u201d which opened to $13.4 million, according to comScore, which compiles box office data. That\u2019s a far cry from \u201cTaken 3,\u201d which arrived the same calendar weekend in 2015 and took in $40.4 million. \u201cThe Commuter\u201d reportedly cost $30 million to make, and its ticket sales are a sign that audiences might be wearying of Mr. Neeson\u2019s action movies (as our critic was).\n\n\u201cThe Post,\u201d a well-reviewed recounting of The Washington Post\u2019s efforts to release the Pentagon Papers that stars Meryl Streep and Tom Hanks, took in $18 million in its first week in wide release, good for second place. Fox has been slowly rolling out the Oscar contender to build word of mouth, and is hoping for attention from the Academy Awards (nominations are released next week) to give it a long tail. The movie cost $50 million to make and drew an older crowd, with 66 percent of its audience over 35.\n\nDespite a 100 percent score on Rotten Tomatoes, \u201cPaddington 2\u201d made just $10.6 million in its arrival to North America, about less than half of what its 2014 prequel made in its first weekend. Warner Bros., which bought the movie from the Weinstein Company following sexual assault accusations against Harvey Weinstein, has excellent exit-polling numbers to bank on \u2014 the movie earned an A CinemaScore grade overall, and an A+ from audience members under 35. And the movie has already made a cool $125 million overseas.\n\n\u201cI, Tonya\u201d and \u201cLady Bird\u201d both increased their earnings compared to their previous weeks, perhaps thanks to victories at the Golden Globes. Coyote.\n\nThe truth is that it appears that most of the conservative architecture in this country \u2014 members of the administration, members of Congress, Fox News, the Republican National Committee, and Trump\u2019s die-hard base \u2014 are all engaged in an exercise to defend, excuse, protect and absolve a man and his behaviors, which may well do irreparable damage to the country.\n\nThey have learned to praise him in order to steady him. Actually, pathetic.\n\nTrump\u2019s defenders have bolstered his insistence that all questioning of his competence is purely political.", "title": "Opinion | \u2018Like, Really Smart\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "The bride\u2019s previous two marriages ended in divorce, as did the groom\u2019s two.\n\nThe couple met in 1998, when both were browsing the poetry section at a bookstore on Union Square, in New York. They struck up a conversation, soon moved to the bookstore\u2019s cafe, and then strolled down to the Strand in search of a book that Ms. Kastan was hoping to find.\n\n\u201cWe just found our way to a bunch of common interests very quickly,\u201d Mr. Gabrels said. \u201cWhen we parted that day, I thought \u2014 I don\u2019t think the word \u2018marriage\u2019 popped into my head \u2014 but I was like, I really like this person. I want to see her again.\u201d\n\nThey were each married to other people at the time, though Mr. Gabrels and his wife were separated. But both felt the spark of something special in their encounter.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s creative and considerate and he\u2019s the kind of guy who always says, \u2018I wonder what would happen if \u2026,\u2019\u201d Ms. Kastan said. \u201cAnd he has this great ability to laugh or apologize, or publish the results, and it becomes a song.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Gabrels says Ms. Kastan is in many ways what he is not, organized and linear, for example, and so they complement each other.\n\n\u201cI think more like a chord, where it\u2019s a stack of notes, and Susan thinks more like a melody, where there\u2019s a single path,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s always interesting because we come to the same conclusion but we arrive at it in different ways.\u201d\n\nNonetheless, that moment in 1998 was not the right time for the two. Mr. Gabrels ended up reconciling with his wife and then moved to Los Angeles. Ms. Kastan, who was then in doctoral studies, also returned her focus to her own family.\n\n\u201cWe just truly enjoyed the conversation and the intellectual spark, and we sort of filed it away under, \u2018maybe in another life,\u2019\u201d Ms. Kastan said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey fell out of touch.\n\nYears later, in 2006, Mr. Gabrels, now living alone in Nashville, was spending his nights scrolling through thousands of messages that had accumulated in an old email account. He came across one from Ms. Kastan that had been sent about a year earlier, not a personal note but instead announcing a new email address to all her contacts.\n\nHe sent her a message immediately. She responded, and in just that brief communication, the two found that they still had much in common. She was now divorced and he was separated and in the process of divorcing, and both had recently been through the death of their mothers.\n\nWithin a few weeks, the two had their first date. It was in Asheville, N.C., a four-hour drive from Nashville and about the same distance from the family wedding she was to attend in Durham, N.C. They met on a Sunday morning, had pancakes in a railroad-car diner, and explored the city\u2019s churches and galleries.\n\nA few months later, after several more long-distance dates, Ms. Kastan decided to move to Nashville.\n\n\u201cWhat the heck!\u201d she said. \u201cYou don\u2019t get a second chance or a third chance that often!\u201d", "title": "\u2018Maybe in Another Life\u2019 Becomes Now", "authors": ["Nina Reyes"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe old-line movie factories essentially pursue one of two strategies. The dominant companies, Walt Disney Studios and Warner Bros., with their vast superhero holdings and ongoing franchises, focus on big-budget, all-audience films. Studios with less access to pre-existing characters \u2014 20th Century Fox, Universal Pictures \u2014 have it much harder, operating on more of an old-fashioned portfolio basis. They serve up a wide mix of movies and hope that some of those bets pay off.\n\nThe power of the second approach was on vivid display over the weekend, as six starkly different films from 20th Century Fox appeared on the box office charts, giving the studio control of more than 50 percent of ticket sales in North America.\n\nA sequel to a sequel, \u201cMaze Runner: The Death Cure,\u201d with its zombie plague and revenge-determined teenagers, arrived to about $23.5 million in ticket sales domestically, dethroning Sony\u2019s \u201cJumanji: Welcome to the Jungle\u201d as the No. 1 attraction at multiplexes. \u201cThe Death Cure,\u201d which was delayed after its resident heartthrob, Dylan O\u2019Brien, suffered injuries on the set in 2016, cost at least $62 million to make. (\u201cThe Death Cure\u201d collected an additional $62.7 million overseas.)\n\nPhoto\n\nAnother Fox movie, \u201cThe Greatest Showman,\u201d an original musical that has become a slow-building, word-of-mouth hit, delivered about $9.5 million in ticket sales (No. 4), for a new domestic total of $126.5 million. Three dramas with varied production budgets, each nominated for best picture at the coming Oscars \u2014 \u201cThe Post,\u201d \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d and \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d \u2014 took in an additional $18.2 million for Fox and its specialty label, Fox Searchlight.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRounding out the Fox portfolio was the animated \u201cFerdinand,\u201d which collected about $1 million, for a new total of $80.5 million ($240 million worldwide).\n\nAs good as the weekend was for Fox, Sony\u2019s \u201cJumanji\u201d sequel demonstrated why studios prefer to focus on all-audience movies with built-in marketplace awareness. \u201cJumanji: Welcome to the Jungle\u201d took in about $16.4 million in second place, for a new total of $338.1 million and global ticket sales of $822 million, according to comScore. It will likely take all six of the Fox releases to beat that one result.", "title": "\u2018Maze Runner\u2019 Sequel is No. 1, Adding to Fox Box Office Bonanza", "authors": ["Brooks Barnes"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "A handful of university officials have already lost their jobs in cases that have prompted national debate, including one involving a professor accused of harassing a half-dozen students over the past 15 years.\n\nWomen Speak Out on Sexual Assault in Asia\n\nThe campaign is testing the limits of a government that frowns on citizen-led movements, has a poor record of promoting women\u2019s rights and controls all news media. While investigative reporting ignited the #MeToo movement in the United States, women in China are forced to tell their stories directly online.\n\n\u201c \u2018Me Too\u2019 was an alarm bell for all of us,\u201d said Sophia Huang Xueqin, 30, a journalist in southern China who started a social media platform to report sexual harassment. \u201cWe\u2019re not brave enough to stand out as one individual. But together, we can be strong.\u201d\n\nMs. Huang, who said she left her job at a national news service several years ago after being harassed by a senior colleague, said many women were ashamed to speak out because of the stigma associated with it. \u201cIt feels like we\u2019re still in a traditional world where women are supposed to stay at home and support the family and feed the kids,\u201d she said.\n\nThe Communist Party often embraces gender equality as a propaganda theme, noting the strides women made in the first decades of its rule. Mao famously declared that \u201cwomen hold up half the sky.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBut in recent years, the government has done little to prevent a resurgence of sexism and workplace discrimination. Men dominate the party\u2019s upper ranks, and government officials and powerful business executives are often protected from allegations of wrongdoing.\n\nLaws on rape and harassment are vague, legal experts say, and courts do not often rule in favor of women who pursue complaints against employers. Employers rarely investigate complaints or dole out meaningful punishments.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMost victims remain silent,\u201d said Li Ying, a lawyer and the director of the Beijing Yuanzhong Gender Development Center, an advocacy group. \u201cThey can\u2019t afford to lose their jobs.\u201d\n\nThe #MeToo movement is largely limited to educated, urban women. Many have been inspired by Luo Xixi, a graduate of Beihang University, an aeronautics school in Beijing, who recently published an essay online that was read by more than three million people. Ms. Luo said she was one of seven women who had been harassed by a professor, Chen Xiaowu.\n\nMore than a decade ago, she wrote, Mr. Chen lured her off campus and tried to have sex with her, despite her pleas that he stop. He denied the allegations, but the university fired him this month, saying he had harassed several students.\n\nIn her essay, Ms. Luo urged Chinese women to \u201cstand up bravely and say \u2018No!\u2019 \u201d\n\nSome have described her story as the \u201cfirst step in the Long March\u201d against sexual harassment in China. But Ms. Luo, who now lives in the United States, said the movement would need to be \u201cmild and gentle\u201d to avoid pushback from the government.\n\n\u201cOnly in this way can the Chinese campaign against sexual harassment live on and develop,\u201d she wrote in an email.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nActivists say it will probably take decades to change public attitudes about harassment. At many companies, women are underpaid and relegated to menial roles. Men take co-workers as mistresses and openly remark on the appearance of female colleagues.\n\nFanny M. C. Cheung, a professor of psychology and vice president of the Chinese University of Hong Kong, said many women did not report harassment because Chinese culture had taught them to respect hierarchy. \u201cPeople are not encouraged to speak up against superiors,\u201d Professor Cheung said. \u201cIf you can\u2019t change public attitudes, it\u2019s very difficult to have a true endorsement of gender equality.\u201d\n\nAlready, the Chinese government appears uncomfortable with the growing number of women who are going public with charges of abuse.\n\nXu Yalu, 28, a marketing specialist, recently took to social media to recount being groped on the street in Shanghai several times. She posted photos of the man but said the police refused to take action, telling her he was too old to be arrested. Soon she was inundated with misogynistic comments and her post was deleted by censors.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not my fault that I was sexually assaulted,\u201d Ms. Xu said. \u201cWhy should I be afraid or ashamed of talking about it?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven relatively mundane calls for change have been stamped out. Censors recently deleted an online petition calling on Peking University to offer seminars on improper conduct and create committees to investigate abuse reports. And a top social media platform has intermittently blocked the use of the \u201cMeToo China\u201d hashtag.\n\nStudents have tried to elude the censors by using different phrases to denounce harassment and assault. But several activists have been warned by professors that they may be perceived as assisting \u201chostile foreign forces,\u201d according to Xiao Meili, a graduate of the Communication University of China in Beijing.\n\n\u201cSpontaneously organized movements are not appreciated,\u201d said Zheng Xi, a doctoral student at Zhejiang University who is leading a campaign to persuade city governments to post signs against harassment.\n\nSome advocates worry that the movement may face more concerted government opposition if it grows too large. In 2015, the Beijing police detained five feminists who tried to distribute leaflets warning of sexual harassment on public transit. Legal aid centers for women have been shut down.\n\nMany Chinese women who have come forward with stories of abuse have been scorned by friends, co-workers and relatives. But some say doing so gave them a feeling of liberation.\n\nFor seven months, Zhang Qiongwen, 22, lived with a secret. A dean at her university in southern China, Zhou Bin, abused her on several occasions, she says, masturbating in front of her and forcing her to kiss him. He threatened to prevent her and her classmates from graduating if she reported him, she says.\n\nMs. Zhang\u2019s friends warned her that if she reported the harassment it would ruin her reputation. Another dean, Cheng Shuijin, asked her not to go public, she recounted, saying, \u201cThe correct thing to do is to pretend nothing happened.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHaunted by the incident, Ms. Zhang began thinking of suicide. But late last year, she broke her silence, posting an essay online titled, \u201cA Must-Read for Female Students at Our School About Protecting Yourself From Predators.\u201d Then she reported Mr. Zhou to the police.\n\nIn December, the two deans, Mr. Zhou and Mr. Cheng, were fired in connection with the case. Both men declined to comment.\n\n\u201cI couldn\u2019t erase such a brutal thing from my mind,\u201d Ms. Zhang said. \u201cI didn\u2019t want my silence to enable more crimes.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Me Too,\u2019 Chinese Women Say. Not So Fast, Say the Censors.", "authors": ["Javier C. Hern\u00e1ndez", "Zoe Mou"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "In an email interview on Tuesday, Ms. Roiphe said her article did not name the woman who started the list.\n\n\u201cI am looking forward to talking about what is actually in the piece when it actually comes out,\u201d she said. \u201cI am not \u2018outing\u2019 anyone. I have to say it\u2019s a little disturbing that anyone besides Trump views Twitter as a reliable news source.\u201d\n\nBut in an article published Wednesday night on the website of New York magazine, the author of the list revealed herself to be a writer named Moira Donegan. And the concern over naming names seemed almost moot.\n\nThe article was a first-person essay under the headline \u201cI Started the Media Men List: My Name Is Moira Donegan.\u201d\n\nMs. Donegan, who wrote that she had graduated from college in 2013, began by explaining that she was the person who had first \u201ccollected a range of rumors and allegations of sexual misconduct, much of it violent, by men in magazines and publishing.\u201d\n\nShe added, \u201cThe anonymous, crowdsourced document was a first attempt at solving what has seemed like an intractable problem: how women can protect ourselves from sexual harassment and assault.\u201d\n\nAfter acknowledging that the list had its pitfalls and made many people uncomfortable, she explained that she had never expected it to gain the attention of people beyond the group of women in media who were its intended audience.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut as more and more women added their own names and descriptions of inappropriate behavior to it, the list began to circulate far and wide. It was mentioned in an article on BuzzFeed and a version was posted on Reddit.\n\n\u201cI had imagined a document that would assemble the collective, unspoken knowledge of sexual misconduct that was shared by the women in my circles: What I got instead was a much broader reckoning with abuses of power that spanned an industry,\u201d Ms. Donegan wrote.\n\nIt is likely that the Harper\u2019s article, which had yet to reach its final version on Wednesday, will be revised to reflect Ms. Donegan\u2019s revealing herself as the person who created what became an important document at a time when powerful men in the media and other fields have been called out and punished not only for instances of alleged rape and sexual assault, but also for modes of behavior that seemed acceptable in workplaces just a decade ago.\n\nHours before the publication of Ms. Donegan\u2019s story on The Cut, Ms. Roiphe said that she herself did not know the identity of the person who had started the list and added, \u201cI would never put in the creator of the list if they didn\u2019t want to be named.\u201d\n\nGiulia Melucci, a spokeswoman for Harper\u2019s, said, \u201cWe\u2019re not going to tell the steps of the editing process.\u201d Through a spokeswoman, James Marcus, the editor of Harper\u2019s, declined to comment.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAn email exchange obtained by The New York Times shows that, during the editing process, a Harper\u2019s fact checker contacted a person said to be a creator of the list and said the article identified her as someone \u201cwidely believed\u201d to be one of the people behind it.\n\nHarper\u2019s said that the fact-checking email exchange did not mean the name was ever meant to be included in the final version. \u201cFact-checking is part of reporting,\u201d Ms. Melucci said.\n\nMs. Roiphe added, \u201cI would not have mentioned it without her approval. I want to be clear on that.\u201d\n\nClaims that Ms. Roiphe\u2019s article would identify someone behind the list appeared on social media around 2:30 p.m. on Tuesday, when Dayna Tortorici, the editor of n+1 magazine, tweeted that \u201ca legacy print magazine is planning to publish a piece \u2018outing\u2019 the woman.\u201d Ms. Tortorici went on to encourage the publication, which she did not identify, not to publish names.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe risk of doxxing is high,\u201d Ms. Tortorici wrote, referring to the practice of online critics publishing people\u2019s personal, private information against their ideological opponents without their consent. \u201cIt\u2019s not the right thing to do.\u201d\n\nSoon afterward, Nicole Cliffe, the founding co-editor of the now defunct feminist blog The Toast, retweeted Ms. Tortorici\u2019s post. Ms. Cliffe added, in later Twitter posts of her own, that Ms. Roiphe was writing her article for the March issue of Harper\u2019s and implored magazine writers to pull their work from the general interest monthly as a protest. She said on Twitter that she would pay the writers the amount they were owed for their articles and help shepherd them toward other publications.\n\nBy Wednesday afternoon, Ms. Cliffe, who declined to comment for this article, had pledged to pay more than $19,000 to reporters who had pulled their stories from Harper\u2019s, according to a person with knowledge of the situation.\n\nBrianna Wu, a video game developer who is a candidate for the United States House of Representatives in Massachusetts, latched on to Ms. Cliffe\u2019s offer. \u201cCount me in for 1/2 that cost,\u201d she wrote on Twitter.\n\nMs. Wu, who said she had experienced online death and rape threats because of articles she has written on video games, said she decided to join the effort because she feared similar repercussions for the creator of the media men list. She added that if she knew the name would not appear in the article, it would \u201cconclude my interest in this.\u201d\n\nMs. Melucci, the Harper\u2019s spokeswoman, said she had no knowledge of writers pulling stories from the magazine.\n\nPart of the social media reaction to the planned Harper\u2019s article most likely has something to do with its author. Ms. Roiphe, 49, is a divisive figure among feminists who first drew public attention for her writing in 1993, when she was a graduate student at Princeton and wrote an article, published in The New York Times Magazine, with the headline \u201cDate Rape\u2019s Other Victim.\u201d In it, she argued that campus feminists had inflated the number of women who had been raped and questioned how the definition of rape was changing.\n\nThe next year, she published her first book, \u201cThe Morning After: Fear, Sex and Feminism,\u201d for which she received death threats, according to an interview with The Guardian in 2013. \u201cI get under people\u2019s skin,\u201d she said in the interview.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe has continued writing in a contrarian vein, publishing five nonfiction books, a novel and articles in Slate, Vogue and other publications.\n\nSince the first social media posts about the Harper\u2019s article appeared on Tuesday afternoon, Ms. Roiphe has undergone something of a trial by Twitter, with numerous insults hurled her way.\n\nMs. Roiphe said she was not surprised by how people were responding to her on social media. \u201cIt\u2019s a little ironic,\u201d she said, \u201cbecause I do address in the piece exactly the sort of Twitter hysteria that we are seeing here.\u201d\n\nGiven the speed of media in the age of social platforms, the subject of the article she has been working on for Harper\u2019s underwent a substantive change just hours after she spoke those words.", "title": "\u2018Media Men\u2019 List Creator Outs Herself, Fearing She Would Be Named", "authors": ["Jaclyn Peiser"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "The three form a torpid triangle for a time (Kate befriends Inez and has an affair with Bill, without knowing Inez is his daughter), propelled less by desire than by a desire for desire; for any kind of strong feeling, really.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cPorn now was a kind of heartache,\u201d Hoby writes of Bill. \u201cHe\u2019d click in a joyless trance, in the hope that some body, any body, would wake him up.\u201d Kate rouses him, but only slightly \u2014 what the characters want from each other or for themselves feels remote, not because they are inaccessible to us but because they are inaccessible to themselves.\n\nThis is a common kind of character these days \u2014 a woman, more usually than not, who doesn\u2019t know how or what to want. She is Reno, Rachel Kushner\u2019s splendidly vacant heroine from \u201cThe Flamethrowers,\u201d and Leah, from Zadie Smith\u2019s \u201cNW.\u201d She is any number of Catherine Lacey\u2019s or Alexandra Kleeman\u2019s stymied women. \u201cI don\u2019t even know what I want,\u201d the character Marnie says on the show \u201cGirls.\u201d \u201cIt\u2019s O.K. to want things,\u201d Bill reassures Kate in \u201cNeon in Daylight.\u201d This preoccupation with exploring uncertainty and ambivalence through the passive personality of a woman (and one usually surrounded by men with very defined desires and ambitions) has antecedents in the great novels of the 1970s: Renata Adler\u2019s \u201cSpeedboat,\u201d Elizabeth Hardwick\u2019s \u201cSleepless Nights,\u201d Joan Didion\u2019s \u201cPlay It as It Lays\u201d (Inez\u2019s name gestures to the Didion-like character in \u201cDemocracy\u201d); a celebrated body of American fiction full of listless women and precise prose.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd precision \u2014 of observation, of language \u2014 is Hoby\u2019s gift. Her sentences are sleek and tailored. Language molds snugly to thought.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nStory isn\u2019t her interest \u2014 or her forte. The foreshadowing can be heavy-handed, and I\u2019m agnostic about the book\u2019s climax, which cribs from Michael Cunningham\u2019s \u201cThe Hours.\u201d Her talent is for evoking mood. The title comes from one of Frank O\u2019Hara\u2019s \u201cLunch Poems\u201d (\u201cNeon in daylight is a / great pleasure\u201d), his collection of odes to New York, a great dispensary of pleasure and strangeness. Hoby shares O\u2019Hara\u2019s keen eye for the city\u2019s grubby beauty, for how, as she writes, \u201ca low-slung sun burned all the day\u2019s dirt into gold,\u201d for its hum and heat and clatter. On her first day in the city, Kate is woken from a nap by the din of a nearby restaurant reaching her third-floor apartment: \u201cThe sounds she woke to were so rude and immediate that it seemed as though all the sidewalk tables of the cafe had levitated \u2014 that the whole tableau of chairs, plates, glasses were suspended right outside this window, with freshly showered men and women dining while their feet dangled happily in the air.\u201d\n\nSummer creeps into fall. Kate grows closer to Inez and Bill even as her departure date nears. Details gradually begin to rhyme and repeat. One chapter ends with Inez holding her foot; the next opens with Bill in a similar pose. A wine stain on a tablecloth prefigures a bloody bedsheet; teenagers twirling around subway poles are echoed by strippers in a later scene. Characters flinch from contact in identical ways and, at key points, find themselves significantly shoeless.\n\nWhat to make of these consonances? We can see what these characters cannot. Their lives seem so particular, so painful and noisy to them. But under the city\u2019s \u201cmerciless\u201d skyline, in the wake of a hurricane, how similar they suddenly are, how small, how human. \u201cIn a sense we\u2019re all winning,\u201d goes another poem by O\u2019Hara, \u201cwe\u2019re alive.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Neon in Daylight\u2019 Lights Up Ambivalence With Shades of Didion and Others", "authors": ["Parul Sehgal", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "The Jaguars nearly became the first team since the 1970 N.F.L.-A.F.L. merger to lead the league in takeaways, sacks and scoring defense, finishing a close second in each category. That stinginess, coupled with a clock-consuming offense headlined by the N.F.L.\u2019s best rushing attack, powered Jacksonville (10-6) to its first playoff berth since 2007 and its first division title since 1999. The Jaguars host the Buffalo Bills on Sunday in a matchup of longtime playoff outsiders.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re built to match up with any team,\u201d safety Barry Church said. \u201cFrom Tom Brady, where they like to do quick stuff and crossing routes, to a guy like Ben Roethlisberger, who likes to develop things and let the play extend, like Russell Wilson as well. We\u2019re going to get tested in the playoffs, but we\u2019re excited for that.\u201d\n\nAs Church hinted, the Jaguars were constructed in a specific way: to counter the increasing diversity of pass-oriented offenses. Their unit is loaded at every level \u2014 elite cornerbacks, speedy linebackers and ferocious rushers.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe assembly spanned seasons. It was initiated by General Manager David Caldwell and accelerated by the first-year head of football operations Tom Coughlin, who was hired a year ago to restore the franchise he shepherded from expansion to contender back to prominence.\n\nNo matter how much young talent Jacksonville had procured, its annual spending splurges tended to promote the same reactions, and results, every year: optimism in the spring and summer but despair in the fall and winter. Investing nearly $184 million in guaranteed money from 2014 to 2016, the most in the N.F.L., according to ESPN, yielded all of 11 victories. Only Cleveland (11) won so few games during that span.\n\nAn exceptional draft in 2016, in which the Jaguars with their first three picks landed budding stars \u2014 the shutdown cornerback Jalen Ramsey, the linebacker Myles Jack and the pass-rushing dynamo Yannick Ngakoue \u2014 helped clarify their needs last off-season. Todd Wash, the defensive coordinator, said they prioritized three areas: another cornerback to play opposite Ramsey; a big defensive end capable of rushing the quarterback and setting the edge against the run; and a versatile safety to upgrade their coverage.\n\nThe missing components identified, Jacksonville went and lured them all \u2014 on the first day of free agency. Beyond the money, the cluster of young talent incentivized cornerback A. J. Bouye, defensive end Calais Campbell and Church to sign. Together they have supplemented production \u2014 Campbell\u2019s 14\u00bd sacks tied for second in the league, while Bouye (six interceptions) and Church have helped anchor the secondary \u2014 with accountability and professionalism.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cA lot of times when you get new guys, they don\u2019t want to step on anybody\u2019s toes,\u201d cornerback Aaron Colvin said. \u201cNot these guys. They just told us straight up what their goal was, why they were here, why we brought them here, the expectations that people here have for them. They\u2019ve fit in perfectly.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. He\u2019s covered Kobe. And LeBron vs. the Warriors.
