Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCoach Doug Marrone agreed, calling the newcomers essential leaders and conduits in the locker room. But early on, Marrone said, he was skeptical as to how everyone would coalesce.\n\n\u201cSometimes you look at the names on paper and you think to yourself: Maybe these guys can be pretty good,\u201d he said in an interview. \u201cBut you can do all the research in the world and not really know until you get the players in. You\u2019re talking about human nature and personalities, and it\u2019s a difficult situation because those guys got paid a lot of money. You really never know.\u201d\n\nThe mileposts have come at regular intervals: a season-opening 10-sack bonanza at Houston; a five-interception windfall against Roethlisberger in Pittsburgh in Week 5; a shutout at Indianapolis; a smothering showing against Wilson and the Seahawks, who a week earlier had stomped N.F.C.-leading Philadelphia.\n\n\u201cComing out of Pittsburgh, we were like, \u2018I think we have a chance to be pretty successful,\u2019 \u201d Wash said in an interview. \u201cWhen you play against an elite quarterback and you have success, you think you might have something.\u201d\n\nWash coaches his group to play \u201con the edge\u201d and \u201cto the echo of the whistle,\u201d much as he did in Seattle, where he tutored the Seahawks\u2019 defensive line in 2011 and 2012 before following Gus Bradley, Marrone\u2019s predecessor, to Jacksonville. These Jaguars, from their Cover 3 scheme to their brash comportment, evoke a less proven version of the Seahawks\u2019 defense that over the past few seasons has set a standard for excellence.\n\nPhoto\n\nBoth teams depended on a four-man rush instead of blitzing, excelled at forcing turnovers and valued speed and athleticism at linebacker to help neutralize pass-catching running backs and tight ends. They also had angular cornerbacks patrolling the boundaries, and every week Ramsey antagonizes, and erases, the opposition\u2019s best receiver the way Richard Sherman did in his prime.\n\nJacksonville has yielded 4.82 net passing yards per pass play (passing yards minus sack yardage divided by total pass plays), the fourth fewest since 2002, according to the sports data service Sportradar. The three teams ahead of them: the 2002 Buccaneers (won the Super Bowl), the 2008 Steelers (won the Super Bowl) and the 2009 Jets (lost in the A.F.C. championship game).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard to say that we don\u2019t potentially have the tools to be as dominant for the next couple of years as those guys,\u201d said safety Tashaun Gipson, referring to Seattle. \u201cWhen you play the Seahawks, you think defense. It\u2019s the staple of what a great defense should look like. Hopefully the comparisons will be null and void, and the Jacksonville Jaguars will be the premier defense for years to come.\u201d\n\nMarrone just wants his team, which surrendered 44 points in a Week 16 loss at San Francisco before rebounding last week at Tennessee, to play well this weekend against Buffalo.\n\nFrom Bill Parcells, Marrone said, he has learned that a team never begins the next season where it left off \u2014 it must prove itself over again. Not that he expects this season to end soon.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t ever want to be defined by this game or this season, and I know this team doesn\u2019t, either,\u201d Marrone said, adding: \u201cI have issues enjoying things. And it\u2019s something I have to work on.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Not the Old Jags\u2019: Defense Brings the Playoffs to Jacksonville", "authors": ["Ben Shpigel"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "We\u2019ve seen it before: Giant discounts on TVs or games consoles or perhaps the latest iPhone generate a frenzy among shoppers.\n\nBut in France, it seems, 70 percent off the hazelnut-and-chocolate spread Nutella can also do the trick.\n\nWhen a supermarket chain slashed the price of 33-ounce jars of the spread on Thursday, scenes grew so heated in one store in Ostricourt, in the north of France, that the police had to be called.\n\nVideos on social media showed shoppers stamping on each other and shouting as they tried to snag the jars at the discounted price of 1.41 euros, or about $1.75.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome stores resorted to restricting sales to one jar per person, with several quickly running out of stock and having to turn away customers.\n\nThe spread is a favorite in France, often used for topping croissants and baguettes. Ferrero, the product\u2019s Italian maker, even has one of its biggest factories in Normandy, in northern France.\n\nFerrero, however, in an apparent attempt to distance itself from the unsightly hysteria, said that it had nothing to do with the promotion by the supermarket chain, Intermarch\u00e9.\n\n\u201cWe regret the consequences of this operation,\u201d the Italian company said in a statement, saying the offer had \u201ccreated confusion and disappointment in consumers\u2019 minds.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Nutella Riots\u2019 in France Show Price of a Sweet Tooth", "authors": ["Palko Karasz"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "In The New York Times Book Review, Amanda Ripley reviews Ann Hulbert\u2019s \u201cOff the Charts: The Hidden Lives and Lessons of American Child Prodigies.\u201d Ripley writes:\n\n\n\nImage\n\nChild prodigies are exotic creatures, each unique and inexplicable. But they have a couple of things in common, as Ann Hulbert\u2019s meticulous new book, \u201cOff the Charts,\u201d makes clear: First, most wunderkinds eventually experience some kind of schism with a devoted and sometimes domineering parent. \u201cAfter all, no matter how richly collaborative a bond children forge with grown-up guides, some version of divorce is inevitable,\u201d Hulbert writes. \u201cIt\u2019s what modern experts would call developmentally appropriate.\u201d Second, most prodigies grow up to be thoroughly unremarkable on paper. They do not, by and large, sustain their genius into adulthood.\n\nOn this week\u2019s podcast, Hulbert discusses \u201cOff the Charts\u201d; Sam Graham-Felsen talks about his debut novel, \u201cGreen\u201d; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; and Lauren Christensen, Barry Gewen and John Williams on what people are reading. Pamela Paul is the host.\n\nHere are the books mentioned in this week\u2019s \u201cWhat We\u2019re Reading\u201d:\n\n\u201cAngel\u201d by Elizabeth Taylor\n\n\u201cFire and Fury\u201d by Michael Wolff\n\n\u201cThe Perfect Nanny\u201d by Leila Slimani\n\n\u201cBenjamin Franklin\u201d by Walter Isaacson\n\nWe would love to hear your thoughts about this episode, and about the Book Review\u2019s podcast in general. You can send them to books@nytimes.com.\n\nHow do I listen? Two ways\n\nFrom a desktop or laptop, you can listen by pressing play on the button above.\n\nOr if you\u2019re on a mobile device, the instructions below will help you find and subscribe to the series.", "title": "\u2018Off the Charts\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump called the United States courts system \u201cbroken and unfair\u201d on Wednesday, the morning after a federal judge\u2019s ruling that ordered the administration to restart a program that shields young, undocumented immigrants from deportation.\n\nRepublicans and Democrats are in the middle of a legislative battle over the program created by President Barack Obama, called the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA. Lawmakers met with President Trump on Tuesday to discuss the program\u2019s future.\n\n\u201cWe find this decision to be outrageous, especially in light of the president\u2019s successful bipartisan meeting with House and Senate members at the White House on the same day,\u201d Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, said in a statement released Wednesday morning.\n\nHours after the White House meeting, Judge William Alsup of Federal District Court in San Francisco wrote that it was not proper to kill the program, and that the administration must \u201cmaintain the DACA program on a nationwide basis\u201d as the legal challenge to the president\u2019s decision in September to end the program moves forward.\n\nMr. Trump has previously criticized the courts system after judges have halted or held up his policy initiatives.\n\nMs. Sanders said the fate of the program should be addressed by Congress.\n\n\u201cPresident Trump is committed to the rule of law, and will work with members of both parties to reach a permanent solution that corrects the unconstitutional actions taken by the last administration,\u201d Ms. Sanders said.", "title": "\u2018Outrageous,\u2019 White House Says of DACA Ruling, as Trump Calls Court System \u2018Broken\u2019", "authors": ["Eileen Sullivan"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nIt was a cool afternoon in July 1973 when my girlfriend, Molly, and I settled down on a wooden bench at the Bronx Zoo.\n\nShe was an Off Broadway actress. I had recently graduated from college and had a job offer in Colorado. I had a ticket in my pocket for a flight out of La Guardia later that day that would drop me off in Denver before midnight.\n\nWe wondered what the future held for us.\n\nWe had argued over favorite snacks: popcorn (hers) or cotton candy (mine). We ended up negotiating a Cracker Jack compromise. But it was our last day together, and Molly and I had left many things unsaid.\n\nBehind a fence no more than 15 yards away, an orangutan had plopped himself down on the grass. Like a wise ascetic, he was scrutinizing us, two skinny creatures holding hands.\n\n\u201cLook at him,\u201d Molly said. \u201cHe\u2019s thinking about something.\u201d\n\nHis orange fur glistened around his pleasing plump physique. His bearded chin rested on his left fist.\n\n\u201cPenny for your thoughts,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m going to miss you,\u201d I said.\n\nMolly laughed.\n\n\u201cNot you, silly,\u201d she said. \u201cHim!\u201d", "title": "\u2018Penny for Your Thoughts\u2019", "authors": ["Eric Sandstrom", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cBut we didn\u2019t see it in the contract,\u201d he added. \u201cWe have the contract and it is without this language.\u201d\n\nHowever, he said, the opera house was instructed by Tams-Witmark to add a sentence to all printed materials stating that the production is taking place without authorization and \u201cis contrary to the requirements for the presentation of the work.\u201d Tams-Witmark confirmed this instruction but did not reply to requests for further information. This statement now appears on advertisements for the opera throughout the city.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Okovacs said that the point of this production is to take the opera \u201cout of context, so it can\u2019t relate to any specific place.\u201d Although the setting is said to be an airport, it is reminiscent of real-life scenes in a Budapest train station in 2015, where migrants and refugees camped for weeks before most of them proceeded to other countries. Hungary\u2019s prime minister, Viktor Orban, and the right-wing government he leads, have been on the offensive since then over the European Union\u2019s migration policies, which require member states to resettle a quota of refugees. Last week, at a meeting in Budapest of the Visegrad Group, an alliance of central European nations, Mr. Orban said, \u201cWe do not wish to become a destination country for migrants.\u201d\n\nThe media here has offered widespread support to Mr. Okovacs for bringing back a popular production after decades. Origo, a government-friendly news website, published an article with the headline \u201cOnly blacks used to be able to perform this opera because of racist restrictions.\u201d And the online theater magazine szinhaz.hu welcomed what it referred to as the Hungarian State Opera\u2019s \u201cbreaking the ice\u201d by staging the opera with \u201cits excellent Hungarian singers.\u201d\n\nMany conservative columnists, including in the daily Magyar Nemzet, have denounced the \u201cpolitical correctness\u201d of performing the opera only with a black cast. \u201cPolitical correctness is slowly devouring aesthetics,\u201d one columnist said.\n\nThe director of the production, Andras Almasi-Toth, told szinhaz.huthat \u201cwhile performance and staging solutions have progressed \u2014 we play, sing and stage Puccini differently from 50 years ago \u2014 this opera was left out, which makes for a very sterile production. It can only take place on Catfish Row in the 1930s, which gives it a fairy-tale like quality, devoid of its real-life aspects.\u201d\n\nIn a telephone interview, Dr. Ronald Crutcher, an African-American music scholar and president of the University of Richmond, said that he thought the idea of transplanting \u201cPorgy and Bess\u201d to somewhere other than Catfish Row was \u201cfascinating\u201d but added that \u201cthe whole notion of recasting the story as an immigrant struggle is hard to imagine. It\u2019s an iconic piece that was written at a critically important time, particularly in America,\u201d he continued.\n\nBut awareness of this is limited here in Hungary. Adam Kertesz, 69, an academic who was in the audience for Saturday\u2019s premiere, said he was unfamiliar with the opera\u2019s historical context. \u201cI didn\u2019t know about all that,\u201d Mr. Kertesz said. \u201cI just love the music. I saw the 1983 production of \u2018Porgy\u2019 here. The singers blackened their faces, but I didn\u2019t know what that meant in the U.S. The music is what I remember.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Porgy and Bess\u2019 With a White Cast Stirs Controversy", "authors": ["Alexandra Ivanoff"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "There\u2019s nothing legally wrong going on here, though. Screen Gems, the Sony imprint that produced and released the movie, paid for use of the song, whose rights don\u2019t belong to Mr. Fogerty. But the incompetence really is something. Or maybe it\u2019s the obviousness. Maybe it\u2019s the inevitability. The whole movie seems to exist just for this sequence. Even if I\u2019d paid just to see Ms. Henson mow down gangs of goons (and I probably did pay only for that), I didn\u2019t get my money\u2019s worth. It\u2019s like I bought a can that said \u201cpeaches,\u201d got peaches in the can, but the can was rusty, so the peaches were, too.\n\nMovies and television have a way of using a soundtrack not just to create a mood but to literalize it. You could always count on a master class in splitting the difference between artistry and obviousness during the so-called Blaxploitation era (which \u201cProud Mary\u201d practically pulls a muscle reaching back to evoke). \u201cShaft\u201d and \u201cSuperfly,\u201d on the one hand. On the other, \u201cCoffy is the color of your skin/Coffy is the world you live in.\u201d\n\nFor its part, in a statement to Entertainment Weekly, Screen Gems made Mr. Fogerty an entreaty: Come see the movie! \u201cHe would see\u201d the statement reads, \u201cthat his complaint that the film has nothing to do with the song\u2019s message as \u2018a metaphor about leaving painful, stressful things behind for a more tranquil and meaningful life\u2019 is inaccurate. That is precisely what our Mary is looking to do, and Taraji nails it perfectly.\u201d\n\nThey\u2019re not wrong. But come on. Mary winds up taking her self-inflicted babysitting assignment so seriously (I won\u2019t spoil the details) that she actually has no choice but to leave the stress behind.\n\nNow, I know what somebody involved with this movie was thinking. The screenplay seems as if it\u2019s been kicking around for who knows how long (Pam Grier could have done this in 1973, title and all), and maybe it used to be called something else. But it\u2019s \u201cProud Mary\u201d now, and Mary is a black woman \u2014 and when was the last time a black woman, who isn\u2019t Halle Berry, carried any movie by herself, let alone one in which she keeps an arsenal hidden in her walk-in closet, not far from her wigs, one that lets her do the old shoot-and-slide along a warehouse floor? This really is a kind of momentous occasion, and for that you need a momentous song, and \u201cProud Mary\u201d more than satisfies the occasion. Every time I hear Ms. Turner spit out the word \u201cleft\u201d or sing \u201cburnin\u2019\u201d or \u201call right!,\u201d I want to fight to ensure voting rights. I want to karate chop something.\n\nSo it all makes a kind of sense, right? Let\u2019s honor the occasion with a song worthy of it. The occasion might warrant this song. The movie is a different story. Leaning on the Ike and Tina version might bring it into better, blacker alignment with the star, but it addresses neither the central incongruity (Why use this song for a massacre? Why use it for a massacre this badly orchestrated?) nor the artistic injustice of Mr. Fogerty\u2019s complaint. There are bullet holes in walls, tire treads on mobsters, and now bullet holes and tire treads all over his song.", "title": "\u2018Proud Mary\u2019 Has a \u2018Proud Mary\u2019 Problem", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Of course, such decisions are kept secret. Israel neither confirms nor denies the existence of the targeted assassination program that Bergman so assiduously documents. The book\u2019s title comes from the Talmud: \u201cIf someone comes to kill you, rise up and kill him first.\u201d This is assassination defined as self-defense. But as Bergman shows, motives aren\u2019t always so righteous and clear-cut; revenge, wrath and other impulses have ways of sneaking in. Before the establishment of Israel in 1948, Zionist underground movements employed what they called \u201cpersonal terror\u201d \u2014 a campaign of bombings and killings \u2014 against the British, who controlled Palestine and restricted immigration by Jews trying to flee Europe.\n\n\u201cWe were too busy and hungry to think about the British and their families,\u201d one assassin told Bergman, recounting how he shot a British officer on a Jerusalem street in 1944. \u201cI didn\u2019t feel anything, not even a little twinge of guilt. We believed the more coffins that reached London, the closer the day of freedom would be.\u201d\n\nImage Ronen Bergman Credit Dana Kopel\n\nMany men who fought in the Zionist underground later became establishment figures in Israel, including Yitzhak Shamir and Menachem Begin; they imported guerrilla methods into the security apparatus they helped create. Assassinations offered a tactical method for a tiny country with rudimentary defenses. The Holocaust, Bergman writes, reinforced the sense that the country and its people would be \u201cperpetually in danger of annihilation.\u201d\n\nMeir Dagan, the spymaster who led the Mossad from 2002 to 2011, kept a photograph in his office of a bearded man in a prayer shawl, kneeling in front of German troops. Whenever Mossad operatives were about to carry out a particularly sensitive mission, he would invite them to his office and explain that the man pictured was his grandfather, shortly before the Nazis murdered him. \u201cMost of the Jews in the Holocaust died without fighting,\u201d Dagan told Bergman. \u201cWe must never reach that situation again, kneeling, without the ability to fight for our lives.\u201d\n\nA number of Bergman\u2019s sources express a version of this sentiment. So pronounced is this line of thinking that others have gone so far as to propose that cowardice kept the Jews from revolting \u2014 a statement Primo Levi found \u201cabsurd and insulting.\u201d Still, Levi recognized that this premise provided a sense of agency and a way out of despair. What it also did, and what Bergman is especially attuned to, is mark the country\u2019s political life from the beginning in terms of existential threats. The hostile regimes surrounding Israel have continually stoked such fears; just hours after Israel declared independence in 1948, seven armies from neighboring countries attacked, and opportunistic despots have encouraged terrorism against Israel and its citizens ever since. Extreme measures seem less extreme when it\u2019s a matter of survival.", "title": "\u2018Rise and Kill First\u2019 Shines Light on Israel\u2019s Hidden Assassinations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Season 3, Episode 1\n\nHello, hello, hello! \u201cRuPaul\u2019s Drag Race All Stars\u201d returned for its third season last night \u2014 thank God, or thank RuPaul, however you worship. Eliminated, brought back, and eliminated once more in Season 7, Trixie fared better off the show, with a country album and a Viceland show \u2014 \u201cThe Trixie & Katya Show,\u201d with beloved Season 7 star Katya.\n\nNext: Milk, a fashionista club kid and a real looker \u2014 \u201cHey kids, Zaddy\u2019s home,\u201d she proclaimed \u2014 whose unconventional runway looks drew mixed reactions in Season 6; the \u201cBayou Queen\u201d Chi Chi DeVayne, who, in her own words, \u201cwasn\u2019t polished enough\u201d in Season 8; and Thorgy Thor, a self-described \u201cfashion clown\u201d still smarting from Bob the Drag Queen\u2019s win in Season 8.\n\nMorgan McMichaels, a bruiser from Season 2, sashayed in. \u201cYou can\u2019t kill evil that easy,\u201d she said. Well, what\u2019s the problem? You got the gist, so shut up. Even the stuff that\u2019s not true, it\u2019s true.\u201d\n\nMr. Murray showed up next as Stephen K. Bannon, the onetime chief strategist to Mr. Trump who was completely cast aside after he was quoted in Mr. Wolff\u2019s book disparaging the president\u2019s children. While Mr. Murray\u2019s delivery was uneven, he did get off a few laugh lines, including telling the MSNBC hosts that he was working on developing a skin care product (\u201cBlotch\u201d) and a line of wrinkled barn jackets called \u201cfrumpers for guys.\u201d\n\n\u201cI convinced this country to elect Donald and I can do it again,\u201d Mr. Murray said. \u201cAlready auditioning candidates, got some prospects. Logan Paul. Martin Shkreli. The Subway guy, Jared Fogle, he\u2019s back. He\u2019s electable. It\u2019s time for America to slide down the Bannon-ster.\u201d\n\nRounding out the impersonations, Leslie Jones appeared as Oprah Winfrey, fresh off her Golden Globes speech that set off days of speculation that she might run for president in 2020. When asked if she was running, Ms. Jones said, \u201cWell, I am a celebrity, so I am qualified.\u201d\n\n\u2018Weekend Update\u2019 Takes On Trump\u2019s Vulgarities\n\nColin Jost and Michael Che targeted the furor surrounding Mr. Trump\u2019s disparaging words this week about Haiti and certain countries in Africa. The hosts responded with a mix of detached bemusement and resignation.\n\nMr. Che said:\n\n\u201cCan I be honest? When someone asked me, \u2018Did you hear what Donald Trump called Haiti and Africa?\u2019 I was like, \u2018Oh, boy. Did it start with an \u2018N\u2019?\u2019 But then I heard what he said, and I was like, \u2018That\u2019s it? I\u2019ve said that about countries for not having a CVS.\u2019 Here\u2019s the thing. My job is to make jokes about the news. But Trump saying something racist isn\u2019t exactly news anymore. It\u2019d be news if Trump said, \u2018You know what we need more of in this country? Haitians.\u2019 And by the way, he\u2019s not the only one here that thinks like that. I\u2019ve lived in this country my entire life and I\u2019ve been asked to go back to Africa several times and it\u2019s never been because they thought I\u2019d enjoy it there. But Donald, you do realize how rich these places are in resources, right? I mean, they\u2019re in bad shape because they\u2019ve been robbed and exploited for centuries by Western powers. So the president of the United States calling Africa a shithole is like telling the kid you molested, \u2018Boy, did you grow up to be weird.\u2019\u201d\n\nMr. Jost followed up and said: \u201cIt was reported that just before the election last year, President Trump\u2019s personal lawyer arranged a six-figure payment to cover up an alleged affair between Trump and porn star Stormy Daniels. So at least there\u2019s one storm Trump will pay for,\u201d while a graphic of Puerto Rico flashed behind Mr. Jost.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe went on: \u201cLet me just say what a thrill it is to be alive at a time where \u2018Porn Star Blackmails President\u2019 is like the fourth-biggest story of the week. At this rate, in a year from now, we\u2019re going to see the headline \u2018Trump Found With Dead Hooker\u2019 right next to the crossword puzzle.\u201d\n\nFollowing the theme of Trump-related fatigue, Mr. Che added a joke later about Ms. Winfrey, saying \u201cMany in the public are calling for a run at the presidency in 2020. Oh, can\u2019t we just have a regular one for a while? Just a regular boring, old white dude president that smiles and shape-shifts into a lizard at night. I\u2019m tired of all these fun ideas for president. I miss boring politics.\u201d\n\nWith all the chatter about Ms. Winfrey this week, there was no way that \u201cS.N.L.\u201d was going to let Ms. Jones only play her briefly in the cold open. She returned during \u201cWeekend Update,\u201d alongside Chris Redd, who played Ms. Winfrey\u2019s longtime partner, Stedman Graham.\n\nMr. Redd ended up being the best part of the bit, as he alternated between telling the audience that Ms. Winfrey was and was not running, based on the ambiguous statements Ms. Jones was making. And when asked what his role would be in the White House if Ms. Winfrey won, Mr. Redd said, with a surprised look, \u201cNo one\u2019s ever asked me a question before!\u201d\n\nMs. Jones did have two big laugh lines of her own. Referring to winning the vote of white women, Ms. Jones said: \u201cSomebody needs to look these women in the eye and say, \u2018You deserve my three favorite things: love, respect and a new panini maker. You get a panini! You get a panini! You get a panini!\u201d\n\nAnd when asked if anyone could beat her in the race, Ms. Jones did not miss a beat: \u201cYes. There\u2019s one thing in my life that\u2019s been able to beat me. Bread!\u201d\n\nThe Delightful Weirdness of Sam Rockwell\n\nSam Rockwell, this week\u2019s host, has spent his entire career taking quirky roles. In the opening monologue, the show tackled the fact that he seldom plays leading roles in major movies.\n\nIt featured Mr. Rockwell, less than a week after winning best actor at the Golden Globes for his role in \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri,\u201d making use of the whole set at Rockefeller Center as he found himself in various (clich\u00e9d) leading man situations \u2014 all while Elvis Presley\u2019s \u201cA Little Less Conversation\u201d played in the background.\n\nMr. Rockwell\u2019s oddball brand was an ideal fit for \u201cS.N.L.,\u201d even though a fine might be coming the show\u2019s way. During his first sketch, in which he played a frustrated PBS host on a faux 1990s children\u2019s show called \u201cThe Science Room With Mr. Science,\u201d Mr. Rockwell tried in vain to patiently explain basic science to barely interested children. In his frustration, Mr. Rockwell let slip an expletive that was not caught by censors \u2014 at least on the East Coast. Certainly, he is not the first to do this in \u201cS.N.L.\u201d history. Hello, Kristen Stewart and Jenny Slate!\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Rockwell\u2019s portrayal of Stanley Tucci \u2014 another talented actor often relegated to sidekick roles \u2014 in the digital short \u201cTucci Gang\u201d was absurd and yet exactly what one would want Mr. Rockwell to do in this setting. And any sketch that celebrates Stanley Tucci is well received around these parts.", "title": "\u2018Saturday Night Live,\u2019 With Help From Old Friends, Skewers \u2018Morning Joe\u2019", "authors": ["Sopan Deb"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI have pity for the child, but the family had no choice,\u201d wrote one user. \u201cUnfortunately, the country has no way of rescuing these children, and they\u2019ll only be exploited.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nChildren with illnesses are often seen as undesirable and costly in China, driving many families to abort or abandon them. Abandoning a minor is a crime in China punishable by up to five years in prison, and courts have argued that if a child dies after being left in dangerous conditions, it is equivalent to murder.\n\n\u201cParents are often nice people who feel hopeless raising these children themselves and believe they will have a better life with a better family,\u201d said Qiu Lili, founder of Beijing Angel Mom Charity Foundation, which helps care for abandoned children.\n\nA health care system marked by high co-payments and deductibles, as well as inconsistent coverage, means that paying for treatments can be devastating for low-income families. Adding to the problem, many families lack insurance coverage for infants, advocates say.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Hern\u00e1ndez", "Iris Zhao"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Looking back on nearly three decades in the tech sector, Peggy Johnson recalled how she and other women used to steer clear of leering colleagues by taking the long way to their desks, and how they felt pressured to laugh at inappropriate jokes in the office.\n\nBut during a panel discussion on sexual harassment and the role of gender in workplace power, held on Tuesday at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Ms. Johnson, an executive vice president at Microsoft, recounted with emotion how her daughter, who recently entered the tech industry, has a different attitude.\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s not laughing,\u201d Ms. Johnson said.\n\nThe panel, created in partnership with The New York Times, took place at a global gathering known more for its extravagant parties and elite guest list than its discussions of gender dynamics. But powerful men have tumbled from their perches in droves since sexual misconduct allegations against the movie mogul Harvey Weinstein were published in the fall.\n\nElisabeth Bumiller, the Washington bureau chief for The Times, moderated the wide-ranging discussion. Panelists spoke about millennials demanding transparency and accountability from future employers, about social media amplifying and empowering whisper networks and about the need for organizations of all sizes and types to elevate more women into leadership roles.", "title": "\u2018She\u2019s Not Laughing\u2019: In Davos, Taking on Sexual Harassment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "[READ: Questions and Answers About This Year\u2019s Flu Season]\n\nHospitalization and death rates, though climbing, are still lower than was expected, Dr. Jernigan added, even though most of this season\u2019s cases are H3N2, which is typically the most deadly seasonal strain.\n\nAlthough 20 children and teenagers have already died of flu or its consequences, the 2014-2015 season \u2014 the one this season most closely resembles \u2014 killed 148. (This year\u2019s final death toll will not be known until summer, because the deaths from lingering pneumonia may occur as late as June.)\n\nThe C.D.C. data comes from hospitals and clinics that report how many cases of \u201cinfluenza-like illness\u201d they treat. Delays can result if clinic statisticians are busy or if state health departments do not pass on the figures quickly.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nKinsa, by contrast, is able almost instantly to spot fever spikes in states \u2014 or even in cities and neighborhoods. More than 500,000 households now own its smartphone-connected oral and ear thermometers, Mr. Singh said, and the company gets about 25,000 readings each day.\n\n(Of course, the company cannot measure hospitalizations, deaths, or which strains of flu are circulating, or consistently distinguish flu from other febrile illnesses.)\n\nKinsa\u2019s technology was approved by the Food and Drug Administration in 2014 and gathered data in subsequent flu seasons; the company hopes to soon publish a study by outside experts assessing its accuracy in measuring the seasonal spread.\n\nThose experts, Mr. Singh said, found the data to be more accurate than Google\u2019s Flu Trends, which Google shut down three years ago after it missed the peak of the 2013-2014 season.\n\nGoogle tracked internet searches for terms like \u201cflu,\u201d \u201cfever\u201d and so on, but could be misled by, for example, searches triggered by news coverage.\n\nKinsa\u2019s smartphone app uses a bubble game to entice children to take their temperatures. If fever is detected, it asks parents about other symptoms and then offers basic medical advice or urges the user to see a doctor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe makers of cold medications, disinfectants, toothbrushes and even orange juice buy advertising on the app, Mr. Singh said.", "title": "\u2018Smart Thermometers\u2019 Track Flu Season in Real Time", "authors": ["Donald G. Mcneil Jr.", "Global Health"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "And is Culber really dead? I don\u2019t know, and I\u2019m not sure we got to know him well enough to care. If Tyler really is a spy, murdering Culber would make sense, as would how he went about it. Wilson Cruz did a nice job portraying Culber in limited screen time, particularly when paired with Anthony Rapp as Stamets.\n\nWhat Worked\n\n1. Mean Captain Tilly\n\nTilly\u2019s transformation into an angry captain in the mirror universe was impressive. She has primarily existed as a foil to Burnham\u2019s dreariness throughout the season, and outside of that, we\u2019ve really seen her be only meek, nerdy and nervous. The mirror-universe arc should allow Mary Wiseman to display more of her acting range.\n\n2. The Original Number One\n\nThe last time Jonathan Frakes sat in the director\u2019s chair for something connected to Trek was two decades ago: the 1998 film \u201cStar Trek: Insurrection,\u201d which was, uh, not good. But that came two years after the brilliant \u201cStar Trek: First Contact,\u201d which Frakes also directed. He also directed several episodes of \u201cVoyager,\u201d \u201cDeep Space Nine\u201d and of course, \u201cThe Next Generation.\u201d\n\nHe did great work in this episode, particularly in the opening scene, during which he effectively ratcheted up the tension as the Discovery crew quickly realized that things were amiss, even beyond the normal scope of time and space. His use of the cameras, which constantly circled the conversations, helped move the story along. In fact, the cameras were rarely stationary, which made the episode even more visually interesting.\n\nI still haven\u2019t forgiven Frakes for this, though:\n\nWhat Didn\u2019t Work\n\n1. Lorca\u2019s Insistence on Protocol\n\nFor some baffling reason, Lorca insists that Culber cannot care for Stamets because Culber\u2019s \u201cmedical objectivity\u201d is compromised. \u201cOh, suddenly you care about protocol?\u201d Culber replies, speaking for all of us. I want to like Lorca. I really do. Jason Isaacs is giving a very compelling performance. But the writers seem to be turning him into a fundamentally different person from who he was earlier in the season. Some might call this character development. Others might say there are more shoes to drop.\n\nI don\u2019t know. But I shared Culber\u2019s incredulity after he reminded Lorca of all the times he\u2019d broken protocol at Lorca\u2019s insistence. Lorca\u2019s response suggests that he doesn\u2019t want to make those mistakes again. But is there another, more qualified doctor on the ship whom we don\u2019t know about?\n\n2. Lorca\u2019s Insistence on Protocol (Part Deux)\n\nLorca seems to have caught on to the romance between Burnham and Tyler. He walks over to Burnham\u2019s station and tells her she can breathe easy because Tyler is safe after a mission.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI need to know that I can rely on my crew to act professionally at all times, particularly now,\u201d Lorca says. \u201cWe\u2019re in dangerous waters.\u201d\n\nThis made me snort. It comes a few episodes after Lorca slept with a superior officer, who repeatedly assailed him for not being professional. Also, perhaps a captain who demands professionalism wouldn\u2019t insist on a mutineer\u2019s becoming a crew member on his ship or on having a phaser within arms reach when he sleeps at night.\n\nAgain, this could all be part of Lorca\u2019s newfound betterment as a captain. If it is, it\u2019s seemed rushed to me.\n\nDid You Catch That?!\n\nHonestly, the entire episode was essentially a callback. So in lieu of the usual Easter egg section, here are a few of the Trek elements that were alluded to most blatantly this week:\n\n1. The agonizer from \u201cMirror, Mirror\u201d:\n\n2. The mirror universe in \u201cEnterprise\u201d\n\n3. The U.S.S. Defiant", "title": "\u2018Star Trek: Discovery\u2019 Season 1, Episode 10: Mirrors!", "authors": ["Sopan Deb", "Star Trek"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSeason 1, Episode 11, \u2018The Wolf Inside\u201d\n\nThe theme of this week\u2019s \u201cDiscovery\u201d episode \u2014 \u201cThe Wolf Inside\u201d: secrets. Burnham doesn\u2019t want to tell Saru that Kelpiens in the mirror universe are slaves. Saru doesn\u2019t want to tell Burnham about Culber\u2019s death. Both do so to protect the other from uncomfortable truths, which brings us to the most uncomfortable truth: Ash Tyler, her first love, is actually a surgically altered Klingon spy \u2014 and our old friend, the villainous Voq. By the end of this episode, he\u2019s finally remembered.\n\nOf course, \u201cDiscovery\u201d had telegraphed this for weeks. It was so obvious that I suggested in last week\u2019s recap that it was too obvious. Even in this episode, in the pre-credit scenes (14 minutes!), while Burnham lies in Tyler\u2019s arms, she says, \u201cWe\u2019re all human here,\u201d before adding, \u201cMaybe none of us, no matter what world we\u2019re from really know what darkness is waiting inside.\u201d Sonequa Martin-Green might as well have said, \u201cI am going to foreshadow right here.\u201d\n\nThis leads me to wonder exactly why the \u201cDiscovery\u201d writing staff even went through the motions of trying to turn this into some sort of plot twist. And if anything, now, there are more questions than answers. If Tyler was truly a Klingon spy this whole time, it once again calls into question Lorca\u2019s decision making. He said he screened Tyler personally. How? And what was the point of Voq having his memories wiped so he wouldn\u2019t remember he was a Klingon until later? Because the memory wipe is what eventually blew Voq\u2019s cover \u2014 as they come rushing back, it spurs Tyler-Voq to attack Mirror Voq.\n\nLike with so much of the \u201cDiscovery\u201d maiden voyage, the ambition and ideas are interesting, but the execution often leaves much to be desired. The pacing is closer to the lesser seasons of \u201c24.\u201d Right when an interesting character or relationship is about to be developed, the story line abruptly ends or shifts, often without a payoff that is worth it. This episode is a concrete example of this: The Voq revelation was just not that interesting, mainly because we didn\u2019t get to know Voq well enough.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat worked\n\nThe opening scene\n\n1. The director T.J. Scott does masterful work in the opening moments, when Stamets\u2019s body is found holding Culber\u2019s body. It is derivative to the scene in \u201cFirst Contact,\u201d when the Borg first beam over to the Enterprise. Long, dark and empty hallways are a tried and tested way to get audiences to the edge of their seats.", "title": "\u2018Star Trek: Discovery\u2019 Season 1, Episode 11: Secrets Abound", "authors": ["Sopan Deb", "Star Trek"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "This episode \u2014 and much of the first season of \u201cDiscovery\u201d \u2014 reminds me of another \u201cStar Trek\u201d product: \u201cStar Trek: Nemesis,\u201d the last of \u201cThe Next Generation\u201d movies. It was not well-received by fans or critics \u2014 even though the special effects and action scenes were top notch. \u201cNemesis\u201d was a good action movie. \u201cDiscovery\u201d has great action. But in both, the characters make such astoundingly odd decisions that it makes it difficult to get invested in the action. The plots exist simply as transportation vehicles.\n\nAnd the ending of the episode \u2014 that the Discovery crew has time traveled within their normal universe \u2014 is another big twist, though it was hard to care much about it, at least for now. Too many plot twists come and go in this show without satisfying resolutions; the characters don\u2019t even seem that interested in shocking news anymore. (When Saru finds out that Lorca isn\u2019t, you know, Lorca, he reacts as if he\u2019s told that the mess hall is out of pudding.)\n\n\u201cDiscovery\u201d is a bottom-line show: It\u2019s more concerned with plot ends than with the narrative means. This leaves viewers with the sort of basic questions that shows answer organically, when they don\u2019t opt for cheap plot twists over careful story development.\n\nWhat Worked\n\n1. The fight scenes\n\nThis week, let\u2019s raise our glasses to Glen Keenan, the show\u2019s cinematographer. Georgiou\u2019s containment field was eye-popping and the choreography in the superb fight scenes were unlike anything we\u2019ve seen in Trek. Whatever the other flaws, Mr. Keenan\u2019s work is a bright spot.\n\n2. Rekha Sharma\n\nIt was wonderful to see Ms. Sharma back in action. Like many characters this season, Landry was killed off far too early, wasting an interesting character in the process. (Along with Georgiou, Culber, T\u2019Kuvma, and others.)\n\nWhat Didn\u2019t Work\n\nWhere to begin?\n\nThe \u201cStar Wars\u201d rip-off\n\nThis one is slight \u2014 but it was enough to get me to shake my fist at the television. When Mirror Lorca says to Mirror Stamets, \u201cYour lack of vision continues to disappoint me,\u201d it was way too close to Darth Vader\u2019s \u201cI find your lack of faith disturbing,\u201d in \u201cStar Wars: A New Hope.\u201d It is one of the most famous lines in cinematic history. You can\u2019t pull off a line like that unless it\u2019s a direct homage. And Lorca is no Darth Vader.\n\nSo many \u201cWait, what?\u201d moments\n\nMore important, there were way too moments during the episode where I was baffled \u2014 either by character actions or exposition in the plot. An incomplete and not-so-short list:\n\n\u2022 Early on, Lorca frees his followers from a room of Agonizers. Why were they alive to begin with? In previous episodes, even allies are killed with impunity in the Terran Empire. Enemies are shown being beamed into space. There is no real incentive for Evil Georgiou to not execute a group trying to pull of a coup.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 An ion storm pushed Mirror Lorca out of his own universe? This is a classic Trek plot device. \u201cWe need a way to get from Point A to Point B. Get me an ion storm.\u201d [Update: Multiple readers have pointed out that an ion storm is how the original Enterprise crew, led by Kirk, ended up in the mirror universe. They are correct, so I\u2019ll offer a mea culpa on this one. I forgot. I will, however, stand by an ion storm being a classic Trek plot device!]\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2022 If you understood how Stamets recovered fully and is able to operate the spore drive with no issues, you are a more attentive viewer than me. Same if you can understand why the spore drive is no longer instantaneous, which is the entire point of the thing, or why the Terran\u2019s bad faith use of the mycelium network would effect other universes.\n\n\u2022 Why does Georgiou want Lorca to be brought to her alive? She thought he was dead this whole time until Burnham brought him back. Why is it important to her that she gets to kill him?\n\n\u2022 Boy, Burnham is sure able to walk around empty areas of Georgiou\u2019s ship for long periods of time exactly when she needs to, even though many people are trying to find her.\n\n\u2022 So Burnham\u2019s plan, when she and Georgiou get to the throne room, was to kick the guards? And why didn\u2019t Lorca just immediately shoot a defenseless Georgiou?\n\n\u2022 Uh, does anyone know what happened to Franken-TylerVoq-enstein?\n\n\u2022 Why does Georgiou assume she\u2019s a fallen emperor? She put down Lorca\u2019s coup (again). Why can\u2019t she eliminate his supporters, since they have no one to follow?\n\nComing up\n\nWhile I\u2019m not very invested in the time travel plot that\u2019s coming up, I am slightly intrigued. Saru is captain now? More Doug Jones? Yes, please. I\u2019m curious about how the writers will approach a world where the Federation has hit a worst-case scenario \u2014 having lost a war. (This has happened before, if rarely: Things looked bleak in \u201cDeep Space Nine\u201d during the Dominion War. In \u201cFirst Contact,\u201d the Borg actually did assimilate all of Earth.)", "title": "\u2018Star Trek: Discovery\u2019 Season 1, Episode 13: Another Death, Another Twist, Another Shrug", "authors": ["Sopan Deb", "Star Trek"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "What Worked\n\n1. Stamets and Culber saying goodbye\n\nWe never got to know this relationship very well \u2014 and that\u2019s too bad. Anthony Rapp and Wilson Cruz have excellent chemistry. Culber is one of the few characters able to get Stamets to stop being so grumpy. The relationship allowed Rapp to explore Stamets\u2019s depth instead of his grouchiness.\n\nI was confused as to how Culber reappeared in order to say good bye. It had something to do with the mycelial network \u2014 but this is one of those Trek moments when the means mattered very little compared to the end. It was very sweet to see brief glimpses of Stamets and Culber as they shared happy recollections about their relationship, especially on a show so filled with anger and bitterness.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n2. Burnham and Georgiou\n\nSonequa Martin-Green is brilliant as Burnham in the scene when Mirror Georgiou tells Burnham, \u201cEverything will be the way it was.\u201d It\u2019s clear that Burnham actually wishes this were the case. Of course, Georgiou means back in the original universe, before the mutiny, back when she was actually a mentor to Burnham. Martin-Green doesn\u2019t say a word \u2014 Burnham can\u2019t reveal her true self at this point \u2014 but her face paints a vivid picture of her internal monologue.\n\nWhat Didn\u2019t Work\n\n1. Why is Saru trying so hard to save Tyler?\n\nDoug Jones is putting in yeoman\u2019s work as Saru, showing genuine concern for The Klingon Formerly Known as Tyler. And yet, I don\u2019t understand why the crew is working overtime to try to save Voq. He is a Klingon spy! He was never actually a human. Saru seems to be trying to save the human side of Voq \u2014 but there never was a human side! He was surgically altered to look like this.\n\nWhich brings up something else: I am further confused over why Voq went so far out of his way to repress his own memories of being a Klingon. Shouldn\u2019t an effective spy know that he\u2019s a spy?\n\n2. The darkness\n\nWe know \u201cDiscovery\u201d is dark. It\u2019s the darkest of all the Treks. It\u2019s also wildly unpredictable. But is anyone having fun watching it? In this episode alone, we see Kelpiens who are either enslaved or eaten. We see a random human\u2019s body explode for a crime we know little about. Mirror Georgiou unexpectedly (and seemingly without justification) kills several people using a device that would be more at home in an \u201cX-Men\u201d movie.\n\nIt would be one thing if this episode were an outlier. But this is the general makeup of the show. (Recently, we saw Culber \u2014 a key character \u2014 have his neck snapped out of nowhere.)\n\nThe crew members seem merely to tolerate one another (Culber and Stamets notwithstanding). No one is having fun. This means the audience doesn\u2019t have fun. The crew of the Discovery doesn\u2019t seem like the type that wants to sacrifice for one another. Why should they? There is very little affection between the characters we see most.", "title": "\u2018Star Trek: Discovery\u2019 Season 1, Episode 12: Man in the Mirror", "authors": ["Sopan Deb", "Star Trek"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "But it also grants her access to files that could help the doctor connect the recent murder to the unsolved abduction and killing of a pair of brother-sister twins several years earlier, which she hands over to Moore on condition that she be kept in the loop of their investigation.\n\nSara\u2019s dialogue is overly mannered at times. But as the cast\u2019s most recognizable face, Fanning brings a steely intensity to the role when confronting her skeptical male colleagues. She becomes a much cooler customer when, at the end of the day, she sheds her painfully confining corset and lights up cigarette while considering the case. It\u2019s a combination of traits \u201cThe Wire\u201d has trained us to recognize as \u201cgood police,\u201d even if no one in Commissioner Roosevelt\u2019s department is prepared or willing to see it. With any luck, a canny cop-show casting director will recognize it in Fanning.\n\nPlaying the title character presents Br\u00fchl with a tougher task. Dr. Kreizler spends his non-sleuthing hours dealing with the living, not the dead; his work with troubled and vulnerable patients \u2014 children in particular \u2014 requires sensitivity, gentleness and genuine care. As such, aloofness, arrogance and the other traits that typically define maverick masterminds like Kreizler would be out of character. In its way that\u2019s a blessing: Do we really need to see the umpteenth knockoff of Sherlock Holmes or Dr. House? Indeed, Br\u00fchl imbues the alienist with a plain-spoken dignity, even in the moments when his behavior is demanding or shocking by the standards of his day.\n\nBut there\u2019s a reason you don\u2019t often see the phrase \u201ceminently reasonable visionary\u201d used to describe fictional detectives. (To be fair, with all due respect to our fictional Times colleague, sexually magnetic crime-solving newspaper cartoonists are rarer still.) Kreizler is so calm and so conscientious that he has a tendency to fade into the meticulously constructed background as a result. When he finally does something truly weird, delivering a concluding monologue about his need to \u201cbecome\u201d the killer in order to catch him \u2014 to \u201ccut the child\u2019s throat myself,\u201d psychologically speaking \u2014 the change is so sudden and stark that the lines land with a thud.\n\nThe fact that serial-killer procedurals from \u201cManhunt\u201d to \u201cMindhunter\u201d have painted their protagonists by pretty much these exact same numbers doesn\u2019t help either. It\u2019s true that the source material here predates the current surplus of unstable cop geniuses, but this adaptation of a 1994 book about an 1896 crime must still move and thrill us in 2018. Like the killer himself, who escapes Kreizler during a peculiar pursuit through an abandoned building after taunting him with a grisly trophy, the answer as to whether it will remains elusive for now.", "title": "\u2018The Alienist\u2019 Season 1, Episode 1: Murder Most Familiar", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Kreizler stands to a priest and blusters his way into getting Police Commissioner Theodore Roosevelt\u2019s tacit approval for his \u201cparallel investigation.\u201d He seems equally self-assured whether he\u2019s arranging a night at the opera or defending the city\u2019s most vulnerable population. He even makes sure to send a tray full of extremely expensive food to Stevie and to his driver, Cyrus, ensuring that they, too, feel part of the team. His affect may occasionally be odd, but no one can doubt his commitment to cooperation.\n\n\u201cThe Alienist\u201d does, however, play to the cheap seats in another way common to period dramas of its ilk: period-appropriate gore and squalor, and as much of it as you can stomach. The episode\u2019s first shot is of a corpse, one of many laid out in a morgue and illuminated by flames lit to burn off the gas inside each cadaver\u2019s bloated belly. A visit to the tenement home of the Santorellis, whose child was one of the victims, reveals a waterfall of sewage, a horde of screeching rats and a baby left to crawl through the hallway while the parents scream at each other inside.\n\nIrish cops beat witnesses to a pulp. Underage sex workers in revealing drag attach themselves like leeches to prospective clients. The eyeless heads of slain humans and cattle stare blindly and balefully at us through the screen. The contrast with the opulence of the opera house and restaurant where Kreizler and his companions convene is striking, sure, but it\u2019s also about as subtle as Captain Connor\u2019s interrogation methods.\n\nMore interesting than all the sociopolitical and physical carnage is the leitmotif that ties it to the rest of the investigation: imagery involving the eye. The emphasis makes perfect symbolic sense as our heroes attempt to bring that which is hidden to light. The grisly removal of an eyeball from a cow\u2019s head by the twin forensics specialists Marcus and Lucius Isaacson (Douglas Smith and Matthew Shear) \u2014 an attempt to determine the killer\u2019s weapon \u2014 certainly makes an impression to that effect, just as an \u201cArkansas toothpick\u201d made an impression on the victims\u2019 eye sockets. The team gazes through magnifying devices (used for the then-fledgling science of \u201cfinger marks\u201d) and later through opera glasses in order to spy on Commissioner Roosevelt and his companions \u2014 an aging Mayor William Lafayette Strong and the philandering robber baron J.P. Morgan.\n\nWhen Sarah and Kreizler ride home from dinner together, their professional and personal chemistry is communicated through a setup that has her staring almost directly into the camera as she speaks, looping the viewer into their conspiracy to carry on with the investigation. Sarah\u2019s eyes also come into play when the corrupt and leering Captain Connor spots an eyelash on her cheek and plucks it from her face, demanding she blow it from his fingers, which are encrusted with the dried blood of a recent assault victim, for good luck. (Her refusal to do so does not sit well with the good captain.)", "title": "\u2018The Alienist\u2019 Season 1, Episode 2: Darkness Descends", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "In April 1895, the idea that he would become the police commissioner was front page news. \u201cHe refuses to confirm or deny\u201d rumors that will take the position, a lead headline said on April 24:\n\n\u201cTheodore Roosevelt, the amiable and gifted author, field sportsman, and legislator, was born in this city thirty-seven years ago. His father, Theodore, was a son of Cornelius Van Schaick Roosevelt, a millionaire merchant and brother of Robert Barnwell Roosevelt, once United States Minister to the Netherlands, publicist, and pisciculturist.\u201d\n\n(That\u2019s someone who runs a fish hatchery. You learn something new every day.)\n\n\u201cRoosevelt will probably accept,\u201d the next day\u2019s headline read.\n\nIndeed he did, and for the next few weeks, his every step was chronicled.\n\nOn June 8, out for a morning patrol, he caught an officer napping. By July, the department was enforcing \u201cdry Sunday,\u201d to end the scourge of drunkenness.\n\nBy 1897, Roosevelt had moved on from the city and its police force, taking up a post as the assistant secretary of the Navy.\n\n[ALSO READ: Review of \u2018The Alienist\u2019 TV series]\n\nAnd a woman on the force\n\nPhoto\n\nDakota Fanning plays Sara Howard, a secretary to Roosevelt who investigates the murders. The series makes much of her being a woman navigating what was until then a department that employed only men.\n\nThe first woman to work in the headquarters of the department was Minnie Gertrude Kelly. Roosevelt hired her during his first week on the job in May 1895. It was a cost-cutting move.\n\n\u201cWhen I took office I found that I had two clerks, one of whom was a stenographer,\u201d he said in a speech on May 9. \u201cI shall be able to get along with one clerk, and he will have to be a stenographer.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe next day, in eight short lines at the bottom of the front page, Miss Kelly\u2019s appointment was announced:\n\nPresident Roosevelt of the Police Board has appointed Miss Vinie Gertrude Kelley of 160 East Eighty-first Street as his private secretary and stenographer. Mr. Roosevelt said he needed only one clerk, and that he had employed Miss Kelley, as he knew her to be a competent stenographer and typewriter.\n\nAs a clerk and a stenographer, she would be paid $1,700 a year to do the work of two men who had previously earned a combined $2,900 to do the same work.\n\n(And yes, The Times apparently got her given name and surname wrong.)\n\nIn December, The Times reported on the minutes of a commissioners\u2019 meeting, at which they discussed an unnamed \u201cyoung woman stenographer\u201d who was to fill in for a week for a regular \u2014 male \u2014 stenographer at the civil service board.\n\n[Mr.] Roosevelt asked how much pay she was to get. Col. Grant said that it has been arranged for her to get $14 for the week. Mr. Andrews said Secretary Bell thought he could get a substitute for $10 a week. Mr. Roosevelt said he believed a woman should be paid as much as a man if she did the work. The other Commissioners agreed with him, and it was finally decided to pay the girl $12 a week during her temporary engagement.\n\n(Two decades later, Isabella Goodwin would become the department\u2019s first female detective \u2014 an occasion that commanded a full-page spread in The Times. Now there are more than 6,000 female officers.)\n\n[ALSO READ: Book review of original Caleb Carr novel]\n\nPhoto\n\nA restaurant like no other\n\nDelmonico\u2019s has been synonymous with fine dining for nearly 200 years, a reputation built on the foundation of the original opened in 1827 by the brothers John and Peter Delmonico. Over the decades, it would move locations, and family members would join and leave the empire, but in 19th-century New York it had no parallel.\n\nIn the novel, the restaurant is practically another character for all the time the detective team spends there. TNT tried to recreate its grandeur.\n\nBy the dawn of the 20th century, the restaurant was housed in the building on Beaver Street that still holds its name, though not its business, today. It had become a regular fixture in The Times. Charles Dickens visited, and The Times was there. A grand duke held forth, and The Times was there, on page one. The deaths of longtime staff members merited obituaries: a beloved bartender named George in 1879, and a man known as Henri the waiter, in 1904. In 1889, the restaurant was so famous that it sued a Paris restaurant that was tricking American tourists by using the name.\n\nIn 1893, a shooting there made the front page. \u201cFive bullets fired into the restaurant by a \u2018crank,\u2019\u201d the headline shouted. The \u201ccrank\u201d was immediately arrested and identified as George A. Roeth: \u201cThe only explanation Roeth gave for his act was that the rich people did not treat the poor fairly, and he wanted to scare them.\u201d\n\nNo one was hurt, though the episode made for dramatic reading. \u201cThe firing attracted a large crowd to the scene, but for a time no one interfered with the man. There was a line of carriages along the curb in front of Delmonico\u2019s, but none of the drivers seemed anxious to take the risk of tackling the maniac.\u201d", "title": "\u2018The Alienist\u2019 and the Gilded Age: A History in Headlines", "authors": ["Erin Mccann"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "For those who could afford it, antiretroviral therapies had granted a reprieve from the death sentence that AIDS represented, but gay men were still routinely regarded with fear, if not contempt. Basic mainstream acceptance of their lives and relationships, much less legal recognition, was a ways off. A taint hung over discussions of gay sexuality, yet the yearning for companionship, love and joy had become far more open since the worst of the AIDS crisis a decade earlier.\n\nPerhaps the most poignant scene in the episode is when the local police are interviewing Antonio D\u2019Amico (Ricky Martin), Versace\u2019s partner. His white tennis shirt and shorts encrusted with his lover\u2019s blood, a forlorn and exhausted D\u2019Amico is asked to explain why \u201cdancers, models and escorts\u201d have been in and out of the house.\n\n\u201cI was his partner, not his pimp,\u201d D\u2019Amico replies. He loved Versace. They were together for 15 years. The officer is mystified.\n\n\u201cThe other men, did they consider themselves to be Versace\u2019s partner too?\u201d he asks.\n\nWhether such a lack of understanding affected Cunanan\u2019s evolution as a killer will presumably be a dominant theme for the rest of the season, which is loosely based on the journalist Maureen Orth\u2019s \u201cVulgar Favors: The Assassination of Gianni Versace.\u201d The first suggestion that he might be lacking a moral compass comes in a flashback to 1990, when a fawning and flirtatious Cunanan approaches Versace and his entourage in a crowded nightclub in San Francisco, but later tells his friends that it was Versace who initiated the conversation.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt emerges that Cunanan \u2014 who graduated from an elite private high school in San Diego and, after dropping out of college, lived off a series of benefactors \u2014 tells so many lies that even he may have come to believe them. A Catholic and a former altar boy, he passes himself off as a Jew. Asked why he tells straight people that he\u2019s straight, and gay people that he\u2019s gay, he replies, \u201cI tell people what they want to hear.\u201d\n\nVersace invites the young fabulist to a night at the opera: a production of Richard Strauss\u2019s \u201cCapriccio,\u201d for which Versace designed the costumes. They exchange origin stories. Versace\u2019s centers on his muse \u2014 his sister, Donatella \u2014 and love of family. Cunanan\u2019s outlandish tale involves a wealthy father who owned a pineapple plantation in the Philippines, became a pilot for Imelda Marcos, and later ran off with a farmhand, who also served as the chauffeur of his Rolls-Royce. Got that?\n\nIf Versace is incredulous, he\u2019s too polite to say so. He is downright avuncular as he tells Cunanan, \u201cYou\u2019re handsome, you\u2019re clever, I\u2019m sure you\u2019re going to be someone really special one day.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s some understatement: Returning to 1997, we learn that Cunanan was wanted for four other murders before Versace\u2019s. A botched nationwide manhunt, it seems, has failed to prevent a serial killer from striking again. The F.B.I. has joined the Miami Beach police as they home in on Cunanan.\n\nMeanwhile, Donatella Versace (Pen\u00e9lope Cruz) flies in from Italy and asserts control over her slain brother\u2019s business empire, which was headed for an initial public offering on the Milan and New York stock exchanges. She comes across as fiercely protective of her brother\u2019s legacy, if a little sinister. \u201cMy brother is still alive as long as Versace is alive,\u201d she declares, making clear that the brand has transcended the man. She later brushes aside a grieving D\u2019Amico, telling him: \u201cThis is not a time for strangers. This is a time for family.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe term \u201cassassination\u201d is, so far, an enigma. The hotels of South Beach, the nightclubs of San Francisco, the gay demimonde and the Italianate arias so lavishly depicted in this series seem fairly removed from the world of politics, particularly at a time when AIDS had begun to recede as a public health crisis and when legal recognition of same-sex relationships still seemed like a distant prospect. How will this show\u2019s creators define politics, including the politics of the closet? What criteria will it use to deem Gianni Versace\u2019s death an assassination? Or \u2014 as the bloodied turtle dove found next to his body suggests \u2014 was it more like a martyrdom?", "title": "\u2018The Assassination of Gianni Versace\u2019 Premiere: Someone Really Special", "authors": ["Sewell Chan", "American Crime Story"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Cunanan emerges as a truly terrifying figure in this episode, thanks to the strong performance by Darren Criss (\u201cGlee\u201d), whose emotional range is put to effective use. He steals license plates in a Walmart parking lot and breaks into a deranged smile when a little girl stares at him in suspicion. He switches the radio station when a newscaster says he is wanted for the murder of Lee Miglin \u2014 a victim we haven\u2019t yet met \u2014 and manically sings along to Laura Branigan\u2019s \u201cGloria.\u201d He checks into a seedy South Beach hotel and smooth-talks the receptionist. Scoping out the Versace mansion, he comes face to face with a life-size medallion of Medusa, the mythical Gorgon whose image Versace adopted as a logo, on the front gate. It\u2019s an even match; Cunanan is scary as hell.\n\nI\u2019m struck by his verbosity \u2014 has any serial killer ever had so much to say? His monologues reflect an eye for detail and, of course, a penchant for self-promotion, even delusion.\n\n\u201cI need to make my way in the world,\u201d he tells the hotel receptionist, explaining his interest in being mentored by the Italian designer. \u201cI think Mr. Versace will find my conversation very excellent. I would say, \u2018Sir, nothing is more inspiring to me than that one outfit that Carla Bruni wore. It was a skirt of crinoline, like a giant floral handkerchief fastened with a gold belt and daringly mismatched with a denim shirt.\u2019\u201d\n\nHe lies with abandon, not caring whether his fabrications are even remotely plausible. Befriending a drifter \u2014 Ron (Max Greenfield), a fellow gay man who is hanging out at the hotel \u2014 Cunanan discusses with him the loved ones they\u2019ve lost to AIDS and other tragedies. Even the most personal statements seem hard to believe, as when he insists that he \u201clost the best friend and the love of my life\u201d \u2014 both that very year.\n\nHe tells Ron that he and Versace met in San Francisco and that the two were once an item and that Versace had proposed \u2014 almost certainly a lie. He gushes about Versace\u2019s talent: \u201cThe man invented his own fabrics. When they told him what he wanted wasn\u2019t possible, he just created it himself.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe adds: \u201cI don\u2019t see something nice. I see the man behind it. A great creator. A man I could have been.\u201d\n\nRon asks: \u201cOr been with?\u201d\n\nLater, as if to complete the occupational tour d\u2019horizon we\u2019ve been on, he tells a young man named Brad (what else?) at a noisy gay dance club that he\u2019s a serial killer, the only definite truth he\u2019s uttered thus far.\n\nWhen Brad looks confused, Cunanan spins again, in a monologue so wondrous it deserves reproduction:\n\nI said I\u2019m a banker. I\u2019m a stockbroker. I\u2019m a shareholder. I\u2019m a paperback writer. I\u2019m a cop. I\u2019m a naval officer. Sometimes I\u2019m a spy. I build movie sets in Mexico and skyscrapers in Chicago. I sell propane in Minneapolis, import pineapples from the Philippines. You know, I\u2019m the person least likely to be forgotten. I\u2019m Andrew Cunanan.\n\nThis Whitmanesque survey of economic possibility took my breath away. What if this young, handsome, eloquent man had pursued dreams that didn\u2019t involve duct tape and scissors? Such a pity.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe other story in this episode is of Versace\u2019s final weeks, focused in particular on his relationships with his longtime partner, Antonio D\u2019Amico, and his sister and muse, Donatella. Played by a sultry, terrific Pen\u00e9lope Cruz, she worries \u2014 unnecessarily we are told \u2014 that her brother\u2019s brand needs refreshing, lest it be overtaken by new designers like Alexander McQueen and John Galliano.\n\nOf greater emotional consequence is Donatella\u2019s stabilizing influence on her brother and on his partner, whom she scorns for not demonstrating greater fidelity or a willingness to start a family. Whether it\u2019s because of her chiding or a premonition of imminent doom or simply the result of getting older, D\u2019Amico relents. \u201cI want to marry you,\u201d he tells Versace. The designer is skeptical.\n\n\u201cYou can say it in the morning,\u201d he asks. \u201cBut can you say it in the evening?\u201d\n\nEarlier in the episode, the couple visit a hospital \u2014 Versace in the celebrity semi-disguise of a hoodie and sunglasses \u2014 where two AIDS patients, emaciated and deathly ill, can be seen. Lifesaving \u201ccocktails\u201d of antiretroviral therapies had become available, lifting the death sentence the epidemic had imposed on a generation of gay men. Versace, who takes a blood test, recalls that before Donatella was born, he lost an older sister, Tina, to peritonitis.\n\n\u201cUntil that moment, I always believed that if you get sick you can also get better,\u201d he says.\n\nThe episode doesn\u2019t explicitly state that Versace was HIV-positive, as the journalist Maureen Orth contended in her book \u201cVulgar Favors,\u201d on which this television series is loosely based. The implication is certainly strong. But from a dramatic perspective, it\u2019s not important what his illness was \u2014 what matters is that the prospect of premature death hung over these men, who grappled with questions of loyalty, commitment and family, years before same-sex marriage seemed possible, much less became the law of the land. It\u2019s poignant and well worth pondering how Versace\u2019s genius and relationships might have evolved had his life not been cut short at age 50.\n\nFragments:\n\n\u2022 Race has so far been a subsidiary theme, but for brief references to Cunanan\u2019s Asian heritage. (His father was Filipino.) But there\u2019s a telling moment when Cunanan is at a pizzeria and an employee, who has seen the most-wanted poster, goes to the back and dials 911. \u201cIs he black or white?\u201d the dispatcher asks the pizza worker, who is himself black and looks confused. \u201cWhite guy \u2014 he killed four white guys,\u201d the worker pleads. As if any greater urgency were needed.\n\n\u2022 A post-mortem scene \u2014 in which Versace\u2019s body is lovingly dressed by his sister before cremation \u2014 is arguably this episode\u2019s most elegant. His ashes are scooped into an ornate metal box, which flies back to Italy with Donatella. Impeccably tasteful.", "title": "\u2018The Assassination of Gianni Versace\u2019 Episode 2: The Great Creator", "authors": ["Sewell Chan", "American Crime Story"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "But whether American audiences will fall in love with newcomers like her remains to be seen. \u201cBachelor Nation,\u201d as the franchise\u2019s fan base is called, has balked at departures from tradition before. In 2017, the first \u201cBachelorette\u201d chapter to star an African-American woman \u2014 Rachel Lindsay, a lawyer from Dallas \u2014 drew precipitously fewer viewers than the season before it.\n\n\u201cI found it incredibly disturbing in a Trumpish kind of way,\u201d Mr. Fleiss said. \u201cHow else are you going to explain the fact that she\u2019s down in the ratings, when \u2014 black or white \u2014 she was an unbelievable bachelorette? It revealed something about our fans.\u201d\n\nIs he worried that a \u201cWinter Games\u201d audience might react the same way to foreign stars? \u201cI really don\u2019t know,\u201d Mr. Fleiss said, after a pause. He acknowledged that he is concerned about \u201cWinter Games\u201d scenes that exclude American talent altogether. \u201cThe scenes that feature two international cast members talking to each other are tricky,\u201d he said. \u201cI don\u2019t know how we get around that, but I can feel that it won\u2019t play as well on American television.\u201d (\u201cWinter Games\u201d will air only in the United States)\n\nBut Mr. Fleiss, who first brought \u201cThe Bachelor\u201d to television 16 years ago, still isn\u2019t feeling risk averse. Of casting a nonwhite lead, he said, \u201cI\u2019m raring to try it again. I think it\u2019s important.\u201d And he and his team chose Arie Luyendyk Jr., a Realtor and racecar driver who was on \u201cThe Bachelorette\u201d in 2012, for the current season of \u201cThe Bachelor,\u201d despite the fact that new leads usually come from the immediately preceding season of the opposite-gender show. (A \u201cBachelor\u201d runner-up might become the next \u201cBachelorette\u201d lead, and so on.) Mr. Luyendyk\u2019s casting led to a social-media outcry and the lowest-rated \u201cBachelor\u201d premiere in the series\u2019 history, but the season\u2019s ratings have since recovered, climbing by 30 percent in its third episode. (The numbers still rank lower than those of his predecessor Bachelor, Nick Viall.)\n\nBut maybe viewers will buck the likely outcome, the way the nervous cast at the cocktail party did. As the night wore on and the drinks set in, the American and international talent began mingling more warmly. Before long, the room took on the air of a diplomatic summit. Some contestants clapped each other on the back and made promises about \u201cstaying friends.\u201d Others negotiated at length over roses without ever promising anything. When Mr. Harrison broke the news that an elimination was nigh, an American contestant named Jamey suggested the cast act multilaterally to resist, invoking a scene from the football movie \u201cRudy\u201d in which the team refuses to play without the titular character. (The international cast blinked blankly at the reference.)\n\nThe night\u2019s sudden bonhomie continued for the rest of the shoot, with the cast members tiptoeing around talk of real-world international relations. \u201cI thought we were going to be a little cliquier,\u201d Ms. Iaconetti said. \u201cBut we all had something in common: being on these shows. We had something to bond over.\u201d", "title": "\u2018The Bachelor\u2019 Goes International. The third and most recent previous installment, \u201cThe Purge: Election Year,\u201d was released in summer 2016 and outgrossed its predecessors, making $118 million worldwide.\n\n\u201cThe First Purge,\u201d as its title implies, is a prequel, depicting the events that led to the creation of the deadly annual free-for-all by the New Founding Fathers of America party.\n\nThe teaser features seemingly patriotic scenes of American flags, the Statue of Liberty, and fireworks as a folksy narrator growls lines like, \u201cYou are the lifeblood of the nation, and your rights as Americans must be safeguarded.\u201d The 30-second spot ends with the movie\u2019s title emblazoned on a red, \u201cMake America Great Again\u201d-style baseball cap.\n\n\u201cThe First Purge\u201d hits theaters, aptly enough, on July 4.", "title": "\u2018The First Purge\u2019 Teaser Takes a Patriotic Approach", "authors": ["Bruce Fretts"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "On Sunday night, the P.T. Barnum biopic \u201cThe Greatest Showman\u201d won a Golden Globe for best original song. On Monday, the soundtrack hit No. 1 on the Billboard chart.\n\n\u201cThe Greatest Showman\u201d (Atlantic), which has been climbing the album chart steadily for the past month, reaches No. 1 this week with the equivalent of 106,000 copies sold in the United States, according to Nielsen; of those, 78,000 were sales of the complete album.
