One of last year\u2019s biggest hits, the album was shut out of the major categories for the 60th annual Grammy Awards, scheduled for Jan. 28 \u2014 an omission that left much of the music industry scratching its collective head.\n\nG-Eazy\u2019s \u201cThe Beautiful & Damned\u201d is No. 3, and Bruno Mars\u2019s \u201c24K Magic\u201d \u2014 a contender for multiple Grammys, including album of the year \u2014 rose 11 spots to No. 4, helped by a remix of its song \u201cFinesse\u201d featuring Cardi B.\n\nPost Malone\u2019s \u201cStoney\u201d is in fifth place, and Taylor Swift\u2019s \u201cReputation\u201d is No. 6, the first time her album has fallen past the top three spots since it was released two months ago.", "title": "\u2018The Greatest Showman\u2019 Soundtrack Repeats at No. 1", "authors": ["Ben Sisario"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "If Omar Vizquel had hit 400 home runs, no one would be debating his Hall of Fame credentials. Marrying that offensive figure with his stellar defensive reputation would have rubber-stamped his induction this year, his first on the ballot.\n\nBut for all of the acclaim Vizquel earned for his play at shortstop over a 24-year career \u2014 including 11 Gold Glove Awards \u2014 advanced statistics say he never had a season as baseball\u2019s top defensive player. He came close, finishing second in the majors in defensive wins above replacement in 1993, but never reached the top.\n\nThere is, however, another first-time Hall of Fame candidate who had an extended run as one of the game\u2019s top defenders, including at least one season as baseball\u2019s best over all. He is Andruw Jones, who at his peak, as a center fielder for the Atlanta Braves, delivered some of the most impressive defensive seasons of any player in history while, almost as an aside, clubbing 434 career home runs.\n\nIn other sports, it would be unthinkable to overlook a player so respected for defensive excellence. Deion Sanders became a first-ballot Hall of Famer in pro football. Dennis Rodman sailed into the Basketball Hall of Fame with a hearty endorsement from Michael Jordan. But despite having at least as many qualifications as Vizquel \u2014 and many other Hall of Fame candidates this year \u2014 Jones is getting very little support in his first year of eligibility, according to Ryan Thibodaux\u2019s tracking of Hall of Fame balloting.", "title": "\u2018The Last Thing You Want to Do Is Hit the Ball to Center Field\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "And once again, they won\u2019t care.\n\nThat is because Trump is man-as-message, man-as-messiah. Trump support isn\u2019t philosophical but theological.\n\nTrumpism is a religion founded on patriarchy and white supremacy.\n\nIt is the belief that even the least qualified man is a better choice than the most qualified woman and a belief that the most vile, anti-intellectual, scandal-plagued simpleton of a white man is sufficient to follow in the presidential footsteps of the best educated, most eloquent, most affable black man.\n\nAs President Lyndon B. Johnson said in the 1960s to a young Bill Moyers: \u201cIf you can convince the lowest white man he\u2019s better than the best colored man, he won\u2019t notice you\u2019re picking his pocket. Hell, give him somebody to look down on, and he\u2019ll empty his pockets for you.\u201d\n\nTrump\u2019s supporters are saying to us, screaming to us, that although he may be the \u201clowest white man,\u201d he is still better than Barack Obama, the \u201cbest colored man.\u201d\n\nIn a way, Donald Trump represents white people\u2019s right to be wrong and still be right. He is the embodiment of the unassailability of white power and white privilege.\n\nTo abandon him is to give up on the pact that America has made with its white citizens from the beginning: The government will help to underwrite white safety and success, even at the expense of other people in this country, whether they be Native Americans, African-Americans or new immigrants.\n\nBut this idea of elevating the lowest white man over those more qualified or deserving didn\u2019t begin with Johnson\u2019s articulation and won\u2019t end with Trump\u2019s manifestation. This is woven into the fabric of the flag.\n\nAs I have written here before, when Alabama called a constitutional convention in 1901, Emmet O\u2019Neal, who later became governor, argued that the state should \u201clay deep and strong and permanent in the fundamental law of the state the foundation of white supremacy forever in Alabama,\u201d and as part of that strategy he argued:\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t believe it is good policy to go up in the hills and tell them that Booker Washington or Councill or anybody else is allowed to vote because they are educated. The minute you do that every white man who is not educated is disfranchised on the same proposition.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | \u2018The Lowest White Man\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Before you can say Horatio Alger, Alkhanshali was assessing coffee crops in Yemen with seasoned disdain and wearing, as you do, a garland of grenades that signaled his \u201cwillingness to take any argument to its logical conclusion.\u201d His mission culminated in the most harrowing return journey this side of the \u201cOdyssey\u201d \u2014 but time and time again, he talked himself out of trouble; he has a preternatural gift for persuading others to join his cause.\n\nPhoto\n\nOf late, Eggers the novelist has succumbed to sermonizing. He likes an easy target, and his recent fiction goes after predictable boogeymen: social media\u2019s encroachment on privacy (\u201cThe Circle,\u201d 2013), say, or addiction (\u201cHeroes of the Frontier,\u201d 2016). It\u2019s narrative nonfiction that is his natural home. Telling other people\u2019s stories seems to focus him. The sentences take on an Orwellian clarity \u2014 they\u2019re lean and clean, flensed of the tics, doodles and strenuous self-consciousness of his early work, and of the dour didacticism of the new novels. In \u201cThe Monk of Mokha,\u201d he moves lightly between story and analysis, and between brisk histories of Yemeni immigration to America; gentrifying San Francisco; coffee cultivation (\u201cquite possibly the most complex journey from farm to consumption of any foodstuff known to humankind\u201d); and the saints and thieves who dispersed the beans around the world.\n\nYou can dispatch the book in one sitting. I did, on a snowy Sunday afternoon. It left me warmed, but also wired, and a little twitchy. What is it about Eggers? What accounts for this aftertaste that is equal parts admiration and suspicion?\n\nSurely few writers have so tirelessly sought to be of service. \u201cI am owed,\u201d he wrote in \u201cA Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius\u201d (2000), his zeitgeist-defining memoir of losing both parents to cancer just weeks apart, leaving him, a college senior, to raise his 8-year-old brother. In every book since, however, the emphasis has shifted. As if to atone for sudden stardom, he considers a different idea: What do I owe?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn his second book, the novel \u201cYou Shall Know Our Velocity!\u201d (2002), two friends embarrassed by their fortune travel the world trying to give it away \u2014 rather like the author himself, who has used the proceeds from his books to establish tutoring centers, schools in Sudan and foundations in the names of his subjects. To find a way to be useful has remained a central concern \u2014 it\u2019s the \u201clapsed Catholic\u201d in him, Eggers has said, who doesn\u2019t believe writing is real work and longs for \u201creal-world application.\u201d \u201cLet us do something, while we have the chance! It is not every day that we are needed,\u201d goes the Beckett quotation, part of which serves as the epigraph for Eggers\u2019s novel \u201cA Hologram for the King\u201d (2012). It\u2019s this very quality that unites him and his subjects. \u201cHe had never felt such energy and purpose. He was needed,\u201d Eggers writes of Abdulrahman Zeitoun, the hero of \u201cZeitoun,\u201d who paddles his canoe around waterlogged New Orleans, rescuing and feeding marooned people and animals.\n\nOf course, Zeitoun himself took a very different turn after the book was published. In 2012, he was accused of attacking his wife with a tire iron. He was charged with attempted murder and, later, for trying to hire another inmate to finish the job. He was exonerated, but the feeling lingers that Eggers treated us to a partial portrait of the man, that he had skirted some inconvenient truths, some essential darkness.\n\nSo it is with \u201cThe Monk of Mokha\u201d \u2014 a conspicuously PG-13 story of race, religion and manhood. As a teenager working at the mall, Alkhanshali adopted a uniform of preppy clothes and was surprised to see how much kinder the world was to him. His friends started calling him Rupert, after the cartoon bear. In essence, this is the character Eggers introduces us to \u2014 the Rupert bear version of Alkhanshali, agreeable to the hilt, whose strongest emotion appears to be mild vexation.\n\nThis is by design. On the first page, we\u2019re told that the trial of the Boston Marathon bombers has just begun. It isn\u2019t mentioned again, but it hovers over the story, supplying the occasion for it. \u201cThe Monk of Mokha\u201d is part of a wave of narratives introducing \u201cthe good Muslim\u201d: funny and cuddly \u2014 almost aggressively unthreatening \u2014 and, crucially, never devout (see also: \u201cMaster of None\u201d and \u201cThe Big Sick\u201d). \u201cHis story is an old-fashioned one. It\u2019s chiefly about the American Dream, which is very much alive and very much under threat,\u201d Eggers writes of Alkhanshali. It\u2019s about \u201cU.S. citizens who maintain strong ties to the countries of their ancestors and who, through entrepreneurial zeal and dogged labor, create indispensable bridges between the developed and developing worlds, between nations that produce and those that consume.\u201d\n\nEggers wants to humanize immigrants, but in his telling, something very different seems to occur. Everything about his characters is outsize \u2014 their bravery and suffering, their resilience and capacity for forgiveness, their contributions to the country. They are supermen, their powers \u201centrepreneurial zeal and dogged labor.\u201d Time was, to make a home in this country it was enough to yearn to breathe free.", "title": "\u2018The Monk of Mokha\u2019 is Dave Eggers\u2019s Latest PG-13 Story About the American Dream", "authors": ["Parul Sehgal", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The attackers got Mr. Siddiqui\u2019s laptop, data drives, phone, passport and luggage. He got away with his life. But not everyone has.\n\nIt has been open season on journalists and critics of Pakistan\u2019s military for years now. Disappearances, extrajudicial killings, torture, intimidation \u2014 all have been brought to bear, and in the vast majority of cases, no one has ever been brought to justice.\n\nMr. Siddiqui is a prominent critic of the country\u2019s powerful military establishment, and on Wednesday he said he believed that \u201cstate agencies\u201d were behind the attack. Human rights investigators frequently accuse the military\u2019s spy agency, Inter-Services Intelligence, or ISI, of being behind attacks or threats against journalists. Often, especially in cases of intimidation, the security officers make no attempt to hide who they are.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis was an attempt to take me away and turn me into a silent statistic,\u201d Mr. Siddiqui said in an interview with The New York Times on Wednesday. \u201cMy worry is that the next time they come for me, it could end up in something much worse.\u201d\n\nMr. Siddiqui is a 2014 winner of the Albert Londres Prix award, the French equivalent of the Pulitzer Prize, and has written articles for several international publications, including The New York Times. He has also been become known as a frequent critic of the military on social media.\n\n\u201cIt is public knowledge that the military establishment is annoyed with Taha\u2019s Twitter activity,\u201d said Iqbal Khattack, the Pakistan representative for Reporters Sans Frontieres. \u201cWhat has happened is worrisome, but not surprising.\u201d\n\nA spokesman for the interior ministry said Interior Minister Ahsan Iqbal had sought an investigation into the attack on Mr. Siddiqui.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe media wing of the Pakistani Army declined official comment.\n\nOne military official, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to speak to the media on the matter, said he doubted the military was behind the attack. He said Mr. Siddiqui had written no articles recently that criticized the army and that it would be \u201ccounterproductive\u201d to carry out such an attack based on a handful of objectionable tweets. The officer then scoffed at the idea that Mr. Siddiqui could have escaped an attack by a dozen trained security agents.\n\nThe threats to journalists and dissidents don\u2019t end with the security agencies. Militants on both sides of the insurgency in Baluchistan Province, for instance, including sectarian groups who mainly fight on the military\u2019s side of the conflict, are known for some of the most brazen attacks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the past year, another avenue of threat has been opened up. Under a sweeping new cybercrimes law passed last January, the authorities have also begun warning or prosecuting journalists and online activists. And that same month, at least five activists known for internet posts critical of the military suddenly disappeared. Four have since been returned and live in exile abroad.\n\nCivil rights advocates, as well as people directly targeted by the authorities, have described actions under the new cybercrime law that included harassment, intimidation, and detention without access to lawyers or family members. In a few cases, physical abuse of those in custody was reported.\n\nMr. Siddiqui was one of dozens of journalists affected by the law. He was summoned last year by the civilian Federal Investigation Agency to answer for Twitter posts they considered to be critical of the military. Mr. Siddiqui refused to answer the summons unless he was formally charged, and filed a court petition claiming harassment. Hearings in the case continue.\n\nPhoto\n\nOffline, too, it has been a perilous decade for Pakistani journalists.\n\nIn one of the latest attacks, in October, another investigative journalist and critic of the ISI, Ahmad Noorani, was gravely wounded in Islamabad. In 2014, Hamid Mir, a prominent journalist and talk show host, survived an attempt on his life. In the same year, the Pakistani writer and broadcaster Raza Rumi narrowly survived a gun attack that claimed the life of his driver in the city of Lahore. He now lives in exile in the United States. In 2011, Syed Saleem Shahzad, an investigative journalist, was found dead, leading to accusations that the ISI was involved.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s going to get much, much worse,\u201d said Zarrar Khuhro, a popular talk show host with Dawn News. \u201cRegardless of who carried out this attack or others before it, the culprits always go unpunished. So why would the attacks stop?\u201d\n\n\u201cOverall, we are looking at a new era of oppression in Pakistani journalism,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is the new normal.\u201d\n\nAzhar Abbas, the managing director at Geo News, Pakistan\u2019s largest news channel, which has repeatedly come under pressure because of its critical coverage of the military and its support for the civilian government, said it was essential for journalists to come together and put pressure on the government to launch a transparent inquiry.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t physically assault people, or make them disappear for having an opinion,\u201d he said. \u201cAs journalists we have to resist these attempts to be silenced and make sure the culprits are caught.\u201d\n\nBut the attacks are raising fears, causing many to self censor rather than risk arrest or threats against their families.\n\nIslamabad\u2019s police superintendent, Syed Mustafa Tanveer, said on Thursday that Mr. Siddiqui\u2019s case was formally under investigation, though he said it was too early to say who the attackers were.\n\n\u201cYesterday, Taha was really shaken, but today we have called him back in to ask some more questions and to help us prepare sketches of the attackers,\u201d Mr. Tanveer said.\n\nMr. Siddiqui said that after reaching the police station on Wednesday, he asked the investigating officer to let him know as soon as anyone was arrested.\n\n\u201cWhen I said that, he just looked right at me and laughed out loud,\u201d Mr. Siddiqui said. \u201cRight to my face.\u201d", "title": "\u2018The New Normal\u2019 in Pakistan: a Journalist on the Run From Gunmen", "authors": ["Mehreen Zahra-Malik"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 Sometimes it feels necessary to resist the easy seductions of beauty. Other times it is pointless to refrain. If designers here produced little in the way of big ideas or innovations this season, they seemed to have agreed on the same aesthetic mandate: Excite the attention of viewers without in any way challenging it.\n\nThis was as true of the often unruly Rei Kawakubo at Comme des Gar\u00e7ons Homme Plus as it was of the orderly and corporately obedient Kris Van Assche at Dior Homme. Where Ms. Kawakubo\u2019s particular line of beauty is typically composed of grand and even baroque gestures, her approach this time was starkly simplified. If you eliminated the muslin dinosaur heads worn by some of the models (they were made by the fabric artist Shimoda Masakatsu) and focused on the clothes, what you saw was a designer more eager than usual to please.", "title": "\u2018The Rich Look\u2019 Lives On in Paris", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe monster romance \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d took the top prize at the Producers Guild Awards on Saturday, an honor that often predicts the best picture winner at the Oscars.\n\nThe movie, directed by Guillermo del Toro, who produced along with J. Miles Dale, beat out \u201cThe Big Sick,\u201d \u201cCall Me by Your Name,\u201d \u201cDunkirk,\u201d \u201cGet Out,\u201d \u201cI, Tonya,\u201d \u201cLady Bird,\u201d \u201cMolly\u2019s Game,\u201d \u201cThe Post,\u201d \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d and \u201cWonder Woman.\u201d\n\nMr. del Toro was not on hand; he was reportedly in Mexico with his ailing father.\n\nThe winner of the PGA frequently correlates with best picture at the Oscars. The producers\u2019 choice has gone on to win the academy\u2019s big prize eight of the last 10 years. But don\u2019t discount the exceptions: last year \u201cLa La Land\u201d won the PGA but lost best picture to \u201cMoonlight, and the year before \u201cThe Big Short\u201d prevailed with the producers but \u201cSpotlight\u201d won over the academy.\n\nOther PGA winners on Saturday evening included \u201cCoco\u201d for animated film; \u201cJane\u201d for documentary; \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d for drama series; \u201cThe Marvelous Mrs. Maisel\u201d for episodic comedy; and \u201cBlack Mirror\u201d for long-form television", "title": "\u2018The Shape of Water\u2019 Wins Producers Guild Award", "authors": ["Stephanie Goodman", "The Carpetbagger"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 The Oscar-winning film director Guillermo del Toro\u2019s dark fantasy \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d received 12 nominations on Tuesday for the EE British Academy Film Awards. \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri,\u201d the crime drama that cleaned up at the Golden Globes on Sunday, got nine.\n\nBoth movies will compete for best film. Other nominations in the same category at the British equivalent of the Oscars, commonly known as the Baftas, include \u201cCall Me by Your Name,\u201d \u201cDunkirk\u201d and \u201cDarkest Hour,\u201d the Winston Churchill biopic.\n\n\u201cDarkest Hour\u201d received nine nominations as well, including for outstanding British film, where it will compete with \u201cThe Death of Stalin,\u201d \u201cGod\u2019s Own Country,\u201d \u201cLady Macbeth,\u201d \u201cPaddington 2\u201d and \u201cThree Billboards.\u201d\n\n\u201cBlade Runner 2049\u201d received eight nominations, including best director for Denis Villeneuve, who is competing against Luca Guadagnino (\u201cCall Me by Your Name), Christopher Nolan (\u201cDunkirk\u201d), Mr. del Toro (\u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d) and Martin McDonagh (\u201cThree Billboards\u201d).", "title": "\u2018The Shape of Water\u2019 by Guillermo del Toro Gets 12 Bafta Nominations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHE WAR I FINALLY WON\n\nBy Kimberly Brubaker Bradley\n\n385 pp. Dial. 16.99.\n\nReaders of Kimberly Brubaker Bradley\u2019s last novel, \u201cThe War That Saved My Life,\u201d will already be familiar with the terrible particulars of Ada Smith\u2019s childhood: her abusive mother, her captivity in a single shabby room in London during World War II, her painful clubfoot and its associated shame. They will have watched her journey out of that dark place, into one of relative safety. Leaving us to wonder: Now what? Now comes Ada\u2019s aftermath, as she struggles not to let her trauma define her life.\n\nIn some ways, the structure of \u201cThe War I Finally Won\u201d could not be simpler. \u201cYou can know things all you like,\u201d Ada says in the very beginning of the book, \u201cbut that doesn\u2019t mean you believe them.\u201d This is the book\u2019s anchor. Ada\u2019s journey, we understand, will be about learning to believe.\n\nAda\u2019s physical and external problems will be solved rather quickly. In the book\u2019s first chapters, her clubfoot is repaired and she finds herself mending in a hospital. She discovers that her horrible mother is conveniently dead, so Ada and her brother, Jamie, can live happily with their kind guardian, Susan, in a comfortable country cottage. But those physical solutions only take her so far, because of course Ada\u2019s journey isn\u2019t really a physical one at all. Her journey is about constructing belief, and that path is less clear.\n\nAda can\u2019t simply shake off the pain of the past, because she suffers from a kind of PTSD. Fearful and nervous, she hoards, mistrusts physical affection, is ashamed to talk about her foot and struggles to express love until the very end of the book. External events occur \u2014 Susan gets sick , a Jewish refugee named Ruth joins them and Ada\u2019s sponsor, Lady Thorton, suffers a great loss when her son dies \u2014 but these events matter primarily because they give Ada the opportunity to learn, to experience empathy and, ultimately, to love.\n\nAda also grows through direct lessons from others, who increasingly inspire trust. Halfway through the book, Susan offers a variation on the theme. \u201cYou don\u2019t have to feel safe to actually be safe,\u201d Susan reassures Ada after a moment of panic on a rooftop. Safety is not something Ada can feel yet, but she is able, after so much work, to accept that maybe the safety is there before she can feel it. And that Susan can help her believe in it. This is key, because Ada\u2019s healing feels most complete when she becomes whole enough to see past her own pain, and able to believe or feel for others. As Ada comes to see that her life is better than it has ever been, she recognizes that some of her loved ones are struggling. In the end, she gets her turn to help, and so becomes stronger, more whole.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBy the story\u2019s final page, that initial anchor sentence has shifted. \u201cYou can know things all you like,\u201d Ada tells us. \u201cAnd someday you might believe them.\u201d That \u201cmight\u201d is my favorite word in the book. It makes me believe in Ada, in her journey. The beauty of this book is in the slightness of this shift, in the fact that Ada is still not quite certain but has hope.\n\nRarely is a children\u2019s book so honest in its approach to suffering, and the possibility that recovery will never be complete. Ada will always limp, and she may always feel survivor\u2019s guilt or struggle to trust those who love her. In this way, \u201cThe War I Finally Won\u201d is daring. But there is comfort too, in Ada\u2019s desire to love and grow.\n\nThis willingness to allow for true contrast is the book\u2019s greatest strength. Despair and hope, coldness and warmth, fear and trust, ugliness and beauty. Bones break and knit back together. A terrifying climb to a rooftop reveals a breathtaking sky full of stars. Children are broken and then made whole. And yet they will always have been broken.\u201cThe War I Finally Won\u201d explores how pain can lead to strength, or fear to joy. In the end, we accept that Ada will carry her burden. But we also know that she will work to be okay. The power of this book is that it describes, slowly and sometimes painfully, that it is possible not just to live through pain, but to live with it.", "title": "\u2018The War I Finally Won\u2019 Tells One English Girl\u2019s Survival Story", "authors": ["Laurel Snyder", "Kimberly Brubaker Bradley", "Children S Books"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "All of this is very familiar, to the point where \u201cThe Woman in the Window\u201d starts off feeling ordinary. It reads too much like another knockoff while the author sets up his very basic story elements. (At heart, this is a locked-room mystery in the great Christie tradition.) We need a rundown of who the neighbors are, especially the Russells, the family Anna spies on most avidly. We need to know about Anna\u2019s past life as a child psychiatrist, and about the husband and daughter who have abandoned her in the house. We need to raise eyebrows about the terse, hunky tenant in the basement.\n\nImage A.J. Finn Credit Hope Brooks\n\nWe don\u2019t need a lot of flaunting of the author\u2019s cineaste credentials, but we get it anyway. This will work better later, when the book intercuts movie dialogue from the DVDs Anna watches with what is actually happening in her real world. There are shades of Hitchcock\u2019s \u201cShadow of a Doubt,\u201d \u201cVertigo,\u201d \u201cSpellbound,\u201d \u201cSuspicion\u201d and, of course, George Cukor\u2019s \u201cGaslight,\u201d which has an enormous influence on the whole book (and has influenced many of its predecessors). But despite the value of \u201cshow, don\u2019t tell\u201d for any writer, this author loves using examples to a fault. At one point, after Anna has dutifully invoked \u201cGaslight,\u201d the book also throws in: \u201cBecause it was no dream. (\u2018This is no dream! This is really happening!\u2019 \u2014 Mia Farrow, Rosemary\u2019s Baby.)\u201d\n\nOnce the book gets going, it excels at planting misconceptions everywhere. You cannot trust anything you read. Even Anna can be made to doubt her own actions and memories, and she has absolutely no allies. Everyone on the street thinks she is peculiar, and that\u2019s the best-case scenario. When she deals with the police \u2014 an inevitable interaction in this genre \u2014 they happen to notice that she has stockpiled enough wine and prescription drugs to sedate an army. There\u2019s no chance they will ever believe anything she says as the danger level rises.\n\nA book that\u2019s as devious as this novel will delight anyone who\u2019s been disappointed too often. (Case in point: those who were hooked by Paula Hawkins\u2019s \u201cThe Girl on the Train\u201d but then suffered through her \u201cInto the Water.\u201d) And \u201cThe Woman in the Window\u201d sneaks in its zenith of trickery into an effortless early scene. Anna makes a disastrous effort to go beyond her front door and meets someone she\u2019s eager to know. The two of them spend a wonderful, confessional evening back in the house, playing chess and getting loaded. This all goes down so smoothly that its consequences come as a complete shock. And there\u2019s a superb snowbound horror story buried deep inside this novel\u2019s many layers.\n\nHow well does it all hold up, once Finn\u2019s cards have been fully played? Pretty well, but there are problems. An enormous surprise meant to arrive more than two-thirds of the way through the book was guessable even by me \u2014 a terrible guesser \u2014 almost from the start. One character has huge credibility problems. And the writing is serviceable, sometimes bordering on strange. \u201cMy robe is smeared across the floor like a skid mark\u201d offers Anna, as well as \u201cthoughts tumble-drying in my brain.\u201d She really does need to get out of the house more, if only to shake off those domestic turns of phrase.\n\nFor hard-core aficionados of classic logical mysteries, this book includes some special delights. Its nods to contemporary tastes are offset by things like a reference to \u201cThe Thinking Machine,\u201d the nickname of Professor Augustus S.F.X. Van Dusen, a fictional amateur detective created by Jacques Futrelle. Van Dusen was beloved in his time, but that time was so long ago that Futrelle died on the Titanic. Finn knows commerce but he also knows the classics, old and new. He truly aspires to write in their tradition.", "title": "\u2018The Woman in the Window\u2019 Nods to Classics Old and New, From Hitchcock to \u2018The Girl on the Train\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "This new collection of stories, like all of Krasznahorkai\u2019s work, consists mostly of the searching, capacious sentences for which he has become known, each additional clause circling the unutterable like \u201ca merry-go-round, around the thing itself,\u201d as the narrator of \u201cObstacle Theory\u201d states.\n\nKrasznahorkai has dismissed the short sentence as \u201cartificial,\u201d a form that is no more than a custom of \u201cthe last few thousand years.\u201d He is not immune, however, to the allure of a succinct end-stop declaration. Several stories in this collection, in fact, begin with them. One starts: \u201cMemory is the art of forgetting.\u201d Another story, \u201cJourney in a Place Without Blessings,\u201d is a series of brief numbered sections, many consisting of only a few haunting words, and some as short as \u201cThe congregation is silent.\u201d Krasznahorkai executes these staccato sentences as skillfully as his signature expansive ones, and witnessing such a distinctive writer deviate a bit in sentence style is an unexpected pleasure of this new book.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs with any writer in translation, that pleasure wouldn\u2019t be possible without Krasznahorkai\u2019s excellent translators: John Batki, Ottilie Mulzet and George Szirtes. Batki is a self-proclaimed kilimologist, an expert in old weavings, which seems like a useful background for the intricate word-tethering of literary translation, and especially of sentences as elaborate as Krasznahorkai\u2019s.\n\nWith impressive subtlety, the translations recreate the playful irony that undercuts the incessant anguish in each story, an anguish that can become predictable and therefore tiresome. In \u201cA Drop of Water,\u201d a man despairs about the towers of excrement among the ancient ghats and temples of Varanasi. But excessive fixation like this also heightens a reader\u2019s attentiveness to the beauty of the next image, when the narrator\u2019s attention shifts to a group of children, \u201cswirling like a whirlpool around the hand holding the iPhone.\u201d What an arresting contrast \u2014 the image of that most ubiquitous of devices causing a whirlpool of children in one of the oldest, continuously inhabited cities in the world.\n\nThe poignant juxtaposition of the ancient and the new is central to the story \u201cBankers\u201d as well. A traveler arrives in Kiev to visit an old friend, hoping to join the catastrophe tourists headed to Chernobyl\u2019s exclusion zone. To his surprise, his friend arrives at the airport with another man already in the car, a man who talks endlessly about workplace minutiae while the arriving traveler looks despondently out the window at the endless banks lining the streets of Kiev. Noticing everything from Megabank to Renesans Kapitol, the traveler, Fortinbras, who shares his name with the Norwegian foil to Hamlet, thinks to himself, \u201cGood heavens \u2026 what is going on here.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFor most writers, an impulse to capture the bewilderment of moving through a bank-ridden city might lead to a playful list of half a dozen bank names. But Krasznahorkai constantly pushes beyond the expected, escalating everything to the brink of deliriousness with an absurd list of 20 banks. To fully experience the exhilarating crescendo of a Krasznahorkai sentence requires a willingness to submit to this kind of frantic excess.\n\nNot all the stories, however, are frantic and interior. \u201cUniversal Theseus,\u201d one of the most haunting in the book, consists of formal lectures delivered in an ominous auditorium. At the outset of the first lecture, the speaker calmly tells his audience that he knows he\u2019s been invited because someone else wasn\u2019t available. He also admits what he does not know, which is who his listeners are or what they expect of him. He tells his audience he has a \u201clingering bad feeling\u201d that they themselves \u201caren\u2019t quite clear\u201d what they want from him either.\n\nAfter these delightfully brazen disclaimers, the lecturer decides to tell his listeners about the \u201cdeadly honey\u201d of melancholy and what makes it \u201cthe most enigmatic of attractions.\u201d When the lecturer observes a gentleman lock the door behind him, rendering him a prisoner in the auditorium, unable to escape his audience, it feels a bit like a self-fulfilling prophecy, as if he has willed himself into such an unbearable situation \u2014 and a subtle comment on the self-sabotage that humanity continually commits.\n\nHow to escape the bewilderments of the 21st century is the central question of the book: a \u201csequence of steps enabling one to back out of the world,\u201d as the trapped lecturer puts it. Krasznahorkai\u2019s stories refuse to submit to the expectation that fiction provide any kind of reassurance or intimation of redemption. What the stories offer instead is a singular kind of immersive intensity in scenes flooded with such despair that reading them feels at times like drowning in the spiritual questions of our era. When Fortinbras enters one of Kiev\u2019s best-known landmarks, St. Sophia\u2019s Cathedral, he is surprised to find hardly any other tourists there. His friend explains that visitors rarely linger in Kiev now. They all rush right to the Zone to take apocalyptic photographs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWandering-standing in the cathedral, alone with the saints, the melancholy Fortinbras is aware of their gaze, inquiring of him what happened to the past. \u201cWhere is it,\u201d he senses the saints asking, \u201cwhere is that place where their soulful nature would mean something?\u201d A chagrined Fortinbras, who had arrived in Kiev as eager to step through the emptiness of Chernobyl as all the other tourists, concludes that such a place may be nowhere.", "title": "\u2018The World Goes On\u2019 \u2014 and So Do the Sentences", "authors": ["Idra Novey", "Laszlo Krasznahorkai"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPASADENA, Calif. \u2014 Get ready for Rose McGowan on the small screen.\n\nMs. McGowan, the actress turned activist whose accusations against Harvey Weinstein helped spur a national reckoning on sexual abuse and harassment, will star in a documentary series, \u201cCitizen Rose,\u201d that is scheduled to premiere on E! later this month.\n\n\u201cIt is a time of reckoning and the reset button,\u201d she said at a Television Critics Association media event on Tuesday.\n\nThe cable network promised that the series will be an unfettered look into Ms. McGowan\u2019s life. Filming began in September, the month before the publication of the New York Times story that disclosed her settlement agreement with Mr. Weinstein, whom she had accused of sexual assault.\n\n\u201cShe kept saying, \u2018It\u2019ll be worth it, I promise,\u2019\u201d Andrea Metz, an executive producer of the series, said of Ms. McGowan\u2019s pitch to Bunim/Murray Productions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJonathan Murray, the chairman of Bunim/Murray, the production company behind reality shows like \u201cThe Real World\u201d and \u201cKeeping Up With the Kardashians,\u201d said, \u201cAs it all blew up this fall, we\u2019ve been filming.\u201d He added that the show will also incorporate footage that Ms. McGowan has recorded over the past three years.", "title": "\u2018This Is Mine\u2019: Rose McGowan Talks \u2018Citizen Rose\u2019", "authors": ["John Koblin"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "At that meeting, an advocacy group presented the women with small, smooth rocks that had words painted on them \u2014 words like brave, resilient and strong. They joked among themselves that perhaps it was not the most prudent decision to give rocks to an army of angry, determined women.\n\n\u201cI took four,\u201d said Ms. Harrison, a senior at Michigan State.\n\nMs. Alvarado selected one that had the word \u201cfaith\u201d on its face. Over the course of the hearing these past two weeks, she squeezed the rock so hard that she wore the paint away.\n\nIn the weeks before making her statement in court, Ms. Alvarado overhauled it five or six times, she said, as she searched for the right words. Ms. Boyce said she spent months revising hers as she read pieces aloud to her husband, Adam.\n\n\u201cI had a lot to say,\u201d Ms. Boyce said, \u201cbecause this has been inside me for the past 20 years.\u201d\n\nMs. Boyce even workshopped her statement with Ms. Harrison, who visited with Ms. Boyce at her home a couple of weeks ago.\n\n\u201cShe has an ice-skating rink in her back yard, so we got to have some fun,\u201d Ms. Harrison said.\n\nFor Ms. Harrison, the writing process was difficult, she said, in large part because she was concerned for her parents. She did not want to cause them additional pain. So before she spoke in court, she rehearsed by reading her statement to her parents at home. She had to turn her back to them, she said, otherwise she would have lost her composure. When she finished, her mother was sobbing.\n\n\u201cShe said, \u2018I\u2019m so proud of you,\u2019\u201d Ms. Harrison said. \u201cThat felt so good, just to hear that she\u2019s proud of me.\u201d\n\nFor all three women, the hearing was a mix of inspiration and devastation, of hope and sadness. They were heartened by the huge number women who gave up their anonymity and reclaimed their voices but were distraught that so many had suffered the same pain. At times, Ms. Alvarado said, the resurfacing of old wounds was nearly too much to bear.", "title": "\u2018This Is the Beginning of Our Story\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTootsie is getting ready to sing.\n\nA musical adaptation of the 1982 hit film will come to Broadway next year, after a production this fall in Chicago, the producers said Wednesday.\n\nThe title character is a difficult actor who is having trouble finding work until he dresses as a woman and auditions for a soap opera. In the musical comedy, the role originated by Dustin Hoffman in the movie will go to Santino Fontana (a Tony nominee for \u201cCinderella,\u201d better known for his television role on \u201cCrazy Ex-Girlfriend\u201d).\n\nDavid Yazbek, the composer who wrote the songs for this season\u2019s best-reviewed new musical, \u201cThe Band\u2019s Visit,\u201d has signed on to write the score. The book is by Robert Horn (\u201cThirteen\u201d) and the eight-time Tony nominee Scott Ellis (\u201cShe Loves Me\u201d) will direct.\n\nThe pre-Broadway production will run at Chicago\u2019s Cadillac Theater from Sept. 11 to Oct. 14, and is then scheduled to come to Broadway in the spring of 2019. The production did not announce a specific theater on Broadway.\n\nThe musical will be produced by Scott Sanders, who last produced the Tony-winning revival of \u201cThe Color Purple.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Tootsie\u2019 Musical Sets Its Sights on a Broadway Opening", "authors": ["Michael Paulson"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Garcia pointed to the president\u2019s plan to hire tens of thousands of border agents, which was announced in February but has yet to come to fruition because Congress still has not provided the funding. The same is true for Mr. Trump\u2019s centerpiece project, the border wall.\n\n\u201cAfter it became evident that there wasn\u2019t a dramatic change on the part of the administration, then the smugglers started selling their product again and the flow began to resume,\u201d Mr. Garcia said.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn releasing the data, the administration acknowledged that it had lost ground in its effort to stem immigration. But it also seized on the statistics to make the case that Congress should overhaul immigration laws to deter more people from coming.\n\nThe Trump administration and Republicans in Congress have been seeking new border security measures in exchange for permitting 800,000 young undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers to remain in the United States. On Tuesday, the president indicated he would even consider allowing millions more unauthorized immigrants to remain in the country, provided Congress took steps to keep new ones from entering.\n\nThe numbers of apprehensions are an indication of border activity, but they do not count those who slip through undetected. Though the recent increase makes clear that the flow of migrants has resumed, the numbers have not approached the crisis levels of 2014, when they reached nearly 70,000 in a single month, many of them children traveling alone. Homeland Security officials noted that the 2017 apprehensions still represented a 40 percent decrease from the year before.\n\n\u201cThe final border apprehension numbers of 2017, specifically at the southern border, undeniably prove the effectiveness of President Trump\u2019s commitment to securing our borders,\u201d Tyler Houlton, a spokesman for the agency, said in a statement. He also called on Congress to close what he said were \u201cloopholes\u201d that incentivized illegal immigration and were being exploited by migrants. By that, he seemed to reference the asylum system, as well as special protections for children who cross the border without adult supervision.\n\nTens of thousands of people apply for asylum annually. The vast majority are denied, and cases can drag on for years, during which time many applicants are released from custody and establish ties to the United States, eventually deciding to stay illegally. Their numbers have contributed to an ever-growing immigration court backlog, with more than 650,000 cases now pending, up from 520,000 in late 2016, according to the Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse, a research group based at Syracuse University.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmong those stopped at the border in December were 8,000 families and 4,000 so-called unaccompanied minors. Family detention centers are so full that many families are being let go, with the parents fitted with ankle monitors, the kind of \u201ccatch and release\u201d practice that the administration has been trying to avoid all along.\n\nResponding to the growing number of people crossing the border, the White House late last year pulled together an interagency task force, which has been meeting to evaluate a suite of new deterrence policies, including separating parents from their children as their cases work through the courts, which immigration advocates have denounced as cruel.\n\n\u201cThe administration is committed to using all legal tools at its disposal to secure our nation\u2019s borders, and as a result we are continuing to review additional policy options,\u201d Mr. Houlton said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRegardless of American policy, immigrant advocates said that as long as Central America continued to be crippled by crime and poverty, migrants would continue to flow north. Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador are often ranked among the most dangerous countries in the world because of drug- and gang-related violence, as well as widespread attacks against women.\n\nA recent contested election in Honduras has also spurred many to seek asylum in the United States since November, the advocates said.\n\n\u201cBased on our observations and interviews, it\u2019s clear that nothing has changed in Mexico or Central America; if anything, things are getting worse,\u201d said Camilo Perez-Bustillo, director of advocacy at the Hope Border Institute in South Texas, which has been analyzing the trends in border crossings for a coming report. \u201cThere\u2019s no reason to assume that the numbers would diminish as long as the conditions prevail.\u201d\n\nOne recent border crosser, an 18-year-old man from the state of Yoro in Honduras who asked not to be identified because he was here illegally, agreed. He entered the United States on New Year\u2019s Day and has been staying at Annunciation House, the shelter in El Paso, since.\n\nHe said he trekked by himself across a mountain west of El Paso known as Mount Cristo Rey, without the help of a smuggler. He said that he had known about Mr. Trump\u2019s policies and stance toward illegal immigrants, but that ultimately, he decided to come anyway.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cBecause of the laws and Trump saying \u2018no more immigrants,\u2019 I was afraid of being caught,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cBut at the same time I want to help my family overcome,\u201d he added. \u201cMy goal was to come here no matter the risks.\u201d\n\nBefore he left Honduras, he overheard other people talk about crossing the border. He said he thought the rumors of a crackdown along the border had been overblown.\n\n\u201cOn the road they say there\u2019s a lot of immigration agents and they\u2019ll chase you and turn dogs on you, go after you on horseback and in cars,\u201d he said. \u201cBut there\u2019s a lot more freedom here.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Trump Effect\u2019 Wears Off as Migrants Resume Their Northward Push", "authors": ["Caitlin Dickerson"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "The Trump name was cemented in place by a four-page licensing agreement, signed in 2000. It described Mr. Trump as a \u201cworldwide renowned builder and developer of real estate who enjoys the highest reputation in these fields among others,\u201d but set only a modest value on the use of his name: $1. Not payable monthly or even annually, but $1 in total.\n\nThe name was not an issue until the presidential campaign in 2016 and Mr. Trump\u2019s subsequent election, when some residents began to object.\n\n\u201cI felt that he was way far right of my politics,\u201d said Harvey Koeppel, who described himself as the first resident of the building. \u201cI also felt he was dishonest. The way in which he conducted the campaign was, well, sixth-grade level would give him too much credit. I found him embarrassing.\u201d\n\nAt three nearby rental buildings \u2014 140, 160 and 180 Riverside Boulevard \u2014 the sentiment among tenants was so anti-Trump that the T-R-U-M-Ps on their buildings were removed before the president even took office.\n\nA resident of 220 Riverside Boulevard, another condominium nearby, initiated a petition to remove the name from her building that garnered support from at least 57 homeowners and 24 renters in the building, although little came of it.\n\nAt 200 Riverside Boulevard, the board\u2019s residential committee conducted an anonymous survey of residents last February about whether to keep or remove the Trump name. The letter announcing the effort assured residents, in capital letters, that \u201cTHIS IS A BLIND SURVEY AND CANNOT BE TRACKED TO AN APARTMENT,\u201d lest they be fearful of answering honestly.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cA majority was in favor\u201d of removing the Trump letters, Mr. Koeppel, an independent management and technology consultant, recalled. He said a minority of residents had no issue with the letters, while others supported the president. Mr. Harvey and his wife, Peggy Koeppel, sold their 12th-floor apartment in July, after retiring and moving to the Hudson Valley, but not before they were forced to drop the price by 10 percent to secure a buyer.\n\nJust before a meeting of unit owners to discuss the survey results, on March 29, Alan Garten, the chief legal officer of the Trump Organization, sent a letter to the board saying that removal of the letters would constitute a \u201cflagrant and material breach of the license agreement.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Garten also said that many apartment owners had reached out to express \u201ctheir grave concerns with the Board\u2019s contemplated action.\u201d\n\nThat cast a pall over the meeting, Mr. Koeppel said. \u201cThere was definitively a fear in the air.\u201d\n\nWith a new board on its way in, a decision was delayed. Then, last week, the residential committee of the board asked the court to issue a declaratory judgment that the condominium has the right to use or remove the letters without violating its licensing agreement with Mr. Trump.\n\nUnder the licensing agreement, the committee acknowledges the board\u2019s obligation \u201cto maintain the building in a manner consistent with \u2018super luxury\u2019 condominiums in Manhattan.\u201d\n\nBut, the committee said in its suit, the agreement \u201cdoes not obligate the board to use or display identifications,\u201d but rather \u201c grants the board the right to use the identifications should the board choose to do so.\u201d\n\nThe lawsuit was first reported by The New York Post.\n\nHarry Lipman, a lawyer for the condominium, said that the committee \u201ctook no position on whether the signage should or should not be removed.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf we obtain the ruling,\u201d he said in a statement, \u201cthe committee will give the unit owners the opportunity to express themselves through a fair and democratic vote on the issue without any threat of legal action by the licensor.\u201d\n\nThat election is not a foregone conclusion, of course, but in the presidential election, Mr. Trump received just 64,929 votes in Manhattan, versus 579,013 for his opponent, Hillary Clinton.", "title": "\u2018Trump Place\u2019 Asks if It Can Be Called by Any Other Name", "authors": ["Charles V. Bagli"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "What I like least about his presidency so far is the tweeting. It\u2019s often immature and lowers the tone of the debate while debasing the office of the presidency. That said, I think the media needs to be a lot more evenhanded in its coverage of him and keep its personal opinions in check.\n\nEMILY ROBERTSON\n\nAUSTIN, TEX.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nGranted we have the most unpresidential president of our time. Crude, rude, clueless dude \u2014 but I believe, with the help of his friends, he\u2019s stumbling through one of the most effective presidencies in memory.\n\nAs the Sonny LoSpecchio character wisely concluded in the movie \u201cA Bronx Tale,\u201d it\u2019s better to be feared than loved. My hope is for our enemies to fear Donald Trump and for his domestic opponents to realize he\u2019s on their side.\n\nSTEVEN LANDIS\n\nHAMPTON BAYS, N.Y.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nAfter voting for Democrats for over 60 years I voted for President Trump. As an immigrant, I was concerned that the country I have grown to love was, to quote a recent Op-Ed article in your paper, beginning to undergo \u201ca national descent into chaos.\u201d Towns were being destroyed by their own citizens for what they saw as police injustice, our police were being slaughtered in cold blood and New York City\u2019s mayor said he had warned his son against the police.\n\nI thought sanctuary cities were unjust to our own citizens, and our attempt to keep intact our reputation as welcoming Uncle Sam was becoming detrimental to our own welfare. Mr. Trump\u2019s language is often inappropriate and juvenile, and I had hoped he would rise to his new position. But although words are indeed important, I thought his tough take-no-prisoners manner and, yes, even his unpredictability might be what was needed at this particular time to cause offending persons and countries to sit up, consider us seriously, and think twice about taking advantage of us financially and otherwise.\n\nANNE MINICH\n\nMILFORD, CONN.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nMy hometown, Newton Falls, Ohio, was once a working-class Mayberry. Though not rich, the men and women of the town had pride and worked hard for their families and for their share of the American dream.\n\nI am 28, and in the nearly three decades I\u2019ve been alive, I\u2019ve seen Newton Falls and its surrounding environs succumb to a despair reflected by the opioid crisis. I have seen Republicans and Democrats sell out through a false dogma of free trade. I have seen my friends sent abroad to foreign lands with ill-defined military missions, coming back mangled or not at all. I have seen a political class eager to replace a working class with an imported labor class, driving down wages.", "title": "Opinion | \u2018Vision, Chutzpah and Some Testosterone\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "SPECIAL POST \u2014 If you would like to see the print version of David Steinberg\u2019s puzzle without having to read Wordplay spoilers:\n\nDavid Steinberg\u2019s January 7, 2018 puzzle", "title": "\u2018Vowel Play\u2019 PDF Only", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Wolfe laughed off her pal\u2019s suggestion because she was in a relationship, albeit a rocky one, and not long out of a long marriage to her high school sweetheart, which had ended in 2012.\n\nAfter the rehearsal, with the infamously sluggish (and small) elevator at Carroll Studios moving even slower than usual, Ms. Wolfe took to the stairwell, when she heard a voice behind her.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cEven Broadway stars take the stairs?\u201d\n\nTurning, she saw the salmon shirt guy. Ms. Wolfe chuckled and flashed a smile before continuing her descent.\n\n\u201cIt was a gutsy move, and I like being made fun of,\u201d said Ms. Wolfe, 35. \u201cPlus I really didn\u2019t think of myself as a Broadway star.\u201d\n\nYet she had been charging Broadway since her childhood in Visalia, Calif., an inland agriculture town known for its citrus, olives and cotton. From an early age, she sought the spotlight. For a preschool concert, she was relegated to the back row but parted the children \u00e0 la Moses to take center stage when the singing started.\n\nAround the house she mounted musicals starring the family cats and broke into song willy-nilly with her hairbrush microphone. While still in grade school, she arrived at the first rehearsal of a junior college production to star in \u201cAnnie\u201d having already memorized her lines. And before the ripe age of 17 she had played the lead in \u201cHello, Dolly\u201d not once but twice.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe was 15 and in New York City for the first time when she discovered a truth about her dream job. \u201cI had no idea that Broadway was the name of a street,\u201d she said. \u201cStarring \u2018on Broadway\u2019 certainly made more sense once I saw that!\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter graduating in 2004 from the University of Cincinnati\u2019s Conservatory of Music with a B.F.A. in musical theater, Ms. Wolfe made her Broadway debut three years later in the revival of \u201c110 in the Shade\u201d and has worked in shows such as \u201cThe Mystery of Edwin Drood,\u201d \u201cThe Last Five Years\u201d and \u201cFalsettos\u201d ever since. She took the lead in \u201cWaitress\u201d last June.\n\n\u201cDon\u2019t tell Betsy she can\u2019t do something because she\u2019ll prove you wrong,\u201d said her mother, Bonnie Wolfe, an artist and speech pathologist. Scott Wolfe, a history teacher, athletic coach and former professional baseball player, wholeheartedly agreed about his daughter.\n\nMonths after the opening of \u201cBullets,\u201d Ms. Wolfe and Mr. Krauthamer met again face to face at an after-show get-together. (Both credit Zach Braff, then a stage neophyte, for inviting musicians to a traditionally actors-only social event. \u201cHe didn\u2019t realize musicians weren\u2019t usually invited to cast gatherings,\u201d Mr. Krauthamer said.)\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Krauthamer maneuvered to start a conversation and was relieved when Ms. Wolfe \u201cdidn\u2019t run away from a musician,\u201d he said. In an easy exchange, the two soon unearthed similarities under their more obvious differences.\n\nMs. Wolfe was raised in a West Coast conservative Christian home; Mr. Krauthamer grew up on Long Island, in Baldwin, N.Y., in a liberal Jewish family, the son of Marshall Krauthamer, a special-education teacher and guidance counselor, and Susan Krauthamer, a nurse practitioner.\n\nBoth sets of parents shared similar values including service to their communities, the necessity of hard work, and a commitment to their children\u2019s ambitions that stopped well short of being pushy.\n\nLike Ms. Wolfe, Mr. Krauthamer\u2019s path to performing started early. He picked up the French horn in grade school after discovering the drums and trumpets had been claimed. A high school music camp cemented his zeal, after which he tracked down and phoned, without his parents\u2019 help, Jerome Ashby, a much-loved horn player then with the New York Philharmonic and also teaching at Juilliard.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter a tough lesson in 1996, Mr. Krauthamer, despite still being in high school, was determined that Mr. Ashby accept him as a continuing student. Eventually, Mr. Ashby (who died in 2007) became his teacher at the Curtis Institute of Music. Mr. Krauthamer graduated in 2004 and received a master\u2019s degree in Music from Yale in 2006.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter college, Mr. Krauthamer worked in restaurants: dishwashing, cooking and bartending while supporting his career. Ms. Wolfe sold household items and furniture on Craigslist, stuff she mostly picked up for free. (She still has this urge when she spies good castoffs on the curb.)\n\nIn that first conversation, the parallels in their temperaments also became evident: Both are known for their honesty and authenticity. \u201cLong before I knew I loved Adam, I loved how we talked to each other,\u201d Ms. Wolfe said. \u201cNot for a second were either of us anyone other than who we are.\u201d\n\nThat night Mr. Krauthamer asked for a date, but Ms. Wolfe demurred. Despite their fun and flirty repartee, she wondered if Mr. Krauthamer\u2019s smooth moves might not be exclusive to her. Also, because of her previous relationships, she had little dating experience.\n\nPhoto\n\nIndeed, Mr. Krauthamer had dated plenty and had had his share of relationships, but none had jelled. He had recently shifted to thinking he might remain single, but after connecting with Ms. Wolfe that notion seemed ridiculous.\n\nAt subsequent gatherings, the two easily picked up where they\u2019d left off, but it took months, a lot of back-and-forth texting, and persistence from Mr. Krauthamer to persuade Ms. Wolfe. \u201cI was willing to wait,\u201d he said.\n\nIn June 2014 his perseverance delivered. \u201cBroadway stars have to eat sometime?\u201d was the line that pushed Ms. Wolfe to agree to dinner; afterward they shared a kiss in Riverside Park.\n\nIn both their professions, timing is paramount. But here it was everything. \u201cI\u2019d been savoring the newness of what I knew was going to be a great relationship, and that kiss was everything I thought it was going to be,\u201d Ms. Wolfe said.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Krauthamer found Ms. Wolfe unusually attentive, especially for someone so busy. Besides his own music career, Mr. Krauthamer founded the Jerome Ashby Scholarship at the Juilliard School. He is also the executive director of Musicians for Pension Security, an organization that works for transparency and accountability in the management of retirement benefits.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAdam is sexy, smart, funny and domestic \u2014 I found it impossible not to love him,\u201d Ms. Wolfe said.\n\nFor Evan Welty, a close friend of Ms. Wolfe\u2019s since childhood, the pluses of this relationship go far beyond a shared love for performance. \u201cAdam\u2019s passion for justice and public policy awakened Betsy to a world outside the theater,\u201d Ms. Welty said. \u201cFor the first time I\u2019ve seen Betsy really enjoying life.\u201d\n\nWith an unspoken understanding, the couple slid into a devoted relationship. The actress left quirky presents and cute notes on his orchestra seat; the horn player cooked her post-show dinners, and, though he is not a coffee drinker, became expert at making Ms. Wolfe\u2019s particular morning brew \u2014 black with a splash of coconut oil. Within the year they had moved in together.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cBroadway careers are filled with crazy ups, downs and in-betweens, and they both really get what it is the other does,\u201d said Adam Kantor, a Broadway actor and friend of Ms. Wolfe\u2019s with whom she often performs.\n\nOn June 15, 2015, nearly a year to the date of their first date, with Ms. Wolfe soon on her way to spending months in La Jolla, Calif., to appear in \u201cUp Here,\u201d Mr. Krauthamer proposed marriage. \u201cWe were deeply in love and I knew I wanted to spend the rest of my life with her,\u201d he said.\n\nCarving out time for a wedding between show schedules was nearly impossible: a 2015 plan to marry in a Manhattan townhouse once owned by Liz Taylor was thwarted after discovering the elevator to the only bathroom was not functioning and couldn\u2019t be fixed on their timeline.\n\nBut on Dec. 17 just over 100 guests gathered in an outside courtyard at the Rancho Valencia Resort in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., for a ceremony combining aspects of both families\u2019 faiths.\n\nLed by the groom\u2019s brother-in-law Matt Gewolb, who was deputized by the County of San Diego for the occasion, the couple exchanged personal vows against a cascade of autumnal-colored roses and eucalyptus leaves.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Krauthamer promised to support Ms. Wolfe\u2019s \u201cwildest dreams and relentless work ethic\u201d and to shop with her even \u201cduring the brief between-show break on a two-show day.\u201d\n\nMs. Wolfe said Mr. Krauthamer is her \u201cfavorite and only barista.\u201d And then she added: \u201cYou are my best friend. You are my person. You\u2019re my home.\u201d\n\nAs the ceremony concluded, the sun set beyond the Pacific Ocean. More than a few guests were teary, including Susan Mathews, Ms. Wolfe\u2019s junior high school drama teacher. \u201cThere\u2019s been no one like her before or since,\u201d she said. In speeches, toasts and bubbling conversations, guests extolled the overwhelming generosity of the groom and bride, to their friends and families and to each other.\n\n\u201cI have never seen such a solid and respectful relationship,\u201d said Dannielle Thomas, Ms. Wolfe\u2019s manager.\n\nMs. Wolfe said: \u201cMy relationship is drama free, I save that for the stage.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Waitress\u2019 Star Has a Tip for You: Marry Your Best Friend", "authors": ["Louise Rafkin"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Judge Cote granted partial summary judgment to the plaintiffs, saying that the song \u201clacks originality,\u201d and focused in her ruling on the changing of \u201cwill\u201d to \u201cshall.\u201d\n\nThe song\u2019s origins have been traced to spirituals at the turn of the 20th century. In 1960 and 1963, the publisher Ludlow Music registered copyrights for it, saying that the song\u2019s authors \u2014 including Pete Seeger \u2014 had made changes to earlier versions of it.\n\nThe plaintiffs sought to have the copyright for the entire song declared invalid, with the case set for trial next month.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe litigation, which began in 2016, had become expensive and Ludlow spent far more on the case than it had earned on the song in recent years, Paul V. LiCalsi, a lawyer for Ludlow and the other defendant, the Richmond Organization, said in a telephone interview on Friday night.\n\nIn a statement, Ludlow said royalties from the song since the early 1960s had been donated to the nonprofit Highlander Research and Education Center in Tennessee, which created the We Shall Overcome Fund to distribute all of the royalties through grants and scholarships in black communities. It was not immediately clear how much money the fund had distributed.\n\n\u201cWithout the same scope of copyright protection, Highlander\u2019s grants and scholarships will be deeply affected in the future,\u201d the statement said.\n\nLudlow also said uses of the song had in the past been \u201ccarefully vetted\u201d but warned that its words and melody could now be used by advertising agencies and others \u201cin any manner they wish, including inaccurate historical uses, commercials, parodies, spoofs and jokes, and even for political purposes by those who oppose civil rights for all Americans.\u201d\n\nThe settlement was \u201can enormously important achievement\u201d because others can now use the song without paying for it or seeking permission, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, Mark C. Rifkin, said in a telephone interview on Friday night. \u201cWe\u2019re really thrilled to be part of an effort to give this song back to the public where it belongs,\u201d he said.\n\nThe case is the latest one to cancel the copyright of a time-honored song that many people may well assume was available for anyone to sing: A judge invalidated the copyright on \u201cHappy Birthday to You\u201d in 2015.", "title": "\u2018We Shall Overcome\u2019 Is Put in Public Domain in a Copyright Settlement", "authors": ["Christopher Mele"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cA. G. Sulzberger Will Become Publisher of The Times on Jan. 1\u201d (front page, Dec. 15):\n\nAs publisher, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr. led The New York Times during 25 of the most turbulent economic years in publishing history. His record: 60 Pulitzers, a new digital vision for the future, national and global expansion, and an unshakable commitment to excellence in journalism.\n\nWell done, Arthur!\n\nTOM JOHNSON, ATLANTA\n\nThe writer is a former publisher of The Los Angeles Times and a former chief executive of CNN.", "title": "Opinion | \u2018Well Done, Arthur!\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "TEBOURBA, Tunisia \u2014 Tense protests have erupted across Tunisia since a new budget took effect on Jan. 1 that raised taxes on gasoline, phone cards, internet usage, hotel rooms and even fruits and vegetables. The demonstrations have claimed at least one life, and have revived worries about the fragile political situation in Tunisia, the only country to emerge from the Arab Spring uprisings with the semblance of a stable democracy.\n\nThose uprisings began in Tunisia in December 2010, when Mohamed Bouazizi, a 26-year-old high school dropout who worked as a fruit and vegetable vendor, set himself on fire in the town of Sidi Bouzid after being shaken down and humiliated by local officials. Thursday was the seventh anniversary of his death.\n\n\u201cPeople have to understand that the situation is extraordinary and their country is having difficulties, but we believe that 2018 will be the last difficult year for the Tunisians,\u201d Prime Minister Youssef Chahed said on Tuesday, emphasizing his belief that the tax increases, while difficult, would help stabilize the economy.\n\nMr. Chahed said the rioting was \u201coutside of the law\u201d and warned that the authorities would arrest those inciting violence. \u201cWe are in a democracy, and those who want to protest can do it during the day, not at night,\u201d he said.", "title": "\u2018You Can\u2019t Survive Anymore\u2019: Tunisia Protests Rising Prices and Taxes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Hundreds of immigrants hoping to escape violence in Yemen and join their families in the United States received an official notice last year from the State Department that started with a long-anticipated message: \u201cYour visa is approved.\u201d\n\nBut those turned out to be just words.\n\nAfter the third version of the Trump administration\u2019s travel ban took effect on Dec. 8, their approvals abruptly turned to rejections, in what lawyers, family members and immigration activists said was a display of bad faith.\n\nThe rejections of Yemeni citizens, many of them women and children, seeking travel documents from the small United States Embassy in Djibouti, in East Africa, occurred even though the State Department had said it would not revoke any visas when carrying out the president\u2019s proclamation imposing the new restrictions on immigration.\n\nMany of those rejected had been told by the embassy that their visas were approved as early as last July, after being interviewed by the State Department. The approval notices, on a half-size piece of paper in English and Arabic, also said: \u201cWe cannot guarantee how long it will take to print it and have your passport ready for pickup. You should check the status of your visa online.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nJulie Goldberg, a lawyer in Djibouti, said hundreds of people had come to her doorstep since mid-December. She estimated that more than 300 Yemeni nationals had been rejected so far. \u201cThere\u2019s no explanation for getting denied \u2014 everybody\u2019s getting denied,\u201d she said in a telephone interview from her home there, which serves as a legal clinic. \u201cIt\u2019s complete hopelessness. I have women sobbing.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the State Department said there was an explanation: However final it may seem, an approval notice is not a guarantee, said an official with the department who spoke anonymously because its employees are not authorized to speak publicly. Such a notice should have been considered provisional, the official said, because at the time, the vetting of the would-be immigrants was not yet complete. The ban\u2019s assurances, the official said, applied only to those holding actual visas.", "title": "\u2018Your Visa Is Approved,\u2019 They Were Told. And Then It Wasn\u2019t.", "authors": ["Liz Robbins"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "The New York Times would like to hear how Koreans feel about the countries' Olympic cooperation.
